Response Message: Title: Patient Presentation - Native-valve Infective Endocarditis  Demographics: Patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male. Occupation is a construction worker and he's a smoker with a 30-pack year history. Currently married  lives with his wife in their own home; they have two grown-up children.  Medical History: The patient has a known history of type II Diabetes Mellitus for the past 10 years  which is poorly controlled. The patient also has a history of Hypertension for the last 5 years. Both conditions were managed with prescribed medication.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with a three-week history of intermittent fever  chills  night sweats and unintentional weight loss. He also reports fatigued feeling over the course of the last month. There is no history of shortness of breath  chest pain  hemoptysis  syncope  or seizures.  Examination: On physical examination  patient was found to be febrile with a temperature of 101°F. There were noticeable Janeway lesions on the palms of his hands. Cardiac auscultation revealed early diastolic murmur best heard at left sternal sector and apex.  Investigations and Diagnosis: Blood cultures were collected and sent for analysis. Transthoracic echocardiography showed a large vegetative mass attached to the bicuspid aortic valve suggestive of Infective Endocarditis.  The patient's symptoms  along with his physical exam findings and echocardiographic findings  make Infective Endocarditis the likely diagnosis.  Treatment and Management: The patient is immediately admitted to hospital given the serious nature of his condition  and intravenous antibiotics are initiated after drawing blood cultures. Surgical treatment options are also being considered based on his clinical condition and echocardiographic findings.  The patient's diabetic control will require optimization and management during his hospital stay. His smoking habits and hypertension control will also need addressing as part of general good health practices and to reduce future cardiovascular risk.

Title: A Presentation of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Good afternoon  colleagues. Today  I am presenting a case of native-valve infective endocarditis in a 58-year-old Caucasian male.  Our patient  Mr. Smith  is a heavy smoker and has been for the last 35 years. He has a significant past medical history including Type II Diabetes Mellitus  Hypertension and Rheumatic Fever  which he suffered from in his early teens. He was recently hospitalized 3 months ago for an unrelated surgical procedure. He also has a history of poor dental hygiene which is notable for this condition.  Mr. Smith presented with a 4-week history of low-grade temperature with noticeable sweats especially during the night time. He also reports losing weight despite having a normal diet and increased ruits and low energy levels for the past month.  Physical examination revealed a diastolic murmur at the left sternal border which was hitherto unwitnessed. We also observed petechiae in his conjunctiva and Roth spots on ophthalmoscopic examination. A few Janeway lesions were detected on the palmar aspects of his hands.   Preliminary blood tests showed evidence of anemia with a high ESR  suggestive of an ongoing inflammatory process. His blood cultures are currently being evaluated. A transthoroscopic echo cardiogram was performed  demonstrating a bulky vegetative mass on his mitral valve  identifying the likely source of infection.  Our working diagnosis  based on clinical findings  past medical history  and initial investigations  is Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  most likely originating from oral bacteria secondary to his poor dental hygiene.  The patient remains hospitalized for further investigations  confirmatory diagnostic modalities and initiation of definitive treatment plan. A multidisciplinary approach  involving cardiology  infectious disease specialists and a cardiothoracic surgeon  has been undertaken for the management of this case.  Thank you.

Patient Presentation:  A 60-year-old Caucasian male presented to the hospital complaining of persistent fever  weakness  and unintentional weight loss over the past three weeks. He has also experienced night sweats  malaise  and occasional confusion. He has noticed a new heart murmur which was not previously noted.  Patient's Demographics Information: Name: Not Disclosed Age: 60 Sex: Male Identifies as: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Plumber Smoking History: 20 pack years (quit 10 years ago) Alcohol: reports moderate consumption Family history: Father had ischemic heart disease. Mother had type 2 diabetes.  Past Medical History: - Diagnosed with rheumatic fever at age 10. - Mild to moderate aortic regurgitation and stenosis noted in the past two years. - Recurrent urinary tract infections in the past year. - No known drug allergies.  - Last vaccination was an influenza vaccine administered last fall. - Regular medications include Lisinopril and low-dose aspirin.   On physical examination  the patient has a low-grade fever of 98.9°F. A systolic murmur was heard on auscultation  and Osler's nodes and Janeway lesions were noted on the palms and soles  classic signs of IE disease.  Upon discussing the patient's health history and results of the physical examination  the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis (IE) was considered. The patient is admitted for further diagnostic workup and treatment  including blood cultures  an echocardiogram to confirm the suspected diagnosis  and empirical antibiotic treatment.   Given the patient's past medical history of aortic regurgitation and recurrent urinary tract infections  as well as his occupational history  the endocarditis might be due to streptococcal or staphylococcal organisms. The diagnosis and treatment plan will depend on the results of blood culture and sensitivity  which will guide the selection of appropriate antimicrobial therapy.   In summary  this patient presents classic symptoms of infective endocarditis that requires immediate medical attention in order to prevent any potential complications  such as heart failure or embolisms.

Patient Presentation:   Our patient is Mr. Alan Henry  a 64-year-old Caucasian male who has presented with symptoms concerning for native valve infective endocarditis (IE).   Mr. Henry lives in a suburban neighborhood in Houston  Texas and is a retired mechanical engineer. He has been a non-smoker for 12 years but has a 20-year history of smoking. He does not consume alcohol or engage in any illicit drug use. He follows a regular diet and maintains a moderate level of physical activity.   In terms of medical history  he has been diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus for the past 8 years  for which he is on oral hypoglycemic agents. He has been compliant with his medication and his diabetes has been relatively well-controlled. No known history of hypertension or cardiovascular disease. He underwent a colonoscopy 5 years back which came back clear with no signs of any polyps or malignancies.   However  over the past several weeks  he has been experiencing intermittent fevers  fatigue  and unexplained weight loss. Recently  he has experienced several bouts of night sweats. These symptoms were initially thought to be an upper respiratory infection or flu and were treated accordingly. But the persistence of the symptoms has led to further investigation. On detailed questioning  he also mentioned experiencing occasional shortness of breath and mild chest discomfort over the past week.  His grandmother suffered from Rheumatic heart disease and his father passed away from a heart attack  so there is a family history of heart conditions. No known allergies to any medications or substances.   Given his symptoms  especially in the context of his diabetic status which puts him at increased risk  along with his family history  we suspect a diagnosis of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis. The patient is currently in stable condition but requires further diagnostic tests  including blood cultures and an echocardiogram  to confirm the diagnosis and determine the most appropriate therapeutic approach.

Title: Infective Endocarditis in A Native Valve: A Case Study  Introduction:  We present a case of a 64-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. X  with infective endocarditis on native valves. Mr. X  a retired teacher  lives with his wife in Charlotte  North Carolina. He was referred to our hospital by his primary care physician after investigations indicated potential endocarditis.   Prior Medical History:  Prior to this  Mr. X enjoyed relatively good health. He has a history of non-insulin dependent Type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past eight years  which has been managed with metformin. In addition  he has mild hypertension  controlled through lifestyle changes and medication. There is no recorded case of drug allergies in his medical history.  Recent History:  In the weeks nursing up to his current presentation  Mr. X complained of recurrent mild fevers and fatigue. His family recounted that he had an unexplained weight loss over the same period. He also reported an episode of nocturnal diaphoresis noticeable for the past few weeks. Mr. X recalls having treated a dental abscess at a local dental clinic around a month ago but denies intravenous drug use or other possible portals of entry for infection.  Current Presentation:  On physical examination  Mr. X exhibited Osler nodes on his fingertips and Janeway lesions on the palms and soles. Both are classical vascular phenomena  typically seen in endocarditis. On auscultation  an early diastolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal edge was perceived suggestive of aortic regurgitation. Ophthalmoscope examination showed Roth spots.  Investigations:  The preliminary bloodwork indicated increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP)  suggesting an ongoing inflammatory process. Three sets of blood cultures have been drawn at different times and have been sent to the laboratory for analysis. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) report showed vegetations on the aortic valve  confirming our suspected diagnosis of infective endocarditis on native valves.  Discussion:  This case illustrates the importance of recognizing various clinical manifestations of infective endocarditis for earlier diagnosis  especially in patients with known risk factors for disease  like diabetes. Though not a typical high-risk patient for endocarditis without any evident cardiac structural deformities or previous history of cardiac valve diseases  the dental procedure potentially served as a point of entry for the causative bacteria.   Conclusion:  Infective endocarditis in native valves is a serious medical condition that requires timely detection and aggressive medical management. The valuable lessons from our patient  Mr. X  underline the grave implications of a seemingly mild dental infection in an otherwise healthy individual. Consequently  it underscores the utility of prophylactic antibiotics in high-risk patients before procedures that may lead to bacteremia.

Title: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis: A Case Presentation  Patient Profile:  The patient is a 70-year-old male Caucasian with a history of intravenous drug use. He is known to the medical community and has been regularly attending for the past 40 years. He is a retired manual labor worker and currently resides in Brooklyn  New York. Because of his addiction  he lives alone and is occasionally taken care of by a social services group. However  his frequent and consistent substance abuse has estranged him from family and friends. He doesn't have a regular eating habit and also suffers from malnutrition.   Medical History:  The patient's prior medical history includes Hepatitis C  Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)  and recurrent infective endocarditis  all likely associated with his IV drug use. His surgical history is benign  although he was hospitalized multiple times due to infections related to IV drug use. Immune suppression due to substance abuse and unhealthy lifestyle makes him vulnerable to recurrent infections.   Presenting Complaint:  Upon presentation  the patient complains of a one-week history of worsening productive cough  subjective fevers  night sweats  malaise  and unintentional weight loss. He also reported increasing difficulty in breathing and occasional palpitations. The patient had pallor and appeared chronically ill with poor dentition. He had a temperature of 38.5°C (101.2°F)  a heart rate of 100 beats per minute  and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute.  Upon examination  he exhibited signs consistent with infective endocarditis  which include Osler's nodes (painful red or purple pea-sized skin nodules)  Janeway lesions (painless flat skin spots)  and splinter hemorrhages in the nail beds. Additionally  he had an audible heart murmur.   Diagnosis:  The patient has a high clinical suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis based on his clinical signs  symptoms  past medical history  and lifestyle. Further diagnostic work-up including blood cultures and an echocardiogram would be invaluable to confirm the diagnosis and guide management.  Conclusion:  Addressing this patient's medical needs will require a holistic and multidisciplinary approach. It is critical to treat his endocarditis  but equally important to address his ongoing substance abuse and ensure he is offered support and resources to help him with addiction. Regular follow-up  providing dietary and lifestyle counselling  and promoting engagement with community resources are key components of this approach.

Subject: Presentation of Patient with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Profile Name: Patient X Age: 62 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Postal Worker  Presenting Issue: The patient presents with persistent fever  fatigue  night sweats  and a new-onset heart murmur. He also mentioned unexplained weight loss over the past few weeks. All these symptoms suggest the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Medical History: Patient X has a significant cardiovascular history. He was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia 10 years ago  which is controlled with medication (amlodipine and atorvastatin). He had an episode of rheumatic fever in his early 20s  which did not have cardiac involvement at that time. He has no known allergies. Patient X has been a smoker for about 40 years  with a 20-pack year history. He quit drinking alcohol about 8 years ago. There is no history of IV drug use.  Family History: Patient's father passed away in his early 70s due to a myocardial infarction. His mother  currently in her late 80s  has chronic arthritis and hypertension. His older sister has type-II diabetes and hypertension.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  the patient appears chronically ill. He is afebrile  with a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 90 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Cardiac examination reveals a new grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border. There is no observable Janeway lesions or Osler's nodes. The rest of the examination was unremarkable.  Investigations and Management: Three sets of blood cultures have been sent to the lab. Echo-cardiography is scheduled to confirm the diagnosis and help decide on the management plan. Empirical antibiotic therapy will be initiated once blood cultures have been collected.  In the presence of a new systolic murmur and persistent fever  native valve infective endocarditis is the leading differential diagnosis for this patient. He is likely to be hospitalized for ongoing medical management until his condition stabilizes and improves.  Thank you for your attention.

Patient Presentation: We present a case of a 65-year-old African American male  Mr. X  who comes in presenting signs and symptoms suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis. He is a retired Postal Service worker  a nonsmoker  and moderate alcohol consumer. He lives with his wife in the suburban area and is relatively physically active with no known adverse environmental exposures.  Medical History: Mr. X has a notable past medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus  for which he has been on oral hypoglycemic medications for the past 10 years. Additionally  there is a history of hypertension  controlled with amlodipine and ramipril. He also has a documented history of rheumatic fever from early childhood.   He has no surgical history but underwent a cardiac catheterization procedure 5 years ago following a suspected myocardial infarction  which was later ruled out. There is no known drug allergy history  and the family’s genetic history reveals no predispositions to cardiac malformations or autoimmune diseases.   Five days prior to his presentation  he had been seen at a local Emergency Room for what had been assumed to be flu-like episode and was discharged home with symptomatic therapy.  Currently  in addition to his chronic anti-hypertensive and anti-diabetic medications  he is on daily low-dose aspirin as prophylaxis for cardiovascular diseases  as per his past Rheumatologist’s suggestions.  Presentation: Today  he presents with a one-week history of persistent high-grade fever  malaise  and exertional dyspnea  accompanied by a new onset of a diastolic murmur on auscultation  prompting considerations for complicated infective rheumatic fever sequelae - Infective Endocarditis.

Patient Presentation  I would like to introduce Mr. Sutton  a 65-year-old Caucasian man with a significant history of intravenous drug use. He is currently employed as a construction worker and is a lifetime non-smoker. He lives with his wife and has six children. Mr. Sutton is a socially active individual with occasional alcohol consumption.  Past Medical History  Mr. Sutton has a notable history of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection five years ago  which was successfully treated with appropriate antibiotics. He also has a history of mild hypertension  controlled with diet and exercise  and type 2 diabetes  managed with Metformin. Despite this  Mr. Sutton's injection drug use is of major concern as he has had episodes of relapse in the past years.   Recent Hospital Admission  Approximately one month ago  Mr. Sutton was admitted to the hospital for a short period due to a non-specific febrile illness with symptoms of malaise  weight loss  night sweats  and loss of appetite. His fever resolved with symptomatic treatment and he was discharged with advice for follow-up.  Current Presentation  Recently  Mr. Sutton has presented with a new onset of concerning symptoms including continuous fever  chills  and shortness of breath. He has also reported progressive weakness and occasional chest discomfort over the last two weeks. Physical examination revealed the presence of a new heart murmur and splinter hemorrhages in the nail beds  raising the suspicion of infective endocarditis.  Imaging and Laboratory Tests  Blood cultures were taken  which subsequently grew Staphylococcus aureus. Transthoracic echocardiography revealed vegetation on the tricuspid valve suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis. Further investigations are being conducted to assess the full extent of the infection.  Summary and Recommendation  Mr. Sutton's past medical history  combined with his continued intravenous drug use and the new onset of systemic and cardiovascular signs and symptoms  strongly indicates a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. I recommend urgent consultation with a Cardiologist and Infectious Disease specialist for further management and will be starting him on empiric antibiotic therapy in the meanwhile.

Title: Presentation of Patient Presenting with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Good Afternoon    Our patient today is Mrs. Jane Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian female who presents with symptoms suggesting of native-valve infective endocarditis. Mrs. Doe is a retired school teacher and lives with her husband in downtown Seattle.   Regarding her medical history  she is known to have a history of rheumatic heart disease  which she was diagnosed with in her mid-thirties. For this  she underwent surgical repair of the mitral valve about ten years ago and has been on long-term antibiotics ever since. Apart from this  she also has a history of hypertension for the past five years  which is well-controlled with medication. She is a non-smoker. She also denies any alcohol and drug use.  Mrs. Doe has arrived at our hospital today following a consultation at a dental clinic  where she underwent a teeth-cleaning procedure a week ago. She reports of having developed a high fever  general malaise  joint pain  and a new heart murmur that were not present in her previous medical examinations. Furthermore  she also has petechial lesions on her skin and mucous membranes.  Given her recent dental procedure  it is reasoned to suspect that it might have resulted in a bacteremia and consequent seeding of the previously damaged heart valve leading to infective endocarditis.   On examination  her temperature is elevated and cardiovascular examination reveals a systolic murmur. Blood tests show raised inflammatory markers. An echocardiogram has been ordered.  The combined clinical  pathological  and imaging findings at this stage strongly suggest a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. Our next step would be to ascertain this possible diagnosis through further investigations and plan out an appropriate treatment and management strategy.  In conclusion  Mrs. Doe's past medical history of rheumatic heart disease and recent invasive dental procedure put her at an increased risk for developing infective endocarditis. Her case thus underscores the requirement for meticulous oral health maintenance in individuals with predisposing heart conditions.  Thank you for your attention.

Presentation:  Good morning/afternoon everyone   Today I'll be presenting the case of Mr. John Doe  a 60-year-old Caucasian male who has presented to our hospital with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Mr. Doe is an engineer by profession and has a history of smoking for the past 20 years. He is otherwise quite fit and active for his age and has no known history of illicit drug use. His current living situation is with his wife in a suburban house  and they have taken a domestic trip within the U.S about 2 weeks ago.  His past medical history includes a grade 3 mitral valve prolapse diagnosed about 7 years ago. He has been on appropriate medical management for the same. He also had an episode of pneumonia around 5 years ago  for which he was hospitalized and treated successfully. Mr. Doe was also diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 2 years ago  and he has been managing it with oral anti-diabetic agents since. He is not known to have any allergies.  Most recently (1 week prior)  he has been complaining of an intermittent high-grade fever  malaise  night sweats  and an unintentional weight loss. Additionally  his wife observed his nails turning pale and reported a few episodes of nosebleeds over the past week. It was these symptoms which prompted them to visit our hospital.  On examination  we noted a low-grade fever  pallor  and a new systolic murmur in the mitral area. There were also splinter hemorrhages near his nail beds and a positive Janeway's lesion on his right foot. We are currently awaiting the results of blood cultures and sensitivity tests to confirm the diagnosis of infective endocarditis and guide antibiotic therapy.  Given Mr. Doe's history of mitral valve prolapse  this could possibly be a case of native-valve endocarditis. His history of smoking and uncontrolled diabetes might have predisposed him to this condition. The patient's condition is being closely monitored and depending on the culture results  we may initiate aggressive antibiotic therapy or consider the need for surgical intervention.  This is a brief overview of our patient's case. Thank you for your time and I am open to any further discussion or suggestions.

Title: Presentation of a Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male – Mr. Smith.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Smith presented with complaints of recurrent fevers  fatigue  and discomfort in his chest area over the past few weeks. He also mentioned unintended weight loss  loss of appetite  and night sweats.  History:  Mr. Smith has a known history of heart disease  specifically aortic valve stenosis  diagnosed six years ago. Apart from this  he is hypertensive and his blood pressure is usually well-controlled with medication. He was treated for pneumonia 5 years ago. He is a non-smoker and maintains a light to moderate alcohol habit. There is no reported history of intravenous drug misuse.  Physical Examination: On examination  Mr. Smith appeared fatigued  with feverishness being noted. His vital signs were generally stable; however  moderate hypertension was noted. Cardiac auscultation revealed a murmur consistent with aortic regurgitation  a new finding compared to his previous examinations.   Further Investigations: Blood work was ordered which revealed a raised ESR and C-reactive protein suggesting a systemic inflammation. His complete blood count indicated mild anemia and leukocytosis. Three sets of blood cultures were ordered given his presentation  fever  and new murmur.   Echo Findings: A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was performed which indicated the presence of vegetations on the aortic valve  providing further evidence towards a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.   In conclusion  given the patient's clinical presentation  symptoms  medical history  laboratory findings  and the results of the echocardiogram  we suspect him to be suffering from infective endocarditis affecting his native aortic valve. He will need to be started on an appropriate course of antibiotics  and the blood culture results will guide any changes to the antibiotic regimen. Cardiology has been consulted for potential valve replacement given the severity of his valve disease. Further  patient education is critical to ensure good oral hygiene and avoidance of any activities that may lead to bacteremia.

Title: Presentation of Native-valve Infective Endocarditis in a 65-year-old Male  Patient Profile: Our patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a BMI of 27  who has been living in the urban population of Utah. He is married and enjoys spending time walking his dog in nearby parks. He used to work as an engineer and is now enjoying his retirement.  Medical History: The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he has been under oral hypoglycemic drug therapy for the past 8 years. He also has a known cardiovascular disease history  having suffered a myocardial infarction 3 years ago. This was treated with percutaneous coronary intervention  stent placement  and aspirin plus clopidogrel daily. He has hypertension which has been well controlled with an angiotensin II receptor blocker. He had a completed course of immunizations and denies any allergies. He doesn't smoke  but has a history of moderate alcohol consumption.  Presenting Signs & Symptoms: The patient presented at the hospital with a 3-week history of low-grade fever  chills  and a loss of appetite. Other symptoms included night sweats  weight loss  and malaise. The patient also reported recently noticing spots on his skin - petechiae  as well as painful  inflamed fingertips (Osler's nodes).  Diagnostic Imaging and Lab Findings: On examination  the patient was found to have a heart murmur suggestive of dysfunctional heart valves. A transesophageal echocardiogram revealed signs of valvular vegetations and regurgitation  indicative of native-valve infective endocarditis. He had a high white blood cell count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate was also elevated. Blood cultures revealed the growth of Streptococcus viridans.   This patient is diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis and would need aggressive treatment with antibiotics. He might also need surgical intervention if his condition doesn't improve with medical treatment. His diabetes mellitus and past history of cardiac diseases make him more susceptible to complications  hence requiring stringent monitoring and follow-up.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in Post-Menopausal Woman  Introduction: The following presentation focuses on a 65-year-old female patient  initially presenting with fluctuating fever and signs of heart failure  later diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis.   Patient's Demographics:  Name : Mrs. Jane Doe Age: 65 years Sex: Female Race: Caucasian Profession: Retired teacher Marital Status: Married Residential Address: Newark  New Jersey  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both managed with medication for over 10 years. She was diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus five years ago  and it has been reasonably well-controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents. She went through menopause at the age of 51 and has been undergoing hormone replacement therapy. Her immunization records are up-to-date  including the flu and pneumococcal vaccines. She has never smoked and consumes alcohol occasionally.   Initial Presentation: The patient initially presented to the emergency department with a three-week history of fluctuating fever  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss. Over the past week  she had also developed increasing shortness of breath  distended neck veins  and swelling of her lower extremities  all of which were suggestive of right-sided heart failure.   Diagnosis: Given her clinical presentation and the presence of new heart murmurs on a physical exam  she was suspected of having infective endocarditis. This diagnosis was later confirmed by transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) which revealed large vegetations on her native mitral valve  and three separate blood cultures  all positive for Streptococcus viridans.   Conclusion: Our patient  a 65-year-old retired teacher with a history of controlled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes mellitus  presented with symptoms related to infection and heart failure. Based on her clinical presentation  imaging results  and blood culture  she was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis caused by Streptococcus viridans  a common etiologic agent in such cases. Her subsequent treatment would include prolonged intravenous antibiotics and careful monitoring for potential complications  with consideration for surgical intervention if her condition deteriorates.

Title: Case Presentation of a Patient with Native-valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Profile: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. A  who works as a postal clerk in a small town in Ohio. He has lived there for most of his life with his wife. They have two grown children who currently live out of state.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. A presents with a two-week history of general feelings of malaise  intermittent fever  night sweats  and recent unplanned weight loss. He has noticed progressive shortness of breath over the past week. He reports no chest pain  cough  nausea or vomiting. The patient appeared diaphoretic and fatigued at the time of presentation.  Past Medical History: Mr. A's past medical history is significant for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus  both of which have been well-controlled with prescribed medications (Lisinopril 20 mg daily  Metformin 1000 mg twice daily). He also has a history of gout  which was managed with Allopurinol.   Rheumatic heart disease  a risk factor for infective endocarditis  is not present in his history. Mr. A has never had any dental procedures done recently. He does not smoke  drinks alcohol occasionally  and denies recreational drug use. He has no known allergies and is up to date with immunizations.   Family History: His father died of a stroke at age 72  and his mother has Alzheimer's disease. His younger sister has rheumatoid arthritis  and his older brother has coronary artery disease.  Discussion: Given Mr. A’s symptoms of general malaise  fever  night sweats  weight loss  and shortness of breath  together with his known prevalence of hypertension and diabetes  an initial diagnosis of infective endocarditis is considered. The definitive diagnosis would require further diagnostic tests such as blood cultures and echocardiography. If confirmed  prompt treatment with specific antibiotics and potentially surgery will be critical due to the high morbidity and mortality associated with this condition. Adequate control and monitoring of his diabetes and hypertension will also be essential in his overall management plan.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis: Case Presentation  Patient Information: The patient is Mr. Smith  a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a residence in the metropolitan area.  Chief Complaint: Mr. Smith presents to the ER with three weeks of progressive weakness  night sweats  loss of appetite  and unintended weight loss. He also reports experiencing chills  fatigue  and a low-grade fever that has persisted despite taking over-the-counter medications.  Past Medical History: In terms of his past medical history  Mr. Smith quit smoking 12 years ago  after having smoked for over 25 years. He is a chronic alcoholic  despite several attempts at abstaining. He underwent gallbladder surgery 15 years earlier with no post-operative complications. He has an established diagnosis of hypertension  which is well controlled with medication (Lisinopril). He does not have any known allergies.  Present Medical History: The patient reports no recent hospitalizations or invasive procedures. He has not had any teeth removed or dental procedures performed recently. He denies intravenous drug use or risky sexual behavior. The patient hasn't traveled recently and he doesn't own any pets. He mentions that his symptoms have progressively worsened over the past week  prompting his visit to the ER.  Physical Examination Findings: Upon physical examination  the patient looks ill and lethargic. Vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 125/80 mmHg  pulse 89 bpm  temperature 38.4°C  and respirations 16 per minute. No signs of cyanosis  jaundice  or lymphadenopathy. Cardiac exam reveals a new murmur  suggestive of valvular disease. His extremities show splinter hemorrhages under the nails.  Laboratory Results: Blood tests reveal anemia  raised ESR  and CRP. White Blood cell count is elevated with a left shift. Blood cultures are pending. His liver enzymes were elevated  correlating with his history of chronic alcoholism.  Conclusion: Based on the presence of significant constitutional symptoms  a new murmur  and preliminary lab results  our primary differential diagnosis is Native Valve Infective Endocarditis  most likely in the setting of chronic alcohol use and older age. We are waiting for the blood cultures to target the treatment accordingly.

Patient Presentation  Title: A Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 58-year-old Caucasian male  presenting with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Demographics:  Living Scenario: Mr. Doe lives alone in a suburban environment in Cleveland  Ohio. He is an ex-smoker (quit 15 years ago) and moderate alcohol consumer.  Occupational History: For the past 20 years  he has been working as a mechanical engineer with minimal exposure to industrial pollutants.  Past Medical History (PMH):  Chronic Illness: Mr. Doe has a 10-year history of uncontrolled Type II Diabetes Mellitus for which he is on Metformin. There is also a 5-year history of Hypertension  managed by Lisinopril.   Cardiovascular History: He had a myocardial infarction four years ago and underwent subsequent angioplasty. He has been on Aspirin and Atorvastatin since then.  Infections: Mr. Doe does not have any significant history of recurring infections  sexually transmitted diseases  or hepatitis.  Surgeries: He underwent an appendectomy at the age of 23.  Allergies: Mr. Doe reports an allergy to Penicillin  characterized by a rash.  Family History: His mother died from Breast cancer  and his father had a stroke in his sixties. His sister has Type II diabetes  and his brother suffers from alcoholism.  Recent Health Status: Recently  Mr. Doe has been experiencing subjective fevers  fatigue  night sweats  weight loss  and a new-onset heart murmur which raised suspicion for endocarditis. He also noticed tiny red or purplish spots (Petechiae) on his skin.  Clinical Assessment: Patient's clinical presentation and investigation results - positive blood cultures and echocardiography showing valvular vegetations  confirmed the diagnosis of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis.  Plan: Mr. Doe has been admitted to the cardiology team for intravenous antibiotic therapy and close monitoring. Cardiac surgery consultation has been sought for possible valve replacement surgery. Mr. Doe will have to maintain good glycemic control  attend regular follow-ups  and follow a strict medication regimen to manage his concomitant conditions and prevent further complications.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 56-year-old African American male who presents to our clinic today reporting persistent fever  chills  fatigue  weakness  and unintentional weight loss over a period of 4-6 weeks. He confirms occasional shortness of breath along with light-headedness upon exertion. The patient also reports recent episodes of night sweats and a sense of generalized malaise. He has noticed the presence of a rash on his lower limbs and red spots on the skin of his palms and soles.   Past Medical History:   The patient’s past medical history is significant for poorly controlled Type II Diabetes  chronic kidney disease (Stage IIIa)  and hypertension. He is also a former IV drug user and has a history of hepatitis C infection. He quit smoking 9 years ago but continues to consume alcohol occasionally. Of note  the patient reports no prior heart conditions  nor a family history of congenital heart defects or any heart conditions.  In review of his past medical records  the patient has had recurrent urinary tract infections over the past year. He has been on a regimen of Metformin and Lisinopril for his diabetes and hypertension  respectively.   In summary  given the patient's symptoms chronology coupled with his past medical history  the patient is suspected to have native-valve infective endocarditis. Further diagnostic procedures including blood culture and echocardiogram are needed to confirm this suspicion.   In the management of his condition  both his current lifestyle and chronic medical conditions will have to be taken into consideration to provide optimal  individualized care.

Title: A Case Presentation of Native-valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information: The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian male  named Mr. Smith  living in an urban neighborhood in New York City. He is a heavy smoker with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and has been an insulin-dependent diabetic for the past 15 years. He is also known to be hypertensive for which he has been on medication. There is no known family history of any major health disorders. Professionally  Mr. Smith is a retired mechanic and denies any alcohol or drug use.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Smith initially reported experiencing a low-grade fever that fluctuates around 100.4ºF (38ºC) for the past few weeks. Accompanying symptoms include malaise  fatigue  and an unintended weight loss of about 8lbs over the past month. Recently  he has also started experiencing shortness of breath and noticing blood in his phlegm. He denies having chest pain  headache  cough  wheezing  nausea  vomiting  loss of appetite  abdominal pain  diarrhea  or rash.  Clinical Examination: The physical examination revealed a systolic murmur best heard in the left third intercostal space and tenderness on the balls of his feet. The patient also presented with splinter hemorrhage under his nails  which is suggestive of endocarditis. No other significant findings were identified.  Summary: In summary  Mr. Smith is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and smoking-induced COPD who now presents with typical features of infective endocarditis. The prolonged low-grade fever  weight loss  shortness of breath  and the physical findings of a heart murmur and splinter hemorrhages indicate a possible diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. Further investigations  including blood cultures  echocardiogram  and additional necessary diagnostic tests  are planned to confirm the diagnosis and formulate an appropriate treatment plan.

[Slide 1] Introduction  Today  we will present a patient diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis  an edge-case that results from a bacterial  fungal  or viral infection that impacts patients with no history of heart disease with normally functioning heart valves.  [Slide 2] Patient's Demographic Information  Our patient  Mr. John Smith  is a 55-year-old Caucasian male from Melbourne  Australia. He has been married for 30 years and has no children. He is a retired banker who has remained largely sedentary since retirement.  [Slide 3] Relevant Medical History  Mr. Smith has a history of mild obesity and type 2 diabetes which were well-controlled till his most recent visit. He also self-reports being a casual smoker and drinks alcohol on social occasions. His earlier visits to the clinic have been characterized by Good glycemic control  measured at an HbA1c of 6.5%. However  he has never had any history of cardiovascular disease  valvular disorder  or rheumatic fever in his past.  [Slide 4] Presenting Symptoms   Mr. Smith presented with a fever of 38 degrees Celsius  ongoing for 2 weeks prior to this visit. He reported feeling generally unwell  with intermittent episodes of night sweats  malaise  and a recent unintentional weight loss of 5kg. On further assessment  we also found splenomegaly and symptoms pointing to mitral valve dysfunction  including a new systolic murmur.  [Slide 5] Investigation and Diagnosis   Blood work showed raised inflammatory markers and three positive sets of blood cultures growing streptococci viridans. An echocardiogram confirmed our suspicions of infective endocarditis showing vegetations on his previously normal functioning mitral valve.   [Slide 6] Conclusion   Mr. Smith’s unremarkable past medical history contrasted with his current diagnosis  reflects the need for a high index of suspicion when dealing with systemic symptoms paired with any evidence of valvular dysfunction  even in those without any prior history. The management plan is continuous observation  IV antibacterial therapy  and education about the gravity of not maintaining optimal glycemic control.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 70-year-old Caucasian male resident of New York City who presents to the clinic today with complaints of fever  fatigue  weight loss  and irregular heartbeats. His symptoms started approximately 7-10 days ago; his fevers have been intermittent but as high as 102 degrees Fahrenheit. He reports having lost approximately 12 pounds unintentionally over the past month.   Mr. Doe has a past medical history that is significant for congestive heart failure and atrial fibrillation  for which he has been receiving treatment over the past 10 years. His other significant history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both well controlled with medication. He has no known allergies.   Mr. Doe's social history informs that he is a retired school teacher  living with his wife and does not smoke or consume alcohol. He reports a lack of physical activity due to progressive shortness of breath on exertion over the past year.  Upon examination  he appears ill and fatigued. Cardiac examination reveals a new murmur and irregular heart rate. Mild lower extremity edema is present.   With the current clinical presentation and past medical history  we suspect a potential diagnosis of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis. Further evaluations  including blood culture tests and echocardiography  will be planned to establish a definitive diagnosis and guide treatment options. His risk factors include his age  existing heart diseases  and diabetes mellitus.  It is crucial that Mr. Doe receive thorough  comprehensive care  which would require collaboration between cardiology  infectious disease specialists  and possibly cardiothoracic surgery should surgical management become necessary. The immediate focus would be on initiating appropriate antibiotic therapy while awaiting culture results and ensuring his hemodynamic stability.

Slide 1: Title: Patient Presentation: Native Valve Infective Endocarditis   Slide 2: Title: Demographic Information  Content: The patient is a 64-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Jones. He is a retired mechanical engineer living with his wife in a suburban neighborhood. He is a non-smoker and reports moderate alcohol consumption.   Slide 3: Title: Past Medical History Content: Mr. Jones has a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension. He underwent coronary artery bypass graft surgery 9 years ago.   Slide 4: Title: Presenting Symptoms Content: Mr. Jones presented to the emergency department with a one-week history of high-grade fever  fatigue  and weight loss. He also complained of a new-onset heart murmur  night sweats  and shortness of breath on exertion.   Slide 5: Title: Physical Examination Content: On examination  he appeared ill and was febrile. Cardiac auscultation revealed a new systolic murmur heard best at the apex. Ophthalmologic examination revealed the presence of Roth's spots.   Slide 6: Title: Laboratory & Imaging Results Content: Initial blood results showed elevated inflammatory markers and blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus. Transesophageal Echocardiography confirmed a vegetation on the mitral valve suggestive of infective endocarditis.    Slide 7: Title: Diagnosis and Plan  Content: The patient was diagnosed with native valve infective endocarditis. He was immediately started on appropriate intravenous antibiotics as per the antibiogram sensitivity of the isolated organism. A referral was made to cardiothoracic surgery for further management  including potential valve replacement.  Slide 8: Title: Conclusion Content: Mr. Jones' presentation of weight loss  fatigue  high-grade fever  and cardiac murmur  coupled with laboratory and imaging results  led to the diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis. Further management will be as per the collaborative decision of the infectious disease team  the cardiology team  and cardiothoracic surgery division.

Title: Presentation of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Profile: Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presented with a two-week history of fever  weakness  loss of appetite and weight  night sweats and fatigue. His current address is 123 Main Street  Anytown  TX. He was accompanied by his wife and he is currently retired  having previously worked as a schoolteacher.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe's medical history reveals hypertension diagnosed ten years ago which is currently well-managed with Lisinopril 20mg daily. Patient quit smoking 15 years ago and has a 30 pack year history of tobacco use. There is no known history of illicit drug use. He had a previous episode of community-acquired pneumonia five years ago  treated successfully with antibiotics. He is not known to be allergic to any drugs.  Family Medical History: His father had ischaemic heart disease and passed away at the age of 70 and his mother was diabetic. There are no other significant family history of diseases.  Presenting Symptoms: On probing further  Mr. Doe mentioned experiencing low-grade fever persistent for the last two weeks  weakness  fatigue  chills  night sweats  lack of interest in eating  and weight loss. His wife also noticed that his skin had developed a slight yellowish tint  and that he looked pale.   Examination: On examination  his heart rate was 90 bpm and his blood pressure was 140/90mmHg. Examination also revealed a new cardiac murmur on auscultation. Further observations included pallor  small pinpoint red spots on skin (petechiae)  and slightly yellow tint of the skin and sclera (suggestive of mild jaundice).   Conclusion: With his ongoing symptoms and new cardiac murmur  the initial clinical suspicion is towards infective endocarditis  specifically native-valve infective endocarditis  considering his increased age  male gender  and chronic medical condition like hypertension. He has been admitted for further investigation and management. Lab investigations including complete blood count  renal function test  liver function test and blood culture have been ordered. An echocardiogram will also be done to get a visual of his heart valves and chambers.  Disclaimer: This is a suspect case based on presenting symptoms and clinical observations. The final diagnosing will depend upon laboratory investigations and imaging studies.

Title: Case Presentation: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis   Demographics: Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male from a rural community. He is retired and lives with his wife.  Presenting Complaints and Symptoms: The patient has presented to the ER with a two-week history of persistent fever  fatigue  and unexplained weight loss of 15 pounds. He also mentions experiencing night sweats in the past week.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of rheumatic heart disease from childhood and underwent repair of aortic valve 20 years ago. He also has controlled hypertension for the past 10 years. He is negative for any history of intravenous drug use or any immunocompromising conditions and his family history is non-contributory.  Clinical Findings: The patient has an elevated heart rate and a systolic heart murmur on cardiac examination. Skin examination showed Osler nodes on the pads of his fingers and Janeway lesions on the palms and soles. His blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg and he's having moderate shortness of breath.  Investigation Findings: His blood cultures have tested positive for Staphylococcus aureus. His echocardiography shows vegetations on native aortic valve with no evidence of abscess formation.  Diagnosis: Based on the patient's history  symptoms  physical findings  and lab results  he has been diagnosed with Native-valve Infective Endocarditis.   Treatment Plan: The patient will be hospitalized for treatment. He will be started on a combination of intravenous antibiotics according to sensitivity reports. The option of surgical intervention will be re-evaluated after an initial period of antibiotic therapy. Prognosis and recovery will be dependent on response to treatment and secondary complications.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Thomas Mitchell is a 62-year-old Caucasian male who presents with flu-like symptoms  including fever  chills  weakness  and significant weight loss over the past 3 weeks. He also reports occasional shortness of breath and has noticed small  red or purple spots on his skin.  Demographic Information:  Mr. Mitchell is a retired office worker  lives with his wife  and has a history of occasional tobacco use. His alcohol consumption is within normal limits  and he has a history of recreational drug use  but declares sobriety for the last 10 years. He lives in a suburban area  exercises regularly  and manages to maintain a balanced diet.  Past Medical History: Mr. Mitchell has a history of mild hypertension  for which he takes Lisinopril. He also had dental work done approximately a month ago. His other past medical history includes intermittent asthma for which he uses a Ventolin inhaler. He has no history of heart diseases  diabetes  or other significant illnesses. He also has no known allergies. He underwent an appendectomy 25 years ago and reports no complications from the surgery. His vaccinations are up-to-date  including flu and pneumococcal vaccines.  The presentation and the timing of the dental work  along with the fact that he did not receive antibiotic prophylaxis at that time  points towards the likelihood of native valvular infective endocarditis induced by bacteremia from the dental procedure. Further investigations including blood cultures and echocardiography are warranted for conclusive diagnosis.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Presentation:   Mr. John Warner  a 58-year-old Caucasian male presents with a 2-week history of generalized fatigue  intermittent fever  night sweats  weight loss  shortness of breath and a new-onset heart murmur. He is a non-smoker and reports occasional alcohol consumption. His occupation is a dental hygienist.  Past medical history: Mr. Warner has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus managed by oral hypoglycemic agents for 10 years. His glycemic control is generally optimal with the last HbA1c reading 7.0% three months ago. He is also hypertensive and on amlodipine 5mg daily. There is no family history of cardiovascular disease or any other genetic disorders.  Physical examination reveals pallor  osler nodes (painful  red  raised lesions on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet)  and Janeway lesions (non-tender flat lesions on the palms and soles). A new onset grade 3 systolic murmur is also appreciated at the left sternal border radiating to the axilla. These signs and symptoms along with patient’s medical and occupational histories raise the suspicion for infective endocarditis.   Further investigations  especially blood cultures  echocardiographic assessment for possible valvular expression  are required to confirm this. Early empirical antibiotic treatment is advised alongside strict blood sugar and blood pressure control given the patient's comorbidities.  Mr. Warner’s occupation in dental healthcare is significant  as oral bacteria may have gained access to the bloodstream during routine procedures  subsequently infecting the heart valve. Healthcare-associated infective endocarditis is of particular concern in this patient considering his occupational exposure.   In summation  Mr. Warner’s symptoms point towards a diagnosis of infective endocarditis. Further diagnostic investigation is required. An interdisciplinary approach involving a cardiologist  infectious disease specialist  and a diabetes and hypertension specialist is beneficial for comprehensive patient management and care.

Slide 1: Introduction  We present the case of a 65-year-old Caucasian male presenting with symptoms indicative of native-valve infective endocarditis.   Slide 2: Demographics   Our patient  Mr. Smith  is a retired engineer  a lifetime non-smoker  and rarely consumes alcohol. He resides in the rural Midwest with his wife and has limited exposure to infectious agents. He does not have a history of intravenous drug use  no known allergies  and reports no recent travel outside of the country.  Slide 3: Symptoms   Mr. Smith has been experiencing recurrent fever and chills  fatigue  weakness  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss for the last four weeks. He has also been complaining of a persistent cough  dyspnea  and dark-colored urine.   Slide 4: Past Medical History   Before this presentation  Mr. Smith had been relatively healthy with a moderate  well-controlled hypertensive condition for which he takes an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor. He also had a appendectomy at the age of 20  but otherwise has an unremarkable surgical history. There is no reported family history of heart disease  cancer  or diabetes.  Slide 5: Recent Medical Events  Approximately six weeks ago  Mr. Smith underwent a dental procedure involving extensive periodontal work. Following the procedure  he received a short course of oral antibiotics as a preventive measure. However  he experienced minor adverse gastrointestinal effects  which led to premature discontinuation of the antibiotics.  Slide 6: Hypothesis  Given the recent dental surgery  ongoing symptoms  and the presence of a predisposing factor - hypertension  native-valve infective endocarditis is a strong diagnostic consideration for Mr. Smith.  Slide 7: Next Steps   We recommend ordering blood cultures to identify potential bacterial or fungal pathogens  as well as an echocardiogram to evaluate possible valvular damage and monitor disease progression. Long-term antibiotic therapy will likely be initiated  while considering Mr. Smith's history of an adverse reaction to antibiotics. We should also educate Mr. Smith on the importance of completing prescribed antibiotic courses to prevent recurrence of endocarditis or antibiotic resistance in future.

Subject: Clinical Presentation for Patient with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Patient Information: Patient Name: Mr. X Gender: Male Age: 64 years Race: Caucasian.   Presenting Concern: Mr. X presents with a two-week history of persistent fever  generalized malaise  and unintended weight loss. His temperature readings have consistently been above 38.5°C. These symptoms were associated with shortness of breath and palpitations.  Medical History: Mr. X has a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  maintained on metformin  and a myocardial infarction 5 years ago. Mr. X underwent coronary artery bypass grafting following his myocardial infarction. He was a smoker but quit following his cardiac event. He consumes alcohol socially.   Family History: There is a strong family history of heart disease  with his father having passed away from congestive heart failure and a brother who has undergone angioplasty.   Current Medication:  Metformin 500 mg BD for diabetes and aspirin 75 mg OD as prophylaxis following coronary artery bypass grafting.  Physical Examination:  On cardiovascular examination  a new systolic murmur was appreciated at the apex  best heard in the mitral area. Lower-extremity pitting edema was seen bilaterally. Osler's nodes were present on examination of the hands  and other skin manifestations  such as Janeway lesions  were not seen.  Putting the clinical picture together  with a history of cardiac disease  persistence of fever  and new cardiac murmur  an initial impression of infective endocarditis is made. Additional investigations including blood cultures and echocardiography have been requested to confirm diagnosis.  This summarizes the clinical presentation of Mr. X who could potentially be dealing with native-valve infective endocarditis. Further investigations and management will be guided accordingly in collaboration with cardiology and infectious disease specialists.

Title: Presentation of a Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Patient  Patient Profile: Name: Mr. John Davis  Age: 72 years  Sex: Male Occupation: Retired engineer  Medical History: The patient in question  Mr. John Davis  is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  with a medical history significant for type 2 diabetes and hypertension. He has been managing both conditions for over 20 years with prescribed medications. He is a former smoker; he quit 10 years ago but had a 30-year smoking history prior to quitting. He denies any illicit drug usage. He has no known drug allergies.  Clinical Presentation: Mr. Davis has presented with a fever and fatigue persistent for two weeks  accompanied by poor appetite and unexpected weight loss. Mr. Davis also reported discomfort in his chest and shortness of breath which has been progressively worsening in the last week. These symptoms raised the suspicion of cardiac issues  which was further confirmed by the presence of a new-onset heart murmur noted during the physical examination.  Diagnostic Evaluation: On systematic examination  splenomegaly was noted. Initial lab investigations showed elevated white blood cell count and C-Reactive Protein (CRP). The subsequent blood cultures were positive for Staphylococcus aureus.   Standard transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was performed due to the heart murmur and revealed the presence of vegetation on the native aortic valve with a moderate regurgitation consistent with a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis (IE).  Management & Conclusion: Following diagnosis  Mr. Davis was admitted to the hospital immediately and started on targeted intravenous antibiotic therapy guided by the antibiotic susceptibility testing from the blood cultures results. He has been referred to a cardiothoracic surgery team for further evaluation and management  considering his further risk of complications due to his age  diabetes  and hypertension.   Mr. Davis's case underscores the complexity and necessity for early diagnosis and intervention in native-valve infective endocarditis  particularly in patients with underlying chronic diseases. His management will require a multidisciplinary approach including cardiology  infectious diseases  and possibly cardiothoracic surgery.

Title: A Case Presentation of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male named John Smith. He resides in a suburban area and is a retired engineer. Prior to retirement  the patient was actively involved in construction projects. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially. He has been married for 30 years and has two adult children.  Medical history: The patient has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus approximately 10 years ago which he manages with oral medications. Additionally  he has a history of hypertension that has been managed with lifestyle adjustments and medication for the past 6 years.   Presenting Complaint: Mr. Smith came to the hospital complaining of low-grade fever  fatigue  and mild shortness of breath that he has been experiencing for the past three weeks. He also mentioned intermittent night sweats during this period. He has lost weight recently – approximately 5kg over the past 2 months without dietary changes or increased physical activity. He reported experiencing a flu-like feeling around 4 weeks ago that resolved on its own.  Clinical Examination: On clinical examination  the patient looked ill and slightly pale. His pulse was 110 bpm and blood pressure was 140/90 mmHg. On auscultation  a new-onset murmur was noted on the mitral area. On fundoscopy  Roth spots were observed.  Diagnosis and Lab Findings: Based on the presenting symptoms  an initial diagnosis of possible infective endocarditis was made. To confirm this  further investigations were requested. His blood test showed an elevated white cell count and ESR. Blood cultures were drawn and staphylococcus aureus was isolated  which confirmed the diagnosis of infective endocarditis.  Impression: Mr. Smith  a 65-year-old male with a clinical background of hypertension and diabetes type 2  presented with weight loss  fatigue  fever  and shortness of breath. He has been found to have native-valve infective endocarditis caused by staphylococcus aureus.  These comorbid conditions and his age put him at an increased risk for complications  including stroke and heart failure  hence warranting immediate hospital admission for infective endocarditis appropriate treatment.

Patient Presentation  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a primary presentation of persistent fevers  generalized malaise  and an unintentional weight loss of around 10 pounds over the last month or two. He also reports occasional night sweats and a recent decrease in appetite. These symptoms initially triggered his visit to our facility for medical evaluation.  In acquiring a thorough past medical history  the patient revealed a previous diagnosis of Diabetes Mellitus (Type II) and Hypertension  both of which have been managed with medication. He used to chronically smoke a pack of cigarettes per day for about 40 years before quitting five years ago. He drinks alcohol socially and denies the use of any illicit drugs. He had a minor surgical intervention for gallstones about ten years ago. There is no history of any cardiovascular disease in his family.  On physical examination  the patient appeared fatigued. His oral examination revealed poor dentition. A heart examination revealed the presence of a new heart murmur. This  combined with his other findings and symptoms  were suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Fecting on this information  it is clear that his hypertension and diabetes pose some threat to the current diagnosis. Also  his chronic smoking might have further contributed to the development and/or worsening of this condition. Therefore  it is recommended to keep him under medical surveillance and immediately start with antibiotic treatment after obtaining cultures. He should also be educated about maintaining good oral hygiene to prevent further complications. If there are no signs of improvement  he may need a cardiac intervention to manage his condition.

Introduction:   Today I would like to present a case of a 58-year-old Caucasian male presenting with native-valve infective endocarditis.   Demographics:   The patient  Mr. X  is a full-time employee working in a recycling plant. He lives with his wife and has two grown-up children. He is a non-smoker and rarely consumes alcohol. He does not have any known drug allergies.  Medical History:   Mr. X has a past medical history of type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and was diagnosed with it at the age of 45. He has been managing his diabetes with oral hypoglycaemic agents since his diagnosis. He has no history of cardiac disease  hypertension  or hyperlipidemia. No surgical history has been mentioned. However  he did have a dental extraction procedure done about four weeks ago.   Presenting Complaint:  Mr. X initially presented with a high-grade fever with chills that was ongoing for the past week. At the onset  he was self-medicating with over-the-counter fever reducers. However  as the fever persisted  he developed additional symptoms including fatigue  loss of appetite and weight loss. He also noticed the appearance of a few small  dark red spots on the palms of his hands and soles of his feet  which were mildly painful to the touch.   As he further continued to feel unwell  he decided to access medical care. Upon initial examination  a cardiac murmur was noted which lead to further investigations  and the definitive diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.   This presentation reinforces the need for close monitoring of patients with a history of invasive procedures like dental extraction  especially those who are immunocompromised like Mr. X  who is a diabetic patient. Early recognition and management are crucial to prevent complications and improve outcomes. It is always essential to maintain a high index of suspicion for infective endocarditis for patients who present with persistent fever accompanied by other non-specific signs and symptoms.

Title: Case Presentation on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Profile: Name: Mr. J.P Smith Age: 56 years old Sex: Male Occupation: Construction foreman Race: Caucasian   Chief Complaint: Mr. Smith complains of an unexplained weight loss  intermittent fever  chills  muscle aches  and night sweats prevalent for the past four weeks.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith is a known hypertensive patient controlled on medication (Lisinopril) for the past 10 years  and he has a 15-year history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus. He admits to poor adherence to his diabetic medications (Metformin and Insulin). He also reported a history of tobacco and alcohol use. He quit smoking 2 years ago but continues to drink alcohol socially. No prior history of any cardiac disease or invasive medical procedures is in record. His family exhibits no indications of genetic cardiac diseases.   Clinical Assessment: Physical examination revealed a paler than normal appearance and moderate splenomegaly. A cardiac examination revealed a diastolic murmur consistent with aortic regurgitation. He was found to be febrile  with an oral temperature of 38.4°C.   Diagnostic Evaluation: Laboratory tests indicated a higher than normal white blood cell count and elevated ESR  suggesting a prolonged inflammatory response. Mr. Smith's HbA1c was also notably high at 9.0%. Echocardiography revealed vegetations on the aortic valve indicative of infective endocarditis. Two separate blood cultures isolated Staphylococcus aureus that confirms bacterial endocarditis.  Conclusion: Given his clinical presentation and diagnostic evidence  Mr. Smith seemingly suffers from native-valve infective endocarditis predominantly due to Staphylococcus aureus. His uncontrolled diabetes is a potential predisposing factor for the infection.  Plan: Mr. Smith would be transferred to the in-patient ward for intravenous antibiotic therapy and closely monitored for potential complications such as arrhythmia  heart failure  and systemic embolism. We also plan to educate him on better diabetes management practices and adherence to medication regime. Regular follow-up is essential for monitoring his ongoing heart health.

Patient Profile: John Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents reporting increased fatigue  shortness of breath  and intermittent fever for the past four weeks.  Medical History: Mr. Doe has had a significant past medical history including Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus well controlled on Metformin. He had a cerebrovascular accident (CVA) five years ago with no residual deficits. Mr. Doe also suffers from hypertension  for which he has been managing well with Lisinopril. He is a former smoker and quit smoking 15 years ago. Mr. Doe reports occasional alcohol use and denies any illicit drug use. His family history is significant for Ischemic Heart Disease and Hypertension.   Presenting Symptoms: Over the past four weeks  he has noticed an increased level of fatigue and shortness of breath  which has become progressively worse. He has also been experiencing intermittent fevers up to 38.5 degrees Celsius. He reports loss of appetite and unintentional weight loss. He denies any lower extremity edema or anginal chest pain. However  he admits to a transient episode of confusion he experienced ten days ago that lasted a few minutes.   Upon physical examination: The patient is ill-looking with mild pallor. His heart rate was irregular  and a pansystolic murmur was heard on cardiac auscultation. There are no visible signs of heart failure.   From the patient’s history and physical examination  the combination of constitutional symptoms  cardiac murmur  and past medical history suggest possible native-valve infective endocarditis. More definitive diagnosis will require further investigations including blood cultures and an echocardiogram. Emergent management would involve empirical antibiotics treatment. These findings need to be interpreted with caution as Mr. Doe is at a higher risk of complications due to his age  diabetes  and past CVA  therefore needs careful monitoring.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 50-year-old Hispanic male  Gustavo  who complains of recurrent fevers and a loss of appetite with unintentional weight loss of 8kg over two months. His symptoms also include profuse sweating  especially at night  along with fatigue and shortness of breath.  Demographics:   Gustavo resides in a suburban mid-income area. He is a nonsmoker  consumes alcohol occasionally  and denies any illicit drug usage. His occupation is in construction contracting. His family history reveals his father passed away from heart disease at 68 years of age  and his mother suffers from type-2 diabetes.  Past Medical History:  Gustavo has a past medical history significant for hypertension  which is kept under control with amlodipine. In addition to that  patient also has a history of dental abscess 8 weeks ago for which he underwent incision and drainage followed by a one week course of amoxicillin. He has no known drug allergies and has been fully compliant with his medications. His immunizations are up to date.   Upon further investigation  Gustavo has a previous history of heart murmurs dating back to his 30s  and his condition has progressed into mild mitral valve regurgitation. His last echocardiogram  performed one year ago  was stable without any hemodynamic compromise.   Summary:  In summary  Gustavo is a 50-year-old Hispanic male with a significant past medical history of hypertension  mitral valve disease  and a recent dental abscess now presenting with fevers  night sweats  appetite loss  and weight loss suggestive of infective endocarditis. Next step will be to carry out further investigations including routine blood investigations  echocardiogram and blood cultures. His recent dental procedure could be the port of entry for bacteria causing native valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:   The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  single  retired construction worker  hailing from San Francisco  California. He denies any tobacco use  alcohol or drug abuse. He has no known allergies.  Past Medical History:   He has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin and insulin pen  for the past 10 years. Additionally  the patient has a history of essential hypertension  controlled with lisinopril and amlodipine for the last 7 years. The patient’s condition remained stable until three months ago  when he complained of persistent  low-grade fever  weight loss  and malaise. He also reported occasional night sweats and arthralgia. He denies chest pain  cough  shortness of breath  or gastrointestinal complaints.   The patient further states that he has not traveled abroad recently and his annual flu vaccinations are up to date. He claims to maintain good oral hygiene  brushes twice a day and visit a dentist annually  the last visit was six months ago for routine cleaning with no lack of dental problems. The patient has no known family history of heart disease.   Given these symptoms  the patient underwent an evaluation which revealed a presence of a vegetation on echocardiogram suggestive of infective endocarditis. The condition appears to be native valve infective endocarditis  affecting the mitral valve.   In conclusion  our patient  with no known history of IV drug use  valvular disease  or intracardiac devices  is a case of native valve infective endocarditis which appears to be late-onset. This case serves as a reminder that although the condition erupts acutely  under certain circumstances it may have a more indolent course and be diagnosed later in the disease process. The rigorous management strategy was implemented for this patient that included antimicrobial therapy and continuous monitoring of the patient's response to treatment.   Further consultation with a cardiothoracic surgical team has been arranged for potential valve surgery perspective. We are hoping for the patient’s successful recovery with our efforts for his comprehensive cardiac care. The patient was advised of the severity of his condition and expressed an understanding of the future treatment plan. He will continue to stay under our care for follow-ups and adjustments to the treatment plan.

Patient Presentation:  We are presenting the case of Mr. John Doe  a 60-year-old Caucasian male  who has presented with symptoms that are highly suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Demographic Information: Mr. Doe is a local resident and lives with his wife. He is a retired construction worker. He has a one-pack-per-day cigarette habit for the past 40 years but denies any consumption of alcoholic drinks. He is not on any illicit drugs. His height is 5 feet 8 inches and weight is 80 Kg  putting him within the normal body mass index range.  Medical History: Mr. Doe has a past medical history significant for Rheumatic Heart Disease (RHD) for which he had been taking benzathine penicillin prophylaxis until five years ago but later discontinued. He also has hypertension for which he takes Lisinopril 10 mg orally  once daily. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 15 years ago. His blood sugar levels have been relatively under control on Metformin 1000 mg  twice daily. There is no history of any cardiac surgeries  implantation of any cardiac devices  intravenous drug abuse  or recent dental procedures.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Doe presented with a two-week history of intermittent fever  malaise  weight loss  and night sweats. He also mentioned that he noticed small  painful red spots over his skin and hemorrhagic lesions on his nails which lasted for some days. He admitted to having mild difficulty breathing  especially when he lies flat.  Assessment: Physical examination revealed a grade 3/6 systolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. Tiny red spots (petechiae) were seen on the conjunctiva and the skin. His oral hygiene was relatively poor. Vital signs showed a heart rate of 95 beats per minute  blood pressure of 130/85 mm of Hg  respiratory rate of 18 breaths/min  temperature of 38.1°C.  Based on his past history of Rheumatic Heart Disease  poor oral health  and present symptoms like consistent fever and heart murmur  a high level of suspicion for infective endocarditis was considered. Further diagnostic tests such as Blood cultures  an Echo cardiogram  and ECG have been advised to confirm the diagnosis.  This case highlights the importance of recognizing the constellation of symptoms and clinical findings  especially in patients with a history of pre-existing heart valve disease to reach a timely diagnosis of a potentially life-threatening condition like infective endocarditis.

Presenter: Good morning  colleagues. I'm here to discuss the case of a 50-year-old African American female presenting with native-valve infective endocarditis.  The patient  Mrs. Johnson  works as an elementary school teacher in California. She's been married for 25 years and has two sons  one of whom has a history of drug abuse. Mrs. Johnson is a non-smoker and reports occasional alcohol consumption. She has no known drug allergies.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Johnson has a medical history of rheumatic fever in her late teens which resulted in minor valvular heart disease. She also has a history of well-controlled hypertension which she has managed with Lisinopril for the past 10 years. Mrs. Johnson was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago which she controls with Metformin and an individualized diet plan. She is also a carrier of Hepatitis B  contracted at birth but has had no clinical symptoms of chronic liver disease.  Presenting Complaint: Mrs. Johnson presents with one week of high-grade intermittent fever  an acute onset of shortness of breath  and generalized fatigue. She has also reported involuntary weight loss and decreased appetite.  Physical Examination: Physical examination shows a temperature of 38.6°C  heart rate of 110 bpm  and blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg. She has conjunctival pallor  petechial rash on extremities and Janeway lesions – non-tender hemorrhagic macular lesions on the palms and soles. Cardiac auscultation revealed a new mild systolic murmur best heard at the apex of the heart.
