In conclusion  given Mrs. Johnson's past medical history of minor valvular heart disease due to rheumatic fever  and her current presentation including symptoms suggestive of heart failure and physical signs like Janeway Lesions  her clinical profile is highly suggestive of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis. Further diagnostics  including blood cultures and an echocardiogram  are being arranged to confirm this presumptive diagnosis.

Title: Presentation of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Patient  Patient Information:   Mr. John Doe is a 68-years-old Caucasian male presenting with signs of heart failure. He lives in San Francisco  CA  and is a retired engineer.   Presenting Symptoms:   Mr. Doe has noted persistent low-grade fever and lethargy for the past few weeks. He complains of increased shortness of breath on exertion  difficulty lying flat  and swollen ankles. He also reported a noticeable weight loss.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a longstanding history of uncontrolled type-2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He had an ischemic stroke 5 years back with complete resolution of symptoms following medical management and rehabilitation. He's also had myocardial infarction 2 years ago  managed with angioplasty and stenting.  Lifestyle:  He's a former smoker with a 30-pack year history whose last cigarette was 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially and is not physically active due to his profession. He lives alone  managing his diabetes with oral medication  and his hypertension with Lisinopril.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  Mr. Doe appears chronically ill and uncomfortable. His extremities are edematous with a grade III/VI systolic ejection murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. There's also a presentation of Janeway lesions on both hands  a common occurrence in infective endocarditis.  Diagnostic Imaging:  Echocardiography reveals mitral valve vegetations and moderate impaired systolic function. Together with his clinical presentation and the presence of positive blood cultures  he has been diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Management Strategy:  The patient requires hospital admission and initiation of IV antibiotic therapy  with follow-up blood cultures to determine effectiveness. Cardiothoracic surgical consultation will be needed considering the significant valve involvement and heart failure symptoms. He also needs strict blood glucose control and modification of his hypertension treatment.   Long term plan should include encouraging lifestyle modifications to control his diabetes and hypertension better and minimize future cardiac events. Additionally  dental assessment is necessary given the potential of oral flora as a source of his infection.   Prognosis:  Native-valve infective endocarditis mortality rates lie around 20%  but substantially increase in patients with comorbidities such as diabetes  high blood pressure  stroke  and previous heart conditions – all of which Mr. Doe has. Therefore  aggressive intervention and thorough follow-up are necessary for his case.

Patient Presentation:  Our patient is a 57-year-old Caucasian male presenting with symptoms suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis. He is employed as a construction worker and lives with his wife and two dogs.  The patient was admitted into the hospital reporting fever  malaise  night sweats  weight loss  and recent onset fatigue. There is no history of hospitalization or emergency department visits in the past year. He also reported difficulty breathing on exertion for the past couple of weeks. He denies any history of IV drug use or recent dental procedures.   Notably  he has a past medical history of untreated  mild mitral valve prolapse diagnosed ten years ago. He also has an eight-year history of type 2 diabetes which is well-controlled by metformin. He has a 30 pack-year smoking history but quit smoking five years ago. His cardiac history is otherwise unremarkable.   He denies any known drug allergies. Current medications include metformin and a daily aspirin. His immunizations are up-to-date.     His family history is significant for coronary artery disease in his father who passed away from a myocardial infarction in his 60s. His mother has a history of rheumatoid arthritis.   On physical examination  his temperature was 38.5 degrees Celsius  blood pressure was 130/85 mm of Hg  pulse was 90 beats per minute  and respiratory rate was 16 breaths per minute. Cardiac examination was notable for a new holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex - suggestive of mitral regurgitation. Examination of his skin showed small  non-tender red spots on his palms and soles (Janeway lesions). No Osler nodes were felt.   In summary  we have a middle-aged male with a history of mitral valve prolapse and diabetes  presenting with constitutional symptoms  new onset exertional breathlessness  and physical signs suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  Patient's name is Mr. Smith. He is a 62-year-old Caucasian male who presents with a two-week history of low-grade fever  chills  malaise  weakness  and a recent onset of heart palpitations. He also complained of mild shortness of breath  particularly on exertion. He noticed some small  painless red spots on his skin.  Patient's past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40 pack-year smoking history. Social history includes working as a carpenter. He lives with his wife  and they have two adult children. His mother had a history of congestive heart failure and his father passed away due to a stroke.   On examination  he looked fatigued and slightly pale. His temperature was 100.7 °F  blood pressure 140/90 mmHg  pulse rate 90 beats per minute and regular. Little red spots (petechiae) were noticed on his palms and soles. Mildly enlarged and tender spleen was palpable. Cardiac examination revealed an early diastolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border.  Investigations showed elevated inflammatory markers (CRP and ESR). Blood cultures were taken and have grown Streptococcus viridans. Transthoracic echocardiogram has shown a vegetation on his native mitral valve.  This clinical picture is suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis. He was started on appropriate antibiotics after being discussed by an infectious disease specialist. He was also discussed by the cardiac team to assess for any potential needed interventions. More investigations are being planned to look for potential systemic complications of endocarditis.   Mr. Smith's significant risk factors include his age  male sex  diabetes  smoking  and possibly his occupational exposure to wood dust. His presenting symptoms and physical examination findings  along with the echocardiogram and blood cultures  provide the major criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis as per the Modified Duke Criteria. This case represents a common presentation of a patient with native-valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Information:  We are presenting a 65-year-old Caucasian male patient  Mr. Smith  who is retired and previously worked as a construction engineer. He currently resides in a suburban environment within New York City  lives with his wife and they have regular visits from their grandchildren. He is a former smoker and quit smoking 10 years ago.  Presenting Symptoms:  Mr. Smith presented to the clinic with complaints of persistent fever  fatigue  night sweats  unexplained weight loss  malaise  and a recently developed skin rash. He also reported experiencing bouts of confusion and occasional shortness of breath.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a documented past medical history of a mild myocardial infarction approximately eight years ago  for which he underwent cardiac stenting. Since then  he has had regular yearly follow-ups and his condition had been stable. He has been routinely taking prescribed medications including Aspirin and beta-blockers. Mr. Smith also has a diagnosis of well-managed Type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he takes Metformin  and he has experienced mild hypertension  controlled by Lisinopril. He has no known allergies.  Physical Examination:  On examination  he was observed to be febrile with a temperature of 101°F. The cardiopulmonary examination revealed a new murmur heard best at the cardiac apex. A skin examination revealed a few non-blanching petechial lesions on the extensor surface of his limbs and soles. Auscultation revealed a diastolic murmur consistent with possible underlying valvular pathology.  Diagnostic Outcome:  Following the suspicion of infective endocarditis based on the aforementioned symptoms and cardiac murmur  Mr. Smith was admitted and a set of 3 blood cultures were performed. Results confirmed bacterial growth consistent with Streptococcus viridans  favoring the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  In summary  the patient's symptoms combined with the positive blood cultures and his cardiac history have led us to his current diagnosis. We are planning a course of aggressive antibiotic therapy while also ensuring vigilant monitoring of his cardiac function. Given his prior cardiac history  a consultation with a cardiothoracic surgery team may be considered for management progression.

Patient Presentation:  We have Mr. John Thompson  a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of type II diabetes  hypertension and mild heart failure (EF 45%). He reports no known allergies or drug intolerances. Mr. Thompson used to be an avid smoker with a pack a day habit for 40 years but he quit smoking 10 years ago.  He presented to the ER with a two-week history of experiencing intermittent fevers  sweating  fatigue  palpitations  shortness of breath  and unintentional weight loss. According to the patient  these symptoms had been progressively worsening  which triggered his ER visit. Upon further questioning  Mr. Thompson mentioned that he had also noticed small  painless  red spots on the skin  mostly on his palms and soles. He denied any recent dental procedures  intravenous drug use  or history of rheumatic heart disease.  On physical examination  he has an irregular heart rhythm with a new holosystolic murmur heard at the apex radiating to the axilla. He also has signs of peripheral emboli including Janeway lesions on his palms and soles  as well as Roth’s spots on fundoscopic examination.  Based on clinical examination and history  Mr. Thompson was suspected to have native-valve infective endocarditis. Further diagnostic procedures  including blood cultures and an echocardiogram  were performed and the patient was admitted for further management including intravenous antibiotics. His recent worsening health conditions and the new murmur observed are significant clinical indicators of a possible infective endocarditis. Further follow-up will be carried out based on his response to treatment.

Title: Case Presentation on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  I. Demographic Information: Patient Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 56 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Construction Worker Residence: Rural Nebraska  II. Chief Complaint: The patient reports experiencing persistent fever  fatigue  and night sweats for the past two weeks. He also noted a significant weight loss during this period  about 10 pounds.  III. Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a known history of mild hypertension controlled by medication (lisinopril) and hyperlipidemia treated with simvastatin. He was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type II five years ago and has been managing it with metformin and a balanced diet. He also has a smoking history of 30 pack-years.  Five years ago  the patient went through a dental procedure where he received inadequate prophylactic antibiotics. He has had no surgeries  allergies or hospitalizations.  IV. Family History: His family history is significant for diabetes (father) and myocardial infarction (mother  at age 65).  V. Social History: Mr. Doe lives with his wife and their two grown-up children. He smokes a pack of cigarettes daily and drinks alcohol occasionally. He denies any illicit drug use.  VI. Review of Systems: Positive for weight loss  night sweats  intermittent fever  and fatigue. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  nausea  constipation  diarrhea  and joint pains. No changes in mental status noted. He has noticed few red spots on his palm which were painless and transient.  Given patient's the medical history  current clinical symptoms  and physical examination findings  we suspect that he may have a case of native-valve infective endocarditis  possibly secondary to his past inadequate prophylaxis during dental procedure. To confirm the diagnosis  we recommend further diagnostic studies – primarily blood cultures and transthoracic echocardiogram. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate treatment are critical to prevent serious complications such as valve destruction  heart failure  and systemic emboli.   VII. Summary: In conclusion  this is a 56-year-old male with a history of hypertension  type II diabetes  and hyperlipidemia presenting with generalized symptoms of fever  fatigue  and weight loss. The differential diagnosis is broad at this point  but given his history and physical we are considering infective endocarditis as a potential cause.

Title: Patient Presentation of a Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Profile: Name: Ms. Julia Rhodes Age: 60-year-old Gender: Female Ethnicity: African-American Occupation: Retired school teacher Residential Address: Houston  Texas  United States  Presenting Complaint: Chief Complaint: Fever  fatigue  shortness of breath  skin rashes  and weight loss for over three weeks.  Medical History: A 60-year old African-American female patient  Ms. Julia Rhodes  with a medical background of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She was diagnosed with these conditions ten years ago and has been well-managed with oral antidiabetic agents and antihypertensives.  Moreover  Ms. Rhodes has no known drug allergies  and she does not report any history of alcohol intake  smoking  substance abuse  or travel outside the United States recently.  Family History: There's a strong family history of cardiovascular diseases  as both her parents succumbed to myocardial infarction. Her older brother  aged 65  is currently managing his heart disease.  Physical Examination and Symptoms: Upon physical examination  she appears uncomfortable  having low-grade temperature spikes. She portrays murmur suggestive of valvular regurgitation. She also has certain manifestations of endocarditis such as Osler's nodes  noted on her fingertips  and Janeway lesions on her palms and soles.  In her blood test  there is an elevation of inflammatory markers like ESR and C-reaction protein. Initial echocardiogram findings indicated valvular vegetations  supporting the suspicion of infective endocarditis.  The range of her symptoms  including persistent  unexplained fever  fatigue  shortness of breath and other non-specific symptoms  align with a diagnostic consideration of native valve infective endocarditis.  Infectious Disease Consult & Management Plan: Her blood cultures isolated Streptococcus viridans  which underpins the diagnosis of Native-valve Infective Endocarditis. The hospital has referred her to an infectious disease consultant for optimal management.  The provisional management plan for Ms. Rhodes includes starting her on IV antibiotics  carefully monitoring her daily vitals and labs  following her antibiotic sensitivity  and considering surgical consultation if her situation worsens or doesn't demonstrate a significant improvement on antibiotic therapy.  Patient Education & Follow-Up: The patient has been educated about her condition  the importance of medication adherence and the potential need for surgical intervention. She will be closely followed for signs of congestive heart failure  arrhythmias  valvular dysfunction or any other potential complications of this disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. D  a 65-year-old Caucasian male retired contractor  presents to the emergency department with persistent fever  fatigue  and weight loss.  Demographic Information:  Mr. D resides in a suburban area in Pittsburgh  Pennsylvania  USA and is living with his wife. He's a non-smoker and drinks socially. He has been retired for two years. Prior to his retirement  he owned and ran a successful construction and renovation business for 40 years. He stays active primarily through gardening and home repair projects. He has Medicare for health insurance.   Past Medical History:  Notably  Mr. D has a long-term history of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM)  a condition that he has been managing with medications under the care of his cardiologist. Otherwise  he has been relatively healthy with no history of surgeries. He's not diabetic and has no known allergies. He does have controlled hypertension  high cholesterol  and a mild degree of osteoarthritis in his knees. He is up-to-date with his immunizations. Two years ago  he had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) with no residual neurological deficits.   Family History:   Mr. D's father died of congestive heart failure in his 70s and his mother died of a stroke in her late 80s. Mr. D has one brother who has coronary artery disease and underwent bypass surgery.  Concern for Current Medical Issue:  Given Mr. D's symptoms and risk factors from hypertrophic cardiomyopathy  there is concern for native-valve infective endocarditis. This will need to be further evaluated with blood cultures and echocardiography. The appropriate course of treatment will then need to be determined based off these findings.

Subject: Presentation of Mr. John Doe with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Identification: The patient is Mr. John Doe  a 56-year-old Caucasian male who lives in Topeka  Kansas with his wife and two adult children.  Chief Complaint: Mr. Doe was admitted to our facility following complaints of low-grade fever  chills  fatigue  and unexplained weight loss in the past few weeks. He has reported experiencing occasional night sweats and symptoms suggestive of heart palpitations.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has past medical history significant for hypertension  high cholesterol and diabetes mellitus. He was diagnosed with these conditions approximately 10 years ago and has maintained medical compliance with a regular regimen which includes Metformin and Lisinopril. He has no known drug allergies.   Social History: He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol moderately  with an occasional glass of wine at family dinners. He retired from his job as an engineer and now spends most of his time at home gardening.   Review of Systems: Mr. Doe has no recent history of hospitalization or invasive procedures. There are no remarkable findings on his respiratory  gastrointestinal  musculoskeletal  or neurological review of systems. Slight pallor is present  suggestive of anemia  and insomnia has recently become a significant health concern. Additionally  he has noticed a slight decrease in his appetite.  Conclusion: Based on these presenting symptoms and Mr. Doe's medical background  he underwent a series of laboratory tests and echocardiography  which revealed the presence of vegetations on his mitral valve  confirming a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. With the presence of underlying chronic conditions  protracted symptoms  and echocardiogram findings  it is crucial to commence targeted antibiotic therapy and monitor the patient's progress closely to avoid potential complications  such as septicemia  valve damage  or heart failure due to uncontrolled infection.

Patient Presentation:  We have a 63-year-old Caucasian male patient  John Doe  who presents to the clinic with major health complaints  including an intermittent fever of 38.7C for the past couple of weeks  general fatigue and a noticeable weight loss.   Patient Demographics:  Mr. Doe is a retired engineer  lives with his wife. He is a former smoker with a history of 20 pack years  quit about fifteen years ago. He is not a known substance abuser nor has a history of IV drug use. He consumes alcohol only socially and in moderation.  Medical History:  His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  currently managed with oral hypoglycemic agents  and hypertension  under control with standard antihypertensive medication. He also has hyperlipidemia  controlled with statin medications. He is under regular follow-up for his chronic diseases  and his medications are well controlled. He also reports a history of a ""heart murmur"" diagnosed in his childhood without significant symptoms.  Apparently  he appeared well until about 3 weeks ago when he began to experience low-grade fevers  more profound in the evenings  loss of appetite and unintentional weight loss.  The combination of Mr. Doe’s prolonged fever  reported heart murmur  and unspecific symptoms prompts concerns of possible infective endocarditis  which requires further evaluation. Staphylococcus aureus  Streptococcus viridans  and Enterococcus species are the most common causes of infective endocarditis.  We've planned to admit him to the hospital for further evaluation and management  including blood cultures and a trans-esophageal echocardiogram to check for vegetation and assessment of valvular damage.

Subject: Presentation of Patient with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Demographic Information: Patient Name: Mr. John Doe Gender: Male Age: 54 Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Accountant  Medical History: Mr. Doe is a 54-years-old Caucasian male  non-smoker with minimal alcohol consumption  who has a history of rheumatic fever during his childhood and has been dealing with Type 2 Diabetes for the last 11 years. He has also reported episodes of hypertension for the past 5 years and maintaining the condition with regular medication. His family history includes his father  who passed away due to a myocardial infarction at age 65  and his mother who is currently alive and well at 80 years-old  with a history of osteoporosis.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Doe presented to the hospital emergency department  reporting a 2-week history of persistent low-grade fever  generalized malaise  and occasional night sweats. He complained of breathlessness during the minimal exertion and also noted that he has been experiencing intermittent episodes of joint pain  more prominent in the morning. He further mentioned experiencing some bloating and loss of appetite.  Clinical Findings and Diagnosis: Upon examination  the presence of a cardiac murmur was noted. Blood tested positive for infectious organisms (Staphylococcus aureus)  consistent with the presentation of infective endocarditis. His chest X-ray showed mild cardiomegaly  while the echocardiogram confirmed the presence of vegetations on the native valves  justifying the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  This patient's diagnosis was based on a combination of clinical presentation  his previous history with rheumatic fever which is a known predisposing factor of endocarditis  and positive findings on imaging studies.  Plan: Following the confirmed diagnosis  a treatment plan was established in consultation with the cardiac and infectious disease team. Mr. Doe is currently undergoing a course of antibiotic therapy and his condition is being monitored closely with routine blood cultures and inflammatory markers. He has been recommended for strict blood sugar control and hypertension management. A dietician has also been involved in patient care to cater to his nutritional needs during the treatment period.

Patient Profile: --- Name: Mr. Smith   Age: 54   Gender: Male   Race/Ethnicity: African American   Occupation: Construction Worker    Presenting Illness: --- Mr. Smith presents to our facility after experiencing recurring episodes of fever  fatigue  and unexplained weight loss that have persisted for almost four weeks. In addition  the patient is also displaying signs of new-onset congestive heart failure  including shortness of breath  cough  decreased exercise tolerance  and ankle edema.   Past Medical History: --- A major aspect of Mr. Smith's medical history is his long-term intravenous drug use  which ceased 3 years ago. He is a recovered addict currently undergoing methadone maintenance treatment  and he is compliant with all his medical appointments.   Mr. Smith does not have any known allergies. He is smoker  with a smoking history of 25 pack-years. The patient also has a history of alcohol use but has significantly decreased the intake over the past two years.  He also has a history of hypertension diagnosed eight years ago and is taking antihypertensive medication. However  no prior heart-related illnesses have been reported. In addition  he has been treated for HCV; the disease is currently inactive.   Social History: --- Patient is divorced and lives alone. He is unemployed but has several friends who are also in recovery and they provide a supportive network. Mr. Smith does not have any known travel history or recent exposure to infectious diseases.  Conclusion: --- In summary  Mr. Smith  a 54-year-old African American male with a history of intravenous drug abuse  hypertension  HCV  and other significant risk factors is presenting with signs and symptoms consistent with native-valve infective endocarditis. His clinical scenario  past medical history  and social background all combine to position him as a higher-risk individual for this condition. His diagnosis needs to be confirmed with further diagnostic tests and prompt treatment should be initiated. His condition also underscores the importance of medical follow-ups and regular health checks for people with significant risk factors.

Patient Presentation  The patient is a 54-year-old Hispanic male named Mr. Rodriguez who presents with a week-long history of intermittent fever  chills and malaise. He was referred to our facility after his primary care physician noticed a heart murmur during a routine check-up. He has noted occasional night sweats but denies chest pain  cough or shortness of breath.   Past Medical History  Mr. Rodriguez has a past medical history of IV drug abuse in his younger years  for which he underwent rehabilitation and has been clean for the past 10 years. He also has a history of mild hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both controlled with oral medications.  Social History  Mr. Rodriguez is a non-smoker and an occasional drinker. He lives with his wife and works as a truck driver.  Family History  There is no family history of heart diseases but his father is a type 2 diabetic  and his mother had hypertension.  Current Medications  He is currently on metformin 500 mg twice a day for diabetes and amlodipine 5 mg once daily for hypertension.  Review of Systems  The review of systems was significant for mild fatigue and a low-grade  intermittent fever. The patient has reported no changes in appetite  weight  or sleep pattern. He denies any recent travel or sick contacts.   Physical Examination  On physical examination  the patient appeared generally well. He was alert  oriented and cooperative. He had a temperature of 100.3 F. Cardiac auscultation revealed a new grade 1/6 holosystolic murmur best heard at apex. No skin rash  Osler's nodes or Janeway lesions were found. Other systems were unremarkable.   Given the patient’s new murmur  history of IV drug abuse and recent nonspecific symptoms such as fever  malaise and night sweats  a presumption of native-valve infective endocarditis is considered. Blood cultures were sent and he was admitted for echocardiogram and further management.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis Patient Presentation  PRESENTING PATIENT:   Mr. Smith is a 64-year-old African American male who has presented with painful swelling in his lower limbs  episodes of low-grade fever  and progressive malaise over the past five weeks. He has noticed recently that he is now experiencing significant weight loss. He comes from a lower socioeconomic background and has lived alone all his life.  MEDICAL HISTORY:   Mr. Smith has a history of long-term chronic cigarette smoking and has battled alcohol abuse  leading to alcoholic liver disease and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He had been diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type 2 about ten years ago  which is currently managed with oral hypoglycemic medications. He has a history of infected ulcers in the past secondary to poor diabetes control.   No previous cardiovascular history has been established  and there is no familial history of any cardiac disorders. Mr. Smith does not have a history of intravenous drug abuse. No hospitalizations within the last six months and no previous history of rheumatic heart disease or cardiac surgery.   Mr. Smith has had poor oral health leading to chronic dental infections  which may place him at risk for bacterial endocarditis.  PHYSICAL FINDINGS:  On physical examination  Mr. Smith has a full range of cardiovascular sounds with a new-onset systolic murmur on auscultation. The dental examination revealed severe dental caries and gingivitis. His overall hygiene appeared poor. He presented with pale skin  low-grade fever  dependent edema in both lower limbs  and clubbing of the fingers.  On his lab reports  abnormal blood cultures reveal positive bacterial growth. Echocardiogram demonstrated vegetations on the native valves suggestive of infective endocarditis. Other labs were remarkable with leukocytosis  mild anemia  and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rates  indicating an ongoing inflammatory process.   PRELIMINARY DIAGNOSIS:  Based on the sociodemographics  medical history  physical examination  and laboratory findings  a preliminary diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis (NVE) was considered. The patient was promptly admitted for further workup and management of the condition.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Smith  I. Demographic Information:  Mr. John Smith is a 65-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired carpenter who is now engaged in part-time teaching in a community college. He lives in a suburban dwelling with his wife  and they have no pets at home. He is a non-smoker  casual alcohol drinker  and denies any history of illicit drug use.   II. Presenting Symptoms:  Mr. Smith presents with a two-week history of low-grade  intermittent fever  malaise  muscle aches and an unexplained weight loss of around 10 pounds. He has also noticed dark spots on the palms of his hands and soles of his feet  which he describes as painless but occasionally itchy.  He also mentions that he has been having night sweats for a few days.   III. Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a known history of type II diabetes for the past 15 years  which is well controlled through oral hypoglycemic agents and diet modification. He has also been diagnosed with hypertension and benign prostatic hypertrophy. He had his last annual check-up six months ago  where a benign heart murmur was noticed but no further investigation was inferred due to absence of any related symptoms.  IV. Medications:  He is currently taking metformin for his diabetes  lisinopril for hypertension and tamsulosin for his benign prostatic hypertrophy.   V. Immunizations:  He is up-to-date with his annual influenza vaccines and he received pneumococcal vaccine 3 years ago. He also completed his series of shingles vaccine last year.  VI. Allergies:  Mr. Smith reports no known allergies to food  medication  or environmental factors.  Given his symptoms and the presence of the heart murmur  Mr. Smith is suspected of having native valve infective endocarditis. Further investigations and clinical management are planned accordingly.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jones is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents with a chief complaint of consistent fever  malaise  and intermittent chest discomfort. The patient has been experiencing these symptoms for approximately 2 weeks now. The erratic temperature ranges from 100 - 103°F  typically higher in the evening. Accompanying symptoms include night sweats  fatigue  and mild weight loss. Due to his ongoing fever and chest discomfort  Mr. Jones decided to seek medical help.  Mr. Jones is married  a non-smoker  and drinks alcohol only occasionally. He is retired but used to work as an engineer for a prominent tech company. The patient lives with his wife and has a supportive system of grown-up children and grandchildren. He is independent in daily activities.  Past Medical History :  Mr. Jones has a past medical history significant for aortic stenosis  diagnosed five years ago  for which he has been under regular cardiology follow-up. He was recommended surgical intervention but opted for conservative treatment. He also has a history of controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He reports no known allergies. His family history includes his father who died of stroke and mother who died of breast cancer.   Current Medications:  The patient's current medication regimen includes Enalapril 5mg daily for hypertension  and Atorvastatin 20mg nightly for hyperlipidaemia.  Physical Examination:  Upon physical examination  Mr. Jones appears in no acute distress. Vital signs are normal except for a fever of 102°F. The Cardiac exam revealed a systolic murmur. During examination  small  non-painful red spots (Osler's nodes) were noted on his palms and soles  and under the fingernails  there were areas of bleeding (splinter hemorrhages).   Preliminary diagnosis of infective endocarditis was made due to the combination of fever  murmur  and other physical signs. This was later confirmed by subsequent blood cultures and transthoracic echocardiography revealing vegetations on the aortic valve. Mr. Jones's medical team scheduled him for a further evaluation and immediate treatment.

Patient Presentation   Name: John Doe Age: 65 Sex: Male Location: San Diego  California   Chief Complaint: Complaints of worsening fatigue  fever  and aching joint for a duration of the last two weeks.  Medical History: John Doe is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus that was diagnosed ten years ago and is managed with metformin. He also has a previous history of hypertension controlled with lisinopril for the past 15 years. He had a surgical history of a hernia repair about 20 years ago but no history of valve replacement or cardiac surgery. He lives alone  is a retired engineer and has Medicare insurance. He has no known drug allergies. His family history is notable for coronary artery disease in his father who passed away due to myocardial infarction at the age of 70. His mother has a history of arthritis.   Over the last two weeks  Mr. Doe has noticed gradually increasing fatigue  intermittent fevers  and aching joints. He also noticed shortness of breath on exertion that was not present before. Initially  he attributed the symptoms to aging and stress  but he decided to seek medical attention when his usual activities  such as grocery shopping and walking  became difficult due to his fatigue and breathlessness.  He denies the chest pain  orthopnea  and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He has no symptoms suggestive of stroke or other neurological pathologies. On review of his systems  he has lost around 5 pounds in the last couple of weeks.  Physical Examination: General appearance: He appears chronically ill  is leaning forward and is using his accessory muscles to breathe but is not in acute distress. Temperature: 38.4 degree Celsius  Blood pressure: 138/82 mmHg  Pulse: 98 bpm  Respiratory rate: 22 breaths per min  SpO2 93% on room air.  Cardiovascular Examination: He has a regular rate and rhythm with a mid-diastolic murmur best heard at the apex. Pulmonary examination: Decreased breath sounds on bases with coarse crackles have been found on auscultation. No signs of peripheral stigmata of infective endocarditis  including Janeway's lesions  Osler's nodes  or Roth spots  were observed.   Differential Diagnosis includes infective endocarditis  pneumonia  viral or bacterial infection  autoimmune diseases  neoplasms  and anemia due to different causes. Urgent investigations including CBC  chest x-ray  blood cultures  autoimmune workup  and Echocardiogram are ordered. Treatment must be individualized according to the pathogen identified. Empiric antibiotic treatment might be started based on the clinical findings of infection and sepsis  likely source and local resistance patterns.

Slide 1: Introduction The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired school teacher  with a history of moderate tobacco use and social alcohol consumption.  Slide 2: Presenting Symptoms  He is presenting with a three-week onset of unrelenting fever  night sweats  weight loss  and vague musculoskeletal pain. The patient also reports a new heart murmur and recent onset of easy fatigability.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  This patient's past medical history is significant for rheumatic heart disease diagnosed in his late 20s. He has been treated with prophylactic antibiotics prior to dental procedures. He also notes long-standing  well-controlled hypertension and had an episode of deep venous thrombosis five years ago after a long-haul flight. He has no known drug allergies.   Slide 4: Social History  The patient lives with his wife and has no history of illicit drug use. He has a 30 pack-year history of smoking but quit five years ago. He admits to moderate alcohol use  with an average of one to two drinks per day.   Slide 5: Family History  His family history includes coronary artery disease in his father who experienced a heart attack at age 55  a mother with hypertension and a sister with adult-onset diabetes.    Slide 6: Potential Diagnosis Given the combination of his systemic symptoms  new heart murmur  history of rheumatic heart disease and his echocardiography findings  the working diagnosis is native-valve infective endocarditis. This is further supported by his moderate risk profile  given his prior heart disease and the presence of valvular abnormality.   Slide 7: Further Tests  Further diagnostic tests that may be beneficial include blood tests for complete blood count and differential  renal function  liver function tests  and obtaining blood for cultures before initiating antibiotics therapy.   Slide 8: Proposed Treatment Prompt treatment should be started to improve survival probability. The treatment includes prolonged antibiotics administration for at least 4-6 weeks and surgery may be indicated depending on the patient's clinical progress.  Slide 9: Prognosis Endocarditis carries a high risk of complications  including heart damage and systemic infections. Timely diagnosis and treatment are critical to improving prognosis and decreasing morbidity and mortality.

Patient Presentation  I am presenting Mr. John Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian male with native-valve infective endocarditis. He hails from Philadelphia and is a retired bank executive. He and his wife of 40 years live together  they are nonsmokers and are conservatives when it comes to alcohol consumption. He came to our clinic presenting with a 1-month history of intermittent fevers  night sweats  fatigue  and a loss of appetite. He reports unintentional weight loss over the past 3 weeks.  Past Medical History  Mr. Smith has a past medical history significant for Type II diabetes  controlled with metformin and lifestyle modifications. His diabetes is well under control with a recent HbA1C level of 6.5%. He additionally suffers from hypertension which is managed effectively with a daily regimen of Lisinopril. He had a myocardial infarction 5 years ago but recovered well after undergoing angioplasty. Mr. Smith has not received any dental care in the last two years. His last colonoscopy  3 years ago  was normal.  There is no history of illicit drug use  tattoos  recent travel  or close contact with sick people. From his personal history  he's not allergic to any food or drugs. Childhood immunizations were received as per the schedule and he had received his annual flu shot.  Family history is significant for heart disease in both parents  his father had congestive heart failure and his mother had a stroke. His two siblings are alive and well with no significant medical history.  Upon physical examination  he appeared ill and had a fever of 100.8 degrees Fahrenheit. Cardiovascular examination showed a diastolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border. Labs were drawn  including blood cultures. He was subsequently admitted and started on empiric antibiotic therapy.  Mr. Smith's case is consistent with native‐valve infective endocarditis. His symptoms  along with the finding of a heart murmur and the significant positive family history of heart disease  are all consistent with this diagnosis. The next steps will be to conduct an ECHO and adjust his antibiotics based on culture sensitivities. With appropriate treatment  he stands a good chance of making a full recovery.

Patient Presentation:  Today we have a 60-year-old African-American male patient known as Mr. A who is presenting with symptoms indicative of native-valve infective endocarditis. Born and raised in Nebraska  he worked as a construction worker for 35 years  has been a two-pack-a-day smoker for the past 40 years  and reports occasional excessive alcohol intake. He is a widower and lives alone since his wife passed away 2 years ago. He has 2 adult children who live in different states.   Past Medical History:  Mr. A has a past medical history significant for several health issues. He was diagnosed with type II diabetes at the age of 45  which has been poorly controlled. He also suffers from hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he has been on antihypertensive meds and statins respectively. Despite advice from his previous healthcare providers  he has a history of noncompliance with his medications. He also had a non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) seven years ago  for which he underwent angioplasty and was started on daily aspirin and other post-MI medications.   About a week ago  he had some dental work done during which he developed a tooth infection and was placed on antibiotics. He is allergic to penicillin; however  his other drug allergies are unknown.  Current Condition:  Mr. A arrived at the emergency department complaining of high-grade fever  malaise  progressive shortness of breath  and fatigue that has worsened over the last two weeks. On physical examination  Osler's nodes were visible (indicative of vasculitis)  along with Janeway lesions on his palms and soles. He has a new murmur upon cardiac auscultation suggestive of valvular regurgitation. These symptoms  in conjunction with his previous dental infection  make us suspect the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis.  We are planning to conduct complete blood works  including blood cultures  and an Echocardiogram for a definitive diagnosis. Pending results  we are considering initiation of empirical antimicrobial treatment. Additionally  his diabetes and hypertension management will be revisited to prevent further complications. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor treatment response and disease progression. Managing Mr. A's case comprehensively will involve addressing his smoking and alcohol consumption habits  ensuring adherence to his prescribed medications  and providing him with psychological support.

Patient Presentation  The patient is a 73-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Robert Jenkins. He is a retired mechanic and lives with his wife in Boston  Massachusetts. He is a non-smoker and non-alcoholic  and leads an active lifestyle which includes a regular walking routine and gardening activities.   Past Medical History Mr. Jenkins has a documented history of type II diabetes mellitus for the past ten years  which is well-controlled with Metformin. He underwent a successful angioplasty procedure for angina five years ago. The patient also suffers from mild hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are managed with medication (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin). He has no known drug allergies. There is no documented history of illicit drug use  and no family history of infective endocarditis or any cardiac diseases.   Presenting Complaint and Examination Mr. Jenkins presented to the emergency department with complaints of a high-grade fever  chills  fatigue  night sweats  and unexplained weight loss for the past two weeks. He also reported a decreased appetite and shortness of breath  especially on exertion.   On physical examination  he appeared pale and lethargic. Auscultation revealed a new onset cardiac murmur over the mitral area. Minimal leg edema was also noted. His body temperature was elevated at 38.5 degrees Celsius.   This presentation is consistent with possible native-valve infective endocarditis given his new onset of a cardiac murmur coupled with his systemic symptoms of fever and malaise. Further investigations  including blood cultures and an echocardiogram  have been requested to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation  I would like to present a patient  Mr. J  a 65-year-old Caucasian male recently diagnosed with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVE). Mr. J has been living in an urban setting of New York City  is a retired engineer  and a non-smoker. He has a history of chronic hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been well-managed with long-term medication. He does not have any known allergies. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes at the age of 58 and has been on metformin therapy since then. He admits to being non-compliant with his diet  and his most recent HbA1c was elevated at 8%.   About two months ago  Mr. J had a dental extraction after which he did not take the prescribed course of antibiotics. This is the likely time when the transient bacteremia seeded his native valves and potentially set the stage for his current condition. He has since been experiencing malaise  fatigue  intermittent fever  and a recent unexpected weight loss. His family members have noticed that he is often confused and lethargic  which is not his normal baseline behavior.   Cardiac examination findings showed a new murmur consistent with aortic insufficiency. Besides  numerous blood cultures have isolated Streptococcus viridians. Echocardiography has confirmed vegetation on his aortic valve with moderate regurgitation suggestive of NVE. Neurologically  he also had couple of transient ischemic attacks  probably as a result of septic emboli. Rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  To summarize  Mr. J is a 65-year-old male with significant cardiovascular risk factors including diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. His current condition of NVE is likely a consequence of a dental procedure followed by lack of prophylactic antibiotics. It seems to be complicated by heart valve damage and systemic embolization causing neurological impairment.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 45-year-old Caucasian male  who works as an accountant and belongs to a middle-class socioeconomic background. He has been living in the urban suburbs.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of intravenous drug use in his early 20s  but he has been clean for the past 15 years. He has a positive medical history for chronic Hepatitis C infection due to his previous IV drug use. He is also a long-term smoker  prone to smoking about 15-20 cigarettes a day. He does not have a history of any major illness or surgery but was recently diagnosed with Diabetes Mellitus Type II  for which he is under oral hypoglycemic agents. He does not have any known allergies.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with a week-long history of persistent fever  night sweats  and unexplained weight loss. He is also complaining of general weakness  muscle aches  a new heart murmur  and blood in the urine. He has not encountered this combination of symptoms before and identifies the fever as being quite high  sometimes reaching 102°F. He has also been feeling unusually fatigued  even when performing minor tasks.  Overall  his symptoms  medical history  and lifestyle can indicate a possible case of native valve infective endocarditis. Further  diagnostic tests are required to confirm the diagnosis  including blood cultures and transthoracic echocardiography. It is imperative to define the causative pathogen in order to start the patient on the suitable antibiotic treatment as soon as possible.   Concluding  this case highlights the importance of considering early diagnosis and treatment of native-valve infective endocarditis  especially in patients with a past medical history that predisposes them to this condition. In such cases  a multidisciplinary approach involving a team of cardiologists  infectious disease specialists  and often cardiac surgeons  should be initiated for improving patient outcomes.

Title: A Clinical Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Patient Presentation: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the hospital with symptoms of fatigue  unexplained weight loss  low-grade fever  night sweats  and a new heart murmur. He reports his symptoms have been getting progressively worse over the past month. He especially complains about feeling extremely tired even with minimal exertion.  Demographics: The patient is a retired engineer. He lives with his wife in their apartment in the city. He denies usage of any recreational drugs  excessive alcohol  or frequent smoking.   Medical History: His medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  which is managed with oral hypoglycemic agents  and hypertension. He has been taking an ace inhibitor for this condition. He also received dental work  specifically tooth extraction  two months ago for which he did not take any prophylactic antibiotics. He reports no known allergies to medicines. He has been hospitalized once previously due to a minor stroke approximately five years ago and retains no major residual disabilities from it. He is not on any anticoagulation.   Family History: His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease; his father died of myocardial infarction at 68 years  and his brother has angina. He denies any family history of rheumatic heart disease or any congenital heart anomalies.  Physical Examination: On physical exam  the patient appeared chronically ill and fatigued. He has a blood pressure of 140/90  pulse rate of 90 bpm  temperature of 38.3C  and respiratory rate of 18 per minute. Cardiac exams reveal the presence of a new cardiac murmur suggestive of aortic regurgitation. Small  non-tender spots (Janeway lesions) are observed on his palms and soles. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Conclusion: Based on clinical findings and history provided  there is a high suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis in this patient  likely secondary to the dental procedure carried out two months ago. Further diagnostic procedures such as blood cultures and echocardiogram are needed to confirm the diagnosis and guide the treatment in this case. The patient requires immediate hospitalization and treatment to prevent further damage to his heart and potential complications.   Thank you so much for your attention. I am now open to any questions regarding this case.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Senior Male Patient  Patient Profile: - Name: Mr. X  - Age: 67 years - Sex: Male - Ethnic Background: Hispanic   Presenting Issue: Mr. X reports a consistent fever over the last 3 weeks  and has been feeling generally unwell with a lack of energy and a marked decrease in appetite. He has reported recent unintentional weight loss and night sweats. He was brought to the ER by his daughter after he experienced a brief loss of consciousness.  Medical History: Mr. X has a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and dyslipidemia. He has no known drug allergies. He is a former smoker  quit 10 years ago  and consumes alcohol socially. He does not have a history of illicit drug use. He has never been diagnosed with heart disease before  and there is no indication of intravenous drug use or immunosuppression. Mr. X had dental work done approximately one month ago.   Assessment and Plan: Initial physical exams showed he was febrile with a heart murmur. Blood culture results are pending. The presence of fever plus the new onset murmur suggests possible infective endocarditis. We are proceeding with the Duke Criteria for diagnosis and are arranging an Echocardiogram to visualize the heart valves and look for signs of vegetation indicative of infective endocarditis.   If the suspicion for infective endocarditis is confirmed  the patient will be prescribed a course of intravenous antibiotics and will be closely monitored. Also  the team will seek the consultation of a cardiologist and other specialists as appropriate  based on the evolution of the patient’s symptoms.  Conclusion: Mr. X's confirmed diagnoses  optimal management  and patient education on future preventive measures will be determined based on lab results  imaging findings  and collaboration with the cardiology team. Given his advanced age and comorbid conditions  careful attention will be given to the management of this patient's potentially serious condition.

Slide 1:  Title: Case Description: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 2:  Introduction  Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old European-American male  presented with symptoms consistent with native-valve infective endocarditis. He resides in urban Cleveland  Ohio  and is a retired school teacher.   Slide 3:  Medical History  He has a past medical history of type II diabetes  controlled with metformin  and hypertension  treated with lisinopril. Title: Infected Native Valve Endocarditis in a 65-Year-Old Male  Introduction Our patient is a 65-year-old male who has presented with symptoms indicating native-valve infective endocarditis  a condition characterized by infection caused by microorganisms of the heart valves within the cardiac cavity.  Demographics The patient is a Caucasian male  non-smoker  with occasional alcohol consumption. He is retired and living with his wife in a rural area. He has no known drug allergies.  Symptoms The presenting symptoms include persistent fever  malaise  loss of appetite  weight loss  and night sweats. He also reports having splinter hemorrhages under his nails  and Osler nodes (painful red nodes) on his fingers and toes. Upon inspection  Janeway lesions  or small erythematous or hemorrhagic macular or nodular lesions on the palms and soles  were also noted. The patient presented with a new murmur  suggestive of valvular disease  which was absent in his last physician visit three months back.  Past Medical History The patient's medical history is significant  as he has a history of untreated dental infection six months ago  which could possibly be the source of his current endocarditis. He has controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. Additionally  he has been treated for hypertension for the last 10 years. Furthermore  he successfully underwent a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery around 5 years back.  Family History The patient's family medical history reveals that both of his parents suffered from cardiovascular diseases. His father died of a heart attack and his mother had a stroke.   Conclusion Given the patient's symptoms and medical history  he has been diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis. The most likely organisms causing infective endocarditis due to the dental source could be viridans group Streptococci or Staphylococcus aureus. Further diagnostic investigations  including blood cultures and echocardiograms  have been recommended for the confirmation of the causal microorganism and to evaluate the degree of valvular damage.   This patient is at high risk and requires aggressive medical management  possibly including hospitalization  heavy-duty antibiotics  and  if deemed necessary by the cardiology team  he may need surgical intervention to repair or replace the damaged heart valves. Regular follow-ups would also be needed to monitor his condition.

Patient Presentation  Our subject patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male presenting with native-valve infective endocarditis. The patient lives with his spouse in an urban part of Detroit  Michigan and has been employed as a construction worker for over 40 years. This individual is a former smoker  having quit cigarette use around 15 years ago  and has a moderate alcohol consumption habit  partaking most nights.  This patient has been previously diagnosed with several comorbidities that are important in the context of this case. Firstly  the patient has a 10-year history of uncontrolled type II diabetes mellitus that has been primarily managed through diet and oral antidiabetic medication  including Metformin  which he has routine difficulties adhering to. Approximately 8 years ago  he was diagnosed with coronary artery disease for which he had an elective percutaneous intervention  and now regularly takes lifelong low-dose aspirin.  Regarding his social history  the patient lives with his wife and has excellent support at home. He is a grandfather to 6 grandchildren and often spends time babysitting them. Despite his chronic illnesses  he continues to be relatively active and enjoys golfing and socializing with friends.  His endocarditis current presentation started around 2 weeks ago with non-specific symptoms of fatigue  anorexia  some weight loss  and an intermittent low-grade fever predominantly in the evening times. Over the last 3-4 days  he has developed a cough and shortness of breath on exertion. He has no previous history of illicit drug use  dental procedures  or recent invasive procedures.  In summary  this is a case of a 67-year-old male who  despite his high-risk profile due to uncontrolled diabetes  coronary artery disease  and moderate alcohol consumption  was able to present at an early stage for medical consultation due to his good home support system. His social history and past medical history provide valuable insight into his overall medical management and prognosis through his infective endocarditis course.

Slide 1: Introduction  Good afternoon  today I will present a case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVIE).  Slide 2: Patient Information  Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  previously residing in an urban setting. He is retired  with a past occupation as a mechanical engineer.  Slide 3: Patient History  The patient has a significant medical history which includes hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes. Additionally  he has previously been a smoker with a 30-pack year history. His only prior surgical history includes appendectomy at age 22. There is no known family history of endocarditis. He is currently on Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia.  Slide 4: Presentation of Symptoms  The patient presented with a 2 week history of malaise  night sweats  shortness of breath  and orthopnea. He also reported a non-productive cough  low-grade fever  and a weight loss of 5kg over a month. No history of chest pain  headache  rash  or recent dental work.  Slide 5: Physical Examination  Examination revealed peripheral stigmata of endocarditis including splinter hemorrhages in the nail beds  Osler's nodes on his fingers and toes  and conjunctival hemorrhages. A diastolic murmur was heard best at the apex  suggestive of Mitral regurgitation. No other abnormal findings were apparent on examination.  Slide 6: Investigation  Upon initial investigation  the patient was found to have leukocytosis and elevated inflammatory markersErythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR) and C-Reactive Protein (CRP). A Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) revealed a vegetative lesion on the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve  indicative of infective endocarditis. Blood cultures are pending.  Slide 7: Diagnosis  Given the clinical  laboratory  and imaging findings  the patient was diagnosed with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis.  In conclusion  timely diagnosis and proper management are imperative in NVIE cases to ensure optimal patient outcomes and minimize morbidity and mortality rates. This patient's condition requires immediate interventions including empirical antibiotic therapy  followed by targeted treatment based on blood culture and sensitivity results  and possibly surgical approach if medical treatment fails.

Title: Case Presentation on Endocarditis in Native-Valve  Patient Details:  Mr. Johnson  a 68-year-old African American male  presents with a chronic cough  high fever  rapid weight loss  and generalized malaise. He resides in the urban area of Philadelphia  Pennsylvania and is retired from his job as a principal in a high school. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. His body mass index (BMI) is 29.4. His family history is significant for diabetes and hypertension.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a well-documented history of rheumatic fever at the age of 17  which suggests potential damage to the heart valves. Over the past 10 years  he has been treated for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Diabetes is controlled by oral hypoglycemic agents and he uses calcium channel blockers for hypertension. He has no known allergies to medications.  Current Physical and Diagnostic Evaluation:  On physical examination  he appears tired. His pulse rate was 98 beats per minute  blood pressure at 140/80 mmHg  and he had a fever of 100.4 F. Cardiac auscultation revealed a grade III systolic murmur best heard at the apex. Laboratory data showed high leukocyte count indicating a possible infection. Blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus viridans  a common organism implicated in endocarditis. Echocardiogram suggested thickening and vegetation on the mitral valve  supporting a diagnosis of infective endocarditis. No other abnormality was detected in the remaining examinations.  In conclusion  considering Mr. Johnson's medical history  clinical manifestations  laboratory results  and echocardiogram findings  a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis is most consistent. The patient requires immediate hospitalization and initiation of an appropriate antibiotic regimen. Further evaluation is needed to decide the requirement for possible surgical intervention.

He has also noted increasing discomfort in his chest region and shortness of breath on exertion. He mentioned having mild joint and muscle pains as well. His wife noticed that he looked slightly pale.  Past Medical History: Mr. Jones has a past medical history significant for uncontrolled type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He was diagnosed with these conditions ten years ago and has been receiving medications for the same. His medications include Metformin 500mg twice daily and Lisinopril 20mg once daily. He also has a history of stable angina defined by occasional chest discomfort with strenuous activity or stress. Mr. Jones has no history of IV drug use or a recent dental procedure. He has no known drug allergies.  Examination: On examination  the patient appears fatigued. Cardiac examination revealed a new-onset heart murmur  suggestive of valvular involvement.
