Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian male named John. He works as a truck driver and lives with his wife and two dogs in a suburban home in Portland  Oregon. John is a heavy smoker with a 30-year pack history and is a moderate drinker. He denies use of illicit drugs.   In terms of past medical history  John suffers from Type II Diabetes Mellitus which is controlled through oral hypoglycemic agents. He also has hyperlipidemia  well controlled on statin therapy. He does not have any personal or family history of rheumatic fever or any other cardiac disease. He had a successful hernia repair surgery 10 years ago.   Recently  he's been suffering from a persistent fever that varies 100.4 to 101.3 °F  a new heart murmur  and unexplained weight loss for about a month. John also reported experiencing night sweats  malaise  and weakness. He has not traveled recently and does not recall any recent tick bites or similar events.   Given the duration of his symptoms and the lack of a clear alternative source of infection  a presumption of native-valve infective endocarditis has been considered. Appropriate diagnostics will be needed to confirm this diagnosis and guide management. This should include blood cultures  inflammatory markers and echocardiography.

Patient Profile:  - Name: Mr. John Doe - Age: 57 years - Sex: Male - Occupation: Construction worker - Ethnic background: African American - Marital status: Married  Presentation:  Mr. Doe presents to the clinic with complaints of persistent high-grade fever with temperatures ranging between 100 °F - 103 °F for the past two weeks. Accompanying the fever are night sweats  fatigue and loss of appetite leading to weight loss. He reports a new onset of a heart murmur  shortness of breath  and occasional chest discomfort. Additionally  he has noted some red tender spots under the skin of his fingers and toes and petechiae on his palate.  Past Medical History:  1. Diabetes Mellitus type 2 controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents for the past 7 years. 2. Hypertension  also well controlled with medication for 5 years. 3. History of Heavy Alcohol consumption and Smoking for 30 years.  Physical examination revealed a mid-diastolic murmur on auscultation suggesting a probable valvular heart disease. Complete blood count showed raised white cell count suggestive of an ongoing infection  and high erythrocyte sedimentation rate indicating inflammation. Blood cultures have been sent and awaiting results.  Given his high-risk profession being a construction worker which exposes him to multiple infectious agents  his lifestyle choices  and the new onset of heart murmur  all point towards a strong possibility of infective endocarditis affecting his native heart valves.   Treatment is deferred until blood culture results and antigen detection to confirm the infective organism and further management would be decided. Education for lifestyle modification has been provided given his previous medical history and current suspected diagnosis.

Title: Presentation of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-aged Female   Introduction:  Our patient  Mrs. A  is a 45-year-old Caucasian female with a history of rheumatic heart disease and intermittent intravenous drug use. She is a resident of Los Angeles  California and works as an elementary school teacher. Her familial history reveals a prevalence of cardiac disease on her paternal side.  Past Medical History:  Mrs. A had rheumatic fever at the age of 13  that led to rheumatic heart disease  characterized by stenosis of the mitral and aortic valves. She has been managed on a regimen of penicillin prophylaxis and diuretics for her mitral valve disease with regular follow-ups with her cardiologist. She has no other known comorbidities such as diabetes  hypertension  or hyperlipidemia. However  Mrs. A also has a history of intermittent intravenous drug use  mainly heroin  which she first disclosed to her healthcare provider 5 years ago. She has been in and out of rehab facilities but struggles to maintain consistent sobriety  a known risk factor for infective endocarditis.  Presenting Complaint:  Mrs. A presents to our clinic today reporting a 2-week history of intermittent fever  fatigue and generalized weakness. She mentions associated symptoms of loss of appetite  severe joint pain and unintentional weight loss of about 10 pounds in a month. She denies any recent dental procedures  but admits to a few episodes of injecting drugs over the past month.  Examination Findings:  Initial evaluation indicates that she is febrile with a temperature of 102°F. Cardiovascular examination reveals a new diastolic murmur heard best at the apex. Fundoscopic examination notes the presence of Roth spots and her palms exhibit Janeway lesions.   Impression:  The patient's history of rheumatic heart disease and recent intravenous drug use  along with her clinical signs and symptoms  raise a high suspicion for infective endocarditis affecting her native valves. Further investigations  including blood cultures and an echocardiogram  are recommended to confirm the diagnosis and to guide the choice of antibiotic therapy.  It is important to manage Mrs. A's condition promptly to prevent further complications such as heart failure  arrhythmias  systemic embolization  and other life-threatening complications that may arise due to untreated infective endocarditis. Simultaneously  a comprehensive plan to address her substance use disorder is also crucial.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. John Smith  presenting with symptoms that suggest native-valve infective endocarditis.  Mr. Smith is from Cleveland  Ohio  and has been married for 35 years. He has two adult children and three grandchildren. He has worked as a factory worker for over 30 years. He reports a history of moderate alcohol consumption but denies any history of smoking or illicit drug use.  In terms of comorbidities  Mr. Smith has a history of hypertension and rheumatic fever during childhood. He has been medically managed for both conditions without any complications. He also has a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus  which he manages with insulin and diet.  Clinical Presentation:  Mr. Smith presents today with a one-week history of lethargy  intermittent fever  night sweats  and a new-onset heart murmur. He noticed his symptoms while gardening and initially attributed them to his physically demanding job and seasonal changes. He sought medical help when these symptoms persisted and his fatigue levels affected his ability to perform daily activities.  On examination  his blood pressure is relatively stable  however  he has tachycardia with a heart rate of 102 beats per minute. Auscultation of his chest reveals a diastolic murmur. His respiratory rate and oxygen saturation are within normal limits. Oral examination reveals mild gingival bleeding and erythema.  These symptoms align with the clinical presentation of infective endocarditis  often seen in patients with a background of rheumatic fever and poor dental hygiene  as indicated by the observed gingival inflammation.  Next steps in management would typically include confirmatory blood cultures and a transesophageal echocardiogram.

Title: Presentation of a Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis Patient  Patient Information: We present a case of a 63-year-old male patient named Mr. John Thomas. He is a White American  born and adult life spent mostly in San Francisco  California. He is a retired librarian  lives with his wife in a suburb  and has no living children.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Thomas initially presented with nonspecific symptoms such as low-grade fever  malaise  and mild fatigue that lasted for a few weeks. He also began to experience night sweats and weight loss  which prompted him to seek medical attention.  Past Medical History: Mr. Thomas has a history of moderate aortic stenosis which was diagnosed 8 years ago  but he was asymptomatic and thus did not undergo surgery. He also has well-controlled type 2 diabetes for which he has been taking Metformin for the past 10 years. There is no history of illicit drug use  and he quit smoking 15 years ago. He also has no known allergies. He has not previously had any surgeries or hospital admissions outside of a hernia repair twenty years prior. His immunization is up-to-date including influenza and pneumococcal vaccinations.  Clinical Findings: A physical examination revealed a diastolic murmur consistent with his known aortic valve disease. Janeway lesions were also found on his palms and soles  and Osler's nodes were observed on his fingers- signs indicative of endocarditis. No petechiae  Roth spots  or splenomegaly were present.  A subsequent echocardiogram showed moderate aortic stenosis with an added finding of a vegetation on the aortic valve suggestive of infective endocarditis. Blood cultures were taken and came back positive for Streptococcus viridans  further confirming the diagnosis.   Given his previous medical history  symptomatology  and the clinical and laboratory findings  Mr. Thomas was thus diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis. Currently  his case has been discussed with the cardiothoracic surgery team and decisions regarding possible surgical intervention are being considered alongside a course of appropriate antibiotics.   Clinical course of Mr. Thomas’ infection  especially relation to his diabetes control will be closely monitored to provide him with the most suitable care plan.

Presentation Title: A Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Overview:  Our patient  Mr. X  is a 63-year-old Caucasian male who has presented with sub-acute symptoms suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis. He lives in the city and is working as an accountant. His main complaint is persistent  low-grade fever for approximately 3 weeks  associated with malaise  reduced appetite  and weight loss of around 10 pounds during this period.   Demographics:  Age: 63 years Gender: Male Occupation: Accountant  Ethnicity: Caucasian  Residence: Urban Religion: Christian  Medical History:  Mr. X has a significant past medical history of moderate tobacco use  consuming a half-pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years  and alcohol use  about 2-3 drinks per weekend. This history corresponds to a high pulmonary risk that may contribute to the on-going problem.  He was diagnosed with type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 10 years ago  which is well-managed on Metformin. Due to this chronic condition  it puts him at an elevated risk for infections  including endocarditis.  Five years ago  he had undergone a mitral valve repair due to severe regurgitation possibly complicating chronic rheumatic heart disease. Ever since then  he has not faced any significant symptoms related to it.  His family history reveals that his father died of a heart attack at the age of 70  and his mother is alive and well at 88. He has one brother who has no significant health issues.  In summary:  Mr. X  a 63-year-old man  has presented with symptoms suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis. With his medical history of diabetes and heart disease  his symptoms are concerning and indicate a need for immediate attention and intervention. As such  he will undergo further evaluation  including blood cultures and echocardiography  to confirm the cause of symptoms and to plan the appropriate treatment strategy.

Title: Case Presentation of a Patient with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Introduction:   We present the case of a 65-year-old Caucasian female recently diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis.   Patient Demographics:  The patient  Mrs. W.  is a retired schoolteacher from rural Nebraska  Caucasian  and has an extensive history of untreated dental problems. She's a non-smoker and has no known history of substance abuse.   Medical History:  Her past medical history includes rheumatic fever at age 15  hypertension for the past 20 years  hyperlipidemia  and chronic atrial fibrillation for which she is on warfarin. She has a known allergy to penicillin  causing rash. She had a fractured femur 10 years ago  treated with intramedullary nailing and now non-weight bearing on the right side. Her family history is significant for cardiovascular disease and stroke.  Presenting Complaint:  Mrs. W presented to the clinic with complaints of fatigue  low-grade fever  chills  and shortness of breath on exertion for the past three weeks. The initial concerns were focused on possible respiratory infection or cardiac decompensation secondary to her atrial fibrillation.   On examination  she appeared pale and was found to have a cardiac murmur not previously documented. Dental examination revealed significant dental decay and gingival inflammation. Lab results revealed positive blood cultures for Streptococcus viridans  with mild anemia and elevated inflammatory markers.  Diagnosis:   Considering her clinical presentation  significant dental pathology  and isolation of a typical pathogen for endocarditis in blood cultures  she was diagnosed with native valve infective endocarditis.  Infective endocarditis  involving native valves  primarily occurs due to the spread of bacteria into the bloodstream (bacteremia) with the capacity to attach to heart lining  valves or blood vessels. In Mrs. W.'s case  her poor dental health probably facilitated bacteremia and subsequently the development of endocarditis.  She has been admitted for further management  which will likely involve lengthy antibiotic therapy and potentially valve repair or replacement surgery. The patient has been informed about the seriousness of her condition  and dental counselling requested for the improvement of her oral health.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of dental hygiene and care in the prevention of serious cardiac conditions such as endocarditis  especially among patients with existing heart diseases.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Profile: - Name: Mr. John Doe - Age: 52 years old - Sex: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Office worker - Current Residence: New York City  NY  Background: Mr. John Doe is a 52-year-old Caucasian male with a previously known medical history of diabetes mellitus type II  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He is noted to have been a smoker for 30 years  consuming a packet a day but quit about four years ago. There is no known drug or alcohol abuse. He works as an office worker and lives in an apartment in New York City. His medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin.   Presenting symptoms:  The patient presents with a two-week history of intermittent fever  night sweats  and weight loss. He also mentions malaise  and shortness of breath that has worsened over the last few days. Recently  he began experiencing toothaches and had dental work done but did not take antibiotics.   Physical Examination: Upon examination  he appears generally unwell and fatigued. Cardiac auscultation reveals a new murmur consistent with possible valve damage. Further examination noted skin changes in the form of petechiae on his lower limbs  and on his palms and soles revealing Janeway lesions.   Based on the patient's medical history  and presenting symptoms as well as physical findings  a suspected diagnosis of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis has been made. Further investigations including blood cultures and an echocardiogram will be ordered to confirm the diagnosis and assess the degree of valve damage.   If the diagnosis is confirmed  the patient will require prompt and proper treatment with intravenous antibiotics  and a referral to Infectious Disease and Cardiology for further decision on the need of surgical intervention. Strengthening oral health care and promoting health awareness are also critical in the management plan to prevent potential relapse and serious complications.

Title: Case Presentation of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Adult Male  Introduction:  Today  we will discuss the case of a 55-year-old Caucasian male patient  Mr. J  who presented with native-valve infective endocarditis. He is a resident of Brooklyn  New York  and works as a civil engineer.   Presenting Complaint:  The patient arrived at the hospital with a one-month history of persistent nightly fever  malaise  weight loss  and fatigue that gradually got worse. He also reported experiencing shortness of breath during mild exertion like walking a short flight of stairs.   Past Medical History:  Mr. J has a history of mild hypertension and high cholesterol  for which he has been taking Lisinopril and atorvastatin respectively. He is a former smoker and gave up smoking ten years ago. There is no known history of drug abuse. He has no surgical history. He has no known allergies.   Social History:  Mr. J. is married with two children. He leads an active lifestyle  including hiking and biking on weekends. He drinks alcohol in moderation  one or two glasses of wine  a few times a week. His family history includes heart disease on his mother's side.  Clinical Findings and Diagnosis: On examination  new-onset systolic murmur was detected. There were also signs of peripheral stigmata of infective endocarditis such as Janeway lesions on palms and soles and Osler's nodes on fingers were observed. Laboratory findings showed elevated inflammatory markers and positive blood cultures for Staphylococcus aureus. The diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis was confirmed by Transesophageal Echocardiogram (TEE) which showed vegetations on the mitral valve.  References: Mr. J's condition is a relatively commonplace presentation in the hospital. Infective endocarditis is an infection that affects the endocardial surface of the heart. The prognosis of this condition usually depends on early detection  appropriate therapy  and effective control of the infection.  In conclusion: Though Mr. J's lifestyle and medical history present minor risks for his current condition  this case underscores the necessity for a careful and holistic investigation when dealing with such non-specific symptoms as fever and fatigue  especially when combined with the new-onset of cardiac murmurs.

Title: Patient Presentation on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 1: Introduction  Patient X is a 65-year-old Caucasian male presenting with signs and symptoms consistent with a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Slide 2: Demographics  The patient is a retired manual worker  lives in a suburban area with his wife  and has a history of smoking 15 cigarettes a day for the past 30 years. He abstains from alcohol and has no known drug allergies. He has never had any occupational exposure to dust or harmful chemicals.  Slide 3: Medical History  Patient X was diagnosed with hypertension and type-2 diabetes mellitus ten years ago. Both conditions are managed with medication - Amlodipine 5mg per day for hypertension and Metformin 500mg twice a day for diabetes. Also  he experienced an episode of acute bronchitis six months ago but has since recovered.  Slide 4: Current Presentation   Over the course of the past two weeks  Patient X has reported having a high-grade intermittent fever  fatigue  a poor appetite accompanied by a weight loss of five kilograms and night sweats. An office-based test showed an elevated ESR and CRP  indicating an inflammatory process.  Slide 5: Clinical Examination  On examination  his blood pressure was 145/90 mm of Hg and the pulse was regular with a rate of 95 beats per minute. Auscultation of the heart revealed a new murmur in the mitral valve area. Ophthalmoscopic examination indicated the presence of Roth’s spots while Janeway lesions were noted on his palms and soles. His oral health being poor demonstrated a potential source for the bacteremia associated with infectious endocarditis.  Slide 6: Diagnosis  Given the clinical features  laboratory findings  and heart murmur heard on the mitral valve  Patient X is highly likely to have native-valve infective endocarditis. Confirmation of the diagnosis will require blood cultures and an echocardiogram.  Slide 7: Management & Conclusion  The patient will be started on empiric antibiotic therapy while confirmatory tests are conducted. Both his diabetes and hypertension will continue to be controlled with his regular medication. Patient X will be counseled on the importance of oral hygiene in preventing endocarditis.

Title: Case Presentation of a Patient with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Name: Mr. Johnson Williams Age: 58 years old Sex: Male Occupation: Retired Teacher Ethnicity: Caucasian Location: New York City  New York  United States  Presenting concerns: Mr. Williams presents with complaints of persistent fever for two weeks  associated with bouts of sweating  weakness  and unexplained weight loss. He also mentions experiencing heart palpitations and discomfort in his chest area. More recently  he has been tormented by persistent coughing and breathlessness.  Past medical history: Mr. Williams has a known history of significant cardiovascular disease  including moderate aortic regurgitation diagnosed three years ago. He has mild hypertension  which is controlled on medication  without the need for hospitalization. Additionally  he has a ten-year history of well-controlled Type II Diabetes Mellitus. He had an episode of pneumonia five years ago needing hospitalization  but he reportedly has had no other instances of serious infections in the past. His medical record reflects consistent immunizations as scheduled  including the pneumococcal vaccine. There is no known history of illicit drug use.  Family History: His father passed away in his 70's due to myocardial infarction  and his mother is currently alive and well. He has two siblings  one of whom has hypertension.  Smoke/Alcohol/Drug Use: Mr. Williams is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally socially  and he denies any illicit or recreational drug use.   Lifestyle/Physical Activity: Mr. Williams enjoys an active lifestyle that includes regular physical activity such as morning walks and is an avid swimmer. He is also part of a book club and enjoys gardening.   In conclusion  Mr. Williams's symptoms of persistent fever  chills  sweating  and chest discomfort  in conjunction with his known history of cardiovascular disease  strongly suggest an infectious process likely localized in the heart. The clinical suspicion is high for native valve infective endocarditis  which needs to be investigated further with appropriate diagnostic testing. His medical history and risk factors warrant rapid initiation of management to prevent further complications  like heart failure  embolic events  or sepsis.

Presentation of Patient:  Patient Name: John Doe Age: 55 years old Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian  Presenting Complaint:  Mr Doe presents with symptoms that are indicative of native-valve infective endocarditis. These symptoms include persistent and unexplained fever  night sweats  fatigue  and loss of appetite. He also reports experiencing shortness of breath  especially during normal daily activities. Furthermore  Mr. Doe has visible  non-painful  red or purple spots (petechiae) on the skin and inside the mouth. On examination  a heart murmur can be detected.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a history of a congenitally bicuspid aortic valve  a condition which puts him at a higher risk for endocarditis. His congenital heart condition has been managed conservatively  with regular follow-ups for the past ten years. Besides this  he suffers from type 2 diabetes and hypertension  both of which are controlled with medication.  Family history:  Mr. Doe's family history is notable for cardiovascular diseases. His father died of a heart attack at the age of 60 and his mother has hypertension.  Lifestyle:  For the past 20 years  Mr. Doe has been a patient at our dental clinic  where he receives semi-annual check-ups and routine dental work. He is a non-smoker and a non-drinker. He leads a sedentary lifestyle and has a diet relatively high in sodium and carbohydrates  which likely plays a role in his present health conditions.  In summary  given Mr. Doe's congenital cardiac anomaly  persistent fevers  existence of petechiae  the presence of a heart murmur  and a lifestyle that might have led to such condition  his presenting symptoms appear to indicate native-valve infective endocarditis. Further examinations and tests are necessary for definitive diagnosis and treatment.

Patient Presentation:  Today we are discussing a 57-year-old African American male named Mr. Johnson presenting with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Mr. Johnson is a self-employed carpenter living in New York  a non-smoker who has records of moderate alcohol consumption. He has no reported allergies and his immunizations are up to date. His family history includes a father who had diabetes and a mother with hypertension.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with Rheumatic Heart Disease (RHD) in his late twenties and has been managing the condition with periodic echocardiograms and prescribed medications. He had episodes of acute rheumatic fever in his adolescent. Apart from this  his medical history is fairly unremarkable  with no history of major surgeries or other long-term medical conditions.  Presenting Symptoms:   Mr. Johnson presented with three weeks history of fatigue  fever with night sweats  and about a six-pound unintended weight loss. He mentioned experiencing a loss of appetite accompanied by generalized malaise and a shortness of breath on exertion. He also reported enduring a mild  non-radiating pain in his chest.  Physical Examination:  On examination  Mr. Johnson was found to be febrile with a temperature of 38.7ºC (101.7ºF). A cardiac examination uncovered a murmur consistent with mitral regurgitation. There were Osler’s nodes present on his fingers and toes  and Janeway lesions were noted on palms and soles.   Given his past medical history and current symptoms  he was suspected to have native-valve infective endocarditis. His blood cultures were drawn and an echocardiogram was ordered.  These are the clinical data collected so far. Further investigations and management plan will be directed based on the results of the above tests.   Due to the presence of endocarditis  it has been necessary to recommend antibiotic therapy. Considering Mr. Johnson's health history  there will be a need for close monitoring and follow-up after his hospital stay to ensure that his condition remains stable and that no other health issues arise.

Patient Presentation:  This is a 60-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Johnson presenting with native-valve infective endocarditis. Mr. Johnson has a predominant urban dwelling and works as an accountant. He does not smoke but does consume alcohol socially. Mr. Johnson is a known hypertensive and diabetic  controlled on medication. He had an appendectomy at the age of 25 and a passing history of rheumatic fever in his childhood  but with no residual heart disease. He has no known drug allergies.  Around two weeks ago  Mr. Johnson started experiencing malaise  low-grade fever  chills  and marked weight loss. He also reported experiencing shortness of breath upon exertion and noticed occasional nocturnal sweating. He complained of new onset pain in his joints and muscles  mainly in his thighs and arms.  In the past week  his conditions worsened  experiencing excessive fatigue and worsening dyspnea. Due to these symptoms  Mr. Johnson sought medical attention.  Mr. Johnson has no family history of hereditary or acquired heart diseases. He is up-to-date with his vaccines and does not have any travel history in the past year.  On physical examination  he was found to be cachectic  mildly icteric with pallor. Conjunctival hemorrhages were observed. Cardiac auscultation discovered a new pansystolic murmur heard at the left sternal edge  suggestive of tricuspid regurgitation. Multiple petechiae and purpuric rashes were noted on his legs and foot  which might be Janeway lesions or Osler's nodes. Pulmonary auscultation was normal. His abdomen was soft  non-tender  with no organomegaly.  Given his constellation of symptoms and findings  Mr. Johnson was admitted to the hospital to get treated for possible infective endocarditis. Further testing  like blood cultures and an echocardiogram  are recommended to confirm the diagnosis. If the diagnosis of infective endocarditis is confirmed  it needs immediate treatment with specific antibiotics  and the patient will be followed for any complications.

Presentation of Patient with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information:  The patient can be identified as Mrs. Amelia Martinez  a 70-year-old Hispanic female from San Antonio  Texas. Mrs. Martinez is a retired secondary school teacher  married with two adult children  and six grandchildren. She is an active member of her community and regularly attends church activities.   Medical History:  Our patient has had a previous medical history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus  which she has been managing for 15 years  and Hypertension for a decade  which she manages through lifestyle modification and medication. She also has occasional episodes of osteoarthritis  which are managed with NSAIDs as needed. In her medical records  it is noted that she has had no past surgical procedures.   In the past  she has shown good compliance with her medication regimens  and her blood sugar levels and blood pressure have been well controlled. She has regular follow-up appointments every three months to monitor her conditions.  Presenting Scenario:  Mrs. Martinez has been feeling progressively unwell for about three weeks now. She complains of a moderate to high-grade continuous fever  malaise  loss of weight  and night sweats. She further reports shortness of breath  particularly during physical activities that she previously had no trouble with.   At home  Mrs. Martinez detected an irregular heartbeat and is experiencing symptoms of peripheral edema  thus she sought medical attention. There is no chest pain  and no history of drug abuse. Her immunization is up-to-date and does not have any known drug allergies.  Possible Diagnosis:  Based on the patient's symptoms  especially the continuous fever  weight loss  night sweats  an irregular heartbeat  and signs of heart failure  a suspected diagnosis is Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis. This suspicion will require further diagnostic procedures  including blood cultures and an echocardiogram  to confirm.   Mrs. Martinez's age  the presence of diabetes  and hypertension puts her at a higher risk for this condition. If the diagnosis is confirmed  appropriate treatment options need to be explored to provide the best possible care.

Patient Presentation  Today we are reviewing the case of Mr. James  a 60-year-old Caucasian male who has been recently diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis. He is married with two adult children and lives in Austin  Texas. He works as a high school teacher and has recently retired.  Mr. James's past medical history is significant for well-controlled hypertension  for which he has been taking medication (lisinopril 20 mg daily) for the past five years. He is also a former smoker who quit twenty years ago after a 20-year history of a pack a day. He denies any history of alcohol or illicit drug use. There is also no known cardiac history  and he has never had rheumatic fever or immunosuppressive therapy. He also had a dental procedure done 2 weeks before the onset of symptoms.  Recently  he has been experiencing fever  chills  fatigue  and night sweats. He also complained of a new onset of lower back pain  weight loss  and reduced appetite. His family practitioner ordered a complete blood count test  the results of which showed an elevated white cell count suggestive of an infection.  As a result of his symptoms and clinical presentation  Mr. James was admitted to the hospital for further evaluation. EKG was completed which showed normal sinus rhythm  transthoracic echocardiography showed vegetations on his native mitral and aortic valves  and a serious of blood cultures were positive for Staphylococcus aureus.  The combination of these clinical findings  his elevated WBC count in peripheral blood  and positive blood cultures were supportive of a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis  more likely related to his recent dental procedure. A subsequent treatment plan has been devised  and Mr. James is currently receiving an appropriate course of antibiotics.   This case is an example of infective endocarditis  which  although rare  can have potentially serious complications  especially when it involves native valves. Early recognition and prompt treatment are essential for a favorable outcome.

Presenting Patient: Ms. Jane Smith  Demographic Information:  Jane Smith is a 75-year-old Caucasian female  retired teacher  resident of Los Angeles  California. She is widowed  lives alone  and has three adult children who live in the nearby vicinity. She does not smoke or drink alcohol and has no known drug allergies.   Past Medical History:  Ms. Smith has a known history of type 2 diabetes which has been well managed through diet and Metformin for the past 10 years; she also has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  controlled with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively. She underwent a cholecystectomy 15 years ago. There is no known history of cardiac disorders  autoimmune diseases  or any other chronic conditions.   Presenting Complaint:  Ms. Smith presents with a two-week history of persistent fever  malaise  night sweats  and weight loss of about 5lbs. She also mentions mild chest discomfort  but no shortness of breath  cough or other respiratory symptoms.   Examination:   On examination  her temperature is 100.8°F  pulse is 90 beats/minute  respiration is 16 breaths/minute  and blood pressure is 128/85mmHg. She has no noticeable skin rashes or lesions but has noted mild pallor. Cardiovascular examination reveals a pansystolic murmur suggestive of valvular involvement. The rest of her physical examination is normal.  Preliminary Diagnosis: Considering her clinical symptoms and physical examination  a preliminary diagnosis of native-valve Infective Endocarditis is suspected. A blood culture and echocardiogram are ordered to confirm our suspicions and to assess the extent of the valvular involvement.   Plan: If the diagnosis is confirmed  we plan to start her on broad-spectrum antibiotics pending the results of the blood culture  followed by more specific therapy based on culture sensitivity results. She will need close monitoring in hospital  and we will consider the need for surgical intervention depending on the severity of her condition.  We also plan to involve a diabetes educator to review her diabetes management under this acute condition  and a dietitian to address her weight loss and to ensure appropriate nutritional intake.

Title: Presentation of Patient with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 1: Demographic Information --------------------------- Patient Profile: - Age: 62 years old - Gender: Male - Ethnicity: African American - Occupation: Retired mechanic  Slide 2: Location and Social History --------------------------- - Residing in rural Georgia - Smoking history: 20-pack year history  still active - Alcohol: Consumes alcohol on social occasions  approximately 3-4 times per month - No prior illicit drug use  Slide 3: Family Medical History --------------------------- - Mother passed away from a stroke at age 68 - Father passed away from lung cancer at age 75 - One younger brother  alive and well - No family history of heart diseases or valve abnormalities  Slide 4: Past Medical History --------------------------- - Diagnosis of Type II diabetes mellitus 10 years ago  currently controlled on Metformin - History of Hypertension  managed by Losartan - Prior episode of cellulitis on right leg 2 years ago  treated successfully with antibiotics - Regular influenza vaccinations  most recent one month ago - No known allergies   Slide 5: Recent Health Status --------------------------- - Started experiencing shortness of breath  fevers  and chills for two weeks - Noticed overall weakness and malaise - Progressive decline in functional status  Slide 6: Point to Consider ---------------------------- - The patient's age  social and medical history may have elevated the risk for infective endocarditis  - Smoking and diabetes may have compromised vascular health - Recent symptoms are indicative of a systemic infectious process  consistent with infective endocarditis. Further diagnostic testing should be conducted to confirm the diagnosis and develop a treatment strategy.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Demographic Information: Patient Name: Mr. X Age: 63 years Gender: Male Occupation: Retired Mechanic Ethnicity: Caucasian Residence: Rural area Smoking Status: Ex-smoker Alcohol Consumption: Moderate  Chief Complaint: The patient presented with intermittent fever persisting over the last three weeks  associated with fatigue  loss of appetite  weight loss  and night sweats. Furthermore  he described a new  subtle murmur  noticeable as a heart sound not detected before.  Past Medical History:  1. Cardiovascular conditions:    - Diagnosed with mild Hypertension five years back  well-controlled under medication.   - No history suggestive of Coronary Artery Disease or Congestive Heart Failure. 2. Respiratory Conditions:    - History of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)  attributed to past smoking. Currently under leukotrine inhibitors and short-acting beta-agonists. 3. Gastrointestinal Conditions:   - Medical history of Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)  managed with proton pump inhibitors. 4. Orthopedic Conditions:   - History of Osteoarthritis affecting the knees  managed by paracetamol and lifestyle modifications. 5. Other Conditions:   - No history of Diabetes  Hepatitis  Renal issues  or Cancers.   - No known allergies.   - Complete vaccination status  including influenza and pneumococcus.     Recent Events: Mr. X underwent a dental procedure about a month back without any prophylactic antibiotics. Subsequently  he noticed the onset of fevers along with fatigue and general malaise  prompting a medical evaluation.  Family History: Both parents are deceased. Father had a history of Cardiovascular Disease  and mother had complications linked to Chronic Kidney Disease. Two siblings are alive and well  save for a sister recently diagnosed with Breast Cancer.  Conclusion: Given the patient's symptoms of persistent fever  weight loss  heart murmur  and recent dental procedure  along with a non-responsive state to broad-spectrum antibiotics  the clinical suspicion is leaning towards Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis. Further diagnostic procedures such as Blood Cultures  Echocardiogram  and other laboratory tests should be undertaken to confirm the diagnosis. Subsequent management will be based on the infecting organism and its antibiotic sensitivity  the patient's health condition  and valve lesion's severity.

Presentation Title: Infective Endocarditis in Native Valve  Patient Information:  - Name: John Doe - Age: 55 years - Gender: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: High School teacher - Location: New York  Medical History:   Mr. John Doe has a pronounced past medical history of congenital heart disease  specifically a bicuspid aortic valve documented since early adulthood. Other significant health conditions include type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  which are well-managed with medications. He underwent a gallbladder removal surgery 5 years ago but has not had any surgical intervention related to his heart condition.  Presenting Symptoms:  Mr. Doe has been experiencing intermittent fevers  chills and night sweats for the last 3 weeks. Over the past week  he developed progressive shortness of breath and fatigue  which prompted his visit to the ER. The Family reports that he appears to have lost weight unintentionally over the last few weeks and he has also complained about moderate joint and muscle pain.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  he had a low-grade fever of 100.4°F and his heart rate was slightly elevated at 90 beats per minute. A heart murmur was appreciated  which was previously documented. Additionally  there were Janeway lesions (small  painless  red or purple spots on the palms of the hands or soles of the feet) and Osler's nodes (tender nodules on finger pads) consistent with infective endocarditis.  Investigations:  A series of tests were ordered  including complete blood count  renal function test  erythrocyte sedimentation rate & C-reactive protein. Blood cultures were taken due to suspicion of bacteremia. A transthoracic echocardiogram was ordered to visualize his heart valves and chambers  which showed vegetation on the bicuspid aortic valve  reinforcing the initial diagnosis of infective endocarditis.  Conclusion:  Mr. Doe is positively diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis  possibly secondary to unrecognized bacteremia  facilitated by his congenital bicuspid aortic valve condition. Appropriate treatment through long-course intravenous antibiotics is immediately initiated. His condition requires close monitoring to prevent severe complications such as heart failure  systemic embolism  and valvular insufficiency. Cardiac surgery consultation has been sought to discuss possible valve repair or replacement due to the severe damage to the native valve.

Title: Patient Presentation: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Patient Information:   Mr. John Doe  a 48-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with a 2-week history of fever  dizziness  malaise  night sweats  and unexplained weight loss. The patient lives in the metropolitan area and is a computer engineer by profession. His wife  who accompanied him  reported that he looks pale and fatigued.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Doe's medical history reveals that he is a type 2 diabetic. He's had the condition for six years but has managed to keep his blood glucose levels relatively stable through medication (metformin) and lifestyle modifications. The patient also battled an episode of acute bronchitis about two years ago but fully recovered following medical treatment.  Additionally  the patient has a known history of intravenous (IV) drug use during his late teens and twenties. He received treatment for drug addiction 15 years ago and has since maintained sobriety. He has no known allergies. The patient's family history is notable for cardiovascular disease.  Current Presentation:  Upon physical examination  the patient exhibits signs consistent with infective endocarditis  including Osler's nodes on his fingers and toes  Janeway lesions on his palms and soles  and petechiae on his conjunctiva and palate.  Initial laboratory results indicate an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-Reactive protein level  suggestive of systemic inflammation. His full blood count revealed anemia. Blood cultures were drawn and sent for further investigation. The echocardiogram showed vegetations on his native valves indicating native-valve infective endocarditis.   Given the patient's history and presentation  he is now being evaluated further and will be started on intravenous antibiotic therapy once the causative microorganism is identified.   Prognosis and further actions depend upon the response to antibiotic therapy  the extent of valve damage  any possible complications  and the adherence to prescribed therapies and follow-up appointments.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information:  The patient  Mr. Alberto Ruiz  is a 60-year-old Hispanic male currently residing in San Diego  California. He is a retired lawyer with a history of tobacco use  having smoked a pack a day for the past 40 years.  Medical History:  Mr. Ruiz has a notable medical history that includes Type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and moderate to severe aortic stenosis  which has been medically managed for the past decade. He has no known drug allergies but does have a remote history of alcohol abuse  which ceased approximately 15 years ago. His surgical history only includes an appendectomy performed 30 years ago. He is currently on Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Aspirin for cardiovascular prevention.  Present Illness:  Mr. Ruiz presented with sporadic fever  chills  fatigue  shortness of breath and a recent unintentional weight loss. Over a period of several weeks  his condition did not improve and he was referred by his primary care physician to the cardiology department for further investigation. Clinical examination revealed a slight heart murmur previously correlated with his aortic stenosis. However  due to the progression of symptoms  it was suggested that his condition might have worsened or that he developed a possible complication  such as infective endocarditis.  Lab Results:  In the following blood tests  findings showed an elevated white blood cell count and C-reactive protein level indicating an ongoing inflammatory process or infection. Blood culture results were positive for Streptococcus viridans. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) exhibited vegetations on the aortic valve which coupled with his symptoms and lab findings  the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis was confirmed.  Plan:  Given the identified infectious agent and its sensitivity  Mr. Ruiz was started on an appropriate course of antibiotics for infective endocarditis. He will also be regularly monitored for response to treatment and potential complications  both systematically and cardiac-wise. Upon improvement and clearance of bacteremia  the need for cardiac surgery will further be discussed taking his overall health and valve damage into consideration. He will also be emphasized about the importance of correct oral hygiene given the identified bacteria. As he's at increased risk for endocarditis  prophylactic antibiotic therapy prior to certain dental procedures will also be recommended.

Title: Presentation of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis Patient  Slide 1:  Introduction  Today we will be discussing Mr. John Smith  a 65-year-old male with a history of degenerative valve disease who recently presented with symptoms indicative of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Slide 2:  Demographics  Mr. Smith is a retired engineer  socially active  married with two grown children. He is a non-smoker and non-alcoholic. He hails from a suburban community with no recent travel history.   Slide 3:  Past Medical History  Mr. Smith has a history of degenerative valve disease and was diagnosed with mild aortic stenosis five years ago. For this condition  he has been on a regular check-up regimen  but no surgical intervention has been needed to date. He also has a history of controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Slide 4:  Symptoms and Physical Examination Findings  Mr. Smith presented with intermittent fever  fatigue  weight loss over the last six weeks  and a new cardiac murmur detected on physical examination. No skin lesions  Osler's nodes  or Janeway lesions were noted in the assessment. But a positive Roth's spot was detected during ophthalmic examination.  Slide 5:  Investigations and Diagnosis  Blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus viridans  an echo-cardiogram showed vegetations on the aortic valve consistent with infective endocarditis. His complete blood count revealed mild anemia and elevated inflammatory markers  and an EKG detected no electrical abnormalities.  Slide 6:  Discussion  Mr. Smith's presentation is indicative of native-valve infective endocarditis  likely resulting from his pre-existing degenerative valve disease. Without prompt and appropriate management  his prognosis may be poor due to complications like heart failure  systemic embolism  or uncontrolled infection.  Slide 7:  Conclusion  Native-valve infective endocarditis is a serious condition that requires an accurate diagnosis and timely intervention. Patients like Mr. Smith  with pre-existing valve diseases  are at a higher risk and need regular monitoring for any signs or symptoms of infection. His case emphasizes the importance of considering infective endocarditis in patients presenting with similar symptoms and a history of valvular heart disease.   Slide 8:  Future Steps  Mr. Smith will be initiated on appropriate antibiotic therapy and observed closely for signs of stability or deterioration. If his condition worsens or fails to improve with medical management  surgical consultation will be considered for possible valve replacement. The importance of his maintaining his follow-ups for aortic stenosis will be stressed to prevent similar future problems.

Patient Profile:   Name: Mrs. Joan Starling  Age: 68 years old  Gender: Female  Race: Caucasian  Mrs. Joan Starling  a Caucasian lady of 68 years  presents today with a complaint of persistent fever  malaise  and symptoms of heart failure  including shortness of breath and fatigue. Mrs. Starling is a retired teacher and lives with her husband in the suburbs. She demises smoking  alcohol  or any illicit drug use but admits to having a sweet tooth and not being active physically.  Past Medical History:  The patient has been notably healthy with few significant medical issues. She has a known history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus for the last ten years and managed with oral hypoglycemic agents. Furthermore  she was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis 5 years ago and is currently on a regimen of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and occasional corticosteroids as a treatment plan. She has no known allergies.  The assessment reveals she is notably tachycardic with a new heart murmur. Blood cultures and an echocardiogram have been ordered to confirm the diagnosis of native valve Infective Endocarditis. Her prolonged fever  symptoms of heart failure  and a newly noticed heart murmur all suggest the same.   Family History:  She mentioned her father passed away from a CVA (Stroke)  and her mother lived till the age of 89 without any significant illness. Her two sisters are alive and well.  Given her history of rheumatoid arthritis  which weakens the immune system and increased susceptibility to infections  and her history of diabetes  which can lead to a higher risk of infections due to high sugar levels being a good medium for bacterial growth; together  these conditions might have predisposed her to the development of native valve infective endocarditis.  According to the updated guidelines by the American Heart Association  her presentation fits the Duke’s criteria for probable infective endocarditis.  Thus  Mrs. Joan Starling is likely suffering from Native Valve Infective Endocarditis  and the isolation of a microorganism from her blood cultures will further strengthen the diagnosis. Immediate initiation of antibiotics therapy is planned.

Subject: Patient Presentation: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  I would like to introduce Mr. John Willard  a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a recent diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. Mr. Willard is from a suburban neighborhood in Austin  Texas  and has been working as an engineer for most of his career. He is a non-smoker and rarely drinks alcohol.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Willard has a history of significant medical conditions which includes type 2 diabetes mellitus  for which he has been taking metformin for 10-years  and a history of Rheumatic fever in his adolescent years. He has been managing his diabetes well through medication and lifestyle adjustments  maintaining good HbA1c levels. He does not report any known allergies.  Current symptoms and diagnosis: Around three weeks ago  Mr. Willard started feeling unwell presenting symptoms such as fever  fatigue  weight loss  and nocturnal sweats  which he initially dismissed as possible flu. Over the span of a few days  he began to experience a new-onset of shortness of breath  mild chest discomfort  and palpitations  which compelled him to seek medical attention.  On examination  abdominal palpation revealed moderate hepatomegaly. The cardiovascular examination unveiled the presence of a new heart murmur suggestive of mitral regurgitation. Blood tests showed elevated inflammatory markers and three sets of blood cultures were positive for Staphylococcus aureus  leading to the diagnosis of infective endocarditis. The diagnosis was further supported by the echocardiographic evidence showing vegetations on the native mitral valve.  Conclusion: Mr. Willard is currently hospitalized and has started the right antibiotic therapy based on culture sensitivity. Given his risk factors and recent symptomatology  he is closely monitored by our multidisciplinary team including Cardiologists and Infectious Disease specialists. Early detection and intervention is crucial in managing Mr. Willard's condition to prevent serious complications like heart failure  embolic events or systemic sepsis. His next steps would involve managing his condition through long-term antibiotics followed by a possible evaluation for a surgical intervention  if necessary.    We continue to leverage Mr. Willard's motivation to improve his health  working together for a better prognosis and quality of life.

Title: Case Presentation of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Patient Profile: Mr. Samuel Watson is a 58-year-old Caucasian male farmer from Albuquerque  New Mexico  with a history of Stage 3 Chronic Kidney disease secondary to uncontrolled hypertension. He presents with a 2-week history of health deterioration involving high-grade fever  fatigue  malaise and a 10-pound unintentional weight loss. No significant family history of cardiovascular diseases or rheumatic fever was reported. Ex-smoker  quit 10 years ago  and moderate alcohol drinker.   Chief Complaint: High-grade fever persistent for 14 days  associated with generalized weakness  fatigue  and malaise.  History of Present Illness: The onset of the disease was gradual  first manifesting as low-grade fever that escalated into regular high-grade fever spikes often exceeding 38.5 degrees Celsius. Symptoms were accompanied by consistent malaise  loss of strength  and rapid weight loss. He denies hemoptysis or dyspnea; no diarrhea or vomiting  and no rashes or joint pain.  Past Medical History: Mr. Watson was diagnosed with hypertension at age 42  poorly managed due to non-compliance until about 10 years ago when he started taking antihypertensive medications regularly. The patient was subsequently diagnosed with stage 3 chronic kidney disease 5 years ago. He had a minor kidney infection which was treated successfully 2 years back. No history of diabetes  heart disease  or any other significant medical conditions.  Medications Record: He is currently on Lisinopril 20mg daily and Amlodipine 10mg daily for his hypertension. He takes Calcitriol 0.25mcg daily and Epoetin Alfa injection weekly for his chronic kidney disease.  Social History: Mr. Watson worked as a farmer for more than thirty years and lives alone. He is a reformed smoker; smoked 1 pack per day for 20 years but quit 10 years ago. Drinks alcohol moderately  about 3-4 glasses of whiskey per week. No history of illicit drug use.  This overall clinical scenario raises a suspicion of infectious endocarditis in the context of unexplained fever  fatigue  and significant weight loss in a patient with chronic kidney disease and hypertension. Further investigations like Blood Culture and Transesophageal Echocardiogram (TEE) are required to confirm the diagnosis.   Please note that other infectious diseases  malignancies  and autoimmune diseases should also be ruled out due to the patient's non-specific symptoms and unexplained weight loss.

Presentation of the Patient   I am presenting a 60-year-old Caucasian male patient with a native-valve infective endocarditis. Residing in Seattle  Washington  the patient works as a construction engineer and has a history of smoking  but quit approximately 3 years ago. He also has a moderate drinking history. However  he abstained from alcohol for the last 6 months. He has been relatively physically active throughout his life due to the demands of his job.   Past Medical History  The patient has a notable medical history of benign prostatic hyperplasia  for which he takes Tamsulosin. He also has a history of occasional atrial fibrillation  managed by Amiodarone  and suffers from hypertension - controlled with Lisinopril. Although he had never required any surgery  nor had he any known allergies  he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 5 years back and is currently on Metformin to manage his blood glucose levels.   Family history comprised of a father with ischemic heart disease who passed away in his late 70s and a mother who suffered from diabetes and died at the age of 82 due to renal complications. Both his older siblings are alive and well with his elder sister diagnosed with hypertension and his elder brother recently diagnosed with colon cancer.   Current Presentation   He presented to the hospital with a 2-3 weeks history of fatigue  lesional skin erythema  low-grade fever  night sweats  and weight loss. Upon examination  the patient appeared chronically ill. He had a new systolic murmur over the aortic area which is suggestive of aortic regurgitation. Additionally  Osler's nodes were also found on his hands and feet. These findings along with subjective symptoms are indicative of native-valve infective endocarditis.   Further diagnostic steps will include ordering blood cultures  an ECG  a chest X-ray  and a transesophageal echocardiogram. Empirical antibiotics will be initiated until the causative organism is identified from the blood cultures. A cardiology and infectious disease consult will be required as well  considering the severity and complexity of the illness.

Presentation:  Ladies and gentlemen of the medical team  I would like you to meet our 63-year-old gentleman  Mr. Smith. He is a retired factory worker and he resides at the suburban area of Philadelphia  Pennsylvania. Mr. Smith is of Caucasian ethnicity and he lives with his wife and a pet dog. He has a history of smoking for over 20 years but quit about 10 years ago; he consumes alcohol occasionally and does not engage in any illicit drug use.  Mr. Smith’s past medical history is significant for Type II diabetes for which he is on Metformin  and hypertension managed with Losartan. He had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) two years ago but fortunately did not have any residual deficits. An echocardiogram done after the TIA revealed mild mitral valve regurgitation  but he was asymptomatic at that time. There is no known history of allergies.  Recently  Mr. Smith was admitted following a week of moderate to high-grade fever  malaise  new-onset heart murmurs and petechiae on extremities. Laboratory investigations revealed elevated ESR  CRP and positive blood cultures for Staphylococcus aureus. A subsequent echocardiogram showed evidence of vegetation on the mitral valve  thus leading us to a diagnosis of Native-valve Endocarditis.  Upon enquiry  Mr. Smith remembered having a dental extraction about 2-3 weeks ago and he did not take any antibiotics prophylaxis prior to the procedure. This is likely to be the underlying cause of his condition  as it placed him at a risk for bacteremia and seeding of the bacteria onto the cardiac valves  leading to endocarditis.  Mr. Smith's case is a good reminder of the importance of prophylactic antibiotic usage prior to certain procedures  particularly in patients with pre-existing cardiac conditions. Going forward  he will be started on an appropriate regimen of antibiotics  and may require surgical intervention if there is no improvement with medical treatment or if there are complications such as heart failure  uncontrolled infection or embolic events.

Mr. Johnson is a 58-year-old Caucasian male who has presented with a 2-week history of intermittent fever  fatigue  and a new onset heart murmur. He works as a farmer and lives a relatively healthy lifestyle  consuming a balanced diet and engaging in regular physical exercise. There are no reported recreational drug use  history of intravenous drug use  or recent dental procedures. He is married and has two adult children. He neither smokes cigarettes nor drinks alcohol.  Looking into his past medical history  we see that Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 10 years ago and is successfully managing it with Metformin and changes in his diet and exercise routine. He also suffered a myocardial infarction (MI) 5 years ago for which he took dual antiplatelet therapy (Aspirin and Clopidogrel) along with Statin. He stopped his antiplatelet treatment 4 years ago.  His diabetes is well controlled  and he has not experienced any diabetic complications such as neuropathy  retinopathy  or nephropathy. His cholesterol profile has been within normal limits after the myocardial infarction and he leads an active life.   In the family history  his father had coronary artery disease and his mother had hypertension; both deceased. His older brother has a history of gout. There are no known genetic disorders or any other disease running in the family.   Given his recent constitutional symptoms  the presence of fever  heart murmur and his high-risk occupation as a farmer  a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis (IE) is suspected. This will be confirmed with blood cultures  and if positive  he will need a transesophageal echo for further analysis and complete assessment of the situation. A treatment plan based on the results of these investigations will be put in place that may include antibiotics as per the isolated organism from the blood culture and sensitivity test. The prognosis of native valve IE will depend on timely and accurate diagnosis and strict adherence to the recommended treatment regimen.

Title: Case Report: A Presentation on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  I will be presenting a case of a male patient  Mr. Abram Thompson  aged 65  diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis (IE). Mr. Thompson hails from a suburban community in Louisville  Kentucky. He is a former marine engineer and retired five years ago. His ethnicity is Caucasian and majorly practices a sedentary lifestyle.  Mr. Thompson has a significant previous medical history which influences his current condition. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus and mild hypertension approximately ten years ago. His compliance with medications for these conditions has been inconsistent. He was a smoker for about 40 years  averaging 20 cigarettes per day  but quit five years ago on physician's advice. He is not a chronic alcohol drinker but enjoys the occasional glass of whiskey. He also has a history of dental cavities and had three teeth extracted approximately three months ago due to severe dental caries.  About three weeks back  Mr. Thompson started to feel unwell. His symptoms began as nonspecific low-grade fever  fatigue  loss of appetite  and weight loss. He also reported nights of excessive sweating and chills. Over the past few days  he developed new murmur and shortness of breath. On physical examination  splenomegaly was noticed and Osler's nodes were palpable on examination of his fingers and toes.  Based on his medical history  there is a high suspicion of infective endocarditis. He has risk factors such as a history of type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and previous dental procedures  potentially contributing to his current condition. His sedentary lifestyle could have also predisposed him to these conditions. To confirm the diagnosis and delineate the right treatment plan  further diagnostic tests including blood culture and echocardiography have been planned.  Prognosis of native-valve infective endocarditis is generally fair with the right treatment but can be complicated given Mr. Thompson's age and his clinical history of poor health condition compliance. Compliance to medications and lifestyle modifications will be key to his treatment success.   In conclusion  this case highlights the importance of managing underlying medical conditions and lifestyle factors contributing to the development of infective endocarditis. Furthermore  this also underscores the need for prompt recognition and timely intervention in such cases.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Jones is a 67-year-old Caucasian male presenting with a 3-week history of ongoing fever  malaise  night sweats  and unexplained weight loss. His symptoms appear to have progressively worsened over this period  despite a course of broad-spectrum antibiotics prescribed by his primary care physician.  Past Medical History:   Significant for a history of intravenous drug use in his twenties  which he has since discontinued. However  he has been diagnosed with Hepatitis C from his prior substance use. He also has a known history of mild aortic valve regurgitation  characterized by occasional dyspnea on exertion  noted on routine echocardiogram 4 years ago but has been stable with no significant progression.  Surgical History:   None noted  Family History:   Father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 59  mother has Type 2 diabetes.  Social History:   He is retired  lives with his wife  and quit smoking and drinking alcohol 10 years ago.  Review of Systems: All other systems were reviewed and negative.  Physical Examination:   Vital signs reveal a fever of 38.8C  heart rate is 102 bpm  blood pressure 130/80 mmHg  and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On cardiac examination  a new grade 3/6 pansystolic murmur is heard at the left sternal edge. Spleen is palpable with tenderness. There are no Roth spots  Osler nodes  Janeway lesions  or splinter hemorrhages noted. Hepatitis C complications seem stable.  Upon initial impression  coupled with his symptoms  history of Hepatitis C from intravenous drug use  and known aortic valve regurgitation  infective endocarditis needs to be considered as a strong differential diagnosis. Referral for a transthoracic echocardiogram and blood cultures for further management and treatment plan will be necessary.

Demographics: Mr. John Doe  a 45-year-old Caucasian male  presented himself to the hospital. He is employed as a construction worker and has been socially active with a history of IV drug use but has been clean for the last six years. He is a smoker and drinks alcohol socially. He doesn't have any known allergies.  Chief Complaint: Mr. Doe reports experiencing persistent fever  fatigue  and weight loss over the last three weeks. He's also been complaining of night sweats  generalized body aches  and intermittent episodes of shortness of breath on exertion.  Past Medical History: He has a history of mitral valve prolapse that was diagnosed 3 years ago but has not been actively managed. He also had a brief episode of pneumonia 5 years ago which was resolved with antibiotics. He has not had any other major health issues such as heart attacks  strokes  diabetes  or cancer. His vaccination status is up-to-date.  Drug History: He is not on any regular medication except for an occasional over-the-counter pain reliever for his chronic back pain. He denies any other medication or use of traditional medicines/herbs.  Family History: His mother suffered from rheumatic heart disease and his father passed away due to colon cancer. One of his brothers has hypertension but no other family members have cardiac problems.  Review of Systems: Upon review of systems  He reports no nausea  vomiting  diarrhea  urinary symptoms  rash  or recent travel. He also denies any chest pain  palpitations  syncope  altered sensorium  seizures  or focal neurological deficits. He admits to poor oral hygiene.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient appeared ill and had low-grade fever. The cardiovascular examination revealed a systolic murmur in the mitral area. Oral examination showed poor dental hygiene. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Based on the above information  a provisional diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis was made. Blood cultures  an echocardiogram  and other necessary investigations are scheduled to confirm the diagnosis.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male patient  Mr. Johnson  presents to the clinic with complaints of persistent fever of approximately 101.5 °F  malaise  fatigue  and weight loss for the past 6 weeks. He also notices a new onset of a heart murmur. He recently had an experience of night sweats and complains of mild  intermittent headaches. He denies any recent travel or illicit drug use.  Mr. Johnson's past medical history is significant for rheumatic fever as a child and a recent dental procedure. He has been on prescription medication for hypertension for the past 10 years. He has no known drug allergies. He is a non-smoker  drinks alcohol occasionally  and lives with his wife. His family history is non-contributory to his current condition.  On physical examination  you notice mild pallor  mild dehydration  and low grade fever. His vitals include a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  heart rate of 85 beats/minute  respiratory rate of 17 breaths/minute  and oxygen saturation of 97% on the room air. Cardiac auscultation reveals the presence of a new systolic murmur. You also observe petechial rash on his extremities and Roth spots on fundus examination.  Laboratory tests were ordered and blood cultures indentified Staphylococcus aureus  giving a pivotal clue towards infective endocarditis. An echocardiogram was arranged  which confirmed vegetation on the mitral valve indicative of native-valve infective endocarditis. His condition appears more serious due to his long duration of fever and the presence of systemic involvement.

Patient Presentation:  A 60-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of persisting high-grade fever for the past three weeks  associated with chills and night sweats. The patient also mentions experiencing fatigue  appetite loss  and unintentional weight loss of about 10 pounds over the same period. He denies any chest pain or shortness of breath but mentions noticing occasional blood in his urine. These symptoms were initially mild  and he attributed them to a common cold  but their persistence led him to seek medical attention.  Upon further questioning  the patient reveals a history of injection drug use  but he quit around ten years ago. He also mentions he was diagnosed with Hepatitis C from his drug usage era but has been in a stable condition with no significant flare-ups in the past few years. He does not have any history of heart disease  diabetes  or hypertension. He has never undergone any surgical procedures in his life  including dental procedures over the past several months.   On physical examination  the patient appears ill and is febrile. Cardiac auscultation reveals a new regurgitant murmur. He is tachycardic with a heart rate of 105 bpm  blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg  and respirations are 18 per minute. On skin examination  Janeway lesions and Osler’s nodes are noted. Rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.   Given the patient's history of intravenous drug use  presence of a new heart murmur  fever of unknown origin  and findings of vascular and immunologic phenomena  a suspicion for infective endocarditis is raised.   The above clinical scenario represents a complete demographic detail with relevant past medical history for a patient possibly suffering from native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 55-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of fever  chills  night sweats  unintended weight loss  and fatigue. Patient also notes a new heart murmur that he did not notice before along with mild shortness of breath. The condition has been gradually getting worse  which led him to seek medical help. The patient has a history of intravenous drug use  specifically heroin  which he last used two weeks ago. His medical history is also significant for Hepatitis C  which is currently being treated. Patient is a smoker with a pack per day for almost 30 years. He drinks alcohol occasionally and denies any allergic history. He lives alone and is currently unemployed. He has never been married and has no family for support. The patient is visibly skinny and looks malnourished. On the social front  the patient remained homeless multiple times in the past. His vitals show a mild fever and heart rate is slightly elevated.

Patient Presentation:  A 54-year-old male presents to the emergency department complaining of high-grade fevers  rigors  and malaise for two weeks. He mentions an associated weight loss of about 10 pounds during this period  which has been unintentional. He also complains of night sweats. Patient denies any cough  chest pain  or difficulty in breathing. Past medical history is positive for hepatitis C (he used intravenous drugs in the past but has been clean for several years)  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes.  Physical Examination:  The patient appears fatigued. Vitals show temperature of 38.8 degrees Celsius  blood pressure of 140/90  HR-96bpm  and RR-18/min. Cardiovascular exam shows a grade 2/6 systolic murmur which was not there  according to the patient  in his last physical check-up. The skin has multiple non-tender erythematous nodules which the patient identifies as new developments  mostly over his lower limbs. Oropharyngeal examination reveals some tiny  painless red spots on the palate. No jugular venous distention  clubbing  or peripheral edema is observed.  Assessment:   Given the history of IVD drug use  new murmur  multiple skin lesions and fever  the suspicion index is high for native-valve infective endocarditis. The patient needs to be admitted  blood cultures ordered  and empirical antibiotic therapy initiated till culture reports come in. Echocardiogram needs to be done for additional confirmation. It will also help in evaluating the extent of valve damage. Further management will be guided by specific clinical and laboratory findings.

A 58-year-old male presented to the emergency department with a high fever  chills  generalized fatigue over the course of 2 weeks  night sweats  unintentional weight loss (15lbs over the past month)  shortness of breath on exertion and a new-onset palpitations. He also reported of having an intermittent headache and blurry vision.   He is a chronic smoker  has a 7 year history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus  and consumes alcohol moderately. He also had been treated for dental abscess a month ago that involved minor oral surgery.  On physical examination  he is found to be febrile (103° F) and tachycardic (HR: 120 bpm). He also exhibits pallor  digital clubbing  and slight peripheral cyanosis. On auscultation  a new grade 2/6 systolic murmur along the left sternal border can be heard. Ophthalmologic examination reveals the presence of Roth spots.  He denies any illicit drug use or unprotected sexual activities. He is living with his wife and works as a civil engineer. He is not taking any chronic medications apart from the Metformin taken for his diabetes.   These findings  including the patient's recent dental treatment  fever  and the new heart murmur  contribute to high suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation: Ms. Patterson is a 68-year-old Caucasian woman who was admitted to the emergency department. The patient reported experiencing intermittent fever over the last three to four weeks accompanied with weight loss  fatigue  and night sweats. She also complained of dyspnea during minor physical exertions such as walking short distances  which was not present before the onset of fever. Similarly  she reported new-onset lower back pain which had started one-week prior.  Past Medical History: Ms. Patterson is a long-term smoker who was diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) eight years ago. She is also hypertensive and has been on anti-hypertensive treatment for the past ten years. She is not diabetic  nor does she have a history of heart disease. However  she was diagnosed with a tooth infection three months ago and had undergone tooth extraction. There is no history of intravenous drug use  recent travels or contact with sick individuals. Ms. Patterson lives alone and is retired.  Given Ms. Patterson's signs  symptoms and recent dental work  the physician suspects infective endocarditis  a serious infection of the endocardial surface of the heart  with particular emphasis on her native heart valves. Further appropriate examinations and investigations are ordered to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  A 58-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with complaints of constant high-grade fever  shortness of breath  and fatigue for the past two weeks. His fever is associated with night sweats and has been unresponsive to over-the-counter antipyretic medications. He also mentions intermittent episodes of heart palpitations. He denies any recent travel  sick contacts  or use of recreational drugs.  Demographics: The patient lives in an urban setting  is a construction worker  and has a 20-pack-year smoking history. He drinks alcohol occasionally but denies any illicit drug use. He has no family history of cardiovascular disease.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of moderate rheumatic heart disease since his early teens and has been non-compliant with prophylactic penicillin therapy for the past five years.   He had a dental procedure carried out about four weeks ago and admits that he did not take any prophylactic antibiotics before the procedure. He denies any allergy to medications.  Other significant medical history includes sub-optimal controlled type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and high cholesterol levels. He is currently on oral hypoglycemic agents  ACE inhibitor  and statin.  On physical examination:  He appears ill  with diaphoresis. He is febrile  with a temperature of 102°F  heart rate of 110 BPM  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg  and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. He has a II/VI systolic ejection murmur heard best at the apex  multiple petechiae over the anterior trunk  and tender erythematous nodules on fingers and toes suggestive of Osler's nodes.  Based on this presentation  the possible diagnosis is native-valve infective endocarditis  likely secondary to poor dental hygiene and history of untreated rheumatic heart disease.

Patient Presentation:  A 55-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with complaints of ongoing fatigue  fever  night sweats  and a recent weight loss of approximately 15-pound in the last 2 months. He reports having intermittent  low-grade fever over the past three weeks which have recently been increasing in both frequency and intensity.   He has a history of intravenous drug use  but reports being clean for the last 5 years. His past medical history includes Hepatitis C infection and recurrent cellulitis secondary to his prior drug use.   Further questioning reveals that the patient has been experiencing shortness of breath on exertion  mild chest discomfort and has noticed visually perceivable red spots on his palms and soles for the past few days.
