The patient lives alone in a shelter and has no known allergies. He has been incarcerated in past but is currently unemployed. His family history is non-contributory. He does not smoke  and states minimal alcohol consumption. He also denies any recent dental procedures  travel history  or contact with sick individuals.

Patient Profile:   A 60-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department.  History of Present Illness:  The patient complains of a four-week history of persistent  low-grade fever  sporadic chills  night sweats  malaise  and unintentional weight loss of about 10 pounds. Two weeks ago  he observed skin lesions resembling red spots on his palms and soles  and occasional small red lines under the nails. Concurrently  he started noticing increased breathlessness on exertion  previously unreported.  Past Medical History:  Significant for a history of intravenous drug use until 15 years ago and uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years. The patient underwent dental procedures around six weeks ago.  Social History:   The patient lives alone with a history of alcohol consumption of about 20 units per week and has been a non-smoker for 20 years now. He denies any recent travel or close infectious contacts.  Family Medical History:   His father had coronary artery disease and his mother had type 2 diabetes.  Review of Systems:  The review of systems is notable for intermittent complaints of joint pain. Other systems were unremarkable.  Vital Signs:  Tachycardia with a heart rate around 110 bpm  blood pressure stable at 130/85mmHg  low-grade fever with a temperature of 38°C  respirations 22 per minute  and SpO2 95% on room air.  Physical Examination:   There are non-tender petechiae on the palms and soles  and linear  red streaks (splinter hemorrhages) under a few nail beds are as observed. Cardiac examination reveals a soft S1  a physiologically split S2  and a grade III/VI diastolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. Lung sounds are clear bilaterally.  Preliminary Diagnosis:  The aforementioned history and examination findings are suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis  likely secondary to his history of intravenous drug use and recent dental procedure. Further confirmation with labs is required.

Patient Presentation  A 58-year-old Caucasian male patient arrives in the Emergency Department reporting a 2-week history of intermittent fever  tiredness  general malaise  weakness  and loss of appetite. The patient seems chronically ill and in discomfort. He experiences waves of unexplained chills and night sweats. He also mentions a recent unintentional weight loss of 15lbs in the last month. There are no complaints about chest pain  cough  or headache.  Demographics and Social History  The patient is a carpenter by trade  lives with his wife and is a non-smoker with occasional alcohol consumption. He doesn't have any travel history recently  nor has he had any contact with sick individuals. He has a two-year administration of penicillin due to his recurrent streptococcal tonsillitis.   Past Medical History  His relevant past medical history includes mitral valve prolapse diagnosed 20 years ago  followed up by annual echocardiograms with stable condition. He is not on any daily medications and has not had any recent hospitalizations or surgical procedures.  On physical examination  his temperature is 38.2 °C  heart rate is 88 beats/min  respiratory rate is 18 breaths/min and blood pressure is 130/80mmHg. He presents with Janeway lesions on the palms of his hands and soles of his feet  and there is an audible murmur noticed on auscultation.   His clinical and medical history along with his presenting symptoms suggest the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis. Further diagnostics including blood cultures and an echocardiogram are ordered to confirm the diagnosis. His mitral valve prolapse puts him at increased risk of endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  A 55-year-old Caucasian male presents to the hospital. He complains of low-grade fever  night sweats  fatigue  and weight loss that have been ongoing for the last 2 months. He also reports experiencing intermittent chest discomfort  shortness of breath with exertion  and occasional palpitations. Patient admits that he does not engage in regular health checkups and has not seen a doctor in more than 10 years.   The patient's past medical history is generally unremarkable except for a history of poor dental hygiene with multiple dental procedures over the years. He has no known allergies  does not smoke  drink alcohol  or use illicit substances. However  he admits difficulty in managing a balanced diet and has led a fairly sedentary lifestyle.   Physical examination reveals pallor  mild tachypnea  a systolic murmur best heard in apex radiating to axilla  and a few petechial lesions on his lower extremities. An initial diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis is made and further investigations are ordered. His family history reveals a cousin who had rheumatic heart disease but no other significant familial health issues. His social history includes working as a bookstore manager and living alone in an urban apartment.

Patient Information: A 60-year-old Caucasian male presents in the emergency department.  Chief Complaint: High-grade fever  malaise  fatigue  and a new heart murmur.  History of Present Illness: The patient has been feeling unwell for the past three weeks  with symptoms such as high-grade fever that intermittently spikes up to 103°F  malaise  fatigue  and night sweats. He also mentions feeling some discomfort in his chest but denies any shortness of breath. Over the past week  he experienced periods of confusion and one episode of a transient  vision loss in his right eye. He does not have any known food or drug allergies.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of intravenous drug use during his early life but has been clean for the past 15 years. He adds that he has not had any surgeries or hospitalizations recently. The patient also had a mitral valve prolapse diagnosed five years ago.   Review of Systems: The patient has no significant findings or complaints related to any of the other body systems.   Family History: His father died of heart disease at age 65 and his mother has diabetes.  Physical Examination: Patient appears fatigued. Vital signs reveal a fever of 103°F  heart rate of 100 bpm  blood pressure 130/80 mmHg  respiratory rate 18 per minute  and oxygen saturation 95% on room air. Cardiovascular examination is significant for a new pansystolic murmur at the apex radiating toward the axilla. There is no evidence of peripheral stigmata of endocarditis.   Initial Suspected Diagnosis: Given his previous history of mitral valve prolapse  new heart murmur  persistent high-grade fever  and systemic symptoms  a preliminary diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis is suspected.   Plan: Blood cultures  Complete Blood Count  ESR  CRP  and a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) are ordered. Pending the results  empiric antibiotic treatment started with intravenous vancomycin and gentamicin.

Patient Presentation:   A 65-year-old Hispanic male presented to the emergency department with complaints of an intermittent high-grade fever of around 101°F for the past 2 weeks  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss of approximately 8 pounds over the past month. The patient also reported experiencing night sweats and a change in his appetite. He denied any recent travels or sick contacts. At presentation  he was shivering  looked ill and fatigued. He was found to have a new murmur on cardiovascular examination (a blowing diastolic murmur heard over the left second intercostal space suggestive of aortic regurgitation).   Demographics:   The patient lives on a farm on the outskirts of the city. He lives with his wife and has no children.  He quit smoking 10 years ago and denies any alcohol or illicit drug use. He keeps cattle and poultry on his farm and does all the associated chores himself.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of rheumatic fever in childhood. He has been treated for a recurrent skin infection – staphylococcal folliculitis – multiple times over the past 6 months. Additionally  he also reports history of chronic hepatitis B infection  which was diagnosed 5 years ago  which he has been managing with doctor-prescribed antivirals. He has no known allergies and hasn’t undergone any dental procedures or surgeries recently. He reports myalgia and joint pains occasionally for which he takes over-the-counter NSAIDs. There is no family history of any significant illnesses. His vaccinations are up-to-date  and he is not on any regular medications.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male  named John  presents to the clinic complaining of several weeks of intermittent fever  night sweats  weight loss about 8 pounds over the last month  weakness  and fatigue. He also mentioned about experiencing an unusual sensation in his left leg recently that feels like numbness and burning.  John has a past medical history significant for moderate rheumatoid arthritis for which he takes a daily dose of methotrexate  and mild aortic stenosis which was detected through a routine check-up two years ago but has been asymptomatic so far and hence not intervened. He has no history of intravenous drug use  implanted medical devices  or recent dental procedures. He is a non-smoker  drinks alcohol socially  and has an unremarkable family history. He has been married 40 years and neither he nor his wife report sexual promiscuity or intravenous drug use.  On physical examination  his temperature is 38.5 degree Celsius and has a new harsh systolic murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border. Conjunctival pallor is noted  there is no clubbing  but there are small  painless erythematous lesions on the pads of his fingers (Osler's nodes) and similar lesions present beneath his toenails (splinter hemorrhages). Though he appears slightly uncomfortable  he is alert and oriented.  Relevant investigations are being planned including blood culture and echocardiogram in suspicion for infective endocarditis. He is recommended to get admitted for further evaluation and management. Recognition of his risk factors (presence of aortic stenosis and immunosuppressive therapy for rheumatoid arthritis) and clinical signs has led to this important differential diagnosis. His prognosis would largely depend on prompt diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic and possible surgical management.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Naomi  a 64-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the emergency department with a chief complaint of fever  fatigue  and exertional shortness of breath for the last 2 weeks. She also reported a sudden loss of appetite and an unintentional weight loss of about 3 kg over the same period. Additionally  she mentioned a new onset of nocturnal sweating and a low-grade fever persisting for more than 10 days.  She lives alone and is independent in her daily activities. She has a 20-year history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes  for which she takes Metformin twice daily; however  her compliance is poor. She also has a 5-year history of rheumatoid arthritis treated with Methotrexate.  Significant past medical history includes a heart murmur identified in her late teens but never resulted in any clinical disease or intervention. She had a dental extraction performed about 1 month ago.  Family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases  both her father died from a heart attack and her mother had a stroke. She is a 40-pack-year smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally.   The patient has no known drug allergies. Her immunizations are up-to-date  with a recent influenza vaccine administration in the last flu season.  She denied any history of IV drug use or recent travel.  On examination  the patient appeared fatigued and in mild distress. Her vitals were: temperature of 38.3 degrees Celsius  heart rate 110/min  BP 130/85mmHg  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 95% on room air.   Cardiac examination revealed a diastolic murmur best heard in the aortic region. Other findings include splenomegaly on abdominal examination and a few petechiae on her lower limbs.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith  a 60-year-old Caucasian male  comes into the office presenting with a fever of 101°F  night sweats  and malaise that he says have persisted over the last two weeks. He has lost a noticeable amount of weight  but he could not specify how much exactly. Mr. Smith also reports experiencing a heart murmur  which is unusual for him. He has a point of maximum impulse (PMI) displaced to the left and down  and signs of small-vessel disease end-organ involvement  including Roth spots  Janeway lesions  and Osler nodes.   Relevant Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a medical history significant for mitral valve prolapse  diagnosed 10 years ago. As per his medication history includes long term utilization of omeprazole for GERD and a brief history of intravenous drug use during his twenties. He has not had any surgeries  and he denies smoking  alcohol  or recreational drug use for the past 30 years. His father died with coronary artery disease and his mother has diabetes.   This presentation combined with his medical history indicates a high suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis. Further diagnostic measures  including blood cultures and echocardiogram  are recommended to confirm this.

Patient Presentation:  A 67-year-old Caucasian male  retired butcher  presents to the clinic with complaints of persistently evolving fatigue  mild weight loss  and a low-grade fever for the past three weeks. He mentions experiencing night sweats and a loss of appetite. The patient also complains of new-onset mild dyspnea on exertion and occasional night coughs. He denies chest pain  nausea  vomiting  and diarrhea but admits to occasional joint pain.  Past medical history reveals that the patient was diagnosed with type II diabetes and high blood pressure about six years ago  but has been compliant with prescribed antihypertensive and hypoglycemic medications. He has no history of IV drug use  recent dental procedures  or recent travel. No prior surgeries. His father died of a stroke at an older age and his mother had breast cancer. He quit smoking 15 years ago; prior to that  he smoked a pack of cigarettes per day for over 35 years.  On examination  a new 2/6 systolic ejection murmur is appreciated at the left lower sternal border. Blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg with a pulse rate of 92 beats per minute. His temperature is 100.4°F. Multiple small  non-tender petechial lesions are observed in the conjunctiva and on his palms.   Given his new onset murmurs  persistent fever  and other systemic signs and symptoms  a differential diagnosis of infective endocarditis is considered. Further diagnostic procedures  including blood cultures and echocardiogram  are planned to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  A 60-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with a two-week history of intermittent high-grade fevers  myalgia  fatigue  night sweats and unexplained weight loss. The patient also reported a new-onset heart murmur decreasing his quality of life due to exertional dyspnea and cough.  The patient's past medical history is significant for Stage III Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)  for which he has been receiving treatment for the past 3 years. He also has a 20-year history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus  treated with oral antidiabetic agents. The patient revealed that he was a heavy smoker for over 30 years but quit five years ago. He admits to consuming alcohol on occasional social events.   Regarding his family history  the patient disclosed that his father had cardiovascular disease and his mother had type 2 diabetes.   On a physical examination  he exhibited signs of clubbing in his fingers  a newly appreciated murmur was detected on his cardiac examination  suggestive of mitral regurgitation.   Given the patient's history  clinical presentation and physical findings  a suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis was raised. The patient was recommended for further diagnostic procedures including blood cultures and echocardiography.

Patient Presentation:  A 62-year-old Caucasian female presents to the Emergency Department with a two-week history of intermittent fevers  chills  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss of approximately 10 pounds. She also reports experiencing shortness of breath especially upon exertion and occasional lightheadedness.  Demographic Details:  The patient is a retired school teacher. She is a non-smoker and rarely drinks alcohol. She does not use illicit drugs. She is married and lives with her husband in a suburban community.  Past Medical History:  She had a diagnosis of rheumatic heart disease as a child and takes warfarin for chronic atrial fibrillation. She reports compliance with her medication and attends regular follow-ups with her general practitioner and cardiologist. She had her last dental cleaning approximately one month ago. She has no known drug allergies and no family history of cardiac disease.  Physical Examination:  On examination  she is febrile (100.8°F or 38.2°C) and her blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. She exhibits mild pallor. Cardiac auscultation reveals a diastolic murmur best heard at the apex. There is no peripheral edema and the rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  The patient's history of rheumatic heart disease from childhood and a recent dental cleaning along with the presence of intermittent fevers  chills  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss raise a concern for native-valve infective endocarditis. An urgent referral to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management is made.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. X is a 69-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the clinic with a two week history of low-grade fever  fatigue  night sweats and unintentional weight loss of approximately 10 pounds.   The patient's past medical history is significant for mild hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2 and a history of smoking for 40 years  which he quit ten years ago. He also mentions having had a dental procedure conducted about a month ago. He denies any history of travel  recent hospitalizations  immunizations or drug abuse  including intravenous drugs. His family history is non-contributory.  On physical examination  he appears moderately ill  has a fever of 38.5°C  a pulse of 90 beats per minute  and blood pressure of 130/85 mm Hg. Cardiac auscultation reveals a new murmur in the mitral area consistent with mitral regurgitation. Fundoscopy reveals Roth spots and skin inspection notes Janeway lesions.  This presentation is suggestive for infective endocarditis  with likely involvement of the native valve. Conexion with the recent dental procedure  which might have resulted in bacteremia  should be considered but further diagnostic tests such as blood cultures and echocardiogram need to be performed.  Given his significant risk factors (age  male sex  diabetes  and a history of smoking)  he is at high risk of infective endocarditis. Further diagnostics and management will be necessary.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Smith is a 63-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the emergency department with persistent fever  chills  malaise  and increasing shortness of breath over the last two weeks. He denies any recent travel or sick contacts. He has lost about 5 kgs in the past month  due to loss of appetite and night sweats.  He has a past medical history of moderate-severity mitral valve regurgitation  diagnosed 10 years ago  and is currently managed conservatively with regular follow-ups. Other significant past medical history includes hypertension controlled with ACE inhibitors  and a 40-pack-year history of smoking  recently quit two years ago. He has no known allergies and takes only medication for hypertension and multivitamins.  He demonstrates signs of potential cardiac failure on physical examination  including bilateral ankle edema and pulmonary rales. Cardiac auscultation reveals a new murmur suggestive of mitral valve involvement. Initial vitals reveal tachycardia with a heart rate of 120 bpm  blood pressure of 110/70 mmHg  SpO2 of 92% on room air  and fever of 38.4°C.  Investigations are underway  including blood cultures  full blood count  liver function tests  coagulation profile  and chest X-ray. Echocardiography has been requested to assess valve involvement. Given his presentation and significant history of valve disease  the clinical suspicion for infective endocarditis is high  and the patient is admitted to the hospital for further monitoring and management.

Patient Presentation:  A 60-year-old male patient presented to the emergency room complaining of persistent high-grade fever  fatigue  shortness of breath  night sweats  and weight loss over the last two weeks. The patient had recently experienced a fluctuating fever reaching up to 102°F. He reported no chest pain  cough  gastrointestinal symptoms  or recent travels.  Demographics: The patient is a resident of New York City. He is a retired teacher and lives with his wife  with regular visits from their grandchildren. The patient has a history of smoking  with a pack a day for 40 years but quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use. There is no known history of similar illness in his family.  Medical History: The patient has a known medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  controlled with anti-hypertensive drugs and insulin. He also has a history of rheumatic fever as a child but no previous hospitalizations for heart diseases. The patient is not aware of any allergies. His last dental procedure was a root canal treatment 1 month ago.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient appeared ill and was diaphoretic. His blood pressure recorded at 120/80 mmHg  heart rate was 102 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 20 breaths per minute  and body temperature was 101°F. Cardiac examination found a pansystolic murmur at cardiac apex radiating to left axilla. Few petechiae were seen on the patient's upper body and lower legs. Other system examinations did not show any significant findings.  Investigations: Initial labs showed high white cell count  raised ESR  and CRP. Blood cultures were positive. ECG showed normal sinus rhythm. Chest x-ray was normal. Echocardiogram suggested vegetations on the mitral valve suggesting the diagnosis of native valve endocarditis.   The patient was started immediately on empirical antibiotic treatment in conjunction with a cardiology consult.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male  John  presents to the emergency department with complaints of persistent fever over the past two weeks  fatigue  and unexplained weight loss. He also mentions experiencing night sweats and a new onset of lower back pain. An avid smoker with a 40-pack year smoking history  John also reveals an undisclosed history of IV drug use about 30 years ago.  John was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 10 years ago  which has been poorly controlled with oral hypoglycemics due to his irregular medication compliance. He also suffers from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to his long-term tobacco use  and he is currently on inhaled corticosteroids and bronchodilators. There is also a significant history of dental problems  with his most recent visit to the dentist being over a year ago for treatment of an abscessed tooth.   John's family history is significant for myocardial infarctions in both his father and older brother in their 40s  and his mother has heart failure. Physical examination reveals an unkempt gentleman in apparent distress. Upon cardiovascular examination  a new murmur could be heard over the mitral area. Examination also reveals the presence of Osler's nodes on his fingers and toes and Janeway lesions on his palms and soles. Upon interviewing  the patient admits to not having been immunized against common preventable diseases.  The constellation of the new murmur  persistent fever  potential septicemia from untreated dental infection  and past IV drug use raises the suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the emergency department complaining of three weeks of persistent  generalized fatigue and high-grade fevers accompanied by night sweats. The patient also reported having a new-onset  intermittent heart murmur that he had noticed himself. He also had unintentional weight loss of about 5kgs over the past month. He denied any chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  nausea  vomiting  abdominal pain  joint pains  or skin rashes.  On further enquiry  he mentioned a recent dental procedure that he had about 4 weeks ago for which he was not pre-medicated with antibiotics. He has a 10-year history of intravenous drug use but has been abstinent for the last five years. He also has a history of heavy cigarette smoking (approx. 1 pack/day for the past 25 years) but doesn't use alcohol.  His past medical history was significant for chronic hepatitis C infection  for which he completed treatment five years ago  and hypertension  which was well-controlled under medication. His family history was non-contributory.   On physical examination  he appeared ill  was febrile (temperature of 38.7°C)  with tachycardia (pulse rate of 110 beats per minute)  and had a diastolic murmur heard best at the mitral area. Other systemic examinations were unremarkable.  These symptoms are consistent with classic signs of infective endocarditis  likely caused by the recent dental procedure and previous IV drug use.

Patient Information:   A 60-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic complaining of a 2-week history of malaise and fatigue accompanied by intermittent low-grade fever  night sweats  shortness of breath  and a weight loss of approximately 6 pounds.  Medical History:  The patient has a known history of intravenous drug use 15 years ago but has been clean for the last ten years. He has been diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes  which are managed with a diet and Metformin. There is a positive history of rheumatic fever during his childhood. He is a smoker with a 30-pack year history but denies alcohol or any other substance use. There is no known history of recent dental or surgical procedures. His family history is remarkable for a brother with coronary artery disease and mother with colon cancer.  Clinical Presentation:  Examination shows a temperature of 39°C. A cardiovascular examination reveals conjunctival petechiae and Janeway lesions on the heels of his feet. There is an early diastolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border suggestive of aortic regurgitation. A splinter hemorrhage is noted under the nail of his right index finger but there is no Osler's node.  Analysis:  Taken together  the potential drug use in the history  presence of constitutional signs (fever  weight loss)  new cardiac murmur (aortic regurgitation)  and presence of vascular and immunologic phenomena (Janeway lesions  petechiae  splinter hemorrhages) make a clinical scenario compatible with infective endocarditis. Further diagnostic tests and consultation with cardiology and infectious diseases specialists are warranted.

Patient Presentation:  A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of intermittent fever  malaise  and unexplained weight loss. Patient reports his highest recorded fever was 39.5°C. He also has been experiencing episodes of night sweats and has noticed increasing fatigue which has culminated in being unable to perform his usual activities. He denies any cough  chest pain  or recent travel.  Past Medical History:  Patient has a known history of bicuspid aortic valve  which was discovered incidentally during a routine checkup 5 years ago. There is no history of previous cardiac surgery  intravenous drug use  or blood transfusions. He is also diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus which is managed by oral hypoglycemic agents.   Social History:  Patient is a retired teacher  does not smoke or consume alcohol  and has no known drug allergies. He has not been in close contact with anyone ill recently. He lives with his wife in their own house.   Family History:  There is a history of cardiovascular disease in his family. His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 70 and his older brother has hypertension.

Patient Information:   A 60-year-old Caucasian male  named Mr. Williams  presented with complaints of fever  malaise  and shortness of breath that had been progressively worsening over the past month. He also mentioned a new-onset  non-radiating lower back pain.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Williams is a known case of rheumatic heart disease and had undergone mitral valve repair 10 years back. Mr. Williams has a 30-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus that is well controlled on oral hypoglycemic agents. He was previously diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he's under medication. He had a Myers-Briggs Weight Loss surgery four years ago due to his morbid obesity. Mr. Williams used to be a heavy smoker (2 packs/day for 25 years) but quit 10 years ago. He doesn't drink alcohol or use any illicit drugs.   Review of Systems:   General: Weight loss  malaise Cardiovascular: New-onset shortness of breath  chest discomfort Musculoskeletal: Lower back pain Neurologic: No alterations in consciousness or focal neurological deficits. No reported changes in urination  bowel habits  skin  or abnormalities in other systems on review of systems.   Family History:   His mother died of a myocardial infarction in her 60s and his father died of complications from Alzheimer's disease. He has two healthy siblings without any significant health issues.   Given his history and clinical picture  the suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis was raised and he was further investigated with appropriate tests.

A 55-year-old male patient  John  of Caucasian ethnicity  presents to the hospital with a one-week history of unusual fatigue  loss of appetite  night sweats  unexplained weight loss  small red or purple spots on the skin  and swells in his feet  legs  or abdomen.   He uses tobacco  single  works as a construction worker  and denies any alcohol or recreational drug use. John has a history of congenital heart defect which was repaired when he was a teenager. His past medical history includes a recent diagnosis of diabetes type 2 and regularly takes Metformin to manage his blood sugar. He also has a history of dental procedure he underwent a month ago and didn't take any antibiotics prior to the procedure. He doesn't have any known allergies and has no previous history of surgery or hospitalization.   There are no specific environmental or occupational noxious exposures. His family medical history includes hypertension in his father and breast cancer in his mother.   Given the patient's history  physical examination  and preliminary test findings  suspected diagnosis is infective endocarditis. A referral for a comprehensive cardiac examination and multiple blood cultures is planned to confirm the diagnosis and determine the appropriate treatment course.   In addition to caring for his diabetes  John must quit smoking  keep his blood glucose level in healthy range  monitor any signs of possible infections  regularly revisit the dentist for proactive care  and may need to prophylactically take antibiotics prior to any future surgeries to minimize the risk of future episodes of infective endocarditis.

Patient Information: 56-year-old Caucasian male  Reason for Visit: Presenting with complaints of intermittent fever  generalized weakness  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss over the past 3 weeks.  History of Present Illness: The patient describes the fever as high and intermittent  occasionally associated with night sweats. He reports a loss of appetite contributing to an overall weight loss of 10 lbs in the last month. He also notes a new-onset exertional dyspnea and occasional chest discomfort for the past week.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of moderate aortic stenosis for last 5 years  for which he has been under regular cardiology follow-up. He also has a history of diabetes mellitus type 2  well controlled with oral hypoglycemic therapy. There is no known history of intravenous drug use  recent dental procedures  or prosthetic heart valves.  Past Surgical History: No significant surgical history.  Social History: He is a retired aircraft engineer  does not smoke  occasionally consumes alcohol (1-2 glasses of wine per week)  and does not report any illicit drug use.  Allergies: Allergy to penicillin develops rash   Medications: Atenolol  Metformin  and Aspirin.  Family History: Father died of myocardial infarction at age 64. Mother has hypertension and is currently 80 years old.  Vital Signs: BP 110/70 mm Hg; Pulse 92 bpm; Temperature 100.7 F; Respiratory rate 18 per minute  Oxygen saturation 96% on room air.  Physical Examination: Examination shows an ill appearing male with apparent weight loss. Cardiac examination reveals an early diastolic murmur best heard at the second right intercostal space  which was not noted in previous cardiology check-ups. There is mild leg swelling but no signs of deep vein thrombosis. Small  non-painful red spots are noted under the fingernails. No Osler's nodes  Janeway lesions  or Roth's spots are seen.  These findings should raise suspicion for possible native-valve infective endocarditis. Consideration for further testing including blood culture and transesophageal echocardiography would be necessary.

A 56-year-old male presents to the emergency department complaining of a low-grade fever that has persisted for the past 3 weeks  chills  and fatigue. He also reports a muffled heart sound that is abnormal in nature  occasional night sweats  and unexplained weight loss during this period. Past medical history is significant for intravenous drug abuse which he quit 6 years ago  hypertension and a dental procedure he had 2 months ago. He also states a recent decrease in appetite. The patient denies any chest pain  palpitations  or difficulty in breathing. His family history is remarkable for coronary artery disease in his mother. He is retired and used to work as a taxi driver. He does not smoke or consume alcohol. He lives with his wife and has 2 kids.

A 60-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with complaints of fever  fatigue  and a newly developed heart murmur during the past few weeks. He also reports unintentional weight loss  night sweats  and weakness. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or cough.   The patient has a past medical history significant for intravenous drug use twenty years ago  which he reports having quit thereafter. His lifestyle has been sedentary in recent years and he has type 2 diabetes mellitus  which is controlled with diet and metformin. He has mitral valve prolapse discovered in a routine health check a decade ago but remains asymptomatic so far. He denies any previous surgical history. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol socially. His father had coronary artery disease and died at the age of 63 due to myocardial infarction.  Physical examination reveals mild pallor and a diastolic murmur best heard at the apex. A series of blood cultures have been ordered  he appears stable with normal hemodynamics. The patient has been admitted and an urgent echocardiogram has been planned to confirm the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old male patient named Mr. Anderson came to the hospital with the chief complaint of recurrent fever for the past two weeks. He explained persistent low-grade fever with occasional spikes up to 100.4°F  associated with night sweats and loss of appetite. Upon further questioning  he reported feeling generally unwell with mild fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. He also mentioned experiencing muscle aches and a small  painless rash on the palms of both hands which he noticed a few days back.  Regarding his past medical history  it was noteworthy to mention that Mr. Anderson had been diagnosed with rheumatic heart disease back in his 30s and also had a similar episode of fever and fatigue five years back  which was diagnosed as infective endocarditis. He has been on chronic low-dose aspirin therapy for coronary artery disease. His family history was also significant for heart disease.  Upon examination  he had a heart murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. Other remarkable findings included mild splenomegaly  Roth spots in his retina  and Janeway lesions on his hands and soles.   In light of his symptoms  signs  and significant past medical history of rheumatic heart disease and previous infective endocarditis  the clinical suspicion of possible native-valve infective endocarditis was raised  and he was immediately sent for further investigations.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male is brought into the ED by his wife who reports a month-long history of unusual fatigue  weight loss of approximately 20 lbs.  persistent low-grade fever  and night sweats. The patient himself complains of intermittent chest discomfort but no acute chest pain. He has a history of untreated dental caries and did not visit a dentist for the past few years. There is no previous history of heart disease but he does have an established diagnosis of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hyperlipidemia  for which he is on oral anti-diabetic drugs and statins  respectively. He denies any illicit drug use and states he quit smoking 10 years ago. On initial physical examination  he appears ill and reports feeling light-headed.  Vital Signs: T=99.3°F  P=102 bpm  R=18/min  BP=140/90 mm Hg  and O2 Sat=96% on room air. HEENT: Conjunctival Pallor noted. Oral hygiene poor with visible dental caries.  Cardiovascular: A new grade 3/6 diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border. Skin: Small non-tender purple macular lesions are noted on the palms and soles.   Further labs  blood cultures  and echocardiography are appropriate to diagnose possible native valve endocarditis.

Patient Information: Ms. Smith  a 54-year-old female  was known to have a history of intravenous drug use.   Chief Complaint: She presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of ongoing fever for 1 week  accompanied by chills  fatigue  and malaise.  Present Illness: Ms. Smith was in her usual state of health until a week ago when she started experiencing flu-like symptoms  which have escalated to include a new heart murmur  night sweats  and loss of appetite. She mentioned a recent use of intravenous drugs within the past month. She has not experienced any chest pain  shortness of breath or cough.   Past Medical History: Ms. Smith’s medical history is significant for opiate addiction and Hepatitis C. She has no other known cardiovascular  respiratory  renal  or metabolic diseases. Her surgical history is unremarkable.   Social History: Ms. Smith is a current smoker with a 30-pack year history. She has a long-standing history of intravenous drug use but denies any alcohol use. She lives alone and has been between homes over the past decade.  Family History: There is a history of hypertensive heart disease in her family  including both parents.  Physical Examination: On examination  she is febrile with a temperature of 38.4°C (101.12°F)  heart rate 110 bpm  and blood pressure 110/70 mmHg. Cardiovascular examination reveals a grade III/VI systolic murmur best heard at the mitral area. There are no signs of peripheral embolization - no Osler nodes  Janeway lesions  or splinter hemorrhages.   These symptoms and findings suggest possible native-valve infective endocarditis  a condition previously observed in patients with intravenous drug use history. Blood cultures are needed to confirm the diagnosis and guide antibiotic therapy. An Echocardiogram should also be done to assess valvular damage.

Patient Presentation:  A 62-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with complaints of ongoing fever  fatigue  and intermittent night sweats for the past 2-3 weeks. Additionally  he reports unintentional weight loss and a new cardiac murmur that has recently been detected. He also mentions having noticed small  painless red spots under the skin on his palms and soles which he found unusual.  He has a past medical history significant for intravenous drug use  alcohol abuse  hepatitis C and recently  uncontrolled diabetes mellitus. He has no previous history of heart diseases.  On examination  he appears fatigued  with fever of 38.6 C  blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg  pulse rate of 90 bpm  and respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. Cardiovascular examination reveals a new 3/6 systolic murmur best heard at the apex. Skin examination showed Janeway's lesions. No Osler's nodes were found on examination of his fingers and toes. His oral hygiene was poor with evidence of dental caries. No other significant findings were reported.   He lives alone and confesses to resuming intravenous drug use 4 months ago. He does not have a regular healthcare provider and this is his first medical consultation in several years. He is currently unemployed and his last Hep C treatment was approximately five years ago.   There is an urgent need to address his present symptoms suggesting infective endocarditis and his high-risk behaviors.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith  a 62-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department with chief complaints of intermittent fevers  night sweats  unexplained weight loss  and fatigue for the last two weeks. Additionally  he also reports a new-onset shortness of breath  along with occasional chest discomfort.   Demographic Details:   Mr. Smith is a retired construction worker  currently living alone. He is a former smoker (30 pack-years) and casual alcohol consumer. He has no history of drug abuse. He has had no international travel for the past 2 years and his vaccinations are up to date.  Past Medical History:  He has a significant medical history of type 2 diabetes  controlled under Metformin and Sitagliptin  and moderate hypertension managed with Lisinopril.   It’s worth noting that Mr. Smith had a diagnosis of Rheumatic Fever as a child and subsequently showed mitral valve insufficiency  for which he has been on regular follow-ups  but has never required surgical intervention.  Family History:  His father had a history of coronary artery disease and his mother had type 2 diabetes. No other significant family history of genetic or chronic diseases.  Current Presentation:  On physical examination  low-grade fever  blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  and heart rate of 100 bpm recorded. Auscultation of the heart showed a new-onset 3/6 systolic murmur located at the apex  radiating to the axilla. Fundoscopy showed Roth spots and peripheral examination revealed Janeway lesions  both indicative of infective endocarditis.  Based on the presentation  relevant past medical history  and physical examination findings  Mr. Smith is suspected of presenting with native-valve infective endocarditis and is scheduled for further diagnostic testing and management.

Patient Presentation:  A 58-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department (ED) with complaints of intermittent fever  fatigue  and night sweats persisting for the past 3 weeks. The patient also reported a significant loss of appetite accompanied by an unintended weight loss of approximately 5 pounds within this period.  History:  The patient had a prior history of Intravenous Drug Use (IVDU) and was last known to use drugs about 6 months ago. The patient was diagnosed with Hepatitis C five years ago secondary to IVDU  but was successfully treated with antiviral therapy about 2 years back. Other significant history included chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) for which the patient was on inhaler therapy. The patient had no known allergies.  Clinical Features:  On examination  the patient seemed fatigued  diaphoretic  and in mild distress. He was febrile with a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F)  his heart rate was 96 beats/minute  blood pressure was 118/85 mm Hg  and oxygen saturation was 99% on room air. Cardiac auscultation revealed a consistent heart rhythm but with a high-pitched blowing murmur heard at the mid-cardiac apex on inspiration. There were no signs of peripheral emboli such as Janeway lesions or Osler's nodes.  Initial Assessment:  Given the patient’s history and current presentation  the suspected diagnosis for this patient was native-valve infective endocarditis  possibly secondary to his background of IVDU. Staphylococcus aureus is the most likely pathogen. This required additional investigation including blood culture and an echocardiogram.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Nicholson is a 60-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic today complaining of a rapid onset fever  marked fatigue  night sweats  and weight loss over the past three weeks. Initially  he thought these symptoms were due to a viral infection or the common cold but became alarmed when they started to worsen.  He has a history of intravenous drug use in his early twenties  although he has remained clean over the past two decades. This is notable as it increases his risk profile for native-valve Endocarditis.   His clinical history also shows he has a moderate degree of non-rheumatic mitral regurgitation for which he has been undergoing periodic observation  but was not considered severe enough for any surgical intervention. He has been well-managed on an outpatient basis for his hypertension and type 2 diabetes. Neither condition has been complicated  but they are stable and well-managed by diet  exercise  and medication.  He denies any recent dental procedures  surgeries  or use of central venous lines. He denies any history of rheumatic heart disease or prosthetic valve placement. He does not engage in risky behaviors and consumes alcohol minimally.   This presentation  combined with his predisposing cardiac condition and history of IVDU  prompts consideration of infective endocarditis. A full clinical exam and further diagnostic investigations including blood cultures and echocardiography have been arranged to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment.   His family history is noncontributory  as both parents are elderly and alive  with no known cardiac conditions. Mr. Nicholson lives with his wife and two grown children  and he retired last year as a high school teacher. He does not smoke and does not own any pets. He appears to adhere to his medication regimen and has had all suggested immunizations.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. John  presents to the clinic with a 3-week history of fatigue  poor appetite  unintentional weight loss  and malaise. He has a medical history significant for rheumatic fever during his adolescence and is on long-term warfarin therapy for atrial fibrillation. Additionally  he has a history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and is a chronic smoker. His family history was significant for cardiovascular disease with his father having had a myocardial infarction at the age of 70. The patient reported having had dental extraction approximately a month prior to developing these symptoms.  On examination  he appears acutely ill and diaphoretic. His pulse is 110 bpm  blood pressure 135/80 mm Hg and has a fever with temperature spiking at 38.4°C. Cardiac examination reveals a diastolic murmur  best heard at the left mid-sternal border. On skin examination  the patient has petechiae on his anterior shins and the back of his hands. He has splinter hemorrhages in his nails and Osler nodes (tender subcutaneous nodules) are present on his palms and soles.  Initial blood tests show elevated inflammatory markers (CRP  ESR)  leucocytosis and anemia. Blood cultures have been taken and are pending. An echocardiogram has been ordered to confirm the suspicion of infective endocarditis. Given the patient’s presentation  the presence of cardiac murmur  and recent dental extraction  a working diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis is considered.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 56 years  Gender: Male Ethnicity: Asian-American Occupation: Dentist  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Doe presents with a 2-week history of fever  malaise  night sweats  loss of appetite  weight loss  and a new murmur on auscultation. He also reports tooth damage from a recent minor accident a month ago  which was subsequently left untreated due to his fear of dental procedures.  Past Medical History: He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 7 years ago and consuming oral hypoglycemic agents since then. Furthermore  he reported minor ischemic stroke 6 months ago  for which he started taking aspirin.  Family History: His father died from a heart attack at the age of 58  and his mother from brain stroke at the age of 69. His younger sister has type 1 diabetes.  Social History: He is non-smoker and doesn't drink alcohol. He has two children and works full time. He follows a balanced diet but lacks regular exercise due to his busy schedule.  Examination: On physical examination  he appeared ill and had a fever of 100.8°F. Cardiovascular exam revealed a new grade 3/6 mid-systolic murmur at left lower sternal edge. Other systemic examination findings were unremarkable. Ophthalmic exam revealed few minor retinal hemorrhages. Dental review showed poor dental hygiene and an untreated fractured tooth.  Investigations: His blood tests showed raised inflammatory markers and streaks of streptococcus mutans were detected in blood cultures. Echocardiography visualized vegetations on the mitral valve in keeping with the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Impression: John Doe  a 56-year-old Asian-American male dentist  with a background of type 2 diabetes and cerebrovascular accident  presented with symptoms consistent with native-valve endocarditis  this was confirmed by echocardiography and blood cultures.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents with a two-week history of fatigue  intermittent fever  poor appetite and an unintentional weight loss of approximately 10 pounds. He also mentions experiencing night sweats  and more recently  discomfort in his left leg.   The patient has a past medical history significant for bicuspid aortic valve disease diagnosed five years ago. He has never undergone any corrective surgery for the valve issue as he had been asymptomatic. He also has a 40-year history of smoking  which was quit a decade ago.  Other significant aspects of his history include type II diabetes mellitus  managed with diet and metformin  and hypertension  controlled with lisinopril. He denies any recent dental procedures  intravenous drug use  or risky sexual behaviors.   In recent lab work  he was found to have elevated ESR and CRP indicating inflammation. His CBC showed mild anemia and leukocytosis. A subsequent blood culture came back positive for Streptococcus viridans.   On examination  he demonstrates a diastolic murmur appreciated best at the right upper sternal border. Cardiovascular examination reveals an early diastolic decrescendo murmur consistent with aortic regurgitation. Several scattered petechiae are noted on his lower legs  along with some erythema and swelling to his left leg.   The presentation of persistent non-specific symptoms  positive blood culture  existing cardiac condition  echocardiographic features  and physical examination findings lead to a diagnosis of potential native-valve infective endocarditis.

Subjective:  The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male farmer  Mr. Jenkins  who presents to the clinic complaining of a progressive onset of tiredness  intermittent chills  night sweats  and recent weight loss. During a routine check-up a few weeks ago  a low-grade fever was detected and he was also noted to have a new cardiac murmur which had not been documented before.  Mr. Jenkins has a history of chronic periodontal disease requiring multiple dental procedures  most recent one being two months ago. He does not report any history of intravenous drug use  recent travel  or contact with sick individuals. He raises a few animals on his farm but does not recall any insect bites  scratches  or injuries while doing farm work.   Objective:  Exam: 62-year-old appearing stated age  in no acute distress but looking fatigued. Vital signs: Heart rate 86 bpm  Blood pressure 128/74 mmHg  Respiratory rate 16/min  Temperature 99.5°F.   Cardiovascular examination reveals a new grade III regurgitant murmur  best heard over the mitral area. No peripheral stigmata of infective endocarditis such as petechiae or Janeway lesions. Oral examination reveals poor dentition and some gum inflammation.  Assessment and Plan:  Considering his recent dental procedures  the new cardiac murmur  low-grade fever  and other systemic symptoms  Mr. Jenkins fits the clinical criteria for possible native-valve infective endocarditis. Consequently  computed tomography  blood cultures  and transthoracic echocardiography will be initially arranged to confirm the diagnosis.   If the diagnosis of infective endocarditis is confirmed  consultation with cardiology and infectious disease specialists will be sought. Inpatient hospitalization for treatment with intravenous antibiotics may be required  depending on the severity of the disease and the patient's response to the initial antibiotic therapy.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presenting with symptoms of high-grade fever  chills  fatigue  new-onset shortness of breath  persistent cough  and a notable weight loss over the past several weeks. The patient also mentions the development of petechiae in his lower extremities and conjunctivae. He has a known history of intravenous drug use and was diagnosed with Hepatitis C approximately ten years ago.   Previous medical history reveals mitral valve prolapse identified 15 years ago  but the patient could not recall when it was last assessed. The patient also has a past history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed with an ACE inhibitor and statins respectively.   The patient lives alone and admits to his IV drug abuse. He denies recent hospitalizations or any foreign travel. Upon physical examination  several Janeway lesions are noticed on the palms and soles. Cardiac auscultation reveals a mid-systolic click followed by a late systolic murmur best heard at the mitral area  indicating his known mitral valve prolapse might have led to mitral regurgitation. His vital signs are as follows - Temperature: 38.5° Celsius  Blood Pressure: 130/80 mmHg  Pulse: 90 bpm  and Respiratory Rate: 20 breaths/minute.   Given the clinical presentation and significant past medical history  a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis is highly suspected. Investigations  including blood cultures and echocardiography  have been requested for further confirmation.

Patient Presentation:  Patient E  a 55-year-old African American male  presents to the emergency room complaining of persistent and worsening fatigue  shortness of breath  and low-grade fever for the last four weeks. He also reports unintentional weight loss and a new onset of lower leg lesions that look like small purplish spots. Further questioning reveals the patient has a history of intravenous drug use  being clean for the last 5 years. His past medical history is significant for Hepatitis C infection  alcohol liver disease  and hypertension - all are currently managed with a combination of medications including antihypertensives and antivirals. He is a regular smoker and consumes alcohol socially.  On physical examination  the patient appears chronically ill and pale. Auscultation of the heart reveals a diastolic murmur at the mid-left sternal border. Skin examination shows splinter hemorrhages under the nails and petechiae on the conjunctiva  palate  and extremities. He is febrile  with a temperature of 38.5 degrees Celsius  blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg  pulse rate is 112 bpm  and respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute.   Taking into consideration the clinical presentation and patient's history  we should include the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis as an important differential and perform the appropriate tests for confirmation and classification. He should undergo a blood culture and an echocardiography to evaluate his heart valve condition.

Patient Presentation:   Mrs. R  a 58-year-old Asian woman with a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and moderate rheumatoid arthritis presents to the clinic. For the past three weeks  she has been experiencing low-grade fevers typically in the range of 100-101°F  new-onset fatigue  and a one-week history of arthralgias in her elbows and knees. These symptoms have become progressively worse  compelling her to seek medical attention.   She denies recent travel or ill contacts and her vaccinations are up to date. She has no known allergies. She reports no changes in her medications for diabetes and rheumatoid arthritis. She has never smoked or used illicit drugs. She drinks socially.   Upon physical examination  it is noted that the patient has new-onset petechiae in the conjunctiva and splinter haemorrhages in the nail beds. On auscultation  a new murmur is heard in the mitral region. Blood tests reveal leukocytosis with left shift  elevated sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein.  Taken together  the hearsay and physical examination findings raise suspicion for Native-valve Infective Endocarditis (IE) and the patient is referred for an immediate echocardiogram.

Patient Profile:  Ms. Johnson  a 55-year-old female  has presented to the clinic today. She is an intravenous drug user (IVDU) with a known history of Hepatitis C  and has no documented regular medical follow-ups.  Chief Complaints:   The patient reports experiencing episodic ""fever and chills"" for the last two weeks  accompanied by fatigue  general malaise  weight loss and night sweats.  Review of Systems:  In the cardiovascular review  she also states she has suffered from some chest discomfort and palpitations. Systemically  she cites poor appetite causing unintended weight loss. The patient denies any recent travel  foodborne sickness  or contact with sick individuals.  Physical Exam:  On physical examination  she is febrile with a temperature of 100.5 F and her blood pressure is slightly elevated  putting her in the hypertensive range. Evaluation of the cardiovascular system detects a new heart murmur not previously noted. Observations of the skin find petechiae and Janeway lesions. A fundoscopic exam reveals Roth spots in the retina.  Summary:  Based on the patient's history  her physical examination findings  and positive blood cultures  she is diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis  most likely secondary to her intravenous drug use. She will require hospital admission for intravenous antibiotics and surgical consultation for possible valve replacement.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. J  a 65-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with complaints of a three-week duration of intermittent fever  malaise  night sweats  and unintended weight loss of about 5 pounds. She reports difficulty in performing her daily activities due to increasing weakness and a feeling of ""being unwell"". She also noticed some small  flat  painless red spots under her skin on the palms of her hands and soles of her feet which she describes as ""new"". On inquiry  she admits to having had poor dental health for the past few years with multiple untreated caries and a recent dental extraction about a month prior to the onset of her current symptoms.   Past Medical History:   Ms. J's past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes managed with diet and metformin  and hypertension being treated with a thiazide diuretic and ACE inhibitor. She denies any history of intravenous drug use or recent travel. She has no known drug allergies or past surgical history.  Relevant Family History:  Both her parents had hypertension  and her father passed away from a myocardial infarction in his late 60s. Her maternal aunt was diagnosed with rheumatic heart disease.  Social History:  She is a retired teacher  currently living alone as a widow. She quit smoking 10 years ago and consumes alcohol only occasionally during holidays. She admits to poor dental hygiene and lack of regular dental care. She has no pet at home and denies recent contact with sick individuals. She has no recent travel history.   This presentation  along with the presence of cardiac murmurs discovered in her physical examination and confirmed by echocardiography  leads to the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis  most likely resulting from oral bacteria entering the bloodstream during her recent dental procedure.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Thompson  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department at the paint removal plant where he works  complaining of a three-week history of persistent fever of up to 38.5 degrees Celsius  night sweats  unintentional weight loss of approximately 4.7 kilograms  intermittent chills  and general fatigue. He rates his energy level as 3 out of 10 and his fatigue as 7 out of 10. He also experiences an intermittent cough with occasional colored sputum but denies any hemoptysis. In the last few days  he developed a painful red rash on his right lower leg  which he described as ""like small broken blood vessels.""  Upon further inquiry  Mr. Thompson reports having a mild dental procedure performed about a month ago  but did not take any antibiotics prior to the dental surgery. Other past medical history includes hypertension  which is controlled with a daily dose of Amlodipine  and mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) from a 40-year history of smoking a pack of cigarettes a day.  On physical examination  he was found to have a few small tender red nodules on the pads of his fingers and the soles of his feet. In addition  an early diastolic murmur was heard when listening to his heart.  Given the unrelenting fevers  history of recent dental work  and the presence of a cardiac murmur  Mr. Thompson was admitted for a workup  including blood cultures and an echocardiogram  for possible native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 63-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with a one-week history of intermittent fevers  fatigue  and weight loss. He reports experiencing night sweats and a decreased appetite. He states that his symptoms have progressively worsened over the past week  prompting his visit today.  He has a past medical history of diabetes mellitus type II  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and completed aortic valve replacement surgery 10 years ago. He does not have a history of intravenous drug use  recent dental procedures  or body piercings. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally.   His current medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. He has no known drug allergies. Upon physical examination  his temperature is 38.5 degrees Celsius  heart rate 90 beats per minute  respiratory rate 18 per minute  and blood pressure 130/85 mmHg. Cardiac examination reveals a diastolic murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border. An initial workup  including blood cultures  is sent to the lab.

Patient Information: Ms. Hayley Davis  a 55-year-old African-American woman  who works as an accountant.  Chief Complaint: ""I have been feeling feverish and tired for two weeks now and experienced some night sweats. I also seem to be losing weight unintentionally.""  Presenting Illness: Ms. Davis has been experiencing high-grade intermittent fever for the past two weeks. She also reports extreme fatigue  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss of about 10 pounds over the same period.  Past Medical History: Ms. Davis has a significant past medical history of Rheumatic Fever at the age of 16. She also has a history of intravenous drug use in her early 20s  but has been clean and sober for the past 30 years. She was diagnosed with Type II diabetes mellitus ten years ago which has been reasonably well-controlled with Metformin. She suffered a minor heart attack seven years ago.   Social History: She quit smoking 10 years ago and denies current illicit drug or heavy alcohol use. Lives alone and is generally sedentary because of her job as an accountant.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  her temperature is 101.3°F  blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg  heart rate is 105 beats per minute  and she appears pale. She has several small  painless  reddish-purple spots on her skin (petechiae) and Janeway lesions on her palms and soles. Upon auscultation  a new murmur is noted over her mitral valve. There are no signs of peripheral edema or hypertension.  Laboratory results and any procedures: Blood cultures sent for analysis  waiting on results. Chest X-Ray shows slight cardiomegaly. An echocardiogram has been scheduled to further evaluate the new murmur and confirm the diagnosis.  Provisional Diagnosis: Preliminary diagnosis suggests a case of native-valve infective endocarditis  but confirmation from echocardiogram and blood culture is awaited.   Plan: The plan is to administer empiric antibiotics following blood cultures and await results. Follow up with the patient after echocardiogram and blood culture results have been obtained.

Patient Presentation:  A 64-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department (ED) with a 3-week history of persistent fevers  night sweats  weight loss  and generalized fatigue. He reports that he also started developing malaise and shortness of breath on exertion one week ago. He denies a cough  chest pain  or hemoptysis. There is no history of recent travel  sick contacts  or illicit drug use.  Past Medical History:  He has a known history of moderate aortic stenosis and underwent a dental procedure six weeks prior without antibiotic prophylaxis. He has poorly controlled type II diabetes mellitus and a 40 pack-year smoking history. The patient does not consume alcohol. He is currently on metformin and an ACE inhibitor for his diabetes and hypertension  respectively. His immunizations are up to date; however  he cannot recall the last flu vaccine he took. No records of acute illnesses or hospital admissions in the past five years.  On examination  the patient appears unwell and diaphoretic. He is alert and oriented to time  place  and person. There is evidence of petechiae on the skin and splinter hemorrhages in the nail beds. Cardiac auscultation reveals a high-pitched diastolic murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space.  The above presentation is suggestive of native valve infective endocarditis. The patient's risk factors include aortic stenosis  recent dental procedure without antibiotic prophylaxis  and poorly controlled diabetes. For confirmation  further diagnostics such as blood cultures and echocardiography need to be considered.

The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian man presenting with a month-long history of worsening fatigue  four days of fevers  sweat  shortness of breath  and a new  prominent heart murmur. The patient is a farmer and avid gardener  with a history of heavy alcohol use  chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  and untreated mitral valve prolapse. He denies any IV drug usage. He took a round of amoxicillin last week for suspected strep throat  but his symptoms didn't improve. He has lost 10 pounds over the last month and has significant loss of appetite. On examination  he appears ill and is in mild respiratory distress. He has Janeway lesions on his palms and a new pansystolic murmur at the apex spreading to the axilla. Initial labs reveal a white blood cell count of 15 000 with 85% neutrophils  hemoglobin is 10.2 g/dL  and platelet count is 415 000. Blood culture bottles are drawn and sent to the microbiology lab.  Chest X-Ray shows a slight enlarging of the heart and a small left pleural effusion. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) reveals vegetations on his mitral valve and severe mitral regurgitation. The patient is admitted to the hospital for further management of suspected native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 63-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of low-grade fever  fatigue  unintentional 10-pound weight loss over the last month  night sweats  and an aching pain in his left leg. He describes no cough  shortness of breath  chest pain  abdominal pain  nausea  vomiting  or diarrhea. He noticed a new rash on his hands and feet that he describes as tiny  painless red spots.  His past medical history is significant for rheumatic fever in childhood  for which he received long-term penicillin therapy. He had undergone dental work without antibiotic prophylaxis two weeks prior to the onset of symptoms. No history of intravenous drug use.  The patient has a 30-pack year history of smoking  but quit 5 years ago and he drinks socially. He is a retired construction worker  married  and lives with his wife.  On physical examination  temperature is 100.5 degrees Fahrenheit. Heart rate is 90 bpm  respiratory rate is 18/min  and blood pressure is 140/70 mm Hg. Cardiac exam reveals a new 3/6 systolic murmur best heard at the apex. He exhibits Janeway lesions on his palms and soles  and Osler nodes on his left fingers and right toes. His left leg is mildly swollen and tender.  Lab tests reveal mild anemia (Hb 11 g/dL)  elevated ESR (60 mm/hr)  elevated CRP (5 mg/dL)  and leukocytosis (WBC - 14 000/uL with neutrophil predominance). Blood cultures are pending.  His baseline EKG  chest X-ray  and serum electrolytes are normal. His echocardiogram shows vegetations on the mitral valve suggesting possible infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old male named Robert Taylor presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of fevers  weight loss  fatigue and night sweats. He also mentions about a new onset of a heart murmur he noticed himself. He explains that he currently lives with his wife and has a history of intravenous drug use  although he has been clean for the past decade.   Past Medical History:  Robert has a known history of diabetes mellitus type II managed with oral hypoglycaemic. He also has a history of being a heavy smoker but quit 2 years ago after a diagnosis of mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He had two episodes of pneumonia in the past three years. There is no history of any previous heart disease or surgery within the family. His vaccinations  including pneumococcal and flu vaccines  are up to date.   Current medication includes Metformin  Atorvastatin for dyslipidemia and Salbutamol inhaler for the COPD. He denies any known drug allergies.   Robert's dental hygiene is poor and a dental examination reveals multiple carious teeth  but he defers dental consultation due to lack of insurance coverage.  Physical Examination:  On physical examination  Robert appears ill and diaphoretic. He is febrile with a temperature of 101.7°F. His blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg when measured on his right arm  heart rate is 105 bpm regular  respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute and SpO2 is 95% on room air. The oropharynx is clear but with evidence of poor oral hygiene.  Cardiovascular examination reveals a new grade 3/6 pansystolic murmur in the mitral area and splinter hemorrhages are noted under his fingernails. The rest of the systems are essentially within normal limits.  These findings are suggesting a case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  most likely of Enterococcal origin considering his poor dental hygiene  intrinsic cardiac abnormalities and previous pneumonia. Further diagnostic procedures  specifically blood cultures and echocardiography  should be carried out to confirm this diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:   A 58-year-old Hispanic male  Mr. Garcia  presents to the emergency department complaining of intermittent fevers  excessive night sweats  and increasing fatigue over the past two weeks. He also reports unintended weight loss and a persistent  low-grade headache.  His past medical history is significant for rheumatic fever as a child and moderate mitral valve regurgitation diagnosed three years ago; he has been on watchful waiting since. He also has a 20 pack-year history of smoking and was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus eight years ago  which he manages with metformin and lifestyle modifications.  In social history  Mr. Garcia is an engineer by profession. He denies alcohol and illicit drug use. He lives with his wife and two grown-up kids.  On examination  he appears febrile and diaphoretic. Auscultation of the heart reveals a murmur consistent with his known mitral regurgitation  but now also with a newly appreciated  high pitched diastolic murmur. In addition  splinter hemorrhages are noted in his fingernails and petechiae on the palpebral conjunctivae of both eyes and the oral mucosa.  Mr. Garcia's presentation and history of pre-existing valvular heart disease raise the suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis. Immediate hospital admission is advised for further diagnostic workup and management as his condition could be life-threatening.

Patient Presentation:   A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with a two-week history of fever  malaise  and weight loss. The patient also reports recent onset of night sweats and intermittent chest discomfort over the same time period. He has noticed a small  painless red rash on the palms of his hands and soles of his feet.   Demographic Details:   The patient is a retired steelworker born and raised in Pittsburgh  Pennsylvania. He lives with his wife of 40 years  and they have two adult children. The patient is a former smoker  with a 30-pack year history but quit smoking 15 years ago. He consumes alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use. His vaccination history is updated.  Past Medical History:   The patient has a known history of a bicuspid aortic valve diagnosed 20 years ago and was under clinical surveillance without any requirement of surgical intervention so far. He also has hypertension  controlled with lisinopril. The patient had a dental procedure performed one month ago. His family history is significant for heart disease and diabetes on the paternal side.   The combination of the patient's clinical symptoms along with his history of a bicuspid aortic valve and the recent dental procedure lead to a high suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Samuel Hudson is a 63-year-old African American male with a history of intravenous drug use who presents to the emergency department complaining of fever  general weakness  and shortness of breath for the past week. He denies chest pain but states he has been feeling weak and has lost his appetite. He reports experiencing night sweats and a weight loss of approximately 5 pounds in the last two weeks. He also mentions experiencing a new-onset heart murmur.  Demographic Details:  Mr. Hudson lives alone in his apartment downtown. He recently lost his job and has been struggling to maintain consistent healthcare follow-ups due to lack of insurance. Mr. Hudson admits to current IV drug usage and has a history of substance abuse.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Hudson was diagnosed with Hepatitis C five years ago that he acquired secondary to IV drug use. He has a history of recurrent cellulitis secondary to injection sites. He is unaware of any family history of premature coronary artery disease. He denied ever being told that he had a heart murmur during any of his past medical visits. He is not under any current medication. He is a known smoker who smokes one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. He reports no known drug allergies.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  presents to the ER complaining of general weakness  intermittent fevers  and a certain loss of appetite over the past 2 weeks. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or cough but admits to an unintended weight loss of approximately 10 lbs over the same period. His past medical history is significant for longstanding poorly controlled type II diabetes mellitus and a 20 pack-year smoking history. He has a known history of bicuspid aortic valve diagnosed incidentally on an echocardiogram done five years ago. He denies any recreational drug use. His only regular medication is Metformin. He underwent dental cleaning and extraction about a month ago. Initial vital signs reveal a temperature of 38.5 C  pulse 90 bpm  blood pressure 120/75 mmHg  and respiratory rate 18 per minute. Physical examination reveals a II/VI systolic murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border. Bilateral lower extremity non-pitting edema is noted as well. Laboratory results reveal an elevated ESR  CRP  and slightly elevated ProBNP. Three sets of blood cultures are drawn  and he is admitted to the hospital for further management with a primary suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis  likely of the aortic valve given his known bicuspid valve. Infectious Diseases and Cardiology team are consulted for further management.

Patient Presentation:  A 45-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with complaints of intermittent high-grade fever of two weeks duration  along with fatigue  weakness  and unintentional weight loss. He also reports multiple joint pains and intermittent night sweats. On probing further  the patient admits to having a new-onset crescendo-decrescendo murmur  which was not present before.  He has a past medical history significant for intravenous drug use but has claimed to be sober for the past six months. He also has a known history of untreated dental caries and has not sought oral health care in many years. He does not have personal or family history of rheumatic heart disease. He denies recent travel history or exposure to communicable diseases. He is a non-smoker and occasionally consumes alcohol.  Examination reveals multiple erythematous  tender nodular lesions located on both palms and soles  consistent with Janeway lesions. Ophthalmic examination uncovers Roth spots in the retina. His body temperature is 38.4°C  and other vital signs are stable.  The constellation of his typical symptoms  along with the predisposing factors of untreated dental caries  and intravenous drug use  suggest the clinical diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. The new murmurs suggest a possible valvular disorder. Further investigations  including blood cultures and echocardiography  are planned to confirm the diagnosis and understand the severity of the disease.

A 58-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department feeling generally unwell  fatigued  and with a low-grade fever of 100.4 degrees Fahrenheit that he's been experiencing for the past 3 weeks. He has also noticed some weight loss and night sweats. He reports having experienced some intermittent  vague chest discomfort and shortness of breath  especially on exertion.
