Over the past week  he noticed small purplish spots on his legs and feet  which he recalls as similar to what his primary physician described as petechiae some years ago.  His past medical history is significant for mitral valve prolapse which was diagnosed five years ago  and for which he has been under regular cardiological follow-up  but he has declined surgical intervention to date. He has no known allergies but is a 20 pack year smoker and a heavy alcohol drinker. His family history is significant for heart disease  with his father having suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. He lives alone and works as a construction worker.  On physical examination  he appears chronically ill. Cardiovascular examination reveals a mid systolic click and late systolic murmur best heard at the apex. There are also vascular signs suggestive of infective endocarditis  including Osler nodes and petechiae seen on his lower extremities.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  known smoker and with a long-standing history of poorly controlled type II diabetes mellitus and untreated dental caries. He presents to the emergency department with a one-week history of intermittent high-grade fever  night sweats  fatigue  and unintended weight loss. He also reports new onset confusion in the last two days and intermittent chest discomfort.  Over the past week  he also noticed small  painful red spots on his fingers and toes  and unexplained bleeding from his gums while brushing teeth. He denies any history of intravenous drug use  recent dental procedures  or invasive medical procedures. The patient recently had a minor skin procedure on his foot to treat a diabetic foot ulcer  which healed uneventfully.  The physical examination revealed fever  a new systolic heart murmur  and splinter hemorrhages under his fingernails. His teeth were in poor condition  with visible dental caries noted. The patient was disoriented in time and place  suggesting a change in mental status.  Given the patient's history  clinical presentation  and findings on physical examination  the suspicion for infective endocarditis has raised. Further investigations  including blood cultures and an echocardiogram  were scheduled to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation: A 65-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with a two-week history of malaise  shortness of breath and persistent fever. Over the last four days  the patient has also noticed a change in the color of his urine  which he describes as being dark  or the ""color of Coca Cola"". Upon further discussion  he also admits to have noticed small red spots on his trunk and extremities. The patient’s medical history is relevant for Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus  Hypertension  and a 30 pack-year smoking history. He had a dental procedure done 3 weeks ago.   The patient doesn’t have any substance abuse history. He looks visibly unwell  sweating profusely and seems anxious. His temperature is 38.8 degrees Celsius and heart rate is 102 beats per minute. Upon examination  the patient’s pulses are irregularly irregular; auscultation of his heart reveals a new murmur which was not documented in his previous medical records. The rest of the physical exam is unremarkable except for the presence of small red spots noted on his body  consistent with petechiae and splinter hemorrhages in his nail beds. Given the patient’s history and presentation  the team is highly concerned for infective endocarditis with a possible embolic event. Further investigations like blood cultures  echocardiogram  and urinalysis are needed to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Profile: Name: Mr. Alan Smith Age: 62 years old Gender: Male Occupation: Accountant Lifestyle: Sedentary Ethnicity: Caucasian Marital Status: Married with two grown-up children  Chief Complaint: Came to the emergency department complaining of fever  fatigue  joint and muscle aches that developed over the past three weeks. Also reports shortness of breath  and a heart murmur was detected by his GP.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a history of moderate to severe dental caries requiring multiple extractions and dental implants. He last had dental work 6 weeks ago. There's no history of drug abuse  and he does not have any known heart disease or prosthetic heart valves. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol on occasion.  Family History: His mother had type 2 diabetes and his father died of a heart attack at the age of 68. His older brother has hypertension and his younger sister is healthy.  Medications: He takes a daily multivitamin and ibuprofen as needed for arthritis pain.  Review of Systems: Cardiovascular: Positive for heart murmur per GP  and shortness of breath. Pulmonary: Negative for cough or chest pain. Gastrointestinal: Negative for nausea  vomiting  diarrhea  or abdominal pain. Musculoskeletal: Positive for joint and muscle aches. General: Positive for fever and fatigue.  Physical examination: Vital Signs: T=100.8 F  P=98 bpm  Blood pressure: 120/80  RR= 18 bpm  Oxygen saturation: 98% on room air. General Appearance: Pale  diaphoretic  and appears acutely ill. Cardiovascular: Regular rhythm  tachycardia  a new grade 3/6 systolic murmur heard at the left lower sternal border. Chest: Breath sounds are clear. Skin: There’s an erythematous  tender lesion on his left forearm that could be an Osler's node. Mouth: Poor dental hygiene with multiple cavities and missing teeth.  Based on his history  clinical presentation  and physical exam findings  he is suspected to have infective endocarditis  most likely related to his recent dental work and consequent transient bacteremia in a patient with poor dental health. Further testing  including blood cultures and transthoracic echocardiogram  should be pursued to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Information:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaint:  Fever  chills  night sweats  shortness of breath and unexplained weight loss.  History of Present Illness: Patient reports that symptoms have been ongoing for the past 3 weeks. He had episodes of fever peaking as high as 38.5 C  mostly in the evening for the past 3 weeks  associated with intermittent chills and night sweats. He also experiences slight shortness of breath on exertion and has an unexplained weight loss of approximately 5 kg over the last month.  Past Medical History: Patient has a history of aortic valve stenosis for which he declined surgical intervention. No history of illicit drug use  no previous endocarditis  no prosthetic heart valve or valve repair  no known congenital heart defect.  Physical Examination: Patient appears moderately ill. There is clubbing of fingers. Cardiac exam shows a early diastolic murmur best heard along left sternal border. There is no peripheral edema. Chest is clear to auscultation  no rales or wheezes noted. No skin rashes or erythema are evident.  Family History: No history of heart disease  auto-immune disease or blood disorders in the family.  Social History: Patient is a retired engineer  non-smoker  drinks alcohol occasionally. No history of illicit drug use. He lives with his wife and has two adult children.  Review of Systems: Negative for headache  chest pain  abdominal pain  nausea  or vomiting.

Patient Information: Mr. Smith  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Smith is complaining of continuous fever  joint and muscle pain that hasn’t improved over the past week. He also reports experiencing shortness of breath and tiredness more than usual.  Medical History: He has a medical history of Rheumatic Fever at a young age  and currently he is under management for Diabetes Mellitus type 2. There are also no significant surgical histories. He had been a heavy smoker in the past but quit 15 years ago.  Recent History: Patient was recently discharged from the hospital about a month ago after treatment for an infected foot ulcer related to his diabetes. His medications include Metformin and Lisinopril.   Examination & Investigation Findings: Upon physical examination  he exhibits pale conjunctiva  small petechiae in his conjunctiva and legs. His temperature is found to be 102°F. Furthermore  cardiac auscultation reveals a new heart murmur not previously documented and an echocardiogram suggests vegetation on his heart valves.   Given the patient's present symptoms  past healthcare exposures  diabetic history and previous Rheumatic fever  there is a suspicion of native valve Infective endocarditis. Further microbiological tests and blood cultures are ordered for verification. Treatment will be initiated based on the bacterial strain identified.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Susan Sanders is a 45-year-old Caucasian female who presents to the outpatient department with a 4-week history of intermittent fever  chills  malaise  and a recent onset of shortness of breath. Her fever is occasionally accompanied by night sweats but no cough or chest pain. She has also noticed some weight loss. She identifies as a non-smoker  drinks alcohol socially  and denies any illicit drug use.  She has past medical history significant for a dental procedure 6 weeks back as well as rheumatic heart disease diagnosed as a teenager for which she had undergone a mitral valve repair 5 years back. She also has hypertension which has been well controlled on amlodipine for the last 5 years.  Recent travel history  animal exposures  or exposure to sick contacts is unremarkable. Her family history is significant for coronary artery disease in her father.   Her lab results suggest a mildly elevated white blood cell count and a raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). The blood cultures are still pending. Echocardiography reveals suspicious vegetations on her native mitral valve with moderate regurgitation.  Based on her clinical presentation  past medical history of rheumatic heart disease and the recent dental procedure  and the preliminary echocardiographic findings  a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis is suspected. Initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics is considered while waiting for the blood culture results.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 62-year-old male who presents to the clinic today complaining of consistent fever  generalized fatigue  and unexplained weight loss over a 5-week period. He also reports increasing shortness of breath  nocturnal sweats  and slight discomfort in his chest. The patient does not recall any recent dental procedures  minor cuts  or any pegs in the last six months. However  he does admit to intravenous drug use in his early 20s.   Demographics:  Mr. Smith is Caucasian  a retired construction worker  living in the suburban area. He neither smokes nor drinks alcohol  and he has a history of intravenous drug use. He has no known allergies. He is divorced and lives alone.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a history of rheumatic heart disease due to recurrent rheumatic fever in his childhood  which affected his valves  particularly damage was noticeable in the mitral valve. A previous 2D echocardiogram noted high-grade mitral regurgitation. He also has a history of hypertension  well-controlled with a daily dose of Lisinopril 10mg. He had a bout of pneumonia around 5 years ago  which required him hospitalization. His family history includes a father who had a myocardial infarction and a mother with a stroke.  Following the interview  Mr. Smith's physical examination reveals pallor  osler nodes on tips of his fingers  and a faint diastolic heart murmur. These findings  combined with a history of fever and rheumatic heart disease  raises a suspicion towards a potential diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. Further investigations like blood culture and trans-esophageal echocardiogram will be requested to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Information:   Ms. Patricia is a 55-year-old African American female with a known history of intravenous drug use and untreated dental caries.   Chief Complaint:   The patient arrives at the emergency center presenting with a two-week history of persisting fever  fatigue  and weight loss. She also states she is experiencing night sweats  shortness of breath and a new heart murmur that she's never noticed before.  History of Present Illness:  Ms. Patricia reports the fever started approximately two weeks ago  ranging between 38.5°C and 39.2°C  mostly observed in the evenings. She also complains of night sweats and has noticed an unintentional weight loss of 5 lbs over the last month. She has been experiencing increasing shortness of breath and a noticeable irregular heartbeat. She denies any recent travels or sick contacts. She does admit to continuing intravenous drug use over the past few months.  Past Medical History:  Ms. Patricia reported having seen a dentist two months ago who recommended several tooth extractions due to severe dental caries  but she did not go through the procedure due to lack of insurance. She also has a history of Hepatitis C secondary to her IV drug use. No surgeries are reported. Her last tetanus booster was approximately 10 years ago. She has no known allergies.  Social History:  Ms. Patricia is unemployed and lives alone. She reports a 30-year history of intravenous recreational drug use  primarily heroin  with the last use being just a few days ago. She is currently not enrolled in any drug rehabilitation programs. She does not smoke or consume alcohol.  Review of Systems:  Substantial details already provided above. She denies any recent changes in vision  hearing  breast lumps  cough  hemoptysis  hematemesis  dysphagia  abdominal pain  dysuria  joint pain  rashes or neurological changes.  Physical exam:  On physical examination  she was febrile (38.8°C) and her heart rate was irregular at 110 beats per minute. She had multiple decayed tooth and poor oral hygiene. Cardiac auscultation revealed a new murmur. Pulmonary  abdominal and neurological exams were within normal limits. No osler nodes  janeway lesions or other peripheral signs of endocarditis were observed.   Given her history  clinical presentation  and physical examination  she is suspected to have native-valve infective endocarditis possibly secondary to her untreated dental caries and IV drug abuse. Blood cultures have been drawn  and she is admitted for empirical antibiotic therapy and further investigation. Cardiology consultation is recommended.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Laura Johnson  a 63-year-old Caucasian woman  presented to the clinic with a chief complaint of persistent fever for the past two weeks  fatigue  loss of appetite  and unintentional weight loss. She also reports intermittent chest discomfort and shortness of breath.  She has a past medical history of severe rheumatic heart disease during her childhood and now has known mitral valve regurgitation. Furthermore  she has been suffering from type 2 diabetes  well controlled on metformin  for the past ten years. No known allergies. She is on prophylactic penicillin for her history of rheumatic heart disease.   She works as a librarian and lives alone. She doesn't smoke or drink alcohol. She also volunteers at a local animal shelter during her free time. Recently  she adopted a cat from the shelter  which bit her on her hand roughly 3 weeks ago  which initially healed well  but now complains of mild pain and discomfort around the bite site.  Upon examination  she appeared in discomfort  mildly confused  and pale. A heart exam revealed a pansystolic murmur associated with her known mitral regurgitation. There is no evidence of peripheral stigmata of endocarditis.   Her vital signs on admission were: pulse 112/min  blood pressure 110/70 mmHg  respiratory rate 20/min  and temperature 38.5°C. Lab investigations revealed mild anemia  elevated inflammatory markers.  The synthesis of her symptoms  physical exam findings  past medical history  and lab results leads to the suspected diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis  potentially triggered by bacterial introduction after being bitten by her new pet cat.

Patient Information: A 52-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use and Hepatitis C.  Chief Complaint: The patient presents to the emergency department expressing complaints of fever  malaise  night sweats  weight loss  and occasional shortness of breath over the past 2 months. Additionally  he reports increased fatigue and weakness  especially while climbing stairs or doing any strenuous activity.  History of Present Illness: His symptoms initially appeared mild but have progressed steadily. He reports no recent dental work  surgeries  or invasive procedures. He denies any recent use of illegal drugs. However  he confesses to a history of intravenous drug use  up until a few years ago.   Past Medical History: A known case of chronic Hepatitis C infection. No known heart disease or any other chronic illnesses. Previous history of intravenous drug use but currently in recovery for several years.   Physical Examination: Fever of 38.5°C  Heart rate 90 bpm  Blood pressure 100/70 mmHg. Inspection revealed pallor and conjunctival pallor. Cardiovascular examination showed a new-onset diastolic murmur best heard at the left third intercostal space. Small  non-tender erythematous lesions were also noted on the palms and soles. No Osler’s nodes or Janeway lesions were found on physical examination.   Assessment: Given the patient’s history and the presence of a new heart murmur and classic cutaneous manifestations  the patient was highly suspicious for native-valve infective endocarditis  likely secondary to his past history of intravenous drug use and currently untreated Hepatitis C infection. Further investigations and management were planned as per hospital protocols for suspected infective endocarditis.      Plan: Immediate blood cultures were ordered. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) was planned to visualize the heart valves and chambers. Depending upon the results of these tests  the patient might require further cardiology consultation and potentially  valvular surgery if significant damage has occurred. Concomitant management of the patient's Hepatitis C is also warranted.

Patient Presentation:   The patient is a 52-year-old Caucasian male who presents with a 2-week history of high-grade  intermittent fever max 101°F  associated with chills and night sweats and a 7-10 pound unintentional weight loss over the same period. He also complains of generalized fatigue  malaise and intermittent  dull chest pain unrelated to exertion.   Past Medical History:   The patient has a known history of intravenous drug use and was diagnosed with Hepatitis C eight years ago. He quit smoking five years ago  consumes alcohol socially and reports occasional cocaine use. He suffered a Staphylococcus Aureus bacteremia five years ago. The patient has had no surgical interventions in the past. Regular screenings have consistently returned negative for HIV.  Exam:   On examination  his vitals reveal a fever of 101.2°F and a heart rate of 102 bpm. Cardiovascular examination reveals a new  grade III/VI diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border. He has scattered petechiae on his upper extremities  palate  and conjunctivae. Small tender nodules are noted on the pads of several fingers. A few erythematous  non-blanching macules are noted on the palms and soles. Abdomen is soft  slightly tender in the right upper quadrant. Sclera is mildly icteric. No other significant clinical findings are noted.  The patient's history of intravenous drug use and recent  ongoing symptoms of fever  sweats  and weight loss  alongside physical findings of petechiae  tender nodules on fingers  and a new cardiac murmur  all fall in line with a likely diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  truck driver by profession  presenting with progressive fatigue  night sweats  unexplained weight loss  and shortness of breath on exertion that has been worsening over the past four weeks. He reports a low-grade fever for the past seven days but denies having any chest pain  nausea  vomiting  diarrhea  or increased urinary frequency.   Past medical history is significant for chronic lower back pain  for which he often uses nonprescription pain meds. He denies any known history of diabetes  hypertension  or heart disease but admits that he had not seen a healthcare provider for over 10 years. He denies any recent surgeries or hospitalizations. His parents both died of heart disease in their 70s. He does not have a history of IV drug use but is a 30-pack-year smoker and admits daily beer consumption.  On physical examination  he appears pale and diaphoretic with vital signs showing a blood pressure of 128/85 mmHg  heart rate of 105 beats per minute (tachycardic)  respiratory rate of 18 breathes per minute  and a fever of 101.2 F. On cardiac examination  a new-onset heart murmur is identified. Small  painless red or purple spots (Janeway's lesions) were noted under the skin of palms and soles.   Given the history  physical exam findings  and high clinical suspicion  a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis is being considered.

Patient Presentation:  A 54-year-old Caucasian male presented in the Emergency Department with 2-weeks history of intermittent high-grade fever  malaise  night sweats  and unintended weight loss. He also reported newly onset shortness of breath and vague chest discomfort  not related to physical activity. His wife revealed that the patient was becoming increasingly fatigued and noticed that his skin had turned pale. She also noticed that he developed small red spots on the palms of his hands and soles of his feet.  He has a past medical history of bicuspid aortic valve  diagnosed 10 years ago on routine health examination  but has been asymptomatic with no history of congestive heart failure or surgical intervention. He has also been managing type 2 diabetes for the past 7 years with Metformin and a controlled diet  with HbA1c values consistently less than 7%. Additionally  he has hypertension  controlled with Losartan.   The patient smokes half a pack of cigarettes per day for the last 30 years and occasionally consumes alcohol. He is a handyman by profession and has no history of any illicit drug use. His immunization is up-to-date  and he has no known drug allergies. His father died of a heart attack at age 66  and his mother has hypertension.  On physical examination  his pulse was 95 beats per minute  blood pressure was 145/90 mm Hg  temperature was 38.4 C  respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation was 94% on room air. He had a soft systolic ejection murmur audible at the upper right sternal border. His skin showed petechiae on the palms and soles. He had no signs of peripheral edema.   This intense  continuous clinical manifestation with a positive heart murmur indicated a suspicion of native valve infective endocarditis in this patient. The doctor instructed further diagnostic tests including blood cultures  ESR  CRP  and transthoracic echocardiography for the possible presence of vegetations on the heart valves.

Patient Presentation:  A 60-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic with complaints of a high-grade intermittent fever for the last two weeks. The fever was associated with a loss of appetite  extreme fatigue  and an unexplained weight loss of about 8 kilograms over the same period. He reports a sharp intermittent pain in his chest that radiates to the left shoulder. He also describes experiencing episodes of night sweats. Additionally  he has noticed the development of a few painless reddish spots on his palms and soles  along with a few petechiae on his lower extremities.  His past medical history is significant for rheumatic fever at the age of 12 that caused mild mitral valve stenosis. He has not had any surgeries before. He has no known allergies  he does not smoke  and his alcohol consumption is reported as moderate. His family history included a brother who suffered recurrent streptococcal throat infections.  On examination  he has a temperature of 38.5°C  pulse rate of 120 bpm  and BP readings of 130/85 mmHg. We observe pallor  petechiae  and small painless red lesions on hands and feet (Janeway lesions). Cardiac auscultation reveals a Murmur best heard at the apex (mitral area).  His presentation and history support a provisional diagnosis of possible infective endocarditis. The patient's history of rheumatic fever and evidence of mitral stenosis increases his risk. Further investigations including blood cultures and echocardiography are indicated to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Profile:  The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Thompson who has been referred from a local clinic. He is a retired teacher and lives with his wife.   Chief complaint: He presents with a three-week history of unexplained fever  chills and malaise.  History of Present Illness:  Mr. Thompson reports experiencing progressive weakness and fatigue over the last three weeks accompanied by episodes of intense shivering that typically occur during the evenings or early mornings. He reports a fever that reaches about 101 – 102°F. He has also reported a loss of appetite over the time period with some weight loss. He has had no cough  sore throat  chest pain  palpitations  shortness of breath  abdominal pain  or joint pain.   Personal/Social History:  Mr. Thompson has never smoked  drinks alcohol occasionally in social settings  and does not use recreational drugs. He has no history of travelling recently. He does engage in gardening and he took a single tick off his dog last month.  Medical History:  He has a history of rheumatic fever during childhood. Mr. Thompson has been diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus five years ago which is controlled through oral medications and diet. Additionally  he has hypertension controlled through medication.  Family History:  His father passed away from a myocardial infarction in his late 50s  and his mother has Type II Diabetes Mellitus and hypertension.  Current Medication:  He regularly takes amlodipine and metformin  however adherence can be variable.  Review of Systems: On general examination  Mr. Thompson is alert but looks fatigued. He has a temperature of 101.5°F  blood pressure of 140/84 mm Hg  a heart rate of 92 beats per minute  and respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute with normal O2 saturation at room air.  Physical Exam:  Cardiovascular examination reveals a previously undiagnosed systolic murmur. He also has finger clubbing but no other peripheral signs of infective endocarditis such as Osler's nodes or Janeway lesions.   These symptoms along with his past medical history and new cardiac murmur increase the suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis. Further detailed examinations and laboratory tests are needed for a definitive diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  A 60-year-old Caucasian male named John Smith presents to his primary care provider's office complaining of several weeks of unexplained fatigue  fever  night sweats  weight loss  and muscle aches. He reports that his symptoms have progressively gotten worse over the past month. He states he has a history of intravenous drug use but has been clean for five years. During his drug use period  he used to share needles and equipment. He has a past medical history of Hepatitis C related to his former drug use.  John is a construction worker but had to stop working due to his current health status. He indicates he is a smoker but denies consuming any alcohol or illicit drugs. He reports malaise  chills  and shortness of breath. His body temperature is 38.4°C. On physical exam  his heart sounds reveal a new murmur consistent with valvular heart disease.   John has episodes of involuntary weight loss and loss of appetite. No specific allergens were reported  and his current medications include ledipasvir and sofosbuvir for the treatment of Hepatitis C virus for the past 1 year. He denies any recent travels  contacts with sick individuals  or pets at home.   Given his history of IV drug use  his new-onset murmur  and recent symptoms  a diagnosis of infective endocarditis is suspected. An echocardiogram and blood cultures are ordered to further assess this possibility.

Patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use and hypertension  who presents with a 2-week history of fever  non-productive cough  and generalized fatigue. He reports a weight loss of about 10 pounds in this period. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or orthopnea. He also reports poor dental health  stating he hasn't seen a dentist in over 5 years.  Physical exam reveals pallor  poor dentition with dental caries and gingival infection  a grade II/VI systolic murmur heard best at the apex  and multiple non-tender  small purpura in the palms. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Pulse is regular and BP is 150/90 mmHg. Edema is not present in any of his extremities and his pulses are intact. He is alert and oriented to time  place and person.  Patient lives alone and admits to recurrent multiple substance misuse  primarily heroin  for many years; he is not on methadone. His past history includes hypertension for last 10 years controlled with medication  hepatitis C diagnosis 5 years ago  and recurrent skin and soft tissue infections. Previous hospital admission was 3 years ago for treatment of septicemia related to a skin abscess.  He is currently on lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension. Allergies include penicillin  causing rash. There is no known family history of heart disease. He smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily and consumes alcohol sporadically. His diet consists primarily of fast food. He does not exercise regularly.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use and rheumatic heart disease  presenting with complaints of an ongoing high-grade fever for the past 10 days. The fever is continuous  high grade ranging between 38.5-39.5 °C but is non-responsive to over the counter medicines. Mr. Smith also mentions experiencing malaise  night sweats  loss of appetite leading to weight loss  and shortness of breath on exertion. He denies any chest pain  abdominal pain  or history of recent travel or sick contacts.  On examination  he appears cachectic and is temperature is elevated (38.9 °C). He reveals Janeway lesions on his palms and soles  as well as painless  erythematous Osler nodes are identified on his fingers. Cardiovascular examination is significant for a new harsh  grade III/ VI systolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. Oral examination shows poor dentition.  Previously  Smith lacked regular medical care and has had intermittent periods of homelessness. He also has a history of chronic back pain for which he used intravenously heroin. He has been previously treated for Hepatitis C infection.  Given his past medical history and recent complaints  the differential is broad. However his fever  new murmurs  along with other findings pointing to septicemia (malaise  night sweats  loss of appetite leading to weight loss) suggests a high possibility of infective endocarditis  which is being tested for confirmation.   Mr. Smith's rheumatic heart disease and past of IV drug use are relevant experiences that increase his risk for infective endocarditis. Rheumatic heart disease may have caused structural changes to his heart  potentially making it more susceptible to infection. Intravenous drug use is another major risk factor for infective endocarditis  as bacteria can enter the bloodstream through needle-based drug administration. His history of poor oral hygiene can also be a potential source for bacteremia.

Patient Information: Mr. A. Johnson  a 72-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaint: Fever  weakness & shortness of breath.  History of Present Illness: The patient reports having a persistent low-grade fever for the last 2 weeks  accompanied by in-growing fatigue and weakness. He also acknowledges recent instances of shortness of breath with minimal exertion.  Past Medical History: The patient has a documented history of severe periodontal disease and has undergone multiple invasive dental procedures. He also has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both of which are managed with diet  exercise  and medication.  Family History: Nil significant.  Review of Systems: Denies chest pain but admits to weight loss over the past month. Reports experiencing night sweats and on further inquiry  also admits to observing blood in his sputum occasionally. He denies any changes in bowel or bladder habits.  Physical Examination: The patient's temperature is 38.5 degrees Celsius. Heart rate 110 beats per minute  blood pressure 135/85 mmHg  and respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute. Cardiovascular examination reveals a new regurgitant murmur on auscultation. Skin exam demonstrates splinter hemorrhages under the nails. Intraoral exam reveals severe periodontal disease.   Provisional Diagnosis: Based on the patient's symptoms  physical examination  and past medical history  a preliminary diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis is suspected.   Plan: The patient will undergo relevant diagnostic studies including blood cultures and Transesophageal Echocardiogram (TEE) to confirm the diagnosis. Antibiotic therapy will be commenced based on culture result. A consultation with cardiothoracic surgery for a possible heart valve replacement will be considered depending on the results obtained.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Clara is a 65-year-old Caucasian woman retired school teacher who presents to the clinic with complaints of low-grade fever persisting for the past three weeks along with fatigue  shortness of breath and weight loss. She has also been experiencing occasional night sweats and a newly appeared mild skin rash. Upon further questioning  she reports a subtle change in behavior  akin to mild confusion off and on  attributed earlier to age-related memory loss.  Mrs. Clara has a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension  and she's a non-smoker. Also  she has a past surgical history of a dental procedure undertaken two months ago. She is taking Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. There is no known drug allergy and no family history of cardiac issues.  She lives by herself and is in general  independent for daily activities. She denies illicit drug use or high-risk sexual activities. Immunization is up to date  and the patient does not travel internationally frequently.  On clinical examination  her BP is 130/80 mmHg; HR is 90 bpm; febrile  with temperature 38.5°C; RR is 20 breaths per minute; saturating 96% on room air. Cardiovascular examination reveals a new systolic murmur best heard at the upper right sternal border and Janeway lesions on her palms. Her neurological exam is slightly abnormal with mild confusion during the interview.  Given her symptoms  clinical findings  coupled with her recent dental procedure  there is a suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis  and further diagnostic evaluation is undertaken.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian female  a retired school teacher  complaining of persistent fever peaking at 101.5°F  night sweats  fatigue  and a new murmur observed during a routine medical checkup. She has remote history of dental procedures about three months ago but denies the use of intravenous drugs or engaging in high-risk behaviors. Her medical history is notable for rheumatic heart disease and a mitral valve prolapse with moderate regurgitation  diagnosed 10 years back. She is currently under watchful waiting and receives no medications. She neither smokes nor drinks alcohol.  The patient is visibly fatigued and in mild discomfort. The physical examination reveals mild pallor  a diastolic murmur heard best at the apical area  and a few petechiae on the conjunctiva and the oral mucosa. There is no evidence of peripheral stigmata of endocarditis such as Osler nodes  Janeway lesions  or splinter hemorrhages under the nails.  Based on the presentation  though blood cultures are still pending  the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis secondary to her underlying mitral valve disorder  possibly following her recent dental procedure  is strongly considered.

A 60-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. Allen  presents with a one-week history of fever  fatigue  and what he describes as an unsettling weight loss over the past month. He also reported experiencing shortness of breath  particularly on exertion.   He is a retired construction worker and is a current smoker with a 20 pack-year history. His past medical history includes hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  both managed through medication. Mr. Allen underwent dental procedures three weeks prior and was given prophylaxis for infective endocarditis due to his hypertension.   On review of systems  he also had low-level persistent chest discomfort with night sweats. No symptoms or history suggestive of immunodeficiency  rheumatoid arthritis  or malignancy were present.  On examination  he presented with a temperature of 38.4°C (101.1°F)  heart rate of 90 per minute  and blood pressure of 140/85mmHg. Cardiovascular examination revealed a soft systolic ejection murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. Oral examination revealed a poor dentition.

A 58-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with complaints of persistent fatigue  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss over the past three weeks. He also reports intermittent fevers but could not quantify their severity. The symptoms started mildly but have progressively worsened. In the last week  he has started experiencing shortness of breath  especially when he tries to perform regular activities.  The patient has a past medical history significant for intravenous drug use (Heroin)  stopped two years ago. He is currently on methadone treatment. He had a septicemia episode four years ago associated with his drug use. The patient reports he has not had any surgery in the past and has not been recently hospitalized. He has a known allergy to penicillin  manifesting as a skin rash. He quit smoking one and a half years ago after being a smoker for 20 years  and he is not a known alcoholic.   On physical examination  he is febrile (38.5 C)  with a blood pressure of 125/70 mmHg  pulse 98/min  respiratory rate 20/min  and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Examination reveals pale skin  mild peripheral edema  and a noticeable cardiac murmur on auscultation. The patient also has Janeway lesions (erythematous  nontender macules on the palms and soles) suggestive of bacterial endocarditis. Laboratory studies reveal mild anemia  leukocytosis  and elevated inflammatory markers (C-Reactive Protein and ESR). ECG  chest X-ray  and transthoracic echocardiography are ordered.  Concerns include possible infective endocarditis  which should be confirmed with further tests  such as blood cultures and transesophageal echocardiography if required. Urgent cardiology consultation is advised given the severity of presentation and increased risk of complications due to the patient’s history of intravenous drug use.

Patient Presentation  A 65-year-old Caucasian male patient comes into the clinic complaining of a persisting low-grade fever for the past three weeks  intermittent chills  night sweats  loss of appetite  and recent unexplained weight loss of approximately 5 kilograms. He also reports feeling fatigued and notes a persistent  mild headache.  He has a known history of mitral valve prolapse that was diagnosed five years ago  but is otherwise generally healthy. He does not smoke  drinks alcohol in moderate amounts  and denies any illicit drug use. A dental procedure was performed about four weeks ago.   His vitals reveal a temperature of 38.5 degrees Celsius. Cardiovascular examination reveals a diastolic murmur over the apex. Rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Labs reveal elevated ESR and CRP levels. Further diagnostic testing including transthoracic echocardiogram and multiple blood cultures over time are ordered to confirm the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Presentation  Mr. Jack Stone  a 60-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department. He is a retired construction worker who lives alone. He has a 20 pack-year smoking history. He has a known history of intravenous drug use  but he has been abstinent for about 15 years now.  Mr. Stone complains of recurrent fever  night sweats  and fatigue for the past three weeks. He also noted unexplained weight loss and shortness of breath that has been persistent for the past week. There is no chest pain  nausea  vomiting  palpitations  cough  or sinus congestion. He also mentioned a new onset of lower back pain and intermittent headaches.  A review of his medical record showed well-controlled hypertension (on Lisinopril 10mg daily)  type 2 diabetes mellitus (on Metformin 500mg twice daily)  and a previous episode of Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia treated successfully about 2 years ago with IV antibiotics.  On physical examination  Mr. Stone appeared pale and tired. Vital signs were notable for fever (100.9°F)  tachycardia (rate of 108 beats per minute)  and hypotension (BP 100/60 mmHg). Cardiac auscultation showed a new grade 3/6 late-peaking systolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. Janeway's lesions were observed on his palms and soles which he hadn’t noticed before. Neurological examination showed a positive Kernig's sign suggestive of meningeal irritation.  Given Mr. Stone's clinical presentation and past medical history  there is a high suspicion for native valvular infective endocarditis with possible secondary septic embolization. Hematological tests  blood cultures  and a transthoracic echocardiography are planned to confirm the initial diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Diaz  a 64-year-old Hispanic male  presents to the clinic with a 2-week history of intermittent high-grade fever  malaise  and night sweats. He has also experienced unintentional loss of appetite and weight loss over the period. He notes a new onset of a heart murmur that was not present earlier. He denies chest pain  cough  or shortness of breath.  Mr. Diaz has a past medical history significant for rheumatic fever during childhood with no subsequent heart-related complications. He has no known allergies and does not consume alcohol  smoke tobacco  or use any illicit drugs.  On physical examination  he appears generally unwell and fatigued. Vital sign assessment shows a temperature of 38.8°C  a heart rate of 102 bpm  a respiratory rate of 18 breaths/min  and a blood pressure of 132/82 mmHg. Cardiac auscultation reveals a new-onset  3/6 scale  systolic murmur best heard at the apex. Examination of the extremities uncovers petechiae on his palms and soles and Janeway lesions on the palms of both hands.  His history of rheumatic fever  the presence of high-grade fever  new-onset murmurs  and cutaneous manifestations are indicative of potential infective endocarditis affecting a native valve  but further diagnostic studies are needed for confirmation.

Chief Complaint: ""I have been feeling weak with chills and sweating.""  Demographics: The patient is a 60-year-old white female named Mrs. Jane who lives with her husband in a suburban area.   History of Present Illness:  Over the past three weeks  she has experienced intermittent fever  chills  night sweats  fatigue  loss of appetite  and unexplained weight loss. She also noticed a red  painful lump on her right finger and small reddish spots on her skin. She reports no chest pain or palpitations but has had some shortness of breath with exertion. She sought medical advice as her symptoms have persisted and seemed to gradually increase with time.   Past Medical History: Mrs. Jane has a known history of mitral valve prolapse. She underwent a minor dental procedure two months ago. Her other medical history includes well-controlled diabetes mellitus and slightly high cholesterol levels. She doesn't smoke and seldom drinks alcohol.   Family History: Not relevant. Her parents passed due to old age  without any significant cardiac health issues.  Medications: She takes Metformin 500 mg twice daily for her diabetes  and Simvastatin 10mg daily before bedtime.  Social/Environmental History: She is a retired teacher  living with her husband. They have two adult children who live separately. She does not smoke  and alcohol usage is occasional. She is moderately active and is involved in her community's social services.   Review of Systems: Positive for fatigue  malaise  sporadic fevers  weight loss  shortness of breath with exertion  and skin changes. Negative for chest pain  pedal edema  cough  altered sensorium  and abdominal symptoms.   Physical Exam: Ill-looking  pale  diaphoretic  with low-grade fever. Newly developed systolic murmur heard best at the apex  and a red  tender lump (Osler's nodes) on the right ring finger. Also  her skin shows non-blanching petechiae on her extremities (Janeway lesions).  All these findings indicate a high suspicion of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis  which needs further evaluation through imaging and blood culture. Considering her mitral valve prolapse and invasive dental procedure  she is at risk of an infection.

Patient Presentation:  A 62-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for intravenous drug use  hepatitis C  and homelessness presented to the emergency department with a complaint of progressive malaise  weight loss  night sweats  and low-grade fevers over the past several weeks. The patient also reported experiencing a new onset of intermittent sharp  localized chest pain which increased with deep breathing. He had started noticing the appearance of small  dark red spots on the palms and soles about a week ago. The patient reports no recent dental procedures or surgeries. He denied any history of heart-related ailments or any rheumatic fever in childhood.  He is a current smoker  a known IV drug user and has a history of noncompliance with medications. He is not under any medication currently. His vitals were stable on presentation with a heart rate of 90 beats per minute  blood pressure of 135/89 mmHg  respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute  temperature of 37.8 degrees Celsius  and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Physical examination revealed the presence of a new-onset cardiac murmur on auscultation.  Several non-tender  erythematous macular lesions were noted on his palms and soles. Few subungual hemorrhages were also identified. No significant peripheral edema was noticed.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 50-year-old male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use and Hepatitis C who presents with a fever of 101.5 F  fatigue  night sweats  weight loss  and shortness of breath for the past two weeks. He also reports a new-onset heart murmur  and small red spots appearing on his palms and soles.  The deleterious lifestyle of the patient including drug abuse could have borne a gateway for the microbes to enter the bloodstream and infect the heart valves causing native-valve infective endocarditis. Given the nature of his symptoms  there may also be indications of complications  such as heart failure or sepsis  which necessitate further investigation.

Patient Information: 68-year-old Caucasian male  Chief Complaint: New-onset shortness of breath  low-grade fever  and malaise  History of Present Illness: The patient describes experiencing generalized malaise  subjective fevers  and increasing shortness of breath over the past 3 weeks. Symptoms have gradually been worsening and are associated with night sweats.  Past Medical History: The patient has moderate rheumatic heart disease with prior history of acute rheumatic fever at age 12 which left him with a damaged mitral valve. He also has hypertension  high cholesterol  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He quit smoking 15 years ago  and drinks alcohol occasionally. He denies using any illicit drugs.  Medications: The patient is currently taking Metformin for his diabetes  as well as Lisinopril and a statin for his hypertension and hypercholesterolemia.  Social History: The patient lives with his wife of 40 years. He is retired and has a history of working in construction.  Physical exam: Vitals are abnormal with a temperature of 38.1°C  HR 92 bpm  BP 136/88 mmHg  RR 18 bpm  and SpO2 of 95% room air. Cardiac examination reveals a new regurgitant murmur. Further investigations show changes in the EKG and blood tests consistent with native valve infective endocarditis.  Family history: Both his parents had cardio-vascular diseases. His father died from a heart attack and his mother had a stroke. He has two brothers that are still alive and well. His only child is an adult female who is healthy.   Summary: This is a 68-year-old gentleman with a significant history of rheumatic heart disease  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes presenting with symptoms suggestive of native valve infective endocarditis likely secondary to his underlying valvular disease. The patient will require further diagnostic evaluation to confirm the diagnosis and determine the appropriate therapeutic plan.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Doe is a 63-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department with two weeks history of fever  chills  night sweats  and unexplained weight loss. Primary complaints include severe fatigue and a new onset of shortness of breath. Examination reveals a diastolic murmur on cardiac auscultation  and Osborne waves (J waves) and ST elevation on Electrocardiogram.   Relevant Past Medical History includes intravenous drug abuse in the younger years which he reports to have stopped over 10 years ago  history of Hepatitis C infection  and a recently completed 14-day course of antibiotics for cellulitis on his forearm.   Family history is significant for Hypertension with his deceased father but has no record of any hereditary diseases. Social history consists of tobacco use up until he was 30 and alcohol consumption only on social gatherings.  The patient lives with his wife but they have no kids or pets. He is an ex-automobile mechanic and now works as a handyman. His main concern was the interference of these symptoms with his work.  Thus  considering the patient's history of IV drug abuse  recent infection  and specific clinical findings  a concern for Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis is raised that demands further investigation and management.

Demographic Details: Patient: Mr. Austin Gender: Male Age: 69 Occupationally Retired Ethnicity: Caucasian  Past Medical History: Mr. Austin has a long-standing history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and dyslipidemia. He is an ex-smoker and quit 15 years ago. He shows evidence of stable coronary artery disease diagnosed 8 years ago and has a past history of mild congestive heart failure. He also has had chronic stage-3 kidney disease for the last 5 years. He has a history of dental extractions and routine dental procedures  but no record of prophylactic antibiotics use.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Austin was brought to the emergency department by his son with complaints of progressively worsening fatigue  dyspnoea on exertion  low-grade fever  chills  new onset confusion  and a loss of appetite for the last three weeks. His son reported that Austin's color appeared to be pale recently and he experienced periods of drowsiness and unresponsiveness  and his skin was cooler to the touch.  Clinical Examination: On examination  he was in a state of obvious discomfort  diaphoretic  and looked acutely ill. His vitals were unstable with BP - 90/60 mmHg  pulse - 102/min  Temp- 100.6 F  and altered mental status. On cardiovascular examination  he had a new systolic murmur best heard at the cardiac apex. He also had evidence of mild pedal pitting edema. Digital clubbing was seen and splinter hemorrhages were noticeable under his nails.  Probable Diagnosis: The clinical symptomatic presentation of Mr. Austin with signs of an infection and the new systolic murmur indicates a possible diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. Further diagnostic tests  including blood cultures and transesophageal echocardiogram  should be ordered to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Profile: A 60-year-old Caucasian male was admitted complaining of fever  chills  and increasing general malaise for the past month. Also reported severe night sweats and a noticeable weight loss of nearly 10 lbs in the past two weeks. He recently had a dental procedure (scaling and root planing) performed about 2 months ago.   Past Medical History:  The patient has past medical history of significant cardiac issues  including a diagnosis of mitral valve prolapse. Additionally  he has mild hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes  both of which are under control via medication. He is allergic to penicillin  causing a severe skin rash. He is a retired mechanic and an ex-smoker  having quit 15 years ago. He admits drinking alcohol sporadically.   At present  the patient appears fatigued and in pain  with a consistent low-grade fever of 100.4°F. Exam found a new murmur in the heart sounds  suggesting possible involvement of the heart valve. Palpable purpura was also noted on the lower extremities. Laboratory results showed elevated WBC counts  increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and positive blood cultures for Staphylococcus aureus. Imaging reports suggested echogenic vegetation on mitral valve suggestive of endocarditis.   The symptomatic and laboratory findings coupled with the recent dental procedure suggest possible native-valve infective endocarditis. The patient was admitted for IV antibiotic treatment and close monitoring of cardiac function.

Patient Profile:   - Age: 56-year-old  - Sex: Male  - Occupation: Construction worker  - Ethnicity: Hispanic   Chief Complaint: Fever and weakness for the past one week  Presenting Symptoms:   - The patient has been experiencing a persistent high-grade fever for the past 7 days  accompanied by generalized weakness.  - He reported shortness of breath  especially on exertion  persistent dry cough  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss.  - He also reported experiencing intermittent drenching night sweats. - He developed new-onset lower-back pain and a few red tender spots on the soles of his feet. - There is also a complaint of loss of appetite and a feeling of general run-down.  Relevant Past Medical History:   - He has a known case of Mitral Valve Prolosis (backflow of blood because the valve doesn’t close tightly). He was diagnosed 10 years ago during a routine medical examination.  - He also has a history of recurrent dental abscesses  for which he undergone multiple dental surgeries. His last surgery was 2 months ago for an infected tooth.   Social History:  - The patient is a chronic smoker with a history of smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years.  - He occasionally drinks alcohol  mostly during social gatherings.  - He denies any current or past use of intravenous drugs.  Physical Examination:  - High-grade fever (102 F) - An irregular heart rhythm was noted. - A cardiac examination revealed a mid-diastolic murmur best heard at the apex (Mitral Region). - Skin examination showed Osler's nodes.  Investigations:  Sample drawn for blood cultures. Echocardiography is planned to confirm the clinical suspicion.   Diagnosis Status: The presentation is suspicious for native-valve infective endocarditis  pending confirmatory tests.

Patient Presentation:  A 47-year-old woman presented to the outpatient clinic reporting a 4-week history of intermittent fevers  generalized body weakness  occasional night sweats  shortness of breath and a poor appetite. She also reported that she had lost approximately 5 kilograms in weight over the past month without trying. Her past medical history was significant for intravenous (IV) drug use  which she stated she stopped approximately 1 year ago.  She reported having a dental extraction procedure performed about 6 weeks prior and mentioned they did not administer antibiotics before the procedure.  Physical examination revealed oral thrush  a new systolic regurgitation murmur best heard at the mitral area  smaller purple-colored spots on her skin (Janeway lesions) and a single larger tender  raised  erythematous lesion on her left thumb.   She has chronic Hepatitis C from past IV drug use but denied any known cardiovascular conditions. She has been in methadone maintenance therapy for opioid use disorder for the past 12 months. Her last normal menstrual period was 3 weeks ago and she denied any possibility of being pregnant. Socially  she works as a librarian and resides alone but has supportive family in the same city. She is a non-smoker and denies any alcohol use.  The rest of the physical examination  including a neurologic examination  was normal. No congenital heart disease was found. Chest radiograph and EKG were normal. Repeat blood cultures were drawn and serologic tests were sent to the lab. The patient was admitted for suspected native-valve infective endocarditis probably secondary to her dental procedure in the context of past IV drug use.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of intermittent fever  chills  night sweats  as well as increasing fatigue. The patient also reports experiencing a loss of appetite leading to unintentional weight loss over the last few weeks. He denies any recent travel  sick contacts  or any known infection.  Past medical history reveals poorly controlled diabetes mellitus type 2 and a history of drug abuse in his 20s  though he has remained sober for the last 30 years. He is unaware of any heart disease in his past and has never had echocardiogram or any other heart evaluation.  Examination reveals pallor and scattered petechiae on his limbs. He is febrile with a temperature of 38.5°C with an irregular heart rate. Cardiac auscultation detects a new murmur. Initial blood tests show evidence of anemia  leukocytosis as well as elevated inflammatory markers such as CRP and ESR. His blood cultures are currently pending.  Taken together  these findings would be suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis. The patient's history of drug abuse (although happened a long time back) along with the uncontrolled diabetes and the presence of new cardiac murmur increases the chances. However  diagnosis would be confirmed with the results of blood cultures  and echocardiogram would be used to further delineate the condition of the heart valves.

Demographic Details: Patient's Name: John Doe Age: 65 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Lifestyle: Non-smoker  occasional drinker   Presenting Complaint:  Mr. John Doe presented to the ER with a three-week history of persistent  low-grade fever  malaise  and unintentional weight loss of approximately 10 lbs. He also expressed concerns over a new  unusual heart murmur he had noticed.  Past Medical History: He is a known patient of Type-II diabetes mellitus under control with medications. He had a previous diagnosis of Rheumatic fever when he was a teenager  with subsequent emergence of aortic stenosis in his adult life which was managed conservatively. He doesn't have any known allergies.  Physical Examination: On examination  he appeared acutely ill and lethargic. Cardiovascular examination detected a new diastolic murmur at the right second intercostal space. A low-grade fever was noted (38.2C). Skin appeared pale with mild jaundice. There were noticeable Osler's nodes on his fingers and toes  additionally small  erythematous  round spots (Janeway lesions) were apparent on palms and soles.  Investigations: He was admitted for further investigations including blood cultures  echocardiogram  Complete blood count (CBC)  Liver function tests  and kidney function tests.  Differential Diagnosis: Infective Endocarditis  Rheumatic fever  Subacute bacterial endocarditis  Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis.  This case presentation is suspicious for Infective Endocarditis given the patient's new-onset murmur and additional systemic symptoms such as fever  weight loss  and the presence of Osler’s nodes and Janeway lesions. The patient's history of Rheumatic fever and subsequent aortic stenosis increases his risk for infective endocarditis.

Subjective:  A 64-year-old  Caucasian male tiler who smokes about half a pack of cigarettes per day  and drinks alcohol socially is admitted to the emergency department. The patient's chief complaint is intermittent  high-grade fevers for the past two weeks. Fevers are associated with chills  nights sweats  loss of appetite and fatigue. He also reports a recent  rapid weight loss of approximately 8 lbs within this duration. He has no known allergies. Patient has a significant past medical history of type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension and aortic stenosis diagnosed 5 years ago. He is on medications including metformin  atenolol  and losartan.  Objective:  Upon examination  he appeared ill-looking. Current temperature was 38.5 degrees Celsius. Blood pressure is elevated at 160/90 mmHg. Heart rate was irregular and tachycardic at 106 beats/minute. His oral examination showed poor dentition.  Cardiovascular examination revealed an early diastolic decrescendo murmur heard best at the left third intercostal space in the parasternal area. Skin examination showed Osler’s nodes on palms and soles and Janeway lesions were observed.  Investigations:  Lab test results: White blood cell count  erythrocyte sedimentation rate  C-reactive protein were all elevated. Blood culture results showed growth of Streptococcus viridans. Echocardiography was performed and revealed vegetations on the aortic valve.  Assessment:  These findings  in context of the patient's chronic valve disease  suggest a diagnosis of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis.  Plan:  The plan is to start aggressive antibiotic therapy as guided by culture sensitivity. Cardiothoracic surgery consultation was also initiated for further management and a discussion on possible valve replacement. The patient should also attend follow-up appointments and regular screenings for cardiological vascular health. He should be counseled on the importance of dental hygiene  smoking cessation  and alcohol moderation  which can all contribute to the development of endocarditis and its complications.

Title: A Clinical Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 1: Patient Demographics  Name: John Doe Age: 56 years old Sex: Male Occupation: Office Worker Lifestyle: Non-smoker  Social drinker  Non-drug user  Slide 2: Past Medical History  John was diagnosed with moderate aortic stenosis at age 45  for which he did not undergo any surgical intervention. Besides  he has a controlled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  and no history of drug allergies.   Slide 3: Presenting Issue  Recently  John has been experiencing episodes of intermittent fever  loss of appetite  and unexplained weight loss over the past 6 weeks. He also mentioned fatigue and occasional night sweats.  Slide 4: Physical Examination  Upon evaluation  John was febrile with temperature of 100.8°F and had a new onset mild systolic murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border. There were also small  non-tender red lesions observed on his palms and soles  characteristic of Janeway lesions.  Slide 5: Diagnostic Findings  Investigations showed elevated ESR and CRP levels  indicating ongoing inflammation. His blood culture was positive for Staphylococcus aureus. An echocardiogram revealed aortic valve vegetations  further leading to a probable diagnosis of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis.  Slide 6: Management and Discussion  John was promptly started on intravenous antibiotics  as per IDSA guidelines for Staphylococcus aureus endocarditis. During the course of therapy  he’ll be closely monitored for his symptoms to evaluate treatment response.   Slide 7: Conclusion   This case underscores the necessity for early diagnosis and close monitoring of patients with heart valve abnormalities  like aortic stenosis  since they are at a heightened risk of developing debilitating conditions like infective endocarditis.

Slide 1 - Introduction: Today we will review a case involving a patient with native-valve infective endocarditis. This case showcases the importance of early diagnosis and treatment  as well as educating patients on associated risk factors  which can help prevent further complications.  Slide 2 - Patient Demographics: The patient is a 50-year-old Caucasian male  who has been a long-term smoker. He works as a plumber and is in contact with water frequently.  Slide 3 - Past Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with mild hypertension 10 years ago and is currently using ACE inhibitors. He has had a couple of episodes of transient ischemic attack (TIA) in the past two years  for which he is on aspirin. He was also diagnosed with a mitral valve prolapse at his last annual check-up but has no family history of heart disease.  Slide 4 - Presenting Complaints: The patient reported fever  chills  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss. In the last few weeks  he's experienced episodes of breathlessness  and in the last couple of days  he’s complained about a persistent cough and moderate chest pain.  Slide 5 - Physical Examination: Upon physical examination  we noted that he had a diastolic murmur  and Janeway's lesions were observed  indicative of possible endocarditis. These red spots on the palms and soles are a classic symptom of the condition.  Slide 6 - Diagnostic Findings: Blood cultures identified Staphylococcus aureus  confirming the suspicion of infective endocarditis. Echocardiogram has revealed vegetation on the mitral valve. Typically  this patient’s occupation  smoking habits  mitral valve issue  and Staphylococcus aureus identify him as being at high risk for infective endocarditis.  Slide 7 - Plan of Action: A course of antibiotics to cover Staphylococcus aureus has been initiated intravenously. In addition  the cardiology team is consulted for the consideration of surgery  as there is a high risk of embolization or heart failure considering the vegetation's size.  Slide 8 - Conclusion: Appropriate antibiotic management along with cardiac surgery (if required) are keys to survival for patients suffering from native-valve infective endocarditis. Additionally  patient education on modification of lifestyle habits is a crucial part in mitigating the risk of future recurrence. Prevention is far better than cure.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis - A Patient Case Study  Slide 1: Introduction - Patient Profile:     - Age: 60 years old     - Sex: Male     - Occupation: Retired Teacher     - Location: Rural area  Slide 2: Demographics - Familial background: No history of congenital heart disease in the family. - Lifestyle: non-smoker  moderate alcohol consumer  largely sedentary lifestyle.  Slide 3: Past Medical History - Chronic Conditions: Hypertension  Type II Diabetes - Previous Surgeries: One appendix removal in childhood - Allergies: Penicillin  Slide 4: Current Presentation - Patient presented with a two-week history of intermittent fever  joint ache  fatigue  shortness of breath  night sweats  and unintended weight loss.  Slide 5: Clinical Examination - Physical examination revealed a systolic murmur and the appearance of petechiae on the patient's lower extremities.   Slide 6: Provisional Diagnosis - Considering the presenting symptoms and findings on physical examination  a provisional diagnosis of Native-valve Infective Endocarditis was suggested.  Slide 7: Investigations and Final Diagnosis - Blood cultures were tested along with an Echocardiogram. Growth of Staphylococcus aureus in blood culture and vegetations on the native heart valves under Echocardiogram confirmed the diagnosis of Native-valve Infective Endocarditis.   Slide 8: Treatment & Management  - Informed patient about the diagnosis and the need for hospitalization for treatment. - Started on a suitable antibiotic regimen (vancomycin administered intravenously due to penicillin allergy).  - Patient carefully monitored to assess the efficacy of treatment and potential side-effects of the antibiotics.  Slide 9: Follow-up and Prognosis - Patient responded well to the antibiotic therapy; follow-up Echocardiogram showed reduced vegetations. - Early detection and prompt treatment contributed to a favorable prognosis. - Advised lifestyle modifications including regular exercise and diet control to manage diabetes and hypertension to reduce the reoccurrence risk.  Slide 10: Conclusion - The case highlights the importance of considering endocarditis in patients showing multiple systemic symptoms  even in the absence of an immediately apparent cardiac cause.  - Early diagnosis and appropriate treatment marked the success of this case which could have otherwise resulted in severe complications.   Slide 11: Questions - Open the floor to questions and discussions regarding the case.

Slide 1: Introduction  Title: Case Presentation: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  - Sex: Male - Age: 65 years - Occupation: Retired - Social History: Non-smoker  drinks alcohol occasionally  Slide 3: Past Medical History  - Hypertension: Diagnosed 12 years ago  well-controlled with medication - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed 8 years ago  on daily oral hypoglycemic - History of a dental procedure: Underwent a tooth extraction 2 months back without any antibiotic prophylaxis - No known allergies  Slide 4: Presenting Complaints  - Fever  Fatigue  Shortness of breath - Subtle signs like weight loss and night sweats - New heart murmur was heard on physical examination  Slide 5: Investigations Progress:  - Blood tests: Elevated white blood cells  high ESR (Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate)  positive blood cultures. - Chest Radiography: Unspecific findings - Echocardiography: Thickened and calcified aortic valves with vegetations  Slide 6: Diagnosis   - Based on the clinical presentation  physical examination  and investigative results  the patient was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis  most likely secondary to the dental procedure. Slide 1: Introduction Today  we are going to discuss a case relating to native-valve infective endocarditis  a serious cardiovascular disease resulting from bacteria or fungi attaching and growing on the heart's valve surfaces or endocardium.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics The patient is a 67-year-old African American male. He lives in a suburban community and is a retired construction worker. He is a widower with three adult children and is a nonsmoker  although he used to be a heavy smoker up until 10 years ago.  Slide 3: Medical History and Lifestyle The patient has a medical history of Type II diabetes  hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he has been taking medications. He has a BMI of 28.1 and has been diagnosed as overweight. His diet is moderate in salt and fats. The patient also reports social drinking.  Slide 4: Presenting Symptoms The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of persistent fever  fatigue  loss of appetite  and weight loss over the past two months. On closer examination  there were noticeable petechiae in the conjunctiva of both eyes.  Slide 5: Clinical Findings Physical examination revealed a diastolic heart murmur suggestive of valvular disease. Lab results showed elevated ESR  CRP  and white blood cell count. An Echocardiogram revealed a mass on the mitral valve showing evidence for valvular vegetations.  Slide 6: Diagnosis Taking into account the patient’s symptoms  physical findings  and the echocardiogram results  he has been diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Slide 7: Treatment and Monitoring The patient is currently on intravenous antibiotic therapy. He is being closely monitored for signs of heart failure and embolic events. Potential surgical treatment options  such as valve replacement  may be considered if medical management is unsuccessful.  Slide 8: Discussion  Infective endocarditis is a potentially lethal disease. Early diagnosis and appropriate treatment are crucial. Despite recent advances in medical and surgical treatment  mortality remains high  especially in elderly patients and those with certain complications. Key to improving outcomes is early recognition and timely intervention.      Slide 9: Conclusion This case highlights the significant health risk posed by native-valve infective endocarditis and the importance of ongoing vigilance and timely treatment  particularly in high-risk populations such as our patient.
