Title: An Illustrative Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 1: Introduction - Native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE) involves the infection of a native heart valve  most commonly caused by bacteria entering the bloodstream and attaching to the heart's lining  a valve or a blood vessel. Today we will discuss the case of a patient diagnosed with NVIE.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics - Case: Mr.Jones - Age: 67 - Gender: Male - Profession: Retired accountant - lifestyle: Sedentary  smoker for the past 40 years  moderate alcohol consumption  Slide 3: Presenting symptoms and history - Symptoms: Mr Jones presented with general weakness  moderate to severe fatigue  loss of appetite  weight loss  fever  chills  night sweats  and shortness of breath.  - Onset: Symptoms began gradually  worsening over the period of 2 weeks - Previous care: Mr Jones initially self-medicated with over-the-counter fever and cough medication with no relief.   Slide 4: Past Medical History - Mr Jones has a history of type II diabetes  hypertensive heart disease  and gingivitis. - He underwent a gallbladder removal surgery 5 years ago. - Mr Jones has been managing his diabetes and hypertension with metformin and lisinopril respectively.  Slide 5: Clinical Findings - Physical Examination: Fever (38.5 C)  heart murmur detected  tenderness in the spleen area  positive Roth’s spots in the eyes  and Osler’s nodes on hands and feet - Laboratory Findings: Elevated ESR  CRP. Blood cultures positive for Streptococcus viridans.  Slide 6: Diagnosis - Based on the clinical findings  history and positive blood culture report  Mr. Jones was diagnosed with Native-valve infective endocarditis.  Slide 7: Future steps and prognosis - The patient was recommended with immediate hospitalization. Antibiotic treatment was started following the advice of Infectious Disease and Cardiology teams. - Patient education on lifestyle modifications was provided to reduce the risk of future episodes. - With treatment  his prognosis is fair  though monitoring for complications will be necessary as untreated NVIE can lead to serious complications including stroke  heart failure  and septicemia.   Slide 8: Key takeaway - This case reinforces the importance of early detection and management of NVIE  particularly in patients with predisposing factors such as poor oral hygiene and systemic disorders like diabetes and hypertension  often associated with NVIE. It is crucial to ensure adequate patient education and adherence to medication and lifestyle changes for maintaining a healthy heart.   Slide 9: Conclusion - In conclusion  health care providers should maintain a high index of suspicion for IE in patients with predisposing factors presenting with nonspecific symptoms and fever.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis: A Case Study  Slide 1: Introduction  In this presentation  we will discuss a case of a patient with native-valve infective endocarditis (IE)  delving into the patient's demographics  medical history  presentation  diagnosis  and treatment.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics Our patient  Mr. J  is a 58-year-old Caucasian male. He works as a plumber and is a non-smoker. However  he does have a history of moderate alcohol consumption. Mr. J lives in an urban setting and is exposed to various environmental factors.  Slide 3: Past Medical History In terms of medical history  Mr. J was diagnosed with Rheumatic Fever at age 7  which was successfully treated at that time. Also noteworthy  he had a major dental procedure 3 weeks prior to the onset of his current symptoms - a potential entry point for bacteria into the bloodstream.  Slide 4: History of Present Illness Mr. J presented at the ER with fever  malaise  and weight loss over the past two weeks. Furthermore  he’s been complaining of shortness of breath and intermittent chest pain over the last few days. On physical examination  he was found to have a new systolic murmur.  Slide 5: Diagnosis Blood culture results showed Staphylococcus aureus  consistent with infective endocarditis. An echocardiogram confirmed vegetations on the native mitral valve  cementing the diagnosis of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis.  Slide 6: Treatment & Management Mr. J was immediately started on empiric antibiotic therapy  including oxacillin plus gentamicin and rifampin for MRSA coverage. His treatment was readjusted according to his culture and sensitivity result. He responded well to medical therapy  and a repeat echocardiogram showed reduced vegetation size. Considering his positive evolution  surgery was not necessary.  Slide 7: Conclusion This case serves as a reminder of the criticality of early diagnosis and prompt treatment of native-valve infective endocarditis. It further underscores the potential sequalae of untreated dental procedures  and the importance of preventative measures among high-risk individuals.   Slide 8: Questions & Discussion We welcome any questions or discussions about this case or related circumstances.

Sure  here is a short case presentation:  SLIDE 1: Title: A Case Presentation of: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  SLIDE 2: Introduction: Infective Endocarditis (IE) represents an infection of the endocardial surface of the heart. It often involves valves  and they may either be native or prosthetic.  SLIDE 3: Patient Demographics: Presenting a 45-year-old male patient named Mr. X. He is a tobacco smoker with a 15-pack-years history and works as a construction worker.   SLIDE 4: Past Medical History: Mr. X has known case of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He also has a history of dental procedure 3 weeks ago but did not take any antibiotic prophylaxis.  SLIDE 5: Presenting Concerns: Mr. X visited the emergency room presenting symptoms of high-grade fever with chills for a week  along with fatigue  joint pain  and unintentional weight loss.   SLIDE 6: Clinical Findings: He had multiple ecchymotic spots on the skin and the presence of a new onset regurgitative murmur noted on cardiac physical examination. A dental examination revealed poor oral hygiene.  SLIDE 7:  Investigations: Blood cultures came positive for Streptococcus viridans. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) showed a vegetation on the mitral valve  confirming the diagnosis of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis.  SLIDE 8: Hospital Course and Management: The patient was admitted and started empirically on intravenous Streptococcal coverage with Ceftriaxone and Gentamicin. A consultation with cardiothoracic surgery was made  who recommended medical treatment before contemplating surgical intervention.  SLIDE 9: Key Points for Discussion: The relevance of good oral hygiene in preventing native valve endocarditis. The role of Streptococcus viridans in development of native valve endocarditis linked to dental procedures. The importance of prophylactic antibiotics in high-risk patients before undergoing invasive procedures.  SLIDE 10: Summary and conclusion: Infective endocarditis is a condition that requires early diagnosis and treatment. High index of suspicion is important in the right clinical setting along with timely use of investigations like blood cultures and TEE  as they can be key in preventing morbidity and mortality associated with this condition.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis: A Case Review  Slide 1: Introduction Infective endocarditis is a serious and life-threatening condition characterized by the infection of the endocardial surface of the heart  typically affecting the heart valves. Despite advances in medical and surgical treatment  the morbidity and mortality rates remain high. Today  we will review the case of a patient with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis.  Slide 2: Patient demographics Our patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use. He is Caucasian and lives in an urban environment. His socio-economic status is low  and he has minimal access to primary healthcare services.   Slide 3: Presenting symptoms The patient presented at the emergency department complaining of high fever  fatigue  and significant weight loss for the past three weeks. Upon physical examination  he appeared frail with poor oral hygiene  his temperature was 38.5 degrees Celsius  and he exhibited Janeway lesions on his palms and soles.   Slide 4: Past medical history The patient has a significant past medical history. He is a long-term tobacco smoker and suffers from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He has a decade-long history of intravenous drug use but reports to be clean for the past six months. No former episodes of endocarditis were documented.   Slide 5: Clinical diagnosis Based on the clinical presentation and past medical history  a suspicion for infective endocarditis was raised. Blood cultures were drawn and transesophageal echocardiogram performed  which revealed vegetations on the tricuspid valve  confirming the diagnosis.  Slide 6: Treatment & Management The patient was immediately started on empiric antibiotic therapy  before the blood culture results  due to high clinical suspicion. Upon culture identification of Staphylococcus aureus  a targeted treatment regimen was implemented. Consideration was given for possible valve replacement surgery  but his frail physical condition made him a high-risk surgical candidate.  Slide 7: Conclusion This case underscores the importance of a high index of suspicion for infective endocarditis amongst high-risk patient populations including intravenous drug users. Early detection and appropriate antibiotic treatment are imperative to improve survival rates.   Slide 8: Questions? End slide with an opportunity to ask any questions and a strong closing statement reinforcing the importance of vigilance when treating at-risk patients to minimize the impact of such a serious condition.

Title: A Case Study on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 1: Introduction   Case Report: Male  65 years old  African-American.  This presentation focuses on a case of a 65-year-old African-American male recently diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Slide 2: Past Medical History  The patient has a history of moderate hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both controlled with medication. The patient is also a former smoker and quit 15 years ago.  Slide 3: Symptomatology  The patient presented with intermittent fever  progressive fatigue  and a loss of appetite declining over four weeks. He has no history of drug use or recent surgeries. He also reported experiencing some periodic ""skipped beats"" but has no prior history of cardiac diseases.   Slide 4: Clinical Examination  Upon examination  the patient showed mild tachycardia  a heart murmur  and slight edema in the lower extremities. Splinter hemorrhages were also observed on his fingernails  suggestive of infective endocarditis.  Slide 5: Diagnostic Imaging and Laboratory Tests  An echocardiogram revealed vegetations on the mitral valve and mild regurgitation indicating native valve endocarditis. Blood cultures tested positive to Streptococcus viridans  confirming bacterial infection. Elevated ESR and C-reactive protein levels also suggested systemic inflammation.  Slide 6: Treatment Plan  The patient was started on intravenous penicillin for 4 weeks to target the streptococcal infection and was closely monitored for signs of heart failure or emboli. Surgery was kept as a reserved treatment approach for indications of uncontrolled infection  resistant organisms  or heart failure from severe valve dysfunction.   Slide 7: Patient Education and Follow-up  Patient education about the importance of maintaining dental hygiene and seeking immediate medical attention for new symptoms was emphasized to reduce the risk of recurrent infective endocarditis. Regular follow-up visits for echocardiograms and blood tests were scheduled to monitor progression and ensure successful treatment.   Slide 8: Conclusion  This case emphasizes the importance of early detection of infective endocarditis in patients presenting with non-specific symptoms like unexplained fever and fatigue  especially those with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus. Timely initiation of antibiotic therapy often results in a good prognosis and can reduce the need for surgical interventions.

Presentation Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis: A Clinical Case Study  Slide 1: Introduction  - Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis is a serious and potentially fatal condition characterized by the infection of the endocardial surface of the heart. - If left untreated  this could lead to severe heart damage and other complications.   Slide 2: Case Demographics  - Patient X: 68-year-old Caucasian male  Slide 3: Past Medical History  - History of intravenous drug use in early adulthood. - Diagnosed with Hypertension and Diabetes Type II  but well-managed with medications.  - Undergone dental procedures in the past  but no recent interventions.  Slide 4: Presenting Symptoms and Signs  - Patient complained of constant fatigue  mild fever  weight loss  and occasional night sweats for four weeks. - Physical examination revealed a heart murmur and Janeway lesions.  - Lab tests showed increased ESR (Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate) and CRP (C reactive protein).  Slide 5: Diagnostic Evaluation  - Blood cultures conducted which returned positive for Streptococcus viridans  providing a definitive diagnosis for infective endocarditis. - An echocardiogram visualized vegetation on the mitral valve indicating the presence of native valve endocarditis.   Slide 6: Treatment Plan  - The patient was admitted to the hospital and initiated on a course of intravenous antibiotics.  - The choice antibiotic was a combination of Penicillin and Gentamicin  as per IDSA guidelines for Streptococcus viridans -induced Infective Endocarditis. - Surgical intervention was deemed unnecessary due to the absence of heart failure symptoms and valve perforation. Close monitoring was maintained to ascertain the success of the antibiotic therapy.   Slide 7: Outcome and Follow-up  - Patient had a progressive recovery with complete resolution of symptoms by the end of six weeks of antibiotic treatment.  - Four-week post-discharge cardiovascular examination and echocardiogram showed no evidence of recurrence  illustrating the effectiveness of the treatment regimen. - Follow-up visits planned at three  six  and twelve months post-discharge to assess the patient's condition and prevent any potential relapse.  Slide 8: Conclusion and Learning Points  - This case reinforces the importance of early detection and aggressive treatment of native-valve infective endocarditis to avoid serious cardiac complications. - A high degree of suspicion should be maintained in patients with persistent nonspecific symptoms and a risk factor history such as previous drug use or valvular disease. - Patient education on maintaining good oral hygiene can go a long way in preventing such infections  particularly in those with risk factors such as the elderly and those with underlying comorbidities.   Slide 9: References and Further Reading

Slide 1: Introduction  Title: Case Study: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  Patient's Info: ""Mr. A""  a 62-year-old Caucasian male  from rural background  nonsmoker  lifelong resident of Midwest USA.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  Mr. A has a history of type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and has mentioned recreational drug use during his youth. He is not known to have any allergies. Has had previous bouts of Staph infections in the last six years.  Slide 4: Presenting Complaint The patient reports intermittent fever  chills  fatigue  an unintentional weight loss of 10 pounds over the last two months  and a new-onset heart murmur.  Slide 5: Clinical Examination Upon physical examination  Mr. A looks fatigued  pale with Janeway lesions on palms and soles  and slightly swollen feet. Cardiac auscultation revealed a new systolic heart murmur at the mitral area.  Slide 6: Diagnostic Investigation Microbial culture from blood samples were positive for Streptococcus bovis. Echocardiogram confirmed vegetations on the mitral valve leaflets indicating infective endocarditis.   Slide 7: Conclusion Considering the observed clinical symptoms  medical history  and diagnostic investigations  Mr. A was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis  possibly resulting from his history of Staph infections and recreational drug use.   Slide 8: Treatment and Recommendations The patient was started on intravenous antibiotics per Infective Endocarditis guidelines  and a referral to a cardiology team was made for possible future surgical intervention given the extent of valve involvement. Regular follow-up appointments and adherence to medication regimen were strongly emphasized.  Slide 9: Case Review and Learning Points A review of the case  highlighting the importance of recognizing and interpreting signs and symptoms of infective endocarditis in conjunction with patient's medical history  and creating a timely and appropriate treatment plan. This case also brings attention to the connection between recreational drug use and the risk of developing endocarditis.

Title: A Case Study on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 1: Patient Demographics - The patient is a 52-year-old Caucasian male - Occupation: Construction worker - Social History: Non-smoker  occasional alcohol   Slide 2: Past Medical History - Slide 1: Introduction - Title: ""Case Study: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-aged Patient"" - The aim of this presentation is to discuss a unique patient case to understand the management  complications  and prognosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.   Slide 2: Patient Demographics - Patient Information: Male  58 years old - Lifestyle: Non-smoker  occasional alcohol use - Occupation: White-collar worker - Living conditions: Lives alone in an urban environment  Slide 3: Past Medical History - History of occasional intravenous drug use in 20’s  - Prior surgeries - Appendectomy in early 30’s - Chronic illnesses: Managed type 2 diabetes  hyperlipidemia - Medications: Metformin 1000 mg bid  Atorvastatin 40mg daily  Slide 4: Presenting Complaint - Presented to the ER with subjective fever  fatigue  and new-onset shortness of breath.   Slide 5: Physical Examination Findings - Fever of 100.8°F  tachycardia  tachypnea - Cardiac examination: Presence of a new murmur over the mitral valve area.  - Evidence of peripheral vascular phenomena  including splinter hemorrhages under the nails  Osler's nodes on the fingers.  Slide 6: Investigations - Blood cultures positive for Staphylococcus aureus; multiple sets - Echocardiogram: Vegetation on native mitral valve along with moderate mitral regurgitation. - Normal CBC  renal function. WBC mildly elevated.   Slide 7: Diagnosis and Management - Diagnosis: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis (IE) - Antimicrobial Therapy: Intravenous nafcillin and gentamicin started as per Infective Endocarditis treatment guidelines.  Slide 8: Case Progress and Complications - Developed acute heart failure due to worsening mitral regurgitation  necessitating ICU admission and stabilization.   Slide 9: Current Status - Transferred to cardio-thoracic surgery for mitral valve replacement after initial stabilization - Recovery post-surgery has been steady and uncomplicated as of last examination.   Slide 10: Discussion & Summary - Reflect on the significance of early detection  aggressive antibacterial therapy  and the potential need for surgical intervention in managing native-valve infective endocarditis. - The patient's case reinforces the importance of a holistic approach to patient care  considering lifestyle factors  medical history  and symptom presentation in diagnosis and management.

Title: A Case Study on Native-valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 1: Introduction to the Patient The patient in focus is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. X  a retired teacher living alone  who presented with symptoms of fatigue  night sweats  low-grade fevers  and unintentional weight loss of approximately 10 pounds over the past two months.   Slide 2: Past Medical History Mr. X has a past medical history significant for rheumatic fever in his youth  which resulted in mild mitral valve stenosis. He has also been treated for hypertension and type II diabetes  both managed with lifestyle changes and medication. He is a non-smoker and denies any alcohol or drug use.  Slide 3: Recent Health Issues About two months prior to current presentation  Mr. X had dental work performed without taking any prophylactic antibiotics  which is relevant given his history of rheumatic fever and mitral valve stenosis.   Slide 4: Examination & Diagnosis Upon examination  Mr. X had a low-grade fever and a regurgitant murmur was auscultated at the apex of his heart. Lab tests showed mild anemia and a mildly elevated CRP level. An EKG exhibited nonspecific ST-T changes. A transthoracic echocardiogram revealed vegetations on the mitral valve  compatible with a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Slide 5: Causative Agent Blood cultures grew Streptococcus viridans  a common pathogen responsible for native-valve infective endocarditis  particularly after dental procedures.  Slide 6: Treatment Plan Mr. X was started on penicillin and gentamicin to cover for S. viridans. Since his symptoms did not improve significantly after two weeks of antibiotics  and after consultation with Cardiothoracic Surgery  he underwent a mitral valve replacement. The postoperative period was uncomplicated and Mr. X was doing well at his 1-month follow-up visit.  Slide 7: Conclusion and Learning Points This case highlights the importance of appropriate prophylactic antibiotics in patients with a history of rheumatic fever and valve disease prior to dental procedures. Early recognition of the symptoms and signs of infective endocarditis  paired with appropriate diagnostic work-up and prompt initiation of treatment  are key to improving patient outcomes.

Slide 10: Conclusion Persistent fever  night sweats and fatigue in a patient with a history of rheumatic fever should be evaluated for possible infective endocarditis. Early diagnosis and immediate intervention are crucial for better prognosis. Regular cardiac monitoring and lifestyle modifications are key in managing native valve endocarditis.

Title: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis: A Case Study  Introduction: Infective endocarditis (IE) is a rare but severe disease having an incidence of 3 to 10 cases per 100 000 person-years. Native-valve endocarditis refers to the infection of a natural  non-prosthetic heart valve. This presentation focuses on a specific case of a patient diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Slide 1: Patient Demographics Patient X is a 58-year-old Caucasian male  a construction worker by occupation  residing in a suburban region. He is married and has one child.   Slide 2: Past Medical History Patient X has a documented history of intravenous drug use. Specifically  he reports a 15-year history of using cocaine  although he has been in recovery for the last five years  attending regular Narcotics Anonymous meetings. He also has a history of hypertension  for which he takes Lisinopril. He does not have any history of heart disease but does have a family history of atherosclerosis. He leads a relatively active lifestyle due to his physically demanding occupation  Slide 3: Presenting Symptoms The patient came in complaining of fatigue  intermittent fever  chills  and unintentional weight loss over a period of three weeks. Upon further questioning  he also complained of recent episodes of night sweats.   Slide 4: Physical Examination On examination  the patient appeared tired. Blood pressure was elevated at 150/90 mmHg  and he presented with a diastolic murmur on cardiac auscultation. A few petechiae were seen on the skin of his lower extremities.  Slide 5: Diagnostic Findings and Conclusions Blood cultures were ordered  which came back positive for S. aureus a known causative agent for native-valve endocarditis. The Echocardiogram unveiled a vegetation on the mitral valve  supporting the diagnosis.   Slide 6: Treatment & Prognosis Treatment involved a regime of intravenous antibiotics for six weeks. Valve surgery was considered due to the patient's drug resistant organism and septicemia  but deferred due to overall stability. Follow-ups for monitoring the state of the valve tissue and the overall cardiac functioning have been scheduled.  Slide 7: Learning Points This case underscores the importance of an earlier diagnosis of infective endocarditis  in individuals with a history of intravenous drug use. Despite the patient's lifestyle changes  the history put him at a higher risk for endocarditis which should have warranted a closer monitoring for potential cardiac issues in regular check-ups. It also highlights the necessity for a multidisciplinary approach in managing such intricate medical cases.  Finally  it underscores instituting good preventative practices especially among populations predisposed to developing such conditions.  End of Presentation.

Title: Case Presentation on Native-valve Infective Endocarditis (NIE)  Slide 1: Introduction In the forthcoming slides  a case study of a male patient diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis will be presented.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics Our subject is a 58-year-old Caucasian male  a non-smoker  with a history of moderate alcohol consumption and works as a carpenter.  Slide 3: Presenting Symptoms/Complaints The patient initially visited the clinic complaining of recurrent fever  malaise  and unexplained weight loss. He mentioned about experiencing intermittent  knife-like chest pains lasting for a couple of minutes.  Slide 4: Past Medical History The patient was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 5 years ago and has been on oral hypoglycemic drugs. He had a history of dental extraction three months prior to onset of symptoms.  Slide 5: Physical Examination On examination  we observed features such as pallor  peripheral stigmata of endocarditis like Osler's nodes  and Janeway lesions. Cardiac auscultation revealed a diastolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border.  Slide 6: Diagnostic Imaging Echocardiography revealed vegetations on the aortic valve  compatible with a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. The ejection fraction was 50%.  Slide 7: Laboratory Findings Blood cultures revealed the presence of Staphylococcus aureus  which is consistent with infective endocarditis.  Slide 8: Treatment The patient was admitted and initiated on a regimen of IV antibiotics  including vancomycin and gentamicin. We plan for 4 to 6 weeks of antibiotic therapy along with regular echocardiogram monitoring.  Slide 9: Complications and Prognosis Complications of NIE can be severe  as it can lead to heart failure or septicemia if not promptly and effectively treated. Early detection and appropriate management are vital for a good prognosis.  Slide 10: Conclusion Infective Endocarditis  though relatively rare  can have severe consequences if untreated or undiagnosed. Patients with risk factors such as diabetes or previous invasive dental procedures should be carefully monitored for symptoms. On time diagnosis and appropriate therapies are critical to mitigate dangerous complications.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis: A Case Study   Slide 1: Introduction Infective endocarditis (IE) is a severe infective disease associated with high morbidity and mortality rates. It often affects those with pre-existing cardiac conditions but can also occur in individuals with native  previously normal valves  leading to native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE).   Slide 2: Patient Demographics Our patient  Mr. Smith  is a 58-year-old Caucasian male. He's a retired construction worker  presently living alone  with no regular exposure to children or pets. He has a significant history of tobacco use with 40-pack years. He has not traveled abroad recently and denies any illicit drug usage.  Slide 3: Past Medical History Mr. Smith has a hypertensive cardiovascular disease well controlled with medication. He has had an episode of myocardial infarct three years ago  with no subsequent events. He does not have any previously known valvular disease. He was diagnosed and treated for an early-stage prostate carcinoma five years ago. He's been in remission since then  and it's crucial to monitor his general health.  Slide 4: Recent Medical History  Patient presented with a three-week history of fatigue  low-grade fever  night sweats  and weight loss. He's treated initially for a urinary tract infection due to his urinary complaints without any improvement in his symptoms. These nonspecific signs can often lead to a delay in diagnosing NVIE in a patient without known valvular disease.  Slide 5: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis Diagnosis Following blood cultures which grew Streptococcus mitis  Trans-Thoracic Echocardiogram (TTE) demonstrated a vegetation on the mitral valve suggestive of infective endocarditis.   Slide 6: Treatment and Outcome  The patient was started on IV Penicillin G and Gentamycin  as per guidelines for the Streptococcus genus. The patient's clinical condition improved following the start of therapy. Surgical consultation was sought  but the team decided to continue with conservative medical management considering the patient's improvement with therapy and lack of valvular dysfunction or heart failure.  Slide 7: Conclusion NVIE  though less common than in those with pre-existing cardiac conditions  can occur and becomes challenging to diagnose due to its nonspecific signs and symptoms. Early diagnosis and management are critical to reduce associated morbidity and mortality. This case also highlights the ongoing challenge and importance of deciding between conservative vs. surgical management in NVIE.  End of Presentation.

Title: Case Presentation - Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 1: Patient Introduction Patient: Mr. Williams  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  Occupation: Retired Teacher  Lifestyle: Non-smoker  social drinker   Slide 2: Symptoms Onset: Developed symptoms two months ago including:  - Intermittent fever  - Fatigue - Weight loss  - Night sweats  Slide 3: Medical History  Past medical history reveals:  - Type II Diabetes Mellitus  - Hypertension  - Mild aortic valve stenosis diagnosed 5 years ago  Slide 4: Recent Activities Recently embarked on dental procedures at a local clinic about 2.5 months ago.  Slide 5: Physical Examination  State on Presentation:  - Conscious  oriented  - Presence of a mild systolic murmur heard best at the right 2nd intercostal space  - Evidence of petechiae in the conjunctiva of the eyes - Splinter hemorrhages under the nails  Slide 6: Investigation & Diagnosis - Blood work: Elevated ESR and CRP - Blood cultures: Positive for Streptococcus viridans - Echocardiography: Vegetations seen on aortic valve consistent with endocarditis  Slide 7: Diagnosis Final diagnosis based on Duke's Criteria:  - Definite Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 8: Management and Follow Up - Started on appropriate antibiotic therapy  - Close monitoring of valve function  - Regular follow-up with cardiology recommended for evaluation of possible aortic valve replacement   Slide 9: Discussion Points - Emphasize the increased risk of endocarditis in valve diseases  - Understanding connection between recent dental procedure and endocarditis  - Make audience aware of the importance of antibiotic prophylaxis in patients with valve diseases before dental or other invasive procedures.

Title: A Case Study on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 1: Introduction - Brief explanation: Native-valve infective endocarditis is an infection of the heart's endocardial surface  typically affecting a native valve. It is most often caused by bacteria and can lead to severe complications if left untreated.  Slide 2: Demographic Data - Profile: 65-year-old Caucasian male - Occupation: Retired construction worker - Lifestyle: Non-smoker  moderate alcohol consumer  no illicit drug use  Slide 3: Past Medical History - Chronic conditions: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Hypertension - Previous surgeries: Appendectomy aged 25 and an inguinal hernia repair at 40  - Medications: Metformin  Lisinopril- No known drug allergies - Family history: Father died from a myocardial infarction  sister with rheumatic heart disease.  Slide 4: Presenting Symptoms & Signs - High grade fever for 3 days - Fatigue and lethargy - Shortness of breath - Swollen feet - Rapid weight loss over the past month - Heart murmur identified during physical examination  Slide 5: Diagnostic Investigations - Blood culture: Positive for Staphylococcus aureus - Echocardiogram: vegetation on mitral valve  moderate mitral regurgitation - Chest X-ray: shows mild pulmonary edema - CBC: Elevated WBC count and ESR  Slide 6: Treatment Plan - Intravenous antibiotic therapy: Vancomycin initiated based on antibiotic susceptibility testing - Symptomatic treatment: Diuretics for pulmonary edema - Monitoring: Serial echocardiograms  regular hematological and biochemical testing  Slide 7: Potential Complications  - Heart failure secondary to valve destruction - Systemic embolization leading to stroke or other organ damage - Abscess formation - Recurrent infection   Slide 8: Prognosis and Follow-Up Plan - Long term antibiotics and regular follow-up visits  - Education on infection prevention  - Possible need for surgical valve replacement in the future  Slide 9: Conclusion - Native-valve infective endocarditis is a serious condition needing prompt diagnosis and management.  - Close monitoring is essential to prevent complications and ensure favourable patient outcomes.  Slide 10: Questions? - Open floor for questions and further discussion.

Title: Case Study: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 1: Introduction  - Patient Profile: 65-year-old Hispanic male. - Chief Complaint: persistent fever  fatigue and shortness of breath for over a week. - Past Medical History: Diagnosis of diabetes mellitus type 2  hypertension  and a 10-year history of alcohol abuse.  Slide 2: Symptoms & Observation  - On physical examination: Noticed Osler's nodes and Janeway lesions  indicative of a systemic infection related to the heart. - Auscultation: Revealed a new-onset murmur on cardiac examination - Further observations: Patient exhibits weight loss  night sweats  and low appetite  Slide 3: Preliminary Diagnosis  - Based on these indications  patient was suspected to have infective endocarditis - an infection of the endocardial surface of the heart.  Slide 4: Confirming the Diagnosis  - Blood culture tests were ordered  which showed the presence of Staphylococcus aureus. - An Echocardiogram confirmed the diagnosis by revealing vegetations on the mitral valve.  Slide 5: Management & Treatment  - Intravenous antibiotic therapy initiated: The patient was immediately started on IV antibiotics (vancomycin and ceftriaxone) according to the microorganism identified. - Serial blood cultures: To monitor treatment response. - Ethanol abuse counseling: Given his medical history of alcohol abuse.  Slide 6: Prognosis  - The early diagnosis and treatment initiation increase the patient's chances of a favorable outcome. - However  considering his age  comorbidities  and alcohol abuse history  careful monitoring and strict management of his underlying conditions will be vital.  Slide 7: Key Learnings  - This case emphasizes the importance of keeping a high clinical suspicion for infective endocarditis in any patient presenting with persistent fever and with a relevant past medical history. - Early diagnosis  identification of the causative organism  and timely initiation of treatment are essential for a good prognosis.   Slide 8: Concluding Remarks  Infective endocarditis is a severe condition that requires immediate attention and prompt treatment. As medical practitioners  we must be quick  efficient  and diligent in identifying and treating such cases to improve patient outcomes.

Title: A Case Study of Native-valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Female   Case Presentation:  Introduction: Today we present a complex case of a 56-year-old Caucasian woman with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis.   Demographics: The patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian woman  unemployed  non-smoker  living in a small town in northern Vermont. She is a former dental assistant with no exposure to occupationally related hazards.  Past Medical History (PMH): The patient has a chronic history of poor dental health and recurrent dental infections along with high blood pressure which is controlled with medication. She reports that she experienced a vague episode of flu-like symptoms in the last two months. She has no prior episodes of rheumatic fever or intravenous drug usage. Patient does not have a history of heart diseases.  Chief Complaint: Patient has been experiencing symptoms such as fatigue  fever  night sweats  weight loss  and a reduced capacity for physical activities over the past six weeks. She also reported experiencing dyspnea on mild exertion.  Physical Examination (PE): On physical examination  the patient was found to have an irregular heart rhythm with an unexpected heart murmur. A cardiac auscultation revealed a diastolic murmur. Ophthalmologic examination showed Roth spots. Splinter haemorrhages were noted under the nails of both the hands.  Clinical Investigations: Lab results showed elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)  C-reactive protein (CRP)  and leukocytes indicating systemic inflammation and infection. The patient tested positive in the Duke criteria. Transthoracic Echocardiogram (TTE) revealed vegetation on the tricuspid valve which confirmed the diagnosis of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis.  Discussion: The patient's chronic dental infections are potentially the source of the endocarditis bacteria with her heart valves being at high risk as a nidus for infection  specifically Streptococci  the chief cause of infective endocarditis in people with a history of recurrent dental infections.  Conclusion/future plan: An integrative approach involving cardiology  infectious disease  and dental teams is crucial to manage this case effectively  with an administration of targeted long-term intravenous antibiotics  and valve repair or replacement if necessary. Additionally  an oral health education campaign would help in preventing further occurrences.  Thank you. Let’s welcome any supplementary questions or comments.

Title: Case Study: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Slide 1: Introduction Patient Details:  - Age/Gender: 69-year-old male  - Occupation: Retired engineer - Lifestyle: Non-smoker; moderate alcohol use  Slide 2: Past Medical History  - Hypertension: Diagnosed 8 years ago  controlled with medication - Type 2 Diabetes: Diagnosed 5 years ago  diet controlled - Coronary artery disease: Myocardial infarction 3 years ago  treated with stenting and on-going medication - No known allergies; up to date with recommended vaccinations  Slide 3: Presenting Situation - Complaints of intermittent fever  night sweats and unintended weight loss over the past 6 weeks - Onset of fatigue  shortness of breath and chest discomfort recently - No history of recreational drug use or recent dental procedures  Slide 4: Examination and Investigation - Initial Examination: Mild pallor; splinter hemorrhages under the nails; Osler’s nodes (painful nodules) on fingers; Janeway lesions (painless  flat red spots) on palms and soles - Lab Find: Elevated ESR and C-Reactive Protein; moderate anemia; positive blood culture with Streptococcus viridans  Slide 5: Diagnosis  - Given the clinical findings and positive blood culture  a diagnosis of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis was made.  - Echocardiogram: Confirmed the presence of vegetations on the mitral valve  Slide 6: Treatment Plan  - Plan: Hospitalisation and aggressive antibiotic therapy (based on susceptibility testing from cultured organism) - Monitoring: To monitor the effectiveness of the antibiotic therapy  daily temperature charting  blood tests including cultures and weekly echocardiograms were initiated  Slide 7: Prognosis and Follow-up  - Timely diagnosis and treatment are key to a favorable prognosis - Close follow-up is needed to monitor any signs of antibiotic resistance  complications such as heart failure  dysrhythmias or embolic events  and to reduce the risk of reinfection - Routine dental hygiene and regular dental examinations are emphasized to prevent recurrent endocarditis.   Slide 8: Conclusion  - This case underscores the importance of considering NUVE in patients presenting with fever of unknown origin  especially in the presence of associated underlying risk factors such as diabetes and coronary artery disease.  - Early recognition and appropriate prompt management are crucial in reducing morbidity and mortality associated with this condition.

Sure  here is a simple  yet detailed presentation of a case study of a patient with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Slide 1: Case Introduction - Patient's Initials: J.H. - Age/Sex: 45-year old Male - Occupation: School Teacher - Location: Urban NYC area  Slide 2: Chief Complaint and Presentation - Chief Complaint: Sudden high-grade fever  shortness of breath  and fatigue. - Duration: 4 days prior to seeking consultation. - Associated Symptoms: Mild chest pain  joint pain  sweating  and unintentional weight loss. Slide 4: Medical History - Significant Medical History: Diagnosed with Mitral Valve Prolapse (MVP) 1 year back  during a routine check-up. No follow-ups after diagnosis due to personal reasons.  - Physical Examination: Temperature: 39.1°C  HR: 99 bpm  BP: 150/90 mmHG. Heart examination revealed a mid-systolic click and late systolic murmur. Slide 6: Diagnostic Investigations - Blood Tests: Elevated ESR and CRP  along with persistently positive blood cultures for Streptococcus mutans. - Echocardiogram: Confirmed MVP  and vegetations were identified on the mitral valve  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Slide 7: Therapeutic Interventions and Follow-Up - Patient received IV antibiotics (Vancomycin and Gentamycin) for 6 weeks. - The patient was monitored closely during his hospital stay with a complete blood count test  renal function tests  and regular echocardiograms. - Upon completion of treatment  the patient showed significant improvement in symptoms and lab results. - The patient was given an appointment for a follow-up consultation every 3 months for the first year  and was advised to maintain good dental hygiene. Slide 9: Take Away Message - Early diagnosis and intervention are key in managing an Infective Endocarditis case. - Regular check-ups and follow-ups are mandatory for patients with heart valve diseases to prevent such complications.  - Educating patients about good hygienic practices and lifestyle changes can prevent the occurrence of such life-threatening infections.

Title: A Clinical Illustration of Native-valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 1: Introduction - Infective Endocarditis (IE) is a life-threatening infection of the endocardial surface of the heart  predominantly affecting the heart valves. - Native-valve IE affects valves that have not been previously damaged or replaced surgically   Slide 2:  Patient Demographics - 68-year-old Caucasian male - Occupation: Farmer - Lives alone in rural Michigan - History of intravenous drug use in his youth - Predominantly sedentary lifestyle  Slide 3:  Past Medical History - Mitral valve prolapse diagnosed in 2002 - Treated for hypertension since 1998 - History of non-compliance with medication  - Previous treatment for sepsis in 2010 - No known allergies  Slide 4:  Presenting Symptoms - Persistent fever of 38.3°C for more than five days - Recent history of cough and shortness of breath - Unplanned weight loss - General malaise and night sweats  Slide 5:  Physical Signs  - Osler's nodes (painful nodules on pads of the fingers) - Janeway's lesions (non painful reddish-brown spots on palms and soles) - Splinter hemorrhages (red or brown lines under the nails) - Roth's spots on retina (white-centered hemorrhages)  Slide 6:  Diagnostic Findings - Blood cultures: Positive for Streptococcus viridans - Transthoracic echocardiogram: Vegetations on mitral valve - Chest X-ray: Normal  Slide 7:  Management - Intravenous antibiotics (Vancomycin and Gentamicin) for 4-6 weeks - Clinical and ECHO assessment  - Surgical intervention may be necessary if complications occur.   Slide 8:  Prognosis - With early diagnosis and appropriate treatment  prognosis can be favorable.  - Adherence to prescribed antibiotic therapy is crucial.   - Monitoring for complications like heart failure  systemic embolization  and persistent infection is essential.   Slide 9:  Conclusion - Our case highlights the importance of early recognition and prompt treatment of Infective Endocarditis. - Patient history and presenting symptoms can provide valuable clues to the diagnosis. - Ensuring patient compliance to treatment can significantly improve prognosis.  Slide 10:  References and Q&A - References for further reading - Open to questions.

Title: A Case Study on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Slide 1: Introduction Today  we are examining a case of native-valve infective endocarditis. Infective endocarditis (IE) is a rare  life-threatening infection of the heart's inner lining or the heart valves caused by bacteria  fungi or other infectious substances.   Slide 2: Patient Profile The patient is a 59-year-old Caucasian male. He has been an active smoker for the last 40 years and a social drinker. He works as a plumber and has a history of poor oral hygiene.  Slide 3: Past Medical History The patient has well-controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes. He also has a past medical history of moderate aortic stenosis with no significant heart failure. Furthermore  detailed past medical history reveals a previous dental extraction performed with questionable sterility.  Slide 4: Symptoms Presenting complaints include high-grade fever for the past 2 weeks  along with night sweats and unintentional weight loss. There's also a new murmur noted on auscultation.   Slide 5: Clinical Findings Preliminary tests show elevated inflammatory markers like ESR and CRP. Cardiac biomarkers were within normal limits. Tooth and gum examination showed poor oral health  with few teeth having periapical abscesses.  Slide 6: Diagnosis Diagnosed with Infective Endocarditis based on clinical signs  blood cultures positive for Streptococcus viridans  and characteristic echocardiographic findings showing vegetations on the aortic valve.  Slide 7: Treatment The standard treatment included appropriate high-dose intravenous antibiotics for a prolonged duration  good oral hygiene instructions  and regular follow-ups to monitor the efficacy of the treatment and progression of the disease.  Slide 8: Prevention Endocarditis can be difficult to prevent completely  however  maintaining good oral and skin health can significantly reduce the risk of developing this disease.  Slide 9: Discussion and Queries Open for discussion about the case and how best to optimize the care plan for similar patients. Other resident doctors  nurses and medical staff are encouraged to ask questions related to this presentation and the given case study.   Slide 10: Conclusion Infective endocarditis remains a serious disease with significant morbidity and mortality. Timely diagnosis  appropriate treatment  and patient education about maintaining good oral hygiene can greatly improve prognosis.

Title: Case Presentation on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Slide 1: Introduction  - In this presentation  we'll be discussing a clinical case of a patient with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  a challenging cardiac infection that affects the endocardial surface of the heart.   Slide 2: Patient Demographics  - The patient in focus is a 60-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired factory worker  married  and resides in rural California. He’s a non-smoker with a history of occasional alcohol consumption.   Slide 3: Presenting Complaint  - The patient presented to the emergency room experiencing a persistent high-grade fever for the past two weeks  fatigue  night sweats  and loss of appetite.   Slide 4: Past Medical History  - Previously diagnosed with moderate aortic stenosis approximately 4 years ago.  - Suffered from Rheumatic fever as a child which may have initiated damage to the heart valves.  - History of dental procedures without prophylactic antibiotics.   Slide 5: Clinical Assessment & Diagnosis  - Physical examination revealed a systolic murmur and Osler’s nodes were noted (painful red or purple swellings in the skin).  - Blood cultures were taken which came back positive for Streptococcus Viridans.  - Echocardiogram confirmed the presence of vegetation on the aortic valve.   Slide 6: Diagnosis  - With the above findings  the patient was diagnosed with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis.  Slide 7: Treatment  - The patient was immediately started on intravenous antibiotic therapy  which included penicillin and aminoglycosides. - The patient's response to the treatment was evaluated on a regular basis with frequent physical assessments and lab testing. - A cardiothoracic surgery consult was made due to the severity of the aortic stenosis.   Slide 8: Conclusion  - Follow up care includes strict adherence to the antibiotic treatment plan  regular cardiac monitoring  and potential for surgical intervention in the future. This case highlights the importance of early detection and diagnosis of infective endocarditis  particularly in patients with a known history of heart valve disease.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis: A Case Study  Slide 1: Introduction   - Spotlight on Native-valve Infective Endocarditis  a rare but potentially fatal condition affecting the inner heart liner with an infectious agent.  Slide 2: Patient's Information   - Patient Profile: John Doe  a 46-year-old Caucasian male  non-smoker  and occasional drinker  employed as a construction worker.  Slide 3: Past Medical History   - The patient has a medical history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which is well controlled with Metformin. He also goes under regular dental procedures for periodontitis  a notable risk factor for infective endocarditis.   Slide 4: Presenting Symptoms & Examination   - Patient has been experiencing unexplained fevers  night sweats  weight loss  and recent-onset fatigue over the past three weeks. - Upon physical examination  he shows signs of Osler's nodes (painful red nodules)  Janeway lesions (non-painful  small red spots)  and a new heart murmur.  Slide 5: Lab Investigations   - Blood cultures were drawn which came back positive for Staphylococcus epidermidis  a common cause of native-valve infective endocarditis.  - Elevated inflammatory markers including ESR  CRP  and white blood cell count.  Slide 6: Imaging  - Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) was done which revealed vegetations on the patient's native mitral valve  confirming the diagnosis.  Slide 7: Management Plan   - The patient was started on appropriate intravenous antibiotic therapy  as per the IDSA guidelines for endocarditis caused by S. epidermidis. - Further management included monitoring for complications  cardiac function assessment  and considering valve surgery if necessary.  Slide 8: Conclusion  - Highlight the importance of early diagnosis and timely management of native-valve infective endocarditis  routine dental care in at-risk patients to minimize the chance of infection  and the potential severity of this condition.

Title: A Case Study of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 1: Introduction   This presentation discloses a case study of a patient diagnosed with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVE)  a severe form of bacterial or fungal infection that affects the heart valves and endocardial surface.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  Our patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  a retired factory worker residing in Boston  Massachusetts. He is a former smoker  with a 20 pack-year history and has been a chronic alcoholic  which has predisposed him to multiple health issues over the years.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  The patient has a history of medically treated hypertension for a decade  diagnosed type 2 diabetes for about 5 years. He has also been treated for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) for several years as a consequence of his smoking history.  Slide 4: Presenting Complaints  He came in presenting symptoms similar to those of a severe flu  which included prolonged fever  fatigue  weight loss  and dyspnea. He also complained of an irregular heartbeat and episodes of dizziness and fainting.  Slide 5: Diagnostic Tests  Echocardiography revealed vegetations on the native valves of the heart. The blood cultures grew Streptococcus viridans  often associated with NVE. Other significant findings included elevated ESR  CRP  and some renal impairment likely secondary to a septic state.  Slide 6: Diagnosis   The diagnosis was confirmed as Native Valve Infective Endocarditis  based on the presentation  positive blood cultures  and echocardiographic evidence of valvular vegetations.  Slide 7: Treatment  He was admitted to the hospital and started on intravenous antibiotics. Management and treatment also involved strict blood sugar control  cessation of alcohol consumption  and maintaining blood pressure within normal parameters. The damage to the heart valves was severe  replacing the diseased valve was considered.   Slide 8: Conclusion and Prognosis  The patient's condition improved gradually with the aggressive antibiotic regimen and supportive measures. Public health interventions must be initiated to prevent the development of NVE  particularly among individuals with predisposing factors like COPD  hypertension  diabetes and alcohol consumption.

Title: Case Study of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Slide 1: Patient Demographics  On this slide  we discuss the general details of the patient. Here  we're looking at a 60-year-old Caucasian male. He's a non-smoker  moderate alcohol drinker  and is not on any illicit drugs. He's a retired firefighter  living with his wife in a suburban setting.  Slide 2: Past Medical History Our patient has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  which he manages with oral hypoglycemic agents. He has no known allergies. His family history reveals that his father had a heart condition  but the specifics are unknown.  Slide 3: Presenting Symptoms  The patient reports experiencing a low-grade fever  chills  fatigue  unintentional weight loss  and a new heart murmur. He's been battling these symptoms for the past three weeks  initially attributing it to a flu  but sought medical assistance when the symptoms persisted.  Slide 4: Diagnostic Criteria Upon consultation  blood tests were carried out and revealed anemia  raised ESR  and leukocytosis. Blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus viridans. An echocardiogram showed vegetations on cardiac valves  consistent with a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Slide 5: Management & Treatment The patient was admitted to the hospital  given intravenous antibiotic therapy with Penicillin and Gentamycin for six weeks. Surgical intervention was considered but not undertaken because of the patient's overall health condition and the risk of procedure-related complications.  Slide 6: Follow-up and Patient Education  Regular follow-ups were scheduled for monitoring. Along with physical therapy  the patient was educated about the importance of good oral hygiene and regular dental care to prevent recurrences.  Slide 7: Conclusion  This case highlights the importance of expedient diagnosis and intervention in cases of infective endocarditis. Prompt treatment is critical to prevent potentially fatal complications and improve the overall health status of patients suffering from this condition.

Title: Case Presentation: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 1: Introduction  - Patient Demographics: M.J.  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  - Occupation: Retired Engineer - Habits: Occasional Alcohol  Non-smoker - Location: Suburban Midwest  USA   Slide 2: Past Medical History  - History of rheumatic fever as a child  - No history of illicit drug use - Under management for hypertension and type-2 diabetes  - No known allergies  Slide 3: Presenting Complaints  - History of prolonged fever  not relieved by over the counter antipyretics - Excessive sweating especially at night - Unintended weight loss of about 5kgs over a month - New-onset  worsening shortness of breath  Slide 4: Clinical Findings  - Physical examination reveals mild pallor  petechiae  and splinter hemorrhages under the nails. - Cardiac auscultation shows presence of a new murmur suggestive of mitral regurgitation - No visible skin  oral or ocular manifestations of endocarditis  Slide 5: Diagnostic Evaluation (In Progress)  - After pertinent clinical examination  the following tests have been ordered:     - Blood culture     - Echocardiogram  Transthoracic followed by Transesophageal if needed.    - Complete Blood Count    - ESR  CRP to assess the level of inflammation  Slide 6: Discussion  - The proceeding slides highlight the characteristic symptomatology of native-valve infective endocarditis.   - The presence of a new murmur  fever  fatigue  and weight loss raise the index of suspicion for this condition.    Slide 7: Management and Prognosis   - Once the diagnosis is confirmed  administration of empiric antibiotic therapy will be initiated immediately  further modified based on culture and sensitivity results. - As this patient has native-valve endocarditis  chances of embolic events and resultant complications warrant close monitoring and immediate attention. - Endocarditis  especially in patients with pre-existing heart conditions  possesses a high risk of morbidity and mortality  underlining the importance of early recognition  diagnosis  and prompt management. Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis: A Case Presentation   Slide 1: Introduction - Brief definition of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  an infection of the heart valves and endocardial surface usually caused by bacteria  particularly streptococci or staphylococci. It is common in patients with preexisting heart diseases and can lead to severe complications if not promptly treated.  Slide 2:  Patient Demographics - The patient is a 58-year-old male  employed as a construction worker and resident of urban area.    Slide 3:  Past Medical History - The patient has been diagnosed with rheumatic heart disease in his late twenties. - Underwent mitral valve replacement 15 years ago. - History of IV drug use but had quit 10 years ago. - Smoker for 35 years  around 10 cigarettes per day. - Occasionally drinks alcohol  about two or three times per month.  Slide 4: Presenting Complaints - The patient presented with a 2-week history of intermittent fever  fatigue and unintentional weight loss. - Also noted are shortness of breath  night sweats  and loss of appetite.  Slide 5: Physical Examination  - Upon physical examination  showed signs of Janeway lesions and Osler nodes. - Heart rate - irregular with heart murmurs detected. - Blood pressure was slightly elevated.  Slide 6: Investigations  - Blood culture and sensitivity confirmed the presence of Staphylococcus aureus. - Transthoracic echocardiogram showed vegetations on the native valves  indicative of endocarditis. - Complete blood count revealed leukocytosis and mild anemia. - Chest X-ray revealed possible signs of heart failure.  Slide 7: Diagnosis - Based on patient's history  presenting symptoms  and investigations  the diagnosis is native-valve infective endocarditis.  Slide 8: Management and Treatment - Initiated high-dose intravenous antibiotics as per sensitivity results  indicated for a duration of 4 weeks. - Daily monitoring of vitals  blood tests to monitor efficacy of antibiotics and condition progress. - Referral to a Cardiologist for the possibility of a surgical intervention.  Slide 9: Prevention and Education  - Emphasized the necessity of meticulous oral hygiene to prevent bacteremia. - Education about the risks of IV drug use  and continued smoking cessation support. - Advised regular follow-ups for rheumatic heart disease and for monitoring valve function.   Slide 10: Conclusions Discuss the importance of early recognition and treatment in patients with risk factors to prevent complications such as heart failure  septicemia  and embolic events.   Slide 11: Questions and Discussion.   This concludes the case presentation. Now  we can open the floor for questions and discussion.

Title: A Review on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis: A Clinico-Pathological Case Study  Slide 1: Case Introduction --------------------------- - Patient: 68-year-old Caucasian male - Occupation: Retired engineer  - Presenting complain: Recurring fever  general weakness  occasional chest discomfort.  Slide 2: Medical History  --------------------------- - Past Medical History: Diagnosis of Rheumatic Heart Disease at age 12  under regular medical follow-up since then. - Surgical History: No previous surgical intervention. - Allergies: None reported. - Medications: Long-term use of Beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors. - Family History: Father died of heart disease.  Slide 3: Present Complaints --------------------------- - Current symptoms: Recurring pyrexia  fatigue  weight loss  night sweats  dyspnea on exertion  occasional palpitations. - Duration: Symptoms persisting for last one month.  Slide 4: Diagnosis -------------------------- - Suspicion: Patient highly suspected of developing Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis given history of rheumatic fever in childhood and presenting complaints. - Examinations: Murmurs heard upon Auscultation. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) reveals vegetation on valves. - Other Tests: Blood culture positive for Staphylococcus aureus.  Slide 5: Case Discussion  --------------------------- - Discussion: Patient's prior rheumatic fever caused structural changes and complications to his heart valves  creating an environment more susceptible to bacterial adhesion and colonization  leading to the development of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis. - Pathogenesis: How Staphylococcus aureus caused vegetation on the valves leading to the patient's symptoms.  Slide 6: Recommended Treatment ---------------------------------- - Treatment: High-dose antibiotic therapy initially. Constant monitoring of the patient to assess response to treatment and possible complications. - Surgical Evaluation: If antibiotic treatment doesn't lead to resolution or complications such as heart failure or uncontrolled infection occur  surgical valve repair or replacement may be necessary.  Slide 7: Outcome & Prognosis  ------------------------------- - Patient's Response: Patient responds well to treatment  his symptoms alleviated  and no surgical intervention was required. - Follow-up plans: Regular visits to monitor for any further complications or recurrence.  Slide 8: Conclusion & Lessons  ------------------------------- - Our case further underlines the importance of early recognition and treatment of rheumatic fever to prevent such complications. - Reiterates the importance of detailed history-taking and continuous monitoring in a patient with cardiac history. - Emphasizes the role of preventive measures and adherence to treatment protocol to avoid complications from a common bacterium like Staphylococcus aureus.   Slide 9: References ------------------ - List of cited literature and research works.

Title: Presentation of a Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Slide 1: Introduction - Discuss what native valve infective endocarditis is.  - Etiological basis and possible complications if untreated.  Slide 2: Case Overview - Male patient  age 65 years - Presenting complaint: Fever  malaise  night sweats  weight loss  Slide 3: Past Medical History - Previous history of intravenous drug use  but sober for the past 10 years - Chronic Hepatitis C infection  - Smoker with COPD - No previous history of heart disease  Slide 4: Physical Examination  - Microcytic  hypochromic anemia - Splinter hemorrhages under fingernails - Janeway lesions on palms and soles - Osler’s nodes on fingers and toes - Murmur on cardiac auscultation: mitral area  Slide 5: Diagnostic Tests - Reminder of diagnostic criteria for endocarditis (Duke criteria) - Blood cultures: multiple samples  all positive for Staphylococcus aureus - Echocardiogram: vegetations seen on native mitral valve - Complete blood count: Increased WBC count  low hemoglobin level   Slide 6: Case Diagnosis - Diagnosis: Native-valve infective endocarditis  - Explanation of contributing factors and pathophysiology  Slide 7: Treatment and Follow-up - Antibiotics: Initially broad-spectrum  later specified to S. aureus  treatment duration 4-6 weeks. - Monitoring of ANC (Absolute Neutrophil Count) and repeat blood cultures. - Monitoring for complications of endocarditis – embolic events  renal impairment  congestive heart failure. - Surgical considerations for valve replacement in case of treatment failure or complications. Slide 1: Introduction - Title: Case Presentation: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 54-year-old Male. - Brief Overview:  This presentation discusses a case of infective endocarditis (IE)  a rare but deadly disease with significant morbidity and mortality and it affects the endocardium layer of the heart. Title: A Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Slide 1: Introduction Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVIE)  a potentially life-threatening disease  usually results from bacterial infection in the native valves of the heart. The case study explores an NVIE patient  analyzing demographics  past medical history  diagnostic process  treatment plan  and progression.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  unemployed  with a past history of mild alcohol abuse. The patient lives in a semi-urban environment and is a smoker with moderate-to-severe periodontitis.  Slide 3: Past Medical History The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes managed with metformin and a recent removal of a dental abscess two weeks ago. No regular cardiac check-ups or cardiological problems reported until now.  Slide 4: Presenting Symptoms The patient presented with symptoms including fever  fatigue  night sweats  weight loss  and several purple  painful nodes on fingers and toes (Osler's nodes). He also had a new cardiac murmur found on physical examination.  Slide 5: Diagnostic Process Blood culture positive for Streptococcus viridans  pointing towards NVIE. Echocardiography revealing vegetations on the mitral valve. Additional findings: mildly elevated troponin level  high ESR  and severe anemia.  Slide 6: Treatment Protocol  Patient promptly started on tailored antibiotic therapy (Penicillin G and Gentamicin) post sensitivity analysis. Co-managed by cardiology for heart failure symptoms (ACE inhibitors  Beta-blockers)  and hematology for severe anemia (iron supplements  blood transfusion).  Slide 7: Progression and Follow-up Progressing well with a resolution of fever and reduction in the size of vegetations on echocardiography. Regular follow-up scheduled with Cardiology  Infectious disease specialty  and dental for improved oral hygiene care to prevent recurrence.   Slide 8: Conclusion NVIE remains a serious health concern  particularly in patients with prior oral infections. Key to management is early diagnosis via clinical suspicion  blood culture  and echocardiography followed by aggressive management with antibiotic therapy and managing complications. Patient education and regular follow-ups are pivotal in preventing recurrence.   Slide 9: Questions and Discussion Open for questions  discussions around NVIE  its risk factors  diagnostics  and treatment choices.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis: A Case Review  Slide 1: Introduction Today we are going to discuss a case of native-valve infective endocarditis  a serious condition characterized by inflammation of the inner layer of the heart due to bacterial infection.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics Patient details: 55-year-old Caucasian male. Profession: Plumber and a part-time farmer  increasing his risk due to potential exposure to certain bacteria in his environment. No reported history of illicit drug use  blood transfusions  or recent dental treatments.  Slide 3: Past Medical History The patient's past medical history reveals diagnosis of Type II Diabetes controlled with Metformin. Previously  he underwent treatment for Helicobacter Pylori infection roughly 5 years ago. Regular body mass index  no occurrence of hypertension  hyperlipidaemia and family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Slide 4: Symptoms & Physical Examination The patient reported a history of recurrent fevers  fatigue  weight loss  and night sweats over the last 3 months. On physical examination  the clinician observed Janeway lesions  Osler's nodes  and a new murmur suggestive of valvular regurgitation.  Slide 5: Diagnostic Tests & Results Blood cultures confirmed growth of Staphylococcus aureus. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) revealed vegetations on the mitral valve  confirming the suspected diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.   Slide 6: Discussion Infective Endocarditis  particularly involving native valves  is often associated with diabetes  and this patient’s occupation as a plumber and a farmer may have increased his exposure to S. aureus. The presented symptoms and physical findings further suggested this diagnosis  which was confirmed by blood cultures and TTE.  Slide 7: Management and Outlook The patient was admitted and started on empiric antibiotic therapy. Given diabetic status and signs of severe mitral regurgitation  a consultation with cardiothoracic surgery for potential valve replacement was initiated.  Slide 8: Conclusion This case highlights the importance of considering a broad differential in patients with vague  nonspecific symptoms and paying close attention to any potential clues in a patient's medical or occupational history.                                       Slide 9: Q&A Any questions or discussion points on this case are welcome.

Title: A Case Study of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Slide 1 - Introduction: Today we are exploring the case of a patient with an acute case of native-valve infective endocarditis  a serious infection of the heart's interior lining and valves.  Slide 2 - Patient Demographics: The patient is a 64-year-old Caucasian male with a height of 5'11"" and weight of 180 pounds. He is a retired mechanical engineer living in rural Georgia with his wife. The patient is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol socially. He follows a balanced diet and maintains an active lifestyle.  Slide 3 - Past Medical History: The patient has a history of mild hypertension controlled with medication and managed Type II Diabetes Mellitus. Over the past decade  he had two instances of Staphylococcus skin infections following minor surgeries  which responded well to antibiotics. He has no known allergies to medication.   Slide 4 - Presenting Complaints: The patient presented with a three-week history of fever  malaise  weight loss  and recently developed shortness of breath. He denies recent travel  sick contacts  or unusual peroral intake.  Slide 5 - Examination and Investigation Findings: Physical examination revealed fever (38.7°C)  tachycardia (HR 102 bpm)  mild pallor  and a systolic murmur at the left lower sternal area. Blood cultures showed growth of Methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA). Transthoracic echocardiogram revealed a mass on the aortic valve indicative of vegetation  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Slide 6 - Diagnosis and Management Plan: The patient was diagnosed with MSSA native-valve infective endocarditis. He was started on intravenous Nafcillin and Gentamicin for empirical treatment. His response to therapy will be assessed continually  and possible surgical intervention evaluated if medical management proves ineffective.  Slide 7 - Conclusion: This case demonstrates the importance of considering a diagnosis of endocarditis in patients presenting with unexplained fever  heart murmur  and septicemia  particularly those with previous episodes of infection. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent complications and improve patient outcomes.   Slide 8 - References: Here  particular studies or relevant medical texts used to inform the presentation material would be listed.

Title: A Case Study on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Slide 1: Introduction  Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis (IE) is an infection affecting the endocardial surface of the heart  resulting in inflammation and dysfunction. Today we'll discuss the case of a 60-year-old male patient who has been diagnosed with this condition.   Slide 2: Demographics  Our patient  Mr. B  is a 60-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired construction worker and resides in a suburban community. He is a non-smoker and has a history of moderate alcohol consumption.   Slide 3: Past Medical History  Mr. B has a known history of Type II Diabetes mellitus and is hypertensive. There's also a history of Rheumatic fever during his early childhood. Over the last year  he has experienced intermittent episodes of fever and unexplained weight loss. He has undergone two dental procedures six weeks ago without antibiotic prophylaxis.   Slide 4: Presenting Symptoms  He presented to the hospital with chief complaints of intermittent fever  fatigue  night sweats  and a noticeable decrease in exercise capacity.  Slide 5: Clinical Findings  Upon physical examination  he showed signs of splinter hemorrhages in the nails  and a new murmur was audible on cardiac auscultation. Blood tests showed raised inflammatory markers  and a positive blood culture indicated Staphylococcus aureus.  Slide 6: Diagnosis With his symptoms  murmur  and positive blood culture  Mr. B was diagnosed with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis. An echocardiogram confirmed the presence of vegetation on his Mitral valve  further strengthening the diagnosis.   Slide 7: Management and Follow Up  He was started on an appropriate course of antibiotics  and his blood glucose level and blood pressure were managed under optimal control. The multidisciplinary team is carefully monitoring his progress  and cardio-thoracic surgery is considering the possibility of valve repair/replacement if his condition does not improve with medical treatment.  Slide 8: Conclusion This case highlights the importance of early detection and prompt treatment of Infective Endocarditis  especially in patients with predisposing factors. Further  it emphasizes the need for prophylactic antibiotic coverage in at-risk patients undergoing dental or other invasive procedures.

Title: Case Study on a Patient with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Slide 1: Background Information  - Patient X is a 64-year-old Caucasian male. - Occupation: Retired mechanical engineer. - Social History: Married  nonsmoking  alcohol consumption within moderate limits.  Slide 2: Past Medical History  - History of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. - Medications: Lisinopril 20mg daily and atorvastatin 40mg daily.  Slide 3: Presenting Concerns  - The patient has been experiencing fever  chills  and fatigue for about two weeks. - He also reports an unintentional weight loss of ~5kg over the past month.     Slide 4: Physical Exam Findings  - The patient appears unwell and reports a loss of appetite. - Vital signs: Temperature 38.2°C  Heart rate 98 bpm  Blood pressure 130/85 mmHg. - Heart auscultation reveals a new systolic murmur.  Slide 5: Investigation and Lab Results  - Blood tests show elevated inflammatory markers. - Three sets of blood cultures are positive for Staphylococcus aureus. - Transthoracic echocardiogram reveals vegetations on the mitral valve consistent with infective endocarditis.    Slide 6: Diagnosis - The constellation of clinical features  laboratory findings  and echocardiogram results confirm a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Slide 7: Management - Patient has been started on empiric antibiotic therapy  in consultation with Infectious Disease specialists. - Regular follow-up and monitoring are scheduled  with a plan to re-evaluate antibiotic therapy based on culture and sensitivity results.  Slide 8: Implications and Prognosis - Native-valve infective endocarditis can lead to serious complications like sepsis  stroke  heart failure  or damage to other organs. - Early detection and appropriate treatment are essential in reducing morbidity and mortality.   Slide 9: Conclusion - The case illustrates the importance of considering infective endocarditis in a patient with new onset fever  elevated inflammatory markers  and new heart murmur. - This highlights the need for early suspicion  prompt investigation  and appropriate management for improved patient outcomes.

Slide 6: Investigations ""Laboratory Investigations:  - Blood tests indicated Leukocytosis and raised ESR. - Blood cultures were taken and were positive for Streptococcus viridans. Imaging: - Transthoracic Echocardiography revealed vegetations on the aortic valve  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.""  Slide 7: Conclusion ""Diagnostics Confirmed: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis""  Slide 8: Learning goals ""Key Points to remember:  - The non-specific signs and symptoms of infective endocarditis - Importance of taking a detailed medical history  particularly any pre-existing heart condition - Importance of timely investigation and diagnosis""

A 58-year-old male with history of intravenous drug use presents with a two-week history of malaise  night sweats  and intermittent fevers. He also reports a new murmur that he says he hears ""swooshing"" in his chest and shortness of breath with minimal exertion. Physical examination reveals a grade III/VI holosystolic murmur heard best at the apex of the heart  small painless lesions on his palms (Janeway lesions) and splinter hemorrhages under his nails. His blood cultures are positive for Staphylococcus aureus. These symptoms are indicative of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 62-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use and chronic hepatitis C  presents with a 3-week history of intermittent fever  chills  and generalized malaise. The patient also reports recent onset of shortness of breath and a new heart ""murmur"" described as an unusual sound when listening to his chest. No known allergies or current medication use. On examination  the patient appears systemically unwell. On auscultation  a new murmur over the mitral valve area is detected. Hand examination reveals splinter hemorrhages under the nails. His temperature is 38.2 C and other vital signs are stable.

A 65-year-old male retired farmer  smoker with a medical history significant for rheumatic heart disease and recurrent urinary tract infections presents with a two-week history of intermittent fever  chills  loss of appetite  and unintentional weight loss.
