He also reports drenching night sweats and noted specks of blood in his sputum a couple of times. On physical examination  he exhibits signs of cardiac murmur  Janeway lesions on palms and soles  and Osler nodes on fingers  suggestive of signs associated with infective endocarditis.

A 64-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of intravenous drug use  presents with a 2-week history of fever  fatigue  and night sweats. He also complains of dyspnea and a new onset of lower back pain. Physical examination reveals a fever of 101.5°F  systolic murmur in the mitral area  and possible lumbar spine tenderness. There are also clinical signs of peripheral emboli including petechiae  Osler's nodes  and Janeway lesions. The patient's history of drug use and his constellation of symptoms raise suspicion for native valve infective endocarditis.

A 63-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for intravenous drug use and untreated dental caries presents with a 2-week history of persistent fever  night sweats  fatigue  weight loss  and new onset dyspnea. He also reports experiencing intermittent joint pain and recently noticed red spots on the palms of his hands. On physical examination  he has a high-grade fever  a new systolic murmur is detected on cardiac auscultation  and Janeway lesions are observed on his palms. There are also signs of possible splenomegaly. His dental evaluation shows evidence of poor oral hygiene with multiple untreated caries. His oxygen saturation on room air is 92% and his blood pressure is lower than normal. These symptoms suggest possible native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 58-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for type II diabetes  and intravenous drug use presents to the clinic with a two-week history of persistent fever  fatigue  and unexplained weight loss. Physical examination reveals Janeway lesions on his palms and soles  Osler's nodes on his fingers and toes  and a new murmur noted on cardiac auscultation suggestive of mitral valve involvement. Blood cultures have been drawn and initial labs reveal elevated inflammatory markers. The patient's clinical presentation is highly suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis  likely secondary to his history of IV drug use. Evaluation continues with echocardiography to confirm the diagnosis and to evaluate for potential valvular damage.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for intravenous drug use presents with a two-week history of high-grade intermittent fevers  night sweats  weight loss  fatigue  and new onset shortness of breath. He also reports experiencing heart palpitations  and physical examination reveals a new heart murmur. Furthermore  the patient has noticed dark purple  tender skin lesions on his fingers and toes. He has no known allergies and is currently not on any medications. His only surgical history is for an old compound fracture. His family history is unremarkable. Social history includes daily use of intravenous drugs  occasional alcohol use and he lives alone. His review of systems is negative except as mentioned.  His vitals are slightly unstable with a heart rate of 100 beats per minute  a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F)  a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg  and an oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. These findings raise high suspicion for native valve infective endocarditis  likely secondary to his intravenous drug use.

Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old male with a history of substance use disorder presents with a 2-week history of worsening fatigue  loss of appetite and nocturnal sweats. He reports non-radiating chest discomfort with occasional shortness of breath which has progressively increased over the last three days. Patient also complains of painful red nodules on his fingers and toes. He has a 30-year history of intravenous drug use but has been in recovery for the last 5 years. His other medical history includes chronic Hepatitis C  type 2 diabetes and peripheral vascular disease. No known drug allergies. A careful physical examination reveals a murmur and Janeway lesions. He was afebrile on presentation. This clinical picture raises strong suspicion for severe native-valve infective endocarditis likely secondary to his chronic IV drug use. Further diagnostic confirmation with echocardiography and blood cultures are recommended.

A 62-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use and untreated dental caries presents with fever  weight loss  and sweating for the last four weeks. Physical examination reveals a new heart murmur  osler's nodes on his fingers  and janeway lesions on his feet. He has episodes of confusion and complains of severe body aches. The patient has not been previously diagnosed with any cardiac diseases nor has any family history of heart diseases. No history of surgery  allergy  or medications. He is a regular smoker and admits to daily alcohol consumption. Vitals show a low-grade fever and increased heart rate.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use and recent dental work  but no significant cardiac history  presents to the hospital with a one-week history of intermittent fever  night sweats  and unexplained weight loss. He also complains of a new-onset heart murmur along with signs of peripheral embolization including pain and erythema in the fingers and toes  and small  tender spots under the skin of his palms and soles. The patient also experiences episodes of shortness of breath  palpitations  and general weakness. The symptoms suggest a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 59-year-old male Caucasian patient  with a past medical history of intravenous drug use  presents with a 2-week history of fatigue  night sweats  weight loss  and a new onset cardiac murmur. The patient also reports experiencing intermittent fever and chills over this period. Physical examination reveals tender red spots under the skin of his fingers and toes (Osler's nodes) and small  painful  red or purple skin lesions on the palms and soles (Janeway lesions)  which suggest an invasive infection. Additionally  there is a presence of an irregular heartbeat characterized by rapid  irregular atrial fibrillations  suggesting probable cardiac involvement. There is no history of heart disease  recent dental procedures  or surgical interventions. Investigations required include blood cultures to identify the causative pathogen and transthoracic echocardiography to confirm the presence of valvular vegetation. The patient's history of intravenous drug use  presence of systemic infection signs  new onset cardiac murmur  and probable skin manifestations of endocarditis suggests a clinical picture of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 55-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use presents with symptoms consistent with native-valve infective endocarditis. He reports a 2-week history of progressive fatigue  intermittent high-grade fevers  night sweats  loss of appetite  and a recent unintentional weight loss. Physical examination reveals an ill-looking patient in distress. He has a cardiac murmur best auscultated at the mitral valve area. There are also splinter hemorrhages underneath his fingernails and Osler nodes (painful  red nodules) on his fingers and toes. Lab work shows elevated inflammatory markers and blood cultures are positive for Staphylococcus aureus bacteria. Transthoracic echocardiogram confirms the presence of vegetations on the mitral valve  consolidating the diagnosis of infective endocarditis.

Patient is a 65-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use presenting with symptoms of fatigue  fevers  night sweats  and unexplained weight loss over the past month. On examination  he exhibits petechiae on his oral mucosa and a soft systolic murmur. His condition is deteriorating despite initial antibiotic treatment  indicating possible native-valve infective endocarditis related to his past intravenous drug use.

A 65-year-old male with a past medical history of type II diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  now presents with a 2-week history of worsening fatigue  intermittent fever  shortness of breath  and unexplained weight loss. He is a retired school teacher  doesn't smoke  occasionally drinks a glass of wine  and has no known drug allergies. There is no history of intravenous drug use or any recent dental procedures. On examination  he appears chronically ill. There are splinter hemorrhages under his fingernails  and Osler's nodes were noted on his fingers and toes. Cardiovascular examination reveals a new onset murmur best heard at the apex. Initial blood workup shows an elevated ESR  CRP  and mild anemia. Blood cultures are pending. Preliminary diagnosis is native-valve infective endocarditis and patient has been started empirically on intravenous antibiotics while awaiting further diagnostic testing including transesophageal echocardiography.

A 56-year-old Caucasian female patient with a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and intravenous drug use presents with 4-week history of malaise  night sweats  low-grade fever  and a newly developed regurgitant heart murmur. She has also noticed several small  painless red-purple spots on her skin and reported rapid weight loss. Her diabetes was previously well-managed on metformin. However  it is noted that her compliance to medication and regular glucose monitoring has been poor recently due to her ongoing struggle with addiction. Her lifestyle with potential exposure to contaminated needles poses a high risk for infective endocarditis involving native valves.

A 60-year-old African-American female with a medical history significant for insulin-dependent type 2 diabetes  chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage III  and no known history of intravenous drug use  presents to the emergency department with complaints of fever  persistent malaise  and new onset of shortness of breath over a period of 3 weeks. She reports episodes of chills and night sweats  as well as unintentional weight loss over the past month. She has a background of poor dental health  with multiple missing teeth and untreated cavities. Current medications include Metformin and insulin. Physical examination reveals an acutely ill looking patient with a heart murmur characteristic of mitral regurgitation  fever of 100.9 F  tachycardia  subsequent laboratory tests indicate raised inflammatory markers  and blood cultures are pending. There is a high suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis given the clinical findings and background medical history.

A 60-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use and hypertension presents with a 2-week history of fever  fatigue  and night sweats. Additionally  he notes increasing shortness of breath  particularly when exerting himself and has lost five pounds over the same period without trying. He denies any cough or chest pain. On examination  he has a fever of 101.5°F  a new murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border  petechiae on the conjunctivae and extremities  and Osler's nodes are noticed on his fingers. His cardiac rate is 105 bpm with an irregular rhythm  and his blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg. The rest of his physical examination is unremarkable.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use and Hepatitis C presents with fever  night sweats  malaise  and a new-onset heart murmur. Examination revealed petechiae on his palms and soles and tender raised purple lesions on fingers and toes. He reports experiencing intermittent high-grade fevers and night sweats over the past two weeks. He also reports experiencing weight loss of approximately 5 kilograms over the same period. No prior history of heart disease. Not currently on any medications and does not have any known allergies.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female with a known history of type 2 diabetes and recent dental surgery two weeks ago presents with escalating malaise  intermittent fever (up to 101.3°F)  night sweats  and unexplained weight loss over the past week. She reports anorexia  but denies any chest pain  difficulty breathing  cough  dysuria  or abdominal pain. On physical examination  she appears chronically ill  has palmar petechiae and osler's nodes on inspection. Auscultation discloses a new murmur consistent with mitral regurgitation. She has been compliant with her diabetes medications but has no regular antibiotics use following her dental intervention. There is no history of intravenous drug use or immunosuppression. The symptomatology raises concerns for possible native valve infective endocarditis  potentially associated with recent dental intervention. An echocardiogram and blood cultures have been recommended to aid with the diagnosis.

A 55-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use presents to the emergency room with a week-long history of fever  chills  fatigue  weight loss  and a new onset of a heart murmur. He further reports experiencing intermittent night sweats. He also mentions that he has been noticing unusual red spots on the palms of his hands and in his eye whites for the past few days. The patient's family history is unremarkable  and he denies tobacco or alcohol usage but admits to ongoing intravenous drug usage. Considering his symptoms and risk factors  the patient's presentation is suggestive of infective endocarditis involving the native valves of his heart.

A 58-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use and Hepatitis C infection presents with a 2-week history of fever  malaise  weight loss  and a new murmur. The patient admits to persistent  low-grade fevers  sweating during the night  and unintentional weight loss of 10 pounds over the past two weeks. On physical examination  a new systolic murmur is noted on auscultation of the heart  along with several small erythematic lesions on his hands and feet. No previous heart conditions are reported but patient acknowledges a history of intravenous drug use without any recent use. These symptoms suggest a possible diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 57-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use and Hepatitis C presents with 2 weeks of fever  malaise  and intermittent chest pain. Physical examination shows heart murmurs  petechiae at the conjunctiva  and Osler's nodes on his fingers. His heart rate is elevated at 100 beats per minute. He reports no recent dental procedures or surgeries. His temperature is 38.7˚C  indicating the presence of a fever. His complaints  physical examination  symptoms  and medical history  together  are suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 60-year-old male patient with a known history of intravenous drug use presents with a three-week history of fatigue  fever  and an unexplained weight loss. Associated symptoms include dyspnea on exertion  night sweats  diffuse joint pains  and occasional floaters in his vision. He admits to continued heroin use over the past few months  but denies any use of needles. Physical examination reveals stigmata of chronic IV drug use  a new heart murmur  small lesions on his fingers and toes  and scattered petechiae across his body. The clinical picture suggests a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis  possibly associated with his continued heroin use.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of untreated dental abscesses and moderate tobacco use presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of unexplained weight loss  intermittent fever  night sweats  and generalized fatigue. He also complains of a new-onset heart murmur and petechial rashes on his limbs. The patient admits to poor dental hygiene and last saw a dentist more than 5 years ago. He also had a history of rheumatic fever as a child. The patient presents signs of congestive heart failure and sepsis upon physical examination  raising suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis possibly due to bacterial spread from untreated dental abscesses and a history of rheumatic heart disease.

A 52-year-old Caucasian male  smoker with a history of intravenous drug use and hypertension  presents with a 2-week history of persistent fever  fatigue  weight loss  and night sweats. He describes a progressing shortness of breath on exertion  mild chest discomfort  and a new skin rash. No prior history of heart disease is reported. Physical examination reveals a low-grade fever  an irregular heart rhythm  and a diastolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. Multiple erythematous  painless lesions are observed on the skin surface. These symptoms and findings suggest potential native-valve infective endocarditis.

Patient is a 50-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use  presenting with persistent fever  malaise  and a new heart murmur. He has noted increasing fatigue over the past month and intermittent fevers for the past week. Past medical history of Hepatitis C and multiple episodes of cellulitis related to injection drug use. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  night sweats  and productive cough. Physical examination reveals oral temperature of 101 F  a new holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border  and multiple erythematous subcutaneous nodules on the extensor surfaces of his arms. There is suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis potentially secondary to his history of intravenous drug use.

A 50-year-old Caucasian male  with a past medical history of intravenous drug use and untreated dental caries  presents with a 2-week history of persistent fever  night sweats  weight loss  and increasing fatigue. Physical examination reveals a new systolic murmur at the cardiac apex  Osler nodes on his fingers  and Janeway lesions on his palms and soles. The patient shows signs of peripheral emboli in his toes and splinter hemorrhages under his nails. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  and cough. He has no known allergies. Family history is non-contributory. The patient is a current smoker and admits to ongoing intravenous drug use. Social history indicates unemployment and homelessness.

A 62-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous (IV) drug use and Hepatitis C infection presents with a three-week history of intermittent fevers  night sweats  unexplained weight loss  and intermittent  migratory joint pain primarily affecting his knees and elbows. He notes recent ongoing fatigue and reports a newly developed harsh murmur that he feels as a chest vibration. He has a notable history of non-compliance with healthcare check-ups. On physical exam  he is febrile and appears chronically ill. He has splinter hemorrhages on his nails  Janeway lesions on his palms  Osler's nodes on his fingers  and Roth's spots in his eyes. Cardiac auscultation reveals a new grade III/VI systolic ejection murmur best heard at the apex. Lab tests reveal leukocytosis and raised inflammatory markers. These symptoms are suggestive of a possible diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for intravenous drug use  and Hepatitis C infection presents with a 2 week history of intermittent fever  night sweats  fatigue  and a new heart murmur. The patient also reports several non-painful red nodules on his fingers and toes. He further complains of lower back pain started a few days ago. His temperature is 38.5 degrees Celsius. Blood cultures are positive for Staphylococcus aureus. An echocardiography reveals vegetation on the mitral valve  suggestive of a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 55-year-old Hispanic female with a history of type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and previously treated strep throat presents to the ER with a 2-week history of high-grade intermittent fevers chills  fatigue  malaise  and recent-onset chest pain. She also reports a new onset of exertional dyspnea and nocturnal cough. Physical examination shows pale conjunctiva  petechiae on extremities  a new systolic murmur heard best at the apex  and splinter hemorrhages under her fingernails. She denies recreational drug use or recent dental procedures. Labs reveal moderate anemia  elevated inflammatory markers (ESR and CRP)  and three positive blood cultures for Streptococcus viridians. EKG shows signs of left ventricular hypertrophy. Echocardiogram demonstrates evidence of valve vegetations.

A 65-year-old male with a past medical history of permanent pacemaker placement  hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents with complaints of high-grade  intermittent fever for the past 3 weeks associated with night sweats and malaise. He reports unintentional weight loss of 7 lbs during this period. On physical examination  he has a new murmur in the mitral valve area  along with scattered petechiae. His vital signs show a heart rate of 98 bpm  blood pressure of 140/85 mm of Hg  temperature of 38.2 C  and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. Laboratory findings reveal leukocytosis and blood cultures grow Streptococcus viridans. An echocardiogram shows a vegetation on the native mitral valve consistent with infective endocarditis.

A 55-year-old male patient with a past medical history significant for uncontrolled Type II Diabetes Mellitus presents with a 3-weeks history of unexplained fever  fatigue  weight loss  night sweats  and new onset heart murmur noted by his primary care physician. The patient also mentions difficulty with fine motor movements on the left hand for the past week. He denies any travel  intravenous drug use  or recent dental surgery. Physical examination revealed petechiae on his upper extremities  Osler's nodes on his fingers and Janeway lesions on his palms and soles. Blood tests showed a moderate increase in erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP). The patient's current clinical presentation and history are suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 55-year-old male with a medical history of intravenous drug use and Hepatitis C presents to the emergency room with a 2-week history of persistent fever  fatigue  and night sweats. He also reports a new onset of intermittent sharp chest pain radiating to the back  along with shortness of breath and occasional lightheadedness. Physical examination reveals splinter hemorrhages under the nails  petechiae on the skin and a new heart murmur. He also has a palpable spleen upon abdominal examination  and a purplish rash on his lower extremities. These signs suggest a potential case of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 45-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use is presenting with a two-week history of intermittent fevers  night sweats  fatigue  and general malaise. The patient also reports a new onset of lower back pain and a notable weight loss. Examination reveals a pansystolic murmur over the mitral area  raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate  and multiple small erythematous skin lesions which are consistent with Osler nodes. The patient also presents signs of subconjunctival hemorrhages in the eyes. No previous history of rheumatic heart disease  congenital heart disease  or prosthetic valves. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are highly suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis  likely secondary to his intravenous drug use.

A 55-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use presents with a 3-week history of fatigue  fever  and night sweats. He also reports recent unintended weight loss and a new-onset  heart murmur noted on physical examination. Moreover  he notices small  painless  red spots on his palms and soles  which suggests Osler's nodes and Janeway lesions. His past medical history includes Hepatitis C  for which he is not currently receiving treatment  and previous bouts of cellulitis secondary to IV drug use. He does not have any known cardiac conditions. Currently  he is experiencing intermittent fever of 101°F  fatigue  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss all highly indicative of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 65-year-old male patient with a past medical history significant for Rheumatic Heart Disease resulting in mitral valve stenosis and Type II Diabetes Mellitus presents with a four week history of intermittent fever  fatigue  and recent onset of shortness of breath. The patient also reports experiencing unintentional weight loss of about 8lbs over the course of his illness. Further  he mentions a new-onset  erythematous  non-pruritic rash on the pads of his fingers and toes that coincide. Upon physical examination  there are signs of splinter hemorrhages in his nails. His vitals indicate a heart rate of 102 bpm and mild hypotension. The combination of constitutional symptoms  the presence of skin and nail findings  and his relevant medical history is suggestive of infective endocarditis on his native mitral valve.

Patient is a 65-year-old male with a known history of intravenous drug use presenting with aggravated symptoms of fever  chills  and fatigue for two weeks. He also has a recent history of unexplained weight loss with night sweats. He reports intermittent headaches and shortness of breath. Physical exam is significant for presence of splinter hemorrhages under the nails and osler nodes on the hands and feet. He also complains of blurred vision. Past medical history includes mitral valve prolapse and Hepatitis C. On auscultation  a systolic regurgitant-type murmur is audible. The presentation strongly suggests native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 62-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use and recent dental surgery presents with symptoms of prolonged fever  lethargy  and night sweats over a period of two weeks. He has a concurrent dull  aching chest discomfort  poor appetite  and has lost 5 lbs in the past month. He reports personal history of Hepatitis C and has no known cardiac disease. On physical examination  he displays conjunctival pallor and peripheral signs of infective endocarditis  including Janeway lesions on the palms and soles  and Osler nodes on his fingers. He has a new-onset diastolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. His blood cultures are positive and an echocardiogram reveals a vegetation on his mitral valve  indicative of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 65-year-old male patient with a history of intravenous drug use presents with fever  malaise  and new onset heart murmur. He describes a several weeks history of intermittent high-grade fevers  fatigue  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss. On physical examination  he has petechiae on his conjunctiva and extremities  along with Osler’s nodes on his fingers and toes. Auscultation reveals a new regurgitant murmur suggestive of valve damage. He has not had previous heart conditions. The symptoms are consistent with suspected native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use  diabetes  and peripheral vascular disease presents with a 2-week history of malaise  swinging fevers  weight loss  and night sweats. He also describes a new murmur and experiences episodes of stabbing chest pain mimicking angina. He noted moderate pleuritic chest pain over the past week. Blood cultures have repeatedly grown Staphylococcus aureus. The patient was admitted for suspected native-valve infective endocarditis. His condition is complicated by pre-existing heart and vascular conditions and a history of intravenous drug use  all of which increase his risk for this type of infection.

A 55-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use presents with a two-week history of fatigue  intermittent fever  and dyspnea. He also complains of lower back pain not related to any injury or trauma. He has lost approximately 10 pounds during this period. On examination  there are signs of congestion in the lungs and right-sided heart failure  small hemorrhages under the fingernails (splinter hemorrhages)  and tender  red bumps on the pads of his fingers and toes (Osler's nodes). His IV drug use history suggests a medium to high risk for infectious diseases  including native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 55-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use presents with a 3-week history of frequent high-grade fevers  malaise  poor appetite  and 10-pound weight loss. He also reports increasing breathlessness  nocturnal dyspnea  and swelling of his lower extremities. Notable physical examination findings include a new systolic murmur on cardiac auscultation  splinter hemorrhages under his nails  and small purple skin lesions on his fingers and toes (Janeway lesions).

A 60-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use presents with fever  malaise  and a new murmur. Over the past two weeks  he has experienced progressive weakness  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss. On examination  he has petechiae on his conjunctiva and fingertips  splinter hemorrhages under his nails  and Osler's nodes on his fingers and toes. His cardiac examination reveals a new pansystolic murmur heard best at the lower left sternal border. These symptoms suggest a case of native-valve infective endocarditis  likely secondary to his history of intravenous drug use.

A 45-year-old male cashier with a history of longstanding intravenous drug use and no known heart disease presents with three weeks of intermittent fevers  weight loss  and fatigue. He also reports a new murmur on cardiac auscultation. He has no family history of endocarditis or any other heart diseases. He does not smoke and has infrequent alcohol use. On physical examination  he also shows osler nodes on his fingers and toes  and Janeway lesions. The symptoms are all suggestive of possible native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 65-year-old male  a history of IVDU 30 years earlier and currently no substance use  presents with complaints of fatigue  persistent fever  and malaise occurring for the last three weeks. He also mentions experiencing a new heart murmur heard best in the 4th intercostal space at the left lower sternal border. Additional symptoms include weight loss of 5 pounds over the last month  night sweats  and chest discomfort. Physical examination reveals peripheral signs of endocarditis including Janeway lesions  Osler's nodes  and Roth’s spots. The patient also demonstrates a systolic murmur. His previous medical history includes Hepatitis C infection and a remote history of right-sided native-valve infective endocarditis. He is not under any regular medications and does not have any known allergies. Cardiac echocardiography results are still pending.

A 55-year-old Caucasian male  with a known history of intravenous drug use  presents with general malaise  persistent fever (>38.5 deg C)  night sweats  and significant weight loss over a course of four weeks. He also reports shortness of breath on exertion and a new onset of a heart murmur discovered upon physical examination. He denies any history of rheumatic fever  congenital heart diseases  or prosthetic valve implants. He has no known allergies. Laboratory findings include leukocytosis and positive blood cultures. Echocardiogram revealing vegetation on the tricuspid valve suggests possible native-valve infective endocarditis. The patient has not been immunized for Hepatitis B  nor does he have any history of sexually transmitted diseases. He has no family history of cardiac diseases. He doesn't smoke  consume alcohol  or use any medications. Current living conditions and recent history suggest poor hygiene practices and continued drug use.

A 55-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use and chronic hepatitis C presents with a three-week history of fatigue  intermittent fevers  night sweats  and weight loss. The patient also reports experiencing dull  crushing pain in his chest and subjective shortness of breath  especially when laying flat or exerting himself. On physical examination  he has low-grade fever  a new murmur suggestive of mitral regurgitation on cardiac auscultation  and several erythematous  tender nodules on his fingers and toes consistent with Osler's nodes. The patient has a history of poor dental hygiene practices but denies recent dental procedures. His blood cultures are positive for Staphylococcus aureus. His echocardiogram shows vegetations on the mitral valve  further raising suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis. There is no history of prior valve replacement or other cardiac surgery. The patient is single  a construction worker by profession  and admits to ongoing intravenous drug use.

A 60-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use presents with a 2-week history of high-grade fever  fatigue  malaise  unintended weight loss  and night sweats. Physical examination reveals a new onset systolic murmur on the left lower sternal border. Lab findings show elevated ESR and CRP along with positive blood cultures. Echocardiogram confirms vegetations on the native valves  indicative of native-valve infective endocarditis. The patient has no known allergies and he denies smoking  alcohol  or drug use since his recovery from substance disorder 5 years back. His family history is unremarkable. He is unemployed and lives alone.

A 65-year-old Hispanic male  with a past medical history of moderate rheumatic heart disease  presents with a 3-week history of fatigue  intermittent fever  night sweats  and an unintended weight loss of 10 pounds. The patient denies any recent dental procedures or intravenous drug use. Physical examination reveals a new pansystolic murmur at the mitral valve area along with few scattered petechiae. Fundoscopy shows Roth’s spots. His vitals are stable including a temperature of 38.3 Celsius. Blood cultures are ordered and are pending. The team suspects native-valve infective endocarditis given the symptoms and underlying history of rheumatic heart disease.

A 58-year-old caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use and chronic hepatitis C presents with a 3-week history of worsening fatigue  dyspnea on exertion  fever  night sweats  and weight loss. His physical examination reveals a new murmur best heard at the lower sternal border  small non-tender erythematous lesions on the palms and soles (Janeway lesions)  tiny hemorrhages in the nail beds (splinter hemorrhages)  and tender nodules on his fingertips (Osler's nodes). His white blood count is elevated  as are markers of inflammation. He is hemodynamically stable. Given his risk factors and symptomatic and exam findings  the patient is likely suffering from native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 55-year-old caucasian male with a known history of IV drug use presents to the emergency department with a 2 weeks history of fever  malaise and weight loss. He also reports developing a new onset of dyspnea and noticing petechiae on his legs. Clinical examination revealed a janeway lesion on the palm of his right hand. A heart murmur is also noted during auscultation. The patient's body temperature was 38.5°C. Other vital signs were within normal limits. No history of any major illness or chronic diseases was reported. There are no known relevant allergies or reactions. He is currently on no regular medications. Family history was unremarkable. The patient lives alone and besides illicit drug use  he reports smoking a pack of cigarettes daily  and consumes alcohol rarely. His immunization history is not completely known. The patient's symptoms along with his history of IV drug use suggest a possible diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 50-year-old male non-smoker  with a known history of intravenous drug use (IVDU) presents with a 2-week history of general malaise  weight loss  night sweats  and intermittent fever. He has noted an increasing shortness of breath  chest discomfort on exertion  a painful red rash on his lower extremities  and a new harsh systolic heart murmur on auscultation. He denies previous history of heart diseases or surgeries  has no familial cardiomyopathy history. He has no known allergies. His mother has diabetes and his father has hypertension. On examination  apart from the heart murmur  he has signs of peripheral emboli including Janeway lesions and Osler nodes. No neurological deficits are present. He appears disheveled and anxious. His vital signs are normal except for persistent low-grade fever. No previous history of rheumatic fever.

A 58-year-old male with a past medical history of intravenous drug use and recent sustained dentition trauma presents with persistent high fevers up to 39.5 C°  fatigue  loss of appetite  and an unintended 10-pound weight loss over the last 3 weeks. He also endorses a new-onset harsh  blowing holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex radiating to the axilla  nonpruritic rash predominantly on his palms and soles  and tenderness in his hip joint. Additionally  he has noticed discomfort and mild bleeding from his gums while brushing his teeth. On examination  there are multiple tender erythematous nodules on the pads of his fingers and toes  and tiny red hemorrhages under his nail beds. No dental abscesses are seen  but there is significant dental decay and gingival inflammation. He reports a continued struggle with opioid use but denies use of any new substances and adheres to harm reduction practices including only using sterile equipment. He does not have any known valve diseases or artificial implants. He has not been to a healthcare provider for a routine check-up in the last five years due to being uninsured. His last objective injection was three years ago for a separate illness.

A 45-year-old male with a history of recent dental procedure and IV drug use presents with a 10-day history of intermittent fever  malaise  and fatigue. The patient also reports a new onset of poor appetite and weight loss of 10 pounds during this course. He denies any history of cough  chest pain  hemoptysis  or urinary symptoms. There is no significant family history of heart disease. On physical examination  he is found to have fever  a new murmur in the heart auscultation  petechiae on his upper and lower extremities  and Osler's nodes on his fingers and toes. He is hospitalized for suspected native-valve infective endocarditis.

Patient is a 64-year old Caucasian male with history of IV drug use and mild hypertension  presenting with 3-week history of high-grade fever  malaise  weight loss  and night sweats. The patient also reports new onset of shortness of breath and easy fatigability. Vital signs are abnormal with elevated temperature of 38.7 degrees Celsius and elevated heart rate at 105 beats per minute. Physical examination reveals a new systolic murmur heard best over the left sternal border and associated with an early diastolic decrescendo murmur. Ocular examination shows Roth’s spots and there are Janeway lesions on the sole of both feet. Subsequent blood cultures are positive for Staphylococcus aureus.   The constellation of symptoms coupled with the patient's past medical history and confirmed positive blood cultures leads to a likely diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis  likely secondary to his IV drug use. The patient is started on empiric antimicrobial therapy and further imaging via transesophageal echocardiogram is planned to confirm vegetation on the cardiac valves.

A 60-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use presented with a 2-week history of persistent fever  malaise  night sweats  and intermittent arthralgia. He has also reported a loss of appetite resulting in a significant weight loss over a short period. On examination  he was febrile with a temperature of 38.5 degrees Celsius  and appeared overall ill. He had several needle track marks on his forearm. There were splinter hemorrhages under his fingernails  and his heart examination revealed a new murmur. No other abnormalities were noted. His past medical history includes Hepatitis C and recurrent skin abscesses. He is not taking any prescription medications. The patient has a history of multiple failed attempts at drug rehabilitation and has been living in a homeless shelter for the past 6 months. The constellation of his symptoms  risk factors  and physical findings suggest possible native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 62-year-old Caucasian male with a previous history of IV drug use and chronic heart failure presents with fatigue  malaise  and unexplained weight loss for the past 2 weeks. He also reports a new onset  intermittent high-grade fever accompanied by night sweats and a persistent dry cough. He states that he has been feeling generally unwell with a diminished appetite. On examination  the patient appears ill  is febrile  and has a grade 2/6 systolic murmur best heard at the mitral region. He also shows Janeway lesions on palms and soles  and palatal petechiae. These clinical findings indicate a possible native-valve infective endocarditis. The patient's IV drug use and chronic congestive heart failure further increase his susceptibility to this condition.

A 60-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use and hepatitis C presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of generalized fatigue  fever  night sweats  loss of appetite  and unintentional weight loss for the past six weeks. Upon detailed clinical examination  he was found to have a new-onset murmur indicative of mitral regurgitation. Suspected native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 56-year-old African American male with a medical history significant for IV drug use and recurrent skin abscesses presents with a two-week history of fever  night sweats  fatigue  weight loss  and joint pain. Further querying reveals that he has also been experiencing shortness of breath and palpitations. On physical examination  Osler nodes are noted on his fingers and red spots on the soles of his feet  suspicious of Janeway lesions. Auscultation reveals a new-onset murmur. Taken together  these symptoms and findings are highly suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 55-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for intravenous drug use  hepatitis C  and prior native-valve endocarditis presents to the emergency department with complaints of fever  malaise  and a new-onset rash on his lower extremities. The patient also reports a new harsh murmur best heard over the mitral area that has been associated with progressive shortness of breath. Upon physical examination  the patient was found to have multiple erythematous lesions on the palms and soles  consistent with Janeway lesions and petechiae on the lower extremities. A complete blood count showed leukocytosis and blood cultures are pending. The patient also represents Osler’s nodes on his fingers and toes. These case characterizations  in combination with the patient's significant cardiac murmur and history of intravenous drug use  point toward a high suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Profile: A 63-year-old Caucasian male  Past Medical History: Prior episode of staphylococcal bacteremia 6 months ago due to a skin infection. He suffers from chronic periodontitis but has no known heart disease or any other chronic diseases.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents with a four-week history of intermittent fever up to 101F  fatigue  and weight loss of approximately 10 pounds. He also complains of occasional night sweats and a new cardiac murmur. Additional symptoms include inflamed and bleeding gums  discomfort in the mouth  loosening of teeth  and poor dental hygiene.   This presentation of fatigue  fever  weight loss  night sweats and new cardiac murmur along with dental issues suggests a probable case of native-valve infective endocarditis  most likely due to hematogenous spread from chronic dental issues. Potential complications such as embolic events or heart failure should be considered  necessitating further investigations  including blood cultures and echocardiography.

A 65-year-old male patient with a known history of intravenous drug abuse presents with a 2-week history of intermittent fever  chills  fatigue  and unintended weight loss. The patient also reports experiencing a new-onset shortness of breath on exertion over the past week and night sweats. He looks malnourished and appears ill. On physical examination  there are Osler's nodes present on his fingers and toes  and Janeway's lesions are seen on the palms and soles  suggestive of embolic phenomena. Upon auscultation  a changing heart murmur is identified. No history of previous surgeries or heart diseases. His social history reveals continued use of intravenous drugs. He is single and lives alone; his last healthcare visit was years ago. Given his presentation and past medical history  there is a strong suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis due to intravenous drug use.

A 64-year-old male patient with a past medical history of intravenous drug use and chronic hepatic disease presents with a two-week history of intermittent fever  profuse sweating  fatigue  and weight loss. He reported a loss of appetite and evening rise of temperature. He also mentioned joint pain  palpitations and a new murmur noted on examination. He has not sought prior medical attention and does not take any regular medications. On examination  he has mild splenomegaly and cardiac examination revealed a new diastolic murmur. There are several petechial rashes on the skin as well. These symptoms - especially heart palpitations and the evidence of a heart murmur suggest possible infective endocarditis. His history of intravenous drug use is a known risk factor for this condition. His weight loss  fever  and night sweats further support the potential diagnosis.

A 65-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use presents to the emergency department with a 10-day history of fever  fatigue  exertional dyspnea  and a new-onset murmur. He also reports diarrhea  night sweats  and weight loss. He denies chest pain but does endorse orthopnea. Physical examination confirms a diastolic murmur and reveals petechiae on the palms and soles. Temperature is 38.5°C and other vital signs are stable. The patient has a past medical history of Hepatitis C and peripheral artery disease. He has had minimal medical care in the past and takes no medications regularly. He does not report any known drug allergies. The patient used to work as a manual laborer and lives alone; he has been unemployed for the past 5 years and has a history of homelessness. His only family is an adult daughter with whom he has irregular contact. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history and admits to ongoing substance and alcohol abuse.

Patient is a 62-year-old white male  with a history of chronic IV drug use  and without any significant cardiac history  who presents with 2 weeks of fever  fatigue  malaise  night sweats  weight loss and a new cardiac murmur on examination. He has recently had multiple skin abscesses due to drug use injections that were treated with incision and drainage but no antibiotics. On presentation  he appears unwell  sweaty  and tired. Lung examination does not reveal any crackles  and cardiovascular examination identifies a new  audible holosystolic murmur along the left lower sternal border. No janeway lesions  Osler nodes  Roth spots or petechiae are seen on skin examination. He is febrile  with a temperature of 38.5C. He is currently hemodynamically stable but admitted to the hospital for evaluation of suspected infective endocarditis.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus and recent dental procedure two weeks ago  presents with 1-week history of high-grade fever  fatigue  and new onset of shortness of breath. Additionally  he reports experiencing a new loss of appetite and a weight loss of 5lbs over the last week. On examination  petechiae were observed in the conjunctivae and extremities  along with slight swelling of his ankles. The patient has a heart murmur not previously documented. A clinical suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis is considered  possibly associated with his recent dental procedure and diabetes status.

A 63-year-old Caucasian female presents with fever  fatigue  and dyspnea over a period of 2 weeks. The patient has a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and atrial fibrillation for which she is on metformin  losartan  and apixaban respectively. She also had dental extraction 3 weeks ago. Vital signs reveal a temperature of 38.5°C  heart rate 102 bpm  blood pressure 145/92 mmHg  and oxygen saturation of 93% on room air. Physical examination is remarkable for a new-onset  grade III/VI diastolic murmur on auscultation of the heart  slight peripheral edema  and faint red spots (Janeway lesions) on palms and soles. Laboratory results show moderately elevated inflammation markers. Blood cultures are drawn and she is admitted for suspected native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 58-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use and no regular healthcare  presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of intermittent fevers  night sweats  and weight loss. The patient also complains of recent onset of shortness of breath and productive cough with greenish sputum. Physical examination reveals a systolic murmur at apex radiating to the axilla  and small  painless  erythematous lesions on the palms and soles. Splinter hemorrhages are noted in the nail beds. Lab tests show elevated inflammatory markers. A transesophageal echocardiogram shows vegetations on the mitral valve suggestive of infective endocarditis.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a 20-year history of intravenous drug use and untreated Hepatitis C presents to the hospital with a 2-week history of generalized malaise  loss of appetite  and unexplained weight loss of approximately 10 pounds. Also reports a new-onset  low-grade  continuous fever accompanied by night sweats. He recently noticed a new rash on his lower extremities and unusual red spots on his palms. On physical examination  there were signs of heart murmur  tiny purple or red spots (petechiae) under the fingernails  and Janeway lesions on palms and soles. He has no known cardiac surgeries or interventions in the past and is generally non-compliant with medical care due to his homeless status. He denies any recent dental work or procedures. The patient's presentation is concerning for native-valve infective endocarditis potentially related to his long-standing history of intravenous drug use.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a significant medical history of rheumatic heart disease  smoking  and recent dental surgery presents with a month-long history of fatigue  fevers  night sweats  and weight loss. On presentation  an examination revealed Osler's nodes (painful red nodules on fingers and toes)  Janeway lesions (non-tender  small erythematous or hemorrhagic macular or nodular lesions on the palms or soles)  and a new-onset heart murmur. The acute onset of symptoms following dental surgery  combined with signs suggestive of vascular phenomena and an immunologic reaction  increases the suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 54-year-old  African-American male with a history of intravenous drug use and Hepatitis C presents with a 3-week period worsening symptoms of fever  chills  night sweats  loss of weight  and generalized fatigue. He also reports a new onset of a murmur that onset 4 days ago. Physical examination reveals a diastolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border  and a positive Osler nodes (painful nodes on the fingers and toes). There are also splinter hemorrhages in his nails. Notably  he has a history of non-adherence to medical advice and follow up in a substance misuse clinic. Currently  resides in a homeless shelter. He denies any recent dental work. His heart rate is elevated  and he is febrile  indicative of an ongoing systemic infection. Consequently  there is a high likelihood of infective endocarditis  likely secondary to his history of intravenous drug use.

A 60-year-old Caucasian male  a previous IV drug user now clean for 10 years  with a past medical history significant for Hepatitis C and congestive heart failure  presents with a 2-week history of progressive fatigue  fever  weight loss of approximately 5 kg and night sweats. On examination  he was found to have a new heart murmur suggestive of mitral regurgitation  petechiae on the palpebral conjunctiva and fingertips  and mild splenomegaly. His laboratory tests reveal elevated inflammatory parameters  moderate anemia  and negative rheumatoid factor. Blood cultures are positive for Staphylococcus aureus. These findings are suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis.

Subject is a 56-year-old male non-smoker with a past medical history significant for Type II Diabetes Mellitus  well-controlled with Metformin  who presents with a three-week history of fever  malaise  and unintentional weight loss. He also reports a new cardiac murmur  night sweats  fatigue and dyspnea on exertion. The patient does not use illicit drugs and has no history of intravenous drug use. He has not recently had any dental procedures. His immunizations are up-to-date  and he has no known drug allergies. On physical examination  the patient appears ill and flushed  with a temperature of 38.6 °C. Cardiac examination reveals a new 3/6 pansystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. Further evaluation and blood cultures are needed to confirm the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for mild hypertension  a 45-year history of smoking  and signs consistent with alcohol use disorder  presents to the emergency department with an intermittent fever of approximately 101.5°F lasting for the past 3 weeks. He also reports diminished appetite  weight loss of around 15 pounds in the past month and an overall feeling of malaise. The patient's physical examination revealed mild tachycardia  a heart murmur suggestive of aortic regurgitation  splinter hemorrhages in the nails  tender red spots under the skin on the palms and soles (Osler nodes)  and small erythematous lesions on the retina and conjunctiva indicative of Roth spots. His laboratory findings show a raised ESR  CRP and positive blood cultures for Staphylococcus aureus. These findings are suggestive of infective endocarditis affecting the patient's native cardiac valves. The patient's history of smoking and alcohol use disorder may have contributed to a compromised immune system  predisposing him to infection.

Ms. Sanchez  a 64-year-old Hispanic female with a history of rheumatic heart disease and uncontrolled diabetes mellitus  presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of intermittent fevers up to 101.7 degrees Fahrenheit  progressive fatigue  reduced appetite and unexplained weight loss. In addition  she reports experiencing general malaise. On examination  it is noted that she has a new-onset grade 3/6 systolic murmur heard best at the apex  Janeway lesions on palms and soles  and Osler nodes on her fingers and toes. Her blood cultures are positive for Staphylococcus aureus. Chest X-ray reveals possible septic emboli. These clinical findings - in conjunction with the patient’s history - suggest a suspected diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 54-year-old male patient with a medical history of intravenous drug use  poor dental hygiene  and previous episodes of cellulitis  presents with a 3-week history of fatigue  fevers  and intermittent night sweats. He further reports a new-onset lower back pain  shortness of breath  and a recently noticed non-painful  erythematous rash on the palms and soles. The physical exam yields the presence of a new heart murmur  splinter hemorrhages under the nails  conjunctival hemorrhages  and splenomegaly. The patient does not have any known allergies  is not on any medication  and denies alcohol or tobacco use. His family history is unremarkable.

A 55-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of intravenous drug use and hepatitis C  presents to the emergency department with a two-week history of fever  chills  malaise  night sweats  and a new-onset heart murmur. The patient also reports painful red bumps on her fingers and toes (Osler's nodes) and white spots on her retina (Roth's spots). She has been non-compliant with her hepatitis C medication. Physical examination reveals a diastolic murmur best heard at the apex  along with petechiae on the skin and conjunctivae. These symptoms suggest a possible diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis  most likely related to her history of intravenous drug use.

A 62-year-old male with history of IV drug abuse presents with a 4-week history of fatigue  malaise  night sweats  and unexplained weight loss. He also reports a new onset of shortness of breath and a persistent cough with occasional blood-tinged sputum. Physical examination reveals low-grade fever  a systolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border  peripheral petechiae  and Janeway lesions on the palms and soles. Lab results demonstrate elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP)  positive blood cultures for Staphylococcus aureus  and negative HIV test. His echocardiogram shows vegetation on the tricuspid valve  suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis.

Patient information: 55-year-old male  Medical History: The patient has a history of intravenous drug abuse and was previously treated for Hepatitis C. No known allergies are reported. He does not have any history of heart surgeries or heart valve diseases.   Presentation of symptoms: The patient presents with a week-long history of persistent fever  sweating  and chills. He reports experiencing unintentional weight loss and reduced appetite. He also notes fatigue and shortness of breath  especially with physical exertion. More disturbingly  he mentions experiencing intermittent chest pain over the past few days.  In summary  this is a 55-year-old male  with a history of intravenous drug abuse and treated Hepatitis C  presenting with potential native-valve infective endocarditis characterized by persistent fever  chills  sweats  weight loss  reduced appetite  fatigue  shortness of breath  and chest pain.

Gender: Male  Age: 60 years old  Occupation: Farmer  Patient presents with a week-long history of episodic  high-grade fever  shortness of breath  and fatigue that has progressively worsened. Patient also reports unintentional weight loss and night sweats over the past month. He complains of persistent nagging right upper quadrant pain. His past medical history is relevant for rheumatoid arthritis treated with low-dose steroids and methotrexate  and a remote history of intravenous drug use in his early adulthood. No known drug allergies.  Patient underwent a dental procedure three weeks ago. On examination  there was a new regurgitant murmur heard best at the left mid-sternal border. A Janeway lesions was evidenced on the palms of his hands. There was moderate splenomegaly palpated on deep abdominal examination.   In context of his history  presentation and examination findings  this patient's clinical picture may be consistent with the diagnosis of infective endocarditis on his native valves. Given his history of rheumatoid arthritis  IVDU and recent dental procedure  he may have been at an increased risk of this condition  and its presentations like splenomegaly and Janeway lesions.

A 62-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use and chronic Hepatitis C  presents to the emergency department with complaints of intermittent fever  fatigue  weight loss of around 10 lbs over last 2 months and a new-onset heart murmur. He has also noted small  red spots on his skin and nails. On examination  he is febrile with a temperature of 101 degrees Fahrenheit  tachycardic with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  and displays Osler nodes on his fingers and Janeway lesions on his palms and soles. His blood pressure and respiratory rate are within normal limits. Cardiac examination reveals a new-onset systolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border. No history of any prosthetic valve or heart surgeries in the past. His hepatitis C is poorly controlled  and he admits to continued intravenous drug use. He has no known allergies or family history of heart disease.

A 55-year-old Caucasian male  with a medical history of type 2 diabetes and regular intravenous drug use  presents with complaints of high-grade intermittent fever lasting for the past two weeks and associated with night sweats and weight loss. He also reports new-onset breathlessness  fatigue  and a decreased appetite. On physical examination  he exhibits a heart murmur suggestive of valvular dysfunction  Janeway lesions on the palms and soles  petechiae across his body  and Osler's nodes on his fingertips. Blood tests show increased ESR  CRP levels  and positive blood cultures for Staphylococcus aureus. The patient's symptoms and signs  together with the positive blood culture  support the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 63-year-old male with a past medical history of type 2 diabetes and dental abscesses presents with a 1-week history of fever  chills  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss. The patient also reports recent onset of night sweats and intermittent chest pain. Examination findings include a new cardiac murmur  Osler's nodes on fingers and toes  and Janeway lesions on palms and soles. Blood cultures are pending. This presentation is consistent with newly developed native-valve infective endocarditis  likely secondary to poor dental hygiene.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a history of Type 2 Diabetes and previous dental work presents with fever  fatigue  night sweats and weight loss over the past two weeks. He complains of new onset shortness of breath and intermittent  non-radiating chest pain. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation over the sternum  a heart murmur  tiny red or purple spots (petechiae) on the skin  and slight edema in the feet and ankles.

A 62-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use  hepatitis C  and heart murmur presents with persistent fever  night sweats  and weight loss over the past 3 weeks. The patient has also experienced increasing fatigue and shortness of breath with minimal exertion. On physical examination  there are petechiae on his palms and soles  a new regurgitant murmur on cardiac auscultation and Osler's nodes on his fingers. The symptoms are suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 57-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for intravenous drug use and Hepatitis C presents with a 4-week history of low-grade fevers  generalized malaise  and unintentional weight loss. On further enquiry  the patient admits to using intravenous drugs with non-sterile needles. He denies chest pain or dyspnea but reports having an increased heart rate which prompted his visit to the hospital. He does not have any known allergies and is not currently on any medication. Physical exam reveals a new-onset pansystolic murmur over the mitral area  petechiae on the upper extremities and nail-bed splinter hemorrhages. Blood cultures are ordered and are positive for Staphylococcus aureus. A diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis is suspected.

A 55-year-old male smoker with a history of intravenous drug use and no known cardiac history presenting with fever  malaise  and night sweats for the past 2 weeks. Examination shows pale conjunctiva  splinter hemorrhages under the nails  and an ejection systolic murmur is noted at the right upper sternal border. Blood tests report a raised inflammatory marker level and blood cultures reveal the growth of Staphylococcus aureus  indicating the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 68-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use and chronic Hepatitis C infection presents with two weeks of fever  fatigue  and unexplained weight loss. Additionally  he complains of a continuous low-grade fever for the past week. On physical examination  he shows signs of peripheral emboli phenomenon  including splinter hemorrhages  Janeway's lesions  and Osler’s nodes. Increased intensity of the tricuspid valve murmur is noted on cardiac auscultation. He denies having any chest pain  shortness of breath  cough  or gastrointestinal symptoms. His laboratory tests show elevated inflammatory markers  positive blood cultures  and microorganisms consistent with Staphylococcus aureus.

A 65-year-old Hispanic female smoker with a medical history of uncontrolled type II diabetes mellitus and recent dental surgery three weeks ago  presents with a three-day history of intermittent fever  chills  night sweats  and general malaise. She also reports experiencing a new onset of positional dizziness and an unintentional 10 lb. weight loss over the last month. She had been previously treated with oral antibiotics for a suspected minor UTI  but her symptoms persisted and have now been associated with a gradual decline in functional status. Examination reveals pallor  dental caries  and a new systolic murmur best heard at the lower-left sternal border that radiates to the axilla. Temperature is 38.5 degrees Celsius. Preliminary labs show elevated ESR and CRP with a positive blood culture. These findings suggest a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis  likely arising from the recent dental procedure.

A 65-year-old male  former intravenous drug user with a known history of hepatitis C and congenital heart defect  presents to the ED with a 2-week history of persistent fever  general malaise  night sweats  weight loss  and recent onset of shortness of breath. Physical examination reveals irregular heart rate  heart murmur suggestive of aortic regurgitation and multiple painful  erythematous lesions on his extremities known as Osler's nodes. Lab findings indicate elevated WBC  ESR and CRP levels. Initial blood cultures have grown out staphylococcus aureus. The combination of persistent fever  positive blood cultures  evidence of heart valvular damage from patient's history and clinical examination  lead to a working diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.

Problem Representation:  A 56-year-old Caucasian male  known case of intravenous drug use  presents to the clinic with a one-week history of high-grade fever  chill  night sweats  and palpitations. He also reports a new murmur and complains of fatigue  difficulty breathing  and a loss of appetite. His past medical history is significant for Hepatitis C infection  and he has a history of hospitalization 10 years prior due to a similar condition. He denies any recent dental work or surgery. On examination  multiple painless erythematous lesions are noted on both his palms and soles  and few tiny red spots under the fingernails (splinter hemorrhages) are seen. He is in mild distress  and a cardiac examination reveals a new-onset systolic murmur. The initial suspicion is of native-valve infective endocarditis likely secondary to intravenous drug use.

A 62-year-old Caucasian male  smoker and with a known history of intravenous drug use and untreated dental caries  presents with a one-week history of fever  fatigue  weight loss  night sweats  a new onset systolic murmur  and incidental petechiae. There is no previous history of heart disease. His vitals on arrival show a raised temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F)  heart rate 106/min  blood pressure 100/60 mmHg  respirations 20/min  and oxygen saturation 94% on room air. Initial lab results indicate leukocytosis with a left shift  elevated ESR  and CRP. The patient's symptoms  examination findings  and known high-risk behavior suggest possible native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 60-year-old male patient with a history of intravenous drug use and hepatitis C presents to the ER with a 2-week history of fever  night sweats  fatigue  and weight loss. On examination  he has a temperature of 38.5°C  an irregular pulse of 110 bpm  and a blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg. Cardiovascular examination reveals a diastolic murmur best heard at left lower sternal border. He also has splinter hemorrhages under the nails and Janeway lesions on the palms of the hands. Blood cultures are obtained and he is admitted to the hospital under suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 50-year-old male with a history of intravenous substance use disorder presents with a two-week history of low-grade fever  malaise  and unintentional weight loss. He also notes drenching night sweats and occasional chest discomfort. On examination  he has a low-grade fever and a new heart murmur on cardiac auscultation  noted to be a diastolic rumbling murmur best heard along the left sternal border. Other physical findings include splinter hemorrhages under the nails  and small  tender  erythematous lesions on the pads of the fingers and toes. An immediate concern is for native-valve infective endocarditis  likely secondary to his history of intravenous drug use.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of intravenous drug use presents with persistent fevers  night sweats  and fatigue for the past 2 weeks. He also reports a recent unexplained weight loss. On physical examination  he appears unkempt and has poor dentition. He has multiple erythematous lesions on the tips of his fingers  Oslers nodes  and a new-onset heart murmur. His lab work shows elevated inflammatory markers. This history and presentation are suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male  with a history of intravenous drug use  currently smoking  presents with persistent fever for a week. The patient also reports experiencing generalized fatigue  unintended weight loss  and night sweats. On examination  he is found to be febrile (38.5°C) with a new murmur noted upon auscultation. Splinter hemorrhages are noted under the fingernails and there are signs of Osler's nodes on his fingers. His last dental procedure was 6 months ago. No structural heart abnormalities were reported in his medical history. The patient's history of smoking and drug abuse along with the symptomatic presentation of prolonged fever and new cardiac murmur raises high suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a 10-year history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus type 2 and former intravenous drug use presents with a two-week history of progressive fatigue  poor appetite  and night sweats. He further mentions experiencing intermittent fever over the past few days. On examination  the patient has a low-grade fever  a systolic murmur best heard over the mitral region  and Osler's nodes are identified over the fingers. He has no previous history of any heart diseases. Results of blood cultures are pending. The constellation of symptoms raises concern for possible native-valve infective endocarditis.

A 62-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of intravenous drug abuse presents with a three-week history of fever  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss. The patient also reports experiencing night sweats  a new-onset heart murmur  and dark urine. He denies any recent surgical procedures  dental procedures  or travel abroad but admits to ongoing drug misuse. On examination  the patient appears cachectic and ill-looking  with splinter hemorrhages under the nails and Janeway lesions on the palms and soles. Cardiovascular examination reveals a diastolic murmur in the aortic region. He is admitted to the hospital with suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis due to illicit intravenous drug use.

Patient is a 65-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use who presents with a four week history of fever  night sweats  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss. Recently  the patient has started experiencing shortness of breath and a new-onset murmur  suggestive of cardiac involvement. Physical examination reveals Osler nodes on his fingers and Janeway lesions on the palms and soles. His history of intravenous drug use and current symptomology indicates a high risk of native valve infective endocarditis. Further evaluation for the potential underlying cardiac damage and sepsis is warranted.

A 60-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous drug use and chronic hepatitis C presents to the emergency department with complaints of fever  chills  fatigue and shortness of breath over the last three weeks. He also reports experiencing a sudden onset of back pain and reduced urine output over the last several days. The patient also mentions noticing blood in his urine. On examination  he has pale conjunctivae  a new systolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border  and signs of vascular occlusion evident in Janeway lesions on the palms and soles. There is also evidence of Osler nodes (painful nodules) on his fingers and toes. His vitals show a temperature of 38.5 deg C  BP 100/70 mmHg  heart rate 110 bpm  and respiratory rate 18 per minute. His condition suggests native valve infective endocarditis  most likely secondary to his intravenous drug use  complicated by renal infarction and possible glomerulonephritis.

Patient Profile: - Name: Mr. Smith - Age: 58 years old - Gender: Male - Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Construction worker - Residence: Urban residence - Marital Status: Married with two adult children - Smoking History: Ex-smoker  quit 15 years ago - Alcohol Consumption: Moderate drinker - Physical Exercise: Rarely  Presenting Problem: Mr. Smith has been experiencing fluctuating fever over the last two weeks along with fatigue  malaise  and unexplained weight loss. Initially  he attributed these symptoms to work-related stress and overexertion. However  upon noticing blood in his urine and producing a persistent cough  he sought medical attention.  Past Medical History: - Mr. Smith has a 12-year history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed with oral hypoglycemic drugs. - He has been hypertensive for the last 10 years  controlled with ACE inhibitors. - He was hospitalized 15 years ago for a coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG) due to severe coronary artery disease. - He was diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease five years ago and has refused to go through surgery  he is currently managed with medications and lifestyle changes.  Family History: - Father died of Heart Attack at the age of 60.  - Mother is still alive at 78 with a history of hypertension.  Past Surgical History:  - Had a laparoscopic appendectomy 25 years ago - Coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery 15 years ago.  Social History: - Mr. Smith smoked for ten years but quit 15 years ago. - He consumes alcohol occasionally in moderate amounts. - Gets minimal exercise due to the nature of his work and fatigue. - He follows an unhealthy diet high in fats and sugars.  Current Medications: - Metformin 1000mg twice daily for type 2 diabetes - Lisinopril 20mg daily for hypertension - Aspirin 81mg daily as a blood thinner - Atorvastatin 40mg daily for cholesterol  The problem representation for Mr. Smith suggests that he is an older man with a chronic history of diabetes  hypertension  coronary and peripheral arterial disease  who presents with new-onset fluctuating fever  fatigue  malaise  and cough  which are indicative of possible native-valve infective endocarditis. This suspicion is heightened by his history of heart disease and surgery  poorly controlled diabetes  and hypertension  which are risk factors for bacterial endocarditis. His lifestyle and habits  including smoking history and unhealthy diet  are additional risk factors for cardiovascular disease or infection. It also indicates a need for adjustment of his diabetes and hypertension management. His urinary symptoms may suggest renal involvement due to endocarditis. Immediate investigation is needed to confirm the diagnosis and commence appropriate treatment.

Patient Profile:  - Name: Mr. John Doe - Age: 67 years - Sex: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired  - Marital status: Married - Children: Two  - Smoking status: Non-smoker - Alcohol consumption: Moderate  socially - Dietary habits: Typical western diet - Physical activity levels: Low due to recent lethargy  Presenting Issue:   Mr. Doe presents with new-onset symptoms of lethargy  fever  chills  night sweats  weight loss  and reduced appetite. A murmur noted in the mitral valve area since the last medical examination. Also complaining of occasional discomfort in his joints  particularly small joints of the hands and fingers.  Relevant Past Medical History:   - Rheumatic fever as a child - Known mitral valve regurgitation diagnosed 10 years ago on echocardiogram  under cardiology follow-up  - Episodes of irregular heartbeat (Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation) managed with beta-blockers - Mildly elevated blood pressure (hypertension) under control with medication - Diabetes type 2  non-insulin dependent  controlled through oral medications and diet - History of dental procedures with a recent tooth extraction 2 months ago - No history of illegal intravenous drug use  Medications:  - Metformin 500mg BD for diabetes - Ramipril 10mg daily for hypertension - Bisoprolol 5mg daily for atrial fibrillation  Allergies:  - No known drug allergies  Assessment:  The history of rheumatic fever along with the chronic valve disease (mitral regurgitation)  together with the current symptoms may suggest the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis (IE). The symptoms of weight loss  fever  night sweats and new cardiac murmur are classic signs of infective endocarditis. This patient also has a fair number of risk factors such as advancing age  male sex  the presence of diabetes  and recent dental procedure. Additionally  paroxysmal atrial fibrillation might require anticoagulant use which could potentially aggravate any existing infection.   Next Steps:  Immediate hospital admission is warranted. Blood cultures should be taken and empirical antibiotic therapy should be initiated while awaiting culture results. The piece of management would be a consultation with the infectious disease specialist and a cardiologist. A Trans-esophageal echocardiogram (TEE) should be performed to visualize any vegetations on the heart valves  determine the severity of the valve disease  and to assess for any potential complications of IE  such as abscess formation. Dental consultation regarding appropriate prophylaxis for future dental procedures is also a consideration due to the apparent association of his recent IE symptoms after dental extraction. In-hospital management would be considered after a diagnosis is confirmed or highly suspected.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 67 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired truck driver Residence: Urban area  Presenting Problem:  John presents with a persistent fever of two weeks duration. He also complains of fatigue  night sweats  joint pains  and unintentional weight loss.
