He noticed a new skin rash and red spots on his palms and soles  and has had shortness of breath on exertion and episodes of dizziness and fainting.  Past Medical History:  John has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he is taking metformin. He had a transient ischemic attack five years ago. He is also a long-term smoker with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and had an episode of community-acquired pneumonia two years ago. He does not have any known drug allergies. His immunizations are up to date  including pneumococcal and influenza vaccines.  Family History:  There is a family history of cardiovascular disease - his father died from a heart attack at age 75 and his mother has chronic heart failure. His younger brother has hypertension and his sister has type 2 diabetes mellitus.  Social History:  John is a widower who lives alone. He has two children who visit intermittently. He's a former truck driver  retired ten years ago. He has a 40-pack year history of smoking but quit a year ago. He admits to being a social drinker. He has a diet high in fats and carbohydrates with minimal fruits or vegetables and doesn't engage in regular physical activity.  Review of Symptoms:  Positive for fever  fatigue  night sweats  joint pain  weight loss  skin rash  shortness of breath on exertion  and episodes of dizziness and fainting. Denied any recent dental procedures  surgeries  or changes in medications. He also denies any urinary symptoms  diarrhea  chest pains or cough.  Physical Examination:  Vital signs show temperature of 38.3°C  BP 144/85 mmHg  heart rate 102 beats per minute  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. He appears fatigued  sweaty and in distress. Cardiovascular examination reveals a new heart murmur. Pulmonary  gastrointestinal  neurological examinations and other systems are within normal limits.  This presentation could represent a case of native-valve infective endocarditis for which further investigations such as complete blood count  blood culture  ESR  CRP  echocardiogram  Chest X-ray  and possibly a transoesophageal echocardiography should be ordered. After confirmation  the patient would likely need hospitalization  intravenous antibiotics  and a consultation with a cardiothoracic surgeon for possible valve repair or replacement surgery.

Patient Profile:  Name: Jane Doe Age: 58 Sex: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Teacher Residence: Suburban Marital Status: Widowed  Presenting Symptoms: Jane presented with a two week history of moderate- to high-grade fevers  weight loss  night sweats  fatigue  and a new-onset heart murmur.  Demographics: Jane is a 58 year-old Caucasian female and does not smoke or consume alcohol. She is a retired high school teacher and lives alone in a suburban area. She had undergone dental work two weeks prior  however  she did not take antibiotics prophylactically.  Past Medical History: Jane has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus (well maintained)  hypertension  and a body mass index (BMI) within the normal range. She does not have a history of valve disease  IV drug abuse or rheumatic fever. She is not immunocompromised and does not have a placement of any indwelling device or prosthesis.  Family History: Her parents had coronary artery disease. Her two siblings are healthy.  Physical Examination: Jane has a body temperature of 38.4°C (101.1 F°)  blood pressure of 130/85  pulse rate of 86 beats/min  respiratory rate of 16 breaths/min and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. A new-onset regurgitation murmur heard at the cardiac apex. No skin petechiae  Janeway lesions  Osler's nodes or Roth's spots are noted.  This patient profile for Jane Doe describes a typical patient that presents with native-valve infective endocarditis. Her dental procedure and lack of prophylactic antibiotics  as well as diabetes  places her at increased risk for this disease.

Patient Profile: - 65-year-old Caucasian male - Sedentary lifestyle  former smoker (quit 10 years ago) - History of moderate alcohol use  currently drinks socially  - Lives alone  has limited support system - Retired truck driver  moderate socioeconomic status  Presenting Problem: - Chief complaint: persistent fever  fatigue  loss of appetite  and unexplained weight loss for the past few weeks - Recent hospitalization 3 months ago for a urinary tract infection after catheterization for a brief episode of urinary retention with fever. Completed course of antibiotics.   Medical History: - Type 2 diabetes mellitus under control with metformin - Hypertension managed with lisinopril and amlodipine - Osteoarthritis in both knees - Family history records indicate that his father had coronary artery disease and his mother had rheumatoid arthritis  Physical Examination: - Mild pallor  looks chronically ill - Multiple hematuria under nail beds - Mild splenomegaly upon palpation - Heart sounds reveal a new murmur  suggestive of aortic regurgitation  Laboratory and Imaging Findings: - Increase in ESR and CRP indicating inflammation - Blood cultures positive for Streptococcus viridans  - Transesophageal echocardiogram revealed vegetations on the aortic valve  Medication  Allergies and Immunization History: - No known drug or food allergies  - On Metformin 500 mg twice a day  Lisinopril 10 mg daily  Amlodipine 5 mg daily - Recently completed a course of Ciprofloxacin for a UTI - Immunizations up to date  Social History: - Had been a domesticated pet owner with regular interaction with a dog - Limited physical activity with a sedentary lifestyle - Quit smoking 10 years ago  has history of moderate alcohol use - Limited diet  minimal intake of fruits and vegetables  Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old male with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  presenting with several weeks of fatigue  fever  appetite loss and weight loss exhibits physical findings of aortic regurgitation and splenomegaly. Relevant history includes a recent urinary infection which was treated with a course of antibiotics. Laboratory results indicate inflammation and blood cultures show Streptococcus viridans. An echocardiogram revealed aortic valve vegetations  consistent with a diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis.

Problem Representation:  A 58-year-old Caucasian woman presents with a three-week history of intermittent fevers  chills  malaise  and unintended weight loss. She reports experiencing a loss of appetite  resulting in a weight loss of approximately 5 kilograms over the past month. She denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or cough. She denies recent travels  illicit drug use  or exposure to sick contacts. Her past medical history is significant for hypertension  managed with daily lisinopril  and a dental procedure three months ago. She is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol socially. She lives alone and is retired.  Physical examination revealed slight pallor  fever of 38.5 °C  heart rate of 95 beats per minute  and blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg. There is evidence of conjunctival pallor and splinter hemorrhages under the nails. Cardiovascular examination is significant for a new onset pansystolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border.  The patient did not receive prophylactic antibiotics during her dental procedure  and a review of her dental records indicates that it involved manipulation of the gingival tissue. These findings raise suspicion for possible infective endocarditis.   Laboratory studies showed a raised total leukocyte count with predominant neutrophilia and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Blood cultures are underway. An immediate transesophageal echocardiogram is recommended to confirm signs of vegetations on heart valves  indicative of infective endocarditis.  This patient's demographic characterization  relevant past medical history  and clinical signs support a high index of suspicion for infective endocarditis of native valve - likely secondary to a dental procedure. Adequate and timely treatment is necessary to avoid severe complications such as valve destruction  heart failure  and septic emboli.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 65-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. Smith.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Smith came to the hospital with complaints of recurrent fever  night sweats and unexplained weight loss for the past month  all of which have gradually worsened over the last week.  Demographics: Mr. Smith is a retired construction worker. He is a non-smoker and does not abuse alcohol or consume illicit drugs. He is married with three adult children and lives in a suburban area.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus which is well controlled with oral medication. He also has a history of mitral valve prolapse detected during a routine physical examination 10 years ago.  Surgical History: Mr. Smith has had no past surgical interventions.  Family History: There is a family history of heart disease (father died of a myocardial infarction at age 74) and diabetes.  Relevant Physical Findings: During physical examination  his temperature was found to be 38.3 degrees Celsius. Heart examination revealed a new murmur suggestive of mitral regurgitation. He also had tender  erythematous nodules in his fingertips (Osler's nodes) and hemorrhagic retinal lesions (Roth's spots).  Problem List: Primary: 1. Suspected Infective Endocarditis   Secondary: 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  3. Mitral Valve Prolapse   Plan: The patient needs to undergo laboratory investigations including complete blood count  blood cultures and inflammatory markers. An echocardiogram is also required to confirm the diagnosis of infective endocarditis and assess the severity of mitral regurgitation. Empirical antibiotic therapy should be started after drawing blood cultures.

Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 54-year-old African-American man  presenting at the outpatient clinic.  Presenting Complaints: The patient complains of unexplained weight loss  intermittent fever  chills  shortness of breath  and a persistent cough over the past several months.  Medical History: Mr. Doe's medical history reveals high blood pressure  which has been relatively well controlled with medication  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  which is managed with oral hypoglycemic agents  diet and physical activity. He quit smoking 5 years ago after a 15-year history of one-pack-a-day. His family history includes a father who passed from myocardial infarction at age 62 and a mother who is currently living with hypertension and diabetes.  Recent History: In the last 6 months  he was hospitalized for pneumonia  from which he recovered after a course of antibiotics.  Social History: He lives alone in a lower income urban area and works as an office employee. Cites no drug use or alcohol abuse.  Preliminary Diagnosis: His symptoms suggest a possible case of native-valve infective endocarditis. Although rare  this condition can occur among non-intravenous drug users with a history of other heart-related health concerns. His recent pneumonia could have also contributed to endocarditis.  Imaging and Laboratory Tests: Further supporting evidence would come from specific laboratory tests  including complete blood count with differential count  blood cultures  C-reactive protein  erythrocyte sedimentation rate  and urinalysis. Transthoracic echocardiography can be used for imaging studies to confirm the presence of vegetation or abscess.  Next Steps: If the preliminary diagnosis is confirmed  the patient may require hospitalization for intravenous antibiotics  with careful monitoring for complications such as emboli  heart failure  or abscesses. In severe cases  surgery may be necessary to replace the infected heart valve.

The patient also has a new onset of shortness of breath on exertion and occasionally at rest  with non-productive cough. Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 65-year-old Caucasian female  Chief Complaint: Persistent fever  fatigue  and unexplained weight loss for 2 weeks  Past Medical History: The patient has a significant past medical history pertaining to conditions like type II diabetes mellitus (well controlled with metformin since past 10 years)  hypertension (on Amlodipine 5mg)  and hyperlipidaemia (managed with atorvastatin 20mg).   Social History: The patient is an active smoker (1 pack/day for over 30 years)  denies alcohol or illicit drug use. The patient recently got an oral dental procedure from a local dentist about 3 weeks ago. She lives with her husband and two dogs  recently retired from work as a school teacher.  Presenting Signs & Symptoms: In addition to fever and fatigue  the patient also reports occasional night sweats  mild joint and muscle aches  intermittent headaches  and a small painful red spot on her left arm. Red and painful spots in her mouth are also noticed.  Diagnostic Test Results: The Physical Exam reveals mild splenomegaly and a new murmur on heart auscultation. Under laboratory investigations  the patient's blood cultures came back positive. Echocardiography reveals vegetation on the native valve suggesting infective endocarditis.  Problem List: 1. Suspected Native Valve Infective Endocarditis 2. Chronic Type II Diabetes Mellitus 3. Hypertension 4. Hyperlipidemia  5. Active Tobacco Use 6. Recent Dental Procedure  7. Positive Blood Cultures   Active Issues: The current priority is to manage and treat the suspected endocarditis. She will likely need IV antibiotics and potentially surgical intervention. Her other chronic comorbidities like diabetes  hypertension and hyperlipidemia also need ongoing management. Her active smoking status is a modifiable risk factor contributing to her overall health status.   Additional Considerations: The recent dental procedure might be the source of the bacteria causing the endocarditis. A thorough review of her medications  diet  and blood glucose levels is necessary for managing her chronic conditions. A pulmonologist consultation for her active smoking status and a nutritional consultation for her unexplained weight loss are also recommended.

Problem Presentation:   Mr. John Smith is a 65-year-old Caucasian man presenting to the ER with a one-month history of intermittent fever  weight loss of around 10 pounds  fatigue  night sweats  and a new murmur detected in a recent routine visit to his primary care physician. He denies any chest pain  cough  dyspnea  or change in bowel habits.   Demographic Characterization:   Mr. Smith lives in a suburban area with his wife. He is a retired engineer and had a long history of smoking  though he quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol periodically. He has no history of illicit drug use. He reports no recent travel  contact with sick individuals or animals  or any significant dietary changes.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Smith has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  well controlled with metformin  and stage 3 chronic kidney disease  managed conservatively. He does not have a history of heart disease  hypertension  stroke  bleeding or clotting disorders. He had a dental procedure performed two months ago for a tooth extraction due to severe periapical periodontitis. There is no history of any prosthetic implantation or any surgeries in the past. His vaccinations  including for influenza and pneumococcus  are up to date.  Family History:  His father died from a myocardial infarction at 70  and his mother had hypertension and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He has one sibling  a brother  with no known medical conditions.  Social History:  Mr. Smith has been married for 40 years and has 3 adult children. He has a supportive network of friends and relatives nearby. He exercises regularly by walking and sometimes cycling. He has never been exposed to asbestos or other harmful chemicals in his work environment.  Review of System:  General health has been deteriorating for about a month with low-grade fever  weight loss and reduced appetite. He's been feeling generally unwell but no specific symptoms noted apart from a vague malaise.  Current Medications:  Metformin 500mg twice daily  multivitamin capsules once daily.   Allergies:  No known drug allergies.   Initial Impression:  Given the fever  fatigue  weight loss  new murmur  and root canal treatment in the recent past  there is a suspicion of possible infective endocarditis. Further diagnostics including blood cultures  echocardiogram should be considered for confirmation. Starting broad-spectrum antibiotics may be required once blood cultures have been drawn and if the patient's condition deteriorates. This needs to be managed urgently given the serious nature of the disease and potential complications.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 65 Sex: M Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired School Teacher Residence: Lives alone in a suburban home   Medical History:  - Mr. Doe has a known history of Type II Diabetes which is controlled by medication (Metformin 1000mg twice daily).  - He has a history of Hypertension which is also controlled by medication (Lisinopril 5mg daily).  - Has a history of rheumatic fever in childhood. - The patient is a reformed smoker but has a 30-pack year history.  - He used to consume alcohol moderately but quit around 10 years ago. - No history of IV drug use. - No known allergies or known hereditary systemic illness in the family. - His prior valve disease was diagnosed 3 years ago based on echocardiogram findings and has been under monitoring. - Previous Echocardiogram: moderate mitral regurgitation  trace tricuspid regurgitation with mild pulmonary hypertension. - Most recent physical examination unveiled systolic murmurs best heard along the left sternal border. Patient Problem Representation:  Demographics: A 55-year-old Caucasian male living in an urban city of the United States. The patient is employed and has a history of inconsistent health care due to lack of health insurance. He is a heavy smoker (30 pack years) and admits to frequent alcohol consumption.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with a 6-week history of intermittent fevers  night sweats  weight loss and generalized body weakness. Over the past week  he has also started to experience increasing shortness of breath and a persistent  productive cough.  Past Medical History: The patient has a past medical history significant for untreated diabetes mellitus type 2  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He has a history of dental abscesses but has never undergone any dental procedures. There is no known drug allergy. He has a family history of congestive heart failure and his father died at the age of 62 due to cardiac arrest.  Physical Examination Findings: On examination  he appears ill and in distress. He is febrile with a temperature of 38.3 °C (101 °F). Irregular heart sounds heard on auscultation with a new-onset heart murmur. Multiple small hemorrhages are seen under his fingernails.   Relevant Investigations: Complete Blood Count shows leukocytosis and anemia. Blood cultures are positive for Staphylococcus aureus. A transthoracic echocardiogram reveals vegetation on the aortic valve.    Diagnosis:  The patient's presentation and examinations are suggestive of Native-valve Infective Endocarditis.

Patient Profile:  Mr. John Smith is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  an ex-smoker with a history of intravenous drug use in his youth. He is sedentary and has been leading a high-stress lifestyle  which involves frequent travel and erratic eating habits with high alcohol consumption. He is a retired engineer with a wife and two adult children. He lives in a suburban neighborhood.  Past Medical History:  1. History of cellulitis of the lower limb 3 years ago  following a minor wound infection and was treated with a course of antibiotics. 4. History of intravenous drug use in his youth.  Presenting Complaints:  1. Fever and chills for the past couple of weeks. 2. Severe night sweats resulting in significant weight loss and fatigue. 3. Shortness of breath with mild exertion. 4. Swelling in the lower legs.  Examination Findings:  1. Fever of 38.5 degrees Celsius. 2. Tachycardia (increased heart rate). 3. An early diastolic murmur heard on auscultation over the chest. 4. Mild peripheral oedema in the lower extremities.  Likely Diagnosis:  Suspected case of native-valve infective endocarditis  given the symptoms and signs of fever  weight loss  night sweats  shortness of breath and cardiac murmur  coupled with the patient's high-risk history of intravenous drug use.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 58 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Construction worker Marital Status: Married Healthcare Coverage: Health Maintenance Organization (HMO) Home environment: Smoker  Moderate alcohol consumption  Family History: Father had heart disease  mother had diabetes and hypertension  Past Medical History:  1. Immunizations: Up-to-date including influenza and pneumococcal vaccine. 2. Past surgeries: Appendectomy done 20 years ago. 3. Major illnesses: Diagnosed with Type II diabetes 6 years ago  well managed on oral hypoglycemic agents. 4. Allergies: None noted. 5. Current Medications: Metformin 500mg twice daily.  Presenting Problem:  The patient presents with fatigue and intermittent fever for the past few weeks which has been high-grade for the past three days. Complaints of shortness of breath upon exertion and noticed blood in the sputum once. He also reports weight loss  night sweats  and reduced appetite.  Diagnostic hypothesis: Native-valve infective endocarditis based on symptoms.   Pre-existing Conditions that make patient susceptible to infective endocarditis:  1. Chronic conditions: Diabetes which could affect the immunity thus making the person more susceptible. 2. Lifestyle habits: Smoking and moderate alcohol consumption  which might also affect immunity and general health.  Investigation plan:  Physical examination findings: Fever  new heart murmur  and possible septic pulmonary emboli (shown by dyspnea and hemoptysis).  1. Laboratory tests: Blood cultures  Complete Blood Count (CBC)  Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR)  and C-Reactive Protein (CRP) to check for inflammation and infection. 2. Imaging: Chest X-ray to rule out any abnormalities in the lung  possible septic pulmonary emboli. 3. Echocardiogram: To identify vegetation characteristics  valve function  possible abscess formation  and other complications.  Treatment plan based on suspected diagnosis of infective endocarditis:  1. Immediate empirical antibiotic therapy until pathogen identification and sensitivity results from blood cultures. 2. Regular follow-ups and redo lab tests to see response to treatment. 3. Patient education about significance of medication compliance.  4. Lifestyle modification advice for better management of diabetes and quitting smoking and moderating alcohol consumption.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 65 years Gender: Male Occupational Status: Retired Accountant Residential Area: Urban   Medical History:  Mr. Doe has been a diagnosed patient of Type II Diabetes and Hypertension for the last 15 years. Problem Representation:  Patient Information: - Demographics: A 60-year-old Caucasian male who is a smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally.  Presenting Complaint: - The patient has been feeling generally unwell with vague symptoms including fatigue and weakness for the past month. - The patient has also noticed a low-grade fever and has lost about 10 pounds in weight over the last month. - Recently has started experiencing night sweats.  Past Medical History: - Treated for hypertension and hypercholesterolemia and is on medication (Amlodipine 5mg  Atorvastatin 20mg) - Hospitalized 3 years ago for myocardial infarction  with subsequent placement of a coronary stent.  - No history of rheumatic fever.  Family History: - Father died at 65 from heart attack. - Mother is alive and well at 85. - One younger brother has type 2 diabetes.  Social History: - The patient is a retired engineer living with his wife.  - No history of intravenous drug use. - No recent dental procedures or surgeries.  Physical Examination: - Temperature of 38.2°C  BP 130/80 mmHg. - Cardiac examination reveals a new-onset regurgitant murmur. - No peripheral manifestations of endocarditis (Janeway lesions  Osler nodes  splinter hemorrhages) are observed.  Based on the above findings  the patient seems to be potentially presenting with a subacute form of infective endocarditis affecting a native valve. Further tests including blood cultures and a transesophageal echocardiogram are warranted to confirm the diagnosis and to identify the causative organism.   The patient's history of cardiovascular disease notably increases his risk for this condition. His fever  weight loss  recent onset of heart murmur  and night sweats are all signs that point towards infective endocarditis. Furthermore  once a causative bacteria is identified  appropriate antibiotic treatment will need to be initiated promptly to prevent further complications like heart failure or systemic embolism.

Problem Representation:  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  residing in a suburban community and reports a history of recreational intravenous drug use. Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 60-year-old Caucasian male  works in agriculture  has been a smoker for 40 years  drinks moderately occasionally. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he is regularly on medication. There is no history of diabetes  tuberculosis  HIV infection  or other significant systemic diseases. This patient appearance with the above demographic  clinical scenario  and investigation is representing a typical case of native-valve infective endocarditis.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  with a history of moderate alcohol consumption (2-3 drinks per night) and 20 years of past smoking history (quit 5 years ago).  Presenting Problem: He presented to the clinic with symptoms of fatigue  unintentional weight loss  night sweats  and a low-grade fever persisting for the past 2 months. The patient also reported feeling short of breath during his daily walks  a symptom he did not experience earlier.  Past Medical History: He has a known history of hypertension which is controlled on amlodipine (5mg daily). He also had a diagnosis of dental caries a couple of months ago but did not seek treatment.  Possible Problem List based on Symptom Profile: 1. Infective Endocarditis (eating away at his heart valve  leading to potential heart failure). 2. Possible development of Heart Failure secondary to Infective Endocarditis. 3. Untreated dental caries - possible source of infection for possible infective endocarditis.  Our primary concern for this patient is the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis  likely from his untreated dental caries which may have been a source of entry for the bacteria into his bloodstream. His age  history of significant alcohol consumption  and history of smoking may place him at a higher risk. Symptoms such as fatigue  unintentional weight loss  night sweats  and low-grade fever are non-specific but can be associated with chronic infection such as infective endocarditis. The new onset shortness of breath could indicate progression to congestive heart failure  a complication of infective endocarditis. His past medical history of untreated dental caries and hypertension - a condition that could have caused wear and tear on the walls of his blood vessels  hence facilitating bacterial seeding to his native heart valves  further support our concerns.

Patient Profile: - Identity: John Smith  50 years old  African-American  heterosexual  employed as a construction worker - Residence: Urban settings  New York  United States - Lifestyle: Non-smoker  occasional alcohol intake (once per month)  no illicit drug use - Family history: Father succumbed to heart disease at the age of 72  mother is known hypertensive  Past Medical History: - Diagnosed with rheumatic heart disease at the age of 30  currently ameliorated  - History of dental procedures without prophylactic antibiotics  - Well controlled hypertension  diagnosed five years ago - Underwent appendectomy 25 years ago  Presenting Complaints:  - Fever persisting for two weeks  - Palpitations  - Shortness of breath - Fatigue and weakness  - Unexplained weight loss   Physical Examination: - Heart: Possible heart murmur - Oral Cavity: Dental caries noted - Skin: No noticeable petechiae or skin manifestation of endocarditis  - Extremities: No peripheral signs such as Osler's nodes or Janeway lesions   These symptoms along with the past medical history suggest an infective endocarditis context with native valve involvement. Further investigations should include blood cultures  inflammation markers  and an echocardiography to confirm the diagnosis and assess the damage to the cardiac structures. Urgent hospital admission is suggested given the probability of serious complications if the condition is not promptly treated.

Problem Representation:   A 58-year-old Caucasian male patient presents with a two-week history of intermittent fever  malaise  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss. He reports recent travels abroad  particularly visiting developing countries as a part of his missionary work with communities with poor sanitation and limited access to clean water.  His past medical history is significant for degenerative disc disease and rheumatoid arthritis  with chronic use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) but no record of immunosuppressive therapy. The patient has no known allergies to medications and has an average alcohol consumption. The patient is a non-smoker and maintains a generally healthy lifestyle.  Moreover  he denies any illicit drug use  any known past infections  or a family history of cardiac diseases. The patient is not diabetic and does not have a history of cardiovascular disease. He does not have any dental problems or recent dental procedures. His immunizations are up to date.  The patient lives in a suburban area with his wife and has no pets. His occupation is a desk job and does not involve exposure to industrial or environmental toxins.  The eminence of his missionary work  relevant past medical history  and current symptoms hint at the possibility of a serious systemic infection  specifically native-valve infective endocarditis  which requires further investigation.  The absence of known cardiac diseases  immunosuppressive therapy  and intravenous drug use deem the patient at low risk for infective endocarditis according to Duke's criteria. However  considering his recent travels and presenting symptoms  it becomes necessary to rule out this condition.  This representation intends to demonstrate a typical patient presentation for potential native-valve infective endocarditis without the general higher risk factors being evident. Further diagnostic measures  including blood cultures and echocardiography  may be required to confirm the diagnosis and begin appropriate treatment promptly.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Smith  a 50-year-old Caucasian male with a history of smoking and IV drug usage  currently working as an automotive mechanic is presented to the emergency department with a fever  malaise  new-onset heart murmur  and Osler's nodes  suggestive of a typical case of native-valve infective endocarditis. The patient has a relevant past medical history of Hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection  managed with antiviral therapy  and reformed IV drug abuse. No known drug allergies. He is currently on a maintenance therapy of methadone for past opioid dependency and receives a monthly buprenorphine-naloxone injection. He does not consume alcohol frequently and has a 15-pack-year smoking history but quit 5 years ago.  Mr. Smith lives in a rented apartment in the city  has limited contact with family members  which include his divorced wife and two teenage children with whom he has shared custody. He has a history of poor compliance with medical appointments due to his challenging work schedule and related socioeconomic factors.  The suspect for infection could be S. aureus or Streptococci considering his history with illicit drug use. His risk is increased due to his profession exposing him to the risk of skin lesions or abrasions  which might act as a possible route of infection. His current symptoms have been persisting for 5 days and have progressively worsened  with no relief from over-the-counter medications. Appropriate blood tests  including cultures  along with an echocardiogram are being considered to confirm infective endocarditis.  This brief characterizes the demographic profile and clinical history of the typical patient with native-valve infective endocarditis. This sketch may not cover all possibilities but provides a general population-based understanding for the condition. Any subsequent clinical decisions should be tailored to the individual patient’s clinical situation.

Patient Profile:  Name: Patient X Age: 55 Sex: Male Race: Hispanic Occupation: Teacher Marital status: Married Smoking: None Alcohol: Moderate Physical activity: Mild exercise 3 times/weekly  Problem Representation:  Chief Complaint: Recurring fever for the past two weeks  fatigue  shortness of breath and weight loss.  History of Present Illness:   Patient X started experiencing a moderate-grade fever  coming and going  about two weeks ago. Over time  he’s grown increasingly fatigued  which is unusual for him  as he’s normally fairly active. He has also noticed some shortness of breath and an unexpected weight loss. He hasn’t observed any visible deformities or skin-related changes.  Past Medical History:  Patient was diagnosed with Rheumatic fever in his childhood. He was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type 2 about five years ago and has been managing it with diet and the oral hypoglycemic drug  Metformin. Patient has also been managed for hypertension with Lisinopril for the past two years. In his late 40s  Patient X experienced frequent dental infections for which he underwent tooth extraction and was on multiple courses of antibiotics.  Drug History:  He is on Metformin 500mg BID for diabetes and Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension.  Examination:  Vital signs show a mild fever  mild hypertension and elevated heart rate. Physical examination reveals significant findings including a heart murmur suggestive of aortic regurgitation  Osler’s nodes on pads of fingers and toes  and Janeway lesions on palms and soles.  Diagnosis:  Based on presenting symptoms  past medical history  and physical examination  Patient X is most likely suffering from Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis.   The history of rheumatic heart disease in childhood  frequent dental procedures  diabetes  and hypertension are factors that increase his risk. This  along with his current symptoms such as fever  fatigue  weight loss  and the presence of Osler nodes and Janeway lesions  are strongly suggestive of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis. The murmur suggests that the infection is affecting the aortic valve.  Further Management:  After the problem representation  the clinician should advise blood cultures  Echocardiography (Transthoracic or Transesophageal) and other necessary laboratory tests to confirm the diagnosis and identify the organism causing Infective Endocarditis. Following identification  antibiotic therapy should be initiated.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 65-year-old Caucasian male (non-smoker  occasional alcohol consumption) presenting with symptoms of fever  fatigue  weight loss  night sweats  and new-onset heart murmur.  Demographic Information: The patient lives in an urban area  works as a retired engineer  and has no known allergies or immunizations due. He lives with his wife and has a family history of cardiovascular disease - his father having died from a heart attack at age 70.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia controlled by medications (Losartan 50 mg  Atorvastatin 20mg). He has no known drug allergies. The patient suffered a transient ischaemic stroke with no residual deficits 5 years ago  for which he has been on aspirin (75mg) since. No history of intravenous drug use or blood transfusions. The patient's dental examination 1 month ago demonstrated evidence of chronic periodontitis.  Presenting Complaint: In the week leading up to admission  the patient had been experiencing a high-grade intermittent fever with rigors. Moreover  he started losing weight  despite having a good appetite. He felt increasingly short of breath and had a bout of syncope. On physical examination  he had a new onset of cardiac murmur and splinter hemorrhages under his nails.   Summary: This patient has many risk factors for developing native valve endocarditis. His age  male gender  family history of heart disease  presence of chronic conditions like hypertension and hyperlipidemia  history of stroke  and the chronic periodontitis all put him at a higher risk of getting this infection. The symptoms he is presenting with-fever  weight loss  night sweats  and heart murmur-further corroborate this possibility.

Patient Profile:  Demographics:  Age: 55 Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Office worker Lifestyle: Non-smoker  occasional alcohol consumption  moderate outdoor activities.  Presenting Signs and Symptoms: - Fever for 1 week - Night sweats - Weight loss  - Fatigue - Heart murmur  - Splinter hemorrhages in the fingernails - Petechiae on the conjunctiva  lips  and oral mucosa  Medical History: - No previous history of heart disease but there is a family history of heart disease. - Diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type 2  managed with oral hypoglycemic agents - Occasional dental infections over the past several years - History of rheumatic fever in childhood - No allergies  Social History: Lives alone but maintains regular communication with family. Works in a job that involves long periods of sitting. Engages in moderate physical activities such as walking and cycling. Travel history is unremarkable with no recent travel outside the country.   Health Maintenance: The patient is up-to-date on immunizations  regular dental check-ups and annual health screenings. Regular follow-ups for diabetes management.   Recent Lab Tests: Blood cultures are positive for Streptococcus viridans. Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP).   EchoCardiogram:  Revealed vegetation on the mitral valve suggesting native-valve infective endocarditis.   Initial Diagnosis: Given the patient's medical history  presenting signs and symptoms  and recent lab tests  diagnosis is native-valve infective endocarditis  a serious infection of the heart valves caused by bacteria  often stemming from other parts of the body like the mouth in this patient’s case.   Treatment Plan: Treatment will require intensive antibiotic therapy and careful follow-up to ensure resolution of the infection  and to prevent potential complications such as heart damage and stroke.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 60-year-old Caucasian male  non-smoker  occasional drinker  not involved in any substance abuse. Professionally  he is a manual laborer.  Chief Complaint: Presents with a history of progressive shortness of breath for four weeks  anorexia  significant weight loss  low-grade fever  and night sweats.  Past Medical History: He has a history of poor oral hygiene with multiple untreated dental caries. He reports a dental procedure approximately six weeks ago. He also has a history of hypertension managed with a calcium channel blocker. About five years ago he had a transient ischemic attack  but no subsequent neurological events. No prior surgeries. No known allergies.  Family History: Parents deceased with cardiac disease  hypertension and diabetes mellitus. One brother deceased from substance abuse-related complications.   Social History: Lives alone  divorced with two adult children. There is no history of recent travel  unpasteurized milk consumption or pet contact.  Physical Examination: On general physical examination  cachexia  pallor  dental caries and mild respiratory distress are noted. He is febrile  with a temperature of 38.5 C (101.3 F)  heart rate of 95 BPM  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  blood pressure of 130/85 mm Hg and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. Cardiovascular exam reveals a new pansystolic murmur at the apex radiating to the axilla. Splinter hemorrhages are seen under his fingernails. Neurological exam reveals no focal deficits.  Investigations: Laboratory investigations reveal leukocytosis  elevated C-reactive protein  and anemia. Chest radiography shows evidence of mild pulmonary edema. Transthoracic echocardiography demonstrates possible vegetations on the native valves. Pending blood cultures.  Impression: The patient's clinical  examination and preliminary investigation findings may indicate native-valve infective endocarditis. Further diagnostic evaluations and antibiotic therapy are planned.

This problem representation provides a comprehensive view of Mr. X's presenting problem alongside his past medical conditions  lifestyle  and hereditary risk factors. Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 65-year-old male retiree  who is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol sparingly  recently returned from a month-long hiking trip.   Presenting Issue: The patient presents with symptoms consisting of high-grade fever  chills  fatigue  weight loss  and a recently developed heart murmur. These symptoms have been ongoing for almost 3 weeks.  Characterization of the Problem: The patient has been previously healthy with no significant hospitalizations or major diseases; he takes no regular medications. He does have a history of poor oral health due to neglecting regular dental check-ups. Observed symptoms now include pale skin  low blood pressure  and rapid heart rate. The patient's physical examination reveals noticeable Osler's nodes on the fingers and toes  and Janeway lesions on the palms and soles.  Medical History: The patient's past medical history is quite uneventful save for occasional dental infections. However  the recently returned hiking trip involved him visiting several remote locations where medical hygiene might have been compromised.  Possible Diagnosis: Based on the presentation and patient's history  a possible diagnosis could be native-valve infective endocarditis  secondary to a bacteremia that may have potentially seeded from the dental infections due to poor oral hygiene.  Immediate Actions: Immediate confirmatory tests include blood culture to identify potential bacteria and an echocardiogram to visualize the heart valves. Begin empirical antibiotic therapy whilst awaiting culture results. Additionally  arrange a dental examination and consultation with an infectious disease specialist to gain a multidisciplinary approach to treatment.   Monitoring Progress: Patient progress should be closely monitored  documenting any changes in symptoms  and adjusting treatment based on culture results. Any complications should prompt additional investigations such as a CT if there's suspicion of emboli.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:   A 65-year-old Caucasian male  non-smoker and moderate daily alcohol drinker presents with high grade fever  chills  malaise  fatigue  weight loss  and new-onset heart murmur  suggestive of native valve infective endocarditis. He also reports a history of gout and occasional episodes of transient ischemic attacks. There is no past history of any invasive surgical procedure or intravenous drug use.   Family History:  There is a family history of cardiovascular disease. His father died of a heart attack at the age of 70.  Social History:  The patient is a non-smoker but does report the consumption of alcohol. He drinks a moderate amount of wine daily. He also reports a sedentary lifestyle  with minimal physical activity.  Medication History:  His regular medications are Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Colchicine for gout. There’s no known drug allergy history.   Review of Systems:  General: Fever  chills  malaise  and significant weight loss over the past 4 weeks. Cardiovascular: New onset heart murmur  occasional shortness of breath on exertion. Neurological: Reports 2-3 episodes of transient visual loss and weakness of the left arm in the past.  Physical Examination:  Vitals: Pulse 96 beats/min  irregular; BP 140/90 mm of Hg  Temperature 100.5 F. Cardiovascular: New onset regurgitant murmur heard best at the cardiac apex. Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: The patient is a 55-year-old Caucasian male who presents with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Present Illness: He reports onset of symptoms 2 weeks ago  which includes fever  shortness of breath  chills  night sweats  and marked weight loss within this period. He also mentions feeling a heart murmur  and localizing signs associated with valvular heart disease.  Medical History: He has a history of intravenous (IV) drug abuse  however  he has been clean for the past 10 years. He has an already known case of mitral valve prolapse with mitral regurgitation  diagnosed 5 years ago. There is no history of heart valve replacement surgery. He also suffers from type II diabetes mellitus that is controlled with metformin.  Family History: His father had a history of rheumatic heart disease due to untreated streptococcal infection in his youth. His mother had hypertensive heart disease but no history of any valvular pathology.  Lifestyle: He is a former smoker and has quit smoking 10 years ago when he stopped IV drug use. He consumes alcohol socially and denies any drug use. He is currently working as a construction worker.  Further Investigation: He will need further investigations  including blood cultures  echocardiography  and possibly a cardiac CT scan to confirm the diagnosis and determine the extent of the disease and valve damage.   Management: Patient treatment would likely include prolonged antibiotic therapy to treat the infective endocarditis  followed by appropriate plans for potential cardiac surgery if indicated. His other chronic conditions like diabetes will also need managing in the overall treatment plan.

He worked as an engineer - Drinks alcohol occasionally - No travel history in recent months   This high-risk patient with a significant medical history of diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  presenting with recent onset fever  weight loss  and shortness of breath  may be developing native-valve infective endocarditis  possibly due to a non-hospital acquired infection. Further evaluation is needed with laboratory tests  imaging  and possibly blood cultures.

Name: John Doe Gender: Male Age: 65 years Occupation: Retired high school teacher  Main Complaint: Recurring fever  chest pain  fatigue  loss of appetite  and weight loss  Taking History: John is a 65-year-old retired high school teacher who presents with a two-week history of persistent fever  fatigue  loss of appetite  and weight loss. He also complains of chest pain and mild shortness of breath.  Past Medical History: John has been generally healthy in his life before his chronic illnesses. He has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes for the last 10 years and hypertension for 5 years. His diabetes is controlled with Metformin  and he is managing his hypertension with Lisinopril.   John has had a past history of dental abscesses which required recurrent dental surgery. His last dental surgery was 3 months ago.  Family History: No history of heart diseases  infectious diseases  or autoimmune diseases in his immediate family. His father died due to lung cancer and his mother due to aging.  Social History: John has been living alone since his wife passed away 3 years ago. He smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years but has significantly reduced the consumption over the past year. He consumes alcohol occasionally during social gatherings and denies any drug abuse. Follows a balanced diet but recently hasn't been much of an appetite. He maintains good personal hygiene but admits poor dental hygiene.   Physical Examination: John appears fatigued. Vital signs reveal mild tachycardia with regular rhythm and a low-grade fever. The cardiac examination reveals a new grade III systolic murmur. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable  with no evidence of Osler's nodes  Janeway lesions  or Roth spots.  Based on all this  we suspect John has native-valve infective endocarditis. This is likely secondary to Streptococcus viridans or Staphylococcus aureus (the common bacterial pathogens for endocarditis)  possibly introduced during his recent dental procedure. A thorough investigation  including blood cultures and echocardiography  is necessary to confirm the diagnosis and guide therapy.   The considerable history of cigarette smoking conditions John to a higher risk of respiratory diseases  including pulmonary complications of infective endocarditis like septic pulmonary emboli. His diabetes imbues a general higher risk of infections  poor wound healing  and potential poorer outcomes in endocarditis.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:  - Gender: Male - Age: 65 years - Ethnicity: Caucasian   Presentation:  -  The patient presents with a two to three weeks history of intermittent fever reaching up to 39 degrees Celsius. - Associated symptoms include fatigue  myalgia and significant weight loss over the period. - Patient also reported a new-onset heart murmur mentioned during a recent visit. Labs:  - Blood counts: Hemoglobin: 10.2 g/dL  WBC: 16 000/µL  Platelets: 120 000/µL. - Liver Function Test: showing mild elevation in AST/ALT. - Renal Function Test: Within normal limits. - Coagulation profile: PT/INR slight elevation. - Blood Culture: Awaiting results. Patient Profile:  Demographic Information: - Age: 62 years - Gender: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Construction worker - Location: Metropolitan city   Past Medical History: - Mild hypertension controlled with medication (Lisinopril). - History of intravenous drug use during his youth but has been sober for the past 20 years. - Diagnosed with Hepatitis C due to his previous IV drug use but completed a full course of antivirals 5 years ago. - Had a minor Stroke 4 years ago  with no visible complications noted since. - No known drug allergies.  Presenting Problem:  The patient presented with persistent high-grade fever for three weeks. He complains of a general sense of weakness  fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. He recently developed localized joint pain in his left knee. He denies any recent dental work or harm reduction practices. He has no family history of heart disease or valve disorders. He was initially treated for flu but his symptoms have progressively worsened and no improvements were noted despite symptomatic treatment at a local clinic.  On physical examination  salient findings include pallor  low-grade fever and a new murmur on auscultation in the mitral valve area. A thorough family history has ruled out any genetic or connective tissue disorders.  Possible Diagnosis: Based on the above clinical findings and his history  the working diagnosis is Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis.   Planning: - Blood culture: To identify causative organism - Transesophageal echocardiography: To visualize the heart valves and confirm diagnosis - Baseline kidney and liver function test: To manage therapy effectively considering patient's past history of Hepatitis C.  - Revaluate hypertension management plan: Evaluating the patient's response to Lisinopril in light of the new diagnosis  may need to adjust or change antihypertensive medication.   References: - As a patient with past IV drug use  the patient is at a higher risk to develop an endovascular infection.  - New cardiac murmur along with persistent fever  shortness breath and history of IV drug abuse raises concerns for infective endocarditis.  - Transesophageal echocardiography is necessary as it has high sensitivity and specificity in detecting infective endocarditis compared to transthoracic echo.  - Given the age and history of this patient  it's necessary to assess comprehensive organ functions.

Problem Representation:   Chief Complaint: A 67-year-old Caucasian male patient presents to the hospital with complaints of high-grade fever  lethargy  and unexplained weight loss for the past three weeks. The patient also reports an occasional cough  night sweats  and gradually increasing shortness of breath.  Demographics:  The patient is a retired teacher who lives in a rural area with his wife. He is a nonsmoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. There are no known drug allergies. No concerns regarding his mental or emotional health have been highlighted previously.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of congenital heart disease (Bicuspid Aortic Valve). He underwent balloon valvuloplasty 12 years ago for significant aortic stenosis. His other medical histories include hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  both of which are effectively managed with medications. He has not undergone any other surgical procedures in the past. No history of hospitalization or travel outside the country within the last six months.  Family History:  There's no family history of similar syndromes  including infective endocarditis. However  cardiovascular diseases run in his family  with both his father and brother passing away due to myocardial infarctions.  Social History:  The patient is generally active in his community  exercising regularly  and maintaining a balanced diet. He lives in a clean and healthy environment. No known exposure to infectious diseases.  Review of Systems:  The patient's neurological and gastrointestinal systems are functioning well  with no complaints of changes in bowel habits  headache  or confusion. Apart from the previously mentioned symptoms related to the cardiovascular and respiratory systems  no other abnormal findings have been observed.  Summary: So  this 67-year-old male with past medical history significant for congenital heart disease (Bicuspid Aortic Valve) and who underwent balloon valvuloplasty 12 years ago  along with controlled hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  presents with high-grade fever  irregular low-grade fever  lethargy  night sweats  occasional cough  shortness of breath  and weight loss  suggestive of possible native-valve infective endocarditis.

Problem Representation:  Patient:  A 60-year-old Caucasian male from an urban setting presents to the emergency room with a three week history of fevers  night sweats  weight loss  and a new onset of heart murmur.  Medical History:  The patient has a past medical history of intravenous drug use (IVDU) but claims to have been sober for the last five years. He has a 20 pack-year history of cigarette smoking and a moderate alcohol intake. The patient has a history of hypertension  which has been managed with medication for the last ten years.  Most recently  he was treated for a dental abscess two months ago  for which he was prescribed a course of antibiotics. The patient admits to poor oral hygiene.  Presenting Symptoms:  The patient is experiencing persistent fever (>38 degrees Celsius)  chills  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss of nearly 10 kilograms over a month. He also reports experiencing night sweats and a decreased appetite.  The presence of general malaise as well as symptoms like fatigue and weight loss suggest systemic disease.  Physical examination:  Upon auscultation  a new onset heart murmur is audible  specifically a regurgitant murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border.  Suspicion of Infective Endocarditis:  Given the patient's history of IVDU  poor oral hygiene and a new onset heart murmur  there is a strong clinical suspicion of infective endocarditis. This is further supported by fever and other systemic signs.  At this stage  a transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) would be the next step in investigating this patient's symptoms  given the high suspicion of infective endocarditis. Blood cultures should be drawn to identify any potential bacterial pathogens.  Patient's Risk Factors:  1. History of IVDU: Injection drug use is a common cause of infective endocarditis. 2. Poor dental hygiene: Poor oral hygiene and recent dental infection could provide a source of bacterial entry into the bloodstream. 3. Hypertension and smoking increase the risk of heart disease.    Given these elements  along with the symptoms  physical findings and risk factors  there is a high clinical suspicion of infective endocarditis.

Patient Profile:  1. Demographics:  The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Smith. He is a retired structural engineer and a widower with two adult children living independently. There is no family history of early onset cancer or neurological disorders.  4. Current Symptoms:  Mr. Smith presented to the hospital with a one-week history of fever  fatigue  poor appetite and night sweats. He reports having experienced intermittent episodes of sharp  stabbing chest pain  not related to exertion. On inspection  he looks unwell  lethargic  and has pallor and mild peripheral edema. Physical examination demonstrates a new systolic murmur  consistent with possible valvular lesions.  5. Initial Diagnosis:  In the context of his symptoms and the new cardiac murmur on clinical examination  an initial diagnosis of possible infective endocarditis is suspected.  6. Additional Relevant Information: Mr. Smith underwent a dental extraction 2 weeks ago. He has no known history of intravenous drug use  recent travel or exposure to sexually transmitted infections.  Problem Representation:  A 60-year-old man with a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and a recent dental extraction presents with fever  fatigue  anorexia  night sweats  and new onset of a heart murmur  raising suspicion for native valve infective endocarditis. His family history of heart disease and personal medical history place him at an elevated risk of cardiovascular complications requiring urgent investigation and management. The confirmation of this diagnosis would require further imaging  blood tests including blood cultures and possibly cardiac imaging. This patient’s case would be complex due to multiple comorbidities affecting his treatment options and prognosis. The potential of an infection source from his dental extraction should be examined and addressed. The patient should be referred to a cardiologist for evaluation and treatment  and infectious disease specialist for antibiotic management.

Problem Representation:  Patient Demographic Information: A 54-year-old Caucasian male  non-smoker with a history of moderate alcohol consumption  working as an office executive.  Presenting Complaint and Symptoms: The patient presents with an intermittent high-grade fever for the past two weeks  drenching night sweats  and unintentional weight loss of around 5 kg in the past one month. He also reports a new onset of shortness of breath on exertion and chronic fatigue not associated with any other symptoms.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus controlled with Metformin and Sitagliptin. There is no history of any heart disease.   Family History: His father has Hypertension and his mother has Rheumatoid Arthritis. There is no family history of heart disease.  Relevant Personal & Social History: The patient denies any history of illicit drug use. He mentions regular dental check-ups but recently underwent dental extraction two months back. He lives with his wife and two kids and leads a sedentary lifestyle.  Clinical Examination Findings: On examination  the patient shows signs of Pallor  Oslor nodes (tender nodules on finger pads)  Janeway Lesions (non-tender lesions on palms and soles)  and a new murmur on auscultation which could merit an echocardiogram to verify the presence of vegetations on the heart valves.  Positive Lab Findings and Results: - Elevated inflammatory markers including ESR and CRP  - Blood cultures are positive for Staphylococcus aureus - ECG showing nonspecific ST-T wave changes   This presentation strongly suggests a diagnosis of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis. The choice of empiric antimicrobial therapy would be guided by the patient’s blood culture results. Following diagnosis  the patient should be referred to a cardiologist for further management. He may require prolonged antibiotic therapy  possibly cardiothoracic intervention depending on the extent of valve involvement  and strict blood glucose control due to his Diabetes Mellitus.    Relevant Differential Diagnoses considering clinical presentation: - Tuberculosis - Disseminated Neoplastic Disease - Autoimmune Rheumatological Disease  Systemic Lupus Erythematosus - Non-infective Inflammatory Heart Diseases  such as Rheumatic Fever  - Sepsis from another source.

Patient Profile:  Name: Patient X Age: 62 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired accountant  Presenting Complaint: Patient X presents with symptoms of discomfort  fatigue  weight loss and occasional fever which has been persistent for the past 3 weeks. Treatment Plan: Patient X's treatment plan includes hospitalization for intravenous antibiotic treatment for extended period  serial blood cultures  regular monitoring of vitals  follow-up echocardiograms  as well as check-ups to monitor diabetes and hypertension.  Overall  this clinical case of represent a typical patient with native-valve infective endocarditis and the details including demographics  past medical history  presenting complaint  examination findings  investigations  along with a planned treatment can effectively capture this disease presentation.

Problem Representation:  Patient Information: A 55-year-old male  Mr X  current smoker with a history of intravenous drug use. He works as a janitor and is edentulous. His medical history includes Hepatitis C and chronic back pain for which he has been self-administrating opioids. Mr X is sexually active with multiple partners and inconsistent use of prophylactics. He lives in a small apartment downtown and tends to consume a diet high in saturated fats.  Chief Complaint: Mr X shows up to the emergency department presenting with intermittent fever  chills  fatigue  and unexpected weight loss for the past 2 weeks. Recently  he also started having shortness of breath  night sweats  and a persistent dry cough.  History of Present Illness: Onset of illness: Noticed symptoms 2 weeks prior to this visit. No fever or other systemic symptoms before then. Progression: Symptoms have progressively worsened  increasing in frequency and intensity  reaching their peak the day before presentation. Frequency: Intermittent but almost daily. Duration: Each fever-chills episode lasts around 4-6 hours. Severity: Progressively worsening.  Past Medical History: -ChronicHepatitis C diagnosed 10 years ago  but not regularly monitored. -Chronic back pain.  -Edentulism. -Intravenous drug use for past 15 years.  Relevant Social History: -Smoker for 30 years  around 20 cigarettes daily. -Illicit drug use  mainly opioids which he administers intravenously. -Occupational exposure to harmful chemicals and biological pollutants as a janitor.  -Sexual history: multiple partners  inconsistent use of protection.  Family History: -Both parents alive; father has ischemic heart disease and mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus.  Significant Findings: Upon physical examination  Mr X appears in fair health. He is flushed  and his body temperature is elevated at 39.2°C.  Cardiovascular system examination revealed a new-onset heart murmur most obvious on auscultation at the mitral area.  Based on the above presentation and history  the suspicion would be toward infective endocarditis. Mr. X should receive empiric antibiotic therapy until blood culture results are available. Problem Representation:  Patient Demographics:   A 65-year-old male patient  Presenting Complaints:  The patient is presenting with fever  fatigue  chills  and shortness of breath that have progressively worsened over the past two weeks. The patient also reports unintentional weight loss and night sweats over the same period.  Past Medical History:  1. The patient has a history of intravenous drug abuse  but he has been clean for the past 15 years. 2. He has a known history of moderate aortic stenosis diagnosed five years ago on routine echocardiography. 3. Chronic Hepatitis C diagnosed ten years ago  stable without any treatment. 4. The patient is a lifelong smoker with a pack per day tobacco history. 5. There is also a history of multiple dental procedures with no antibiotics prophylaxis taken.  Family History:   There is a significant family history of heart disease. His father died of a heart attack at the age of 62 years. His mother has hypertension and is alive.  Social and Lifestyle History:  The patient lives alone and is retired. He has two adult children who live in another city. He denies alcohol consumption. His diet is rich in red meats and processed food. He is sedentary and has minimal physical activity.  Physical Examination:  Physical examination showed cardiac murmur consistent with aortic stenosis and an additional new diastolic murmur. He also displayed peripheral stigmata of infectious endocarditis including Janeway lesions  Osler nodes  Roth spots  and splinter hemorrhages under his fingernails.   Review of Systems:  He denies any headache  changes in vision  any joint pain/ swelling  any recent rash  or any urinary complaints. He also denies any recent travel or exposure to sick contacts. He confirmed that he has no allergies.  Given the patient history  examination findings  and risk factors  the clinical picture is strongly suggesting a case of native-valve infective endocarditis  likely the aortic valve infected given his past history of aortic stenosis. He will need further evaluations including blood cultures and echocardiogram to confirm the diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic therapy and possible surgical intervention as per Infective Endocarditis guidelines.
