Problem Representation:  Demographic Characterization: Mr. John is a 56-year-old white male  currently employed as an accountant  living in a suburban area. He is married and has two adult children. He is a non-smoker  only consumes alcohol moderately and has no known drug abuse history. He lives in a two-story suburban home. No known travel history is reported.  Historical & Current Description: Mr. John presents complaints of persistent high-grade fever for the past 3 weeks that does not respond effectively to over-the-counter medication. In addition  he complains of severe fatigue  occasional night sweats  and a noticeable loss of appetite leading to weight loss. He also reports having mild joint and muscle pain. He denies any previous similar episodes.  Physical Examination: On examination  his blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg  pulse 100 beats per minute  respiratory rate 19 breaths per minute  and temperature 39.0°C (102.2°F). Pale conjunctiva and petechiae in his lower-limb are noted. A systolic murmur is heard on auscultation. The remaining examination  including neurological examination  is unremarkable.  Past Medical History: He has a history of Rheumatoid Arthritis  for which he has been taking methotrexate and hydroxychloroquine regularly. His mother and two uncles have a history of coronary artery disease. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago  which is managed by diet and Metformin. His last HbA1c  checked six months back  was 7.2%.   Clinical Suspicion: The demographic features  history  clinical features  and physical examination of Mr. John suggest Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis (IE).  Relevant Investigations: To confirm the clinical suspicion of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  relevant investigations may include Blood Culture Tests to identify the causative organism  Complete Blood Count to check for anemia or leukocytosis  ESR  CRP to assess inflammation  and imaging studies like Echocardiography (Transesophageal preferred) to visualize any vegetations on the heart valves.   This patient’s predisposing factors may include his history of rheumatoid arthritis and its treatment  which may have immunosuppressive effects  and poorly controlled diabetes  which may potentiate infection risks.

Patient Representation:  Patient Profile: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 58 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Carpenter Marital Status: Married Smoking History: Ex-smoker  quit 5 years ago Alcohol Use: Occasional social drinker Recreational Drug Use: None  Presenting Complaint: Symptoms: Fever  fatigue  shortness of breath  night sweats  weight loss  and persistent cough.   Physical Examination: Examination findings include a low-grade fever  a heart murmur suggestive of valvular heart disease (turbulent blood flow heard on auscultation)  Osler's nodes (painful nodules on fingers or toes)  and Janeway lesions (painless  flat red spots on palms or soles).   Past Medical History: - Rheumatic fever in childhood - History of invasive dental procedures - Mitral valve prolapse diagnosed 10 years ago - Controlled Hypertension for the past 15 years - Hyperlipidemia controlled with statins for 10 years   Laboratory Findings: Blood Culture: Positive for Streptococcus viridans Complete Blood Count (CBC): Elevated WBC count indicative of infection C-reactive protein (CRP): Elevated indicating presence of an inflammatory process Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR): Elevated indicating presence of an inflammatory process  Imaging: Transthoracic Echocardiogram (TTE): Shows vegetations on the mitral valve suggestive of bacterial endocarditis   This patient's long-standing mitral valve disease and history of invasive dental procedures put him at higher risk for developing native valve infective endocarditis. Presenting symptoms along with the clinical  laboratory  and imaging findings are consistent with a diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis.

Problem Representation:  Demographic Information: Patient Profile: Mr. P. A.  Age: 62  Gender: Male  Ethnicity: Hispanic. Occupation: Retired factory worker. Living Status: Resides with his wife.  Chief Complaint: The patient presents with a high-grade fever (103°F)  general malaise  and signs of weight loss for the past month.   History of Present Illness: Persistent fever dated from one month prior to admission  associated with fatigue  poor appetite  an unintentional loss of about 15 pounds  and night sweats.  Past Medical History: Mr. P. A.  has a history of rheumatic heart disease and had a mechanical mitral valve replacement ten years ago due to severe mitral valve stenosis and regurgitation. He also has controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetic mellitus.   Family History: His brother died from myocardial infarction at age 68. His father had a stroke at age 72.  Social History: The patient is a former smoker  quit five years ago. He doesn't drink or use recreational drugs.  Exposure History: Worked in a paper factory for 34 years and exposed to chemical substances.   Immunization History: Up to date with immunizations  received his flu shot this year. He had not received any prophylactic antibiotic before dental procedures.  Medication History: He has been on warfarin due to his mechanical mitral valve replacement  along with metformin for his diabetes  and a thiazide diuretic for his hypertension.  Dental History: Poor dental hygiene and untreated decayed teeth.  Summary: Given the long-standing unexplained fever  poor appetite  weight loss  night sweats  along with the history of rheumatic heart disease  mechanical mitral valve replacement and poor dental hygiene  the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis arises for investigation. Further diagnostic examination is suggested  such as Blood cultures and Echocardiography.

Patient Representation:  Name: Patient X Gender: Male Age: 65 years old Demographic Information: Patient X is a retired teacher and lives with his wife. He is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially. He is an active volunteer in his local community.  Past Medical History: Patient X was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes 5 years ago and is on oral hypoglycemic agents. He had an MI (Myocardial Infarction) 2 years ago and underwent PCI (Percutaneous Coronary Intervention) successfully. He is on secondary preventive medication including aspirin and statin. Patient X also has a history of chronic Rheumatic Heart Disease since his 30s. He did not have valve surgery or valve replacement.   Presenting Symptoms: Patient X presents with prolonged feelings of malaise  marked weakness  unintentional weight loss  and night sweats. The symptoms have been going on for 2-3 weeks. In recent days  he has noted a lower grade fever and some new  undefined chest discomfort.   Physical Examination: On examination  Patient X has pallor and mild peripheral edema. There are no obvious stigmata of endocarditis on the skin or eyes. Heart sounds reveal a new murmur  not previously documented.  Hypothesis: The persistent malaise  fever  and new heart murmur in a patient with a history of rheumatic heart disease leads to a suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis. Confirmatory investigations like blood cultures and echocardiography will be needed.

Patient Demographics: - Gender: Male - Age: 65 years - Occupation: Retired teacher - Smoking Status: Non-smoker - Alcohol Consumption: Moderate drinker - Body Mass Index (BMI): 29 (Overweight)  Clinical Presentation: The patient is a 65-year-old male presenting with a history of intermittent fever and chills for the last two weeks. He has been increasingly fatigued  and reports new onset of night sweats and unintentional weight loss over the past month. He has also noted an increased heart rate without exertion and a decrease in his exercise tolerance. A new heart murmur is heard on physical examination.  Past Medical History: 1. Diabetes Mellitus Type 2 - diagnosed 15 years ago and is managed with oral hypoglycemic agents. 2. Hypertension - diagnosed 10 years ago and is controlled with medication. 3. History of Rheumatic fever - patient had it during childhood. 4. Previous history of dental procedures without antibiotic prophylaxis.   Medications: 1. Metformin 500mg - twice a day for his diabetes 2. Lisinopril 10mg - once a day for his hypertension  Family History: No significant family history of cardiac diseases.  Social History: The patient is retired and lives with his wife. He was a school teacher for over 40 years  is a non-smoker  and enjoys a glass of wine with dinner every now and then.  Problem Representation: The problem is a subacute systemic infection presenting with nonspecific symptoms including intermittent fever  night sweats  weight loss  and decreased exercise tolerance. The new heart murmur and history of dental procedures raises suspicion for infective endocarditis.   Hypothesis: A 65-year-old male with a past medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2  hypertension  rheumatic fever in childhood  and recent dental procedures with no antibiotics  now presents with intermittent fever  night sweats  weight loss  increased heart rate  decreased exercise tolerance  and new heart murmur suggestive of Native valve infective endocarditis.

Patient Representation:  Name: John Doe Age: 58 years Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Socio-demographic details: Married  with two children  living in a suburban area. He is a retired commercial pilot. He's a non-smoker and non-alcoholic. Presenting complaints: High-grade intermittent fever  night sweats  fatigue  loss of appetite  and weight loss for the past 4 weeks. He was initially managed as viral fever but did not respond to symptomatic treatment.  Relevant Past Medical History: John was diagnosed with Hypertension 10 years ago and has been on regular antihypertensive medication. He also had a history of Rheumatic fever in his childhood  which led to Mild Mitral stenosis detected in his early adulthood  but it has not required surgical correction yet.  John has had no known allergies. He has not had any previous surgeries or hospitalizations  and there is no known history of significant infectious diseases  including sexually transmitted diseases or tuberculosis.   Family History: His parents are deceased. His father had Coronary Artery Disease and mother had Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. He has a younger sister who is healthy.  Review of systems: - Cardiovascular system: No chest pain  palpitations  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or syncope. - Respiratory system: No history of cough  wheezing  dyspnea  or hemoptysis. - Nervous system: No history of seizures  weakness  numbness or tingling. - GI System: No nausea  vomiting  diarrhea  constipation  or abdominal pain.  - Endocrine: No history of polyuria  polydipsia  or polyphagia. - Musculoskeletal: No joint pain or swelling.   Immunization history: Up-to-date with annual flu shots and adult immunizations according to guidelines. No history of recent travel.  Potential risk factors: Age  previous structural heart disease (mild mitral stenosis secondary to rheumatic fever)  and untreated dental caries and poor oral hygiene.   Physical Examination on presentation: Evidence of oral infection  mild splenomegaly  new regurgitant murmur detected on cardiac auscultation.   Provisional Diagnosis: Native valve infective endocarditis  based on history  clinical symptoms  physical examinations and risk factors.   Further confirmatory investigations required: Blood cultures  Echocardiography  Complete Blood Count  ESR  CRP  Kidney function tests.   Planned Management: Consultation with a cardiologist  empirical antibiotic therapy after appropriate cultures  meticulous oral hygiene maintenance and possibly a dental consultation  and close monitoring of his clinical progress and response to treatment. If confirmed  a discussion on the possibility of valve repair/replacement  depending on the severity of valve damage.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 65 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Civil Engineer (Retired)  Presentation:  Mr. Doe presents with a few weeks history of intermittent fever  night sweats  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss. He had been attributing his symptoms to aging and seasonal flu. But the persistence of symptoms and an episode of chills and shortness of breath brought him to seek medical attention.  Medical History:  He was diagnosed with rheumatic fever at the age of 20  which left him with mild mitral stenosis  but he has been asymptomatic for most of his life. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus ten years ago and has been managing it with metformin. He also suffers from hypertension  for which he takes lisinopril. He had dental work done approximately 1 month ago.  Family History:  No significant family history of heart diseases. His mother had type 2 diabetes and his father died of lung cancer.  Social History:  Mr. Doe does not smoke or consume alcohol. He retired five years ago and lives with his wife. He has been trying to maintain an active lifestyle post-retirement and takes regular walks in his neighborhood park.  Medications:  Metformin for type 2 diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. No known drug allergies.  Recent Investigations:  Physical examination reveals a new heart murmur  splinter hemorrhages under his nails  and Janeway lesions on his palms and soles. His resting heart rate is slightly elevated and blood pressure is within normal range.  Work up includes a blood culture to identify the causative organism  and investigations for possible septicemia  an echo for assessing the condition of the valves and vegetation and a chest x-ray for assessing the lung field. The symptoms  history  and new heart murmurs in this patient suggest a possible diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis  particularly given his history of rheumatic heart disease and recent dental work. His age  sex  and comorbid conditions like diabetes and hypertension further enhance his risk profile.

Problem Representation:  Demographics and Background: A 65-year-old male presenting for evaluation of intermittent fever and lethargy over the past three weeks. He also noticeably lost weight during this period. He is married  living with his wife  and is a retired school teacher. He is a non-smoker and rarely consumes alcohol.  Medical History: He has been a long-term diabetic (Type 2) for 20 years on oral antidiabetic drugs and has a history of Rheumatic heart disease during his childhood  but he reports no cardiac symptoms thereafter. He also had a history of a dental procedure around 4 weeks ago. Additionally  he has hyperlipidemia and is on statins; he does not have any known drug allergies.  Exposure History: He lives in a suburban residential area with no exposure to farms  wild animals  or recent travel. His dental procedure 4 weeks ago involved tooth extraction.  Clinical Exam: Upon examination  he appears fatigued  pale  and cachectic. He has a diastolic murmur on auscultation  splenomegaly on abdominal examination  and petechiae on extremities. He also has Osler's nodes on his fingers and toes.  Laboratory Findings: His blood tests show normocytic anemia and his blood cultures are pending. His EKG and Chest X-ray are normal  but echocardiogram shows vegetations on the mitral valve suggestive of endocarditis.  Clinical Question: In a 65-year-old man with a history of diabetes  rheumatic heart disease  dental procedures  presenting with features of subacute infective endocarditis  what is the best course of antibiotics and is surgical intervention required?  Reasoning: This patient has several risk factors that increase his likelihood of developing native-valve infective endocarditis  including a history of rheumatic heart disease and recent dental procedure. His clinical findings indicate the presence of endocarditis with cardiac involvement  necessitating an aggressive treatment plan with appropriate antibiotics. Management must also consider the need for surgical intervention  dependent on the severity of his condition and his response to initial treatments.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: - Demographics: 65-year-old Caucasian male  - Occupation: Retired construction worker - Social History: Living with wife  no known drug use  non-smoker  occasional alcohol  Clinical Encounter: - Presenting Complaint: 3-week history of intermittent fever  night sweats  inexplicable weight loss  and general malaise. Recent episode of chills  weakness and shortness of breath  prompting visit to the healthcare facility. - Physical Examination: On observation  struggles with mild dyspnea. Oral examination reveals poor dental hygiene  with several missing and decayed teeth.  Past Medical History: - Cardiovascular: Previous diagnosis of aortic stenosis  moderate severity  under medical management for 5 years. Patient is compliant with medication. - Orthopedic: History of carpel tunnel syndrome in both hands  successfully previous managed with surgery. - Infections: Had a root canal procedure performed 4 weeks ago.  - Regular Medications: Ramipril  aspirin  furosemide  atorvastatin  Family History: - Father underwent Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG) at the age of 70 and died of myocardial infarction at 77. - Mother has osteoarthritis  hypertension  no history of cardiac disease.  Clinical Impression: The patient's history of poor dental hygiene  recent dental procedure  indolent symptoms like fever  night sweats  and weight loss  as well as preexisting heart condition suggest a clinical suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis. The suspicion is supported by the new onset of symptoms like shortness of breath  which can point to a cardiac condition.   Next Steps: - Laboratory examination  including complete blood count and inflammatory markers (ESR  CRP) etc. - Blood cultures for identifying the causative organism. - Transthoracic echocardiogram to visualize potential vegetations on the heart valve and assess the degree of valve dysfunction. - High-dose IV antibiotics empirically  and adjust according to blood culture & sensitivity results  under Infectious Diseases and Cardiology consultation.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: Subash  62-year-old Asian male.  Demographics: Current city: Sydney  Australia. Occupation: Retired Engineer. Marital status: Married. Children: Yes  two. He experiences fatigue  malaise  excessive sweating at night  unintentional weight loss  and slight shortness of breath. He has also noticed some blood spots in his sputum. He has a low-grade fever that comes and goes through the day.   Medical history: Subash has a history of native heart valve disease (mitral valve prolapse) which was diagnosed five years ago. He was being managed on medications for the same but has been lax with his follow-up appointments. He has also been diagnosed with hypertension for 15 years and is on medication that is well controlled. Subash also has controlled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. He underwent a surgical procedure (prostatectomy) for Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia 8 years ago.  Surgeries or procedures: Prostatectomy (for BPH) - 8 years back.  Family history: Father: Passed away at 74 due to myocardial infarction. Mother: Suffered from rheumatoid arthritis  alive  aged 92. Brother: Alive  59  with history of colon cancer. Sister: Alive  55  fit and healthy.  Risk factors: Existing heart condition (mitral valve prolapse)  poor dental hygiene (has not been to a dentist for a couple of years)  underwent an invasive procedure (prostatectomy)  aging  diabetes  hypertension.  Allergies: No known drug allergies.  Immunization history:  Flu vaccine - annually  last received 7 months ago. Pneumococcal vaccine - received 5 years ago. Covid-19 vaccine - Fully vaccinated  last received 4 months ago.  Product use history:  No history of illicit drug use or tobacco consumption.  Current medications:  1. Metoprolol for Hypertension and Mitral valve prolapse. 2. Metformin for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. Problem Representation:  Patient Demographics: A 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  married with two adult children  non-smoker  with a moderate alcohol consumption of 1-2 glasses of red wine a night.  Presenting Problem: Patient presents to the clinic with a 2-week history of recurrent fever (with temperatures recorded up to 39 Celsius  or 102.2 Fahrenheit)  malaise  and unexplained weight loss. He also reports night sweats and noted a decline in exercise tolerance due to fatigue.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of mitral valve prolapse without significant regurgitation  diagnosed 10 years ago. He is also hypertensive  well controlled on a single medication. His family history is remarkable; his father died of myocardial infarction at 67 years  and his mother died of stroke at 74. He denies any history of intravenous drug abuse or recent dental procedures  tattoos or piercings  and any allergies.  Physical examination: Physical examination revealed poor dental hygiene. Cardiac auscultation showed a high-pitched blowing holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex radiating to the axilla indicative of mitral regurgitation. He also displayed subungual hemorrhages (splinter hemorrhages) on examination of the nails. His vital signs were stable with signs of fever.  The clinical presentation of fever  in a patient with an existing heart condition (mitral valve prolapse)  the presentation of a new murmur  and other accompanying signs and symptoms suggest the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis. More diagnostic tests (such as blood cultures and an echocardiogram) would be needed to confirm this diagnosis  and further management would be required according to the results.

Problem Representation:  Patient Demographic Information: The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  who presents with symptoms such as fever  malaise  night sweats  and unexplained weight loss over the past few weeks. He lives in a suburban area  is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of Type II diabetes mellitus that is well-controlled with metformin. He also suffers from mild hypertension for which he has been prescribed Lisinopril. The patient has hypersensitivity to penicillin. No reported history of sexual transmitted diseases  intravenous drug use  or dental procedures recently. He had a surgical procedure for the removal of gallbladder stones about 10 years ago. No reported family history of endocarditis or any heart diseases.  Recent Problems: 4 weeks ago  the patient started experiencing fatigue  general malaise  and high fever. He also reported a loss of appetite and moderate  unexplained weight loss. The patient complains of persistent night sweats and intermittent red spots on his palms and soles. He did not seek medical attention initially  expecting the symptoms to resolve spontaneously.  Primary Problem: The patient's condition  his symptoms of fever  weight loss  night sweats  malaise  and the appearance of red spots on the skin are consistent with a presentation of infective endocarditis primarily affecting a native heart valve.  Risk Factors: The presence of diabetes mellitus and hypertension does increase the patient's susceptibility to develop infections including endocarditis. His age and male gender may also increase the risk slightly.  Overall  investigating a diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis is plausible considering the patient's symptoms and history. Appropriate tests and cultures are required to confirm the diagnosis  identify the microorganism responsible  and plan treatment.

Patient Profile: - Age: 60 years old - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired Accountant - Social History: Non-smoker  occasionally consumes alcohol  no history of recreational drug use  Past Medical History: - Hypertension - Type II Diabetes Mellitus - High cholesterol - No history of heart disease  surgery or valve replacements - No history of rheumatic fever - No history of IV drug abuse  Presenting Complaint: - Has been experiencing intermittent fevers over the past week  highest recorded temperature at 39.5°C. - Loss of appetite and unintentional weight loss noted over last two weeks - Complaints of general fatigue and muscle weakness. - Has noted increased breathlessness on exertion over the last few days.  On Examination: - BP: 140/85 mmHg - PR: 90 bpm - RR: 18/min - Temp: 38.5°C - Heart: A new murmur noted on auscultation - Lungs: Normal vesicular breath sounds; no added sounds - Non-pitting peripheral edema detected on bilateral lower limbs  Given the above presentation  the hypothesis would be that the patient might be suffering from native-valve infective endocarditis (IE). Further diagnostic tests including blood cultures  complete blood count  and echocardiogram would be recommended to confirm the diagnosis. The persistent fever  new murmur  and clinical signs of heart failure (fatigue  dyspnoea on exertion  peripheral edema) are indicative of IE. The patient's demographic profile and past medical history of conditions like hypertension and Diabetes Mellitus that predispose to vascular diseases make this a probable diagnosis.

Problem Representation:  Patient Demographics:  A 60-year-old Caucasian male manual laborer who smokes 10 cigarettes daily and occasionally uses intravenous drugs.  Chief Complaint:  Fever  weakness  chills  and a new heart murmur.  History of Present Illness:  The patient has been experiencing a fever  fatigue  night sweats  and chills for the past three weeks which have progressively worsened  accompanied by a noticeable unplanned weight loss. He is also experiencing a shortness of breath on exertion and occasional light-headedness.  Past Medical History:  The patient had a dental extraction 4 weeks ago. He has a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both of which are poorly controlled. He is also known to occasionally use intravenous drugs.  Family History: His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 62  and his mother has diabetes and hypertension.  Social History:  He has been a heavy smoker for 35 years and drinks alcohol socially. Although he doesn’t inject often  he uses intravenous drugs mainly heroin  specifically in the past months due to stress at work. He has been living alone since his divorce 5 years ago.  Physical Examination: On auscultation  a new murmur is heard mid-diastole  specifically over the right second intercostal space  associated with fever  pointing towards infective endocarditis. He has splenomegaly  and Janeway lesions are seen on his palms and soles.  Investigations:  Serology reports show signs of inflammation with raised ESR and CRP. Blood cultures are positive. An Echocardiogram shows vegetations on the heart valves  confirming endocarditis.  Problem: Infective endocarditis present in a 60-year-old Caucasian male patient with a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension  a known smoker  and an occasional intravenous drug user. He recently had a dental extraction. His lifestyle and pre-existing conditions make him vulnerable to bacterial infections and endocarditis.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: - Age: 65-year-old - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired army officer - Residence: Urban - Lifestyle: Non-smoker  occasional alcohol consumption  physical activity - moderate  Chief Complaint: - High-grade fever  - Fatigue  - Shortness of breath  - Weight loss  Past Medical History (PMHx): - Cardiovascular Problems: History of rheumatic heart disease - Any infectious episodes: Had Staphylococcus aureus skin infection 2 years ago - Surgical History: Underwent knee replacement surgery 1 year ago  Family History (FHx): - Father passed away due to heart failure - Brother suffered from rheumatic heart disease at a young age  Social History (SHx): - Living with wife at home  two children - Travels frequently  last travelled internationally 2 months ago   Recent events:  - Visited the dentist for a tooth extraction 1 month ago  Upon further investigation: - Blood cultures positive - Echocardiogram reveals vegetations on the heart valves  Suspected Diagnosis: Infective Endocarditis  Reasoning: Patient's age  gender  past history of rheumatic heart disease  Staphylococcus aureus infection and recent dental extraction along with present symptoms of high-grade fever  fatigue  weight loss  shortness of breath are specifically indicative of native-valve infective endocarditis. The diagnosis is further confirmed by the presence of vegetations on heart valves in an echocardiogram and positive blood culture.

Problem Representation:  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male. He is a smoker with a 30-pack year history and reports occasional alcohol consumption. He works as an electrician and has no known drug allergies.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of type II diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  all of which are managed with medication  as well as a past myocardial infarction treated with angioplasty and stent placement. He experienced no post-procedural complications. He does not have a family history of cardiovascular disease but his father had type II diabetes.   Current Presentation: He has been experiencing intermittent  low-grade fevers for a few weeks  accompanied by chills  fatigue  and a loss of appetite. Additionally  he complains of new-onset weakness in his right hand  poor coordination and a sudden  sharp and severe headache which prompted him to seek medical attention.  Physical Examination Findings: Upon physical examination  he appears fatigued and slightly diaphoretic. His vital signs reveal a fever of 38.3°C (100.9°F)  heart rate of 90 beats per minute  blood pressure of 140/85 mmHg  and respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute with an oxygen saturation of 96% in room air. Auscultation of his heart reveals a new murmur suggestive of mitral regurgitation.  Diagnostic Findings: Complete blood count reveals leukocytosis and mild anemia. Blood cultures demonstrate growth of Streptococcus sanguis. Neurological imaging identifies a small right parietal infarct. Echocardiogram shows vegetations on the mitral valve.  Problem Statement: This problem involves a 60-year-old male with a history of extensive cardiovascular disease who presents with fever  new-onset neurological symptoms  and a newly appreciated murmur. His blood cultures reveal bacteremia with Streptococcus sanguis and echocardiogram confirms the presence of vegetations on the mitral valve. The constellation of these findings strongly suggests infective endocarditis affecting a native valve  leading to septic emboli and stroke. This condition may precipitate a conduction disturbance  acute heart failure  or another embolic event  which could potentially be life-threatening.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presenting at the hospital with signs suggesting native-valve infective endocarditis.  Demographic Information: The patient is retired and lives with his wife in a suburban area. He is a non-smoker and drinks occasionally. His diet includes red meat and dairy products  and he goes for a walk every morning and evening for exercise.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  which is moderately controlled with oral antidiabetic medications. In addition  the patient also had a myocardial infarction 10 years ago  for which he received percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). Since then  he has been on aspirin and an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor. There is no significant family history relevant to the current presentation.  History of Present Illness: The patient has been experiencing intermittent low-grade fevers associated with sweating for the past 15 days  along with malaise  anorexia  and weight loss. These symptoms have been progressively worsening over this period. A week ago  he noticed the appearance of painless red spots on his palms and soles. He also reported a new-onset heart murmur identified in a routine clinic visit.  Physical Examination: Physical examination reveals pale conjunctiva  Janeway's lesions on palms and soles  and splenomegaly. Cardiac exam reveals a harsh systolic murmur best heard at the apex and radiating to the axilla. No other significant findings were noted.  Given the patient's symptoms  signs  and relevant past medical history  the suspicion of infective endocarditis is high. The patient should undergo further investigations  such as blood culture and echocardiography  to confirm the diagnosis and guide the choice of antibiotic therapy. The patient's diabetes and past history of myocardial infarction might complicate the management  hence they should be carefully managed too.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Female  Patient Information  A 70-year-old female  of Caucasian ethnicity  was admitted to the hospital with a one-week history of progressive fatigue  night sweats  and low-grade fever. She had no history of drug use or recent dental procedures. The patient recently experienced weight loss that was not intentional  though the amount was unspecified. Her past medical history was significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both under stable control with medication.   Clinical Findings  Physical examination revealed a temperature of 38.3°C (100.94°F)  blood pressure of 130/80mmHg  pulse rate of 90 beats per minute  and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. There was no evidence of skin or conjunctival pallor. Her cardiac examination revealed a grade II/VI systolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal edge. She showed no signs of peripheral stigmata of endocarditis like Janeway lesions  Osler's nodes  or Roth's spots.    Diagnostic Focus and Assessment  Given the symptoms and physical findings  infective endocarditis was contemplated. Blood cultures were obtained  and empiric antibiotic therapy was started with vancomycin and ceftriaxone. Laboratory workup showed an elevated white blood cell count of 13 000/uL and C-reactive protein of 130 mg/L. Hepatic and renal function tests were normal. An ECG showed normal sinus rhythm.  Transthoracic echocardiogram revealed a large mobile vegetation (1.2 x 0.8 cm) on the aortic valve with moderate aortic regurgitation. Subsequent transesophageal echocardiogram confirmed the presence of the vegetation.   The blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus viridans  which is sensitive to penicillin  vancomycin and ceftriaxone. The diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis was established.  Therapeutic Focus and Assessment  Antibiotic therapy was switched to penicillin  which was administered for six weeks. Despite appropriate therapy  the patient's condition deteriorated due to severe congestive heart failure secondary to worsening aortic regurgitation. She was referred for surgical consultation  and eventually underwent successful aortic valve replacement. Following surgery  further antibiotic therapy was continued for two more weeks.  Follow-ups and Outcomes:  The patient made a full recovery and was discharged in a stable condition. Follow-up at 6 months showed no signs of recurrent infection or valvular dysfunction.  Patient Perspective:   The patient expressed gratitude for the medical care she received  stating that she felt significantly better following treatment  and expressed the intention to continue follow-ups regularly.  Informed Consent: The patient provided written informed consent for the publication of this case report.  Take-away:  This case underlines the importance of high clinical suspicion for infective endocarditis in elderly patients presenting with nonspecific symptoms like fatigue and fever. It underscores that early diagnosis and appropriate therapy  coupled sometimes with surgical intervention  are key to improved outcomes in native-valve infective endocarditis.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis In A 62-Year-Old Male With Past Medical History of Intravenous Drug Use - A Case Report  I. Patient Information:  The patient is a 62-year-old male  married  of Caucasian descent  and hail from a semi-rural community. He was referred to our hospital's emergency care unit by a local clinic.  II. Chief Complaint:  The patient presented with persistent chills  shortness of breath  extreme fatigue  and a recently developed  unexplained weight loss over the last four weeks. The patient also reported occasional episodes of night sweats and explained that attempts to warm up often didn't help.  III. Medical History:  The patient has a past medical history notable for end-stage renal disease requiring hemodialysis  hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus well-controlled with oral hypoglycemics. He also has a long history of intravenous drug use but had reportedly been clean for five years until a lapse into use approximately two months prior to presentation. There is no documented history of any heart diseases.  IV. Physical Examination:  Upon physical examination  the patient had slightly elevated blood pressure  fever (38.5°C)  mottling of the skin over the extremities  and splinter hemorrhages were observed under his nails. On cardiac auscultation  a new systolic murmur was detected at the left sternal border. The lungs were clear to percussion and auscultation  and the liver and spleen could not be palpated.  V. Diagnostic Assessment:  Given the clinical findings  infective endocarditis was suspected. Numerous blood cultures were taken  and the patient underwent a series of diagnostic tests such as a full blood count  renal profile  liver function tests  and C-reactive protein level. An echocardiogram was performed  revealing vegetations on the tricuspid valve. Blood cultures confirmed the growth of Staphylococcus aureus. Hence  a diagnosis of community-acquired native-valve infective endocarditis was clinched.  VI. Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was initially started on empiric antibiotic therapy  which was later adjusted based on blood culture sensitivities. The treatment also included general supportive care and management of his underlying kidney disease. He was closely monitored for potential complications and improvements in his symptoms.   VII. Follow-Up and Outcomes:  Over several weeks of treatment  the patient showed gradual improvement in symptoms. Repeat echocardiography showed a decrease in the size of vegetations  and subsequent blood cultures turned out negative. After completing a 6-week course of appropriate antibiotics  the patient was discharged in stable condition. He was referred to an addiction counseling service and was continually monitored in the outpatient department to avoid a recurrence of his condition.  VIII. Patient Perspective:  The patient was relieved upon his recovery and shared his commitment towards sobriety  realizing that his recurrent substance abuse had imperiled his health.  IX. Informed Consent:  Informed patient consent was obtained for the publication of this case report.  This case underlines the prolonged covert clinical course of native-valve infective endocarditis  particularly in patients with a history of intravenous drug use. Despite being uncommon  it should be included in the differential diagnosis in individuals presenting with unexplained symptoms  such as fever  persistent chills  and malaise  particularly in those with past or present substance abuse.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  A 54-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. B was presented to the hospital emergency department. His primary complaints were fever  fatigue  weight loss  and night sweats. He lives in a urban residence and is currently unemployed.   Clinical findings:  The patient was initially alert and oriented but appeared visibly fatigued. He exhibited signs of pallor. His vital signs were recorded as follows: Temperature- 38.8°C; Blood Pressure- 140/90 mmHg; Heart-rate- 112 beats/min  irregular; Respiratory rate - 20 Breaths/min; Oxygen saturation - 95%.   On cardiac examination  a new murmur of mitral regurgitation complicated by pulmonary edema was noted. Splinter hemorrhages  Osler nodes  and Janeway lesions were present  suggesting an endovascular infection. No history of intravenous drug use was reported.  Past Medical History:  His medical history included hypertensive cardiovascular disease and peptic ulcer disease  for which he was being treated with a calcium channel blocker and proton pump inhibitor respectively. No known allergies were reported. He is a smoker with a 30 pack-year history but does not consume alcohol or illicit drugs. No prior surgeries or hospitalizations were listed.  Diagnostic Focus  Assessment and Therapeutic Intervention:  Blood cultures were drawn  and the patient was started on empiric antibiotic therapy given the high suspicion of infective endocarditis. Subsequent blood cultures demonstrated the presence of Viridans group Streptococci. In addition  a transthoracic echocardiogram report showed vegetation on the native mitral valve  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Upon confirmation of diagnosis  the patient was continued on targeted intravenous antibiotic therapy guided by culture sensitivity. In consultation with Cardiothoracic Surgery  it was determined that due to the patient's symptom severity  surgical intervention  specifically mitral valve replacement  was necessary.  Follow-up Case Outcome:  Postoperatively  Mr. B made a steady recovery. His antibiotic course was completed  and subsequent blood cultures were negative. He showed no signs of heart failure  and his symptoms significantly improved. On follow-up outpatient visit  the patient expressed a willingness to quit smoking and agreed to regular check-ups for early detection of any recurrence of the disease.   Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of recognizing clinical signs of infective endocarditis in patients presenting with fever and a new heart murmur. Despite having no significant past history of valve disease or intravenous drug use  this patient developed severe native-valve endocarditis  necessitating surgical intervention. The case should encourage physicians to include infective endocarditis in their differential diagnosis  even in the relatively low-risk individuals.

Patient's Case Report   Demographics A 55-year-old Caucasian male  a resident of New York City  and a professional salesman by occupation presented himself at the clinic. He lives with his wife and two college-age kids. He has a history of occasional alcohol consumption and is a non-smoker. His family has a history of cardiac problems  with his father having passed away in his late 60s due to heart failure.  Presenting Problem The patient complained of persistent fever  fatigue  night sweats  unintentional weight loss (approximately 7 kg over the past three months)  and intermittent chest pain for the past two weeks. He also reported experiencing mild to moderate joint and muscle aches  generalized weakness  and a decrease in appetite. He confirmed no recent travels  major illnesses  or any significant changes in his diet or lifestyle.   Past Medical History The patient was diagnosed with type 2 Diabetes Mellitus five years ago  for which he has been managing through lifestyle modifications and oral hypoglycemic agents. He also has a history of hypertension for 10 years  currently controlled with an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (Lisinopril). He was briefly on statins five years ago to treat moderate hypercholesterolemia but stopped finally due to muscle pain side effects. He had no previous history of heart diseases  rheumatic fever  or recent dental procedures. He had received medical treatment for pneumonia three years ago.  Clinical Findings Physical examination revealed mild pallor  a low-grade fever (38.1°C)  and a systolic murmur on cardiac auscultation. Chest examination appeared clear  and no hepatosplenomegaly or peripheral stigmata of endocarditis was evident. Blood pressure was 130/85 mmHg  pulse rate was 88 beats/min  and he had a respiration rate of 16 breaths/min.  Diagnosis and Management Investigations  including a full blood count  liver and renal function tests  and chest X-ray  were conducted. Elevated inflammatory markers (erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein)  abnormal liver function tests  normocytic normochromic anemia  and leukocytosis were noted. Blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus viridans. An echocardiogram confirmed valvular vegetations and mild aortic regurgitation consistent with a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.   The patient was admitted and initiated on high-dose intravenous antibiotics as per local guidelines and the infectious diseases team's advice. After seeing a significant improvement  he was discharged with a plan for closely monitored long-term outpatient parenteral antibiotic therapy. He was also referred to a cardiologist for ongoing management of his heart condition and potential surgical considerations.    Due to his history with diabetes and hypertension  added attention was given. In addition  health education on lifestyle modifications and regular follow-ups to monitor blood pressure  blood glucose levels  and the appropriate management of his health conditions was arranged.  This case portrays the complexities and the high index of suspicion necessary to diagnose native-valve infective endocarditis  particularly in a patient with pre-existing chronic diseases. Careful monitoring and regular follow-ups are critical for the prevention of severe cardiac events in the future.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Patient Information: A 46-year-old male presented himself at the emergency department with complaints of unexplained fever  fatigue  intermittent chest pain  shortness of breath  and night sweats lasting for about 3 weeks. The patient is a non-smoker and non-alcoholic. He works as a mechanic and has no known history of illicit drug use. He has no known drug allergies. His family history revealed that he has a father with cardiovascular disease.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of rheumatic fever during his childhood and a recently diagnosed uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus. He does not have any past medical history related to valvular heart disease  immunosuppression  or congenital heart disease.  Investigations and Diagnosis: Routine blood investigations revealed elevated white blood cell count with neutrophil predominance. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein were raised. His blood cultured positive for Staphylococcus aureus. An echocardiogram was performed that showed vegetation on the mitral valve indicative of infective endocarditis.  Treatment: The patient was immediately started on empiric intravenous antibiotic therapy with Gentamicin and Vancomycin  which was later switched to IV Oxacillin  based on blood culture and sensitivity results. His blood sugar levels were managed with insulin therapy. He was also provided with supportive care for symptom management.  Progress and Outcome:  After ten days of antibiotic treatment  the patient's fever and chest pain subsided. Follow-up blood cultures were negative  suggesting successful eradication of infection. However  a repeat echocardiogram showed significant mitral regurgitation indicating valvular damage. The patient was then referred to a cardiothoracic surgeon and underwent successful mitral valve repair surgery.  The patient was discharged with a one-month supply of oral Oxacillin and a strict follow-up schedule. He was given lifestyle modification advice including appropriate diet  regular exercise  and strict control of his diabetes.  Discussion:  This report emphasizes the importance of considering native-valve infective endocarditis in diabetic patients presenting with nonspecific symptoms like fever  fatigue  and breathlessness. Early diagnosis and aggressive management with suitable antibiotics are crucial to prevent complications such as heart failure  systemic embolization  and destructive valvular disease. Adequate control of risk factors like diabetes is also paramount.

Title: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-aged Male Patient: A Case Report  Patient Demographics:  Mr. X is a 59-year-old African-American male  living in an urban neighborhood in Detroit  Michigan  with no significant travel history. He works as an HVAC technician and is a divorced father to two grown-up children.   Past Medical History:  The patient is a known hypertensive  diagnosed approximately 11 years ago. He has also been managing Type II Diabetes Mellitus for about eight years. He is a former smoker and reported a 20-pack year's history before he quit smoking eight years ago when he was diagnosed with diabetes. There is no history of any substance abuse. No known allergic reactions were reported. In terms of family history  his elder brother died from a myocardial infarction at age 65  and his mother has a long history of rheumatoid arthritis.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of persistent high-grade fever for ten days  which was associated with chills  fatigue  loss of appetite  and unintentional weight loss. He also reported a two-week history of malaise and experiences of breathlessness on exertion. He denied any cough  chest discomfort  palpitations  abdominal discomfort  or changes in bowel or urinary habits.  On examination  the patient was ill-looking  lethargic  and had a temperature of 38.6°C. He had mild pallor  but no visible jaundice or cyanosis. Cardiac examination revealed a new pansystolic murmur on the apex radiating to the axilla. Respiratory  abdominal and neurological examinations did not reveal any significant findings.  Workup and Diagnosis:  An initial complete blood count revealed leukocytosis. Inflammatory markers were elevated. ECG and Chest x-ray findings were insignificant.  Given his symptoms and the presence of a murmur  the patient underwent a transthoracic echocardiogram  which identified a vegetation on his mitral valve with moderate mitral regurgitation. Three sets of blood cultures were positive for Staphylococcus aureus  providing a diagnosis of infective endocarditis.  Management and Follow-up:  The patient was started on intravenous antibiotic therapy as per local antibiograms and guidelines for S. aureus endocarditis  and his condition improved significantly over the next few days. He was referred to a cardiologist for potential surgical intervention given the severity of his mitral regurgitation and the large size of vegetation.  This case report illustrates an instance of native-valve infective endocarditis  emphasizing meticulous examination of all patients  especially those with persistent or unexplained fever. It should alert healthcare professionals to have a high index of suspicion of infective endocarditis even in people without a significant past history of heart valve disease.

Title: Infective Endocarditis in a Native Valve of an Elderly Patient: A Case Report  Introduction  Patient Presentation  A 74-year-old Caucasian woman presented to the emergency department with a four-week history of intermittent low-grade fevers  chills  generalized malaise  and unintentional weight loss of approximately 10 pounds. The patient also reported intermittent chest discomfort and shortness of breath upon exertion  but no orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or lower extremity edema. She denied any illicit drug use  recent dental procedures  or known heart murmurs.  Demographics  The patient is a retired high school teacher  a non-smoker  and drinks alcohol occasionally. She lives with her husband in a suburban community and has no known environmental exposures.   Past Medical History  She was found to have hypertension and dyslipidemia approximately ten years ago  which has been well managed with Losartan and Simvastatin. There is no known history of diabetes  malignancy  or autoimmune diseases. Her surgical history is significant for cesarean delivery about 40 years ago.  Clinical Findings  Upon physical examination  she appeared chronically ill. Her temperature was 101.2°F  blood pressure 140/80 mmHg  pulse rate 90 beats per minute  and respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute. Cardiac auscultation revealed a soft systolic murmur. Splenomegaly was noted on abdominal palpation. No petechiae  Osler's nodes  Janeway lesions  or Roth spots were observed.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment  Laboratory findings revealed a normocytic anemia with hemoglobin 9.4 g/dl and an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 85 mm/hr. Blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus viridans. Chest x-ray was unremarkable. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) showed an oscillating intracardiac mass on aortic valve leaflet indicating vegetation with moderate aortic valve regurgitation. The diagnosis of infective endocarditis was made based on the Duke criteria.  Therapeutic Focus and Assessment  The patient was managed with intravenous penicillin G and gentamicin for synergistic activity against Streptococcus viridans. After six weeks of antibiotics  the patient's symptoms and inflammatory markers notably improved. Repeat TTE showed a decrease in vegetative size with stable aortic regurgitation.  Conclusion  This case underscores the importance of early detection and prompt initiation of appropriate antibiotics in managing infective endocarditis  a potentially life-threatening cardiovascular infection. It also emphasizes that infective endocarditis should be considered in geriatric patients with non-specific symptoms like persistent fevers  weight loss  or generalized weakness  particularly in the context of a new heart murmur.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis: A Case Report  Introduction: We report a case of a 67-year-old male suffering from native-valve infective endocarditis (IE).  Patient Information: Mr. XX  a Caucasian male  resides in Rural town  Montana. He is a retired mechanic  a smoker with a 40-pack year history  and moderate alcohol consumer. The patient has a medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Clinical Findings: Mr. XX presented to the emergency department (ED) with a two-week history of intermittent fevers  chills  malaise  and unintended weight loss approximating 10 pounds in the last month. Additionally  he complained of chest discomfort with exertion  progressively worsening over the recent weeks.  Diagnostic Assessment: Clinical examination revealed a temperature of 38.6°C  heart rate of 98 beats/min  and blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg. Heart examination revealed a grade 3/6 systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. Splinter haemorrhages under the nail beds were noted. A complete blood count showed leukocytosis (WBC count of 13 000/uL)  anemia (Hemoglobin at 10.3 g/dL)  and raised ESR (50 mm/hr). Blood cultures were drawn  and after 48 hours  grew Methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus. The patient was started on empiric antibiotic therapy with Oxacillin and Gentamicin.  Trans-thoracic echocardiography (TTE) demonstrated a large vegetation on the aortic valve with significant regurgitation suggestive of valve perforation. No signs of abscess formation or dehiscence was noted.  Therapeutic Intervention: The Infectious Disease Team and Cardiovascular Surgeons were consulted. Considering the patient’s comorbidities  large aortic valve vegetation  valve perforation  and hemodynamic instability  as well as the pathogenicity of the isolated bacteria  the decision was to proceed with surgical intervention. He underwent successful aortic valve replacement with a bioprosthesis without any operative complications.  Follow Up and Outcome: The patient's postoperative recovery was uneventful. His fever resolved  and his blood cultures were sterile by the 5th postoperative day. Repeat echocardiography showed normal prosthetic valve function without any residual vegetations or regurgitation. Antibiotics (Oxacillin and Gentamicin) were continued for 6 weeks post-discharge  and he was also started on lifelong aspirin therapy.  Conclusion: This case emphasized the importance of early recognition  prompt diagnosis  and management of infective endocarditis. This condition remains a major therapeutic challenge  particularly in patients with aortic valve vegetations causing severe regurgitation. Surgical intervention along with effective antibiotic therapy may improve outcomes significantly.  Note: This is a purely fictitious case and does not represent any real individuals or events.  Authorship: Assistant.

Patient Information:   A 64-year-old Caucasian male patient presented previously to the outpatient department complaining of a two-week history of progressive malaise  fatigue  intermittent fever  chills  and night sweats. The patient lives in a suburban residential area and is retired after previously working as an accountant. There is no history of alcohol  tobacco  or illicit substance use and no recent travel activity. He has been on medications for hypertension and type 2 diabetes for the past 10 years. He has a prior history of dental procedures but reported not having any recent dental work done.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  the patient had a temperature of 38.5 degrees Celsius  blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg  and pulse rate of 110 beats per minute. Heart auscultation revealed a diastolic murmur heard along the left lower sternal border. No apparent skin abnormalities nor peripheral stigmata of endocarditis were noted.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Blood tests indicated leukocytosis (WBC count of 14x10^9/L)  raised ESR (50 mm/h)  and moderately impaired renal function (creatinine 1.5 mg/dL). A set of three blood cultures were drawn which all turned positive for Streptococcus mitis  a viridans group streptococcus. Transthoracic Echocardiography (TTE) revealed a large  mobile vegetation on the ventricular side of the aortic valve  with some degree of aortic regurgitation but with preserved left ventricular systolic function.  Diagnosis:  The patient was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis (IE) based on the clinical presentation  positive blood cultures for Streptococcus mitis  and evidence of vegetation on the aortic valve seen on TTE  meeting the Duke Criteria for the diagnosis of IE.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was initially started on empirical antibiotic treatment with intravenous vancomycin and gentamicin. Once blood culture results were known  the regimen was adapted to a 4-week course of high-dose intravenous penicillin G and gentamicin  as recommended for native-valve IE caused by viridans group streptococci. Monitoring of serum antibiotic levels and renal function was performed to avoid nephrotoxicity.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  He showed good clinical response to the treatment with resolution of fever after 1 week and improvement of fatigue and malaise. Serial blood cultures turned negative and control TTE showed a reduction in vegetation size. The patient completed the 4-week antibiotic course. Surgical intervention was not required and the patient was discharged with close follow-up recommended. At six-month follow-up  the patient remained symptom-free without any signs of recurrent IE.   This case emphasizes the importance of early detection  prompt initiation of appropriate antibiotic therapy  and vigilant monitoring in managing patients with IE.

Title: A Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Patient with Chronic Kidney Disease.  Case Report:  Introduction: A 72-year-old African-American male was admitted to our medical center with a clinical presentation suggestive of infective endocarditis.  Patient Information: The patient  a retired school principal  hails from a suburban setting. He lives with his son and daughter-in-law and has no history of alcohol or tobacco use. His only travel history involves two trips to Canada three years ago. He has a known medical history of type 2 diabetes and stage 3 chronic kidney disease. He has no known allergies but has a moderate intolerance to high doses of both metformin and diuretics  causing mild gastrointestinal discomfort.  Clinical Findings: He presented with a two-week history of fever  fatigue  night sweats  exertional breathlessness  and loss of appetite. On physical examination  he was found to be febrile with a heart rate of 102 beats per minute and blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg. Auscultation of his heart revealed a diastolic murmur at the apex suggestive of mitral regurgitation.   Diagnostic Assessment: Laboratory findings demonstrated elevated levels of leukocytes and C-reactive protein indicating an active inflammatory process. Renal parameters were consistent with chronic kidney disease stage 3  and random blood glucose was within acceptable range  suggestive of adequately controlled diabetes.  Transthoracic echocardiography revealed vegetations on the mitral valve. Blood cultures were also drawn and demonstrated growth of Streptococcus viridans  a common agent of native-valve endocarditis.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately started on intravenous Penicillin G and Gentamicin as per the AHA guidelines to treat Streptococcus viridans. He was also put on dialysis due to his escalating kidney symptoms.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: The therapy was successful  and the patient's symptoms improved dramatically over the next two weeks. Repeat echocardiography showed a marked reduction in the vegetation size. Unfortunately  his kidney function did not show significant improvement necessitating his continued requirement for dialysis. However  his diabetes was well controlled throughout.  Patient's Perspective: The patient was initially quite anxious due to the severity of his symptoms but has since expressed relief at his treatment's progress. He indicated his willingness to adhere to any necessary lifestyle changes  required medications  and dialysis sessions to manage his conditions.  Conclusion: This case underscores the serious implications of infective endocarditis in patients with comorbid chronic kidney disease and diabetes. Aggressive management with early initiation of appropriate antibiotics and dialysis can be life-saving in such complex scenarios.

Title: A Case Report on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 72-year-old Female Patient  I. Patient Introduction The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian female  currently living in an urban area. She is a retired school teacher  a non-smoker  and only consumes alcohol socially. She reports no known allergies to drugs or food.  II. Past Medical History The patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which are under control with medication. Additionally  she was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis five years ago  for which she takes methotrexate. The patient has no known history of heart diseases or any other major illnesses. Her family history conveys hereditary risk factors for cardiovascular diseases  with her mother passing away from a stroke and her father having a history of heart disease.  III. Presenting Complaint The patient was presented at the emergency department with high-grade fever  loss of appetite  unexpected weight loss  shortness of breath  and lethargy that persisted over the past three weeks. She also complained of joint pain  particularly in her knees and hands.  IV. Clinical Assessment On examination  the patient was conscious but pale. Upon auscultation  a diastolic murmur was audible. Blood pressure was slightly elevated at 145/89 mmHg  with a pulse rate of 98 beats per minute. The patient presented with slight tenderness at her left knee.  V. Investigation Blood test results showed elevated white cell count and C-reactive protein  indicating active inflammation. Echocardiography revealed vegetation on the native mitral valve suggesting infective endocarditis; no significant valve insufficiency was observed. Additionally  three sets of blood cultures grew Streptococcus viridans  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  VI. Treatment The patient was immediately placed on intravenous antibiotics - high-dose penicillin G and gentamicin. After 2 weeks of this regimen  the patient showed signs of improved clinical condition. Her appetite returned  and lethargy lessened.   VII. Follow Up Due to the advanced age and comorbid conditions  the patient was not considered eligible for valve replacement surgery. After four weeks on antibiotics therapy  the repeat blood cultures were negative and the liver function test results were normal. The patient was discharged from the hospital with close follow-up appointments with the cardiologist.   VIII. Conclusion Despite several comorbidities  the patient responded well to the conservative treatment strategy for native-valve infective endocarditis. Further close follow-up is required to monitor the condition of the mitral valve and to prevent potential complications.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Male with History of Intravenous Drug Use: A Case Report  Patient Information:  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a history of intravenous (IV) drug use and alcoholism. He is a smoker with a 40-pack-year smoking history and is homeless. He has no known family history of heart disease. The patient does not have any known allergies and is not on any current medication.  Clinical Findings:  The patient presented to the emergency department (ED) complaining of fever  shortness of breath  loss of appetite  weight loss  and general fatigue. On examination  he was noted to have a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  blood pressure of 115/73 mmHg  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  and a temperature of 38.6°C (101.5°F). Cardiac auscultation revealed a new heart murmur suggesting possible valvular dysfunction.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment:  Laboratory tests revealed an elevated white blood cell count of 15.3 x 10^9/L (normal: 4-11 x 10^9/L) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 78 mm/h (normal: 0-22 mm/h). Blood culture grew Staphylococcus aureus  indicating bacterial infection. A chest X-ray showed no signs of pulmonary congestion or pneumonia. An electrocardiogram indicated sinus tachycardia but no signs of myocardial infarction.  A transesophageal echocardiogram confirmed the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. It showed a large mobile vegetation on the mitral valve with valve destructive changes without significant regurgitation.  Therapeutic Focus and Assessment:  The patient was admitted to the hospital and started on empiric antibiotic therapy with intravenous vancomycin and cefepime. After blood culture results  the regimen was narrowed down to nafcillin  given the sensitivity of the isolated S. aureus. The patient's clinical condition slowly improved over the following week  with resolution of his fever and a decrease in his inflammatory indices.  Despite the initial medical management  the echocardiogram showed disease progression with persistent vegetation and mitral valve destruction. Given his complex condition and severity of valve destruction  involvement of cardiothoracic surgery for valve replacement was deemed necessary  and the patient was transferred to a tertiary care center for surgical intervention.  Follow-Up and Outcomes:  Surgery was successfully performed without complications. Post-operative recovery was uneventful  and the patient was discharged on a prolonged course of antibiotics to complete six weeks of treatment. He was followed up in the Infectious Disease Clinic and showed good health status one month after discharge. He was also referred to a drug rehabilitation program.  Patient Perspective:  The patient was initially apprehensive about undergoing surgery. However  after a detailed discussion about the risks and benefits  he agreed to undergo valve replacement. Post-surgery  he expressed gratitude for his improved health status and committed to stopping IV drug use.  Informed Consent:  Written informed consent for the publication of this case report and any accompanying images was obtained from the patient.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of prompt diagnosis and management of infective endocarditis  especially in patients with a high-risk profile such as IV drug users. The management should involve not only appropriate antibiotic therapy but also timely surgical intervention when indicated. It also highlights the importance of addressing underlying social and behavioral factors in a holistic care approach.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 65-Year-Old Male Patient - A Case Study  Introduction: This report presents the unusual occurrence of the native-valve infective endocarditis in a 65-year-old male patient with a complicating medical history.  Case Presentation:  Demographic information: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  a retired construction worker  and a life-long smoker with a 40 pack-year history. The patient is a teetotaler and denies any illicit drug use. His family history is significant for early coronary disease in his father and brother.  Past Medical History: The patient's past medical history includes a ten-year history of uncontrolled Type II Diabetes Mellitus  a recent diagnosis of Stage III Chronic Kidney Disease  and Hypertension  under medication management for the past 15 years. He is on Metformin  Lisinopril/Hydrochlorothiazide  and Amlodipine. There was no history of valvular heart disease nor any surgical or invasive procedures in the recent past.  Presenting Complaints: He presented to the emergency department with complains of high-grade intermittent fever and shaking chills for the past 3 weeks  associated with malaise  drenching night sweats  and unintentional weight loss. He also experienced exertional dyspnea  which was progressive in nature.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination showed pallor  icterus  and peripheral edema. Vitals were stable except for a slight tachycardia. Cardiac examination revealed a new cardiac murmur suggestive of mitral regurgitation. Laboratory investigations demonstrated leukocytosis  elevated ESR and CRP levels  along with a slight increase in serum creatinine and poor glycemic control. He was noted to have positive blood cultures with Streptococcus Viridans within 48 hours of incubation.  Diagnosis & Treatment: After correlating the clinical picture with the diagnostic findings  a diagnosis of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis was made. Transthoracic echocardiography confirmed a vegetation on the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve compatible with mitral valve endocarditis.  The patient was immediately started on intravenous antibiotics following the sensitivities of the cultured organism. He was shifted to the Cardiology department for infective endocarditis management and cardiothoracic team consultation for possible surgical intervention considering the severity of valvular damage.  Conclusion: This case represents a classic presentation of native-valve infective endocarditis in a patient with predisposing factors including uncontrolled diabetes and chronic kidney disease. The case emphasizes the importance of early diagnosis and prompt intervention in the management of this life-threatening condition.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-aged Caucasian Female  Patient Information: Ms. A is a 49-year-old Caucasian female who currently resides in a suburban setting. She is employed as a school teacher and has a history of smoking  but quit ten years ago. She is not a known alcoholic or drug user. Her only noted family history is that of cardiovascular disease  affecting her father and grandfather in their later life.  Clinical Findings: The patient presented with chills  fatigue  night sweats  shortness of breath  and unexplained weight loss over the past two weeks. She also reported a mild intermittent fever that had been present for the same duration. She indicated a recent dental procedure about one month ago but was not given prophylactic antibiotics.  Diagnostic Assessment: Physical examination showed slightly elevated temperature  normal blood pressure  and increased heart rate. Auscultation revealed a heart murmur  not previously recorded. Lab results showed an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP)  indicating inflammation. Blood culture demonstrated the presence of Streptococcus viridans.  Transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) showed vegetations on the tricuspid valve suggestive of native-valve endocarditis. Chest X-ray did not reveal any lung infiltrates or emboli  and electrocardiogram (ECG) showed mild tachycardia but was otherwise normal. The patient was tested negative for HIV and Hepatitis B and C.  Therapeutic Intervention: Intravenous antibiotic therapy was initiated with Penicillin G and Gentamicin to cover Streptococcus viridans as per the current guidelines for native-valve endocarditis. The patient was closely monitored for signs of congestive heart failure  embolic events  and any adverse effects from the antibiotic therapy.  Outcome and Follow-up: The patient showed signs of clinical improvement after two weeks of intravenous antibiotic therapy  with a decrease in inflammatory markers and resolution of fever. The decision for a surgical procedure was deferred considering her clinical improvement. She was discharged on a six-week course of oral antibiotic treatment and had a follow-up with a cardiologist every two months. The patient was also educated about the risk factors and importance of prophylactic antibiotic use before any invasive procedures including dental work.  After one year of initial presentation  the patient remains symptom-free and follow-up echocardiography shows no evidence of valve dysfunction or recurrence of infective endocarditis.  Learning Points: This case highlights the need for a high index of suspicion for infective endocarditis in patients presenting with similar symptoms  especially with a preceding invasive procedure. Early diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic therapy as per the current guidelines are crucial for a favorable outcome. The case underscores the importance of patient education about disease condition  treatment  and preventive strategies.

Title: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Male with Chronic Rheumatic Heart Disease  Introduction:  This report presents the case of an 82-year-old male suffering from native valve infective endocarditis  overlaid on a past medical history of chronic rheumatic heart disease (RHD). The report aims to contribute to understanding the complexities in diagnosis  prognosis  and management of infective endocarditis in the presence of pre-existing valvular heart disease.  Case Presentation:  Patient’s Profile  Mr. X  an 82-year-old retired teacher  raised in the rural outskirts of California  presents with a history of rheumatic heart disease (RHD). He is a non-smoker  and denies alcohol or illicit drug use. His family history is significant  with his father and older brother each having suffered from heart disease.  The patient was referred to our clinic for further evaluation for a three weeks’ history of intermittent fever with chills  malaise  and dyspnea on exertion  which had been progressively worsening. He also reported a significant weight loss over the past two months. On further inquiry  no history of dental procedures  skin infections or recent hospitalizations was noted.  Clinical Findings  Upon physical examination  the patient was febrile with a temperature of 38.3 °C  blood pressure was 130/85 mmHg  and pulse was 90 beats per minute. Cardiac examination showed a diastolic murmur in the mitral area. Spleen was palpable on deep palpation while no peripheral stigmata of infective endocarditis were found.  Investigations and Diagnosis  Laboratory investigations revealed a raised total leucocyte count (14 200/cu mm) and elevated CRP (34mg/L). Blood cultures were drawn and empiric antibiotic therapy was started. The patient’s sputum was tested negative for tuberculosis.  Echocardiography revealed a large vegetation on the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve  suggestive of infective endocarditis. The valve showed significant thickening  possibly due to his past history of RHD. Blood culture results later confirmed the presence of Streptococcus viridans  further supporting the diagnosis.  Management and Progress   The patient was hospitalized and continued on intravenous antibiotics  targeting Streptococcus viridans  as per the infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) guidelines. Follow-up blood cultures showed no growth after 72 hours of antibiotics initiation.  The patient’s general condition gradually improved over a week; however  the dyspnea persisted. Repeated echocardiogram showed persistent large vegetation and worsening mitral stenosis.   Given his age  comorbid conditions  and risks associated with surgery  the decision for surgical intervention was deferred. He was discharged on prolonged course of antibiotics and advised close follow up.   Conclusion:  This case underlines the importance of considering native valve infective endocarditis  particularly in patients with a history of rheumatic heart disease presenting with prolonged fever and cardiac murmur. Early diagnosis and initiation of antibacterial therapy can considerably reduce morbidity and mortality; however  managing endocarditis overlaid on chronic RHD presents major challenges.

Title: Acute Native Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Hypertensive Patient: A Case Report  Case Report:  Patient Profile: The patient is a 71-year-old Caucasian female. Her body mass index was recorded at 27 kg/m2 indicating that she is overweight. Her primary language was English and she lived alone. She was a retired teacher with an occasional alcohol consumption history but no history of smoking or recreational drug use. No known allergies were reported.  Past Medical History: She had a well-controlled hypertension for the past fifteen years managed with angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors.) She had been diagnosed with osteoarthritis 5 years ago  managed by occasional non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). She had also been diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia ten years ago and has been on statins. There was no history of heart surgery or any implanted cardiac devices. She had a pacemaker implanted three years ago due to sick sinus syndrome.  Presenting Complaints: The patient sought medical attention because of a 2-week history of worsening fever  chills  fatigue  and an unintentional weight loss. She also reported intermittent shortness of breath and a new-onset heart murmur noticed by her primary care physician.  Diagnosis: Physical examination revealed a low-grade fever (100.6°F) and cardiac auscultation found a diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal edge. Blood cultures taken from her grew Streptococcus bovis and serologic markers showed elevated inflammatory markers. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) showed large vegetation on the mitral valve with moderate mitral regurgitation  highly indicative of native-valve infective endocarditis (IE).   Treatment and Outcome: The patient was immediately put on a course of intravenous antibiotics  to which S.bovis was sensitive. Her clinical status was monitored  and due to deteriorating cardiac function and development of heart failure  she was referred to cardiac surgery.
