Surgical intervention involved a mitral valve replacement  followed by completion of six weeks of intravenous antibiotics. Post-operative course was uneventful. Her subsequent blood cultures were negative. She is to follow up for regular reviews at the cardiology and infectious disease clinics.  This case highlights the significant role of early identification  appropriate antibiotic therapy  and timely surgical intervention in the management of native-valve IE  particularly in patients with underlying cardiac abnormalities like pacemaker presence. It also underscores the potential diagnostic importance of new-onset heart murmurs in an elderly patient.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 56-year-old Male Patient  Patient Profile: Mr. A.  a Caucasian 56-year-old smoke shop owner residing in New York City  presented to the emergency department (ED). He is married with two children and no family reported of any heart disease. He is an occasional smoker with a one-pack-year history and drinks alcohol socially.  Presenting Complaint: He came with a chief complaint of prolonged fever lasting for about 17 days accompanied by malaise  night sweats and an unintended weight loss of about 6 kilograms in 4 weeks. He also reported some shortness of breath with minimal exertion in the past week.  Medical History: Mr. A’s medical history includes well-managed type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 7 years ago  and hypertension diagnosed 5 years back. He also shared about history of a root canal procedure two months before presenting to the ED.  Examination and Diagnosis: Upon examination  the patient appeared acutely ill. He was febrile with a body temperature of 38.5°C  heart rate of 90 bpm  with blood pressure of 147/87 mm Hg  respiration rate of 20/min  and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Notably  he had a new systolic murmur heard at the lower left sternal border. Blood cultures were taken  and the patient was immediately started empirically on intravenous antibiotics.  Two-dimensional echocardiography revealed vegetations on his native mitral valve with attendant moderate mitral regurgitation. Blood cultures turned positive for Staphylococcus aureus. These findings  coupled with the his clinical presentation  led to a definitive diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Management and Outcome: Given the size of the vegetation and moderate regurgitation  a cardiac surgical referral was considered. However  due to his stable condition  a conservative management was decided on.  The patient’s antibiotic regimen was adjusted based on culture sensitivity results; he was continued on intravenous cefazolin and rifampicin. The patient remained stable throughout his four-week antibiotic treatment with notable improvement. He was relieved of his chief symptoms and inflammatory markers returned to normal range. Follow-up echocardiography showed a significant reduction in the size of the vegetation  but with residual mild mitral regurgitation.  Mr. A was discharged with instructions for continued oral antibiotics at home and regular out-patient follow-up with cardiology. Emphasis was made on proper oral hygiene and the need for antibiotic prophylaxis prior to any future dental procedures.

Title: A Case Report of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Male Patient with a History of Intravenous Drug Use  Introduction: The purpose of this report is to detail the clinical presentation  diagnosis  and management of a case of native-valve infective endocarditis in a 38-year old male patient with a past medical history significant for intravenous drug use.  Clinical Presentation: The patient presented at the Emergency Department with a one-week history of fever  malaise  and pleuritic chest pain. The patient also reported a history of intermittent fever with chills and night sweats for the past month. He has a known history of intravenous drug abuse but denies any recent drug use.  Medical History: The patient is a 38-year-old Caucasian male with a history of Hepatitis C and substance abuse  for which he had completed a rehabilitation program three years ago. He has a history of tobacco use and occasional alcohol intake but denies any other significant medical conditions  recent surgeries  or allergies. There is no family history of heart disease.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  the patient appeared ill  diaphoretic  and in distress. Vital signs were significant for fever of 38.5°C  heart rate of 115 beats per minute  and blood pressure of 96/62mm Hg. Cardiovascular examination revealed a new pansystolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. There were no cutaneous manifestations of infective endocarditis such as Janeway's lesions  Osler's nodes  or splinter hemorrhages.   Diagnostic Evaluation:  Blood cultures were drawn and an echocardiogram was ordered. The patient's hemogram revealed a mild leukocytosis. Electrolytes  liver function tests  and renal function tests were within normal limits. Blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus  confirming the diagnosis. The echocardiogram revealed a vegetation on the tricuspid valve  consistent with his diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Management and Follow-up: The patient was started on intravenous antibiotics as per the treatment guidelines for native-valve infective endocarditis  which consisted of ceftriaxone and gentamicin. Given the patient’s history of intravenous drug use  a mental health consultation was also arranged. After six weeks of inpatient intravenous antibiotic therapy  the patient’s symptoms resolved  and follow-up blood cultures were negative. The patient was discharged with plans for continued outpatient follow-up and substance abuse counseling.  Conclusion: This case emphasizes the importance of early recognition and treatment of native-valve infective endocarditis in intravenous drug users. The prompt diagnosis  appropriate antibiotic therapy  and provision for substance abuse counseling contributed to the successful management of this patient's case.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 78-year-old Caucasian Male  Patient Description:  The patient is a 78-year-old Caucasian male  residing in the urban area and retired as a public servant. He lives with his wife and was brought into the emergency department by his daughter  due to persistent fevers  general malaise  and loss of appetite over several weeks' period.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a significant past medical history  including hypertension controlled with diuretics and ACE inhibitors  Type II diabetes managed through diet and Metformin  and a previous transient ischemic attack (TIA) five years back. He does not smoke  only consumes alcohol occasionally  and has no known drug allergies. He has no family history of cardiac disease or rheumatic fever.   Physical Examination:  On examination  the patient appeared generally unwell and pale. His vital signs showed temperature of 38.2 °C  BP 130/82 mmHg  HR 94 bpm  and oxygen saturation 96% on room air. Auscultation found a new diastolic murmur which was absent earlier. Ophthalmologic examination demonstrated Roth's spots and retinal hemorrhages  consistent with signs of infective endocarditis. No petechiae or Osler's nodes were noticeable.   Investigations:  A complete blood test showed elevated markers of inflammation (ESR  CRP)  anemia  and leukocytosis. Three sets of blood cultures were drawn which returned positive for Streptococcus viridians  indicating bacterial endocarditis. Echocardiography confirmed findings of native-valve infective endocarditis  evidenced by vegetations on the mitral valve without significant mitral regurgitation.   Management:  The patient was immediately started on high-dose intravenous Benzylpenicillin and Gentamycin in line with the guidelines for Streptococcus viridians endocarditis. Hospitalist  infectious diseases  and cardiology consultants were involved in his care. The patient's condition gradually improved over the following weeks of treatment. New issues with heart failure  emboli  or valve destruction were closely monitored  but luckily  no complications have been detected.   Conclusion:  Older age  hypertension  and diabetes are identified risk factors for native-valve infective endocarditis. This case highlights the importance of prompt diagnosis and treatment of this life-threatening condition to prevent complications like congestive heart failure or systemic embolization. It also emphasizes the role of multidisciplinary care in managing complex cases of infective endocarditis. Future investigations into strategies for early detection and prevention of native-valve endocarditis in at-risk populations are warranted.

Title: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Male: A Case Report  Abstract: A case of native-valve infective endocarditis in a 55-year-old Caucasian male was presented with non-specific  flu-like symptoms. A detailed evaluation suggested endocarditis. This case report highlights the importance of clinical suspicion and prompt intervention in the management of infective endocarditis  despite non-specific presenting symptoms.  Case Report:  Patient Information: A 55-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with a 14-day history of malaise  night sweats  and intermittent fevers. The patient was a non-smoker  moderate alcohol drinker  not on any regular medications and with no known drug allergies. He had no relevant exposures or travel history  and there was no family history suggestive of a hereditary health problem. The patient lived alone  worked as a plumber and denied intravenous drug use.   Clinical Findings: On examination  the patient looked systemically unwell  but hemodynamically stable. His body temperature was elevated at 38.8°C. A cardiac examination revealed a new systolic murmur. He had no peripheral stigmata of infective endocarditis.   Diagnostic Assessment: Blood tests showed an elevated white cell count (WCC) of 15.0 x 109/l (4.0 - 11.0) and raised C-reactive protein (CRP) at 104 mg/l (<6). His renal function  liver profile were within normal limits. A set of blood cultures was drawn  which isolated Streptococcus viridans.   An echocardiogram was performed given the high clinical suspicion of the medium-risk profile of native-valve infective endocarditis. This confirmed the presence of an oscillating mass on the patient’s mitral valve consistent with infective endocarditis.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately started on empiric IV antibiotic therapy  which was later tailored based on sensitivity data. He received 6 weeks of intravenous ceftriaxone and after completion of antibiotic therapy  the patient's symptoms had all but resolved  and inflammatory markers returned to normal.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: The follow-up echocardiogram showed resolution of the vegetation on the mitral valve and the patient was cleared of infection. He has since remained well  with no recurrence of symptoms.   Discussion: This case highlights the importance of considering a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis in patients presenting with non-specific flu-like symptoms such as malaise and night sweats. Clinicians need to maintain a high index of suspicion for this potentially life-threatening condition  especially in patients with new cardiac murmurs on examination. Prompt diagnosis and treatment are vital for a favorable prognosis.   Conclusion: Native-valve infective endocarditis should be considered in patients presenting with non-specific  flu-like symptoms  and clinical or echocardiographic evidence suggestive of endocarditis. Early recognition and treatment are essential to prevent serious complications and improve patient outcomes.

Patient Profile:   This report talks about a 62-year-old Caucasian male  John Doe. He is married and lives suburban with his wife. He is a retired engineer and spends most of his time gardening. He doesn't smoke and drinks socially.   Demographics:  - Sex: Male - Age: 62 years old - Race: Caucasian - Location: Suburban - Occupation: Retired Engineer  Initial Presentation: John presented to the office with symptoms of fever  night sweats  mild shortness of breath  and unintentional weight loss of about 5kg over two months. Upon further inquiries  he mentioned having occasional 'heart flutterings' in recent weeks. No notable changes were seen in his bowel or urinary habits.   Past Medical History: John is known to have type 2 diabetes mellitus and has been under medication for the past 12 years. He also has a history of hypertension managed with lifestyle modifications and medication for three years. He did dental work six months ago and was not prescribed prophylactic antibiotics. There is no known history of illicit drug use  HIV  hepatic disease  or immune disorders in him.  Examination: On physical examination  John appeared fatigued and pale. He was febrile (38.3°C) and tachycardic (110 bpm). Cardiac auscultation revealed a systolic murmur. Funduscopy demonstrated an ominous Roth spot. No Janeway lesions  Osler's nodes  or splinter hemorrhage were seen.  Investigations and Findings: Blood cultures were obtained which grew Staphylococcus aureus. His complete blood count revealed anemia and leukocytosis. Inflammatory markers  ERPC and C-reactive protein were also found elevated. Transesophageal Echocardiogram (TEE) showed vegetation on the mitral valve  confirming the suspicion for native valve infective endocarditis.  Treatment:  An intravenous regimen of antibiotics was immediately initiated as per the guideline for Staphylococcus aureus endocarditis. After liaising with the cardiothoracic team  it was also decided that he would also need valve replacement surgery in the near future.  This case highlights the importance of taking a thorough history  especially for susceptible individuals such as those with diabetes. It also underlines the requirement for endocarditis prophylaxis for all dental procedures in at-risk populations  even those procedures not traditionally considered invasive. Regular dental hygiene advice also needs to be reinforced in high-risk groups as prevention is better than cure.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 67-year-old Female with a History of Rheumatic Heart Disease: A Case Report  Case:  Patient Information: The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian female presented with one week of progressive fatigue  fevers  and shortness of breath. She lives in a suburban community with her husband and has no known drug allergies. She is a non-smoker and reports occasional alcohol use. Her family history is significant for cardiovascular disease.  Past Medical History: The patient had been under regular medical attention for rheumatic heart disease  diagnosed 15 years prior. She also has controlled hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. Other notable medical history includes mitral valve regurgitation  but she had previously refused surgery owing to personal preference.  Present Health Status: On examination  the patient was diaphoretic with a heart rate of 112 beats per minute (bpm)  blood pressure of 105/78 mmHg  a temperature of 38.2°C  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Cardiac examination revealed a pansystolic murmur at the apex radiating to the axilla  with no other significant findings.   Investigations: Complete blood count demonstrated profound leucocytosis (WBC 19 500/μL)  mild anemia (Hb 10.7 g/dL)  and a high erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR 70 mm/hr). Blood cultures were taken  which subsequently grew Streptococcus Viridans. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) revealed vegetation on the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve with moderate to severe regurgitation. A subsequent transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) confirmed the TTE findings and diagnosis of infective endocarditis.  Treatment: The patient was initiated on intravenous antibiotic therapy based on culture and sensitivity results  with penicillin and gentamycin. Subcutaneous insulin was given for her diabetes  and antihypertensive was adjusted for her blood pressure control.   Follow-up and Outcomes: Following four weeks of intravenous antibiotics  the patient's symptoms improved significantly  including resolution of fevers and reduction in fatigue. A repeat blood culture was negative  and an echocardiogram showed reduced valve regurgitation. The multi-disciplinary team concluded that there was no immediate need for surgical intervention  considering her clinical improvement.   Patient Perspective: The patient expressed relief at her symptomatic and instrumental improvement and felt reassured by the decision to avoid immediate valve surgery. She resolved to adhere strictly to her medications and follow-up appointments.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of early recognition  aggressive antimicrobial therapy  and thorough re-evaluation in the management of elderly patients with infective endocarditis  particularly in the context of existing valve disease such as rheumatic heart disease.   This report is compliant with the CARE guidelines for clinical case reporting. Information has been de-identified for privacy.

Case Report:   Demographics:  Patient Profile: M Age: 67 years Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired School Teacher Location: Sacramento  California Marital Status: Married Insurance: Medicare   Presenting Complaint:  The patient presented with a 2-week history of intermittent fever  fatigue  moderate weight loss  and shortness of breath.  Medical History:  The patient had a history of hypertension and type II diabetes  both of which were being managed with medication. He had not undergone any surgical procedures in the past. He was a non-smoker and drank alcohol occasionally. There was no known drug allergy. Family history included a father who passed away due to a stroke and a mother who passed away due to breast cancer.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  the patient showed signs of pallor and shortness of breath. He had a temperature of 100.4°F (38°C). Heart sounds revealed a soft systolic murmur. There were also signs of splenomegaly. No rash or signs of septic emboli were observed. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.   Investigation and Management:  Laboratory results revealed elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP). Blood cultures drawn were positive for Staphylococcus aureus. Transthoracic echocardiography demonstrated a 1.5cm by 1.0 cm oscillating mass attached to the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve  indicative of a vegetation.  Diagnosis and Treatment:  A diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis was made. The patient was initially managed with intravenous vancomycin and gentamicin. After a consultation with cardiology and cardiothoracic surgery specialty  a decision was made to monitor the patient closely on medication with the plan for surgery if there was evidence of further valve destruction or embolic events.  Conclusion:  Native-valve infective endocarditis is a challenging infection to diagnose and manage due to its insidious onset and varied clinical presentations. Early recognition through clinical examination and timely treatment are crucial to prevent complications. This case highlights the need for increased awareness among clinicians when presented with a similar picture.  (Note: This case report is a made up for the purpose of illustrating an example and does not represent a real patient's health information.)

Case Report  Patient Identification: The patient  a 57-year-old male  Caucasian ethnicity  presented to the specialty clinic with a chief concern of progressive dyspnea and persistent fever. He resides in Tucson  Arizona  and is employed in manual labor. Relevant social history accounts for moderate alcohol use  occasional tobacco smoking  and no illicit drug use.  Clinical History: From the medical history review  the patient has been hypertensive for the past 15 years. He is also diabetic (Type II) for around 10 years and is taking Metformin for the same. He does not have any history of malignancy or apparent immunosuppression. No family history of heart disease is reported. He did not have any documented history of rheumatic fever or congenital heart disease.  Presenting Complaints: The patient reported experiencing symptoms for the past two weeks which includes moderate to high-grade fever  malaise  progressive shortness of breath  night sweats  and unquantified weight loss. He also reported reduced exercise tolerance and generalized weakness.  Clinical Examination: On physical examination  he appeared febrile and diaphoretic. Reduced breath sounds with basal crackles were evident on pulmonary auscultation. Cardiovascular examination revealed a grade 3/6 pansystolic murmur over the mitral area.  Investigations: Laboratory tests showed raised inflammatory markers (WBC count of 14x10^9/l  C-reactive protein of 100 mg/L). Blood cultures were also taken. Transthoracic echocardiography exposed vegetations on the mitral valve with moderate mitral regurgitation  suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus viridans after 24 hours of incubation  which provides an account for the patient's underlying infection. The patient's serological markers for HIV  Hepatitis B  and Hepatitis C were negative  ruling out possible underlying immunosuppressive conditions. His chest X-ray and computed tomography (CT) scan revealed multiple left lung based consolidations suggestive of septic emboli.  Management: The patient was started on empirical antibiotic therapy with intravenous vancomycin and gentamicin as per hospital's protocol for infective endocarditis  considering his allergic history to penicillins. Once the blood culture results were obtained  the treatment was streamlined to intravenous ceftriaxone.  Follow-up & Current Status: Over the course of two weeks  the patient's condition improved clinically  and he showed signs of recovery. Repeated blood cultures came back negative after one week of antibiotics  and the patient was continued on the same regimen for six weeks in total. Reporting 3-months after his initial diagnosis  the patient reported feeling significantly better and is continuing regular follow-up at the cardiology clinic and is currently being considered for valvular surgery.  This case highlights the importance of early detection and management of infective endocarditis in patients with non-specific  constitutional symptoms and underlying chronic diseases.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis with Current Intravenous Drug Use   Case Report:  Patient Information:  Mr. J  a 45-year-old Caucasian male  presented to our emergency department with complaints of malaise  low-grade fever  and intermittent night sweats persisting for two weeks. The patient has a past medical history of intravenous drug use and was under methadone maintenance treatment. He has no known allergies and was not on any regular medications except for methadone. He has a history of homelessness and poor social support. The patient does not have a family history of endocarditis or any other major cardiac disease.  Clinical Findings:  Upon examination  his heart rate was slightly elevated at 110 beats per minute  and he was febrile with body temperature at 38.2°C. Cardiac auscultation indicated a diastolic murmur in the mitral area  and the physical examination found minor peripheral stigmata such as Janeway lesions and clubbed fingers. No neurological deficits or immunological phenomena were observed.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Laboratory studies showed increased inflammatory markers (C-reactive protein was 180 mg/L  and erythrocyte sedimentation rate was 45 mm/h). Blood cultures were taken  which grew Staphylococcus aureus. An echocardiogram revealed vegetation on the native mitral valve  irrespective of significant valve regurgitation or heart failure. Thus  the diagnosis of infective endocarditis was made according to the modified Duke criteria.   Therapeutic Intervention:  Empiric therapy was initiated promptly with intravenous vancomycin (30 mg/kg/day) and gentamicin (3 mg/kg/day) considering his risk factors and pending blood culture results. After confirming the organism as MSSA (Methicillin-Sensitive Staphylococcus aureus) through blood culture susceptibility  the treatment was switch to intravenous nafcillin (9g/day) and gentamicin was continued.    Follow up and Outcome:  During a 6-week course of treatment  the patient's clinical state gradually improved. The patient's inflammatory markers normalized  and a repeat echocardiogram showed significantly reduced vegetation. He was discharged with instructions to complete a 6-week course of antibiotics and to abstain from intravenous drug use. Regular follow up was scheduled with cardiology  infectious disease  and addiction services.   Patient Perspective:   The patient expressed gratitude for the treatment received and recognized the severity of the disease. He showed strong motivation to abstain from future illicit drug use and wished to continue engagement in the addiction services treatment program.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of early recognition and prompt treatment in native-valve infective endocarditis  particularly in susceptible populations such as intravenous drug users.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 67-year-old Caucasian Male - A Case Report  Introduction:  Native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE) is a rare but serious infection involving the inner endocardium of the heart  often with fatal outcomes if left untreated. We present herein a case of NVIE in a 67-year-old Caucasian male.  Case Presentation: A 67-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes was admitted to the hospital with a two-week history of fatigue  weight loss  fever  and night sweats. He lived alone  was an ex-smoker and had no history of intravenous drug use  dental procedures or recent surgeries. He had no known allergies and was on metformin and lisinopril for his pre-existing conditions.  On examination  the patient had a fever of 38.5 °C  blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg  and his heart rate was 90 beats per minute. Cardiac auscultation revealed a pansystolic murmur in the aortic region. There was no peripheral stigmata of infective endocarditis. His skin and sclera were normal and he showed no signs of vascular phenomena or immunological phenomena.  Laboratory findings showed an elevated white blood cell count of 14 500/ µL  hemoglobin was 10g/dL  and the platelet count was 200 000/ µL. Blood cultures were drawn and results demonstrated growth of Streptococcus bovis. Chest X-ray did not show any signs of infection or congestion.  Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) revealed a large echogenic mass on the aortic valve consistent with vegetation  confirming the diagnosis of NVIE. No other valvular abnormalities were observed.  The patient was started on appropriate antibiotic therapy according to the identified microorganism (i.e.  Ceftriaxone and Gentamycin). He responded favorably to antibiotic therapy  with resolution of his fever and constitutional symptoms over the next few days. Repeat blood cultures after two weeks of antibiotics were negative.  Due to the size of the vegetation  ensuing valve damage and the risk of systemic embolization  a decision was taken to refer the patient for surgical evaluation. He successfully underwent aortic valve replacement surgery  with postoperative course being uneventful.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of early diagnosis and treatment of NVIE  particularly in older patients with pre-existing comorbidities. High clinical suspicion  accurate blood culture  and TEE contributed to the successful management of NVIE in this case.  Keywords: Native-valve infective endocarditis; Streptococcus bovis; Transesophageal echocardiography; Aortic valve replacement.

Patient Information: A 56-year-old Caucasian male presented to the hospital with malaise  weakness  shortness of breath  and a low-grade fever. He is a non-smoker and rarely drinks alcohol. The patient is a construction worker and reports no recent travels or sick contacts.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of rheumatic fever in childhood and had been diagnosed with mitral valve prolapse ten years ago  for which he did not receive any surgical intervention  but was under ongoing surveillance. He denied prior use of intravenous drugs or any recent dental procedures.  Clinical Findings: His initial vital signs revealed a body temperature of 100.4°F  blood pressure of 120/80mmHg  pulse rate of 96/min  and respiratory rate of 16/min. The physical examination revealed a diastolic murmur perceived at the apex of the heart. There were no signs of peripheral stigmata of endocarditis. His chest was clear to auscultation  and there was no peripheral edema.   Diagnostic Assessment: Laboratory tests showed elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). White cell count was slightly increased  and blood cultures were taken. Electrocardiogram demonstrated no significant changes. Chest X-ray was unremarkable.   Transthoracic echocardiogram was performed and revealed a vegetation on the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve along with moderate mitral regurgitation. The patient underwent transesophageal echocardiography  which confirmed these findings. Subsequently  blood cultures grew Streptococcus viridans  endorsing the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was started on empirical intravenous antibiotics adjusted later according to culture sensitivity  including ceftriaxone and gentamicin  under the care of an infectious disease specialist. He was also administered antipyretics for fever control.   Follow-up and Outcomes: After six weeks of antibiotic therapy  repeat imaging showed a reduction in vegetation size  and blood cultures were negative. He was discharged and referred to a cardiologist for ongoing management of his mitral valve disease. He was also educated about the importance of dental hygiene and regular dental visits to prevent future endocarditis episodes.  Patient’s Perspective: The patient was initially shocked by the diagnosis. He was not aware that his previous heart condition could result in such a severe disease. Nonetheless  he was relieved to notice improvements in his symptoms and committed to follow the prescribed regimen and necessary lifestyle modifications.  Informed Consent: The patient provided informed consent for the publication of this case report. Efforts have been made to maintain the anonymity of the patient.   Conclusion: This case emphasizes the fact that patients with mitral valve prolapse  especially with a prior history of rheumatic heart disease  are at an increased risk for native valve endocarditis. Regular follow-up and patient education about potential risk factors are crucial for these patients to prevent severe life-threatening infections like infective endocarditis.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 72-Year-Old Male: A Case Report  Abstract:  This report presents a case of a 72-year-old Caucasian male who developed native-valve infective endocarditis resulting from Staphylococcus aureus.  Introduction  Native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE) is a serious infectious disease of the cardiovascular system  often associated with significant morbidity and mortality. It commonly involves infection caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus.  Case Presentation  A 72-year-old Caucasian male was admitted to our department complaining of ongoing intermittent fevers  fatigue  night sweats  and progressive dyspnea over the past three weeks. The patient’s medical history outlined a controlled case of Type 2 diabetes  hyperlipidemia and no known drug allergies. He was a former smoker and consumed alcoholic beverages socially  but had no illicit drug use. He reported no recent dental procedures or any invasive medical procedures.   Clinical Findings  Upon physical examination  the patient displayed a temperature of 38.5 degrees Celsius and heart murmur was present during auscultation. A series of blood tests were ordered which revealed elevated C-reactive protein levels  leucocytosis  and positive blood cultures for Staphylococcus aureus. Anemia and mild kidney function impairment were also noted.   Diagnostic Assessment  An echocardiogram revealed a mobile vegetation on the aortic valve  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. No other valves appeared to be affected. The presence of Staphylococcus aureus was confirmed in multiple blood cultures  correlating with the patient’s presenting symptoms and the echocardiogram findings.  Therapeutic Intervention  The patient was started on intravenous flucloxacillin as per the Infective Endocarditis treatment guidelines for native-valve Staphylococcus aureus infective endocarditis. In addition to antibiotic therapy  supportive treatments were provided which consisted of fluid management and antipyretics.  Follow Up and Outcome  After two weeks of intravenous antibiotic treatment  the patient's symptoms gradually resolved. A repeated echocardiogram after six weeks of therapy revealed a significant reduction in the size of the vegetation. The patient was discharged with a four-week course of oral antibiotics and was advised to undertake regular outpatient follow-ups.  Conclusion  This case emphasizes the importance of early recognition and treatment of NVIE to avoid complications  such as metastatic infections and heart failure. It also reiterates the value of thorough history-taking in understanding the development and progression of the disease.

Title: A Case Report of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis: A Challenge in the Management   Patient Demographics  The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. J  living in a suburban area. He was born and lived most of his life in Maryland  United States. He is a retired engineer  married with two adult children  and is a current smoker from the past 25 years with a daily consumption of 10 cigarettes. He lives alone with his wife and has Medicare insurance. The patient revealed a family history of heart diseases  with his father dying of a heart attack in his 60s.  Past Medical History  Historically  the patient has Type II Diabetes Mellitus  under control with oral hypoglycemics  and hypertension  managed with medication. He was diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) 5 years ago due to his smoking habit. His vaccinations  including pneumococcal and influenza  are updated according to age and chronic conditions. The patient does not have any known drug allergies.   Presenting Conditions  Mr. J presented at the emergency department with a complaint of high-grade fever  chills  fatigue  shortness of breath  and weight loss over the past two weeks. He additionally reported experiencing recent episodes of night sweats. He denied chest pain  cough  or other respiratory symptoms.  Clinical Findings  On examination  the patient appeared acutely ill  with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg  respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute  and fever of 39°C. Cardiac examination revealed a new systolic murmur. Laboratory findings included raised inflammatory markers  normocytic anemia  and urine analysis demonstrating microscopic hematuria. His blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus viridans. Transthoracic echocardiography revealed a 1.5 cm vegetation on the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Treatment and Outcome  The patient was treated with intravenous penicillin and gentamicin in line with the recommended therapy for Streptococcus viridans infective endocarditis. Despite aggressive antimicrobial therapy  his condition did not improve satisfactorily and eventually required surgical management. He underwent mitral valve replacement surgery successfully and demonstrated significant clinical improvement post-surgical intervention. Following discharge  he was enrolled in a comprehensive disease management program which includes cardiologist  pulmonologist and endocrinologist consultations  along with strict smoking cessation counseling.  Conclusion  This case illustrates the challenges in managing a complicated case of native-valve infective endocarditis in a patient presenting with multiple comorbidities. A multidisciplinary approach to management and the necessity of surgical intervention were highlighted in this case.

Patient Information:  Mr. J is a 57-year-old Caucasian male from a suburban area.  Clinical Findings:  Mr. J was admitted to the hospital reporting dyspnea  prolonged fever of two weeks  night sweats  fatigue  and decreased appetite. On physical examination  he was noted to have pale skin and enlarged  tender spleen with few lesions on the skin suggesting vasculitis. A heart murmur was also detected during a cardiovascular examination.   Medical History:  Mr. J has a history of Type II diabetes that is well-controlled by oral hypoglycemic agents. He also has hypertension treated with ACE inhibitors. There is no prior history of heart disease. He's a non-smoker  consumes moderate alcohol  and denies any illicit drug use.   Diagnostic Assessment:  In response to his symptoms and examination  blood cultures were ordered and demonstrated the growth of Streptococcus viridans consistent with bacteremia. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) showed a valvular mass suggestive of vegetations on the mitral valve indicating infective endocarditis.   Therapeutic Intervention:  Mr. J was initiated on intravenous vancomycin therapy for initial empiric treatment. After positive blood culture results  the treatment was narrowed down to intravenous penicillin G and gentamicin. His therapy was planned for four weeks under close monitoring of his symptoms and laboratory parameters including liver function tests and renal function tests.  Follow Up and Outcomes:  Throughout the treatment  Mr. J was under regular monitoring for potential side effects and therapeutic response. His fever resolved after eight days into treatment and other symptoms also gradually decreased. A repeat blood culture came back negative on the 15th day of treatment. A follow-up echocardiogram post-treatment demonstrated the resolution of vegetations.   Teaching Points:  This case illustrates native-valve infective endocarditis without previous heart disease potentially linked with a suboptimal oral hygiene condition. It emphasises the importance of looking beyond the typical risk factors and being aware of infective endocarditis's varying clinical manifestations. It also highlights the need for a high index of suspicion for early diagnosis and treatment initiation in febrile patients  especially with findings suggestive of sepsis or vasculitis.   Patient consent was obtained for the case report.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Patient Information: Mr. J  a 60-year-old male of Hispanic descent  was admitted to the hospital. He has a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with metformin  hyperlipidemia managed with atorvastatin and hypertension controlled with a combination of lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. He doesn't have a history of IV drug use or any known heart valve disease.  Presenting Complaints: The patient presented with a 2-week history of intermittent high-grade fever associated with night sweats  generalized fatigue  unintended weight loss  and a new-onset poor appetite.  Physical Examination: Upon physical examination  the patient was moderately distressed  his BMI was 29.2  blood pressure was high at 160/90 mmHg  heart rate was 110 bpm and his temperature was elevated at 102.5 F. Cardiovascular examination revealed a diastolic murmur best heard at the apex. Patients showed oral thrush and minor petechiae in his lower limbs upon further examination. There was no jugular venous distention  organomegaly  or peripheral edema.  Investigations: Laboratory studies showed leukocytosis (WBC 16×10⁹/L with 80% neutrophils) and elevated CRP of 18 mg/L. Blood cultures were taken and sent for analysis. EKG showed left ventricular hypertrophy with no acute ischemia. Chest X-ray was unremarkable.  An urgent transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) exhibited thickening with a tiny vegetation on the mitral valve leaflets consistent with infective endocarditis (IE). Blood cultures returned positive for Streptococcus bovis.   Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis due to Streptococcus bovis. His condition is potentially complicated by his age  history of hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and the source of infection associated with a high risk of systemic embolization.  Treatment: The patient was started on IV Penicillin G and Gentamycin as per IDSA guidelines  antipyretic for fever control  and all his chronic medications were continued as before. Consultation with cardiology and infectious disease specialists was sought for further management.  After 2 weeks of antibiotic treatment  the patient's symptoms improved significantly. A repeat echocardiogram showed a reduced size of vegetations on the mitral valve.  Because of the presence of Streptococcus bovis  which is associated with colorectal neoplasia  the patient was referred to gastrointestinal specialists for a colonoscopy.  This case should remind clinicians to consider infective endocarditis in the differential diagnosis when patients with known risk factors present with persistent fever and other systemic symptoms. The case also highlights the importance of identifying the causative organism as it can be associated with extra-cardiac malignancies.

Title: Case Report of a 45-year-old Male with Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Profile and Medical History: A 45-year-old Hispanic male with a history of tobacco use  diabetes mellitus type-2  hyperlipidemia  and hypertension was admitted to our medical facility. He has had no previous surgeries or known allergies.  Presenting Complaints: The patient presented with a three-week history of persistent fever  lethargy  and pronounced weight loss.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed a temperature of 38.8°C  heart rate of 102 beats per minute  blood pressure of 120/85 mm Hg  and respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. Cardiac auscultation elucidated a new murmur consistent with mitral regurgitation. The patient also had multiple petechiae on his lower extremities and palpable spleen.  Diagnostic Assessments: A complete blood count indicated leukocytosis and anemia. Blood culture grew Staphylococcus aureus. Chest radiograph was unremarkable while the electrocardiogram indicated left ventricular hypertrophy but no changes suggestive of acute ischemia.   Trans-esophageal echocardiography (TEE) confirmed the presence of a vegetation on the atrial side of the mitral valve leaflet  consistent with infective endocarditis.   Patient Management and Outcome: The patient was initially managed with intravenous antibiotic therapy including ceftriaxone and gentamicin. Due to continuing fever and bacteremia despite adequate antibiotic therapy for five days  and considering the size of vegetation on the valve  surgical evaluation was sought.   Upon evaluation  patient underwent surgical debridement and mitral valve replacement. The post-operative period was uneventful and the patient was discharged on prolonged antibiotics with regular follow-up appointments and blood cultures  to ensure complete eradication of the infection.  Discussion: This case highlights the significant morbidity associated with native-valve infective endocarditis in individuals with pre-existing heart conditions. It underscores the importance of swift diagnosis and aggressive management  including surgical intervention if necessary  for improving patient outcomes.  Despite a strong treatment regime  the patient's condition mandated surgical intervention indicating that early detection plays a crucial role in decision-making and avoids complications. Delays may lead to serious consequences such as systemic emboli  heart failure  or even death.   Conclusion: Native-valve infective endocarditis can lead to severe complications and high mortality rates. Therefore  clinicians should maintain a high degree of suspicion and promptly start appropriate management. This case also emphasizes the importance of periodic evaluation and patient education  especially among those with underlying cardiovascular diseases.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 63-Year-Old Male: A Case Report   Patient Description:  We present a case of a 63-year-old Caucasian male patient who was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis (IE). The patient was a non-smoker and reported moderate alcohol consumption. He had no family history of cardiovascular disease or infection-related diseases.   Past Medical History:  The patient's past medical history comprised hypertension (HTN) diagnosed 10 years ago  well-controlled on therapy with amlodipine 5 mg daily. He was also under treatment for type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) for the last seven years  using metformin 1000 mg twice daily. No other significant medical history was noted.  Case Presentation:  The patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of fever  fatigue  and exertional dyspnea of two weeks' duration. Additionally  he reported unintentional weight loss of about 10 lbs over the last month. He had no known allergies. On examination  he was febrile (38.5 °C) and exhibited a heart rate of 98 beats per minute. Blood pressure was 132/84 mmHg. Cardiovascular examination revealed a new-onset murmur at the apex  heard best at end-diastole with the patient in the left lateral decubitus position.  Investigations and Diagnosis:  An initial blood culture revealed the growth of Streptococcus viridans. An electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrated sinus rhythm without any acute ischemic changes. A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) confirmed presence of a mitral valve vegetation measuring 1.5 cm  satisfying the echocardiographic criteria for definite IE according to the modified Duke's criteria.  A diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis (IE) was made.  Treatment and Follow-up:  The patient was initiated on IV penicillin G and gentamicin  in line with the American Heart Association's (AHA) treatment guidelines for IE due to streptococci. Anticoagulation therapy remained withheld in fear of embolic events from the large vegetation. Despite aggressive medical therapy  his clinical status deteriorated and he developed severe mitral regurgitation  leading to decompensated heart failure. The case was re-evaluated by a multidisciplinary team  and a decision was made for surgical management. The patient underwent successful mitral valve replacement with a mechanical valve.   He was discharged on lifelong anticoagulation to prevent thromboembolic complications for the mechanical valve. During the six-month follow-up  the patient's condition was stable and he continued to remain asymptomatic.   Conclusions:  This case underscores the importance of early and aggressive management of community-acquired native-valve IE  including surgical intervention when required. It also highlights the significance of multidisciplinary discussions for managing complicated cases of IE.   Acknowledgement:  The patient consented to the publication of this case report and the case report was approved by the institutional ethics committee.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 60-Year-Old Male with History of Rheumatic Heart Disease  Report:  Introduction:   We herein report a case of a 60-year-old male patient with an existing history of rheumatic heart disease complicated by native-valve infective endocarditis.  Clinical Information:  The patient  a 60-year-old Caucasian male  presented in the Emergency Department with the chief complaint of fever  chills  malaise  and body aches for the past one week. He also reported experiencing a shortness of breath  orthopnea  and weight loss  but denied any chest pains  palpitations  or syncope. His past medical history revealed long-standing rheumatic heart disease  with preserved systolic function reported in his last echocardiogram.  On examination  the patient was febrile (38.6°C)  with a heart rate of 96 beats per minute  and blood pressure measured at 130/80 mmHg. Cardiac auscultation revealed a diastolic murmur at the apex. Current medications included warfarin for stroke prevention  lisinopril for blood pressure control  and aspirin for secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease.  Investigations:  Blood tests demonstrated elevated inflammatory markers (C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate) and anemia (hemoglobin 10.1 g/dl). Electrocardiogram showed sinus rhythm with no ST or T wave changes. Blood cultures isolated Streptococcus viridans; however  no vegetation was detected at transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE). Serologic tests were negative for rheumatoid factor and anti-nuclear antibodies  ruling out connective tissue diseases.  Management and Outcome:  The patient was diagnosed with definite infective endocarditis based on clinical  microbiological  echocardiography results and Duke's criteria. He was started on intravenous (IV) antibiotics  specifically ceftriaxone and gentamycin for a total of 6 weeks. Regular follow-ups after completion of IV antibiotic therapy showed significant improvements in his symptoms and inflammatory markers. The patient was eventually transferred to a rehabilitative unit due to ongoing weakness and anemia.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of a high degree of suspicion for infective endocarditis in patients with pre-existing heart disease and the benefits of early treatment initiation. As healthcare professionals  we need to incorporate an aggressive approach to patients with rheumatic heart disease who present with unexplained symptoms  such as fever or changes in murmur  to limit and prevent lethal complications of infective endocarditis.   Facility and Date:  The Johns Hopkins Hospital  Baltimore  Maryland  United States August 2022.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 65-year-old Caucasian Male   Introduction:  The following case report describes a 65-year-old Caucasian male with native-valve infective endocarditis and no prior history of valvular heart disease.  Patient Information:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired  non-smoker  with a known history of Type-2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both controlled with oral medication (metformin and lisinopril  respectively). He is not on regular anticoagulation  and he follows a Mediterranean diet. He has no known allergies to drugs. The patient lives in a suburban area with his wife. He reported no recent travels or unusual food intake.  Clinical Findings:  The patient was presented to the emergency department with a 2-week history of malaise  night sweats  and a recently developed shortness of breath. There was no history of chest pain  cough or orthopnea. Physical examination showed mild pallor  blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg  irregular pulse of 100 bpm  and a temperature of 37.8 degrees Celsius. Cardiac examination revealed a grade 3 systolic murmur. No peripheral signs of infective endocarditis were found.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Laboratory tests revealed an elevated white blood cell count of 15 000 cells/mm3  and raised C-hs reactive protein levels at 60 mg/L. His HbA1C was 7.3 %. His renal function was normal. An electrocardiogram demonstrated atrial fibrillation. An echocardiogram showed vegetation in the mitral valve with severe mitral regurgitation and no signs of abscess or other complications. Blood cultures grew Streptococcus viridans  confirming the diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis. The patient was negative for HIV  HCV  and HBV.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was admitted to the cardiology department and intravenous antibiotics were commenced (Penicillin G)  alongside subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin (enoxaparin) for the atrial fibrillation.  Outcome:  The patient's general condition improved over the following 4 days with a reduction in fever and general malaise. Repeat echocardiogram completed after 2 weeks of intravenous antibiotic therapy showed reduction in vegetation size. However  the severity of the mitral regurgitation persisted  and the patient was referred for surgical consultation.  Follow-up:  A successful mitral valve replacement was performed 5 weeks after the initial presentation. At a subsequent follow-up visit 6 weeks postoperatively  the patient reported feeling well with resolution of his symptoms. His INR on warfarin was within the therapeutic range.  Conclusion:  The presented case underlines the importance of maintaining a high index of suspicion for infective endocarditis in patients presenting with non-specific symptoms particularly when concurrent signs of new murmurs or uncontrolled atrial fibrillation are present.  Consent:  Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report and accompanying images.

Abstract:  The following is a case report about Mr. X  a 62-year-old male patient who presented with signs of native-valve infective endocarditis. The report contains detailed demographic data  a full medical history  and a review of the diagnosis  treatment  and follow-up associated with this disease.  Case Presentation:  Mr. X is a 62-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He lives in a suburban area and is a retired school teacher. He has moderate alcohol use and does not use tobacco or illicit drugs.   He presented at the hospital with complaints of a high fever  severe fatigue  weight loss  and occasional breathlessness for about two weeks. He also had a non-productive cough and intermittent chest pain  particularly on the left side. In addition  he had developed a few  non-itchy  red spots on the palms and soles  recognized as Janeway lesions.  Physical Examination:  Upon physical examination  the patient exhibited a low-grade fever (38.1°C) and moderate systolic murmur (3/6). He was slightly dyspneic at rest. Blood pressure was 142/88 mmHg  and pulse was regular at 88/min. The patient showed finger clubbing  Osler nodes on fingers  and Janeway Lesions on palms.  Laboratory Findings:  Blood investigations showed an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP)  whereas white blood cell (WBC) count was within normal limits. Hemoglobin and platelet levels were marginally low. Blood cultures demonstrated Staphylococcus aureus growth  suggestive of bacteremia. The patient also had increased glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) attributable to type 2 diabetes.   Imaging:  A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) and Transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) was done which showed an oscillating intracardiac mass on a native valve consistent with vegetations confirming the diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis.   Management:  Mr. X was admitted to the hospital and immediately started on high-dose intravenous antibiotics (Vancomycin and Gentamycin) based on sensitivity of S.aureus to these drugs from the blood culture report. His blood sugar was managed by giving insulin. Follow-up blood culture reports showed a decrease in S. aureus load over the next two weeks  indicating a positive response to the treatment. Close monitoring of renal function was maintained due to risk of nephrotoxicity from the antibiotics.   Outcome:  Mr. X was hospitalised for six weeks  during which he clinically improved  and his inflammatory markers gradually returned to normal. Repeat echocardiograms showed decreasing size of vegetations and no new cardiac complications. After deescalation to oral antibiotics  he was discharged with recommendations for regular follow-up and instructions regarding strict glycemic control and continuing the oral antibiotics for several weeks.  Summary:  This case underscores the importance of early diagnosis and aggressive treatment of native valve infective endocarditis  particularly in patients with a prior history of diseases like diabetes. Rapid initiation of antibiotic therapy can significantly decrease morbidity and improve outcomes in such patients.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Aging Male Patient with Diabetes Mellitus and History of Alcohol Abuse.  Case Report:  Patient Information:   We report the case of a 67-year-old Caucasian male who presented to our hospital complaining of a two-week history of fever  fatigue  and malaise.  Medical History:  The patient has a known medical history of type II diabetes mellitus  which had been under poor control with recent HbA1c values persistently above 9.0%. His medical history also entails chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  uncontrolled hypertension  and chronic alcoholism which he admitted to quit just two years ago. He denied ever using intravenous drugs or having any history of rheumatic heart disease  valvular heart disease  or any other underlying heart conditions. He has had no previous surgical history or relevant familial history of any cardiovascular diseases. Additionally  on social history  he was a lifelong non-smoker.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  he appeared unwell with a temperature of 38.8°C. Cardiovascular examination revealed a new systolic murmur best heard at the apex of the heart. His blood pressure was 135/85 mmHg  his pulse rate was 88 beats per minute and regular  and his respiration rate was 18 breaths per minute. No peripheral stigmata of infective endocarditis were found.  Diagnostic Assessments:  Laboratory investigations showed elevated levels of inflammation markers with a white cell count (WCC) of 13.0 x 109/L and C-reactive protein (CRP) of 114 mg/L. His random blood sugar level on admission was 312 mg/dL and HbA1c was 9.5%.  Three blood cultures were collected in 24 hours  all of which grew Gram-positive cocci  identified as Staphylococcus aureus. Chest X-ray was normal  while echocardiography confirmed the presence of a vegetation on the mitral valve  with no significant regurgitation and preserved ejection fraction.   Therapeutic Interventions:  The patient was diagnosed with infective endocarditis based on Duke's criteria and promptly started on treatment with intravenous ceftriaxone and gentamicin per Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) guidelines. He was also managed for his diabetes  hypertension  and COPD.  Follow-Up and Outcomes:  On a fortnight from his admission  the patient condition significantly improved. The repeat echocardiogram after four weeks of therapy showed a reduction in vegetation size. The patient is currently in the outpatient setting for continuation of antibiotics as his infectious disease management.  Conclusions:   This case amplifies the fact that patients with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus and a history of alcohol abuse could be susceptible to native-valve infective endocarditis due to Staphylococcus aureus. Early detection and effective medical intervention can lead to a positive clinical outcome.

Title: Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 50-Year-Old Female With Chronic Rheumatoid Arthritis  Introduction: This case report discusses a 50-year-old Caucasian woman diagnosed and successfully treated for native-valve infective endocarditis. It underscores the importance of early diagnosis and prompt initiation of antibiotic treatment in patients with predisposing comorbid conditions to prevent possible complications.  Case Presentation:  The patient was a 50-year-old woman who presented to the emergency department complaining of persistent fever  fatigue  night sweats  and weight loss over the preceding two weeks. The patient’s past medical history was significant for chronic rheumatoid arthritis  for which she was on methotrexate and corticosteroids. She had no known drug allergies and had not undergone any surgical procedures in the past.  On initial examination  her vital signs were as follows: temperature  38.3ºC; blood pressure  120/85 mm Hg; heart rate  90 bpm; respiratory rate  20/minute; and oxygen saturation  96% on room air. Physical examination revealed conjunctival pallor and a newly appreciated systolic murmur best heard at the apex. No subcutaneous nodules  digital clubbing  or Osler’s nodes were observed. A complete blood count demonstrated moderate normocytic anemia and leukocytosis with left shift. Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein levels were elevated.  Given her persistent fever and new cardiac murmur in conjunction with her systemic symptoms  a diagnosis of infective endocarditis was considered. Blood cultures were drawn  and the patient was empirically started on intravenous vancomycin and gentamicin.  Transthoracic echocardiography revealed a mobile vegetation (15 mm x 10 mm) on the atrial side of the mitral valve without significant mitral regurgitation. Following echocardiography results and Duke Criteria  a definitive diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis was made. Blood cultures later grew Streptococcus viridans.  Given the patient's diagnosis  her rheumatoid arthritis medications (methotrexate and corticosteroids) were temporarily withheld. Her antibiotic therapy was adjusted according to the sensitivity of the cultured organism  shifted to ceftriaxone for a total of 4 weeks. Repeat blood cultures after two weeks of antibiotic therapy were negative.  Conclusion:  The patient responded well to the treatment  with the resolution of her fever and systemic symptoms. No surgical intervention was required  as there was no evidence of heart failure  uncontrolled infection  or persistent vegetation after appropriate antibiotic therapy. She was referred back to her rheumatologist for the management of her rheumatoid arthritis  with the recommendation for close follow-up given her increased risk of future endocarditis.  This case underscores the need for clinicians to maintain a high index of suspicion for infective endocarditis in patients presenting with systemic symptoms  especially those with predisposing conditions such as autoimmune diseases or immunosuppression. Early recognition and prompt initiation of treatment are critical in preventing potential fatal systemic complications.

Title: Case Report on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Woman with Diabetes Mellitus  Case Presentation: Ms. A  a 55-year-old Asian woman  presented with a three-week history of intermittent fever  fatigue  and a noticeable weight loss of approximately five kilograms within the past two months. Her past medical history included type II diabetes mellitus  diagnosed ten years prior  with inconsistent management due to medication nonadherence. She also reported a 20-pack-year smoking history and occasional alcohol use. She has not undergone any recent dental or invasive procedures. She had no known history of drug abuse and did not have any recorded previous heart problems.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed visible weight loss and pallor. Her vitals showed mild tachycardia at 108 bpm  with a blood pressure of 120/90 mmHg. Cardiovascular examination identified a diastolic blowing murmur best heard along the left sternal border. There were no peripheral stigmata of endocarditis visible. The rest of the general and systemic examinations were unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment: Complete blood count showed anemia of chronic disease and raised leukocyte counts. Fasting and postprandial glucose levels were above the normal range. Blood cultures grown demonstrated the presence of Streptococcus viridans  suggesting bacteremia. Echocardiogram showed a mobile  oscillating mass attached to the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve  suggesting vegetation  alongside mitral regurgitation. This confirmed the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Therapeutic Intervention: Based on her clinical status and the sensitivity pattern of the bacteria isolated  Ms. A was started on intravenous ceftriaxone (2g daily) and gentamicin (1 mg/kg thrice daily) for a period of 6 weeks. Regular blood glucose monitoring was done  and her diabetic therapy was adjusted accordingly with Insulin due to her increased glucose levels. She was recommended to quit smoking and to limit her alcohol consumption.  Follow-up and Outcomes: On serial follow-ups  she showed a gradual symptomatic improvement. Repeated blood cultures after two weeks of antibiotic therapy came out sterile. Follow-up echocardiography at six weeks revealed significant reduction of the vegetation size. She was encouraged to adhere to her diabetic medications and was referred for tobacco cessation counseling.  Patient Perspective: Ms. A expressed gratitude towards her healthcare team for the comprehensive and thorough management of her condition. She is motivated to maintain her health  control her blood glucose levels  and give up smoking.  Discussion: This case emphasizes the importance of considering infective endocarditis in patients presenting with unexplained fever  especially with a history of predisposing factors such as poorly controlled diabetes. It underlines the necessity of timely intervention to prevent further complications and also draws attention to the need of patient education for adherence to therapy  lifestyle modifications  and regular follow-ups.

Patient Profile:  Name: Confidential (to protect patient privacy) Gender: Male Age: 54 years old Nationality: American Occupation: Taxi driver  Past Medical History:  The patent  at his age  has had hypertension for over a decade  for which he takes Amlodipine tablets regularly. There is no known history of diabetes mellitus  autoimmune disorder  or other significant systemic illnesses in the past. He denies any history of intravenous drug use  cardinal symptoms of HIV/AIDS or rheumatic heart disease. His family history includes coronary artery disease in his older brother.  Present Illness:  The 54-year-old male presented to the emergency department with high-grade fever accompanied by rigor  intermittent shortness of breath  progressive malaise  and fatigue. Symptoms had been started about three weeks before his presentation in the hospital. He also complained of pain and swelling of the right lower limb. The patient reported moderate weight loss in recent few weeks without any intention to lose his weight. However  he denies recent travels  contact with sick individuals or consumption of raw/undercooked foods  or exposure to uncommon pets or animals.  Clinical Examination Results:  On physical examination  the patient was found to be febrile (Body temperature: 38.4 ºC) and tachycardic (heart rate: 110 bpm  regular). He demonstrated conjunctival pallor and minor petechial rash on the extremities. Upon auscultation  a diastolic heart murmur in the aortic area and rales at the lung bases bilaterally were noticed. The right lower limb was swollen  warm  tender  and showed signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The systemic examination revealed no hepatosplenomegaly.  Investigations:  Blood investigations revealed anemia and a significantly raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP). Blood culture results returned positive for Staphylococcus aureus. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) showed a 2 cm mass attached to the right coronary cusp of the aortic valve with mild-to-moderate aortic regurgitation suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Management and Progress:  He was immediately started on intravenous antibiotics based on bacteria isolated from blood cultures. Unfractionated heparin was started for deep vein thrombosis while further surgery for valve replacement was planned. Despite active management  his condition worsened  and heart failure ensued. He was transferred to the Invasive Cardiology Department where he underwent successful aortic valve replacement.  Follow-up:  The patient has been regularly attending follow-up appointments. Prosthetic valve function was found to be satisfactory during follow-ups and he has completed the prescribed antibiotic regimen. After four weeks the patient was restarted on Warfarin for prophylactic anticoagulant therapy following mechanical valve replacement.  Conclusion:  This case report outlines initial presentation  diagnosis  and management of a patient with native-valve infective endocarditis. This case is of peculiar importance due to the rarity of DVT associated with endocarditis  which makes it an interesting clinical scenario.

Patient Information: A 57-year-old white male presented to the community hospital emergency department complaining of generalized weakness  intermittent fever  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss over the past month. He has no known allergies.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of moderate cigarette smoking for the past 40 years  type 2 diabetes mellitus managed by diet and oral hypoglycemic agents  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with a couple of hospital admissions over past years due to COPD exacerbations. He does not have any family history of cardiac disease. His drug history includes Metformin  Salmeterol inhaler  and Salbutamol inhaler.  Social History: He is a retired truck driver  lives with his wife  has two adult children  and four grandchildren. His alcohol consumption is moderate and within recommended limits.   Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed a temperature of 38.2°C  blood pressure of 110/75 mmHg  pulse rate of 103 beats per minute  and respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute. Clinical examination demonstrated an ill-looking male with peripheral cyanosis and finger clubbing. Cardiac auscultation revealed a diastolic murmur at the apex radiating to the axilla. Other signs such as splinter hemorrhages or Roth spots were not evident.  Diagnostic Assessment: Laboratory results showed leukocytosis of 16 000 with 80% neutrophils  erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 110 mm/hr  C-reactive protein of 98 mg/L  and elevated blood urea nitrogen & creatinine suggesting renal impairment. Liver enzymes and electrolytes were normal. Chest radiography was consistent with previous documentation of COPD and did not show any pleural effusion or pulmonary edema. ECG was normal without any ischemic changes or signs of pericarditis.  An urgent transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) revealed a large  mobile echodensity attached to the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve with moderate mitral regurgitation suggestive of vegetation and possible infective endocarditis (IE).   Blood cultures taken at the time of admission subsequently grew Staphylococcus aureus  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE).  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was started empirically on intravenous vancomycin and ceftriaxone after obtaining blood cultures at presentation. After confirming the blood culture results  the antibiotic was switched to Nafcillin and Gentamicin based on susceptibility testing. Infectious disease service was consulted and they advised continuing antibiotic therapy for six weeks. Cardiac surgery was consulted but they decided to defer surgical intervention due to ongoing infection.  Follow-Up: The patient showed steady improvement with the resolution of fever and decrease in leukocytosis over the following days. He completed 6 weeks of intravenous antibiotic therapy and was discharged home. Repeat blood cultures at the completion of therapy were negative and repeat echocardiography showed a reduction in vegetation size. His renal function gradually returned to normal. The patient was advised regular follow-up every 3 months with infectious disease  cardiology  and nephrology services.   This case emphasizes the importance of an early diagnosis and prompt treatment of infective endocarditis to prevent potentially fatal complications such as heart failure or embolic events. High clinical suspicion and regular follow-ups are key factors in managing such patients.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Diabetic Patient: A Case Report   Patient Information:  Patient: Mr. A Age: 75 years Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired   Clinical History:  Mr. A has a documented history of type 2 diabetes mellitus for approximately 20 years. Other significant past medical history includes moderate hypertension and hyperlipidemia  all of which are managed with oral medication. The patient has been compliant with his medications and regular follow-ups.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. A presented to the emergency department with a 2-week history of fatigue  less appetite  low-grade fever  chills  and a new onset of a systolic murmur over the left lower sternal border. He had previously been treated with oral antibiotics from a local clinic for a presumed respiratory tract infection  but the symptoms persisted.   Clinical Findings:  On examination  he was febrile with a temperature of 38.3 Celsius. His other vital signs were within normal ranges. The cardiac examination revealed a grade 3/6 systolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. No other abnormalities were noted on physical examination  and he did not exhibit any peripheral signs of endocarditis such as petechiae  Osler's nodes or Janeway lesions.   Diagnostic Assessment:  Blood cultures were drawn and sent to the microbiology laboratory. Whilst awaiting results  he was admitted to the hospital and put on empirical antibiotic therapy.  His echocardiogram showed a 1.5cm vegetation on the aortic valve  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.   Laboratory findings were significant for mild leukocytosis and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP). Blood cultures later grew Streptococcus viridans  which proved to be sensitive to penicillin.   Therapeutic Intervention:  Mr. A was started on intravenous Penicillin G  3 million units every 4 hours for 6 weeks as per the sensitivity report. The patient's fever gradually subsided  and his general health improved over the next week.  Follow-up and Outcome:  During his follow-up  his clinical symptoms were completely resolved. A repeat blood culture at the end of treatment was negative  and follow-up echocardiogram showed a resolution of the valvular vegetation.   Learning Points:  This case illustrates the importance of comprehensive history taking  and early suspicion of infective endocarditis in patients with persistent fever and identification of new murmurs. Timely intervention and guideline-based antimicrobial therapy can result in a satisfactory outcome even in high-risk patients. Even so  more effort is needed in the prevention and control of risk factors that may potentiate heart valve infections  such as quality diabetic control.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Abstract: A 62-year-old Caucasian male presented to the medical center with frequent fever  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss  later diagnosed as Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis.  Patient profile: The patient is a 62-year-old male  Caucasian  retired mechanic with a history of moderate smoking and social alcohol drinking. His initial profession apparently exposed him to potential sources of bacterial contamination. He lives with his wife  has no children  and denies any illicit drug use. There is a significant family history of cardiac diseases. The patient has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia.  Initial Presentation: The patient reported a 2-month history of episodic fever and chills  fatigue  mild shortness of breath  and an unintentional weight loss of 10 lbs over a month. His regular medications include metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient appeared chronically ill. His body mass index (BMI) was 28  temperature was 100.4 F  blood pressure 130/85 mm Hg  heart rate 88 beats per minute  respiratory rate 14 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. Cardiovascular examination revealed a diastolic murmur in left lower sternal border and an increased intensity of P2. Abdominal and genital examination did not show any unusual sign. He had no visible skin lesions  and neurological examination was normal.  Investigation Findings: A complete blood count showed mild leukocytosis and mild anemia. Blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus bovis. Electrocardiogram showed non-specific ST-T wave changes. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) and later transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) demonstrated a large vegetation on the mitral valve along with severe mitral regurgitation. Besides  there was evidence of pulmonary hypertension.  Diagnosis and Management: The patient was diagnosed with Native-valve Infective Endocarditis (NVE). Initially  he was started on intravenous penicillin G and gentamicin  according to the sensitivity of the isolated bacteria. His fever started to subside after 5-day of antibiotic treatment. After a detailed discussion with the patient and his family about potential risks and benefits  surgical intervention was agreed upon to control the infection  which included mitral valve replacement with a bioprosthetic valve. The postoperative period went uneventful. The patient was eventually discharged on a 6-week course of antibiotic therapy.  Conclusion: This case emphasizes the importance of early detection  timely medical  and possibly surgical intervention in patients with NVE. It also signifies the common association of Streptococcus bovis  a constituent of gut flora  with endocarditis  marking the need for gastrointestinal evaluation for possible lesions in these patients.

Title: An Unusual Presentation of Streptococcus viridans Infective Endocarditis in a Native Valve  Introduction:  Infective endocarditis (IE) is a rare but severe infection of the endocardial surface of the heart  which can predominantly affect native as well as prosthetic valves. We present a case of native-valve Streptococcus viridans infective endocarditis in a middle-aged woman with no prior cardiac history.  Case Presentation:  A 62-year-old Caucasian woman presented with a three-week history of worsening fatigue  loss of appetite and unintentional weight loss of approximately 10 kilograms. The patient also reported experiencing episodes of low-grade fever and night sweats but no other significant symptoms. There was no known drug or alcohol abuse  and her personal and social history were non-contributory.  Past medical history  including cardiovascular history  was unremarkable. She was on no medications and had no known drug allergies. She had recent dental procedure two months ago without any antibiotic prophylaxis.  On physical examination  she was febrile (temperature 38.5°C)  with blood pressure of 120/70 mmHg  heart rate 98 bpm  and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Cardiac examination found an early diastolic murmur heard best in the fifth intercostal space along the right sternal border. Fundoscopic examination showed Roth spots  and there were splinter hemorrhages present in the nail beds. These clinical signs were suggestive of infective endocarditis.
