Laboratory findings showed elevated inflammatory markers (erythrocyte sedimentation rate 60 mm/hr  C-reactive protein 110 mg/l)  normocytic anemia  and elevated urea and creatinine levels but normal liver function tests. Blood cultures were drawn  resulting positive for Streptococcus viridans. Transeosophageal echocardiography revealed vegetations on the mitral valve consistent with native valve endocarditis.  The patient was admitted to the hospital  where she received a four-week treatment course of intravenous penicillin G and gentamicin. Subsequent blood cultures showed eradication of the organism after 2 weeks. Her clinical status improved significantly over the course of treatment.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of careful examination and recognition of clinical signs of infective endocarditis  particularly in patients presenting with non-specific symptoms. Streptococcus viridans  a common oral flora  can lead to potentially fatal conditions following dental procedures in the absence of prophylactic antibiotics. It underlines the necessity for the dental community to adhere strictly to prophylactic antibiotic guidelines in patients at risk for infective endocarditis.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 65-Year-Old Male: A Case Report  Patient Information: A 65-year-old Caucasian male  former heavy smoker (40 pack/years  quit 10 years ago)  and a history of alcohol abuse and hypertension  was presented to the emergency department. He has a known history of type II diabetes mellitus and atrial fibrillation; he's on oral anticoagulation.  Clinical Findings: The patient was acutely ill-appearing  and presented with a three-week history of intermittent fever  malaise  anorexia  and weight loss. He also reported recent bouts of night sweat  nonspecific arthralgias without joint swelling  and an observed heart murmur on physical examination.  Diagnostic Assessment: Elevated inflammatory markers  signs of anemia  and slightly impaired renal function were observed upon laboratory investigation. An ECG showed atrial fibrillation with a heart rate of approximately 100/min. The chest X-ray was unremarkable. Transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiography revealed a 10 mm vegetation on the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve and moderate regurgitation. Blood cultures were positive for Staphylococcus aureus. The diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis was made.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was commenced on high-dose intravenous antibiotics  including flucloxacillin and gentamicin  as per the local guidelines for native valve S. aureus endocarditis  with an initial plan for six weeks of therapy.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Three days into his inpatient stay  he developed dyspnea and pulmonary edema due to acute mitral regurgitation. Despite optimal medical therapy including intravenous diuretics  the condition of the patient deteriorated. A multi-disciplinary team approach was agreed for immediate surgery after considering the high surgical risks. Mitral valve repair  including debridement of the infected tissue and vegetations  was performed. The postoperative course was complicated by acute kidney injury requiring temporary hemodialysis  and by hepatocellular injury.   With intense rehabilitation  the patient gradually improved and was discharged home four weeks later. Outpatient follow-up after six months showed the patient has fully physically recovered and returned to his normal activities.  Lessons learned: This case underscores the importance of early diagnosis and prompt treatment of infective endocarditis  which can escalate to life-threatening conditions if left untreated. The management requires a comprehensive evaluation and the combination of medical and surgical approaches in some cases.

Title: A Case Report: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis in an Aging Female with Past History of Atrial Fibrillation and Diabetes Mellitus  Abstract:  This report presents the case of a 75-year-old Caucasian female with a history of atrial fibrillation and type 2 diabetes mellitus who was admitted to the hospital following recurrent episodes of fever and acute onset shortness of breath. Subsequent clinical evaluation resulted in a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Case Presentation:   A 75-year-old Caucasian female came to the emergency department with complaints of recurring fever and extreme shortness of breath for the past 10 days. The patient's medical history revealed atrial fibrillation  for which she was on blood thinners. She also had Type 2 diabetes mellitus  controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents.  Physical examination showed pallor  a respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute  a heart rate of 108 beats per minute  and fever of 38.6 degrees Celsius. Cardiovascular examination revealed a diastolic murmur at the left fifth intercostal space.  Investigations:  A complete blood count showed elevated white cell counts suggestive of infection. Blood cultures were positive for streptococcus viridans. A diagnosis of infective endocarditis was made based on the modified Duke's criteria with 2 major criteria (positive blood cultures and evidence of endocardial involvement on transthoracic echocardiography)  and 1 minor criterion (fever >38°C).   The patient also underwent Chest X-ray  which showed mild pulmonary congestion but no signs of pneumonia. The electrocardiogram (EKG) showed atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.   Management:  The patient was initiated on empiric parenteral antibiotics regimen of vancomycin and gentamicin after confirming the microbial sensitivity. The recurrence of her symptoms despite ongoing treatment prompted the consideration of surgical intervention. After thorough discussion  she was submitted to elective surgery  where an aortic valve replacement was done.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of a thorough clinical evaluation in patients with persistent or recurrent fevers  especially in those with known risk factors such as diabetes mellitus and atrial fibrillation. Timely recognition of native-valve infective endocarditis and prompt initiation of appropriate therapy  with consideration for surgical intervention if necessary  can lead to desirable patient outcomes.  Keywords: Native-valve infective endocarditis  Atrial Fibrillation  Diabetes Mellitus  Case Report.

Title: Case Report on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Female Patient  Patient Information: A 50-year-old Caucasian female presenting to the emergency department   Presentation: The patient presented with a 3-week history of persistent fever (39°C)  chills  malaise  and unintentional weight loss of about 10 pounds over the past month. She also complained of generalized weakness and loss of appetite. She denied having any chest pain  breathlessness  cough  or other respiratory symptoms. No history of any skin rashes  joint pain or swelling. She reported that she had been previously healthy with no known contacts with sick individuals and no recent travel history.  Past Medical History: Upon careful questioning  she admitted to a medical history of type 2 diabetes managed with metformin  hypertension controlled with amlodipine  and a previous dental extraction 5 months ago. She has no known drug allergies. She was a non-smoker and consumed alcohol socially  but not frequently.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed the patient to be oriented to time  place and person with no focal neurological deficits. Mild pallor was noted. Cardiac examination showed irregular heart rhythms with a grade 2/6 systolic heart murmur noted at the left sternal edge with no radiation. No Janeway lesions  Osler’s nodes  splinter hemmorhages or Roth's spots were observed. Rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.    Diagnostic Assessment: Laboratory findings showed elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)  C-reactive protein (CRP)  white blood cell count  and low hemoglobin  consistent with an infection and anemia of chronic disease. Blood culture was positive for Staphylococcus aureus indicative of bacterial infection. Transthoracic echocardiography revealed a large  mobile vegetation on the mitral valve  with mild mitral insufficiency  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. ECG and chest X-ray were normal.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was started on intravenous antibiotics (Vancomycin and Gentamicin) as per the IDSA Guidelines for the Management of Infective Endocarditis. Despite appropriate antibiotic treatment  her condition did not improve significantly and she was referred for surgical intervention. She successfully underwent mitral valve replacement surgery without any complications.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: Postoperative course was uneventful and her symptoms resolved gradually. Six-week follow-up showed stable clinical picture with no signs of infection or heart failure. She was advised on the importance of good oral hygiene and was scheduled for regular follow-up visits.  This case of native-valve infective endocarditis in a patient with significant history highlights the necessity of vigilance and proactive measures post-dental procedures in patients with predisposing factors. Early recognition and aggressive management may greatly reduce morbidity and mortality associated with this disease.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 65-Year-Old Male: A Case Report  Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with a two-week history of progressive shortness of breath  fatigue  low-grade fever  and weight loss of about 12 pounds. The patient also reported nocturnal sweats and intermittent confusion over the same duration. He lives alone and is a retired carpenter. The patient is a nonsmoker and reported no past illicit drug use  recent dental treatment  or surgical procedures.  Past Medical History: The patient's previous medical history was significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  well controlled on oral hypoglycemics. He also had a history of hypertension controlled with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors. The patient was previously diagnosed with left ventricular hypertrophy and there was no past history of heart valves disease or prosthetic implants. He was not on regular use of antiplatelet or anticoagulant. He reported an allergy to penicillin that results in a rash.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  the patient appeared ill and pale. His temperature was 38.2℃  blood pressure of 135/85 mmHg  pulse of 98 beats per minute and regular  and respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. Cardiac examination was notable for a soft pan-systolic murmur over the mitral area without radiation. Chest auscultation revealed crackles in the base of the lungs bilaterally. There were no signs of peripheral stigmata of endocarditis on skin and eye examination. No abnormal findings were seen on the neurological examination.  Diagnostic Assessment: To assess the patient's condition  a complete blood count  chest x-ray  12-lead EKG  electrolyte  renal function test  liver function test were ordered. His leukocyte count was 13 900 per cubic millimeter  hemoglobin 10.2g/dL  and platelets 198 000 per millimeter. The chest X-ray showed slight cardiomegaly and early signs of pulmonary edema. EKG revealed features of left ventricular hypertrophy. Blood cultures were drawn and sent.  Management and Follow-up: Given the clinical suspicion of infective endocarditis  the patient was started empirically on intravenous vancomycin and gentamicin  pending blood culture results. Transthoracic echocardiogram revealed a mitral valve vegetation  confirming the diagnosis of native valve endocarditis. Subsequently  blood cultures showed growth of Streptococcus viridans which was sensitive to vancomycin.  The patient received 4 weeks of intravenous antibiotic treatment  as per Infective Endocarditis Guidelines. He was watched closely for signs of heart failure and embolic complications. Over the course of treatment  his condition improved considerably. Repeat blood cultures showed no growth and echocardiogram showed the resolution of vegetations.  At a 3-month follow-up visit  the patient reported feeling well with no complications. He was advised to maintain good oral hygiene  regular exercise  continuous control of his diabetes mellitus  and hypertension  along with proper care for future procedures to avoid the recurrence of endocarditis.    Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of early diagnosis and management of native-valve infective endocarditis in patients presenting with non-specific symptoms like fever  weight loss  and changes in mental status. It also underscores the need for detailed evaluation for patients with predisposing conditions like diabetes and hypertension  which are well-recognized risk factors for infective endocarditis.

Case Report Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Male; A Case Study  Introduction:  Infective endocarditis (IE) is a rare but severe infection of the endocardial surface of the heart. The condition is life-threatening  necessitating immediate diagnosis and treatment. This case report presents an elderly male patient diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis (IE).  Patient Information: The patient under study is an 82-year-old Caucasian male residing in an urban setting. He is a retired engineer  has a history of smoking but quit around 20 years ago  consumes alcohol moderately and has no known allergies. His familial history reveals hypertension  with his father diagnosed with coronary artery disease.  Medical History: The patient was previously diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus for which metformin had been prescribed. However  his glycemic control was poor. Also  there were occasional episodes of hypertensive emergencies in the last two years  yet he had not been on any anti-hypertension medication. Records showed no known history of intravenous drug abuse or any prior cardiac surgeries.  Presenting Concerns: The patient presented with four weeks history of fevers  night sweats  weight loss of approximately 5Kg  decreased appetite  and increased fatigue. Physical examination demonstrated pallor and presence of a systolic murmur. No petechiae or Osler’s nodes were identified. Neurological exam was non-focal.  Clinical Findings and Diagnostic Assessment: Blood tests revealed anemia and leukocytosis. Blood cultures taken were positive for Streptococcus oralis. Chest X-ray was unremarkable. An electrocardiogram showed normal sinus rhythm with no signs of ischemia or infarction. Echocardiography revealed a large vegetation on the mitral valve with severe regurgitation  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately started on empiric antibiotic therapy with intravenous vancomycin and gentamycin pending blood culture sensitivity. After the culture results  the therapy was adjusted to Penicillin G and Gentamycin for six weeks as per the AHA/ACC guidelines for management of endocarditis caused by viridans group Streptococci.   Follow-Up and Outcome: The patient responded well to the antibiotic therapy. His symptoms gradually improved over the course of the first two weeks  and he was discharged after six weeks of treatment. He was indicated for regular follow-up visits. The patient and his family were educated about the disease  its implications  and the importance of compliance with medication. The hypertension issue was addressed  and treatment initiated to control the blood pressure.  Inclusion in a clinical trial: N/A  Conclusion: IE can be challenging to diagnose due to its insidious onset and non-specific symptoms. A high degree of clinical suspicion is required  especially in patients with risk factors. This case reaffirms the importance of early recognition and treatment of IE  considering the mortality associated with it.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in A Middle-aged Male with Chronic Alcoholism – A Case Report  Patient Profile: The patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian male who is a resident of Phoenix  Arizona. He works as a construction labourer and lives presently with his daughter in a one-bedroom apartment. He has a history of chronic alcoholism  smoking and indigence.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient presented with two weeks of persisting high-grade fever  night sweats  malaise and a loss of appetite. His daughter mentions observing progressive lethargy and confusion in her father over this time.  Past Medical History: The patient has been struggling with alcoholism for about 25 years  drinking approximately 150 mL of whisky daily. He also admits to smoking 1 packet of cigarettes every day for the past 30 years. He had been diagnosed with mild chronic liver disease two years ago  a likely outcome of his heavy alcohol intake. Other than liver disease  his medical history is unremarkable.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the patient displayed symptoms of fever (38.5°C) and mild confusion. A cardiac examination revealed a harsh systolic murmur on the mitral area of the heart  suggestive of mitral regurgitation. A skin examination confirmed Janeway lesions and splinter haemorrhages. There was also evidence of paleness  poor oral hygiene  and poor nutritional status. The liver was mildly enlarged and tender on palpation.  Investigations:  The blood culture was positive for Staphylococcus aureus. An echocardiogram revealed a vegetation on the anterior leaflet of his mitral valve with moderate mitral regurgitation. Biochemical analysis revealed elevated liver enzymes with hypoalbuminemia  indicating worsening of the chronic liver disease. His chest X-ray was within normal limits.  Diagnosis and Management: The patient was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis  secondary to Staphylococcus aureus infection. He was immediately put on a regimen of intravenous antibiotics according to the sensitivity patterns. He further underwent a successful mitral valve replacement surgery.  Post-surgery  the patient engaged with Alcoholics Anonymous and while recovery was initially complicated by his ongoing alcohol addiction  he managed to decrease his intake substantially during the rehabilitation process. He was also referred to a nutritionist for dietary advice.  Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the importance of considering infective endocarditis in any patient with persistent fevers  especially amongst those living in less-than-ideal conditions and those with pre-existing conditions such as chronic alcoholism that can lead to immunosuppression. Prompt diagnosis and intervention along with addressing concomitant social issues were crucial in managing this patient's health condition.

Patient Background: The patient is a 63-year-old Caucasian male residing in suburban New York. He is employed as an accountant. The patient has a history of moderate alcohol use but is a non-smoker and does not use illicit drugs. His medical history reveals he suffers from type II diabetes and hypertension and underwent left knee replacement surgery two years ago. There is no history of any known congenital heart defects  rheumatic heart disease  or any previous heart surgeries.  Presenting symptoms: The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of high-grade fever  fatigue  weight loss  and shortness of breath. The symptoms occurred intermittently for three weeks prior to admission. The fever was associated with chills and night sweats. He also reported a decreased appetite and a weight loss of approximately 8 pounds in this period.  Examination and Diagnosis: Upon physical examination  the patient demonstrated signs of peripheral embolic phenomena  including petechiae in the conjunctiva and oral mucosa  as well as Osler's nodes on the fingers and toes. Cardiac examination revealed a diastolic murmur suggestive of aortic regurgitation.   Blood cultures were done  and after 48 hours  they showed the growth of Streptococcus viridans  indicative of bacterial endocarditis. Transthoracic echocardiography was performed  which revealed large vegetations on the leaflets of the aortic valve  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Management and Course: The patient was started on intravenous treatment with penicillin G and gentamicin in accordance with the hospital's endocarditis treatment guideline. Blood glucose and blood pressure were periodically monitored and managed with appropriate medications.   At the end of 4 weeks of treatment  the symptoms had largely resolved  blood cultures remained negative  and follow-up echocardiography showed significant reduction in vegetations. No complications related to congestive heart failure or systemic emboli were observed during the hospital stay. It was recommended to the patient to have regular follow-ups to monitor his condition.  Conclusion: This case underscores the importance of early recognition and treatment of infective endocarditis in patients presenting with nonspecific symptoms  such as fever and weight loss  particularly in the presence of predisposing factors like diabetes and hypertension.    Comment: Despite being less commonly associated with injective drug use  infective endocarditis caused by Streptococcus viridans involving native valves is not uncommon and remains a significant cause of morbidity and mortality. Awareness  early diagnosis  and prompt effective treatment are crucial for a better prognosis.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Female  Case Report:  A 55-year-old Caucasian female presented to our Department of Cardiology with a one week history of low-grade fever  fatigue  malaise  night sweats  and weight loss. Her past medical history was unremarkable aside from mild hypertension  for which she took Amlodipine 5 mg daily  and occasional migraines.  She was a school teacher by profession  denied any use of tobacco or illicit drugs  and had no known exposure to intravenous drug users. Her family history was significant for coronary artery disease  in her father  who had a myocardial infarction in his late sixties. She did not have a history of any dental procedures or invasive procedures in the last 6 months.  On examination  her blood pressure was slightly elevated at 140/80 mmHg  with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute and a temperature of 38.2°C. Her cardiac examination revealed a diastolic murmur in the aortic area. There were no signs of peripheral stigmata of endocarditis.  Laboratory investigations indicated a raised white cell count of 14 000/µl with a predominance of neutrophils. Her hemoglobin and platelet counts were normal. Significant for elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate at 50 mm/hr and C-reactive protein was 80 mg/L. Blood cultures drawn were positive for Staphylococcus aureus. An echocardiogram revealed vegetations on the patient’s native aortic valve  and mild aortic regurgitation.  Given the patient's clinical manifestations  the vegetations detected on the aortic valve in the echocardiography  and the positive blood cultures for Staphylococcus aureus  we diagnosed the patient with native-valve infective endocarditis.  She was immediately started on an empiric antibiotic therapy with IV Vancomycin and Ceftriaxone. She was hospitalized and monitored for any signs of congestive heart failure  embolic events  and arrhythmias.   Discussion:   This case highlights that a diagnosis of infective endocarditis  albeit an uncommon condition  should be entertained in patients presenting with consistent clinical signs and symptoms even in the absence of known risk factors such as intravascular device  immunosuppression  recent dental or invasive procedures. Early diagnosis and prompt treatment are essential in the management to prevent severe complications like cardiac failure  embolic events  or even death.  This case also emphasizes the need for clinicians to always consider the possibility of a native-valve endocarditis in patients presenting with fever and other constitutional symptoms  even in those with a seemingly innocuous medical history. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate management are paramount to reduce morbidity and mortality associated with this potentially lethal condition.

Title: Infective Endocarditis in a Native-Valve Setting: A Case Report   Patient Information:  The patient was a 67-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the hospital with a three-week history of persisting fever and weakness. He was a retired engineer  non-smoker  had occasional alcohol intake and was active in community fundraising activities. He was married and had two children. He had no known drug allergies.  The patient had a past medical history of hypertension  for which he had been taking an ACE inhibitor and beta-blocker for six years. He had type-2 diabetes mellitus  controlled with metformin for five years. He also had a history of severe Diverticulosis five years ago that was managed conservatively with dietary modifications. He had no known history of heart disease or any other significant illness.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed a fever of 38.5 degrees Celsius  blood pressure of 135/80 mmHg  a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  and heart rate of 100 beats per minute. Clinical cardiac examination showed a grade III/VI holistic pansystolic murmur best heard at the apex. There were no signs of peripheral stigmata of infective endocarditis (IE).   Diagnostic Assessment:  Complete blood count showed raised levels of leukocytes suggestive of an infectious process. Blood cultures were drawn and repeated after 12 hours. While awaited the culture result  the patient underwent an echocardiographic examination  which revealed large echogenic masses attached to the mitral valve  consistent with vegetations in native valves  supporting a diagnosis of native valve IE.   The patient’s blood culture confirmed the presence of Streptococcus agalactiae sensitive to Penicillin and Amoxicillin.   Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was started on intravenous Amoxicillin as per sensitivity results. Alongside  he continued to take his antihypertensive medications and metformin for his underlying conditions.  Follow-Up and Outcomes:  The patient responded well to treatment; his symptoms improved significantly over the following week  and follow-up blood cultures showed no growth. A follow-up echocardiography after four weeks showed a significant reduction in vegetation size.   Conclusion:  Native valve infective endocarditis  though less common than prosthetic valve IE  can present without overt clinical signs. High clinical suspicion  swift diagnosis with echocardiography  and timely management can result in successful patient outcomes.

Case Report: Patient X  Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Introduction:  Patient X is a 52-year-old male of Caucasian descent presenting to the cardiology clinic with signs of systemic infection and a new murmur.   Patient History:  The patient's past medical history reveals that he is a non-smoker  with moderate alcohol consumption habits. He has well-controlled Type II diabetes mellitus  for which he takes Metformin  and suffers from hyperlipidemia  which is managed with Atorvastatin. There is also a history of hypertension  treated with Lisinopril.   The patient has a prior history of gout  which flares up occasionally  but is generally controlled with Colchicine. There are no previously noted cardiac abnormalities. He has no known drug allergies and familial risk factors include his paternal history indicating myocardial infarction  a brother with early-onset diabetes  and an older sister who passed due to stroke.  Presenting Complications:  Upon arrival  the patient complained of heart palpitations  night sweats  fever  and shortness of breath for the past two weeks. He expressed considerable weight loss (8 lbs in two weeks) amid loss of appetite and also indicated intermittent low-grade fever. Physical examination revealed an ill-appearing male patient with oral temperature of 100.2°F  blood pressure of 120/78 mm Hg  pulse rate of 101 bpm  and sporadic heart murmur.   Investigative Actions:  Suspecting infective endocarditis (IE)  the attending physician ordered a two-dimensional transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) and blood cultures. Interim blood work showed neutrophil-predominant leukocytosis and mildly elevated creatinine level (1.4 mg/dL) suggesting possible acute kidney injury secondary to systemic infection. Other lab values included elevated ESR and CRP  suggesting an inflammatory process.   The TTE revealed the presence of vegetations on the native mitral valve leading to mild mitral insufficiency  and blood cultures were positive for Staphylococcus aureus  consistent with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Management:  The patient was admitted to the hospital for further management and began empiric antibiotic therapy. In light of severity of the infection and ongoing systemic symptoms  the patient was started on intravenous treatment with Oxacillin and Gentamicin. Cardiac surgery was consulted regarding possible valve replacement.  Outcome:  After a total of six weeks of inpatient treatment  the patient's infection showed considerable improvement. Symptoms including fever  night sweats and palpitations had greatly subsided. Follow-up TTE revealed decreased vegetation size. Post-treatment labs showed adequate kidney function and the patient was discharged on a course of oral antibiotics. The cardiac surgery team recommended continued monitoring of the mitral valve without immediate need for surgical intervention.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the requirement for high clinical suspicion for native-valve IE in patients with new-onset heart murmurs combined with systemic signs of infection. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate management with antibiotic therapy can yield positive outcomes  even in high-risk patients with comorbidities.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Adolescent Female: A Case Report  Introduction: Infective endocarditis is an infection of the endocardial layer of the heart which commonly involves the heart valves. Here  we present a case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis (IE) in a previously healthy adolescent female.   Case Presentation: The patient is a 15-year-old Hispanic female with no significant past medical history  who initially presented to the emergency department with a high-grade fever of 39.4 degrees Celsius (103°F)  malaise  and generalized fatigue of a week's duration.  The patient denied nausea  vomiting  chest pain  difficulty in breathing  or any urinary or bowel complaints. No history of illicit drug use was reported. Family history was non-contributory with no history of rheumatic heart disease or any congenital heart abnormalities. Prior to the onset of her symptoms  she was a high school student with good academic standing and was particularly active in sports.   On physical examination  the patient appeared ill and was in moderate distress due to fever. Examination of the cardiovascular system revealed a grade III/VI systolic murmur in the mitral region. No conjunctival pallor  peripheral stigmata of infective endocarditis  or other systemic findings related to vasculitis were found. Initial vital signs showed tachycardia and low-grade fever which prompted further investigations.  Investigations: Lab reports showed a negative rheumatoid factor and antinuclear antibody. However  there was a significant elevation in Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (74 mm/hr) and C reactive protein (90 mg/L). Blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus  confirming a bacterial infection.  A Transthoracic Echocardiography (TTE) was performed which indicated vegetations on the mitral valve  indicating Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis (IE). The patient was further investigated with Chest X-ray and EKG  which revealed no abnormalities.  Treatment/Management: The patient was started on empiric therapy with Vancomycin and Gentamycin. Upon the identification of Staphylococcus aureus from blood cultures  therapy was deescalated and the patient was switched to a regimen of Nafcillin and Gentamycin.   The patient responded well to treatment with the resolution of her symptoms. On serial echocardiograms  the vegetations on the mitral valve were seen to be resolving. She was then discharged after 4 weeks with oral antibiotics  and a follow-up appointment in the outpatient department.  Discussion: This case emphasizes the importance of maintaining high clinical suspicion for Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in febrile patients with cardiovascular signs  even in the absence of predisposing heart conditions or risk factors. Timely diagnosis and treatment were pivotal in the successful outcome achieved for this patient.  Conclusions: Infective endocarditis  although rare  can occur in healthy adolescents. High clinical suspicion and early intervention play a key role in management and result in better patient outcomes.

Case Report:  Patient Information: A 57-year-old Caucasian male presented to the outpatient clinic in Nevada with a two-week history of intermittent fever  night sweats  fatigue  five-kilogram unintentional weight loss and generalized weakness.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  he was alert and cooperative but appeared pale and fatigued. He was febrile (38.5°C)  heart rate was 100 beats/minute  blood pressure was 130/85 mmHg  and his respiratory rate was 18 breaths/minute. Cardiac examination revealed a new systolic murmur. The rest of the clinical examination was unremarkable.  Medical  Family  and Psychosocial History: The patient had a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  moderate hypertension  and dyslipidemia. His medications included metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. His parents had a history of coronary artery disease  and his older sister had type 2 diabetes mellitus. He had a 20-pack-year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. He does not consume alcohol or use illicit substances.  Diagnostic Procedures: Laboratory studies showed a white blood cell count of 12 000/uL (normal: 4 000-10 000/uL)  C-reactive protein of 25 mg/dL (normal: 0-5 mg/dL)  and erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 70 mm/hr (normal: 0-22 mm/hr). Blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus. Echocardiogram demonstrated vegetations on the mitral valve and moderate mitral regurgitation. These findings confirmed the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient received intravenous cefazolin for six weeks. His clinical status improved remarkably during hospitalization. The fever subsided  and he gained weight progressively. Laboratory findings normalized over the course of treatment. Serial echocardiograms demonstrated a decrease in the size of the vegetations.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Blood culture at the end of treatment was negative. His condition stabilized  and he was discharged for outpatient follow-ups. Over a five-month period  he remained symptom-free  indicating infection control.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed relief and gratitude for the treatment he received. He pledged to adopt a healthier lifestyle to better manage his chronic diseases.  This case emphasizes the importance of early recognition and aggressive management of infective endocarditis. Particularly  patients with chronic conditions such as diabetes and hypertension  which increases their susceptibility to infections  should be appropriately educated about the signs and symptoms of severe infectious diseases.

Patient Information  Name: Confidential  Gender: Male Age: 53 years old Occupity: Accountant Residential Area: Urban Ethnicity: Asian-American  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented to the hospital with symptoms of fever  fatigue  and shortness of breath that had been persisting for the past two weeks.  Medical History:  The patient has Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for approximately 15 years  controlled with metformin and sitagliptin. In addition  he was diagnosed with essential hypertension 10 years ago  which is managed with amlodipine  hydrochlorothiazide  and losartan. Previous health screening records reveal an occasional smoking history  but no significant alcohol or illicit drug use.  He underwent dental cleaning two weeks prior to the onset of his symptoms. His immunization records are up-to-date. He doesn’t have any known allergies  and there is no significant family history of heart disease or infectious diseases.  Examination:  On physical examination  the patient had a fever of 38.3°C  pulse rate of 100 beats per minute  and blood pressure of 110/70 mmHg. Cardiac examination revealed a new systolic murmur. The patient appeared fatigued and displayed signs of pallor. He was tachypneic  with respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute but oxygen saturation was normal (98% on room air).  Investigation and Diagnosis:  Laboratory studies showed leucocytosis and mild anemia. Blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus Viridans. An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed atrial fibrillation without any significant ST-T changes. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) revealed a mobile  echogenic mass on the mitral valve consistent with a vegetation  along with mild to moderate mitral regurgitation  suggestive of native valve infective endocarditis.  The diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis was confirmed based on these investigations  and the patient was started on appropriate antibiotics. The clinical course was complicated by embolic stroke but was managed successfully with continued antibiotics and no neurological sequelae. After completing the antibiotic course  the patient's condition improved significantly  and he was discharged.  Conclusion:  This case serves as a reminder that early recognition and treatment of infective endocarditis are crucial  especially in patients with predisposing factors such as diabetes and recent dental procedures. Regular health screening  careful reviewing of symptoms  and history taking play an essential role in the management of such cases.

Title: Native Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 65-year-old Male  Patient Information:  Mr. J  a 65-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaint:  Fever and malaise  History of Present Illness: The patient has been experiencing subjective fevers  chills  generalized malaise  and unexplained weight loss for the past month. He was seen by an internist three weeks ago and prescribed anti-pyretics  but the symptoms persisted.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of Diabetes Mellitus type-II controlled on Metformin. He is a former smoker with a 30-pack year history  but quit smoking five years ago. His family history includes hypertension  stroke  and coronary artery disease. He denies any known drug allergies and does not consume alcohol.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  the patient was febrile with a temperature of 38.9 degrees Celsius. His pulse rate was slightly tachycardic (110 beats per minute)  blood pressure registered at 130/85 mmHg  and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. He had evident peripheral stigmata of endocarditis  including Osler nodes on his fingers. Cardiac examination detected a regurgitant murmur best appreciated at the left lower sternal border.  Diagnostic Assessment: Initial laboratory testing revealed leukocytosis with left shift and normocytic anemia. Blood cultures were drawn and subsequently showed Gram-positive cocci. An echocardiogram was performed revealing vegetation on the aortic valve consistent with infective endocarditis.  Treatment: After consulting with Infectious Disease specialists  the patient was started on empiric therapy of intravenous Vancomycin pending further blood culture results. He was also placed on Atenolol to control heart rate. Strict blood sugar control was emphasized given his diabetes  and Metformin dose was adjusted.  Follow Up and Outcome: The patient responded well to treatment; within a few days  his fever subsided and he began to feel better overall. Five days into treatment  blood cultures returned positive for Streptococcus viridans. Therefore  the patient was treated with a tailored  definitive antibiotic regimen including four weeks of IV Ceftriaxone. His follow-up echocardiogram showed reduction in the size of the vegetation over time. The patient was discharged after four weeks with arrangements for outpatient care and follow-up to monitor his recovery.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of considering infective endocarditis in the differential diagnosis of a persistently febrile patient with cardiac murmurs. Prognosis can be dramatically improved with a thorough diagnostic evaluation and prompt  aggressive antimicrobial therapy. It also emphasizes the foundational role of the history and physical examination in guiding further workup and treatment.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 68-year-old Male with a History of Diabetes Type 2 and Bicuspid Aortic Valve   Patient Demographics:  Mr. X is a 68-year-old Caucasian male residing in Seattle  Washington. He is a retired factory worker and nonsmoker. He consumes alcohol occasionally  once a month approximately. He is married with two children and three grandchildren.   Past Medical History:  Mr. X has a known history of Diabetes Type 2 for the past 10 years well controlled on Metformin. He is also diagnosed with a bicuspid aortic valve 5 years ago which was discovered incidentally during an echocardiogram that was done to investigate a heart murmur. He has no history of rheumatic heart disease  congenital heart defects  previous valve surgery  or any intravenous drug misuse. He had undergone a cholecystectomy approximately 20 years ago. His family history is significant with a father who had ischemic heart disease and a mother with hypertension.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. X was admitted to the hospital with a 2 weeks history of sudden weight loss  fatigue  loss of appetite  fever  and night sweats.  Case Progress:  On examination  he was found to have a high-grade fever  pulse rate 92/min  blood pressure of 152/90 mmHg. He exhibited signs of congestive heart failure such as mild peripheral edema  increased jugular venous pressure  and a new Grade 3 diastolic murmur was noted on cardiac auscultation. Blood tests showed leukocytosis  increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate  and C-reactive protein. His HbA1c was within normal limits showing good diabetic control.  Echocardiography showed large vegetation on the aortic valve highly suggestive of endocarditis. Three sets of blood cultures were obtained before initiating antibiotics and were positive for Staphylococcus aureus  further confirming the diagnosis of infective endocarditis.     Treatment and Follow up:  Mr. X was started on intravenous antibiotic treatment as per the infective endocarditis regimen  which included Vancomycin and Gentamycin. Over the course of two weeks  Mr. X’s condition improved significantly with a reduction in fever  and normalization of inflammatory markers.   He was discharged with 4 more weeks of intravenous antibiotic regimen with daily nurse visits for PICC line care and weekly lab work for blood cultures and full blood counts. A follow-up care plan included regular echocardiograms and consultation with the cardiothoracic surgeon for possible future aortic valve replacement.   Conclusion:  This case emphasises the importance of considering a diagnosis of infective endocarditis in patients with a history of valvular heart disease presenting with symptoms such as fever  weight loss  and signs of congestive heart failure. Given Mr. X's prompt diagnosis and early initiation of appropriate antimicrobial therapy  the outcome was successful.

Title: A Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 45-year-old Female  Patient Profile: A 45-year-old African American female was brought to the emergency department with complaints of fever  malaise  and shortness of breath. She lives in rural Virginia and works as an office clerk. The patient is an ex-smoker who quit smoking 10 years ago and non-alcoholic. She has no known drug allergies.   Past Medical History: The patient has been previously diagnosed with Diabetes Mellitus type II  which she manages with Metformin. She also has a history of Hypertension controlled with Lisinopril. There is no past history of valve disease or Rheumatic heart disease. She has no history of IV drug use. Family history is significant for Coronary Artery Disease (father  deceased at 65 yrs) and Hypertension (mother  70 yrs  alive).  Presenting Complaints: The patient expressed a history of fever for the past one week  breathing discomfort  a rapid weight loss  and increased fatigue. She also complained about experiencing mild chest pain for the last couple of days.   Examination Highlights: On examination  her vitals were stable except for fever (100.8°F). Cardiac auscultation revealed a diastolic murmur noted at the left sternal edge. Skin was pale with petechiae noted on the lower limbs. There were no peripheral stigmata of endocarditis noted.   Investigations: Blood tests showed elevated white cell counts (15000 cells/μL) and raised C-reactive protein levels. Her HbA1c was 7.8%  and random blood glucose was 200 mg/dl. The ECG showed normal sinus rhythm with no ST or T wave changes. Chest X-ray was normal. Two sets of blood cultures were sent and both came back positive for Streptococcus viridans. Transthoracic echocardiography revealed vegetations on the mitral valve consistent with infective endocarditis.   Conclusion: Based on clinical presentation and investigation findings  a final diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis was made. The patient was commenced on IV antibiotics with Penicillin G and Gentamicin according to the culture and sensitivity report. Subsequent blood cultures were cleared after 2 weeks of therapy. She was also referred to the cardiothoracic team for consideration of valve repair or replacement surgery.   Her diabetes and hypertension were managed with adjusted doses of her regular medications. Through multidisciplinary team management  the patient recovered well and was discharged with follow-up appointments scheduled to closely monitor her heart condition.   This case highlights the importance of considering native-valve infective endocarditis in patients presenting with non-specific symptoms such as fever  weight loss  and increasing fatigue  especially in the backdrop of a significant cardiac auscultation finding. Prompt diagnosis  early antibiotic intervention  and regular follow-ups can lead to a positive outcome.

Title: A Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Patient with a History of Intravenous Drug Use  Background: Infective endocarditis (IE) is a rare but life-threatening infection of the endocardial surface of the heart. It predominantly affects individuals with pre-existing heart diseases  specifically valve diseases  or those who inject drugs. This case report presents the history  clinical manifestations  diagnosis  treatment  and prognosis of a patient with native-valve IE.  Case Presentation:  Mr. X  a 50-year-old Caucasian male  was referred to our emergency department with severe shortness of breath  intermittent fever  weakness  and unexplained weight loss for the past month. He was a chronic smoker and reported history of intravenous drug use  mainly heroin  but has been abstinent for the past five years.  On examination  his blood pressure was 110/70 mm Hg  heart rate 102 bpm  respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 94% on room air. Cardiac examination revealed a murmur suggestive of aortic regurgitation. No peripheral stigmata of IE were noticed.  Investigations:  We proceeded with transthoracic echocardiography which showed an oscillating intracardiac mass on a native cardiac valve  supporting the diagnosis of IE. Our suspicions were strengthened by the presence of one of the Duke's major criteria (positive echo) and two of the minor criteria (fever and predisposing heart condition or use of intravenous drug use).  Blood cultures were collected and sent to the lab. They grew methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus. The septic screen was positive  and the WBC count  ESR  and CRP were also elevated  indicating ongoing systemic infection.  Management:  Immediately after aerobic blood culture results were available  the patient was started on intravenous Nafcillin as per the guidelines. Along with medical management  the patient was assessed and monitored for any indication for surgical interventions. He was also referred to a specialized drug rehabilitation center for relapse prevention and psychological support.  Outcome and Follow-up:  The patient showed significant progress over the course of two weeks with reduction in fever  breathlessness  and general symptoms. After six weeks of antibiotic therapy  a follow-up transthoracic echocardiogram was performed  showing complete resolution of the vegetation. He was further advised for rigorous follow-up  healthy lifestyle changes  and cessation of smoking.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of in-depth understanding and suspicion of IE in patients with compatible clinical symptoms and history of intravenous drug use. Timely diagnosis and prompt intervention can significantly improve the prognosis in such patients. A multidisciplinary approach involving cardiology  infectious diseases  and addiction medicine departments is crucial in managing these patients.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-aged Male: A Case Report  Introduction:  This case report describes a 57-year-old male patient who presented to the emergency department with symptoms suggestive of infective endocarditis affecting his native valves.  Patient Information:  The patient is a Caucasian male  57-year-old  who is a non-smoker and moderate alcohol consumer. He works as a construction engineer and has no history of illicit drug use. His past medical history includes controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he has been taking antihypertensive (angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors) and statin medications respectively. There is no familial history of heart disease. He has no history of allergy or immunodeficiency  and he is up-to-date with his immunizations. There is no recent history of dental procedures or surgeries.  Clinical Findings:  The patient complained of flu-like symptoms including low-grade fever  fatigue  night sweats  muscle discomfort  and unexplained weight loss for the past three weeks. He also reported experiencing chest discomfort  breathlessness  and a new heart murmur was noticed  which had not been recorded in his previous health checks.  Diagnostic Assessment:  A series of investigations were conducted  including blood tests  which revealed elevated inflammatory markers (ESR and CRP). Blood culture was positive for Staphylococcus aureus  confirming our suspicion for infective endocarditis. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was performed  which demonstrated vegetations on the patient's native aortic valves confirming native valve endocarditis. Subsequent transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) was performed to assess the severity and involvement of other cardiac structures.  Pathological Findings:  Gross pathological findings revealed large vegetations on the leaflets of the aortic valve. The valve was thickened and showed signs of severe inflammation  consistent with bacterial endocarditis caused by Staphylococcus aureus.  Treatment:  The patient was immediately started on intravenous antibiotic therapy with flucloxacillin  following standard treatment protocols for native-valve infective endocarditis caused by Methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus.  Outcome and Follow-up:  There was significant improvement in the patient's symptoms after two weeks of antibiotic therapy. Repeated cultures revealed no growth  indicating the successful eradication of bacteria. However  due to the substantial damage to the aortic valve  the patient was referred for valve replacement surgery. Post-surgery  the patient demonstrated remission of symptoms and complete recovery in the cardiac function. Follow-ups six months after discharge showed no recurrence of infective endocarditis.   Discussion:  This case highlights the importance of early diagnosis and prompt treatment of infective endocarditis. It underlines the need for high clinical suspicion in patients presenting with persistent flu-like symptoms and new heart murmurs  specifically in patients with prior cardiac conditions. Further  it emphasizes the importance of comprehensive management  including antibiotic therapy and  if necessary  surgical intervention to achieve optimal patient outcomes.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 60-year-old Male with a History of Intravenous Drug Use: A Case Report  Patient Information and Clinical Findings: The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male presented with flu-like symptoms. His main complaints were a two-week history of persistent fever  rigors  malaise  night sweats  anorexia  and weight loss. From the physical examination  the patient was found to be febrile (temperature recorded at 38.8℃) and tachycardic with mild tachypnea. Examination revealed a diastolic murmur on the left side of the sternal edge suggesting possible aortic regurgitation. No peripheral signs of endocarditis were noted.  Medical  Family  and Social History: The patient's past medical history included fibromyalgia and hepatitis C (presumed secondary to past intravenous drug use)  for which he was receiving non-interferon-based antiviral therapy. The patient had a history of psychiatric illness with multiple depressive episodes and had undergone treatment for opioid addiction. He had been abstinent from all substances for the past 10 years. Ethnicity and family history were unremarkable for cardiac or metabolic disease. The patient lived alone and had been unemployed for many years.  Diagnostic Assessment: Blood cultures were subsequently drawn  which isolated Staphylococcus aureus. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) revealed aortic valve endocarditis with severe aortic regurgitation and relatively preserved left ventricular function. These findings were confirmed with a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE)  which also demonstrated a large oscillating aortic vegetation.  Therapeutic Interventions:  The patient was started on intravenous cefazolin and gentamicin for empirical treatment  which was narrowed to targeted therapy with intravenous cefazolin upon blood culture results. The patient underwent an aortic valve replacement  which confirmed an infected  destructed native aortic valve.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: Postoperative recovery was uneventful. The patient was discharged after 2 weeks of hospital stay with oral antibiotics for 4 weeks. Three months later  the patient was noted to have marked clinical improvement and continued to remain substance-free. Repeat echocardiogram showed a well-functioning prosthetic aortic valve with no residual regurgitation.  Patient Perspective: ""I never realized that my past could catch up with me like this. It was a wake-up call  and it scares me  but at the same time  it has strengthened my resolve to remain clean and sober.""  This case illustrates the potential for severe sequelae of intravenous drug use  demonstrating both the typical pathogen and the more unusual presentation in the aortic rather than the tricuspid valve. It underscores the importance of a comprehensive physical examination and history taking  as well as the need to consider infective endocarditis in patients with past intravenous drug use presenting with persistent fever and a new cardiac murmur.

Case Report  Patient Information Mr. AB  a 45-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with a one-week history of persistent high-grade fever associated with chills  night sweats  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss. The patient also reported experiencing a dull  aching chest discomfort and shortness of breath  more so with exertion.  Medical History Mr. AB has a past medical history of type II diabetes mellitus  which has been under fairly good control with Metformin for the past six years. He was also diagnosed with Rheumatic Fever at the age of 12  which caused him mild mitral valve regurgitation. The patient also has a history of chronic lower back pain treated with NSAIDs. He denies any smoking  alcohol  or illicit drug usage  and he is currently unemployed.  Clinical Findings Upon presentation  Mr. AB was febrile with a temperature of 101.3 °F (38.5 °C). Cardiac examination revealed a grade III/IV systolic murmur best heard over the left sternal border. Blood pressure was 134/86 mmHg  pulse rate 96 bpm  and respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute. An initial physical exam indicated paleness of the skin (possibly suggestive of anemia)  splenomegaly  and petechiae on his extremities.  Diagnostic Assessment  An immediate complete blood count showed leukocytosis (WBC: 17 500 per dL) and anemia (Hemoglobin: 9.3 g/dL). The erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) was elevated at 100 mm/hr  and CRP also elevated at 15 mg/dL  indicating infection or inflammation in the body. Blood cultures were drawn immediately and sent for analysis. A transthoracic echocardiogram was ordered  revealing thickened and vegetated mitral valve leaflets  indicative of infective endocarditis. Blood cultures returned positive after 48 hours for Streptococcus viridans.  Therapeutic Intervention Mr. AB was put on intravenous antibiotics (Penicillin G)  based on culture sensitivity results under the Infectious Disease team's guidance. He also received supplementary treatments to manage his symptoms  including antipyretics for the fever.  Follow-Up and Outcomes The patient responded well to the therapy with significant improvement in his symptoms over two weeks. His repeat blood cultures after two weeks turned out negative. The patient was discharged with instructions for a six-week course of IV Penicillin G. He was advised regular follow-ups and monitoring with the Cardiology and Infectious Disease departments  with emphasis on strict diabetes control and good oral hygiene.  Patient Perspective Mr. AB expressed relief about the improvement of his symptoms and pledged to follow his treatment regimen and scheduled medical visits seriously.  Informed Consent Informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Diabetic Patient  Case Presentation:  The patient is a 75-year-old Caucasian male  living in Oregon  United States  who was admitted to the hospital complaining of recurrent fever  fatigue  and shortness of breath over the last two weeks. He has experienced significant weight loss over the past month  despite no alteration in his diet.   Medical History:  The patient's medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes  managed with metformin and a dietary regimen. He was diagnosed with diabetes twenty years ago. Hypertension and hyperlipidemia are also part of his medical history  controlled by hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin  respectively. He has no known family history of cardiovascular diseases. One year ago  he quit smoking  having smoked one pack per day for the past 40 years. He lives independently  doesn't drink alcohol  and has no known drug allergies.  Clinical Findings:  On clinical examination  he was found to be febrile (38.5°C)  with a pulse rate of 96 beats/minute  blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg  respiratory rate of 20 breaths/minute  and SpO2 of 92% in room air. Cardiac examination revealed a new murmur  suggestive of aortic regurgitation. Blood tests showed elevated inflammatory markers including ESR and CRP. Blood cultures came back positive for Staphylococcus aureus.  Diagnostic Assessment:  The diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis was confirmed with transesophageal echocardiography  which showed a predominant vegetation on the aortic valve leaflet. His glomerular filtration rate was below the normal value  indicating compromised renal function.  Therapeutic Intervention:  He was started on empiric antibiotic therapy with vancomycin and ceftriaxone as per IDSA guidelines  pending culture sensitivity results. His blood sugar was optimally controlled to avoid any further risk. Given his age and comorbidities  the cardiothoracic team recommended against surgical intervention at this stage.  Outcome and Follow-up:  The patient's symptoms improved significantly over the course of two weeks. His renal function tests improved  but did not return to fully normal. Given the nature of his bacteremia and resulting endocarditis  a prolonged course of antibiotics was continued for six weeks. The patient was discharged with close follow-up instructions for cardiology  infectious disease  and primary care.   Conclusion:  This case illustrates the importance of early recognition and prompt management of infective endocarditis  particularly in patients with risk factors such as diabetes. It underscores the role of long-term antibiotic therapy  optimal control of comorbid conditions  and careful follow-up in these complex patients. It also stresses the need for healthcare providers to keep a high index of suspicion among elderly patients presenting with nonspecific symptoms like fever and fatigue.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Female Patient: A Case Report  Case Summary:  The patient is a 55-year-old Caucasian female presented to the emergency department with fever  chills  malaise  and a new-onset murmur. The patient complained of having lost significant weight over the past month  having a poor appetite  and general weakness. She showed no signs of rheumatic diseases or illicit drug use. Her medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  which she manages with medication and diet. She had no known allergies and denied smoking  alcohol  or illicit drug use.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed a systolic murmur  and she was febrile (38.4 °C). A series of blood tests showed elevated inflammatory markers including ESR and C-reactive protein  leukocytosis  and normocytic normochromic anemia. Blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus viridans in multiple sets.  Diagnosis:  With the clinical context of persistent fevers  weight loss  and evidence of persistent bacteremia in blood cultures  a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis was highly suspected. This was confirmed by a transesophageal echocardiogram which showed a large vegetation on the mitral valve  mitral regurgitation  and no intracardiac abscess.   Treatment:  The patient was started on intravenous Penicillin G in combination with Gentamicin  according to the current guidelines for Streptococcus viridans endocarditis. She responded well and her fever gradually subsided.  Outcome & Follow-Up:  She made a clinical recovery and was safely discharged 6 weeks after her treatments ended  with instructions for a follow-up consultation with a cardiologist and infectious diseases specialist. Surveillance echocardiograms were proposed for the next year to ensure resolution of the vegetation.   Conclusion:  This case report highlights the importance of high clinical suspicion of infective endocarditis in patients presenting with unexplained fever  weight loss  and new-onset murmur  even in the absence of risk factors. Properly managed  patients can show good clinical progress despite the serious nature of this condition.  Author: A Medical Profession Institution: (Your Institution) Date: (Today's Date)

Patient Information  Initials: T.J. Age: 67 years old  Sex: Male Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired   Chief Complaint  The patient presented with fatigue  fever  and night sweats inflicted for two weeks.  History of Present Illness  T.J. reported an onset of intermittent  low-grade fever four weeks ago which has been consistent for the past two weeks. He also described general weakness and fatigue  night sweats  and a weight loss of approximately 10 lbs during this same period. He denied experiencing any cough  chest pain  or difficulty in breathing.   Past Medical History  T.J. has a medical history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus managed for the past 10 years  and hypertension controlled with medication for eight years. He also faced an incident of deep vein thrombosis five years ago. He has a 20-year history of smoking but quit two years ago. There is no record of illicit drug use or blood transfusion. He has no known drug allergies.  Examination and Tests  On physical examination  T.J. appeared pale and fatigued. His blood pressure was 140/90 mmHg  and his pulse rate was irregular at 110 bpm. He had a fever of 38.5°C (101.3°F). Cardiac auscultation revealed a new systolic murmur. An oral exam showed poor dental hygiene with some evidence of dental caries but no obvious abscesses.   Laboratory tests reported a White Blood Cell count of 13 000/uL indicative of an infection. His Hemoglobin level was 10.8 g/dL  further confirming the paleness and fatigue symptom due to mild anemia. The patient's renal function was mildly impaired (Creatinine: 1.7 mg/dL; reference: 0.7-1.3 mg/dL).   Blood cultures were collected  and after 48 hours of incubation  they revealed the presence of Streptococcus viridans - a common bacterial cause of native-valve endocarditis. ECG showed signs of atrial fibrillation but didn't show any ischemic changes. An echocardiogram confirmed a mobile vegetation on the mitral valve consistent with endocarditis.  Summary  Given the patient's symptoms  medical history  and investigation results  T.J. was diagnosed with subacute native valve infective endocarditis (IE). The presence of Streptococcus viridans in the blood culture  dental caries  the murmur found on a cardiac exam  and finally  the vegetation on the mitral valve displayed via echocardiogram led to this diagnosis. Antibiotic therapy course was started immediately  with follow-up echocardiograms scheduled to monitor progress and any needed valve repair/replacement procedure.

Title: Immediate identification and management of Native-valve Infective Endocarditis: A Case Report  Introduction:  Native valve endocarditis is an inflammatory reaction within the heart involving the native valves and often characterized by the presence of vegetations. It is typically caused by infection with various bacteria  but occasionally  viral  fungal  and protozoal agents may also be responsible.  Case Presentation:  A 65-year-old African-American male  with a known history of type-II diabetes mellitus managed with metformin  presented to the emergency department complaining of persistent fever  chills  malaise  and an unintentional weight loss of approximately 5 kilograms over the last two months. The patient also has a 10-year history of hypertension  which is controlled with amlodipine and atenolol.  Detailed physical examination revealed the presence of Roth’s spots  Osler's nodes  and Janeway lesions. A grade III diastolic murmur was heard over the aortic valve region. No previous history of valvular heart disease  congenital heart disease  or intravenous drug use was noted. The patient also denied having any dental procedures in the recent past.  Investigations:  Laboratory tests revealed leukocytosis  elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate  and C-reactive protein levels. Blood cultures were positive for Staphylococcus aureus. A transthoracic echocardiogram showed thickened aortic valve leaflets with mobile echo-dense vegetations on the aortic valve  suggestive of infective endocarditis. The patient was immediately admitted to the cardiology service.  Treatment:  The patient was empirically started on intravenous vancomycin and ceftriaxone based on the suspected presence of S. aureus. After blood culture and sensitivity results  the regimen was revised to nafcillin and gentamicin. His fever subsided after three days of antibiotics initiation.   Outcome and Follow-up:  The patient responded well to the therapy  causing the resolution of his symptoms over the next week. He completed 4 weeks of antibiotic therapy. At the 8-week follow-up after discharge  the patient remained asymptomatic. Repeat echocardiogram at this visit showed no evidence of residual vegetations or valvular dysfunction.  Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the importance of recognizing the classical triad of fever  heart murmur  and vascular phenomena associated with infective endocarditis for early diagnosis. Physicians should be aware of the potential for S. aureus bacteremia  especially in patients with a history of diabetes mellitus. Early detection with prompt appropriate antimicrobial therapy can prevent serious complications  reduce morbidity and mortality  and improve patient outcomes.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 58-Year-Old Caucasian Female   Introduction:  Infective Endocarditis (IE) is a serious infection of the inner layer of the heart  often affecting the heart valves. This report presents a case of a 58-year-old Caucasian female diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE).  Case Presentation:  The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian female  presenting with a two-week history of general malaise  low-grade fevers  intermittent chills  and unintentional weight loss of around 5kg over a month. She has been a non-smoker and reports moderate alcohol intake. She lives in a suburban community and is a school teacher by occupation. She has a pet cat at home but denies any scratches or bites.   Her past medical history includes well-controlled hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  for which she takes Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively. Both her parents had cardiovascular disease; her father passed away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 65  and her mother has been living with chronic heart failure.   On examination  she appeared fatigued with a slight pallor. Her vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg  heart rate of 90 bpm  respiratory rate of 18 per minute  and a temperature of 38.1-degree Celsius. Cardiac auscultation revealed a new-onset grade 4/6 systolic murmur. A full neurological examination was normal  ocular examination showed no Roth spots  and there was no splenomegaly. Further examination revealed two painless erythematous nodules on her palms and soles  consistent with Janeway lesions.   Investigations:  Complete blood count showed Hemoglobin of 10.2 g/dl  WBC count of 13.6 x10^3 /µL with 85% neutrophils. The inflammatory markers were raised with ESR of 68 mm/hr and CRP of 180 mg/L. Three sets of blood cultures were taken which later grew Staphylococcus aureus. Transthoracic echocardiography confirmed a large mobile vegetation on the mitral valve with moderate mitral regurgitation.  Treatment and Outcome:  The diagnosis of NVIE was made and treatment was initiated with Intravenous Vancomycin and Gentamicin  adjusted per renal function. The patient's clinical condition gradually improved over two weeks of antibiotic therapy. Repeat blood culture after two weeks of treatment was negative. The patient was subsequently discharged after four weeks of intravenous antibiotics and closely followed-up at the outpatient clinic. Her repeat echocardiography after six months showed a reduction in the size of the mitral valve vegetation with no significant regurgitation. She remained asymptomatic during the follow-up period.  Conclusion:  This report emphasizes the typical presentation of NVIE  its approach to diagnosis  and management. It also underscores the need for maintaining high clinical suspicion for infective endocarditis in patients presenting with nonspecific symptoms and apparent cardiac involvement.

Case Report:  Patient Information and Demographics:  We report the case of a 64-year-old gentleman  Mr. B  of Caucasian origin. He is a retired accountant  a non-smoker  and has a history of moderate alcohol consumption. His past medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has been regularly taking antihypertensive medication (amlodipine) and oral hypoglycemic medication (metformin) for his respective chronic conditions. He is not known to have any adverse or allergic drug reactions. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease  with the patient's father having suffered from myocardial infarction at 68 years.  Clinical Findings:  Mr. B presented at the emergency department with symptoms of fever  night sweats  and loss of appetite persisting for three weeks. He also complained of feeling generally unwell  experiencing significant fatigue  and reported unintentional weight loss.  He had noted an occasional heart palpitation but denied chest pain or dyspnea.   Diagnostic Assessment and Intervention:   Upon clinical examination  there were no signs of heart failure. Blood was drawn for testing  and the patient was admitted for hospitalization due to the ongoing and undiagnosed symptoms. Mr. B's blood cultures grew Streptococcus sanguinis. The patient was diagnosed with native valve infective endocarditis based on the clinical features  blood culture results  and echocardiogram findings  which revealed vegetations on the mitral valve.  Infective endocarditis is a rare but potentially life-threatening disease. Considering his causal microorganism  Mr. B was treated with penicillin G and gentamicin for a period of four weeks. In addition  his medications for hypertension and diabetes mellitus were adjusted according to current clinical guidelines and considering the effect of his acute infection on these chronic conditions.  Therapeutic Intervention and Follow-up:  The patient responded well to the antibiotic therapy  with resolution of his fever after two weeks and improvement in his general condition. Repeated blood cultures remained sterile  and repeat echocardiograms showed a decrease in the size of the vegetation. No surgical intervention was needed.   He spent the majority of his treatment in the hospital under strict monitoring and was discharged after being afebrile for a week and showing general improvement in his clinical condition. His diabetic control and blood pressure were stabilized at discharge.  Mr. B was scheduled for regular outpatient follow-ups to perform routine blood works  echocardiograms  and monitor his control of chronic comorbidities. During his latest clinic visit  he had remained symptom-free  and there were no signs of relapse.  Conclusion:  While native-valve infective endocarditis is infrequent  it remains particularly difficult to diagnose since the symptoms can often be vague  as seen in Mr. B's case. Rapid identification of the etiologic organism and appropriate antibiotic therapy can lead to successful management  as demonstrated by the favorable outcome observed. Clinicians should always consider endocarditis as a possible diagnosis in patients presenting with persistent fever and other non-specific systemic symptoms.

Patient Information:  A 63-year-old Caucasian female  Mrs. X  living in a suburban community  comes with a 2-week history of persistent fever  chills  fatigue  and unexplained weight loss. The patient has no known underlying medical conditions or habits such as drug abuse. Her family report she has 5 siblings  but none have any history of heart disease or similar symptoms. She is married with two children and she works as a schoolteacher. She is a non-smoker and occasionally consumes alcohol.  Clinical Findings:  The patient presented with a fever of 38.5°C  heart murmur  and multiple  small  painless hemorrhagic skin lesions. As part of her physical examination  reduced body weight was noted (10 kg less than the same period last year). Breath sounds were clear  without any rhonchi or crepitations. Cardiac examination revealed a systolic murmur. No hepatosplenomegaly was noted. Her blood pressure was within the normal range.  Diagnosis  Treatment  and Outcome:  With the patient's clinical presentation  history and examination findings  a diagnosis of infective endocarditis was suspected. Blood cultures were drawn and she was admitted for further observation and management. Echo-cardiography revealed large vegetations on the mitral valve. Blood culture grew Staphylococcus aureus  which was sensitive to methicillin.   Based on the Duke criteria for the diagnosis of endocarditis - positive blood cultures  echocardiographic findings and the presence of a fever - a definitive diagnosis of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis due to Staphylococcus aureus was made.   She was treated with intravenous antibiotics (Cefazolin 2g every 8 hours) for six weeks. The patient's fever gradually subsided and symptoms improved  but due to the size and position of vegetations  mitral valve replacement was done after completing antibiotic treatment. The post-surgical outcome was successful  with the patient showing full recovery and rehabilitation at the 3-month follow-up.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the need for early suspicion  diagnosis  and treatment of infective endocarditis  even in patients without any relevant medical or drug abuse history. It also underscores the importance of taking into account non-specific symptoms  such as unexplained weight loss  that could nonetheless indicate systemic infection. Regular follow-ups should be advised to such patients to ensure complete recovery and to screen for potential complications.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. IH is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who recently presented to the clinic with a chief complaint of intermittent fever and nights sweats for the past two weeks.  Medical History: The patient has a notable past medical history of congestive heart failure  which is currently managed with beta-blockers. IH was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type II ten years ago that is maintained on oral hypoglycemic agents. Apart from occasional alcohol intake  he reports no use of drugs or tobacco. IH had no known allergies and his immunization records are up-to-date.  Presenting Problem: IH reported that he has been feeling fatigued and has experienced significant weight loss over the past month. He reported that his fevers peaked in the late afternoon and were associated with chills and night sweats. He denied any chest pain  cough  dyspnea  or other localized symptoms. The patient also indicated suffering from lack of appetite and having joint pain  predominantly in the knees.   Physical Examination & Diagnostics: Upon physical examination  IH was febrile with a temperature of 100.4°F and had mild tachycardia with a heart rate of 100 beats/minute. Cardiac examination revealed a mid-diastolic murmur at the mitral area. A full blood count showed elevated white blood cells with neutrophilia. His liver function test results were also abnormal  with elevated transaminases.   Echocardiography showed a mass on the mitral valve  confirming the suspicion of infective endocarditis. Blood culture was positive for Staphylococcus aureus. A diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis was established.  Treatment and Follow Up: Intravenous antibiotic therapy with vancomycin was initiated. The patient was informed about the seriousness of his condition and the crucial need for hospitalization and invasive treatment. A cardiologist was consulted for a possible surgical intervention considering the patient’s persistent fever and evidence of cardiac failure.
