Discussion: This case highlights the importance of index suspicion for infective endocarditis in patients with significant cardiac history who present with unexplained fever. Timely identification and management of such patients are critical to prevent potential complications and reduce mortality associated with this severe infection.

Title: Case Report on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Healthy 55-year-old Male  Abstract: This report represents a case study concerning native-valve infective endocarditis (IE) detection in a middle-aged male  with no prior history of heart diseases or immune suppression. The purpose is to stress the importance of considering IE among seemingly healthy individuals who present with prolonged  unspecific clinical symptoms as the timely diagnosis can potentially decrease the mortality and morbidity rates.  Patient Information: The patient involved is a Caucasian male  aged 55 years old  with no reported prior medical history relevant to cardiovascular disease or immunodeficiency. He resides in the rural upper Midwest region of the USA and works as a carpenter.  Clinical Findings: The patient initially approached a local clinic with complaints of persistent low-grade fever  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss over a span of 2 months. He also mentioned occasional night sweats without any respiratory symptoms. He denied any previous episode of rheumatic fever or history of intravenous drug use. Additionally  the patient reported experiencing intermittent arthralgia.  Diagnostic Assessment: Despite the absence of classic peripheral stigmata of endocarditis during the initial physical examinations  the presence of a new cardiac murmur triggered an echocardiogram. Results demonstrated bulky vegetations on the native mitral valve  which led to the provisional diagnosis of Native valve infective endocarditis. Blood cultures grew Streptococcus viridans  further confirming the diagnosis. The patient was devoid of any visible dental caries or periodontal disease but admitted to not seeking routine dental care. Additional workup for immunodeficiency  including HIV test  was negative.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient received treatment with intravenous ceftriaxone and gentamicin for two weeks. Due to persistent fever and increasing size of the valvular vegetations on repeat echocardiogram  he underwent successful mitral valve replacement surgery. Histopathology of excised mitral valve confirmed the presence of vegetation and active inflammation consistent with Infective Endocarditis.  Follow Up and Outcomes: Post-surgical recovery was unremarkable  and the patient was discharged on prophylactic oral antibiotics with regular follow-up appointments scheduled. At six months post-operation  he remained symptom-free and was physically active  with regular echocardiograms showing excellent prosthetic valve function.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed gratitude and relief post-treatment  stating that the experience had reinforced the importance of regular medical and dental check-ups.  Conclusions: Thus  this case underscores the importance of maintaining a high clinical suspicion of IE in patients presenting with unclear symptoms and the role of early detection through proactive echocardiogram analysis in securing a more favorable prognosis. It likewise emphasizes the need for routine dental care to prevent such instances in the future.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Male Patient with Type 2 Diabetes  Patient Profile:   The patient  Mr. A  is a 68-year-old Caucasian man residing in urban New York. He is a retired mechanical engineer  a non-smoker  and has a moderate alcohol consumption history. His family history reveals no significant genetic predispositions or illnesses.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. A presented to the emergency department with a two-week history of fever  chills  fatigue  and shortness of breath. He also reported unintentional weight loss but denied any chest pain  cough  or abdominal pain.   Past Medical History:  He was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes thirty years prior and has been managing it with daily oral hypoglycemic agents. He also had a history of hypertension for over a decade  controlled with amlodipine. Routine bloodwork  including fasting blood glucose and HbA1c levels  were regularly monitored and poorly controlled. Mr. A had no previous history of cardiac diseases  surgeries or hospitalizations.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed mild pallor  an irregular heartbeat  and petechial lesions on the extremities. A grade 3/6 diastolic murmur was audible at the left sternal border. The rest of the systemic examination was unremarkable. Preliminary lab investigations showed a raised white blood cell count and ESR  consistent with an infection. His blood glucose level was elevated  and HbA1c was 8.0%  indicating poor glycemic control.  Imaging and Diagnosis:  Transthoracic echocardiography revealed an oscillating intracardiac mass on the atrial side of the mitral valve. Further diagnostic work-up involving blood culture grew Streptococcus viridans  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis (IE).   Treatment:  A regimen of intravenous antibiotics (Penicillin and Gentamicin) was initiated as per the sensitivity report. Mr. A also received insulin to control blood glucose levels. Despite being counseled on the possible need for valve replacement surgery in the future  he wished to proceed with medical management alone for now.  Follow-up:  Post six weeks of antibiotics therapy  Mr. A showed significant clinical improvement. Repeat echocardiography revealed a considerable reduction in vegetations's size  and his blood cultures turned sterile. He continues to be under follow-up care with improvements in diabetic control and regular cardiac assessment.   Mr. A’s case serves as a reminder of the crucial link between poorly controlled Type2 Diabetes and the risk of serious infections. Timely diagnosis  management  and adequate glycemic control have played pivotal roles in the favorable outcome in this case.

Patient Information  The patient was a 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension and cigarette smoking. He was an accountant and lived in Tremont  Ohio with his wife. He had no known allergies. He had recently been to a routine doctor's appointment a month ago and was known to be adhering to his anti-hypertensive medications. He also had an apparent history of poor dental hygiene.  Clinical Findings  The patient was admitted to the emergency department with high-grade fever  general malaise  and fatigue. He reported an episode of chills  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss for the past two weeks. He admitted having a poor appetite accompanied by nausea. On physical examination  the patient was noted to have signs of mild pallor  petechiae on his palate and conjunctiva  and notable inflammatory changes in his gums  indicative of gingivitis.  Diagnostic Assessment  Based on these symptoms  a differential diagnosis of infective endocarditis was suspected. The patient underwent a series of investigations. A full blood count indicated mild anemia and a high white cell count. The serology was positive for inflammatory markers CRP and ESR  and Procalcitonin. Three sets of blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus viridans. The urine analysis did not provide significant findings. Echocardiography revealed vegetation on the patient's native mitral valve and moderate mitral regurgitation  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.   Therapeutic Interventions  The patient was treated with a two-week course of intravenous penicillin combined with gentamicin. He responded well to this course of antibiotics  showing significant improvement both clinically and in laboratory parameters. The patient was encouraged to maintain good dental hygiene and regular follow-ups to monitor his condition  and received counselling for smoking cessation.  Follow-up and Outcomes   Subsequent blood cultures at the end of his antibiotic course were negative. The patient was discharged approximately three weeks after admission. Follow-up echocardiography three months after discharge showed resolution of the vegetation and unchanged mitral regurgitation. The patient was advised further follow-ups with the Infectious Diseases and Cardiology Departments for optimum management of his condition.  Patient Perspective   The patient was scared at initial diagnosis but  upon understanding his condition better  adapted well to the treatment process. He understood the implications of the disease and engaged actively in maintaining better health habits  which included proper oral hygiene and giving up smoking.  Conclusion  This case highlights the importance of a high index of suspicion for infective endocarditis in febrile patients with risk factors  such as poor oral hygiene and cardiovascular disease. Timely diagnosis and appropriate treatment resulted in a favorable outcome for the patient. It also reinforces the critical role oral hygiene can play in eliminating potential sources of bacteremia leading to endocarditis.

Title: A Case Report on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information: The patient is a 60-year-old male named John Doe who hails from a suburban setting in Dallas  Texas. His professional life included 30 years as a construction worker. He was a smoker but quit 10 years ago  but he continues to use alcohol moderately. He is married  has no children  and lives with his wife.  Clinical Findings: Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department (ED) following a period of 3 weeks of intermittent high fever  chills  fatigue  and multiple joint pains with notable weight loss. He had no previous history of cardiac illness. No family history of infective endocarditis was identified. On physical examination  he was ill-looking  with a temperature of 39 °C  blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg  and heart rate of 110 beats per min. Cardiac auscultation revealed an audible systolic murmur over the left upper sternal border. Blood tests showed raised inflammatory markers (CRP  ESR) and relatively normal cardiac enzymes. His dental hygiene was noticed to be poor.  Diagnosis: Based on clinical examination and symptoms  a suspicion of infectious endocarditis was raised. Two sets of blood cultures were drawn. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was conducted  revealing vegetation on his native mitral valve suggestive of infective endocarditis. Blood cultures isolated Streptococcus oralis  which linked the poor dental hygiene to the infectious endocarditis.  Treatment: After discussions with Infectious Disease specialists  the patient was initiated on appropriate antibiotics  which included intravenous Penicillin G and Gentamicin for synergy  for 6 weeks. The patient was equally referred to a dentist for regular dental cleanings and education.  Outcome and follow-ups: The patient's condition started improving within a week of antibiotic treatment. The patient was discharged after 6 weeks of intravenous antibiotic therapy. He showed significant improvement at the four-week outpatient clinic follow-ups  with the resolution of fever and reduction in inflammatory markers. Repeat echocardiography at 6 months showed a significant decrease in vegetation size  indicating a good response to treatment.  Learning Points: This case illustrates the importance of recognizing unusual presentations of diseases. Infective endocarditis should be considered in patients presenting with prolonged unexplained fever  especially when accompanying murmurs are found on examination. The case also highlights the importance of good dental health in preventing conditions like infective endocarditis.  Conclusion: Infective endocarditis  while relatively rare  can present without much of a discernible history of cardiac disease  as seen in this case report. A comprehensive examination  including dental health  is crucial in such scenarios to identify potential sources of infection. Timely recognition of signs and symptoms with prompt initiation of appropriate therapy can lead to favorable outcomes.

Case Report  Patient Profile:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male residing in rural South Dakota. He is a retired farmer  a lifetime non-smoker  and does not consume alcohol regularly. The patient resides with his wife and has regular contact with his children and grandchildren.  Presenting Symptoms:  He presented to the outpatient department with persistent and high-grade fever for the past two weeks  alongside rigors  night sweating  and a weight loss of approximately 15 lbs during this period. The patient reported an aftermath of fatigue and mild breathlessness on exertion but denied any history of cough  chest pain  palpitations  or fainting episodes.  Past Medical History:  His past medical record includes hypertension  managed with amlodipine 5mg daily for the past 10 years. He has no known allergies. There is no significant family history of note–barring an elder sister who succumbed to breast cancer at the age of 68.  Physical Examination:  Upon physical examination  the patient was found to be febrile  with a recorded oral temperature of 39.5℃. He appeared pale and had splinter hemorrhages under his fingernails  with slight clubbing. Cardiac auscultation revealed a diastolic murmur best heard at the mitral area. No other significant findings were recorded during the full body examination.  Investigations and Diagnosis:  Given the historical and clinical findings  a suspicion of infective endocarditis was raised. To confirm the diagnosis  transthoracic echocardiography was performed  which demonstrated thickened leaflets and a possible vegetation in the mitral area. His hemogram showed elevated total white cell counts (13 000/μL with 82% neutrophils) and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP). Blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus mutans  which corroborated the diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis caused by oral flora  likely due to poor dental hygiene.  Treatment and Follow-up:  The patient was promptly initiated on targeted IV antibiotics according to the sensitivity pattern of the cultured organism (Penicillin G and gentamycin). Surgical intervention was deferred due to patient preferences and relatively preserved cardiac function with no immediate signs of heart failure. A course of 6 weeks of antibiotics was planned.  The patient also received counselling for maintenance of oral hygiene. On completion of the treatment  repeat blood cultures were negative  and there was a resolution of fever and other symptoms. His condition is currently being monitored through regular follow-ups.  Discussion:  This case emphasizes the importance of clinical suspicion and early recognition of infective endocarditis  particularly in patients presenting with unexplained fever. It also underscores the association between poor oral hygiene and the development of infective endocarditis. Regular check-ups and careful monitoring are pivotal for patients suffering from this condition to improve prognosis and limit complications.

Title: Infective Endocarditis in a Native Heart Valve: A Case Study  Patient Information: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired engineer and a non-smoker with a history of moderate alcohol consumption.   Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes mellitus type II  which are well-controlled with medication: Losartan 25 mg daily  Atorvastatin 20 mg daily  and Metformin 500 mg twice daily. He has no known drug allergies. He has been requiring regular medical follow-ups due to his chronic conditions.   Presenting Complaints: He presented to the emergency department with a week-long history of high-grade fever  chills  malaise  fatigue and mild shortness of breath. There was no associated chest pain  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or pedal edema.  Clinical Findings: On examination  his temperature was 38.5°C  blood pressure 137/85 mmHg  pulse rate 85 beats/minute (regular)  respiratory rate 18 breaths/minute  SpO2 96% on room air. Cardiac examination revealed a diastolic murmur in the aortic area. Pulmonary  abdominal  and neurological examinations were unremarkable. There were no signs of peripheral stigmata of endocarditis.  Timeline:  Week 1: High-grade fever (up to 38.5°C)  chills  malaise  fatigue  mild shortness of breath Week 2: Admitted to hospital  Intravenous antibiotic therapy initiated  Diagnostic Assessment: Laboratory studies showed white cell count (WCC) 11x10^9/L  hemoglobin (Hb) 12 g/dl  and C-reactive protein (CRP) 90 mg/L. Blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus. Chest X-ray was clear. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) revealed moderate aortic regurgitation with an oscillating mass suggesting an aortic valve vegetation  consistent with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was admitted and empirical intravenous antibiotic therapy was initiated with Vancomycin and Gentamicin  after obtaining blood cultures. Viridans group streptococci sensitivity was found and antibiotic therapy was de-escalated to Penicillin G and Gentamicin.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: Over the next few weeks  the patient's condition improved gradually with reduction in fever and he reported feeling less fatigued. Serial blood cultures turned negative. Repeat TTE at 6 weeks showed reduction in vegetation size with improved aortic regurgitation.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of suspecting infective endocarditis in elderly patients who present with unexplained fever  even in the absence of heart murmurs or peripheral stigmata of endocarditis. Timely diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic therapy can significantly improve patient outcomes and decrease the risk for potential complications. The patient will require continued surveillance with TTE to monitor recovery.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 53 years Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Residence: Pennsylvania  USA Occupation: Truck Driver  Presenting Complaints: Patient presented with intermittent fever  fatigue  and increased discomfort in the chest area  which has been for the past three weeks. There was also a complaint of sudden weight loss.  Past Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of mitral regurgitation and was prescribed long-term medications. He is also diagnosed with type II diabetes which is being managed with Metformin. There is no history of any major surgeries or transplants. The patient reported a dental procedure done around a month ago. The patient has been a smoker for the past 15 years with moderate alcohol consumption.  Clinical Findings & Diagnosis:  On examination  he appeared very pale and exhausted. He was febrile with a temperature of 100.5°F (~38.3°C)  blood pressure 130/85mmHg  and pulse rate of 95 bpm. On cardiac auscultation  a murmur was noted indicating valvular abnormalities. The routine blood tests showed an elevated white blood cell count and ESR. Blood cultures were drawn and sent to the lab.   An echocardiogram was ordered which showed vegetations on the mitral valve indicating the probability of Infective Endocarditis.   His blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus  confirming the diagnosis of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVIE).    Management & Follow-up:  The patient started with empirical antibiotic therapy immediately. Once blood culture reported growth of Staphylococcus aureus  the patient was put on intravenous nafcillin  in line with the condition's standard treatment guidelines.   Given the patient’s pre-existing mitral regurgitation  consultation with a cardiothoracic surgeon was done considering the chance for valve replacement if required in the future. The patient was also advised on the importance of prophylactic antibiotics before any future dental or surgical procedures due to his increased susceptibility to NVIE.   After six weeks of aggressive antimicrobial therapy  noticeable improvement in the clinical status of the patient was seen. This was evidenced by the resolution of fever  fatigue  and weight gain. Repeat blood cultures were negative and Echocardiography showed reduction in the size of the vegetation.  Discharge and Follow-up:   The patient was discharged after 8 weeks of hospital stay and was advised to follow up every month as outpatient for the next 3 months for a repeat Echocardiogram  blood tests  and general check-up. Further long-term follow-ups were advised every six months for the surveillance of his cardiac condition.   In summary  this case demonstrates the successful management of NVIE in a patient with underlying mitral regurgitation and highlights the potential risks associated with dental procedures in such individuals. It emphasizes the importance of prompt diagnosis  appropriate antimicrobial therapy  and regular follow-ups in managing such cases.

Title: A Rare Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Previously Healthy Middle-Aged Man  Introduction: This case focuses on a 48-year-old male presenting with symptoms consistent with native valve infective endocarditis  a serious cardiac infection that often affects individuals with pre-existing heart conditions.   Case Presentation: The patient  a Caucasian 48-year-old male  working as an IT consultant  presented to the emergency department with symptoms of fatigue  intermittent fever  night sweats and unintentional weight loss over a period of 3 weeks. He denied any recent travels  dental procedures  intravenous drug use or known contacts with infectious diseases. He has no smoking history but declared moderate alcohol consumption. The patient reported no family history of cardiac or autoimmune diseases and no noteworthy allergies.  Clinical Findings: On examination  he was found to be febrile (38.6°C) and tachycardic. Cardiac auscultation revealed a grade III/IV diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border. No Osler's nodes  Janeway lesions  Roth's spots or splinter hemorrhages were noticed. Initial investigation showed elevated inflammatory markers  namely ESR and CRP. Blood cultures were taken  which grew Streptococus Oralis  highly suggestive of infective endocarditis.  Investigations: Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) revealed a 1.3 cm vegetative mass on the aortic valve  confirming the diagnosis of infective endocarditis. No signs of heart failure were noted upon chest X-ray or electrocardiogram results.  Treatment: The patient was started on intravenous therapy with ceftriaxone and gentamicin as per the local antimicrobial protocol for streptococcal endocarditis. Surgery was not immediately considered due to the absence of heart failure  aortic regurgitation or abscess.  Outcome and Follow-Up: Due to the early detection and aggressive antibiotic therapy  the patient showed significant clinical and echocardiographic improvement within 2 weeks. He completed a 6-week course of intravenous antibiotics followed by 6 months of oral suppressive therapy. Regular transthoracic echocardiography was used to monitor the resolution of endocarditis. At 1 year follow-up  no relapse reported  indicating a successful treatment without the need for surgical intervention. The patient was trained on oral hygiene as a preventive measure against further occurrences.   Discussion: This case emphasizes the importance of early recognition of native-valve infective endocarditis even in individuals without any known cardiac history. Noteworthy in this case is the rarity of infective endocarditis in a previously healthy individual with no predisposing factors. Oral hygiene and dental health must be highlighted when educating the community about the prevention of infective endocarditis.   Patient's Perspective: ""The diagnosis was truly a shock as I believed to be in great health. Though the treatment was long and at times uncomfortable  I am relieved to be in good health again.""  Learning Points: This case reinforces two important aspects: no patient history detail is too small when diagnosing  and that healthy individuals are not immune to severe infections like infective endocarditis. Vigilance and patient education are indispensable tools for prevention and early diagnosis.

Patient Information: Mr. X is a 58-year-old Caucasian man who works as a construction supervisor. He resides in a suburban area and is a non-smoker. He has a history of alcohol consumption but quit drinking 5 years ago. He is a widower  living alone with occasional visits by his adult children. His only regular medication is ibuprofen  taken as needed for knee pain.   Medical History:  The patient has hypertension which was diagnosed ten years ago  for which he was on antihypertensive medication until a year ago when he quit due to the side effects. He has been in good health and has not been hospitalized before. He denies illicit drug use  recent travel or any recent infectious disease contacts.   Presenting Complaint:  He presented to the emergency department with a two-week history of fever  malaise  and night sweats. He also complained of exertional dyspnea  reduced exercise tolerance  and an unintended weight loss of approximately ten pounds within the past month.   Clinical Findings:  On examination  he was febrile  with a temperature of 38.5°C. He had a systolic murmur  and vascular phenomena such as Janeway lesions on his palms and soles. He also had Osler’s nodes which were tender subcutaneous nodules on the pulp of the digits indicating vasculitis. There was no evidence of peripheral edema  and his lungs were clear on auscultation.   Diagnostic assessment:  Blood cultures grew Streptococcus viridans  consistent with Infective Endocarditis (IE). Transthoracic echocardiography showed a thickened aortic valve with moderate aortic regurgitation and a mobile vegetation. He underwent transesophageal echocardiogram which confirmed a 15mm mobile mass attached to the ventricular side of the aortic valve.  Therapeutic Intervention:  He was initiated empirically on intravenous vancomycin and gentamicin  which was later switched to penicillin G and gentamicin based on culture sensitivities. Despite four weeks of antimicrobial therapy  the patient continued to have intermittent fevers and his inflammatory markers remained persistently elevated.   Follow-up and outcome:  He ultimately required surgical intervention – an aortic valve replacement – after which he fully recovered. The patient was educated about the importance of good oral hygiene to reduce the risk of recurrent infective endocarditis since he was found to have significant dental caries that might have been the initial source of bacteremia.   Patient Perspective:  Mr. X was grateful for the successful surgical intervention and was committed to improving his oral hygiene to prevent a recurrence. He expressed a wish to better understand and manage his hypertension in the future.   Acknowledgements:  The patient gave his consent for this case to be reported. His identity remains confidential.

Patient Information:  A 65-year-old African American male presented with symptoms indicative of infectious disease  notably shortness of breath  malaise  fever  chills  and increased heart rate. The patient resides in a suburban part of Baltimore  Maryland  is retired  and lives with his wife. As per his experience  the symptoms appeared suddenly over the past week  which prompted him to seek medical attention. The patient had no recent history of travel or known contact with infectious diseases.  Past Medical History:  The patient's medical history is significant for a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus 10 years ago  managed using metformin and lifestyle modifications. Additionally  the patient has hypertension under control with Lisinopril. He also has a history of rheumatic fever at age 12  but no significant complication was reported. The patient had no history of IV drug use  alcohol dependency  or illicit drug use. He had been a tobacco smoker but quit 20 years ago. The patient also had a myocardial infarction 3 years back  managed and treated with coronary angioplasty. His family history revealed that his father had coronary artery disease and his mother had a stroke.   Presenting Symptoms:  At the time of admission  the patient was febrile  with a temperature of 38.7 degrees Celsius. The pulse rate was 112 bpm  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  and blood pressure 138/90 mmHg. In addition to mentioned symptoms  the physical examination revealed a new murmur  suggesting possible valvular incompetence.  Diagnostic Assessments:  Complete blood count showed leukocytosis and moderately elevated ESR. On blood culture  Gram-positive cocci grew  which were identified as Streptococcus viridans. Echocardiogram revealed vegetations on native valves  affecting mitral and aortic valves.  Physician Conclusion:  Based on clinical findings  symptoms  and diagnostic assessments  the 65-year-old male was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis. The causative organism identified was Streptococcus viridans  a common agent in native valve endocarditis  frequently associated with the oral cavity - per medical history  he had poor oral hygiene.  Management and Outcome:  The patient was started on appropriate antimicrobial therapy (intravenous penicillin G and gentamicin) as per the infectious disease specialist’s recommendation. After a total of four weeks of antibiotic treatment  a follow-up echocardiogram showed a significant reduction in vegetation size. The patient's condition and symptoms notably improved during hospital admission  marked with a decline in fever  heart rate  and normalization of leukocyte count and ESR. As a part of secondary prevention  a referral to a dentist was made to address his oral health. He was also counseled on proper oral hygiene practices and the importance of regular dental check-ups to mitigate endocarditis risk.   The patient was discharged and scheduled for an outpatient follow-up for continued monitoring. This case emphasizes the crucial role of both early diagnosis and appropriate management in ensuring favorable patient outcomes in infective endocarditis.  Patient Consent:  Acquired (assumed for the case scenario)

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-Aged Female: A Case Report  Introduction: Infective endocarditis (IE) is a severe infection of the heart's endocardial surface  usually involving the heart valves. It is often associated with significant morbidity and mortality and has diverse clinical presentations  thus posing a significant challenge in diagnosis and treatment process. We report a case of native valve infective endocarditis in a 52-year-old woman with no known predisposition for endocarditis.  Case Presentation: The patient  a 52-year old Caucasian woman  a housekeeper by occupation  presented to the emergency department of our hospital with a 3-week history of intermittent fever  unintentional weight loss  loss of appetite  accompanied by fatigue  generalized weakness  night sweats  and a recent episode of syncope. She denied any history of recreational drug use  dental procedures recently  or any known cardiac conditions. Her past medical history was remarkable for intermittent asthma and osteoarthritis. She was a non-smoker and consumed alcohol occasionally.  On physical examination  she was febrile  with a temperature of 38.5°C  blood pressure of 110/70 mmHg  and a heart rate of 102 beats/minute. Examination of the heart revealed a diastolic murmur best appreciated at the left lower sternal border. Pulmonary exam was clear to auscultation. The spleen was palpable  but the rest of the examination was unremarkable. There were no identifiable peripheral stigmata of endocarditis.  Investigations revealed an elevated white blood cell count of 14 000 cells/μL  with 87% neutrophils and a mild anemia with a hemoglobin of 10.2 g/dL. Blood cultures were obtained and she was started on empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics. Transthoracic echocardiogram exhibited a mobile echodense mass attached to the ventricular side of the anterior mitral leaflet suggestive of a vegetation  and a moderate mitral regurgitation was noted.   Blood cultures grew Streptococcus mitis  a viridans group streptococci  which are known to be a common causative organism of native valve endocarditis. This  coupled with her clinical symptoms and echocardiographic findings  confirmed the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  The patient was treated with a 4-week course of penicillin and gentamicin  considering the sensitivity of the isolated organism. The post-treatment course was uneventful  and at three months follow-up  she showed no signs of infection or heart failure  and a repeat echocardiography showed the disappearance of the vegetation and improvement in mitral regurgitation.  Conclusion: While infective endocarditis is typically associated with known cardiac conditions  intravenous drug use  or recent invasive procedures  it can occur in individuals with no known risk factors. Early identification  appropriate antibiotics  and management of complications are crucial for reducing morbidity and mortality in these patients. Further research is required to improve the understanding and management of IE in patients with no established predisposing factors.

Title: A Case Report of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Female   Patient Information:  Ms. Johnson  an 80-year-old African American female  presented to the outpatient department of our hospital. She was a retired school teacher and lived with her daughter and grandchildren.  Presenting concerns:  The patient complained of persistent fever  progressive weakness  and loss of appetite over the past three weeks. She also reported intermittent chest discomfort and shortness of breath for the last week.  Past Medical History:  Ms. Johnson had a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension for the past 10 years  well controlled with Metformin and Losartan respectively. She also had osteoarthritis and was on regular acetaminophen for pain relief. She was not known to have any cardiac diseases  allergies  or addictions. Her surgical history was significant for a total right knee replacement five years ago due to severe osteoarthritis.   Clinical Findings:   On general examination  Ms. Johnson had low-grade fever. Her pulse rate was 86 beats/minute  respiratory rate was 18 breaths/minute  and blood pressure was 140/85 mm Hg. Cardiac examination revealed a new diastolic murmur. Skin examination disclosed Janeway lesions on the soles.   Diagnostic Assessment:  Blood work revealed increased white blood cell count  erythrocyte sedimentation rate and slightly elevated blood glucose levels. Blood culture results demonstrated the growth of Streptococcus viridans. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) identified vegetations on the mitral valve  consistent with infective endocarditis.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Ms. Johnson was admitted to the medical ward promptly. Intravenous Antibiotic therapy (Ceftriaxone and Gentamicin) was initiated based on the sensitivities in the blood culture report.   Follow Up:  Her fever gradually subsided over the next week  and her general condition improved significantly. Repeat blood cultures at the end of two weeks showed no bacterial growth  confirming that the antibiotics were effective. The patient was discharged after four weeks with advice on continuing oral antibiotics as prescribed  blood pressure monitoring  and regular follow-ups.   Teaching Points:  This case underlines the need for a high index of suspicion for infective endocarditis in elderly patients presenting with unexplained fever and cardiac murmur  particularly those with a history of diabetes and hypertension. Early diagnosis and prompt initiation of appropriate antibiotic therapy can result in positive patient outcomes.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 57-year-old Male: A Case Report  Introduction: Infective Endocarditis (IE)  an infectious disease prevalent in individuals with pre-existing heart disorders  mainly infects the heart's endocardium region. However  cases involving the native-valve  relatively rare  can cause significant harm if not treated promptly.   Case Presentation: This case concerns a 57-year-old Caucasian male from urban New York  presenting previously undiagnosed native-valve infective endocarditis (IE). He worked as a banker  had no known drug allergies  was a non-smoker  and had moderate alcohol consumption. Family history was unremarkable.  Clinical Findings: The patient first presented to his primary care physician with persistent low-grade fever  chills  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss over four weeks. On examination  he had grade 3/6 systolic murmur and splenomegaly. He had a medical history of hypertension  and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  managed with ramipril and metformin respectively. He had no history of intravenous drug use or any recent dental procedures.  Diagnostic Assessment: On investigation  his Complete Blood Count showed leukocytosis  mild anemia  and elevated ESR. His blood cultures grew Streptococcus viridans. Electrocardiogram showed signs of left ventricular hypertrophy. Transthoracic echocardiogram revealed large vegetations on his own tricuspid and mitral valves with no significant regurgitation. With these findings  he was diagnosed with native-valve IE per the Duke’s criteria.  Interventions: The patient was immediately admitted to the hospital and treated with intravenous antibiotics as per the American Heart Association (AHA) guidelines  with penicillin G and gentamicin. After two weeks of IV therapy  the patient's condition significantly improved  the fever subsided  and the vegetation size on echocardiography decreased.  Outcome and Follow-Up: The patient completed a six-week course of antibiotics and was subsequently discharged with no surgical interventions necessary. He was followed up monthly in the outpatient department. After four months  repeat echocardiography showed no vegetations  and the patient remained symptom-free.  Conclusion: This case suggests considering a diagnosis of IE  even with non-specific signs such as unexplained fever  weight loss  and fatigue. Successful conservative management with prolonged antibiotic therapy highlighted the importance of early diagnosis and treatment in the management of native-valve IE. To avoid severe complications  healthcare providers should promptly initiate aggressive therapeutic strategies based on established guidelines.

Title: A Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a Middle-aged Woman  Introduction: Native-valve infective endocarditis (NVE) is a severe condition that posits a significant health threat if not managed promptly. It refers to an infection of a heart's native valves caused by bacterial  fungal  or other microbial agents. We present a unique case of a 45-year-old female individual with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Case Presentation: A 45-year-old Caucasian woman  with a history of intravenous drug abuse  presented to our facility with a two-week history of severe fatigue  night sweats  weight loss  and general malaise. She had a prior medical history of untreated type-2 diabetes mellitus and hepatitis C that she contracted in her early 30s due to previous intravenous drug use. She had no history of congenital heart disease  heart surgery  placement of heart devices  or any antecedent valvular diseases. She was a smoker  consuming approximately a pack of cigarettes a day  but denied any consumption of alcohol. Notably  she reported no recent dental procedures or trauma.  On admittance  her vitals were unstable: blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg  temperature of 39.0°C  pulse rate of 120 beats per minute  and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. Physical examination was remarkable for pallor  Osler nodes on hands and feet  and Janeway lesions on the palms and soles. Cardiac auscultation revealed a new cardiac murmur suggestive of aortic regurgitation.  Investigations: Laboratory analysis showed an elevated white blood cell count of 17.5 × 10^9/L (normal: 4-11x 10^9/L) with 89% neutrophils  indicating a high likelihood of bacterial infection. Inflammatory markers were significantly elevated: C-reactive protein (CRP) of 150 mg/L (normal: <5 mg/L) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 70 mm/hr (normal: <20 mm/hr). Blood samples were taken and sent for cultures. Serologic tests for HIV came back negative. Chest X-ray findings were insignificant. An echocardiogram demonstrated vegetations on the aortic valve suggestive of NVE.   Culture results confirmed the diagnosis  showing the presence of Staphylococcus aureus  a common causative agent for NVE  especially in patients with a history of intravenous drug use.   Management and Outcome: The patient was initiated on high-dose intravenous antibiotic therapy (vancomycin and gentamicin). After initial stabilization  considering the persistent fever  poor echocardiographic features  positive blood cultures  and large vegetations  she was referred for valve surgery. Postoperatively  she responded well to treatment with complete resolution of symptoms and no complications. She was discharged after two weeks of in-hospital recovery and put on a course of oral antibiotics for 6 weeks  along with an integrated care plan for her diabetes and hepatitis C. She was also referred to a drug rehabilitation program.  Discussion: This case highlights the significance of prompt identification and management of individuals presenting with NVE. It emphasizes the severity and complications that can arise due to delayed treatment and illuminates the connection between a history of intravenous drug abuse and this life-threatening condition.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Male   Case Overview:   A 72-year-old Caucasian male presented to our cardiac unit with a two-week history of worsening malaise  shortness of breath  and intermittent fever. The patient lacked any significant hematologic  immunologic  or neoplastic disease history. He had a history of hypertension  managed through medication  and occasional smoking.   Case Presentation:  Mr. Smith  a retired engineer  visited the emergency department complaining of persistent fatigue  difficulty in breathing  fever  unexplained weight loss  and night sweats for the past 14 days  raising suspicion for a possible systemic infection. He also reported a recent  albeit vague  history of dental procedures two months ago without prophylactic antibiotics.   Examination findings included a temperature of 38.6°C  blood pressure of 110/80 mmHg  pulse rate of 92 beats per minute  and respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. Physical examination indicated a slight murmur best heard at the cardiac apex. There were no peripheral stigmata of infective endocarditis.  Investigations:  For laboratory and diagnostic workup  we collected blood samples with three separate venous sites drawn 30 minutes apart. The complete blood count revealed leukocytosis (14 500 cells/µL)  with predominantly neutrophils and elevated C-reactive protein at 8 mg/L. The patient's chest X-ray appeared normal.  Results from blood cultures grew Streptococcus sanguinis in all three sets. Echocardiogram demonstrated mitral valve vegetation with moderate mitral regurgitation  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis (S. sanguinis).  Treatment:  The patient was initiated on intravenous ceftriaxone (2g/day) along with gentamicin (3mg/kg/day) as an empirical regimen  pending sensitivity reports. Following the culture and sensitivity results  the treatment was continued for a total of six weeks. No complications were noted during treatment  and the patient's clinical status progressively improved. He was discharged with an appointment for close follow-up.  Outcome and Follow-up:  Six weeks post-treatment  the patient showed significant improvement in symptoms with the resolution of fever and a reduction in the leukocyte count. Follow-up echocardiography demonstrated a reduction in valve vegetation size. The patient remains in good health at present  with no recurrent episodes.  Discussion:  This case emphasizes the importance of a careful and detailed history  especially in elderly patients presenting with systemic symptoms indicative of endocarditis. It also serves as a reminder of the significance of oral health and the use of prophylactic antibiotics for dental procedures in patients with a history of cardiac disease or risk factors for infective endocarditis. The case underscores the importance of prompt initiation of empirical therapy while awaiting culture and sensitivity results in cases of suspected infective endocarditis  which significantly reduces the morbidity and mortality associated with this serious condition.  Necessary permissions and approvals from the patient were obtained for publication. Written informed consent for the case to be published was provided by the patient.

Patient Information:  A 68-year-old Caucasian male presented to the hospital reporting a 4-week history of fatigue  mild fever  night sweats  and decreased appetite.  Medical History:  The patient’s past medical history is significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and mild hyperlipidemia. He is a non-smoker and has quit drinking alcohol six years prior to visiting the hospital. At the time of presentation  he has been on metformin  an ACE inhibitor  and a stable  low-dose statin for the past 3 years.  Clinical Findings:  Examination findings showed a diastolic murmur on cardiac auscultation  slight splenomegaly  and petechiae on the lower extremities. No osler nodes  Janeway lesions  Roth spots  or heart failure symptoms were evident. Blood examination revealed leukocytosis  an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate  and C-reactive protein. Transthoracic echocardiography identified 1.5 cm vegetation on the aortic valve.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment:  Based on positive blood cultures  presence of vegetations on heart valves  a new regurgitant murmur found during cardiac auscultation and sustained fever symptoms  the patient was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis according to the Modified Duke Criteria.  Therapeutic Focus and Assessment:  The patient was promptly started on empiric antibiotic therapy with vancomycin and gentamicin. After the causative bacteria (Staphylococcus aureus) was identified from the blood cultures  therapy was adjusted to cloxacillin and continued for 6 weeks. Local complications were monitored with serial echocardiography and showed progressive regression of the vegetation.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  The patient's symptoms progressively subsided. After 6 weeks of treatment  repeat echocardiography showed resolution of the aortic valve vegetation  and the murmur was barely perceptible. The patient was discharged and counselled on the importance of oral hygiene  as poor dental health can contribute to bacteria entering the bloodstream.   Teaching Points:  This case highlights the importance of early recognition of infective endocarditis symptoms. Though rare  infective endocarditis can lead to serious or fatal complications if not detected and treated promptly. Importantly  prudence and vigilance must be adopted while managing patients with risk factors such as chronic conditions and damaged heart valves. Further  emphasizing dental hygiene can act as a preventive measure  particularly in susceptible patients.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 62-Year-Old Male with a History of Rheumatic Heart Disease: A Case Report  Patient Profile: The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male residing in urban Nevada  USA. He is retired  lives with his wife  and has two grown children. He has a past medical history of rheumatic heart disease from his early 30s  with no previous heart valves intervention or consistent antibiotic prophylaxis. He reports a 20-pack year history of smoking and occasional alcoholic beverage intake.  Presenting Concerns: The patient presented to the emergency department with a week-long history of progressive symptoms  including worsening fatigue  fever  chills  and unexplained weight loss. He later developed a new cardiac murmur and experienced severe dyspnea on exertion.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed pallor  mild bilateral pitting edema of the lower limbs  and a grade III/VI systolic murmur was detected at the cardiac apex. There were no petechiae  Janeway lesions  or Osler's nodes. Central nervous system examination was normal.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment: Given the patient's history of rheumatic heart disease and presenting symptoms  a differential diagnosis of infective endocarditis was considered. Blood culture was performed  and cardiac echocardiography was ordered. Blood cultures grew Streptococcus viridans sensitive to penicillin. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) showed vegetations on the mitral valve consistent with infective endocarditis.  Therapeutic Focus and Assessment: The patient was admitted to the cardiology unit and initiated on intravenous penicillin G for 4 weeks  per American Heart Association guidelines for infective endocarditis due to sensitive Streptococcus viridans. The monitoring of the patient included serial echocardiograms and clinical evaluations of endocarditis progression or potential complications.   Follow-Up and Outcomes: The follow-up after two weeks of hospitalization showed a significant clinical improvement with a reduction in fever  fatigue  and dyspnea on exertion. The repeated blood culture after two weeks of antibiotic therapy came back negative. The follow-up echocardiogram showed a distinct reduction in vegetation size. By the end of treatment  the vegetation had completely resolved. The patient was sent home with a follow-up appointment in the outpatient clinic and instructions to adhere to a strict oral hygiene regimen to prevent recurrence.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed his satisfaction with the medical care he received and committed to follow the recommended oral hygiene regimen to prevent future occurrences.  Lessons Learned: This case underscores the importance of considering infective endocarditis in patients with rheumatic heart disease presenting with non-specific symptoms. Early diagnosis using echocardiogram and blood cultures is crucial to prevent fatal complications.

Title: A Case Report on Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 62-Year-Old Male  Patient Information:  A 62-year-old Caucasian male was presented at the Emergency Department of a regional hospital. The patient lives in a rural area  is a retired engineer with a history of smoking for 40 years but quit 10 years ago. He reported moderate alcohol intake.  Medical History:  The patient has a medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both well controlled with medication. No allergies have been reported by the patient. He has no past hospitalizations or surgeries. Family history includes a father with coronary artery disease and a mother with stroke. Patient denies any illicit drug use.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient came in complaining of fatigue  loss of appetite  a ten-pound weight loss over the past month  and a fever  which was intermittent in nature  accompanied by night sweats. There was no history of domestic traveling or exposure to animals in the past.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  the patient was febrile (temperature 38.5°C)  with a blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg  pulse rate 90 bpm  and saturating 95% on room air. Cardiac exam revealed a diastolic murmur best heard at the aortic area. No Osler nodes or Janeway lesions were noted. Lab findings showed mild leukocytosis  an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment:  The patient's clinical symptoms along with lab findings pointed toward possible infective endocarditis. An echocardiogram was ordered which revealed a vegetating mass on the aortic valve  confirming the diagnosis. Three separate blood cultures were taken 30 min apart  which grew Streptococcus viridans  corroborating with the diagnosis.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was started on intravenous (IV) Penicillin G  targeting the identified organism  and Gentamicin for its synergistic effect. Infectious Disease services were consulted for input on antibiotic regimen and duration. Upon the approval of the infectious disease team  the initial treatment regimen was continued.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  The patient responded well to treatment with resolution of fever after one week. Repeat blood cultures taken at the end of the second week showed no bacterial growth. The patient's general condition also improved significantly. He was discharged on the 28th day of admission with instructions to complete a 6-week course of IV antibiotics via a peripherally inserted central catheter. He will continue to follow up at the infectious diseases and cardiology outpatient clinics.  Patient Perspective:  The patient was relieved to see improvements in his health after starting the treatment. He expressed gratitude for the medical team's efforts and was committed to complete the full course of his prescribed medications.  Informed Consent:  The patient provided informed consent for producing this case report.  Peer Review:  This case report was peer-reviewed by the hospital’s Infectious Disease Board.

Title: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis in an Elderly Patient with Previous Rheumatic Heart Disease  Case Report: Patient Identity: A 71-year-old Caucasian male   Clinical Presentation: The patient presented to the emergency department with persistent high-grade fever for the past 10 days  associated with chills  sweating  fatigue  and loss of appetite. He also reported a recent unintentional weight loss (~7% of his body weight over two weeks). Notably  he had experienced similar episodes of fever three times in the last six months  each lasting a week and subsiding on its own without any specific treatment.  Past Medical History: The patient had been diagnosed with rheumatic heart disease (RHD) at the age of 12 and had been taking penicillin prophylaxis until the age of 20. Since then  he only took the medicine sporadically and discontinued it completely after the age of 40. He reported no other chronic conditions and mentioned he had been a social drinker up until 10 years ago. Regular annual medical check-ups for the past 5 years had not revealed any significant abnormality. He did not report any recent dental procedures  surgery  or intravenous drug use.  Physical Examination: He was febrile (102.5°F)  with a heart rate of 105 beats/minute and blood pressure at 115/70mmHg. Cardiac examination revealed a diastolic murmur over the mitral area. There were no notable pathological findings in other organ systems. There were no signs of peripheral stigmata of endocarditis.  Investigations: A series of blood cultures were ordered  all of which came back positive for Streptococcus viridans. Echocardiography revealed vegetations on the mitral valve  confirming the diagnosis of infective endocarditis (IE). There were signs of moderate-to-severe mitral regurgitation but no evidence for abscess  fistula  or other valvular abnormalities. Chest X-ray and ECG were within normal limits.  Treatment and Outcome: The patient was initiated on a four-week course of intravenous penicillin G and gentamicin in keeping with the sensitivity pattern. He responded well to the therapy  with fever subsiding within a week and significant improvement in his general condition. Post-treatment echocardiogram showed a reduction in the size of vegetations  and blood cultures were negative. However  due to persistent mitral regurgitation  the patient was referred for surgical evaluation of potential mitral valve repair or replacement.  Conclusion: This case underlines the significance of long-term prophylaxis in patients with RHD and the potential complications  such as IE in those who discontinue it. It emphasizes the importance of a high degree of suspicion for IE in patients with RHD presenting with recurrent unexplained fever. The further investigation  timely diagnosis  and appropriate antibiotic management are crucial in the overall prognosis of such patients  potentially avoiding the need for cardiac surgery.

Case Report: Title: Case of Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 58-year-old Woman  Patient Information: A 58-year-old Caucasian woman with a medical history of hypertension  Type II Diabetes Mellitus  and dyslipidemia presented to her primary care physician with complaints of general fatigue  intermittent fevers  overall weakness  and unexpected weight loss over a period of several weeks.  Description of Illness: The patient was initially managed with oral antibiotics for a presumed bacterial infection. However  her symptoms persisted despite the initial treatment. The woman reported that the fever was intermittent and predominantly in the evening  often associated with chills and sweats. She also indicated that she had lost around 10 pounds in the last month without trying to do so. No change in diet or exercise was reported.  Investigations: Physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg  an elevated pulse rate of 98 beats per minute  and a temperature of 38.5°C. Heart auscultation demonstrated a soft systolic ejection murmur in the aortic valve area and the presence of a new diastolic rumble at the apex. Laboratory analysis revealed elevated inflammatory markers  anemia  and positive blood cultures for Staphylococcus aureus. An electrocardiogram (ECG) exhibited no abnormalities. Chest x-ray was unremarkable.  Given the persistent bacteremia and the new cardiac murmur  the suspicion for endocarditis led to further investigations. A Transthoracic Echocardiogram (TTE) revealed an oscillating intracardiac mass on the aortic valve suggestive of a vegetation  confirming the diagnosis of infective endocarditis.   Treatment: The patient was urgently referred to a tertiary care center for specialized treatment. Empiric antibiotic therapy was immediately started with intravenous vancomycin and ceftriaxone  which was later adjusted to targeted treatment based on the sensitivities of Staphylococcus aureus isolated from her blood cultures.  Outcome and Follow-up: The patient's condition improved gradually following antibiotic therapy. However  due to the size and location of the vegetation on the valve  she eventually required surgical intervention to prevent further complications. A follow-up TTE after six weeks of starting antibiotics and post-surgery showed no vegetations with a normally functioning aortic valve. She was referred back to her primary care physician for continuous monitoring and follow-up.   Learning Points: This case highlights the atypical presentation of native-valve endocarditis in a patient with significant comorbidity. The importance of early detection  understanding the characteristic signs and symptoms  and prompt treatment of infective endocarditis is essential in significantly reducing associated morbidity and mortality. Clinicians must suspect endocarditis in any patient presenting with persistent fever and other systemic symptoms  regardless of their past cardiac history.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 68-year-old Male  Patient Information:  A 68-year-old Caucasian male was presented to the emergency department with symptoms including persistent fever  shortness of breath  and significant unintentional weight loss over the past month.  Medical History:  The patient had hypertension and hyperlipidemia that were being managed with prescribed medications: Amlodipine 5mg daily and Atorvastatin 20mg daily. He has an extensive history of tobacco use but quit smoking 12 years ago. He reported having a ""heart murmur"" years ago; however  he had not had any follow-up or treatment for it. He denied any previous history of intravenous drug use. He had no known drug allergies.  Investigations and Diagnosis:  On physical examination  he looked chronically ill  having a fever of 39.2 degrees Celsius. Cardiac examination revealed a pansystolic murmur most prominent in the mitral area. Laboratory tests showed marked leukocytosis  elevated C-reactive protein and a raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Blood cultures were taken.  An ECG showed sinus tachycardia but was otherwise unremarkable. Chest radiography demonstrated no active disease. The patient was admitted to the hospital  and empirical antibiotic treatment was initiated with Vancomycin and Gentamicin.  Transthoracic and Transesophageal echocardiography revealed significant mitral regurgitation with a vegetation of 1.2cm on the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve  suggestive of infective endocarditis. Blood cultures later confirmed growth of Streptococcus viridans.  Throughout his hospital stay  the patient underwent serial Echocardiograms to monitor progression of his vegetative lesions. His antibiotics were de-escalated based on culture sensitivity to Ceftriaxone alone  which was continued for the next six weeks.  Therapeutic Intervention:  His case was discussed with cardiothoracic surgery  and given the size of the vegetations and significant mitral regurgitation  he underwent mitral valve repair surgery. Post-operatively  the patient improved significantly. He had no further fever spikes  and his shortness of breath lessened.  Follow Up and Outcome:  The patient continued his six-week course of antibiotics post-operatively. He experienced a significant improvement in symptoms  his laboratory parameters returned to normal  and repeat echocardiography showed a well-functioning mitral valve with no residual regurgitation or vegetation.  The patient was discharged home on long-term prophylactic antibiotics (oral amoxicillin) and asked to follow up at a cardiology outpatient clinic regularly.  Conclusion:  This case report indicates the importance of considering a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis in older patients with a history of a heart murmur presenting with unexplained fever and weight loss. It also underscores the importance of the multi-disciplinary management of infective endocarditis  including cardiac imaging  targeted antimicrobial therapy  and when indicated  surgical intervention. Regular follow-up care is vital in managing symptoms and preventing potentially fatal complications.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 65-Year-Old Male: A Case Report  Introduction: Infective endocarditis (IE) is a severe and potentially life-threatening infection of the endocardial surface of the heart. Its presentation can be an insidious onset of non-specific systemic symptoms or an acute infection with rapidly progressive disease. We describe here a case of native-valve infective endocarditis in a 65-year old male.  Case Presentation: The patient  Mr. J  is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  non-smoker  who lives in an urban area. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed with amlodipine and metformin respectively.   Mr. J presented to the ER with a two-week history of intermittent fever  fatigue  and a new onset of shortness of breath. On admission  he was febrile (38.5°C)  his blood pressure was 130/80 mmHg  and his heart rate was 96 beats/minute. On physical examination  he had a diastolic murmur heard on the left sternal border  and Osler's nodes were present on examination of his hands and feet. No relevant travel or contact history was reported.  Investigations: Laboratory results on admission showed elevated white blood cell count (15 x 10^9/L)  elevated C-reactive protein (140 mg/L)  and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (70 mm/hr). Blood cultures were drawn. The patient also had elevated levels of HbA1c (8.6%).   A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) revealed vegetations on the tricuspid valve with severe tricuspid regurgitation  confirming the diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis. Blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus  a common causative agent of IE.  Management and Outcome: The patient was started on empiric intravenous antibiotics: nafcillin and gentamicin. After blood culture results  the regimen was continued due to the sensitivity of the Staphylococcus aureus bacteria to these antibiotics. The patient's infective endocarditis was managed medically due to the absence of indications for emergent surgical intervention  such as heart failure  uncontrolled infection  or the occurrence of systemic emboli.  Following four weeks of antibiotic therapy  the patient's condition improved significantly. Repeat blood cultures turned out negative  echocardiography showed a reduction in vegetation size  and he was no longer febrile. The patient was discharged and instructed to monitor his blood glucose levels more regularly.  Discussion: This case illustrates a typical presentation of native valve IE. It underscores the importance of early recognition given the substantial morbidity and mortality associated with the condition. It also emphasizes the importance of comprehensive patient history  physical examination  and the use of appropriate laboratory and imaging techniques for a timely diagnosis and treatment.  Conclusion: In infective endocarditis  early diagnosis and treatment can significantly improve outcomes. Despite improved diagnostic strategies and therapeutic options  IE remains a serious condition with high morbidity and mortality rates  especially in patients with risk factors like diabetes. Therefore  increased vigilance and aggressive treatment are essential.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 61-year-old Male: A Case Report  Introduction:  This case report presents a 61-year-old gentleman diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis. The aim of this report is to offer better insight into the clinical manifestations  risk factors  cardiac complications  and the importance of early diagnosis of this rare disease in middle-aged men.  Case Presentation:  A 61-year-old Caucasian male was admitted to our hospital with complaints of intermittent fever  night sweats  general malaise  and unintentional weight loss of about 10 pounds over a two-month span. The patient's medical history was remarkable for aortic stenosis and hypertension. He is a non-smoker and has a history of moderate alcohol intake. The patient has been on antihypertensive medication (Lisinopril) for the last 8 years and did not report having any dental procedures or invasive surgery recently.  On physical examination  the patient appeared generally unwell. He had a temperature of 38.8 degrees Celsius  blood pressure of 140/90 mm Hg  pulse rate of 92 beats per minute  and a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute. Cardiac auscultation revealed a diastolic murmur in the left sternal edge. There were no peripheral stigmata of endocarditis.   Investigations:  Laboratory findings showed leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 16 000/uL  raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate at 80mm/hr  and C-reactive protein at 96mg/L. Blood culture showed growth of Streptococcus Bovis. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) revealed large vegetation measuring 1.5 cm attached to the ventricular side of the aortic valve. The patient also underwent colonoscopy due to the association between Streptococcus Bovis and colorectal carcinomas  which was negative.  Diagnosis:  The patient's clinical presentation  positive blood cultures  and echocardiographic evidence clinched the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Management and Follow-Up:  The patient was started on intravenous ceftriaxone and gentamicin as per the AHA guidelines. Despite being on antibiotics  the patient's condition deteriorated due to congestive cardiac failure secondary to aortic valve destruction. We had an urgent consultation with the cardiothoracic team for valve replacement and the patient underwent successful biological aortic valve replacement.  The patient made a progressive recovery post-surgery and completed six weeks of antibiotic treatment. On follow-up visits  he was asymptomatic with a marked improvement in his overall condition. There were no signs of congestive heart failure and serial blood cultures were negative indicating resolution of endocarditis.  Conclusion:  This case report underscores the varied presentations of native-valve infective endocarditis. High clinical suspicion and early cardiac imaging are vital for prompt diagnosis. Despite successful valve replacement and antibiotic treatment  the prognosis remains challenging due to cardiac and embolic complications. It further elaborates the link between Streptococcus Bovis bacteremia  infective endocarditis  and colorectal cancer  emphasizing the importance of gastrointestinal screening in such patients.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 55-Year-Old Male  Demographics: Patient Information: Mr. J  a 55-year-old Caucasian male  Occupation: Manager at a local bank  Geography: Lives in an urban setting in Philadelphia  Medical History: Mr. J is a non-smoker with a medical history significant for diabetes mellitus type II which is well-controlled with metformin. He also has a documented history of hypertension treated with Lisinopril and Amlodipine. His family history reveals a father with ischaemic heart disease and a mother with rheumatoid arthritis. There are no previous episodes of infections requiring hospitalizations or prolonged antibiotic treatment.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. J presented to the hospital with a two-week history of intermittent fever  chills  malaise  and unintended weight loss of about 8-10 pounds. He also reported an episode of a night sweat. No history of chest pain  cough  or difficulty in breathing was reported.  Examination: Mr. J appeared pale and fatigued. His vital signs were as follows: Blood pressure - 140/90 mmHg  Heart rate - 100 beats per minute  Respiratory rate - 16 breaths per minute  and Temperature - 38.8°C. Cardiovascular examination revealed a diastolic murmur heard at the left sternal border. Other examinations were unremarkable.  Investigations and Diagnosis: Blood investigations showed a raised white cell count and C-reactive protein. Three sets of blood cultures were obtained over the next 24 hours as a part of the febrile illness workup. All blood cultures grew Methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA). Transthoracic Echocardiogram (TTE) identified an echodense vegetative mass attached to the native aortic valve  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Treatment & Outcome: Treatment was initiated immediately on confirmation of the diagnosis  with intravenous antibiotics (Nafcillin and Gentamycin) for 6 weeks duration guided by cultures sensitivity. His diabetic and hypertensive medications were continued and adjusted as necessary. He responded well to treatment  with resolution of fever  and serial blood cultures taken in the following weeks were negative. On repeat TTE at the end of therapy  the vegetative mass was significantly diminished. He was discharged with a plan to follow up in the outpatient clinic.  Conclusion: This case demonstrates the importance of maintaining a high index of suspicion for infective endocarditis in patients with equivocal symptoms  especially those with risk factors like diabetes. Always consider endocarditis in patients with unexplained fever  weight loss  and positive blood cultures. Early detection and treatment can result in good outcomes as in our patient Mr. J.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 65-year-old Male  Patient Information The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  currently a resident in Boston  Massachusetts. He is a retired engineer with a notable history of moderate tobacco use  being a smoker for 30 years before ceasing 10 years ago.   Medical History Prior to his current health concern  the patient was diagnosed with hypertension  which has been managed with amlodipine besylate and lisinopril for the past 10 years  and type II diabetes mellitus for 8 years controlled by diet modification and metformin. He has no known drug allergies. There's a familial history of coronary artery disease  with his father dying from a myocardial infarction at age 70. The patient has been highly compliant with all medication and regularly follows up with his primary care physician. He is of average build and has a BMI within the normal range.   Current Medical Issue Recently  he presented with a three-week history of intermittent fever  fatigue  and unexplained weight loss. Physical examination revealed a new systolic murmur at the left sternal border. His temperature was elevated at 38.4 Celsius  and blood pressure was relatively stable at 130/80 mmHg. Apart from mild pallor and diaphoresis  no other signs of illness were noted on physical examination.   Clinical Findings  Laboratory findings showed leukocytosis with a WBC count of 13 000 per mm3. His ESR was elevated at 60 mm/hr. Blood cultures grew Streptococcus viridans  and transesophageal echocardiography revealed a 2 cm vegetation on the mitral valve  leading to a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.   Diagnosis The patient was diagnosed with definite native valve infective endocarditis (IE) based on the modified Duke Criteria: Two major criteria  (1) positive blood cultures with typical IE organisms  and (2) evidence of endocardial involvement with positive echocardiogram showing a vegetation.  Treatment Patient was administered empiric IV antibiotic therapy (Vancomycin and Ceftriaxone) as per the American Heart Association (AHA) guidelines for IE.   Discussion This case highlights the importance of the early diagnosis of infective endocarditis in patients with new onset cardiac murmurs and prolonged unexplained fever. The patient was at a higher risk owing to his advancing age  the presence of risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes mellitus  and a history of smoking. Successful diagnosis and management require integrating the clinical history  physical exam  microbiologic  and imaging data. Early and appropriate treatment is critical to prevent complications such as heart failure  systemic embolization  and death.   Acknowledgement The patient  his immediate and extended family  as well as the medical team are thanked for their relentless support  effort  and cooperation that ensured successful diagnosis and initiation of treatment. All medical ethical guidelines have been strictly adhered to throughout the case.   Confidentiality The identity of the patient has strictly been kept confidential and is known only to the administrative staff involved in the case. The name of the patient has not been disclosed here to protect his identity.

Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 65-Year-Old Male: A Case Report  Introduction  This case report describes a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presented with symptoms and signs of native-valve infective endocarditis (IE). The patient agreed to provide consent for his case to be written for potential publication.  Case Presentation  A 65-year-old Caucasian male  a retired construction worker  presented to the emergency department with complaints of high-grade fever  chills  fatigue  mild shortness of breath  night sweats  and weight loss over the past four weeks. The patient denied any history of intravenous drug use  recent dental procedures  or any systemic illnesses.  Past Medical History  The patient had a history of hypertension for the past ten years  which was well-managed by enalapril  and type II diabetes  controlled with metformin. He had no known allergies or previous major surgeries. The patient had a history of smoking one pack of cigarettes per day for the last 40 years.  Clinical Findings  Physical examination revealed a temperature of 38.8° C  a regular pulse rate of 110 beats per minute  blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  and respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. Cardiac examination found a new systolic ejection murmur in the aortic area while lung auscultation revealed no crackles. Mild splenomegaly was noted on abdominal examination.  Investigations  Lab parameters showed an elevated white blood cell count  elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)  and C-reactive protein (CRP). Blood cultures were drawn and sent to the lab for testing. Transthoracic echocardiography revealed an oscillating intracardiac mass on the aortic valve  suggestive of vegetation. Blood cultures confirmed growth of Streptococcus viridans  confirming the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Treatment  The patient was started on intravenous antibiotics according to the susceptibility of the cultured organism. The antibiotic regimen consisted of ceftriaxone (2g every 24 hours) and gentamicin (1 mg/kg every 8 hours). Despite intensive antibiotic therapy  the patient showed no clinical improvement  and surgical intervention was deemed necessary. The patient underwent successful aortic valve replacement.  Outcome and Follow-up  Post-operatively  the patient showed good progress with resolution of his fever and symptoms. He completed a six-week course of intravenous antibiotics. A follow-up echocardiogram after one month showed normal prosthetic valve function  and blood cultures were negative. He was advised on stringent blood sugar control  cessation of smoking  and regular follow-up.  Discussion  This case accentuates the importance of early diagnosis and management of native-valve infective endocarditis. Meticulous attention to clinical findings  combined with appropriate investigations  can aid in prompt diagnosis. Timely initiation of appropriate antibiotics  along with surgical intervention when indicated  plays a crucial role in patient prognosis.   Consent  Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.  Keywords: Case report  Native-valve infective endocarditis  Streptococcus viridans

Case Report:  Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis in a 65-year-old Male with a Past Cardiovascular History   Patient Information:   A 65-year-old Caucasian male was presented to the hospital with a 1-week history of high-grade fever  fatigue  anorexia  and mild difficulty in breathing. These symptoms had been increasing in severity over the week. The patient resides in San Francisco  California  and is retired. He is divorced  has two children  and lives alone. He was a chronic smoker until five years back and consumed alcohol occasionally. The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension and ischemic heart disease.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  the patient appeared ill and in discomfort. His temperature was 101.2°F (38.4°C)  pulse rate was 88 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 20 breaths per minute  and blood pressure was 145/90 mmHg. Heart sound examination revealed a diastolic murmur. Minor petechiae were observed on his extremities.   Diagnostic Assessment:  Laboratory blood tests showed leukocytosis (16 000 cells/µL) and elevated C-reactive protein (56 mg/L). Blood cultures were performed and found positive for Staphylococcus aureus. An echocardiogram was conducted which indicated vegetations on the mitral valve  confirming the diagnosis of infective endocarditis. Stress electrocardiogram test showed symptoms of ischemic heart disease.
