He is a lacto-ovo vegetarian with no history of alcohol or drug abuse.  Past Medical History: Mr. A has a reported past medical history of Rheumatic Fever as a child  hypertension  and Type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he has been on medication. He had a hip replacement operation 2 years ago  due to osteoarthritis and he has been experiencing recurring dental infections for the last 6 months which were intermittently managed with antibiotics.  Family History: Mr. A’s father died at 65 from a stroke  and his mother died at 78 from complications of diabetes. He has one brother who is alive and well  with no known illnesses. There is no family history of heart diseases or other genetic disorders.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. A was admitted with a three-week history of intermittent fevers  night sweats  loss of appetite  weight loss  and increasing fatigue. He also reported experiencing a general malaise and shortness of breath  especially on exertion. There was no chest pain  coughing or palpitations. A full cardiovascular examination revealed a new heart murmur.  Investigations and Diagnosis: The investigations included blood tests  cardiac monitoring  and echocardiography. Blood culture results indicated the presence of Streptococcus viridans. His EKG showed slight irregularities. The transthoracic echocardiogram highlighted vegetation on the mitral valve  confirming a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Management and Prognosis: The patient was started on a regimen of IV penicillin and gentamicin for aggressive antibacterial therapy. He was also managed for his symptoms and other co-morbidities. The patient responded positively to treatment at the six-week follow-up. He was advised on strict blood glucose level management and better oral health to prevent recurrence.  In conclusion  Mr. A's case was unusually complex due to his comorbidities and social demographics. The combined input of cardiology  infectious disease  and oral health teams was necessary to manage his condition effectively. This situation underscores the importance of considering a wide differential diagnosis in elderly patients with non-specific symptoms. It also highlights the integral role dental health plays in the bigger picture of overall wellness and prevention of severe conditions such as endocarditis.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Information: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male named John. He has a history of intravenous drug use and has been clean for the last 15 years. He is a retired mechanic  currently living with his wife  and has a family history of heart disease  with his father dying at the age of 68 due to a heart attack. His mother  aged 85  is alive and suffers from type 2 diabetes and hypertension.   Medical History: The patient has an existing medical condition of type 1 diabetes for over 25 years  for which he uses insulin. He also suffers from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to a history of heavy smoking  and he quit smoking ten years ago. He has no known allergies. His last documented dental examination was about 2 years ago  unaware of any dental problems.  Presenting Issue: John presented to the ED with complaints of high fever  chills  night sweats  shortness of breath  persistent cough  and generalized body weakness for the past 3 weeks. He also reported unintentional weight loss of approximately 10lbs  fatigue  and occasional chest discomfort.  Examination: Physical examination revealed pallor  petechiae over the upper body and a temperature of 102 Fahrenheit. Cardiac examination showed a diastolic murmur. Respiratory examination revealed reduced breath sounds in lower zones. There was no peripheral oedema.  Lab and Diagnostic Test: Blood tests showed increased WBC count  elevated ESR and CRP. Three sets of blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus. Chest X-ray showed no evidence of any lung infection. ECG was unremarkable. Transthoracic echocardiogram revealed large mobile vegetation attached to the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve. These findings were consistent with infective endocarditis.  Management & Follow-up: The patient was started on empiric antibiotic therapy with Vancomycin until the sensitivity report was available. Given the size of the vegetation and potential for embolization  the case was discussed with the cardiothoracic surgery team. The patient underwent successful mitral valve replacement and is currently recovering well. This case merits careful follow-up for assessment of treatment response  complication surveillance  and secondary prevention.  Teaching Points: This case emphasizes the importance of considering infective endocarditis in a patient with heart murmurs and persistent unexplained symptoms like fatigue  fever  and weight loss. Native valve IE  frequently seen with S. aureus infections  should also alert physicians of the possible underlying immunosuppressive conditions  such as Diabetes in our patient  as S. aureus is a common organism causing IE in these patients. Regular dental check-ups and good oral hygiene also play a vital role in preventing infective endocarditis.

Subject Case Presentation:  Patient Profile  The patient  Mr. L  is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  a retired engineer  who resides in the mid-west region of the United States and has a history of chronic smoking (30 pack years)  regular alcohol consumption (20 units per week)  and type 2 diabetes mellitus (diagnosed 14 years ago). He was referred by his primary care physician for further investigation due to persistent fever and malaise for the last three weeks. He lives with his wife and has two adult children. There is no significant family history of cardiac disorders or other chronic illnesses.   Presenting Complaint   Mr. L. complained of intermittent fever  fatigue  loss of weight  and night sweats lasting for 3 weeks. He was diagnosed with a severe middle ear infection 1 month ago  but his symptoms persisted despite receiving antibiotics.  Clinical Findings   Physical examination revealed a diastolic murmur in the aortic region. Ophthalmic examination noticed Roth's spots and the patient reported experiencing double vision occasionally. Laboratory tests noted increased ESR (Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate) and CRP (C-reactive protein)  suggesting an inflammatory process. Echocardiography revealed a mobile echogenic mass on the aortic valve suggestive of vegetation. Blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus. Additional investigations also showed the presence of microabscesses in the spleen  suggesting septic emboli.  Diagnosis  Based on the patient's clinical presentation  laboratory findings  history of recent middle ear infection  and echocardiographic findings  he has been diagnosed with Native Valve Infective Endocarditis predominantly involving the aortic valve. The presence of Staphylococcus aureus in blood cultures suggests a secondary septicemia leading to infective endocarditis.  Treatment Plan   The patient is currently on empirical antibiotic therapy under hospital surveillance. The therapy includes an intravenous regimen of nafcillin and gentamicin  with the aim of targeting the isolated Staphylococcus aureus. Blood glucose levels are controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents. Consultation with Cardiology and Infectious Disease specialists have been arranged. The patient's progress will be closely monitored  and cardiac intervention might be required if his condition persists or deteriorates.   Patient Education and Follow-Up   Mr. L has been encouraged to abstain from alcohol and smoking to improve his overall health status and reduce the risk of comorbid conditions. He will be closely monitored throughout his active treatment  and a long-term follow-up plan will be established to avoid any re-infection or potential complications related to infective endocarditis.

Patient Information: The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. J  a retired engineer  who resides in Ohio. He has a 30-year history of controlled hypertension and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 10 years ago. His father had a history of stroke in his late 70s  and his mother died of a heart attack in her 60s. Mr. J has been married for 40 years and has two adult children  both healthy. He is a non-smoker but admits to having 1-2 glasses of red wine every night before dinner since his retirement. He reports that he struggles with maintaining a regular exercise regime due to arthritic pain in his knees.  Presenting Problem: Mr. J was admitted to the emergency department with complaints of persistent fever  weakness  loss of appetite  and weight loss over two weeks. Physical examination revealed a systolic murmur and an echocardiogram showed vegetation on mitral valve consistent with infective endocarditis.   Investigations: Upon admission  blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus viridans  the underlying bacteria typically associated with dental procedures. He recently visited a dentist for his biannual check-up where he had a tooth extraction for a dental abscess. However  he didn't take prophylactic antibiotics before the procedure due to his reported penicillin allergy. An EKG was performed to rule out any other cardiac pathology  which appeared within normal limits.   The patient's blood glucose level was elevated due to poor glycemic control. His HbA1c was 8.5%  and his LDL cholesterol was above the recommended limit. He was also found to be slightly anemic  with a hemoglobin of 11g/dL.  Diagnosis: Based on his clinical presentation  lab results  and echocardiogram findings  Mr. J was diagnosed with native valve infective endocarditis.  Current Status: Mr. J is currently stable and has been put on intravenous antibiotics. Consultation with a dietician has been done to address his elevated blood sugar levels and LDL cholesterol. We have also consulted cardiology for a potential treatment plan if the mitral valve damage continues to deteriorate.  Course of Treatment:  Considering all potential problems including diabetes  arthritis  hypertension  and recent heart condition  a comprehensive treatment plan will be implemented. Although the patient’s endocarditis is being targeted with broad-spectrum antibiotics for 4-6 weeks  a multidisciplinary plan regarding dietary changes  improved diabetic management  rehabilitation program (that takes into account the patient's knee arthritis) is in development.   Due to his penicillin allergy  sensitivities were conducted after culture of the bacteria in order to prescribe the most effective and safe antibiotic. Regular follow-ups with the cardiology team  in addition to the echos already completed  will be essential to monitor Mr. J's heart valve function.  Long-Term Prognosis: If Mr. J responds well to antibiotic treatment  has good control of his blood glucose level  maintains a balanced diet as guided by the dietician  and adheres to regular exercise within his ability  his quality of life can be maximized  and the risk of further cardiovascular complications can be minimized. This case underscores the importance of always considering infective endocarditis in patients with a history of any heart valve disease who present with persisting unexplained fever  particularly if they have undergone any dental procedures recently. It also highlights the necessity of antibiotic prophylaxis in at-risk patients undergoing invasive procedures.

Patient Information: Mr. J  a 58-year-old Caucasian male.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. J presented with a 3-week history of fever  fatigue  weight loss and night sweats.  Medical History: Mr. J has a past medical history of rheumatoid arthritis for which he has been on long-term steroid therapy. He also has a moderate to high consumption of alcohol. Recently  Mr. J underwent a dental procedure for which he did not receive antibiotic prophylaxis.  Family History: He has a strong family history of heart disease with his father having died of a heart attack at the age of 65. His mother is alive and well at 82.   Physical Examination: Upon examination  Mr. J appears unwell with a low-grade fever of 100.8°F. His heart sounds include a distinct murmur which was not documented in his previous medical records. He also displays evidences of peripheral stigmata of endocarditis including splinter hemorrhages under the nails and Janeway lesions on the palms and soles.   Investigations: Blood tests show elevated inflammatory markers  anemia and evidence of renal impairment. Blood cultures show growth of Streptococcus viridans. An echocardiogram reveals vegetations on the mitral valve suggestive of infective endocarditis.   Assessment: Based on his recent dental procedure  symptoms  physical examination and lab results  Mr. J is diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis. Not receiving antibiotic prophylaxis before his dental procedure and his immunosuppressed state due to long-term steroid therapy for his rheumatoid arthritis are likely contributory risk-factor.  Plan: Mr. J will be initiated on appropriate intravenous antibiotic therapy for at least 4-6 weeks as recommended by the local antibiotic guidelines and depending on the antibiotic sensitivity. He will regularly be followed up with blood tests  echocardiograms and closely monitored for any sign of treatment failure  complications or side effects. Alcohol cessation counselling and resources are also provided.   The above case presentation is a simplified example and real-life cases may involve a more detailed evaluation and more complex decision-making steps.

Patient Presentation:  Patient identifier: AS   Sex: Male   Age: 58   Ethnicity: Caucasian   Occupation: Construction worker  Chief Implementation:  AS presented to the hospital with a 7-day history of fever and malaise. He initially took over the counter analgesics  but when the fever did not subside  he decided to seek further medical help. He also reported a mild to moderate joint and muscle pain  occasional night sweats  and loss of appetite.  Past Medical History:  AS was previously diagnosed with type II diabetes and hypertension. He disclosed a history of rheumatic fever in his teens. He has been treated for dental caries on numerous occasions. No prior surgeries noted. He is a smoker of 20 years and has a history of moderate alcohol consumption.  Family history:  Father died at the age of 65 from heart disease. Mother is alive and has hypertension. He has no siblings. One son  age 30  is healthy.  Physical Examination:  On physical examination  AS appeared ill but not in acute distress. His temperature was 101.3°F  pulse was 95 beats per minute  blood pressure was 135/85 mm Hg  and respiratory rate was 20 breaths per minute. Cardiac auscultation revealed a systolic murmur. Skin inspection revealed petechial rashes on his lower limbs.  Investigations:  Blood investigations revealed markedly elevated white blood cell count. Blood cultures returned positive for Streptococcus viridans. Transthoracic echocardiography showed vegetation on the aortic valve with evidence of valve destruction and regurgitation.  Diagnosis:  On the basis of these findings  the patient was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis.  Treatment Plan:  Initially  AS was admitted to the hospital and started on intravenous Penicillin based on blood culture sensitivities. He was also given Gentamicin for its synergistic effect against S. viridans. Patient will need long-term antibiotic therapy. It was decided to monitor the valve function closely and intervene surgically if signs of heart failure developed or if there were complications related to endocarditis.  Patient Education and Follow-up:  Patient was counselled on the need for good oral hygiene considering his dental history. He was also advised and encouraged to quit smoking and reduce alcohol intake. A follow-up after one week of the initial treatment was scheduled to check for the therapeutic effectiveness and potential side effects of the medication.  In summary  this case highlights the importance of early recognition and management of infective endocarditis in a patient with history of rheumatic fever and several risk factors such as poor oral hygiene  smoking  and diabetes.

Patient Profile:  Mr. J is a 58-year-old Caucasian male who presented at the hospital with complaints of acute fever  malaise  and unintended weight loss in the past month. He hails from a semi-rural region and documents suggest sporadic  non-compliant encounters with healthcare providers in the past mostly due to financial constraint.  Current Presentation:  The patient arrived at the hospital  appearing septic and fatigued. Upon physical examination  fever (39.8 C) and a new murmur were discerned. Lab tests  including blood cultures  were immediately ordered and treatment initiated for presumed sepsis while awaiting definitive culture and sensitivity results.  Medical History:  Mr. J is a known smoker  with a 20-pack year history and an occasional alcohol drinker. He has a past medical history of rheumatic fever at age 19  and he was treated with Penicillin. Following that bout  he was diagnosed with mild aortic regurgitation. Mr. J does not take any daily medications.  Family History:  There is no family history of infective endocarditis  rheumatic fever  congenital heart diseases  or early-onset of atherosclerotic diseases. His father died of lung cancer at the age of 67 and his mother of a stroke at age 80. He has one brother who is in good health.  Clinical Findings:  Echocardiography indicated aortic vegetations  and blood cultures became positive for Streptococcus viridans. WBC count was significantly elevated and inflammatory markers (CRP  ESR) were significantly high.   Diagnosis:  Given his clinical presentation  significant findings on the physical exam  positive blood cultures  and confirmation of vegetations on echocardiography  Mr. J was diagnosed with native valve infective endocarditis.  Treatment:  Mr. J was started on empirical antibiotic treatment with Vancomycin and Gentamycin under sepsis protocol initially and then de-escalated to intravenous Penicillin G based on culture and sensitivity results  exhibiting sensitivity towards Streptococcus viridans  for a treatment duration of 4 weeks.  Discussion:  Infective endocarditis in a case of native valve disease triggered by Streptococcus viridans is a fatal condition that necessitates prompt diagnosis  aggressive blood culture-guided antimicrobial treatment  proper valve surgery when indicated  and steps to prevent further systemic complications. This case is critical as it underlines the importance of regular follow-ups in patients with a predisposition  such as rheumatic heart disease  for infective endocarditis  and the requirement of correct antibiotic therapy based on culture sensitivities.  This case also highlights the importance of understanding our population's social determinants of health. Lower socioeconomic status and barriers to accessing healthcare can contribute to these types of severe disease presentations. Recognizing these barriers and addressing them at a system level is crucial to prevent such occurrences.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 60-year-old Caucasian male  has been presented with a confirmed case of native-valve infective endocarditis. The patient is known to smoke about a pack of cigarettes a day with a 35-year smoking history. He is a known alcoholic but quit about 5 years ago. His father had cardiovascular disease and his mother died at the age of 78 from complications of diabetes. He has a brother diagnosed with hypertension. There is no other significant family history of illnesses. John works as a construction manager and has no known allergies.  Past Medical History:  John has a medical history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension  both of which are moderately controlled by prescribed medications. His diabetic condition was discovered about 10 years ago and he has been on Metformin since then. His hypertension was diagnosed 5 years ago and managed by Lisinopril. He is noted to be under continuous surveillance for these conditions.   Presentation of Illness:  John presented to the hospital with complaints of acute shortness of breath  high-grade intermittent fever  rapid weight loss  night sweats  and fatigue for the past 2 weeks. He also observed small red or purple spots on his skin  consistent with petechiae. Physical examination revealed a new cardiac murmur suggesting valvular vegetations. No noted neurological  abdominal  or pulmonary changes were present.   Diagnostics:  His CBC reported a high white cell count indicating the presence of an infection and an elevated ESR  both suggesting an inflammatory process. Blood cultures were taken which came back positive for Staphylococcus aureus. An Echocardiography confirmed the presence of mobile vegetations on the mitral valve  suggesting infective endocarditis. Other routine tests such as kidney and liver functions were normal  except for a slightly impaired glucose intolerance.  Discussion:  Considering the serious nature of his condition  the patient was started on empirical antibiotic therapy before blood culture results were available. Once the organism was identified  the treatment strategy was altered to target the specific pathogen. He was admitted to the hospital for close monitoring and continued intravenous antibiotic therapy as per Infective Endocarditis guidelines by American Heart Association.  Plan:  The plan is to complete 4–6 weeks of targeted antibiotic therapy and regularly monitor his symptoms  inflammatory markers  and cultures. Regular echocardiograms will be taken to monitor the condition of his heart valves. Due to his smoking habit and medical history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension  he is at risk for further cardiovascular complications. The patient has been advised to quit smoking with the help of a cessation program. Counseling on lifestyle modification  diet  and exercise were also advised to better control his diabetes and hypertension. The patient will be kept for regular follow-ups to monitor his condition. If the infection cannot be properly controlled with antibiotic therapy  the option of surgical intervention may have to be contemplated.

Patient Description The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis (NVIE). Past medical history reveals he had suffered a mild heart attack five years prior  and has been on a regular coronary artery disease medication schedule ever since. He also has a past history of high cholesterol that is well-controlled with medication.  Medical History The patient was diagnosed with type II diabetes about eight years ago and is insulin-dependent. There is no history of any kidney disease  liver disease  or chronic pulmonary disease. Past surgical history reveals he had undergone an appendectomy 30 years ago  and cholecystectomy 10 years ago. He neither smokes nor drinks alcohol  and maintains a balanced diet. Despite his past illnesses  the patient remains active with regular exercise.  Family History His father died from a heart attack at 65  while his mother died at 70 due to complications of Alzheimer's disease. Patient has one elder brother diagnosed with diabetes in his late fifties.   Current Presentation He presented to the hospital with complaints of excessive fatigue  night sweats  intermittent fever  and unexplained weight loss for the past month. Physical examination revealed a temperature of 101F  blood pressure at 130/90 mmHg and heart rate at 110 bpm. Cardiovascular examination showed early diastolic murmur at the left sternal edge. The patient was immediately admitted for further diagnostic workup.  Investigations Lab findings included leukocytosis  raised ESR  and positive blood cultures for Staphylococcus aureus. Echo cardiogram revealed vegetations on the ventricular aspect of the aortic valve. This  coupled with his clinical and laboratory findings  confirmed the diagnosis of NVIE.  Summary The patient was started on an empiric antibiotic therapy (vancomycin and gentamicin) for NVIE  pending the results of blood culture susceptibility tests. His diabetes also needed better management to reduce further complications. Cardiology consultation was sought for potential surgical intervention  given the patient's history of coronary artery disease and the present condition. His course of treatment also includes aggressive cardiovascular risk factor modification  lifestyle alterations and stress reduction procedures. Regular follow-ups and ongoing cardiac monitoring were suggested for the patient.

Case Presentation:  Patient Profile: Mr. James Brown is a 62-year-old African American male with a history of intravenous drug use. He is currently homeless and has been frequently living in shelters. He was brought to the ER after one of the homeless shelter workers noticed something was off - he was feverish  disoriented  and with complaints of severe fatigue  breathlessness  and chest discomfort.  Past Medical History: His medical history is significant for unrepaired Tetralogy of Fallot diagnosed in childhood which has untreated bicuspid aortic valve and moderate asthma. His dental condition is poor and he reports that his last dental visit was over two years ago. His last contact with health services was a year ago when he was treated for community-acquired pneumonia. For psychiatric history  he is a recovering heroin and alcohol addict  although still tends to relapse occasionally.  Family History: Patient's father died of a heart attack in his late sixties and mother has hypertension. He has two siblings - one has diabetes and the other with no significant history.  Examination and Investigations: On physical examination  he appeared ill  sweating profusely and with evident difficulty breathing. His body mass index (BMI) was 22. Cardiovascular examination revealed irregular heart sounds consistent with a heart murmur. His vital signs showed elevated heart rate and body temperature of 101°F. Lab work revealed elevated white blood cell count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Blood cultures were sampled and sent for identification. A subsequent transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was helpful in further evaluation  demonstrating vegetations on the bicuspid aortic valve.  Diagnosis: After observing the patient’s symptoms  past medical history  and the initial assessment and diagnostic studies  the patient was diagnosed with native valve infective endocarditis  a common condition among intravenous drug users. This diagnosis was supported by his symptoms  physical examination outcomes  and both laboratory and imaging evidence of infection. His unrepaired congenital heart condition and the bicuspid aortic valve are risk factors for endocarditis.  Management and Follow-Up: The patient was admitted to the cardiology department and was started on broad-spectrum IV antibiotics  according to the potentially causative organisms and as per guidelines. A multi-disciplinary team approach  including infectious diseases  cardiology  and cardiac surgery was discussed given the severity of his condition and his social circumstances. The patient's dental health was also addressed and referred for urgent dental care. He was also enrolled in a drug rehabilitation program.    In conclusion  this case emphasizes the need for urgent attention to signs and symptoms suggestive of potentially serious conditions like infective endocarditis  particularly in high-risk groups. Collaboration between different specialties is also vital for optimal management.

Presenting Patient Information:  Patient Profile: A 52-year-old Caucasian male.  Presenting Complaint: Complaining of intermittent fever paired with rigours  chills  migraines and episodes of night sweats for the last 10 days.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of rheumatic fever during childhood but no significant illnesses past that point. He was occasionally consuming alcohol and was prescribed nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS) two weeks ago for left shoulder pain secondary to osteoarthritis.  Family History: His mother died of a myocardial infarction in her 60s  and his father is alive in his 80s with hypertension.  Examination: On examination  the patient appeared acutely ill  with a temperature of 38.5°C  heart rate of 90/min  blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg  and a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per min. On cardiac examination  a systolic murmur was noted at the apex radiating to the axilla.  Investigations: Lab tests showed a high erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein suggestive of inflammation. The full blood count demonstrated anemia and mild leukocytosis. Multiple sets of blood cultures grew Streptococcus oralis. Chest X-ray was normal while Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) showed a vegetative lesion attached to the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve.  Diagnosis: The patient met definitive infectious endocarditis (IE) criteria based on Modified Duke Criteria - positive blood cultures (for S. oralis – a known IE-causing organism) and echocardiographic evidence of vegetative lesion on mitral valve. Given his history of rheumatic fever  this is classified as Native Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVIE).  Treatment: He was started on Penicillin G and Gentamicin as per the specialist advice. The patient was counseled about his condition and importance of adherence to the therapy.  Discussion: This case represents a typical presentation of NVIE with a history of rheumatic fever  presenting symptoms  and confirmatory lab and imaging results. The patient didn't have any recent dental procedures but was on NSAIDS  which might have been a risk factor. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial in managing this serious condition as delay can lead to grave complications including heart failure  systemic embolism  and death.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Jones  who was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis. He works as an office clerk and lives in a suburban neighborhood with his wife.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Jones has a history significant for rheumatic fever at the age of 12  managed with antibiotic therapy. He also suffers from Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  diagnosed ten years ago and is managed by hyperglycemic agents and lifestyle modifications. His lipid profile shows borderline hyperlipidemia. He is a reformed smoker. His BMI is 28  and he is working on weight management and fitness with diet and low-intensity exercises on the advice of his physician. He reports no known allergies to food or medications.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Jones presented with a 2-week history of low-grade fever  chills  malaise  and a significant reduction in weight. He also complained of a occasional chest discomfort  mostly noted at rest  but not radiating and without any known triggers.  Family History:  His father passed away at 67 due to myocardial infarction  and his mother is alive at 83  diagnosed with hypertension and osteoarthritis. His younger brother  55  has recently been diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus.  Laboratory Findings:  Blood cultures came back positive  revealing Streptococcus viridans. ESR  CRP  and WBC count were elevated. Echocardiographic findings were consistent with infective endocarditis  revealing vegetations on the mitral valve. In addition  HbA1c level was found to be 7.2%.  Management Plan:  Mr. Jones was admitted to the cardiology department and started on empiric IV antibiotics  with a plan to adjust as per the culture and sensitivity results. His diabetic medications were reviewed and adjusted  as maintaining good control of his blood sugar levels is essential for his overall management. After a heart team discussion  surgery is being considered if there's no response to medical treatment given the extent of valve's involvement and symptoms of heart failure.  Discussion:  In this patient  the infective endocarditis could likely be attributed to the sequela of past rheumatic heart disease which damaged heart valves and predispose them to infections. His suboptimal diabetes management may have also played a role in the risk towards this infection.  In terms of Mr. Jones' cardiovascular risk  the combination of familial predisposition  diabetes  obesity  and hyperlipidemia places him in a high-risk category. Though he has stopped smoking  his past history may have contributed to his overall cardiovascular burden. His management needs to be multidisciplinary  involving cardiology  infectious diseases  diabetology  and dietetics. His family should also be educated about the nature of the condition  compliance with treatment  and symptoms that warrant urgent medical care.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presented with a two-week history of fever  night sweats  and fatigue. He has no known allergies. His past medical history includes hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  which are well controlled with his current medication regimens of metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin  respectively. He does not smoke  drinks alcohol occasionally  and denies illicit drug use. His family history is significant for early onset cardiovascular disease  having a father who died at age 50 of a heart attack. In terms of the social history  he’s a retired engineer  married with two children.  Upon admission  a physical examination revealed a dental abscess and a new murmur over the mitral valve area. The patient reported recent poor dental hygiene due to fear of going to the dentist during the COVID-19 pandemic. Other findings include weight loss of approximately 5 pounds over the last month unintentionally. Laboratory test indicated increased serum inflammatory markers (ESR and CRP)  leucocytosis  and anemia. EKG showed no signs of ischemia or infarction.   Blood cultures were drawn and returned positive for Streptococcus viridans. Echocardiogram demonstrated thickening consistent with vegetation on his native mitral valve  with no significant valvular dysfunction noted. Based on these findings  the patient was diagnosed with native-valve infective endocarditis due to streptococcal infection.   Management and Treatment:  The patient was started on appropriate antibiotic therapy (penicillin G and gentamicin). The patient was carefully monitored for potential complications including heart failure  systemic embolism  and abscess formation. He was informed about the need for strict dental hygiene measures to avoid recurrence of infective endocarditis.  Recommendation:  It was recommended that the patient stay admitted to receive the complete course of IV antibiotic therapy and to procure supervision from a dental care provider for management of his dental abscess. It was advised that he resume his daily medications while recovering in the hospital.  Furthermore  he was referred to a cardiologist for a follow-up to monitor the progress of his treatment. Patient education was provided regarding signs and symptoms of complications of infective endocarditis that should prompt immediate medical attention.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  A 55-year-old Hispanic male  Past Medical History: Known case of type II Diabetes Mellitus on oral hypoglycemics for the past 10 years. History of smoking and chronic alcohol consumption.  Presenting Complaints:   The patient was brought into the Emergency Department with complaints of fever of unknown origin for the past two weeks. He has been having highs and lows with intermittent peaks. It has been associated with chills  and profuse sweating especially at night  but without any localized pain or specific time period. He also complains of generalized fatigue  weight loss of about 5 kilos over the past month  loss of appetite  and shortness of breath on exertion for the past week. He denies any cough  chest pain  vomiting  diarrhea  burn micturition  or rashes.  Physical Examination:  On examination  he is febrile and appears ill  conscious but disoriented. His vitals are BP- 110/70 mm Hg  pulse- 88 bpm  RR-22/min. Cardiovascular examination reveals a heart murmur.  Based on the above history and examination  a further evaluation with focus on infective endocarditis may be conducted.+

Patient Information:  Mr. Smith  60-year-old male  hailing from Hoboken  New Jersey. He is working as a construction manager and leading a sedentary lifestyle. His BMI is 31 and has a history of cigarette smoking (30 pack- year). He neither consumes alcohol nor uses illicit drugs.  Past medical history:  Mr. Smith has a known hypertensive since 10 years and has complained of dyslipidemia. He had a dental extraction performed one month ago.  Presenting Complaints: The patient reported a sudden onset of high-grade fever accompanied by chills  sudden weight loss  fatigue  night sweats and shortness of breath  especially on exertion. On further questioning  he mentions experiencing a loss of appetite and a new  changing heart murmur.  Upon examination  Osler's nodes in his fingers and toes and Janeway's lesions were noted. A cardiac examination revealed a diastolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border.  Blood cultures were positive for Streptococcus viridans  and immunological investigations show positive rheumatoid factor and elevated ESR and C - reactive protein.  With these clinical features and investigations  a tentative diagnosis of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis is made  more investigations are planned to confirm the diagnosis. The patient has been advised hospital admission for further work-up and management.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. Derek Webb  male  65 years old  Caucasian  married  retired engineer. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. He resides in the urban suburbs of Chicago  Illinois with his wife.  Past Medical History:  He has a medical history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension  managed with Metformin and Lisinopril respectively for the past 5 years. He is also regularly monitored by his primary care physician and takes his medications compliantly. He underwent a dental procedure 2 weeks ago. There is no known allergy history.  Key Complaints: Mr. Webb presented to his primary care physician complaining of an intermittent high-grade fever of 2 weeks duration  associated with chills  fatigue  and significant weight loss. He also mentioned experiencing night sweats and intermittent headaches  which he initially attributed to his age and changes in the weather. Also  he reported experiencing a new-onset palpitation  which was rare before and was reviewed as mild.   Physical inspection revealed paleness  mild edema on his feet  slight petechiae on his upper extremities  and a small painless erythematous lesion on his foot. His oral hygiene was noted to be poor with gingivitis present and a recent dental extraction site was noted. Auscultation of his heart detected a new murmur.   The persistent fever  new-onset palpitations  weight loss  fatigue  and evidence of heart murmur raised a suspicion of Infective Endocarditis.   Significance: This training case lends itself to a discussion on Native-Valve Endocarditis  focusing on predisposing conditions  such as poor oral hygiene and the recent dental procedure. It allows for the exploration of the signs  symptoms  and possible complications of native-valve infective endocarditis. Diagnostic tests that would confirm this diagnosis  such as blood cultures and echocardiograms  should be discussed. This case also brings to light the importance of robust history taking and the need for heightened clinical suspicion in a high-risk patient presenting with nonspecific symptoms that could easily be attributed to flu or other common conditions.

Patient Case:  Demographics: Gender: Male Age: 49 Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Construction worker Location: Rural midwestern United States  Past Medical History: 1. History of IV drug misuse  clean for the last 5 years. 2. Ongoing issue with poor dental hygiene with multiple untreated dental caries. 3. A smoker since adolescence  with about 20 pack-years history. 4. No known allergies. 5. No previous surgeries or hospitalizations.  Presenting Complaints: 1. The patient presents to the ED with a 2 week history of intermittent high-grade fever with chills and excessive night sweats. 2. He also reported worsening fatigue  unintentional weight loss of around 10 lbs over the past month  and reduced appetite. 3. He has been experiencing increasing shortness of breath over the past week  initially only with exertion but now at rest  which led him to seek medical attention. 4. There is an associated dull aching non-radiating chest pain  not influenced by breathing or position  intermittently lasting for several minutes. 5. He also complains of discomfort in his mouth and a foul taste  suggestive of poor dental hygiene.  Given these presenting symptoms  thorough investigations need to be conducted for a clinical suspicion of infective endocarditis. This should include blood cultures  echocardiography  and more  to confirm the diagnosis and decide upon treatment strategies which will include antibiotic therapy  methods to handle possible complications  and potentially  surgical intervention.  Needing to address both the immediate critical risks of sepsis and heart failure and the man's deferred dental care  treatment will need to be interdisciplinary  involving cardiology  dental  and addiction specialists  as well as patient education to help prevent recurrence.

Patient Information:   Mrs. Jane Doe  a 62-year-old African American female  was admitted presenting fever  fatigue  weight loss and shortness of breath. She is a retiree living with her husband and has no children. She has been generally in good health but experienced a sudden decline over the past month.  Past Medical History:  Mrs. Doe has a history of rheumatic fever in her childhood with a residual mitral regurgitation documented on a recent echo 2 years ago. She was on prophylactic Penicillin until late teens and has stopped it since then. She has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes managed with diet control and Metformin for the past 5 years. She was diagnosed recently with Stage 2 hypertension and is currently on Lisinopril and Hydrochlorothiazide. Mrs. Doe has no history of recent dental work  IV drug use  or alcohol abuse. She has not traveled recently and has no history of any recent infectious diseases.  Key Complaints:  Mrs. Doe presented with a history of low-grade  intermittent fever for the past one month  accompanied by undue fatigue and a weight loss of about 12 lbs  which was unplanned. She also complained of experiencing breathlessness on minimal exertion  such as simply walking inside her home. On further questioning  she mentioned bouts of night sweats and a decreased appetite  but denied any chest pain  orthopnea  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.  Physical examination revealed that Mrs. Doe appeared pale and had a slight tremor in her hands. She had a low-grade fever of 100.8 degrees Fahrenheit  a moderate systolic murmur heart best at the cardiac apex  and slight pitting edema in the lower limbs.   Assessment:   Native-valve infective endocarditis may be suspected based on her previous history of rheumatic fever and mitral regurgitation  and characteristic symptoms such as persistent fever  fatigue  and weight loss. The risk of acquiring this condition is also increased with her diabetic status.    Plan:   To confirm the diagnosis and to guide optimal treatment  we will obtain blood cultures  perform an echocardiogram  and commence empirical antibiotic therapy. Should IE be confirmed  therapy will be adjusted according to sensitivity results and continued for a prolonged period  alongside regular monitoring of the patient’s clinical progress and potential complications.

Case Report:  Patient Profile:  - Name: Alex Morgan - Age: 62 years  - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired teacher  Past Medical History:  - Diagnosis of rheumatic heart disease at age 40. - Underwent Mitral valve repair 15 years back. - No history of IV drug use. - No history of any other chronic illness like diabetes  hypertension  etc.  Presenting Complaints:  - For the past 6 days  the patient has experienced low-grade fever with evening spikes. - He reports chills  night sweats  and unexplained weight loss over the past month. - The patient noticed small  red spots on his palms and soles. - He is also experiencing fatigue  malaise  and occasional chest pain. - He complains of shortness of breath  especially during physical activities  and occasional nocturnal dyspnea. - Recently  the patient has developed a new onset of lower leg swelling and mild discomfort during urination.   The symptoms  past medical history of rheumatic heart disease  and mitral valve repair point to a suspected case of native-valve infective endocarditis  which will require further assessment using blood cultures  echocardiogram  and other related investigations.

Patient Information:   The patient is a 45-year-old white male who hails from a small farming community. He is married and has two early teenage kids. He's a lifelong smoker and doesn’t consume alcohol. He had been working as a construction worker for the past 20 years. He's slightly overweight and doesn't participate in any regular physical exercise.  Past Medical History:   The patient was diagnosed with Rheumatic fever at the age of 15  and since then  has suffered from intermittent episodes of it throughout his life. He also experiences bouts of strep throat every winter. His mother has a history of cardiovascular disease  but the patient has not been diagnosed with any cardiovascular diseases himself.  Presenting Complaints:   The patient initially presents to the emergency room complaining of weakness  fatigue  low-grade fever that he has experienced for approximately 3 weeks. In addition  he has been experiencing night sweats and a decrease in appetite leading to significant weight loss. The patient also complains about a persistent and worsening headache  shortness of breath accompanied by mild chest pain and occasional dry cough.   On inquiry  he mentions a sore throat and a skin rash which he dismissed as trivialities a month ago. He also notes new-onset joint and muscular pain  and he’s noticed blood in his urine over the past week. He denies any traveling in recent times  significant dietary changes  use of drugs  or recent dental procedures.   The onset of symptoms is gradual  and symptoms have progressively worsened  leading him to hospital admission. On general physical examination  the patient is moderately built and nourished but looks unwell and fatigued. High and early diastolic murmurs are noted upon cardiac auscultation secondary to aortic regurgitation. Multiple Janeway lesions and Osler’s nodes are observed in the skin of his palms and soles.   These symptoms  combined with his history of rheumatic fever  classically point towards native-valve infective endocarditis. Hence  further investigations like blood cultures  EKG  and others should be ordered to confirm this differential diagnosis.

Case Report - Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information: • Age: 64 years old • Gender: Male • Ethnicity: Caucasian • Occupation: Retired Engineer  Past Medical History: • History of moderate to severe mitral valve regurgitation. • Hypertension  well-controlled with medication • Former smoker; quit 15 years ago • No history of drug use • Family history of heart disease • Cholesterol levels slightly above normal   Presenting Complaints: • An ongoing low-grade fever for past one month • Tires easily  experiencing decreased energy levels • Anorexia and unintentional weight loss over two months • Night sweats  which have been particularly distressing • Mild discomfort in the chest  • Shortness of breath  particularly when lying down or on exertion  • Episodic  non-productive cough.  Key Findings: • On physical examination  the patient shows signs of pallor and weight loss. • Both Splinter hemorrhages under the nails and Janeway’s lesions on the palms and soles are obvious. • A new heart murmur identified during the cardiac examination  indicating probable valvular disease. • Auscultation reveals a diastolic rumble suggestive of possible mitral insufficiency. • No signs of peripheral edema  but spleen may be palpable on deep inspiration.  These findings indicate the possibility of infective endocarditis  most likely affecting his native mitral valve given his history of regurgitation  and a full diagnostic workup should be undertaken including blood cultures  a full blood count  ESR  CRP and an Echocardiogram. */  The purpose of this case is to educate medical students on the presentation  physical examination  potential complications  and classical presentation of a patient with native-valve infective endocarditis. This case emphasizes the importance of a comprehensive history taking  a full physical examination  and the formulation of a relevant and focused investigation plan.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. Carlson  a 65-year-old male of Caucasian descent  presents to the clinic. He has a past medical history of intravenous (IV) drug use which he completed rehabilitation for 20 years ago. He also has a known history of mitral valve prolapse which has been monitored regularly without any intervention so far. He does not consume alcohol and quit smoking 15 years ago.  Primary Complaint: He reports a two week history of intermittent fevers  night sweats  unintentional weight loss  and increasing fatigue. He has also been experiencing a new onset of palpitations over the past week. There has been no complaint of cough  shortness of breath  chest pain  nausea  vomiting  or change in bowel habits.  Assessment:  Given his age  medical history  and current symptoms - fatigue  palpitations  fevers  and night sweats  there's suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis.  Plan: The plan is to proceed with a detailed physical examination  followed by diagnostic tests including blood cultures  echocardiogram  and if necessary a cardiac CT. The team should prepare for possible in-hospital treatment which includes intravenous antibiotics  observing for changes in his condition  and the possible need for surgical intervention if medical management fails to improve the patient's condition.  Learning Objectives: 1. Understand the risk factors for native-valve infective endocarditis. 2. Recognize the common clinical manifestations of this condition. 3. Learn the importance and method of diagnostic evaluation. 4. Understand the management plan for native-valve endocarditis.    This case encourages medical students to apply their knowledge of cardiovascular history taking  learn to look for vital clues  and critically decide on further necessary investigations. The management will also help them understand the multidisciplinary approach in treating such conditions.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Demographics: Mr. Smith is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  employed as a construction worker living in the suburbs of Omaha  Nebraska. He is a smoker with a 20 pack-year history and is a known alcoholic  with a moderate daily consumption of alcohol for the past 25 years.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension for the past 10 years. He also suffers from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) secondary to his long-term smoking habit. Furthermore  he has had multiple dental abscesses over the past year due to poor oral hygiene  but seldom seeks dental care.  Presenting Complaint: Over the past three weeks  Mr. Smith has reported generalized weakness  a low-grade fever  and episodes of sweating  particularly at night. He also reported that he had lost weight unintentionally in the past month. Recently  he has noticed some swelling in his feet and ankles.  This case is designed around native-valve infective endocarditis. The aim is to enable students to deduce the diagnosis based on patient's risk factors (poor dental hygiene  uncontrolled hypertension)  suggestive symptoms (fever  weight loss  and generalized weakness) and signs (edema which suggests congestive heart failure  a common complication of endocarditis). Learning points would also include working out the link between oral health and cardiovascular diseases  and understanding the importance of history taking and physical examination in forming a preliminary diagnosis.

Patient Information:   A 65-year-old Hispanic male patient named Mr. Garcia  presenting to the emergency department.  Past Medical History:  Our patient has a history of type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which is reasonably well-controlled with metformin. He also has mild hypertension and a mild impairment in renal function. He has no known drug allergies. His immunizations are up to date. He does not smoke  occasionally drinks alcohol  and denies any recreational drug use.   Chief Complaint:  Mr. Garcia reports intermittent fever  chills  night sweats  and fatigue for the last two weeks  which seemed to progressively worsen. Additionally  he noticed an unintentional weight loss over the past month. He reports mild-to-moderate dyspnea on exertion and mild discomfort in his chest  unrelated to physical activity. Mr. Garcia also reports a decrease in appetite but denies nausea  vomiting  diarrhea  or abdominal pain. No cough  hemoptysis  or changes in bowel or bladder habits are reported.   Physicians may find this case useful for teaching students about the potential clinical presentations and diagnostics involved in native-valve infective endocarditis. This patient's presentation could prompt them to consider whether he might be suffering from this potentially life-threatening condition or another disease. It will also allow for discussions around treatment and prevention strategies in patients with similar demographics and past medical histories.

Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 45-year-old Caucasian male working as an office executive.  Presenting Complaints: Fever of unknown origin  persisting for 2 weeks  associated with chills  night sweats  fatigue  malaise  10-pound unintentional weight loss  and a new  mild heart murmur. The patient also reports intermittent  dull chest discomfort over the past week but denies shortness of breath or other symptoms of heart failure.  Medical History: Previously healthy with no significant cardiac history. No known drug allergies. Never smoked nor used illicit drugs or alcohol excessively. Has a family history of benign heart murmur but no family history of valvular heart disease or endocarditis.  Review of Systems: Positive for acute weight loss  fatigue  intermittent fevers  chills. No changes in vision  hearing  headaches  cough  hemoptysis  abdominal pain  changes in bowel movements  urination  joint pains  rashes or skin changes. Denies recent dental procedures  intravenous drug abuse  or other obvious sources of infection.  Physical Examination: Vital signs within normal ranges except for an elevated temperature of 38.5°C. Heart auscultation revealed a new  mild systolic ejection murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. No Janeway lesions  Osler's nodes  Roth's spots  or splinter hemorrhages were observed.  Laboratory Studies: Complete blood count shows mild leukocytosis with a left shift. Blood cultures collected.  Please continue with differential diagnosis  further diagnostics  treatment options  course of patients hospital stay  discharge plan  and follow up.

Case Study: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Demographics: Mr. J. Davis is a 69-year-old Caucasian male residing in the suburb. He is a retired factory worker and lives with his wife  is a former smoker  and has a history of occasional alcohol use.   Past Medical History: Mr. Davis has a known history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension  for which he is taking Metformin 500 mg twice daily and Losartan 50 mg once daily. He also has a history of gout  being occasionally treated with colchicine. He has no history of any known heart conditions  but a family history of heart disease is present on his mother's side. He also has been subjected to dental procedures a month back.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Davis presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of intermittent  high-grade fever which is non-responsive to over-the-counter (OTC) fever medications. In addition  he has been feeling fatigued and weak  with an unintentional weight loss of 5kg within the last month. He also complains of night sweats and has noticed reddish spots on his feet and hands  which have appeared unexpectedly. Over the last week  he has had increased shortness of breath  especially with even minimal exertion.  This case report is designed to provide a working assessment of a patient presenting with primary symptoms  which can indicate various possible diagnoses including infective endocarditis. Subsequent history  physical exam  and further investigations are required to substantiate the diagnosis and rule out other potential medical conditions. The students should be encouraged to utilize their theoretical knowledge and clinical reasoning skills to propose the next steps in this patient's management.   NOTE: In the learning context  it should be emphasized that this patient has risk factors for endocarditis including older age  being male  and past dental procedures. The symptoms such as fever  fatigue  weight loss  night sweats and signs like spots on his feet and hands  and shortness of breath are consistent with a possible diagnosis of infective endocarditis  but further investigation is necessary for the definitive diagnosis.

Patient Description:  Mr. James Peterson is a 65-year-old male from Westborough  Massachusetts.   Past Medical History: He has a history of untreated dental caries  hypertension  and chronic rheumatoid arthritis. For his conditions  he takes medication for hypertension and painkillers for his arthritis.   Key Complaints:  Mr. Peterson presents with a one-month history of worsening fatigue  intermittent fever  night sweats  loss of appetite  and unintentional weight loss around 10 lbs within the past month. In the last two weeks  he has also reported feeling short of breath during his routine morning walks and it has progressively become worse to the point that he becomes breathless with minimal exertion. He has mild confusion that his family noticed  increasing in the past week. No chest pain  cough  hemoptysis  or palpitations were reported. He denies any recent dental procedures  history of intravenous drug use  or recent travel.  Endocarditis is suspected due to his symptoms of fever and signs of systemic illness combined with a potential for exposure via untreated dental caries. Hospitalization is suggested for further investigation and treatment as his systemic symptoms seem to suggest severe infection. This case will focus on the evaluation  diagnosis  principles of treatment  prevention  and outcomes of native-valve infective endocarditis to guide medical students to handle real-life patient scenarios effectively.

Patient Profile: - Name: John Doe - Age: 72 - Sex: Male - Race: African American - Occupation: Retired banker  Past Medical History: - Diabetes Mellitus type II for 10 years - Hypertension for 15 years - Percutaneous coronary intervention 5 years ago - Prosthetic hip joint due to a fall 1 year ago - Occasional alcohol use - Lifetime non-smoker  Presenting Complaints: Patient arrives at the emergency department with complaints of: - Persistent high-grade fever for two weeks - Unintended weight loss of around 6 lbs in the last month - Loss of appetite - Night sweats - Increasing fatigue and weakness - Shortness of breath on effort - Mild  dull constant  central chest pain for the last 3 days - One episode of unprovoked nose bleed last week - Recent onset confusion  deterioration in cognitive functions noticed by his caregiver   The patient's past medical history  combined with the reported symptoms  suggest a potential diagnosis like native-valve infective endocarditis. Complex factors such as the patient's diabetes  hypertension  and his prosthetic hip joint—alongside his current symptomatology—point towards a potentially severe  systemic infection that may involve the heart valves.   Next steps would involve physical examination  blood cultures  echocardiogram and other necessary investigations to confirm the diagnosis and decide the best treatment plan. Emphasize the importance of early detection and intervention in a case of Infective Endocarditis to prevent severe complications.

Patient Demographics: The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male named John Doe  residing in New York City  and working as an accountant.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a history of moderate-to-severe rheumatoid arthritis  for which he is under immunosuppressant therapy. He is also a former I.V. drug user but has been clean for over two decades. He does not consume alcohol or tobacco. His family history includes ischemic heart disease in his father who passed away at the age of 72.  Key Complaints: Mr. Doe visited the outpatient department complaining of persistent night sweats  a weight loss of approximately 15 pounds over the past two months  and an on-and-off fever for the last three weeks  which he initially assumed was due to a seasonal flu. Besides  he has been experiencing generalized weakness  fatigue  and occasional shortness of breath particularly on exertion. In the last week  he also noticed small  painful  reddish spots on the soles of his feet and palms of his hands.   These symptoms have been causing significant distress and worsening his quality of life  raising concerns as his generalized weakness and shortness of breath are hampering his ability to carry out his daily activities.   Please note that although he hasn’t visited the dentist or undergone any invasive procedures recently  his immunosuppressant therapy and history of IV drug use places him at risk for infective endocarditis. It's advised that the medical students working on this case should perform relevant investigations aimed at diagnosing infective endocarditis in Mr. Doe in order to establish an effective treatment plan.

Patient Information:  Name: Mr. Richard Thompson Age: 60 Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Semi-retired plumber Location: Birmingham  Alabama  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Thompson presents with a three-week history of intermittent fever  generalized weakness  and recent onset shortness of breath especially on exertion. He also mentions unintentional weight loss of around 10 pounds over the last month and some discomfort in his joints.  Past Medical History: Mr. Thompson has a history of bicuspid aortic valve disease detected in his 40s during a routine check-up but has been asymptomatic ever since. He is otherwise in good health  not taking any regular medications. He has a history of smoking but quit 15 years ago and drinks socially.  Family history: He has a family history of heart diseases with his father passing away from a heart attack.  Social History: He lives with his retired wife. He has a history of injection drug use in his 20s but has been clean for the past 30 years. He has no recent travel history and no exposure to any illnesses.  Summary: Given the symptoms  past medical history  and possible exposure risks  the differential to consider is native-valve infective endocarditis exacerbated by his undiagnosed bicuspid aortic valve disease. Further clinical assessment  imaging  and blood cultures need to be performed to confirm this diagnosis.

Patient Demographics: Name: Jane Doe Age: 65 years old Gender: Female Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired school teacher  Past Medical History: 1) Rheumatic fever at age 15 without any cardiac complications.  2) Type II Diabetes Mellitus  well-controlled with metformin.  3) Hypertension  managed with losartan. 4) Mild osteoarthritis.  Key Complaints: Patient presents with a four-week history of low-grade fever  fatigue  weight loss (about 5 kilograms in the last month)  and occasional night sweats. In the past week  she has also been complaining of intermittent chest discomfort which she describes as 'like heartburn'. The pain does not radiate and is not related to exercise. She denies cough  shortness of breath  palpitations  or lower extremity swelling. Her fatigue has disturbed her daily activities and the chest discomfort is making her anxious. She has no family history of ischemic cardiac disease. She is a non-smoker and denies alcohol or recreational drug use.   Summary: 65-year-old female with a history of Rheumatic fever  type II diabetes mellitus  and hypertension  presents with a four-week history of low-grade fever  fatigue  unexplained weight loss  and recent onset chest discomfort. She denies dyspnea  orthopnea or peripheral edema. Further evaluation is warranted with suspicion towards possible infective endocarditis.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Demographics:   Mr. B is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  married  with a history of homelessness. He graduated from high school but has been unemployed for the past 3 years. He is a smoker of 20 cigarettes per day for the past 30 years and has a history of intravenous drug use.   Past Medical History:   He has a known history of Hepatitis C (HCV+)  uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hypertension. His family history includes diabetes and cardiovascular disease. Mr. B has a history of intermittent adherence to his medications  attributing this to financial difficulties and his transient lifestyle.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. B presents to the emergency department complaining of fever and chills that have been ongoing for several weeks. He also describes feeling general fatigue and weakness  loss of appetite  and unintentional weight loss. He adds experiencing shortness of breath  especially when lying flat  along night sweats and a persistent cough with occasional sputum. He further notes a change in color in several of his toes and finger tips  turning to a bluish color. Recently  he developed a few reddish spots on his palms and soles. Mr. B also mentions a weeklong history of discomfort in his lower back without any clear aggravating or alleviating factors.

Patient Profile: Name: John Doe Age: 60 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Smoker: Yes Alcohol Consumption: Moderate  Medical History: John Doe has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and was diagnosed with rheumatic heart disease in his twenties. He has had two episodes of pneumonia in the last four years. His medications include Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  aspirin for heart disease prevention  and statins for cholesterol management.  Key Complaints: For the past 2 weeks  John has been experiencing recurrent fever marked by intermittent chills and night sweats. He reports progressive fatigue  unexplained weight loss  and an occasional dry cough. Additionally  he has noticed blood in his urine. He experienced mild chest discomfort in the past few days  which has since progressed to moderate pain that is non-radiating and a mismatch with his usual angina.  Notes for Medical Students:  From the given patient history and symptoms  Native Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVE) is a key possible diagnosis. In the case of John Doe  it's essentially important to focus on his previous history of Rheumatic Heart Disease which put his valves at risk for bacterial infection. Given his complaints of weight loss  fever  fatigue  and hematuria  coupled with a history of heart disease and the new onset of chest discomfort  NVE should be considered. The history of smoking and moderate alcohol consumption are additional factors increasing the probability of such diseases.   You should further examine for signs of infectious endocarditis such as Janeway lesions  Osler's nodes  splinter hemorrhages  and consider treatments including various intravenous antibacterials  possible surgery for valve replacement and anticoagulants to prevent embolic events.   Further diagnostic investigations should include Blood Culture  ECG  Echo (TTE/TEE) and Chest X-ray.

Case Report:  Patient Information:   - Age: 65 years - Gender: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian  - Occupation: Retired electrician  Past Medical History:  - Diabetes mellitus (Type 2)  - Hypertension  - History of intravenous drug use in his 20s (clean for over 30 years) - Occasional tobacco and alcohol use   Presenting Complaints:  The patient presents to the clinic complaining of a low-grade fever  fatigue  weight loss  and general malaise that has lasted for about three weeks. He also notes an intermittent  dull chest pain and shortness of breath especially during normal daily activities which he initially attributed to aging. He mentions occasional night sweats but denies any cough  hemoptysis  or recent joint pains. He also complains of experiencing unexplained bruises on his legs and a small painful red bump on his finger (Osler's node). He has no known allergies.  The patient looks ill and is anxious about his symptoms since they don't seem to resolve and impact his daily activities. Heart sounds reveal a low-pitched  rumbling diastolic murmur best heard at the apex with the patient in the left lateral position. On skin examination  petechiae over the conjunctivae  palate  extensor surfaces  and legs are noted. The physician also observes Janeway lesions on the palms and soles.  The primary preceptor mentioned the patient fits a sub-acute presentation of native-valve infective endocarditis and orders blood cultures  echocardiography  Complete Blood Count (CBC)  ESR  chest X-ray  and starts broad-spectrum antimicrobial therapy while awaiting blood culture results.   The objective of this case is to train learners on the key clinical presentations  complications  and management of native-valve infective endocarditis. It guides medical students to differentiate it from other differential diagnosis and trains them on emergency intervention and referral to a higher center if necessary.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Patient Information:  Name: XYZ Age: 65 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired construction worker Marital Status: Married  Medical History:  The patient has a chronic history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus and peripheral artery disease. He is a smoke pack-year history of 35 and a social drinker. The patient does not have any known drug allergies. The patient remains non-compliant with his diabetic medications and follow-ups at the outpatient department.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient presented to the Emergency Room with high-grade intermittent fever for the past two weeks that did not respond to common antipyretics. The fever was associated with night sweats  fatigue  and unintentional weight loss of 10 pounds over one month. The patient also complained of shortness of breath on exertion and new-onset muffled heart sounds  which were identified as a murmur during physical examination. Furthermore  he also stated experiencing intermittent chest pain  mostly located in the central chest region  lasting for approximately 10 minutes  and then subsiding on its own.  Physical examination:  On inspection  peripheral stigmata of endocarditis  such as Janeway lesions in palms and soles and Osler nodes on his fingers  were noted. On auscultation  a systolic murmur best heard at the apex  and a diastolic murmur best heard in the left sternal border were noticed. He does not have any signs of heart failure.   Initial results:  The laboratory findings revealed leukocytosis and elevated inflammatory biomarkers. His blood glucose levels were significantly high. Initial chest X-ray did not show any signs of congestion or any other abnormalities. An EKG showed no significant ST-T wave changes.   This case will navigate through how the students would work this patient up leading to the diagnosis of infective endocarditis including history of the complaint  physical examination  laboratory findings  use of Duke criteria  importance of blood cultures and echocardiograhic evidence. It would also focus on the management of infective endocarditis  focusing on antibiotic therapy and possible surgical intervention. It will encourage the students to consider the impacts and assessment of patient compliance in managing chronic diseases.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  A 45-year-old Caucasian male  working as a construction worker  married  lives in an urban area  and has a history of moderate smoking and occasional alcohol use.  Past Medical History:  Patient has a history of congenital heart disease (specifically bicuspid aortic valve)  for which he has not required any surgical intervention. He has had intermittent low-grade fevers since he was diagnosed with the condition. No other significant past medical  surgical  or family history reported.  Key Complaints:  Patient presents to the emergency department complaining of persistent high-grade fever with temperatures around 39°C for the past two weeks. The fever is associated with chills  night sweats  and fatigue. He also reports unintentional weight loss over the past month  but he does not know his pre-illness weight.   Recently  he has noticed that his usual dyspnea on exertion has been worsening  he now becomes breathless after just a few minutes of mild activity. Over the past week  he has also noticed multiple red spots on the palms of his hands and soles of his feet. In addition  he states that he has increasingly been finding it difficult to focus on his work due to the fatigue and aching musculoskeletal pain.  This case is designed around a presentation of native-valve infective endocarditis - existent structural heart disease (congenital)  nonspecific symptoms of infection like prolonged high-grade fever  chills  night sweats  fatigue  and peculiar skin signs like petechial rash. Further clinical evaluation of this patient would likely reveal more classical signs of endocarditis such as Osler's nodes  Janeway's lesions along with cardiac murmurs on auscultation. The patient's history of smoking and occupational exposure could have contributed to his susceptibility to this condition. The case might end up focusing on differentiating various etiological agents causing endocarditis based on patient-specific factors and risk profiles  guiding students in creating comprehensive differential diagnoses and treatment plans. A key learning point will also be the significant morbidity and mortality associated with infective endocarditis  emphasizing the importance of early recognition and aggressive management.

Patient Details: Name: Confidential Age: 65  Gender: Male Race: White Occupation: Retired construction worker   Past Medical History: Patient is a smoker with a 40-pack-year history. He has a diagnosis of controlled hypertension and had a bout of Streptococcal pharyngitis eight months ago. He also had a dental procedure completed approximately four weeks ago.  Key Complaints: The patient has reported a recurrent moderate to high-grade fever over the past two weeks. Accompanied by rigors  it fluctuated with peak episodes in the evening. Fatigue  shortness of breath upon exertion and a mild brief loss of consciousness once during this period was narrated. Recent poor oral intake has caused weight loss and malaise. Additionally  he mentioned experiencing nightsweats.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  evidence of poor dental hygiene was noted upon oral inspection. Cardiac examination revealed a new blowing diastolic murmur heard best at the left lower sterno-costal edge. Several small  non-tender  petechial lesions were observed on the skin of the lower limbs.  Suspected Diagnosis: Based on the clinical presentation and physical findings  a suspicion of native valve infective endocarditis has been raised.   Further Investigation: Blood cultures  Echocardiogram and Complete Blood Count (CBC) have been ordered to confirm the diagnosis and the specific pathogen causing it  as well as to assess the possible damage to heart structures.  Management Plan: Depending on the results of the investigation  therapies targeting the suspected bacterial causative agent (likely streptococcus viridans or staphylococcus aureus given past history and lifestyle) will be initiated. This will likely involve a prolonged course of targeted intravenous antibiotics  supplemented by a dental care plan to address the source of infection.  Follow Up: Follow up will involve regularly monitoring the patient's response to treatment and any signs of complications (e.g.  heart failure  abscesses  septicemia).   Educational Highlight: This case provides a classic presentation of native valve infective endocarditis  highlighting the importance of considering this diagnosis in a patient with fever  cardiovascular signs  suggestive skin lesions  and risk factors such as poor dental hygiene.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male  who resides in urban New York. Retired  the patient previously worked in construction. He is a smoker with a 30-year history of tobacco use  consuming 1 pack a day  and admits to social drinking  having approximately 7-10 beers a week. The patient is widowed with no children and lives by himself.  Past Medical History: The patient had a medical history significant for Intravenous Drug Use (IVDU) which he has not engaged in for the past 10 years. He also has a known history of Hypertension and Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease  for which he is under medication with an ACE inhibitor and long-acting beta-agonist respectively. There are no known allergies or reaction to any medicines.  Key Complaints: He presented to the Emergency Department with complaints of persistent high-grade fever for the past 2 weeks  associated with night sweats. He also complained of recent-onset fatigue  weight loss  and intermittent chest pain that is sharp in nature and tends to increase with deep breathing.  Clinical Observations: On examination  his temperature was 102.1 ºF  blood pressure 130/80 mm of Hg  heart rate 98/min  the respiratory rate of 18/min  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. He had poor dental hygiene with multiple caries. Cardiac auscultation revealed a diastolic murmur  best heard at the left sternal border.  Clinical Suspicion: Upon initial analysis  considering his long history of IVDU and the presence of poorly treated teeth  the suspicion of Infective Endocarditis was raised. Further diagnostic investigations were advised accordingly.  This case is designed to enable the medical students to understand the correlation between the clinical signs and their significance in the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. It highlights the importance of noting historical clues such as IVDU and poor dental hygiene which increases the risk of Infective Endocarditis  thus reinforcing the need for longitudinal patient-centered care.

Case Report:  Patient Information and Demographics: Mr. James Ross  a 60-year-old male  Caucasian  working as an accountant  hailing from uptown Chicago.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Ross has been previously diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type II which is controlled by medications. He also has a history of intravenous drug usage in his 30s  but had quit about 20 years ago. Additionally  he has a history of moderate rheumatic heart disease but has not required surgery or interventions.
