He does not use tobacco  consumes alcohol in moderation  and has no known drug allergies.  Chief Complaint: Mr. Ross presents to the emergency department (ED) with complaints of intermittent high-grade fever with chills lasting for the past 2 weeks. He also mentions increasing fatigue  a 10-pound unintentional weight loss over the past month  and occasional night sweats. He reports experiencing shortness of breath while climbing stairs or during light physical activities  a new issue for him. He has also noted swelling in both of his ankles.  This case is designed to highlight the essential components of diagnosing native valve infective endocarditis. Key points of focus should be a careful evaluation of the patient’s history and a thorough physical examination looking for key signs such as Osler nodes  Janeway lesions and Roth spots. The subsequent steps should involve utilization of the modified Duke criteria in establishing the diagnosis  addressing the importance of blood cultures  and Echocardiography. The case should conclude with the appropriate choice of antibiotic therapy and the implications of patient’s past structural heart disease on management and prognosis.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Smith Age: 62 Gender: Male Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired  Medical History:  John is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history of intravenous (IV) drug use and untreated dental caries. He has not visited a dentist in the past five years. Additional history includes chronic hepatitis C  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and a 30-pack year smoking history.  Presenting Complaints: John presents to the emergency department stating he has been experiencing intermittent fever for the last three weeks. He reports chills  significant lethargy  intrusive night sweats  and unintentional weight loss of about 10 pounds within the month. He also mentions a new murmur that he has never noticed before  persistent shortness of breath  and an intermittent  dry cough.  Emergent physical examination reveals Janeway lesions on his palms and soles and Osler nodes on his fingers and toes. There is also some evidence of splenomegaly.  Findings in The History:   The history of untreated dental caries  IV drug use  and new-onset cardiac murmur are suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis. Moreover  the persistent fever  fatigue  and weight loss are systemic symptoms consistent with this condition. The physical findings  such as Janeway's lesions  Osler nodes  and splenomegaly  further contribute to the suspicion of infective endocarditis.  Learning Objectives:  1. Understand the pathophysiology and etiology of native-valve infective endocarditis. 2. Identify the risk factors  such as IV drug use and poor dental hygiene  associated with the disease. 3. Recognize the importance of a thorough patient history and physical examination for the diagnosis and management. 4. Understand indications for ordering preliminary tests including complete blood count  blood cultures  EKG and echocardiography. 5. Recognize and manage complications  including heart failure  stroke  and sepsis.  6. Formulate a treatment plan including antimicrobial therapy  possibly future dental repair or care  or endocarditis prophylaxis when indicated

Case Report:  Patient Information:  Mr. A  a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history notable for rheumatoid arthritis and non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus  presents to the emergency room.  Past Medical History:  Diagnosed with Rheumatoid Arthritis 7 years ago  currently managed with Methotrexate. Type 2 diabetes diagnosed 5 years ago  managed via diet control and Metformin. No known drug allergies. Previous medical history also includes untreated dental caries. Patient is a smoker with a 30 pack-year history but denies drug or alcohol abuse.  Chief Complaints:  Presenting symptoms include a high-grade fever persisting for the last six days  associated with chills  night sweats  and moderate discomfort in the chest while breathing. The patient also reports a weight loss of approximately 5kgs in the last two months  fatigue and remarked that he noticed reddish spots on his trunk and legs. He has also been experiencing intermittent throbbing pain in the fingers of his right hand. Denies any neck stiffness or cough.  Examination:  Physical examination findings were significant for a temperature of 101.2°F  heart rate of 102 beats/minute  and blood pressure of 130/90 mmHg. Skin exam showed Janeway lesions on his palms and soles  with Osler's nodes noted on his fingers. Lung auscultation revealed clear breath sounds  while a cardiac examination detected a new regurgitant murmur suggestive of mitral regurgitation. No pedal edema or jugular venous distension was noted on examination. Normal bowel sounds were heard on abdominal examination. Neurological examination was within normal limits.  This case has a focus on Native Valve Infective Endocarditis  a challenging complication observed mainly in patients with underlying heart valve disease or patients with risk factors such as untreated dental caries or intravenous drug use. This challenge encourages students to consider a wide differential diagnosis  collect appropriate clinical history  perform a thorough examination  and interpret clinical findings to propose a likely diagnosis and corresponding investigation and management plan. Additionally  it prompts students to consider the importance of preventive measures in at-risk populations.

Patient Details: 56-year-old Caucasian male  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of intravenous drug use (IVDU); he has been sober for the past 6 months and is on a methadone program. He also has a record of seasonal flu every year.   Key Complaints: Patient presents with a two-week history of fatigue  moderate to severe joint pain  and a fever. He reports unintentional weight loss and night sweats over the past month. He also complains of experiencing shortness of breath on exertion for the past one week.  Case Description:  The patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian male with a history of IVDU  presenting with fatigue  joint pain  and fever for two weeks. His complaints are indicative of systemic illness or infection. Additionally  he reports unintentional weight loss and nights sweats over the past month  raising suspicion of chronic infection  malignancy  or other systemic disease. The appearance of shortness of breath on exerting himself for the past week is a new symptom for him. Given his past medical history of IVDU  the differential diagnosis should include native-valve infective endocarditis.  A physical examination reveals injection marks on his arms  signs of poor dentition  and splinter hemorrhages in his nails. Heart auscultation reveals a new murmur over the aortic valve area  indicative of possible valvular dysfunction. Eyes examination shows Roth spots and conjunctival hemorrhage  suggesting vasculitis associated with endocarditis. He also has a low-grade fever.   Blood tests  echocardiography and blood cultures for bacteria and fungi would be the next steps for final diagnosis.   Patient history  physical examination and symptoms suggest potential infective endocarditis. Thus  this case can serve as an introduction to diagnosing native-valve infective endocarditis  with emphasis on connection between IVDU and the disease  symptomatology  physical examination and related tests.

Patient Information :   Mrs. Anna Adams is a 67-year-old Caucasian woman who works as a freelance writer based in San Francisco  California. She lives with her husband in their own house and has two grown-up children who live independently. She is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol socially.  Past Medical History:  Mrs. Adams is diagnosed with Diabetes type II since she was 55 years old. She also has a history of rheumatic fever during her adolescence. She had a mild form of Gout  which was optimally managed with medications and lifestyle modification. She does not have a known allergy to any medication. Mrs. Adams has not undergone surgery or any significant medical procedure in the past.   Key Complaints:  She presented to the emergency room with persistent fever of 101°F for the past five days accompanied by fatigue and mild shortness of breath. She also reported unintentional weight loss over the past few weeks and vague chest discomfort. Additionally  she complained of experiencing intermittent chills and night sweats. She also noticed a few petechiae (red spots) on the skin of her lower limbs.     Review of systems was significant for exertional dyspnea with no orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. No symptoms suggesting gastrointestinal  urinary  or neurological abnormalities. SEO risks and regular checkups have demonstrated good control over her Diabetes thus far.  Displayed symptoms of fever  fatigue  weight loss  and mild dyspnea are suggestive of infective endocarditis. These are particularly concerning considering her age  the fact that she has a persistently high fever  and has an underlying condition of Diabetes which often compromises the immune system. She also has a history of rheumatic fever  a known predisposing factor for the development of infective endocarditis. Further diagnostic evaluations and lab testing would be recommended to confirm and assess the severity of her condition.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Demographics:  - Mr. Johnson - Age: 65 - Gender: Male  - Occupation: Retired teacher - Ethnicity: Caucasian  - Residency: New Jersey  USA  Past Medical History:   - Patient has been diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for 20 years.  - Underwent a cholecystectomy 10 years prior.  - No known allergies.  - Current medications include Metformin and a daily aspirin.  Key Complaints: - The patient presents with a 2-week history of intermittent fever peaks up to 102 degrees Fahrenheit.  - The fever was initially thought to be a viral infection  however  it did not resolve after initial symptomatic treatments. - Patient also reports night sweats and weight loss of about 10 lbs over the last month  which he initially attributed to stress.  - Additionally  he complains of fatigue and shortness of breath  especially when going up stairs or walking short distances.  - He denies chest pain  cough  or abdominal discomfort.  - Mr. Johnson was recently seen at the dentist about a month ago for a deep clean and root canal treatment.  - There has been no recent travel  ill contacts  or changes in diet. - Smoking history: 1 pack/day for past 35 years. - Drinks alcohol occasionally.

Case Description:  Patient Demographics:  A 63-year-old Caucasian male who is a retired school teacher.  Past Medical History:  He has a history of poor dental hygiene. Past medical history is significant for type-2 diabetes and hypertension  both controlled with medication. He has no known drug allergies. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally.  Key Complaints: He presents to the hospital with progressive fatigue and a low-grade fever for the past two months. He also complains of night sweats  weight loss  and a decreased appetite over the same period. He denies chest pain but acknowledges experiencing some palpitations recently.   This is a basic structure for your case. You may further customize it or add laboratory findings  physical examination  and case discussion for a more comprehensive training case.

Case Report: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis   Patient Information: Sex: Male Age: 58 years  Occupation: Mechanic  History of Present Illness: The patient presents to the emergency department with recurrent fevers  night sweats  and generalized fatigue for the past three weeks. He also reports sudden onset of back pain and loss of appetite  as well as unexpected weight loss.   Past Medical History: The patient had a history of being diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus five years ago which is poorly controlled. He also has mild hypertension  and a long history of heavy smoking. The patient does not have any documented allergies. The patient doesn't have personal or family history of cardiac diseases.  Social History: The patient lives alone and works as a mechanic in an auto repair shop. He does not drink alcohol but smokes about a pack a day which he began during his mid-twenties. He doesn't have any illicit drug use history.  Physical Examination: On presentation  the patient was conscious  oriented but seemed unwell. His vital signs revealed an elevated heart rate (tachycardia) and an elevated body temperature (fever - 38.6 C). On auscultation  a mitral regurgitation murmur was audible. On examination  the clinical signs of infective endocarditis  including Osler's nodes (painful nodules on the fingers or toes)  Janeway lesions (painless spots on the palms or soles)  and Roth spots (retinal hemorrhages)  are not easily demonstrable but should be searched for.  Investigations: Blood cultures  Complete Blood Count (CBC)  Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR)  and C-reactive protein (CRP) are to be immediately ordered  followed by an echocardiogram to visualize any signs of valvular damage or vegetation.  The case should then proceed based on the results of these investigations  focusing on the need for long-term intravenous antibiotic therapy  possible need for valve replacement surgery  and the importance of good blood glucose control in preventing such infections. Additionally  efforts to quit smoking should be discussed due to its adverse effects on the cardiovascular system.

Case Study: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information Name: Mr. Williams Age: 62 years old Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer  Past Medical History Mr. Williams has been previously diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  for which he is taking Metformin  Lisinopril  and Simvastatin respectively. He has a history of mild dental caries but showed negative for bacterial endocarditis in last year's dental extraction event. Mr. Williams is also a former chain smoker but quit about five years ago.  Presenting Complaints Mr. Williams presented with a 4-week history of low-grade fever  night-sweats  a weight loss of around 14 pounds  and fatigue. He also mentioned that he had experienced a mild bout of a flu-like illness about six weeks ago. He reported repeated episodes of gum bleeding over the last month during toothbrushing  attributing it to his usual gum problems.  For the purpose of training: Upon evaluation of these presenting conditions  students are expected to consider a range of differential diagnoses. The combination of fever  weight loss  fatigue  and the chronicity of symptoms with an underlying history of gum issues should hint towards the possibility of infective endocarditis. Despite the patient not having an immediate history of heart valve disease  his age  and existing comorbidity (diabetes)  and his episodes of gum bleeding open up the possibility of native-valve endocarditis via hematogenous spread. Further investigation will be necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

Case Report - Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information:  Mr. Smith is a 60-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired truck driver  a non-smoker  and does not consume alcohol. He lives with his wife and has two grown children.  Past Medical History:  He has a known history of type 2 diabetes  which is currently managed by Metformin 500mg two times a day. Also  he was diagnosed with rheumatic heart disease at age 16 and has been on prophylactic antibiotics before certain dental and surgical procedures according to AHA guidelines.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Smith presented to the Emergency Department with a two-week history of generalized weakness  fluctuating fever up to 38.5 C  night sweats  and mild shortness of breath. He denies chest pain but reports mild weight loss in the past month.  Physical examination findings include mild pallor  an intermittent low-grade fever  a new heart murmur on auscultation  several small skin petechiae  and mild ankle edema bilaterally. No signs of embolic phenomena or conjunctival hemorrhages are seen.  The above case suggests the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis in this patient. The major criteria would include new regurgitant murmur heard on examination  persistently positive blood cultures  and presence of fever  as well as minor criteria including predisposing heart condition and vascular phenomena. The subsequent steps would involve blood cultures  echocardiographic studies  and potential initiation of antibiotic therapy.

Case Report:  Patient Presentation: Mr. Johnson  a 58-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department with a three-week history of general fatigue  unplanned weight loss  low-grade fever  night sweats  and a new-onset  regurgitation-type murmur. He has a past medical history significant for intravenous drug use  type 2 diabetes mellitus  moderate chronic renal insufficiency  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia.  His lifestyle  occupation  and habits include working as a chef  drinking alcohol socially and a 30-year history of intravenous heroin abuse. He quit tobacco smoking five years ago. According to his account  he has been clean from drug use for the past two years.  Chief Complaint: The patient states  ""I'm feeling really weak and tired lately  and I have lost about 15 pounds unintentionally over the last couple of weeks. I've also been having night sweats  and sometimes I feel really hot  although I don't think I have a fever. I've noticed a new kind of chest discomfort recently on exertion  and something seems odd with my heart  which bothers me a lot.”  Lifestyle and Personal History: As an IV drug abuser  the patient is at high risk of deep vein thrombosis  abscesses  sepsis  and infective endocarditis due to the possible contamination of needles. He has been attending a local methadone clinic and claims to have been clean from heroin for two years.   Medical and Psychiatric History: He has a confirmed history of type 2 diabetes mellitus for 10 years  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and moderate chronic renal insufficiency. There's no family history of any genetic or inherited disorder. He has been under medication to control his blood sugar and hypertension levels. There's no past psychiatric history  although he did visit a psychologist to help him cope with his struggle with addiction.   This case can be used to educate students regarding clinical  historical  and physical exam findings suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis  particularly in a patient with the risk factor of prior intravenous drug use. It also serves to highlight the importance of a thorough history and physical exam in any patient presenting with vague constitutional symptoms and new-onset cardiac signs.

Patient Profile: Name: Mr. Harry Smith Age: 58 Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Plumber  Chief Complaints:  The patient presented at the clinic with a 2-week history of worsening malaise  intermittent fever  and unexplained weight loss. Mr. Smith also complained of occasional night sweats and shortness of breath on exertion.  Past Medical History:  No known history of illicit drug use. The patient has a documented case of rheumatic fever at the age of 12  but since then  has managed to lead a relatively healthy life. There is no significant familial history of heart diseases. The patient got his teeth cleaned at a dental clinic about a month ago.   Social History: The patient is a heavy smoker (30-pack years) but maintains a moderate alcohol intake.   Clinical Examination: On physical examination  the patient appeared tired and had a slight fever (100.4°F). He had a new murmur (III/VI systolic murmur) heard best at the cardiac apex on auscultation. In addition  scattered petechiae were observed on the patient's palms and soles.   Based on his symptoms and physical exam  Mr. Smith is suspected of having native-valve infective endocarditis. Further diagnostic workups including blood cultures  echocardiography  and eventually valve tissue culture (if required) may be ordered to confirm the diagnosis.

Case Study: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Patient Demographics: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male named John  born and lives in Ohio. He is married with 3 children and 5 grandchildren. He is retired and used to work as a school teacher.   Past Medical History:  John has a history of type II diabetes mellitus under control with oral medications for the last 20 years. He was also diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago and has been taking medication regularly. Mr. John has a known history of moderate to severe native-valve (mitral) regurgitation due to age-related degenerative changes diagnosed during a routine checkup 3 years ago but has so far managed to avoid surgery.   He has a 20 pack-year history of smoking but quit about 10 years ago and is a non-alcoholic. He is up-to-date on his routine vaccinations and has no known drug allergies.   Key Complaints: John reports the gradual onset of fatigue and having less appetite over the last three weeks. Additional symptoms include a low-grade fever and night sweats that he initially dismissed as possible flu. He also reported unintentional weight loss over this period. The most peculiar symptom he reported was a new onset of low back pain.  Considering that fever  fatigue  and night sweats are systemic signs of infection along with newly developed back pain  they raise a suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis with a possible seeding in the spine. This may be due to his pre-existing mitral requurgitation  which increases the risk of endocarditis. The presence of comorbidity such as diabetes might have contributed to his susceptibility to infection.   This case is important for medical students as it emphasizes the importance of recognizing nonspecific signs and symptoms in order to make an accurate and timely diagnosis of a condition like infective endocarditis  especially in a patient with known valvular heart disease. It communicates the understanding and detection of symptoms and manifestations related to metastatic infection  hence leading to comprehensive patient management.

Patient Profile: Name: Mr. Jones Age: 52 years Sex: Male Occupation: Construction Worker Ethnicity: African American Place of Residence: Urban setting in California  Past Medical History: 1. History of Intravenous Drug Use  ceased use approximately 10 years ago. 2. Non-Insulin-Dependent Diabetes Mellitus controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents. 3. History of poor dental hygiene with multiple untreated dental caries  have not visited a dentist in 12 years.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Jones presents to the emergency department with complaints of: 1. High-grade fever persisting for the last 1 week  not associated with chills or rigors. 2. New onset of fatigue and malaise. 3. Increasing shortness of breath on exertion over the last five days. 4. Noticeable weight loss and decreased appetite in the past week. 5. A new heart murmur noticed by the regular internist at the last outpatient visit. 6. Night sweats and intermittent  non-specific  arthralgia.  Diagnosis: Infective endocarditis (native valve)  This clinical scenario showcases a middle-aged man who has significant risk factors for infective endocarditis. His history of drug-use confers the risk of bacteremia while his poor dental hygiene further suggests an alternative avenue of infection. The patient's diabetes could accelerate the progression of endocarditis. The signs of lethargy  malaise  weight loss  fever  and heart murmurs are typical of infective endocarditis. These symptoms combined from his past medical history hint towards the possibility of infective endocarditis complicating native cardiac valves.   This case will allow further discussions about pathophysiology  microbiology  diagnostic strategies  management  and prevention of infective endocarditis. Moreover  the impact of health behaviors  such as intravenous drug use and poor dental hygiene  is highlighted as potential risk factors.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:   Mr. J.A.  a 65-year-old African American male  living in urban settings  unemployed  with a past history of intravenous drug abuse 20 years ago.  Past Medical History:  Mr. J.A. has been diagnosed with congestive heart failure (CHF) and diabetes mellitus type 2 (DMT2). He has been managing these conditions with medications. He discontinued intravenous drug usage two decades back and has been sober since then.  Chief Complaint:  Mr. J.A. presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of intermittent fever for the past two weeks  accompanied by fatigue  shortness of breath  night sweats  and unintentional weight loss of approximately 10 pounds over the same period.  On further questioning  Mr. J.A. also reveals some instances of blood in the urine  and not being able to perform his daily functions (getting dressed  going for walks  etc.) as easily due to malaise and weakness. He denied chest pain  cough  or recent travel.  Mr. J.A. has self-administered over the counter flu medicine for a week  but the fever and other symptoms have not resolved.  Based on the information provided  the medical students will further discuss the potential causes of these complaints  preferably focussing on native-valve infective endocarditis considering the past medical history of the patient  examine inferences that can be drawn  diagnostic tests that can be ordered  and possible treatment and management strategies.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  The case involves a 60-year-old African American male who works as a construction worker  weighing 88 kg  and stands approximately 6 feet tall. The patient lives in the urban area of New York  and is a smoker with a pack/day habit for the past 35 years. He is a social drinker and denies any illicit drug use.  Past Medical History:  The patient’s past medical history is significant for rheumatic fever during childhood  but not much medical attention was sought for this. He also has a long history of poor oral hygiene resulting in multiple dental caries and tooth extractions. He has not had any major illnesses or hospitalizations. He denies any known allergies and does not take any routine daily medications. There's no family history of congenital heart diseases  although both his parents have hypertension and his father had a myocardial infarction at 65 years.  Chief Complaints: Over the past 2 weeks  the patient has been feeling generalized fatigue  low-grade fever  night sweats and unexplained weight loss of approximately 5 kg during the same period. Additionally  he noticed that he became easily short of breath especially when walking up stairs  a task that was easy for him earlier  and experienced occasional chest discomfort. He also complains of having a new-onset  low-grade  constant headache which appears to be worsening.    The training case will further explore symptoms  diagnostic procedures  laboratory findings  and management related to native-valve infective endocarditis while also considering the patient's personal and medical history. This clinical case can provide a thorough understanding of this condition in a real-life context  allowing medical students to apply their theoretical knowledge to practical situations.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. Smith  Age: 54  Sex: Male  Occupation: Construction Worker Race: Caucasian  Marital Status: Married  with 2 children  Insurance: Covered under employer's health insurance plan  Session: The routine health check-up turned to an in-depth case study.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith previously suffered from an acute episode of Rheumatic fever at the age of 13  which may have resulted in some prior damage to his heart valves. He is diabetic (Type II) and a chronic smoker. He stated these conditions were managed through diet  exercise  and oral medication. Mr. Smith is allergic to penicillin and follows a restrictive diet due to mild gastritis. There are no surgical histories  family history accounts for a familial hyperlipidaemia.  Key Complaints: 1. Mr. Smith's main complaints are constant fatigue and feeling unusually weak recently. 2. He experienced weight loss in the last month  which he found alarming.  3. For the past 2 weeks  he has been having low-grade fevers  mostly in the late afternoon and early evening. 4. He mentions having intermittent bouts of night sweats.  5. Smith notices a change in his heart rhythm – he has started to feel palpitations. 6. He also presents with a new heart murmur noticed incidentally in a regular diabetic check-up.  This presentation aims to highlight the case of native-valve infective endocarditis in a patient with significant history and comorbidities. It is crucial to understand the subtle indication of endocarditis through a thorough understanding of the patient's history and symptomatology. The attention should be given to the critical complaints like low-grade fevers  fatigue  weight loss  and new-onset heart murmur  which often overlooked but potentially indicate a serious condition like infective endocarditis.

Patient Information:  A 68-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the Emergency Department (ED).  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus  intravenous (IV) drug abuse (sober for five years now)  and prior episodes of Staphylococcus aureus skin infections. He has no known allergies and is currently only taking metformin for his diabetes. His family history is remarkable for heart disease.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient arrived in the ED complaining of a high-grade fever (~39.8°C) persisting for 2 weeks  fatigue  and loss of appetite. He also mentions he has experienced recurrent chills  night sweats  and weight loss in the past month. Additionally  he reports occasional chest discomfort and shortness of breath along with a new heart murmur noticed by his primary care physician.  In this case  the patient demographics (an older male with a history of IV drug use and recurrent staph skin infections)  coupled with his symptoms (fever  fatigue  appetite loss  chest discomfort  and new heart murmur)  strongly suggest the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis. This case can be used to teach students about the risk factors  clinical presentation  and diagnostic approach to a patient with suspected infective endocarditis. The students should be instructed to assess the Duke criteria and possible use of echocardiography in the diagnosis and management of native valve endocarditis.

Patient Information:   A 55-year-old Caucasian male  Past Medical History:   The patient has a history of intravenous drug use  currently in recovery for about 5 years. He has been diagnosed with diabetes 3 years ago and is currently under metformin treatment. No known allergies. He has no previous hospitalizations and has not had any surgical interventions. He has a 10-pack year smoking history but quit 4 years ago. Receives regular check-ups  last being six months ago. Family history reveals cardiac disease in his father  who passed away from myocardial infarction in his early 60s.   Chief Complaints:   The patient came to the emergency department with chief complaints of high-grade fever that's been persistent in the past 2 weeks  fatigue  shortness of breath  and unintentional weight loss. He also reports swelling in both ankles. He notes a new heart murmur which he describes as a constant ""whooshing"" sound in his ears which he's never experienced before. He also noticed rashes on his abdomen and chest and some red painful spots on the pads of his fingers and toes. He denies any headache  chest pain  or fainting spells. There has been no recent dental work.   This case emphasizes the importance of a thorough history taking and physical examination  including knowledge about risk factors (history of IV drug use  diabetes) in approaching the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. It also incorporates some of the classical symptoms (fever  new heart murmur  peripheral signs such as findings on the skin and nails) associated with this condition.

Patient Information: 67-year-old Caucasian male  Presenting Complaint: Intermittent fever  chills  fatigue  malaise  loss of appetite  weight loss  and a new heart murmur noticed over the past few weeks.  Past Medical History:  1. History of intravenous (IV) drug use which he quit four years ago 2. Hypertension managed on losartan for the last 10 years 3. Smoker and occasional alcohol consumer  Social History: Retired engineer  lives alone. Has two grown-up children living out of state.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient appeared pale and fatigued. The oral cavity showed some dental caries. Cardiovascular exam revealed a new murmur  best heard across the mitral area with an irregular rhythm. No Osler's nodes or Janeway lesions were noted on the skin.  Key Complaints to Discus: The key complaints and findings to be discussed here include fever  fatigue  weight loss  new-onset heart murmur suggestive of a valvular abnormality  and medical history of IV drug use which predisposes him to infective endocarditis (IE). His poor dental hygiene status is a potential source of bacterial entry.   Teaching points should include an overview of native valve endocarditis  pathophysiology  the importance of oral health in cardiac disease  clinical features  and the link between IV drug usage and infective endocarditis. Importantly  students should be encouraged to appreciate the fact that while the patient had given up IV drug usage  the effects on his cardiovascular system continue to manifest and lead to disease presentations such as this. Understanding the underlying mechanisms and high-risk factors for IE is of pivotal importance in secondary prevention strategies.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: A 75-year-old African-American female is under review.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  peripheral vascular disease  and stage 3 chronic kidney disease. She had no known allergies. The patient had a 10 years history of IV drug use  but has been clean for the past 25 years.  Chief Complaints: The patient presents to the emergency department complaining of fever  fatigue  weight loss over the past month and increasing dyspnea on exertion for the past week. She also mentions experiencing an intermittent headache and night sweats. She denies any chest pain  cough  sputum production  or gastrointestinal symptoms.   Brief Review: Upon physical examination  the patient is noted to be febrile with a temperature of 38.5 C  tachycardic with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg and has an elevated respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. Cardiovascular examination reveals a diastolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal edge  dental examination shows poor oral hygiene with multiple dental caries. There is no peripheral stigmata of infective endocarditis. A chest X-ray does not show any evidence of heart failure. These symptoms and signs indicate possible native-valve infective endocarditis.    Diagnosis and further investigations such as blood cultures  echo-cardiograms  and possibly valve tissue histology  are suggested to confirm the diagnosis and guide therapy. Endocarditis due to Streptococci  Staphylococci  or Enterococci (the HACEK group of bacteria) should be suspected in this case.   The utility of this case for medical education lies in its focus on native-valve infective endocarditis – an important differential to consider in a patient with a history of IV drug use  even if long ago  presenting with sepsis and new heart murmurs. It also emphasizes the importance of a comprehensive examination and interpreting physical signs in the context of the patient's history and presenting complaints; bringing together pieces of clinical information to formulate a logical differential diagnosis and subsequent investigative and management plan.

Patient Information:   Mr. Smith  a 55-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  living in Brooklyn. Currently a non-drinker  non-smoker  with no known drug allergies. Previously experienced homelessness and had a history of intravenous drug use.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Smith has a past medical history significant for Hepatitis C and hypertension  both of which are currently under control. He has been clean from substances for the past 10 years and has no known heart diseases.   Presenting Complaints:   Mr. Smith has been presenting to the clinic with four weeks of vague symptoms that have progressively worsened. He reports experiencing a low-grade fever  fatigue  worsening dyspnea on exertion  and weight loss. He also mentions experiencing a persistent  dry cough and night sweats. Mr. Smith has newly developed heart murmur.   For the past three days  Mr. Smith has developed a painful  erythematous rash on the palms of his hands and soles of his feet that are not itchy. He is concerned as he has also recently noticed red spots present on the white part of his eyes.   Given Mr. Smith's past medical history  clinical features  and recent complaints  it would be essential to consider native-valve infective endocarditis in the differential diagnosis.   This case will help to train medical students to recognize complex clinical pictures  take comprehensive histories  and should lead to discussion on the approach towards diagnosis. Further steps to confirm diagnosis might include blood cultures  echocardiography  and meeting modified Duke criteria for infective endocarditis. Additionally  the course for this patient could include treatment options such as antibiotics and possible surgical intervention.

Patient Information:   Mr. J  a 74-year-old retired Caucasian male  non-smoker  living in New York with a past medical history of chronic rheumatic heart disease. He is on regular medication for the same. He also has a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus well-controlled with oral medications. He is allergic to penicillin. No history of drug use  blood transfusion or recent dental procedures.  Chief Complaints:   The patient presented to the emergency department with 2 weeks of fever  intermittent chills  fatigue and recent onset of dyspnea on exertion. He also reports unintentional weight loss over the past fortnight. His family members have noted him to be slightly confused over the past 3 days.  On examination  the patient appeared acutely unwell  diaphoretic and in mild distress due to shortness of breath. His vitals on presentation were: BP-105/60mm Hg  Pulse-101/min  Temp-101°F  RR-23/min  SPO2-95% on room air. Chest auscultation revealed a high pitched  harsh  pansystolic murmur graded 3/5 best heard at left sternal border.   This case introduces medical students to the clinical presentation of native-valve infective endocarditis. Future steps will examine diagnostic approach  including the need for blood cultures and echo along with the modified Duke's criteria. Discussion should also be guided towards understanding the importance of early diagnosis  proper antibiotic therapy with necessary referrals for possible surgical interventions in the management of native-valve infective endocarditis.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Patient Profile: The patient is a 66-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Davis  who is retired and living in rural Colorado. He lives alone and is a widower for the last five years. He is a smoker with a 45 pack-year history.   Past Medical History: Mr. Davis has a known history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus  which is currently managed with metformin. He has a prior documented history of Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia. He's been on anti-hypertensive medication (Lisinopril) and high cholesterol medication (Atorvastatin) for the past 12 years. He also has a history of Rheumatic Fever in his late teens. He does not have any known allergies. His immunizations are up to date  including a recent influenza vaccine.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Davis reported feeling generally weak and fatigued over the past three weeks  with no apparent reason. He has also experienced episodes of high-grade fever with chills  intermittent night sweats  and unexplained weight loss of around 5 kg in the last month. Recently he has noticed that his ankles have become swollen.   He has also been experiencing a shortness of breath  especially after basic daily activities such as walking a short distance. Additionally  he has been suffering from recurrent dizziness along with occasional chest discomfort and palpitations. He has not been feeling hungry lately and has been having trouble sleeping. Mr. Davis mentioned that he has not seen any open wounds or skin infection recently.   This concise training case focuses on the potential diagnosis and treatment of native-valve infective endocarditis  given the patient's history and key symptoms.

Patient Information:  A 60-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Johnson  with a body mass index of 27  former smoker  and residing in the urban area.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a history of stage II hypertension under control with amlodipine and type II diabetes mellitus managed with oral hypoglycemic metformin. He was previously diagnosed with rheumatic heart disease in his younger years and currently on prophylactic penicillin.  Chief Complaints: Patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of high grade  intermittent fever for 1 week associated with chills and fatigue. He also reports experiencing drenching night sweats and a weight loss of approximately 15 lbs in the last month. In addition  he mentions gradually worsening shortness of breath during normal activities and an episode of blood in his urine. He also noticed a red painful spot on the underside of his left foot  which he believes appeared three days ago. His family noticed changes in the patient’s behavior including occasional confusion  which is unusual for him.  This case report could be utilized to provide medical students the opportunity to think critically about the symptoms and signs of native-valve infective endocarditis  given the patient’s history  demographics  and chief complaints. The symptoms including fever  chills  fatigue  shortness of breath  weight loss  hematuria  neurological symptoms  and Janeway’s lesions (painless  flat  erythematous spots on palms and soles) are suggestive of the condition. The patient's history of rheumatic heart disease and prophylactic penicillin usage is a crucial clue  indicating underlying valvular defects - a risk factor for infective endocarditis. The task would be to derive a differential diagnosis  pinpoint pertinent tests to confirm the diagnosis  and recommend appropriate management in light of the patient's overall health status.

Patient Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  Sex: Male Age: 65 years old Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Dentist Residence: Urban Marital Status: Married  Past Medical History:  1. No known allergies. 2. Medical history significant for valvular heart disease (mitral valve prolapse). 3. Regular medications include aspirin  metoprolol  and multivitamins. 4. Smoking history of 10 pack years  quit 15 years ago. 5. Occasional alcohol consumption  denies illicit drug use.  Key Complaints:  The patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of intermittent high-grade fever with chills and night sweats for the past two weeks. He also reported generalised malaise  unintentional weight loss  and a new-onset shortness of breath on exertion  which has gradually worsened. The patient denies any chest pain  cough  orthopnea  syncope  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Interestingly  the patient recalled a dental extraction procedure performed approximate a month ago  followed by which he developed a mild fever that resolved spontaneously. Prior to this episode  the patient had not been noticing any similar symptoms.   The case should be designed to guide students through a detailed evaluation process  leading towards the right diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis  especially in a patient with previous valvular heart disease and recent dental procedures. This will also open up opportunities to discuss the importance of prophylactic antibiotics in such scenarios. Essentials would include history taking  physical examination (looking for signs like Osler’s nodes  Janeway lesions  Roth’s spots  or a new murmur)  laboratory and imaging studies (blood culture  echo) and their interpretations. It would also ideally include the management and potential complications of the condition.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Jacob Thompson  a 54-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the Emergency Department.  Chief Complains: The patient reported consistent fever and lethargy for the past two weeks. He also complained of having a new heart murmur.  Past Medical History: Mr. Thompson has a history of intravenous drug usage for two years and has been clean for five years now. His medical history also includes managed type II diabetes  previous bouts of recurrent cellulitis  and recent dental work done a month ago.  Physical Exam Findings: Temperature: 38.3°C Heart rate: 106 beats/min  Respiratory rate: 20 breaths/min  Blood pressure: 140/90 mmHg  Oxygen saturation: 97% on room air  There are Osler's nodes on his fingers and toes  and Janeway's lesions visible on his palms and soles. Cardiac examination reveals a new-onset regurgitant murmur at the left lower sternal border. Routine chest auscultation reveals coarse breathing sounds.  Labs:  Hemoglobin: 11.0 g/dL  WBC count: 15 000/µL  ESR/CRP: Elevation noted  Blood cultures: Pending  Diagnosis: The clinical presentation aligns with a diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis. The chronic history of intravenous drug use  recent dental work and identifying signs such as Osler's nodes  Janeway's lesions  and new onset murmur suggest this possibility. Additional diagnostic criteria for endocarditis (Duke criteria) may be further used to establish the diagnosis definitively. Further confirmatory culture tests and an echocardiogram should be ordered immediately.   This case should prompt discussions on the clinical signs and symptoms of infective endocarditis  consequences of chronic intravenous drug usage and importance of prophylaxis before dental procedures in high-risk patients. It should also highlight the need for identifying valve involvement and potential risks associated with the condition. Considering the patient's history of diabetes  it is also important to discuss the ways in which bacterial endocarditis could present differently in this patient group.

Patient Case Description:  Patient Demographics: Name: Patient X Age: 65 years old Sex: Male Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Civil Engineer Living situation: Lives alone  Past Medical History: 1. Treated for Rheumatic fever at age 15. 2. Hypertensive for past 20 years under medication. 3. History of IV drug use in early adulthood; abstinent now. 4. History of smoking  now quit about 5 years ago.  Presenting Complaints: Patient X has been experiencing persistent  low-grade fever for the past couple of weeks. Accompanied with this fever  he is also reporting having a loss of appetite and unintentional weight loss. He mentions feeling extremely fatigued  but initially attributed the symptoms to aging and work stress.   However  over the past few days  he has also noticed small  reddish or purplish spots (petechiae) on his skin and inner side of his mouth. He turned most worried when he started experiencing intermittent heart palpitations.  He presents to the emergency department after fainting in his home due to these recurrent palpitations and shortness of breath. Relations to physical activity are unclear. No known allergies reported.

Case Report  Patient Background Information:  Age: 57 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Construction worker Living Situation: Lives alone in a suburban setting.  Past Medical History:   - History of intravenous drug use in his early 20s.  - He quit drugs at 25 and remained sober since then. - Diagnosed with hypertension at the age of 40.  Presenting Complaints:  - Fever lasting for more than two weeks. - Weight loss noticed at the same time as the fever onset. - Fatigue and general malaise. - Night sweats. - Experiencing shortness of breath  particularly when lying down or walking a short distance. - Palpitations occasionally experienced.   Summary:  A 57-year-old Caucasian male  with a past history of intravenous drug use and hypertension  presented with chief complaints of fever persistent for over two weeks  weight loss  fatigue  and night sweats. Furthermore  he reported experiencing shortness of breath  notably when lying flat or walking short distances  which was not normal for him. On occasion  the patient also experienced palpitation which was described as a feeling of a rapidly beating heart. He sought medical attention as the symptoms started to interfere with his daily life and work obligations.  Consideration:  In this case  students need to connect the symptoms and past history of the patient to suspect infective endocarditis. The patient's history of previous intravenous drug use is crucial  which puts him at risk for this condition. Furthermore  the presence of persistent fever  weight loss  and complaints of breathlessness may suggest possible involvement of a valve pathology. This case will educate the students about the importance of understanding the patient's past medical history  symptoms  and considering all these aspects in making a potential diagnosis. During this exercise  students will learn to identify the risks  signs  symptoms  diagnostic tests  and possible treatment modalities for infective endocarditis.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. Jackson  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  presented to the hospital.  Chief Complaints: Mr. Jackson complained of continuous high-grade fever for two weeks  intermittent chills  sweating  loss of appetite  weight loss  and general weakness. He also mentioned experiencing breathlessness on mild exertion  which was new to him.  Past Medical History: The patient has a 10-year history of uncontrolled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  and Hypertension for which he takes Metformin and Lisinopril respectively. He was diagnosed with a mild Mitral Valve Prolapse (MVP) 5 years ago with no significant regurgitation and has regular follow-ups with a cardiologist. He has no known drug allergies. He is a non-smoker and denies any illicit drug usage. Mr. Jackson has no prior hospitalizations and lives with his wife. He adheres to his medication regimen as prescribed and has no significant family history of cardiac problems.  Based on the patient's complaints  demographics  past medical history  and risk factors  students should be encouraged to consider native-valve infective endocarditis due to the MVP in their differential diagnosis. The high-grade fever suggests a possible infection  while the breathlessness on mild exertion implies potential heart failure secondary to the infective endocarditis. The students should be taught to investigate the patient's symptoms through a targeted history  physical examination  and necessary diagnostics to confirm the diagnosis and initiate appropriate therapy.  This case will also provide an opportunity to discuss the etiology  pathophysiology  clinical presentation  complications  and management of native-valve infective endocarditis  highlighting the significance of early diagnosis and intervention in such cases. Suggestive treatment approaches should involve antibiotics per latest guidance  considering the patient's age  comorbidities  allergy status  lab results  and culture sensitivities. The team should be reminded to take into account the patient's comfort  preferences  lifestyle  and overall well-being while formulating the treatment plan.

Case Report: Native-valve Infective Endocarditis   Patient Information: Name: J.D. (Initials  real name confidential) Age: 60 years old Race: Caucasian  Gender: Male Occupation: Retired engineer  Medical History: J.D. has a history of Type 2 Diabetes for 5 years. The disease is maintained under control with oral hypoglycemic agents. He was operated on for colorectal cancer approximately one year ago. J.D. had a history of heavy smoking for 40 years before quitting 3 years ago. The patient also has been diagnosed with Hypertension 3 years ago which is managed with medications. There is no history of illicit drug use.  Presenting Complaints: J.D. presents to the emergency department with complaints of intermittent fever  lasting 1-3 hours  occuring 2-3 times daily for the past two weeks. The fever peaks to around 39 degrees Celsius  associated with fatigue and general body ache. He also reports experiencing shortness of breath on exertion for the past 7 days  forcing him to limit his activities.  Over the past week  he noticed the appearance of petechial rashes on his lower legs which he ignored initially  believing them to be bug bites. He has also lost appetite in the past week which has led to a weight loss of about 4 kilograms.  He is specifically bothered by a recently noticed change in his urine  which has turned dark and tea-colored. He has no prior history of known heart disease. He has not been exposed to anyone who is sick or has traveled outside the country recently.   This case report is prepared whilst addressing the key symptoms indicating a possible diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis  proving an effective teaching tool for medical students.

Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 55-year-old Caucasian male  working as a construction worker  and a resident of New York City.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe is a smoker with a 30-year pack history. He also has longstanding uncontrolled type 2 diabetes and a 10-year history of intravenous drug use  though claims to have been clean for the past 2 years. There is no previous history of heart diseases reported.  Presenting complaints: Mr. Doe presents to the emergency department complaining of high-grade fever with chills for the past two weeks. He also reports experiencing fatigue  night sweats  weight loss  intermittent headaches  and shortness of breath on mild exertion. He further mentions the occurrence of a few  small  painless red lesions on his fingers and toes.  In the past month  he had undergone dental treatment for root canal therapy and had 2 episodes of allergic reactions which resolved spontaneously. He admits to not regular with his follow-up for diabetes management due to personal reasons.  Summary: This training case focuses on a 55-year-old male patient with a history of uncontrolled diabetes  intravenous drug use  and recent dental procedure  presenting with symptoms like high-grade fever and fatigue  which are suggestive of native valve infective endocarditis. The patient's history of intravenous drug use  possible bacteremia following the dental procedure  his diabetes and non-healing skin lesions are potential risk factors and provide a platform for medical students to delve into the relationship between these factors and the development  diagnosis  and management of infective endocarditis.

Patient Details: Name: Patient X Age: 65 years Gender: Male Occupation: Retired teacher Race: Caucasian  Past medical history: Patient X has a history of IV drug use in the past  he is suffering from chronic treatment-resistant hepatitis C  and has been through multiple rounds of unsuccessful antiviral therapy. He has been sober for the last 20 years but continues to have annual check-ups for hepatitis C. The patient also has a history of rheumatic fever in his childhood which led to moderate aortic valve disease. He also had atrial fibrillation for which he has been on warfarin therapy for several years. He was a heavy smoker but quit a decade ago.  Key Complaints: Patient X was admitted with a two-week history of lethargy  malaise  and intermittent fever. He also complained of newly onset shortness of breath  especially on exertion. He indicated he had lost weight unintentionally over the past few weeks. Furthermore  he mentioned experiencing night sweats and a decrease in appetite. He reported an episode of seeing blood in his sputum a few days ago.   Travel/ Exposures: The patient has not travelled recently and lives alone. He mentioned a dental procedure performed about a month ago where antibiotics were not prophylactically given.   Lifestyle: Patient X used to be a heavy smoker but gave up a decade ago. He has a history of intravenous drug use  but he became sober 20 years ago.  Reason for the Report: This patient's complaints of fever  fatigue  an episode of hemoptysis  and noticeable weight loss combined with a significant past medical history of IV drug abuse and aortic valve disease could indicate a possible diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. The absence of prophylactic antibiotics during a dental procedure adds to the risk. Hence  medical students should consider these symptoms to recognize and initiate the management of potential infective endocarditis.

Case Report  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 63-year-old Caucasian male.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of intravenous drug use and was treated for hepatitis C three years ago. He also has a history of smoking (1 pack/day for 30 years) and moderate alcohol consumption. He has no documented history of heart disease  hypertension or diabetes.  Chief Complaints: The patient presents to the emergency department with new onset fever  general malaise  fatigue  and shortness of breath on exertion for the last 2 weeks. He also reports having night sweats  intermittent chills and a weight loss of approximately 8 pounds over the same period. The patient admits to a few episodes of passing dark colored urine in the past week. He denies having chest pain  cough  abdominal pain  or nausea and vomiting.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 58 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Plumber Social habits: Smoker (1 pack/day for 30 years) Location: Urban  Case Report:  Mr. John Doe  a 58-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the outpatient department with a two-week history of fever  night sweats  chills  and unintentional weight loss of about 10 pounds. He also mentions experiencing fatigue  shortness of breath  and a persistent cough  which he initially assumed to be related to his smoking habit and season change. He denies any history of illicit drug use but admits he smokes a pack of cigarettes daily and has done so for the last 30 years.  Past medical history is significant for rheumatic fever in childhood  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes which he manages with oral medications. He has no known allergies.  On examination  he appears cachectic  and his temperature is elevated at 38.6°C (101.48°F). Cardiovascular examination reveals a new systolic murmur heard best at the apex that radiates to the axilla. His lungs are clear to auscultation and percussion. He has non-tender splenomegaly. His skin shows petechiae on his lower extremities and his conjunctiva are pale.  The overall clinical presentation and past rheumatic fever history suggest a native-valve infective endocarditis case  requiring further evaluation and management.  Key clinical features for the case: Onset of nonspecific symptoms including persistent unexplained fever and weight loss which may indicate a systemic infection. New onset murmur may suggest valvular damage due to infection. A history of rheumatic fever which put him at risk of endocarditis. Physical findings such as petechiae and splenomegaly which are consistent with endocarditis.  Skin and systemic physical findings suggest the diagnosis of infective endocarditis. Habits which exacerbate his overall health and predispose him to risks of infections such as smoking.  Laboratory findings of anemia  raised CRP  positive blood cultures (which will be confirmed after subsequent testing).

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Demographics:  Mr. X is a 60-year-old Caucasian male who is a retired school teacher. He is a non-smoker  occasionally consumes alcohol and has no known drug allergies.   Past Medical History: Mr. X has a significant past medical history including type 2 diabetes mellitus  chronic kidney disease stage 2  and hypertension. He is well managed with metformin for diabetes  lisinopril for hypertension  and a restricted diet for his kidney condition. He has no known previous cardiac conditions or surgical interventions.   Initial Presentation / Key Complaints: Mr. X presents to the emergency department with a four-week history of low-grade fever  malaise  unintentional weight loss  and a new-onset change in character of previously regular heart beats. Over the past week  he has also begun to experience dyspnea on exertion and a nocturnal cough. He reports no chest pain  nausea  or dizziness. However  he has noticed several scattered dark red spots on his palms and soles.  This case report can be utilized for a training scenario dealing with a presentation of native-valve infective endocarditis. The subsequent steps would involve differential diagnosis  investigation (including blood cultures  an echocardiogram)  diagnosis confirmation  treatment decisions (including antibiotic therapy  possible surgical considerations)  management of treatment complications  and considering prophylaxis in the future.

Patient Information: A Caucasian woman  aged 65 years  presents to the emergency department at a local hospital.   Past Medical History: Patient has a history of rheumatoid arthritis  for which she was prescribed methotrexate. She is also a regular smoker with a 30-pack year smoking history.  Presenting Complaints: For the past week  she complained of persistent high-grade fever  chills  fatigue  and night sweats. Other symptoms include loss of appetite leading to significant weight loss and a new heart murmur. She also mentioned an unusual shortness of breath  especially when performing strenuous activities. On specific inquiry  she disclosed experiencing arthralgia predominantly affecting her knee and shoulder joints. She did not report any recent dental procedures or surgeries and she denied any drug abuse.  Physical Examination Findings: Upon physical examination  she appears exhausted and diaphoretic. Vital signs revealed: temperature - 38.6 degrees Celsius  pulse rate - 101 per minute  respiratory rate - 22 per minute  blood pressure - 105/65 mmHg  oxygen saturation - 96% on room air. Her heart examination showed a new regurgitant murmur best heard at the mitral area. Skin examination revealed petechiae in the conjunctiva and splinter hemorrhages in the nail beds. No Osler nodes or Janeway lesions were noted.   Potential Clinical Concern: The clinical presentation of consistent fever  fatigue  weight loss  new onset cardiac murmur and evidence of vasculitic lesions in the patient raises the suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis. Additional investigations like blood cultures and echocardiogram are needed to confirm the diagnosis. Appropriate treatment should be initiated promptly to reduce the risk of potential complications  such as heart failures and systemic embolizations.  Additional Recommendations: This case can be used to teach medical students about the importance of detailed history taking  holistic examination and high clinical suspicion in diagnosing non-specific presentations like infective endocarditis. It also emphasizes the alterations in presentation due to underlying co-morbid conditions and the knowledge about potential triggers like use of immunosuppressants for rheumatoid arthritis.

Patient Case Report  Patient Demographics:   Name: Patient X (To maintain confidentiality) Age: 55 years old Sex: Male Occupation: Janitor Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian Marital status: Married Residential location: Urban area  Past Medical History:  1. Type 2 diabetes mellitus - diagnosed 8 years ago and being managed with diet control and Metformin. 2. Hypertension - diagnosed 5 years ago  managed with hydrochlorothiazide. 3. History of IV drug use in his 20s. 4. Dental procedure performed 2 weeks prior. 5. No known allergies. 6. Tobacco user (20 cigarettes/day for the past 30 years) 7. No major surgical interventions reported.  Presenting complaints:  The patient presented with a 2-week history of: 1. Fever  with temperatures up to 38.6 degrees Celsius. 2. Intermittent sweating. 3. Progressive fatigue. 4. Unintended weight loss of approximately 5kg over the past month.  5. Joint pain  particularly in the knees and elbows. 6. New onset heart murmur noticed by primary care physician. 7. On further inquiry  patient has noticed occasional small  painless red spots on the palms of his hands and soles of his feet.  Summary:   55-year-old male with a history of type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and previous IV drug use presents with fever  sweating  fatigue  weight loss  joint pain  a new heart murmur  and appearance of petechiae  with a recent history of dental work. The constellation of symptoms  signs  and risk factors points towards a possible diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. Further diagnostic confirmation is required  which might include blood cultures and echocardiography.

Patient Demographics:  The patient is a 55-year-old Caucasian male. He is married  owns a small business and has three children.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of intravenous drug use in his early 20s. He has been clean for the past 25 years. He suffers from hypertension and has been on medication (lisinopril 10 mg daily) for the past 10 years. He does not have any known allergies. He has no history of surgery or hospitalization. His family history includes a father who died of a heart attack at 60 and a mother who is alive and well at 85 years old.  Key Complaints: The patient presents with a four-week history of unexplained sustained low-grade fever (100.4-101.2 F)  fatigue  loss of appetite  10 pounds of unintentional weight loss  night sweats  muscle aches and a newly noted heart murmur by his primary care physician. Over the past week  he has noticed small red spots on his palms  and recently noted black and blue spots under his fingernails.  Suspicion: Based on the presented symptoms  the need for differential diagnosis becomes critical. However  the history of IV drug use (though over two decades ago)  new heart murmur  and persistent fever without clear infectious source raise high suspicion for native-valve infective endocarditis  despite the prolonged absence of relapse into drug use. It would be essential to further investigate for a definitive diagnosis.

Patient Identification:  - Mr. J.R.  51-year-old Caucasian male with primary language English.  Demographics: - Occupation: Construction worker - Marital Status: Married  - Socioeconomic Status: Middle Class - Residence: Suburban Area - Insurance status: Private insurance holder   Past Medical History: - Diagnosed with Rheumatic fever in his childhood  causing some degree of damage to his heart valves. - Has a 20-year history of smoking  averaging a packet a day.  - No known allergies. - Dental procedures done 1 month back. - Family history of early coronary artery disease and hypertension.   Presenting Complaints: - History of ongoing fatigue and weakness for around 2 months. - Recently started complaining of night sweats and low-grade intermittent fever for past 2 weeks. - New onset of moderate continuous dull ache sensation in the chest. - Notable weight loss over 2 months. - Obscure back pain and dyspnea on exertion for the past few days.  This case scenario sets up for a classic presentation and known risk factors of native valve infective endocarditis  given the past history of rheumatic fever and recent dental procedures. Presenting complaints of fatigue  fever  chest pain  weight loss  and back pain may hint toward the possible diagnosis. The intention is to enable students to connect clinical manifestations  risk factors with the possible diagnoses  work up an effective diagnostic plan and subsequently  appropriate management. Future steps with this scenario would include guiding learners through possible differential diagnoses  identification of key history  examination and investigations needed to confirm the diagnosis of infective endocarditis.

Patient Information:   Mr. John Doe  57-year-old Caucasian male.  Past medical history:   Mr. Doe has a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  which is well-controlled with medication and diet. He has been treated for hypertension and high cholesterol. He does not have any history of smoking  alcoholism  or intravenous drug use. He does not have any known drug allergies. Past medical history does not include any surgeries or hospitalizations.  Presenting complaints:  Mr. Doe has visited the clinic with the primary complaints of persistent  low-grade fever (~100.4°F) that has been present for the past three weeks. He reported occasional night sweats  generalized malaise  and a weight loss of about 5 pounds over the past month. He also complained of experiencing an intermittently irregular heartbeat for the past week  something he had never experienced before.  On further probing  Mr. Doe admitted to a loss of appetite and occasional shortness of breath but denied any cough  abdominal pain  or dysuria. He also denied any recent travels or encounters with sick persons.  This real-life case is designed to make the students reflect on Infective endocarditis as a differential in such clinical scenarios and predict the necessary diagnostic steps. It will further emphasize the significance of early diagnosis and line of management for native-valve infective endocarditis. The case will also challenge students to think about potential complications if the condition is not treated promptly.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: A 60-year-old female Caucasians has visited the hospital  living in an urban area  married  employed as a high school teacher.  Past Medical History: Patient has a past medical history of rheumatic fever suffered in her mid-20s and uncontrolled type-2 diabetes mellitus. There is no history of congenital heart disease  IV drug use  or previous valve surgery. Patient has been generally healthy with her last hospitalization about 25 years ago due to childbirth.   Key Complaints: Patient presents to the Emergency Department complaining of unexplained weight loss of about 10% of her body weight over the past 2 months  associated with low-grade fever  fatigue  night sweats  and a lack of appetite. Over the past week  she started experiencing shortness of breath on exertion and some vague chest discomfort. She also noticed dark reddish spots on her palms and soles  painless and not pruritic. She mentioned having a change in her urinary habits  needing to go to the bathroom more frequently. No history of cough  abdominal pain  nausea  vomiting or recent travels. Patient denies any smoking  alcohol  or illicit drug use.   This case presentationist to help medical students understand the presentation pattern of native-valve infective endocarditis in individuals who have a history of rheumatic fever. It is crucial to note the non-specific complaints which may hinder prompt diagnosis and treatment  potentially resulting in adverse outcomes.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 62-year-old African-American male.  Past Medical History: The patient's past medical history includes hypertension  Type II diabetes mellitus  and tobacco use - 2 packs per day for the last 40 years. He has not ever been diagnosed with heart disease or rheumatic fever and denies past illicit IV drug use. Three months ago he suffered from a dental abscess which was treated by his dentist without complications.  Current Complaints: The patient presents to the ER with complaints of fever and fatigue for three weeks  intermittent night sweats  new onset of shortness of breath for five days  and a two day history of swollen feet. He acknowledges weight loss of ten pounds over the last month due to decreased appetite but denies chest pain or cough. He notes that he has been feeling generally unwell but thought it was the flu until he developed difficulty in breathing.   On physical examination  he is found to be very pale  febrile (38.7 C)  tachycardic (118 bpm)  and displays mild peripheral edema. Upon auscultation of the heart  a new murmur is detected - a grade III/VI mid-systolic ejection murmur best heard at the left upper sternal border.  This clinical case focuses on pneumonia and heart disease  with a particular emphasis on native-valve infective endocarditis  its risk factors  diagnostic investigation  and management. The presence of a new heart murmur  the patient's recent history of dental abscess along with non resolving fever despite it's non-specific presentation should raise suspicion of infective endocarditis in this patient. Investigation plans should include blood cultures  echocardiography  and possible other sources of infection like dental examination. This case will provide a good learning opportunity on multi-system influence considering cardiovascular  infectious disease and potential hematologic issues related to subacute bacterial endocarditis.

Patient Information:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 57 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Carpenter  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe is an otherwise healthy man with no significant past medical history. He has a 20-year history of smoking and consumes alcohol socially. There's no record of homelessness  drug addiction  or significant travel history.  He has not been previously hospitalized or undergone any surgical procedure  and he does not have any history of congenital heart diseases or rheumatic fever. He doesn't remember ever having dental procedures without proper antibiotic prophylaxis. He's not on any chronic medication and he doesn't have known drug allergies.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department with high-grade fever (~39.5°C  103.1°F) for the past two weeks  associated with chills and rigors. He also complained of fatigue  loss of appetite  and weight loss. He mentioned feeling unusually short of breath  especially while performing his usual daily activities  and experiencing a mild  dull ache in his lower back which he initially attributed to his occupation as a carpenter. He also noticed a painless  red rash on his palms and soles that appeared over the past week.  He denies chest pain  palpitations  cough  night sweats  nausea or vomiting. He has not noted any changes in his urine or bowel habits or any joint pain or swelling. However  he does recall having toothache and underwent a dental procedure about a month ago.  Conclusion:  Based on Mr. Doe's symptoms and a history of recent dental procedures without prophylaxis  he's suspected to have infective endocarditis (IE). His condition could be a classic presentation of subacute bacterial endocarditis. His symptoms of fever  fatigue  and loss of appetite are non-specific but are often seen in IE. Presence of Janeway lesions (painless  red rashes on palms and soles) is another clue to IE. The combination of both cardiac (shortness of breath) and renal (lower back pain interpreted as flank pain) symptoms suggest possible systemic embolization  a known complication of IE. This case allows students to delve deeply into the various presentations and complications of native-valve infective endocarditis.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  Mr. John  a 58-year-old Caucasian male  who works as a farmer  presented at the outpatient department of our institution. He is a lifelong resident of a rural area and lives with his wife.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes that has been managed by lifestyle modifications and metformin for the past ten years. He also had rheumatic fever at the age of 10  which was managed accordingly. There is no history of any cardiovascular diseases  hypertension  respiratory diseases  kidney diseases  liver diseases  or autoimmune diseases. He mentions being a non-smoker and only consumes alcohol during social events. However  he does not undertake regular physical exercises.  Key Complaints: Mr. John presented with a 3-week history of intermittent fever  chills  fatigue  a significant loss of weight  night sweats  and a reduced appetite. Moreover  he complains of shortness of breath on moderate exertion. He reports no cough  chest pain  palpitations  ankle swelling  nausea  vomiting  or abdominal pain. He has not travelled recently  has no significant family history  does not own any pets  and has not been exposed to any infectious diseases to his knowledge. Currently  he does not use any medications except for his diabetes. His immunization history is up-to-date  including pneumococcal and yearly influenza vaccines.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Demographics: The patient is Mr. Jones  a 66-year-old African-American male. He resides in an urban city in a low-income  densely populated neighborhood. He spent his career as a sanitation worker and now lives with his wife  who is his primary caregiver.  Past medical history: Mr. Jones has a long history of uncontrolled Type II diabetes and periods of intravenous drug use in his younger years. He quit his habit 10 years ago  though. In addition  he suffered a minor stroke 3 years prior. He also suffers from chronic periodontitis with recurrent dental infections. His medical compliance history is poor  and he has sporadic follow-ups.  Key Complaints: Mr. Jones has been brought to the hospital by his wife citing a decline in general health over the past week. He complains of high-grade intermittent fevers  chills  worsening weakness  and unintentional weight loss. He also mentions having epigastric discomfort and back pain for the past few days. He noticed a few small red spots on his palms and soles yesterday. He denies any acute changes in his vision or hearing  cough  or urinary complaints. His wife reports that he has been increasingly confused the past two days.  These symptoms should alert the medical students to consider a differential diagnosis including native-valve infective endocarditis  especially given the patient's history of poor dental hygiene and past intravenous drug use. Further physical examination  lab tests  and imaging studies would be required to confirm this.

Patient Information: Mr. John Miller  59-year-old Caucasian male  works as a gardener  residing in Austin  Texas.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Miller presents with a two-week history of fever  fatigue  weight loss  night sweats  and intermittent joint pain. He also reports a new murmur  suggestive of a heart condition  which was not previously documented.  Past Medical History: He has a history of Intravenous drug use in his mid-twenty years but has been clean for over three decades. Mr. Miller was treated for Hepatitis C 8 years ago. He is a non-smoker  does occasional social drinking  and has no known allergies. There is no history of heart disease in his immediate family.   Clinical Findings: On examination  he appears ill and fatigued. Vital signs revealed a fever of 38.5 degrees Celsius  a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  and blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg.
