Cardiac exam found a new 3/6 systolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. Lab findings showed leukocytosis and positive blood cultures for Staphylococcus aureus.  This training case on native-valve infective endocarditis prompts students on crucial aspects of medical care including medical history and physical examination  proper diagnostic testing  and treatment decision-making. It highlights the importance of understanding risk factors associated with infective endocarditis  particularly among patients with a history of intravenous drug use. Furthermore  the case emphasizes the recognition of the various and often non-specific symptoms that patients with infective endocarditis may present.

Patient Details:  Name: J.D. (Initials used to protect identity) Age: 62 Gender: Male Occupation: Retired school teacher Race/ Ethnicity: White Living Situation: Lives alone in rural Montana  Past Medical History:  1. The patient is obese and has been diagnosed with Type II Diabetes  which has been well controlled with Metformin & lifestyle modifications. 2. He suffered from Rheumatic Fever as a child. 3. No known allergies. 4. He is a former smoker who quit 12 years ago.  5. The patient consumes alcohol socially.  Present Complaint:  J.D. presented to the clinic with complaints of fever persisting for three weeks  accompanied by fatigue and mild intermittent chest pain. He also mentioned experiencing night sweats and loss of appetite  which resulted in weight loss over the past month. Additionally  he reports noticing some small  purple  painless spots on his skin and under his fingernails.   Physical Examination:  Upon manual examination  a systolic murmur was audible in the left sternal border  which increased with the Valsalva maneuver. Patient's dentition was poor with multiple untreated caries and evidence of gingivitis. Additionally  a few petechiae were noted on his legs and feet.  These characteristics are suggestive of a patient with native-valve infective endocarditis. For verification  further medical investigation with blood cultures and imaging tests needs to be advised.

Case report:  Patient Information:   A 53-year-old Hispanic female presents herself to the hospital. She does not drink alcohol or use illegal substances. She is a heavy smoker having smoked a pack a day for 30 years.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of rheumatic heart disease from her adolescence and currently has mitral valve stenosis. As a part of her follow-up  she has been on Penicillin prophylaxis. She has no known drug allergies. She is not on any other medication. She had an episode of pneumonia 5 years ago  but no other significant lung issues. She has a history of untreated Dental Caries and her last dental checkup was over a decade ago.  Key Complaints:  Over the past 2 weeks  she has been experiencing relentless fever with temperature spiking to 102°F  associated with chills  night sweats and general malaise. She also complains of increasing fatigue  unintentional weight loss  and recent breathlessness on exertion over the past week. Moreover  she noticed that her ankles had started to swell towards the end of each day. She remarked on having an oddly metallic taste in her mouth. Upon inspection  she was found to have multiple untreated dental caries.

Patient Information:  Mr. Smith  a 52-year-old Caucasian man  is being assessed at our outpatient facility. He's a lifelong resident of the city  working as a construction worker. He has been married for 30 years and has two adult children.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith is a non-smoker and reports moderate alcohol use. He has a past medical history of rheumatic fever in childhood  but no history of intravenous drug use or recent dental procedures. His immunizations are up-to-date  and he typically enjoys good health. His maternal family history includes a history of structural heart diseases.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Smith reports a two-week history of feeling generally unwell but interpreted it as a prolonged flu. His symptoms have escalated over the past few days  including high fever  perspiration  weakness  fatigue  and weight loss. Additionally  he describes experiencing a continuous  mild  and dull chest discomfort  but no acute chest pain. He further reported discomfort in his lower back paired with joint aches but no visible swelling. He has also noticed tiny  flat  painless red spots under the skin of his palms and soles and occasional shortness of breath  particularly when climbing stairs or walking briskly.  Training Case Focus:  This patient's symptoms  history of rheumatic fever  and recent onset of non-specific symptoms such as fatigue  fever  and mild chest discomfort may indicate infective endocarditis. The presence of petechiae  the tiny red spots on his hands and feet  further strengthens this suspicion. Native-valve infective endocarditis (as opposed to prosthetic-valve) is indicated due to the lack of record showing valve-repair or -replacement surgery.  Next Steps:  Physical examination should include observing for additional signs of endocarditis such as Osler's nodes  Janeway lesions  or Roth spots. An echocardiogram and blood cultures should be ordered. If endocarditis is confirmed  a cardiologist should be consulted  and antibiotic treatment should be started. This case highlights the importance of considering past medical history  and non-specific symptoms while diagnosing.   The students should also keep in mind the broader differential for fever of unknown origin  including malignancies  autoimmune conditions  and other infectious diseases  and learn to systematically rule them out. Finally  they should consider the patient's lifestyle  profession  and family history in identifying potential risk factors for complex conditions such as infective endocarditis.

Patient Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. Rodriguez  a 68-year-old Hispanic male  Past Medical History: Known diabetic on oral hypoglycemic treatment for the past 8 years. Presents with a history of Rheumatic Heart Disease (RHD) from his childhood  for which he did not have regular follow-ups post his teen years. He is also a former smoker who has successfully abstained for the past decade but consumed alcohol socially until about a year ago. He has been inconsistent with his dental visits partly due to fear of oral procedures and partly due to his inability to afford them.  Chief Complaints: Mr. Rodriguez was brought to the clinic with fatigue  mild shortness of breath  low-grade intermittent fever  and weight loss continuing for the past three weeks. He also mentioned experiencing occasional night swea10ts and rapid heart rate episodes. He also emphasized that he recently started to experience overall weakness  especially during his routine activities. He also noted general malaise and decreased appetite.  These indicators are clues towards a possible infectious disease with systemic involvement. Given the patient's previous history of RHD and lack of oral care  a different diagnosis like native-valve infective endocarditis should also be suspected.  (Note: Remember this is a hypothetical case; real-life situations may call for different approaches based on available facilities  personnel  and patient specifics.)

Patient Information:  A 58-year-old Caucasian female patient Residence: Urban Occupation: College professor  Past Medical History: Mitral valve prolapse diagnosed 5 years ago. No history of illicit drug use. History of goiter treated non-surgically 8 years ago. Non-smoker and moderate alcohol drinker. Current medications include beta-blockers for MVP management and levothyroxine for hypothyroidism.  Key Complaints: The patient presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of intermittent fever  malaise  and fatigue. She also mentions recently experiencing drenching night sweats. Over the past few days  the patient noted fleeting joint pain and an unexplained weight loss of 5 lbs. There is no cough  chest pain  dyspnea  or gastrointestinal symptoms.   On examination  the patient appears pallid and fatigued. Her temperature is 100.6 F  blood pressure 120/80 mmHg  pulse 92/min  and respiration 20/min. Cardiac examination reveals a diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border. Wide-spread petechiae are visible on her legs and feet  with no obvious signs of trauma or injury.  Given her symptoms and mitral valve prolapse history  the possibility of native-valve infective endocarditis should be considered. Further diagnosis awaits comprehensive tests including blood culture  echocardiography  and other necessary examinations.

Case Report – Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Demographics:  Mr. AB is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who resides in urban Albany  New York. He is retired and lives with his wife. He has a smoking history of 15 years but quit 20 years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally.  Past Medical History:  Mr. AB was diagnosed with type II diabetes 7 years ago which is currently regulated on metformin. He has hypertension and has been on amlodipine for the past five years. He does not have any known drug allergies. He had a laparoscopic appendectomy 15 years ago and a herniorrhaphy 10 years back.  Key Complaints:  Mr. AB presented to the emergency department with a high-grade fever of 103°F  which was intermittent and associated with chills and rigors for the past one week. He also complained of fatigue  night sweats  and unexplained weight loss over the last month. There was also a shortness of breath and palpitations for the past 2-3 days. On specific questioning  he noted some small  painless red spots on the palms of his hands that he thought were allergy related.   Further evaluation  history  and a physical examination might reveal symptoms suggestive of infective endocarditis such as new or changed heart murmur  evidence of vascular phenomena like emboli  hemorrhages  or Janeway lesions  and immunological phenomena like Osler's nodes  Roth spots  or glomerulonephritis  ultimately leading to appropriate investigations  diagnosis and appropriate management for native-valve infective endocarditis.   This case can be used to illustrate to medical students the importance of taking a detailed history  recognizing key symptoms of infective endocarditis  and understanding its pathophysiology  diagnosis  and management.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department.  Chief Complaint: The patient has been experiencing fever  chills  fatigue  night sweats  and weight loss for the past 3 weeks. He's been having a new onset of shortness of breath for the last three days and was suffering from slight chest discomfort.  Past Medical History: The patient smoked 1 pack/day for 30 years but quit 10 years back. His medical history reveals a diagnosis of diabetes mellitus type 2  which is under control with metformin and diet. He does not have any known allergies. He does not have a history of intravenous drug use  recent surgeries  or dental procedures.  Social History: The patient is retired and lives with his wife. The patient denies any alcohol or illicit drug use. He has two adult children who are health professionals.  Physical Exam: On physical examination  the patient has a low-grade fever (38.1 Celsius / 100.58 Fahrenheit) and mild tachycardia. Auscultation of the heart reveals a new murmur  suggestive of aortic regurgitation. There are several small  painless erythematous lesions on the fingers and toes (Osler's nodes) and hemorrhagic macular lesions on his palms and soles (Janeway lesions).  Imaging and Labs: Blood cultures are ordered and are positive for Staphylococcus aureus. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) reveals aortic valve vegetations. Complete blood count shows leukocytosis  and ESR and CRP are elevated suggestive of ongoing inflammation.  This case aims to teach medical students about native-valve infective endocarditis. This patient's constellation of symptoms  physical exam findings  and positive blood cultures points to infective endocarditis (IE). IE is a serious infection and needs to be treated promptly to avoid possible life-threatening complications such as heart failure and systemic embolization. This case helps to illustrate the importance of recognizing the symptoms and signs of IE and ordering appropriate diagnostic tests. Moreover  it illustrates the role of heart valve vegetations in blood culture negative endocarditis.    Further medical management should include IV antibiotics therapy following the consultation with a infectious disease specialist and the consideration of surgical intervention based on the patient's response to treatment  as guided by a cardiologist or cardiothoracic surgeon.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information: A 65-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the clinic for evaluation of persistent symptoms.  Chief Complaints: The patient complains of a two-week history of intermittent fever  chills  fatigue  unexplained weight loss  and night sweats. He also mentions experiencing a periodic shortness of breath and a persistent productive cough.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of previous aortic valve replacement due to a congenital heart defect  mild persistent asthma  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  which is well-managed by oral hypoglycemic medications. Former smoker  quit 5 years ago  with a 25 pack-year history. There is no history of IV drug use  recent dental procedures  or recent travel.   Home Medications: The patient’s medications include Metformin 500mg BID for diabetes  Salbutamol inhaler as needed for his asthma  and periodic Paracetamol 500mg for fever. He was adherent to his medication regimen.  Family History: The patient's family history is notable for coronary artery disease in his father and diabetes mellitus in his mother  suggesting a genetic component to his medical history.   Social History: The patient is a retired automotive engineer  lives with his wife  and has three children who are all in good health. He does not consume alcohol and has no known drug allergies.   Brief Consideration: This case can be designed to highlight key diagnostic modalities for the diagnosis of native valve infective endocarditis  such as echocardiography  blood cultures  and the Duke criteria. Further  discussion can be steered toward the medical management of infective endocarditis. This may include long term IV antibiotics  possible surgical intervention  and the importance of pre-procedural prophylaxis in high-risk patients. The necessity of managing other comorbid conditions – such as diabetes and asthma  in this particular patient - can also be discussed.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  A 69-year-old Caucasian man  a retired plumber  living in the Midwest.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a long-standing history of rheumatic heart disease  resulting from rheumatic fever in his childhood. He also suffers from uncontrolled diabetes mellitus type 2  hypertension  and has a smoking history of 30 pack-years. He had a dental procedure 2 weeks ago but does not recall taking any antibiotics prior to the procedure.  Chief Complaints:  The patient presented to the ER with a 1-week history of high-fever  generalized weakness  chills  excessive night sweats and unintentional weight loss. He also reports shortness of breath  a new onset heart murmur  and lower back pain along with a swollen  painful right ankle.  This case is designed to enable medical students to diagnose and manage a case of native-valve infective endocarditis. The patient's rheumatic heart disease coupled with his recent dental procedure without appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis should prompt students to suspect infective endocarditis. Symptoms such as fever  chills  night sweats  weight loss  and a new murmur reinforce this suspicion. The patient's lower back pain and swollen  painful ankle are indicative of possible septic emboli  another common complication of infective endocarditis. As the patient also has a history of diabetes and hypertension  any treatment plan must take these conditions into account.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Patient is a 64-year-old Caucasian female known as Mrs. A. She is from a suburban community and is a retired schoolteacher. She has a history of occasional alcohol intake but denies smoking or drug use. She lives with her husband and has three adult children.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of rheumatic fever at the age of 15 with minimal cardiac sequelae  hypertension controlled with losartan 50mg daily  type 2 diabetes mellitus that is diet-controlled  and dyslipidemia treated with atorvastatin 20mg daily. She previously had a dental procedure two months ago where antibiotics were not administered prior to the procedure.  Key Complaints: Mrs. A presents to the emergency room with a two-week history of persistent  low-grade fever  tiredness  joint pain  and a recent onset of a new heart murmur pointed out by her primary care physician. She also noted a decreased appetite and unintentional weight loss of around 5 pounds over the same period. There have been occasional episodes of night sweats in the past week. The patient has a history of intermittent toothaches for two days following her dental procedure two months back  which was managed with over-the-counter analgesics.  In the past week  she has been experiencing difficulty breathing  especially when lying down or during exertion. There have been episodes of dizziness and palpitations as well. However  she denies chest pain  cough  nausea  or vomiting. She also indicates experiencing a mild  constant headache over the past few days along with some visual disturbances in the form of spots in her vision.  This case report could then proceed to clinical findings  diagnostic assessment  therapeutic interventions  and final outcomes to teach medical students how to approach  diagnose  and manage potential infective endocarditis in a patient.

Case Study: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis   Patient Information: - Age: 64 years old - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired company executive  Medical History: John  the patient  has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 10 years ago  managed by diet control and oral hypoglycaemic agents. He also has hyperlipidaemia for which he uses a statin. There is no history of surgeries  allergies or tobacco use. He consumes moderate amounts of alcohol socially. There is no family history of coronary artery disease or any other significant heart-related issues. Furthermore  John has no known history of intravenous drug use.   Presenting Complaints: John presents with a 2-week history of intermittent fever  fatigue  moderate unintentional weight loss  and night sweats. He also reported experiencing new-onset shortness of breath on exertion and dull aching pain in his lower back. John reported experiencing these symptoms progressively worsening over the course of several days.   On further enquiry  he also reported having poor dentition and recently had invasive dental procedures done without antibiotic prophylaxis. He denied any chest pain  syncope  orthopedic symptoms  or changes in bowel or urinary habits.   Assessment and Plan: The symptoms  especially when taken into consideration with John's recent dental procedures  are suggestive of native-valve infective endocarditis. The shortness of breath may be due to heart failure secondary to infective endocarditis.  For further confirmation  blood cultures should be drawn and a Transthoracic Echocardiogram (TTE) can be ordered to identify vegetations on the valve  if any. If the TTE is negative but suspicion remains high  a Transesophageal Echocardiogram (TEE) can be performed. If diagnosis is confirmed  antibiotic therapy should be started as per standard guidelines.  Teaching Point:  This case illustrates the importance of considering infective endocarditis in patients who present with unexplained fever  fatigue  weight loss along with a history of recent invasive dental procedure. The case also emphasizes the importance of addressing poor dentition and the use of appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis before dental work in patients at risk. It also highlights the need for being observant and watchful  as early diagnosis and timely treatment significantly contribute towards better prognosis.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Demographics:  The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian male  John Doe  who is a retired police officer from New York. Living with his wife in a non-smoking household. He has a history of moderate alcohol consumption but quit drinking 10 years back.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus for the past 10 years  which is well-controlled with the use of metformin. He was diagnosed with Hypertension 8 years ago and is regularly taking losartan. Six years ago  he was treated for Rheumatic fever.  Key Complaints:  The patient presented with a two-week history of increasing shortness of breath  low-grade fever  and loss of appetite. He also complained of weight loss  night sweats  and generalized fatigue for the same duration. Mr. Doe also reports noticing blood in his urine for the past couple of days. Of late  he has also experienced joint pain  and upon close inspection  small  painful  red or purple sores (Osler's nodes) have developed on his fingertips and toes.  The above clinical presentation  along with his previous history of Rheumatic fever  raises a strong suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis. Further investigations are warranted to confirm the diagnosis. Once confirmed  an appropriate treatment plan will need to be developed  with consideration given to his existing comorbidities.

Case Subject: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Mr. Gustavo Salinas  a 65-year-old Hispanic male stockbroker comes in with his wife  Marisol  who mentions that he has been complaining of frequent headaches  episodes of mild fever  and unexplained fatigue for the past four weeks. Gustavo also reports night sweats  anorexia  and unintended weight loss over the same duration. Gustavo does not have a history of illicit drug use  risky sexual behavior  or recent dental procedures.   Patient Demographics:  - Age: 65 years - Sex: Male - Race: Hispanic - Occupation: Stockbroker  Past Medical History:  - Chronic smoker (1 pack/day for 30 years) but quit 10 years ago. - Stage II Hypertension-controlled with medication (Lisinopril). - No known allergies. - Family history of coronary artery disease (father died from a myocardial infarction at age 70). - No history of surgeries or transfusions. - No history of diabetes  hepatitis  or autoimmune diseases. - Routine vaccinations up-to-date (including pneumococcal and annual influenza vaccines).  Key Complaints:  - Frequent incapacitating headaches. - Intermittent low-grade fever. - Marked fatigue. - Night sweats. - Unintended weight loss. - Anorexia.   This case is designed to simulate a real-life situation of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis in a patient. The students are expected to work through this scenario to identify the presenting symptoms of infective endocarditis  consider the patient's history  and establish a diagnosis. Further  they should also be able to propose a relevant investigatory approach and design an effective treatment plan.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mrs. Helen Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian woman  lives with her husband in a suburban community.   Past Medical History: She has a past medical history of moderate rheumatoid arthritis  treated with methotrexate  prednisone  and occasional non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. She does not have any known allergies. She has no history of dental procedures since the onset of her rheumatoid arthritis. She has a 40-pack-year smoking history  but quit 15 years ago. Her mother died of complications from breast cancer and her father had cardiovascular disease.   Presenting Complaint: She visits her primary care doctor with a complaint of a low-grade fever (around 99.5 F)  malaise and fatigue for the last three weeks. She mentioned feeling mildly short of breath  having pain in the joints and seeing some ""red spots"" on her palms and soles. Mrs. Smith has lost 5 kgs in 4 weeks. She also mentioned of occasional dizziness  but no palpitations  chest pain or syncope.   On physical exam: She has a few petechiae on her palate  bilateral lower limb edema and Osler’s nodes on her fingers. Her vital signs were initially stable  but she was afebrile with the body temperature of 98.6 F  heart rate of 80 beats per minute  blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. On auscultation of her heart  a new murmur was heard over the mitral area. A detailed clinical evaluation is planned with an initial diagnosis of Native Valve Infective Endocarditis.   This case can spark discussions about the differential diagnosis  clinical manifestations  and investigation of infective endocarditis  particularly considering Mrs. Smith's age  sex  rheumatoid arthritis  and the prolonged use of immunosuppressive drugs. It also provides an opportunity to discuss about the management and prognosis of this serious condition.

Patient Case Report  Patient Demographics: • Age: 60 years old • Gender: Female • Occupation: Retired school teacher • Socioeconomic status: Middle-class • Residential area: Urban  living alone  Past Medical History: • Diagnosed with Rheumatic Heart Disease at 16 years old • Underwent heart valve replacement surgery at 40 • History of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed at 50 years old • Severe allergy to Penicillin noted  anaphylactic reaction encountered in the past. • Has a known addiction to illicit Intravenous Drug Use (IVDU)  specifically heroine  for the past 2 years. • History of multiple emergency room visits owing to drug intoxication episodes  needle-stick injuries  and peripheral abscesses due to unhygienic needle practice. • Partially compliant to her diabetes and rheumatic prophylaxis medications.  Key Complaints: The patient has been experiencing the following symptoms for the past three weeks: • Persistent  high-grade fever resistant to over-the-counter antipyretics. • Chills and severe night sweats causing sleep disturbance. • Progressive fatigue and generalized body weakness • Severe weight loss (more than 10% of her body weight) in the last month. • Recently  she has been feeling more breathless especially when lying flat  and can't walk as fast as she used to due to breath shortness. • Painless red spots on her palms and soles. • Her caregiver reports intermittent disorientation and confusional state particularly during fever spikes.   This case study will allow us to train medical students on the diagnostic approach  management  and implications of native valve infective endocarditis  particularly in patients with predisposing factors such as illicit drug use and pre-existing cardiac conditions. For this particular patient  care should also be taken while deciding the empirical antibiotic therapy due to her severe Penicillin allergy.

Case Report:  Demographics:  A 53-year-old Irish Caucasian female.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of intravenous drug abuse through her late 20s and 30s that led to chronic Hepatitis C infection  which is currently in remission. She has had previous contact with the healthcare system for the management of her Hepatitis C infection  and also for managing withdrawal symptoms from drug abuse. She has been clean for the last decade  is regularly attending Narcotics Anonymous meetings.  Presenting Complaints: She presents to the emergency department complaining of fatigue  loss of appetite  and unintentional weight loss over the past 2 months. She also started experiencing worsening dyspnoea on exertion  intermittent fevers  night sweats  and chills over the past two weeks. The patient also noted that she has a new heart murmur which was absent during her regular check-ups in the past. The patient denies recent dental work  surgery  or piercings.  Final Thoughts: Considering the patient's history of IV drug use  the new heart murmur  and the systemic symptoms she's been facing  it's important to consider infective endocarditis as a differential diagnosis. Performing a physical exam  blood cultures  and possibly an echocardiogram  may help in diagnosing her condition.  This case highlights the importance of considering a patient's social and drug history when dealing with cardiac issues  as well as how symptoms may present systemically before affecting the specific organ.

Patient Information:  Mr. Johnson is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who lives in a suburban area. He is retired and lives with his wife. He is a former smoker and admitted to moderate alcohol consumption. He reports no illegal drug use.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a history of type II diabetes  which is well-controlled with diet and metformin. Additionally  he has long-standing hyperlipidemia managed by simvastatin. He underwent dental extraction 2 weeks ago. Presence or absence of prophylactic antibiotic use before the procedure is unknown.  Presenting Complaints:  He presents with a three-day history of high-grade fever  fatigue  malaise  and weight loss of 5 lbs over the last month. Additionally  he complains about experiencing shortness of breath and a new onset of intermittent chest pain over the last week. He denies any recent travel  food poisoning  or diarrhea. He mentions being unusually tired and having sweats at night.   On physical exam  his temperature is 101°F. His heart rate is elevated  and blood pressure is normal. Upon cardiac examination  a new systolic murmur is noted along with signs of heart failure. Janeway lesions are seen on his palms and soles  and Osler's nodes are found on his fingertips  indicative of systemic embolization.    This case report encompasses the typical presentation of native-valve infective endocarditis in a patient. The documented presentations like new systolic murmur  systemic embolization in the form of Janeway lesions  and Osler's nodes coupled with risk factors such as age  diabetes  and recent dental procedure should lead medical students towards getting an echocardiogram and blood cultures  suspecting infective endocarditis. However  teaching emphasis should also be put on considering broad differentials  including but not limited to pericarditis  acute coronary syndromes  pneumonia  and sepsis in such presenting complaints.

Patient Demographics: Name: Ace Goodman Age: 59 years  Sex: Male  Race: African-American  Profession: Long-distance truck driver  Past Medical History: -A history of intravenous drug use around 10 years ago  followed by successful rehabilitation. -Chronic smoker - has smoked about a pack a day for the past 30 years. -Risk of developing cardiovascular diseases due to poor dietary habits and sedentary lifestyle. -Had a bout of Rheumatic Fever in his early 20s.  Key Complaints: -Complains of persistent fever (101-102 F) for 2 weeks. -Feels generally unwell  reports fatigue and weight loss. -Shortness of breath on exertion. -Unexplained night sweats. -Recent onset of heart murmur noted during a primary care visit. -Nil complains of chest pain  palpitations  syncope. -Also seen are few palpable  non-tender  purplish skin nodules on hands and leg  Janeway lesions  red linear streaks in the nail bed - splinter hemorrhages.  This patient’s persistent unexplained fever along with heart murmur  a history of intravenous drug use  poor lifestyle habits  and physical signs such as Janeway lesions and splinter hemorrhages all point towards a likely diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. Further investigations are required to confirm this.

Patient Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 56 years Sex: Male Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Office Clerk  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a documented history of mild hypertension and Type II diabetes mellitus. He has been adherent to his medications and regular follow-ups. He denies any prior surgeries or hospitalizations. He is not allergic to any known drugs. He has a 15-pack year smoking history and is an occasional alcohol consumer. There is no family history of infectious diseases or cardiovascular conditions.  Chief Complaints: Mr. Doe perceived fever and fatigue for about a week. He also complained of occasional chest discomfort in the last 4-5 days. Over the past two days  he noticed swelling and redness in his lower legs along with an unexplained weight loss. He also mentioned the occurrence of night sweats. He denies any recent dental work  illicit drug use  alteration in skin color  or any other systemic symptoms.  This case report with demographic details  past medical history  and chief complaints provides the primary data needed for medical students to ponder on the diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis. Relevant clinical symptoms  signs  and test results would be revealed progressively throughout the training session to guide participants into the comprehensive management of this infectious disease.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 65-year-old  Sex: Male Race: White   Chief Complaint:   The patient presented with a 2-week history of persistent fever  fatigue  and recent onset of shortness of breath.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes 10 years ago  which is managed with Metformin. He also has a history of hypertension and intermittent atrial fibrillation for which he is prescribed Lisinopril and Amiodarone respectively. He doesn't smoke or consume alcohol.  Key Complaints:  1. Persistent fever: The patient has been experiencing a high-grade fever for the past two weeks despite taking over-the-counter anti-pyretics. He also reported chills and night sweats.  2. Fatigue: He complains of progressively increasing fatigue and is unable to perform his daily activities.  3. Shortness of Breath: The patient experiences shortness of breath  particularly on exertion  which has been of sudden onset in the last 2 days.  4. Weight loss: He also reports unintentional weight loss of around 5 kg in one month.  5. Osler's nodes: On examination  painful nodules were found on the palms of both hands and soles of the feet.  Additional high-risk characteristics such as his age  male gender  presence of diabetes  and intermittent atrial fibrillation contribute to the suspicion of native-valve infective endocarditis in this case. Furthermore  the patient's signs and symptoms like persistent fever  fatigue  weight loss and Osler's nodes further elevate this suspicion.  Mr. Doe returned from a dental procedure a month ago  where he had required a root canal treatment  but did not receive any prophylactic antibiotics  increasing his risk of developing infective endocarditis. No recent travel or risky sexual behaviors were reported.   Family history reveals cardiovascular events in his father and older sibling. He lives with his wife  and his diet is standard American.    This case emphasizes the importance of thorough history taking  identification of high-risk patients  and the relevance of prophylactic measures in potentially fatal conditions such as infective endocarditis. It is vital for medical students to understand the cardiac complications of infective endocarditis  and the multidisciplinary approach required for managing these patients.

Patient Information:   Mr. J  a 62-year-old Caucasian male  non-smoker  with a known history of intravenous drug use (quit 15 years ago)  referred by his primary care physician to the hospital.  Past Medical History:   Mr. J has a medical history of chronic Hepatitis C and hypertension  for which he is taking Enalapril. He completed a treatment regimen for his Hepatitis C infection five years ago  but it has resulted in mild cirrhosis of the liver.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr J. has presented with a three-week history of persistent fevers  night sweats  and unintended weight loss of approximately 10 lbs. He also reports a new-onset nonspecific chest discomfort  fatigue  and shortness of breath  especially on exertion.  Over the past week  he's also noticed that his urine appears to have blood in it  although he denies any obvious fresh or altered blood in the urine. To complicate matters  the patient also complains of a dull  ongoing pain in his right knee joint that has been progressively worsening.  Physical Examination:  Mr. J appears lethargic but is oriented and cooperative. He's febrile with a temperature of 38.5 degrees Celsius. He has a heart murmur best heard at the left sternal edge  pain  and swelling in his right knee along with petechiae on his extremities. His blood pressure and oxygen saturation levels are within normal range.  This case is intended to guide medical students in diagnosing  managing  and understanding the pathophysiology  treatment  and potential complications of native-valve infective endocarditis  with a focus on its correlation with a history of intravenous drug use-related diseases and signs  symptoms  physical findings  and further diagnostic modalities needed to confirm the diagnosis.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 65 years old Gender: Male Occupation: Retired school teacher Ethnicity: Caucasian  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of mild Hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus  both managed with lifestyle modifications and oral medication. He has not had any surgical procedures or significant hospitalizations before. Family history is significant for Ischemic Heart Disease in his father.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Doe came to the emergency department (ED) with complaints of persistent high-grade fever for the past 2 weeks. The fever was associated with chills  night sweats  fatigue  and significant unintentional weight loss. He also reported a new onset of a heart murmur that was not previously identified. He complained of experiencing joint and muscle pains  intermittently over the past month.  He mentioned minor dental procedure 3 weeks ago. He has poor dental hygiene with some untreated dental caries and abscesses. No previous episodes of infective endocarditis and no intravenous drug use.  Upon further inquiry  he noted symptoms like light-headedness and breathlessness on exertion  which can imply congestive heart failure or anemia.  This case is best suited to educate medical students about native-valve infective endocarditis. The students should be made aware of the need for a detailed clinical history  regarding medical and dental procedures  intravenous drug use that could predispose to bacteremia and endocarditis. The essence of a thorough clinical examination should also be highlighted  especially to identify peripheral signs of infective endocarditis. This case has the potential touchstone to several areas including microbiology  immunology  cardiology  and general medicine  bringing a multidisciplinary approach to medical learning.

Case Title: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information: Ms. Martinez  a 65-year-old Hispanic female.   Past Medical History: She has a diagnosed history of rheumatic heart disease in her early twenties. History of oral contraceptive use is notable and she quit smoking 30 years ago after a 20 pack-year history. There are no known allergies  and she is on maintenance medication with beta-blockers and statins for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  respectively.  Presenting Complaints: She has come to the ER with chief complaints of a high-grade fever persisting for the past two weeks  associated with profuse night sweats  weight loss  and loss of appetite. She also mentions increased fatigue and occasional shortness of breath. A noticeable new heart murmur has been reported by her primary care physician during a visit last week  which was absent during her previous visits.  Preliminary Observations: On examination  she appears obviously ill and in mild distress. Vital signs include a temperature of 101.6 F  heart rate of 110/min  respiratory rate of 20/min  blood pressure of 140/90mmHg  and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Cardiac examination reveals a new holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and right upper sternal border.   The above history and clinical findings raise suspicions of endocarditis secondary to her underlying rheumatic heart disease. This warrants further diagnostic testing including multiple blood cultures before the initiation of any antibiotics  EKG  and echocardiography  among others.  The purpose of this case study is to teach the students how to approach  diagnose  and manage a case of suspected infective endocarditis. The case provides an opportunity to discuss the importance of recognizing the classical signs and symptoms of this infection  potential risk factors  as well as the impact of underlying heart diseases in developing endocarditis. The necessity of prompt and efficient diagnostic strategies should be emphasized given the risk of severe complications and mortality associated with untreated infective endocarditis. Finally  the case study could allow a broader discussion of preventive measures and treatment guidelines.

Case Report: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis  Patient Information: Mr. X is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired teacher  residing in urban downtown. He is a nonsmoker  moderate drinker and denies any illicit drug use. He has a known history of mild hypertension controlled with thiazide diuretics and hyperlipidemia managed with statins.  Past Medical History: Besides hypertension and hyperlipidemia  the patient was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 5 years ago managed with metformin. A dental procedure performed 2 months ago due to a tooth infection. He has no known drug allergies.  Presenting Complaints: The patient presents to the emergency department with a two-week history of low-grade fever  fatigue and an unexplained weight loss. He also reports sweating excessively  particularly nocturnal sweats. New onset shortness of breath has been noted over the past week.   Additionally  he complains of intermittent  dull  and aching chest pain that has been worsening over the past three days. He admits to noticing small  red spots on the skin and around the mouth.  On further questioning  he expressly denies any known history of heart disease or defects  recent intravenous drug use  or procedures involving his gastrointestinal or genitourinary tract.   The chronicity and description of these symptoms along with the patient's recent dental procedure suggest the need for thorough investigation for a potential case of native-valve infective endocarditis. Clinical examination  blood culture testing  and echocardiographic evaluation will be fundamental in confirming the diagnosis and formulating an appropriate treatment plan.

Patient Demographics:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 65 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer  Past Medical History: 1. Rheumatic fever - occurred in childhood 2. Type II diabetes mellitus - diagnosed 8 years ago  currently managed with oral hypoglycemic agents 3. Hypertension - diagnosed 7 years ago  managed with diet  exercise  and medication 4. Occasional alcohol consumption and past 20 years history of tobacco use with an estimated 30 pack-years.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Doe presents with a two-week history of low-grade  nocturnal fevers  night sweats  and progressive fatigue. He complains of a recent unexplained weight loss  loss of appetite  and general malaise. He also mentions experiencing an intermittent  throbbing headache for the past week and having difficulty with concentration and short term memory. He denies chest pain  cough  dyspnea  urinary complaints  and skin rashes.  Over the last few days  he has noticed a new onset of edema in his lower extremities and occasional shortness of breath when he climbs stairs or walks more than a block. He also noticed dark-colored urine. The patient was previously functional and active  now he feels too weak to perform his daily activities optimally.  On further investigation  he mentioned a dental procedure he underwent around 4 weeks back for a severe tooth abscess for which he was prescribed a course of antibiotics without any record of prophylactic antibiotics for endocarditis.  This case unfolds a patient with a history of an underlying condition and a recent dental procedure  who presents with signs of systemic infection and potential native valve endocarditis. The subsequent training should then focus on the diagnosis  management  and possible complications of infective endocarditis.

Patient Case Report  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 63-year-old Caucasian male carpenter named John Smith from Kansas city. He is a smoker with a 30-pack year history and has a history of moderate alcohol consumption. He lives with his wife and has adult sons.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a medical history of Diabetes Mellitus type II  well controlled with metformin and diet. He also has a history of Rheumatic fever that caused mild Valvular Heart Disease. He has been treated for Staphylococcal skin infections multiple times over the past five years.  Presenting Complaints: He presented with a two-week history of episodic fever  malaise  and night sweats. He has also reported new onset of shortness of breath on exertion for the past week. He has mentioned unintentional 10-pound weight loss over the past month. Furthermore  he has noticed small painful red bumps on his fingers and palms. On further questioning  he also reveals he has been suffering from lower back pain for 3 weeks which he initially attributed to physical strain at work. He denies experiencing any chest pain  palpitations  syncope  or cough.  Physical examination to be conducted should include inspecting for signs of infective endocarditis  including Osler’s nodes (small painful red bumps on fingers or toes)  Janeway lesions (small painless red or purple spots on the palms of the hands or soles of the feet)  Roth spots in the retina  splinter hemorrhages under the nails  along with other signs of valvular disease  weight loss  or Staphylococcal skin infection. Further investigations including blood cultures for bacteremia and an echocardiogram could be ordered to confirm a diagnosis of native-valve infective endocarditis.   Management plan should include identifying the causative organism  choosing appropriate antibiotic therapy  duration of treatment  managing complications and deciding on a possible need for surgery while also managing his diabetes  and encouraging him to make lifestyle changes like cessation of smoking  reducing alcohol consumption  maintaining good personal hygiene  and regular follow-ups.

Case Name: Native-Valve Infective Endocarditis (NVE)  Case Report   Patient Demographics:  Mr. Jenkins  a 58-year-old Caucasian male  is the patient in this case. He resides in Kansas City  Missouri  and is an office clerk by occupation. The patient is a non-smoker but reveals a history of moderate alcohol consumption.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed with Metformin for the past eight years. He also has mild hypertension under control with Lisinopril. There is no known history of heart disease in the family or any previous cardiac issues.   Key Complaints:  Mr. Jenkins presented to the emergency department with a 2-week history of unremitting high-grade fever with chills  sweating  an unexplained weight loss of approximately 10 pounds  and general malaise.   The presenting symptoms correspond with an overall feeling of illness and might point toward an infectious disease. Given the patient's past medical history  it is crucial to rule out infectious endocarditis  which albeit rare  is a severe condition especially in those with certain risk factors  including diabetes.   This case aims to emphasize the presentation of native-valve infective endocarditis and its consideration in differential diagnosis with extensive fever. It also highlights the importance of careful examination  patient's history  and the use of appropriate diagnostic procedures.

Patient Case Report  Patient Demographics: Name: Anonymous Age: 61 years old Gender: Male  Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired  former intravenous drug user Residence: Urban Suburbs  Presenting Complaints: The patient presents with a week-long history of persistent fever  malaise  and significant weight loss over the past month. He also describes an intermittent  non-productive cough  night sweats  and general loss of appetite. Additionally  he has been experiencing shortness of breath and fatigue on mild exertion.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of intravenous drug use (heroin) from the past (last reported usage 20 years ago). He has been clean since then with long-term opioid maintenance therapy. He was diagnosed with Hepatitis C (HCV) 15 years ago  currently in remission. He also has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both which are well-controlled on medication.   He has no known allergies  doesn't smoke  and consumes alcohol occasionally.   Clinical Examination: On physical examination  the patient appeared ill and in mild distress. Vital signs are temperature 38.6°C  pulse 106/min  respiration 22/min  blood pressure 110/70 mm of Hg. Cardiac auscultation reveals a diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border. Additionally  physical examination revealed petechiae on his limbs and conjunctivae  and nail-bed hemorrhages (splinter hemorrhages). Chest sounds were normal in breath sounds.  This case can engage participants to consider the possibility of native valve infective endocarditis in the differential diagnosis  and to appreciate high-risk individuals and early symptoms of this potentially fatal condition. This encourages the development of a thoughtful  comprehensive approach to diagnosis and management  bearing in mind the need for a multidisciplinary approach in medicine.
